webTitle: British film crosses new sex frontier

fields.headline: British film crosses new sex frontier
fields.standfirst: Viewers' groups attack 18 rating for screen version of Hanif Kureishi's  Intimacy that depicts uncensored oral sex, reports  John Arlidge
fields.trailText: Viewers' groups attack 18 rating for screen version of Hanif Kureishi's Intimacy that depicts uncensored oral sex, reports John Arlidge.
fields.body:
The most sexually explicit British film, featuring the first uncensored scenes of oral sex, will go on show in cinemas next month.

Intimacy, described by the British Board of Film Classification as 'strongly explicit', is certain to spark controversy. The regulator gave it an 18 certificate last month.

The film, shot in London with a mainly British cast, is an adaptation of two novellas by Hanif Kureishi - Intimacy and Night Light. It tells the story of Clare, played by Kerry Fox who starred with Ewan McGregor in Shallow Grave, and her affair with Jay, played by Mark Rylance, artistic director of the Globe Theatre.

Clare, who is married to Andy, played by Timothy Spall, visits Jay for sex every week. From the beginning of the film the couple are pictured having sex. In one scene Clare performs oral sex on Jay.

The BBFC, which passed the film without cuts, is bracing itself for a public outcry. The regulator relaxed its guidelines on sex last year after a survey of cinema audiences revealed that the majority opposed censorship.

Sue Clark, spokeswoman for the board, said: 'Audiences may be used to seeing explicit sex scenes in foreign language films, such as The Idiots, which is Danish, and the Japanese film Ai no corrida, but this is the first time many will see such scenes in an English language movie.

'There is one very explicit scene, which features fellatio, which has not been seen before now.

'Some people may think it is too strong, particularly when it is with actors they recognise, but we passed the film without cuts because there is no violence. The two people are equally involved in the relationship, there is no coercion, and it does not contravene our guidelines. Serious filmgoers will think it is a good film.'

Fox and Rylance will not discuss the film before its release. Rylance is appearing in the National Theatre's production of Yasmina Reza's Life x 3 at the Old Vic, and Fox has just had her first child.

McDonald and Rutter, the film's London publicists, described the film as 'raw'. Jonathan Rutter said: 'The aim of the couple is not to have intimacy, just sex. They don't really communicate; they just have sex. It is the first film to deal with sex in such a raw manner.'

Intimacy won the Golden Bear award for best film and Kerry Fox won the best actress award at the Berlin Film Festival in March. It is directed by Patrice Chereau, who made La Reine Margot, starring Isabelle Adjani.

Kureishi, who wrote the Eighties hit film My Beautiful Laundrette, described Intimacy as 'shocking'. 'The point is to look at how difficult sex is, how terrifying, and what an obscenity our pleasures can be.'

The film's release follows the BBFC's decision to approve the French film, Romance, which features graphic sex scenes. Another French movie, Baise-moi ( Screw me ), which features a violent rape, has also been cleared for release.

The board's new liberal approach towards sex on screen has been bitterly criticised by conservative viewers' groups. Media Watch UK - the new name for the National Viewers' and Listeners' Association - campaigned against the release of Baise-moi and a spokesman described Intimacy as 'a film which sounds anything but intimate'.

John Milton Whatmore, chairman of Media Watch, said: 'I have not seen Intimacy but, if it is as explicit as reports suggest, giving it an 18 certificate is not enough. There are 18-year-olds who are comfortable with sex and sexuality and there are those who are not.

'Young impressionable people are influenced by what they see on screen and, if you unload too much explicit information on them too soon, you can confuse or scare them. I do not blame the film-makers for making a film that they think has artistic merit. It is up to the regulators to protect the public and by approving this film they are failing in their duty.'

Anna Butler, marketing director of Pathé, the film's UK distributor, dismissed the criticism. 'It's a serious intelligent film. It has sex scenes but they are not exploitative. They are in the context of a relationship. They are not offensive and they are performed by a great cast, directed by a reputable director.'

webTitle: 'All we need to tell the poor is: Come on, fellas, shape up'

fields.headline: 'All we need to tell the poor is: Come on, fellas, shape up'
fields.standfirst:
Myron Magnet's Victorian cures for social ills are now a cornerstone of President Bush's thinking, writes Edward Helmore in New York
Blair's big error, by Bush's guru
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Myron Magnet is not a politician and he speaks with the robust confidence of a theorist who knows he will never have to implement the social theories he espouses. From his offices at the influential neo-conservative think-tank, the Manhattan Institute, it is hard not to be beguiled by his argument that the persistent underclass that exists in America and Britain is a product not of failed economic policies and incentives, but of cultural attitudes.
fields.body:
Myron Magnet is not a politician and he speaks with the robust confidence of a theorist who knows he will never have to implement the social theories he espouses. From his offices at the influential neo-conservative think-tank, the Manhattan Institute, it is hard not to be beguiled by his argument that the persistent underclass that exists in America and Britain is a product not of failed economic policies and incentives, but of cultural attitudes.

The argument at the heart of his book, The Dream and the Nightmare, that now sits squarely at the centre of President George Bush's formative social policy and has furnished him with 'the vision thing' his father lacked, is that the values that gained credence in the Sixties wrought terrible consequences.

'The great question is how come we even have an underclass?' Magnet asks. 'And how did it come into being at the moment the US economy started booming just as we had passed the 1964 Civil Rights act?' It's a question to which Magnet, with his bushy sideburns and amiable manner of character from Charles Dickens, thinks he knows the answer.

Unlike many conservative gurus, Magnet does not locate the root of the problem in the personal failings of the poor, but in the attitudes of the middle-classes that took root during that period. The culture that has victimised the have-nots, he argues, is the culture of the haves - specifically radical individualism and personal liberation.

'We devalued all of the things you have to do to get out of poverty, like hard work, personal responsibility, getting married and taking care of family, staying in school, and we highly valued all the things that if you're poor and you do them you'll stay poor forever, like taking drugs, having children out of wedlock, dropping out and not being serious about work.'

Efforts to break the cycle of poverty, such as welfare programmes, job training, and quota systems for minorities, failed because government failed to understand that the underclass is less an economic matter than a cultural one. 'The ideas themselves created the reality, not economic changes or the failure of government programmes,' he says. 'The effect of those ideas have proved harmful to the middle-classes, but disastrous to those beneath.'

Magnet rejects the notion that the symptoms of social malaise - crime, drugs, homelessness, illegitimacy - are the product of racial and social injustice. 'The problem of the endemic poor isn't simply lack of money. What we need is a social policy that believes the condition of the worst-off is a concern of government, and that's what's new about compassionate conservatism, but it's a rejection of the ways liberals have tried.'

Government can't save anyone, Magnet says, 'but it can nurture a physical and social environment in which people discover they can save themselves'. If Magnet's analysis sounds like simplistic conservative politics, it is not. It draws far more heavily on Freud than Marxist theorists who hold human behaviour is little more than a condition of larger economic and social forces. Magnet and with other theorists behind 'compassionate conservatism' feel they have the wind behind them. They cite President Bill Clinton's cutback of welfare programmes in 1996 as an unequivocal success in transforming the lot of the poor. The foremost proof of the policy lies in the turnaround of New York. 'Nobody predicted that the so-called hard cases are finding employment at the same rate as everybody else,' he says.

In getting the liberal elites to engage in a discussion on the causes of social problems or to raise the idea that the poor can help themselves, Magnet has frequently been branded a bigot. Mayor Rudi Giuliani, who says he has been influenced by Magnet, calls the political correctness that rules New York intellectual life 'like the Spanish Inquisition'.

Bush read The Dream and the Nightmare in 1998 while preparing to run for his second term as governor of Texas and invited Magnet for a brainstorming session. Magnet's ideas made their way into almost every Bush campaign speech.

Magnet draws much of his inspiration from Victorian England where a generation of reformers effected a transformation that turned a gin-swilling nation with a high bastardy rate into a country with strong families and prosperity. 'I know this sounds like hopeless Victorian schoolmistress talk,' he says, 'but the lesson can be applied to America and Britain in 2001. You just need to say, "come on fellas, shape up". Everybody has to be held responsible for their actions.

'In rich open societies like England and the US, anybody can be part of the mainstream. There is huge social mobility despite what people think. But if you say to people "you're a victim, the system is unjust, we're going to make all kinds of allowances for you, and we're not going to hold you responsible," that's a very disabling message.'

fields.headline: Free trade summit provokes clashes
fields.standfirst:
Battles in Quebec as American leaders discuss creation of trade bloc

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Battles in Quebec as American leaders discuss creation of trade bloc.
fields.body:
Police clashed with tens of thousands of anti-globalisation protesters on the streets of Quebec yesterday as free trade talks between leaders of 34 American countries got under way in spite of the violence and escalating tension.

Between 25,000 and 30,000 protesters were expected to march against a proposed free trade zone that could become the largest in the world. Tear gas and water cannon were fired amid scuffles with a small group of protesters that had separated from the main march before lunchtime.

The protesters include Labour rights activists, environmentalists, human rights advocates and anti-capitalist and anarchist groups. They believe the free trade zone will help big business to the detriment of the poor.

The action yesterday followed violence at the start of the Summit of the Americas on Friday night when tear gas was used during running battles and more than 100 people were arrested and eight policemen injured.

The battles between protesters and the police echo those staged in Seattle two years ago, when anti-globalisation and anti-capitalism protesters demonstrated against the World Trade Organisation.

Yesterday Jose Bove, the French sheep farmer who has been lionised by anti-globalisation campaigners for his fight against McDonalds and other multinationals, addressed the start of the union-organised march. Almost 2,000 people crowded into a tent in the Old Port area of the city to hear the man arrested for dismantling a fast food restaurant.

'We must keep our protest non-violent,' he said to huge applause from a crowd which included several children.

Masked teenagers waiting outside the tent were less patient for the demonstration proper to start.

When asked if there was likely to be more clashes with the police yesterday, one 19-year-old from Montreal wearing swimming goggles and a red nose said: 'I don't know but I wish.'

More than 7,000 police officers and members of the armed forces are on duty. Those arrested on Friday night included the leader of the Anti-Capitalist Convergence Group, Jaggi Singh, and members of Black Bloc, an anarchist group.

Eight policemen were hurt, one seriously, and an unknown number of protesters were injured.

Clouds of tear gas covered three flashpoints along the perimeter fence as police officers attempted to prevent protesters entering the secure area where the 34 heads of state were meeting in private.

The 150ft section of the security fence that had been torn down on Friday was still gaping open yesterday morning, protected by riot police.

George Bush supported the proposed free trade zone in his opening remarks to the summit yesterday. 'Trade not only helps spread prosperity, but trade helps spread freedom,' the US President said.

Jean-Paul Chrétien, Canada's Prime Minister, condemned 'a small group of extremists' in his first speech to the meeting. 'Violence and provocation is unacceptable in a democracy... These people do not represent the majority of those who have come to Quebec City peacefully to express legitimate concerns.'

Both men also underlined the need for all participating countries to uphold democratic values.

fields.headline: Heavenly host much in demand
fields.standfirst:
As venture capitalists vanish, business angels have become a vital cog of entrepreneurial culture, says Faisal Islam. But dying dotcoms need not apply

More internet news
fields.trailText: As venture capitalists vanish, business angels have become a vital cog of entrepreneurial culture, says Faisal Islam. But dying dotcoms need not apply
fields.body:
They may not match the selfless altruism of traditional angels, nor the glamour of Charlie's Angels , but anyone professing to be a business angel is proving mighty popular at the moment. 'I get about 400 emails a day from dying dotcoms,' says one high-profile angel, who preferred to remain anonymous to restrain the growth of his inbox.

For thousands of early-stage businesses caught up in the funding euphoria that accompanied the tech-stock boom, cash piles are now running dangerously low. These 'Zomb-e' or 'living dead' companies know they will soon be running on empty, but equally that the prospects for funding in current market conditions are bleak.

Business angels, normally the first resort for early-stage finance, have become the last resort now that the funding plug has been pulled by venture capitalists. A report last week showed the total value of private equity deals in Europe fell by 70 per cent over the first three months of this year. Venture capitalists are, for now, quite content to sit on the huge cash piles already raised for investment.

But do current conditions scare off even the angels? Yes and no is the unhelpful answer. Clearly there are fewer individuals around willing to risk their hard-earned entrepreneurial wealth on the exuberant whims of a 22-year-old web programmer. Then again, those people who got sucked in by tech-stock euphoria were probably not real angels anyway.

Serious, season-ticket-holding business angels are not so fickle as to be controlled by market fashions. They are in for the long haul. Julie Meyer, co-founder of First Tuesday, the high-profile networking organisation, says: 'They are very market-neutral - they don't go on about where the Nasdaq is.'

Ryan Prince agrees. He runs i-gabriel, a syndicate of high-profile angels, including Charlie Muirhead, Esther Dyson and Paul Myners (chairman of Guardian Media Group), who invest in 'enabling technologies'. 'From a number of perspectives angel investment is where you want to be right now. The IPO (initial public offering) window has closed, but angels typically invest two to four years before an IPO, and in this market valuations are more in line with fundamentals. It's a great opportunity,' he says.

So, it appears that genuine business angels have a protective halo that insulates them from the waxing and waning of stock markets. Academic studies of the informal private-equity market in the UK show that angels invest over a longer-run.

'Most angels are serial investors. Macroeconomic fundamentals - the stock market, inflation, the interest rate - do not register as a significant influence on angels' invest ment behaviour. The only factor that did affect things was the tax regime,' says Professor Colin Mason of Southampton University, who has carried out numerous surveys of angel investment.

The issue in the current market is more that there was a glut of over-investment in companies with flaky business prospects. This means angels have had to be more circumspect about the quality of early-stage companies that had already secured funding in the past. This may have changed now.

'A lot of the frothier business plans, the me-too con cepts, have sunk. The quality of businesses and of intellectual property being built is now far better and more bankable,' says Prince.

Mason estimates there are 20,000-40,000 business angels investing £1 billion in up to 6,000 companies a year in the UK. This funding plays a vital role in giving the initial impetus to early-stage start-ups, which tend to be overlooked by venture capitalists. Precise figures are impossible to obtain because many angel investors do not want to volunteer their status. But it is clear they are a vital cog in the workings of an entrepre neurial culture. 'The average entrepreneur doesn't need £5 million to get an idea off the ground - it's, say, £100,000,' says Meyer, who now runs Ariadne Capital. And if they don't happen to have a rich uncle, many good ideas can go unfunded.

Unsurprisingly, angel investment culture is very different and more developed in the US. Some $40 billion is estimated to be invested by angels over there.

'Europe is dominated by families who made it in the old economy,' says Meyer, who has toured the Continent looking to connect businesses. 'They will invest if they know one or two things about it, otherwise they won't touch it. Then they give the nod to a whole network of friends across Europe and they'll all come in.

'In the US there are these under-35 year olds, as new money as it comes, who are driven by recycling entrepreneurial wealth and know-how, as well as making more money,' she says.

Indeed despite the cash crunch, this passing on of know-how and contacts often proves more important than the funding itself. In the US there are formalised mentoring groups from which angel investment may sprout organically. The Indus Entrepreneurs (TiE) is one such group, originally focused on Silicon Valley's South Asian technology immigrants, but open to all.

Charter members offer mentoring sessions for young entrepreneurs with ideas and business plans. For older members who have already made their millions, it is a chance to replay the entrepreneurship game by proxy. Young entrepreneurs get advice, access to valuable contacts, potential clients, suppliers or partners, and possibly a slice of investment.

'We're not doing it fundamentally as a favour,' says Kanwal Rekhi, TiE's president. 'If you invest, it can be a lucrative activity.'

But there is an all-pervading spirit of community entrepreneurship. And TiE has just opened in London. The organisation stresses that mentoring, not angel investment, is its primary purpose. But the scheme, which begins next month, will offer aspiring entrepreneurs a helping hand.

Angels ganging together are not a new concept. The caricature of British angel investors is a network of Hertfordshire gentlemen farmers who will all pile in on the nod of one of their members. Syndicates such as i-gabriel promise to bring a more formal edge to the UK.

The real benefit from angel investment is that such investors are in a position to take greater risks because it's their own money, and they have a genuine understanding of the sector. Out goes ghastly due diligence and in comes gut feeling, and a few rules of thumb.

Those risks don't always pay off, though. According to Mason's survey data, angels in the UK lose their money in around 40 per cent of investments and make high returns - of 50 per cent or above - on under a quarter.

'It's vital for entrepreneurial culture,' says Meyer. 'Take Stockholm and Copenhagen. There's a massive difference in entrepreneurial culture in these two cities, and it's all because generations of Stockholm people made their money in technology and digital media and then reinvested it in this community.'

So what are the tricks of the trade for tempting an angel to invest?

'You wouldn't speak to an angel unless you knew it was a good idea because your credibility is at stake,' says Charlie Hoult, an entrepreneur who relied on angels for his Metrocube incubator. 'The first question they ask is "Is it Eis-able?",' he says, referring to the special tax advantages on offer to serial investors under the Enterprise Investment Scheme. Should an investment go bust then it can be reclaimed against a tax liability.

Entrepreneurs who make the effort to go to TiE's London meetings will also discover that they can get into legal difficulties by soliciting investment on spec from more than 50 angels. But if it's the cash you're after, there's plenty out there.

'The problem is not the supply of funds, there's simply not enough investable opportunities,' laments one angel. 'The entrepreneurs who come looking are not investment-ready; they don't know how to make a business plan or to make a pitch.' And angels are unlikely to bail out the living dead.

Julie Meyer, co-founder of First Tuesday, the high-profile networking organisation, says: 'They are very market-neutral - they don't go on about where the Nasdaq is.' Ryan Prince agrees. He runs i-gabriel, a syndicate of high-profile angels, including Charlie Muirhead, Esther Dyson and Paul Myners (chairman of Guardian Media Group), who invest in 'enabling technologies'. 'From a number of perspectives angel investment is where you want to be right now. The IPO (initial public offering) window has closed, but angels typically invest two to four years before an IPO, and in this market valuations are more in line with fundamentals. It's a great opportunity,' he says. So, it appears that genuine business angels have a protective halo that insulates them from the waxing and waning of stock markets. Academic studies of the informal private-equity market in the UK show that angels invest over a longer-run. 'Most angels are serial investors. Macroeconomic fundamentals - the stock market, inflation, the interest rate - do not register as a significant influence on angels' invest ment behaviour. The only factor that did affect things was the tax regime,' says Professor Colin Mason of Southampton University, who has carried out numerous surveys of angel investment. The issue in the current market is more that there was a glut of over-investment in companies with flaky business prospects. This means angels have had to be more circumspect about the quality of early-stage companies that had already secured funding in the past. This may have changed now. 'A lot of the frothier business plans, the me-too con cepts, have sunk. The quality of businesses and of intellectual property being built is now far better and more bankable,' says Prince. Mason estimates there are 20,000-40,000 business angels investing £1 billion in up to 6,000 companies a year in the UK. This funding plays a vital role in giving the initial impetus to early-stage start-ups, which tend to be overlooked by venture capitalists. Precise figures are impossible to obtain because many angel investors do not want to volunteer their status. But it is clear they are a vital cog in the workings of an entrepre neurial culture. 'The average entrepreneur doesn't need £5 million to get an idea off the ground - it's, say, £100,000,' says Meyer, who now runs Ariadne Capital. And if they don't happen to have a rich uncle, many good ideas can go unfunded. Unsurprisingly, angel investment culture is very different and more developed in the US. Some $40 billion is estimated to be invested by angels over there. 'Europe is dominated by families who made it in the old economy,' says Meyer, who has toured the Continent looking to connect businesses. 'They will invest if they know one or two things about it, otherwise they won't touch it. Then they give the nod to a whole network of friends across Europe and they'll all come in. 'In the US there are these under-35 year olds, as new money as it comes, who are driven by recycling entrepreneurial wealth and know-how, as well as making more money,' she says. Indeed despite the cash crunch, this passing on of know-how and contacts often proves more important than the funding itself. In the US there are formalised mentoring groups from which angel investment may sprout organically. The Indus Entrepreneurs (TiE) is one such group, originally focused on Silicon Valley's South Asian technology immigrants, but open to all. Charter members offer mentoring sessions for young entrepreneurs with ideas and business plans. For older members who have already made their millions, it is a chance to replay the entrepreneurship game by proxy. Young entrepreneurs get advice, access to valuable contacts, potential clients, suppliers or partners, and possibly a slice of investment. 'We're not doing it fundamentally as a favour,' says Kanwal Rekhi, TiE's president. 'If you invest, it can be a lucrative activity.' But there is an all-pervading spirit of community entrepreneurship. And TiE has just opened in London. The organisation stresses that mentoring, not angel investment, is its primary purpose. But the scheme, which begins next month, will offer aspiring entrepreneurs a helping hand. Angels ganging together are not a new concept. The caricature of British angel investors is a network of Hertfordshire gentlemen farmers who will all pile in on the nod of one of their members. Syndicates such as i-gabriel promise to bring a more formal edge to the UK. The real benefit from angel investment is that such investors are in a position to take greater risks because it's their own money, and they have a genuine understanding of the sector. Out goes ghastly due diligence and in comes gut feeling, and a few rules of thumb. Those risks don't always pay off, though. According to Mason's survey data, angels in the UK lose their money in around 40 per cent of investments and make high returns - of 50 per cent or above - on under a quarter. 'It's vital for entrepreneurial culture,' says Meyer. 'Take Stockholm and Copenhagen. There's a massive difference in entrepreneurial culture in these two cities, and it's all because generations of Stockholm people made their money in technology and digital media and then reinvested it in this community.' So what are the tricks of the trade for tempting an angel to invest? 'You wouldn't speak to an angel unless you knew it was a good idea because your credibility is at stake,' says Charlie Hoult, an entrepreneur who relied on angels for his Metrocube incubator. 'The first question they ask is "Is it Eis-able?",' he says, referring to the special tax advantages on offer to serial investors under the Enterprise Investment Scheme. Should an investment go bust then it can be reclaimed against a tax liability. Entrepreneurs who make the effort to go to TiE's London meetings will also discover that they can get into legal difficulties by soliciting investment on spec from more than 50 angels. But if it's the cash you're after, there's plenty out there. 'The problem is not the supply of funds, there's simply not enough investable opportunities,' laments one angel. 'The entrepreneurs who come looking are not investment-ready; they don't know how to make a business plan or to make a pitch.' And angels are unlikely to bail out the living dead. faisal.islam@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Bidders invited for Tube work despite PPP feud

fields.headline: Bidders invited for Tube work despite PPP feud
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: London Underground was accused this weekend of 'jumping the gun' on the hotly disputed public-private partnership scheme for financing the Tube by putting out contracts to tender before a final decision is made.
fields.body:
London Underground was accused this weekend of 'jumping the gun' on the hotly disputed public-private partnership scheme for financing the Tube by putting out contracts to tender before a final decision is made.

The department in charge of the Bakerloo, Central and Victoria lines last week invited bidders for a £10 million contract to integrate new information technology systems over the next five years. An industry source said this was done 'on the assumption that PPP will go ahead and the new private sector owner will take over the contract'.

But the source said this was premature because London Mayor Ken Livingstone and his transport chief Bob Kiley have taken the Government to a judicial review over its plans to break the Tube network into three parts and lease it to different private sector groups. A hearing is likely just before an expected June general election.

If Livingstone and Kiley succeed in blocking the PPP in favour of a single, publicly controlled management structure placed over private sector partners the new company is unlikely to want to take over the contract now out to tender.

The source said other contracts were likely to be offered. Even if the Government scheme is forced through, there is no guarantee that the successful bidder for the Bakerloo, Central and Victoria lines would favour a contractor chosen by the current Tube management.

fields.headline: British pilots overcome by fumes
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A British passenger jet flying into Birmingham with five crew and 42 passengers on board narrowly avoided disaster after fumes leaked into the cabin and overcame the pilots.
fields.body:
A British passenger jet flying into Birmingham with five crew and 42 passengers on board narrowly avoided disaster after fumes leaked into the cabin and overcame the pilots.

Official documents, seen by The Observer, show that the pilot and co-pilot almost passed out after fumes, thought to have come from the engines, filled the cabin. The incident, last November, is the latest example of what critics say is a serious safety risk in the British-built BAe 146.

The British-European aircraft was flying into Birmingham from Paris on 5 November last year. Shortly after take-off passengers reported an oily smell in the rear of the cabin. Just before the aircraft began its descent into Birmingham International Airport, the captain, followed by the co-pilot, left the flight deck to go to the toilet. After returning to the cockpit, they both reported feeling ill.

The captain said he felt nauseous, had difficulty concentrating on the flight path and told the crew that his vision had become blurred. The co-pilot's pupils dilated sharply and he needed two stewards to help him put on his oxygen mask. His hands were trembling and he could not speak normally.

The captain managed to land the plane safely. He and the co-pilot were taken to hospital on arrival. The incident is being investigated by the Air Accidents Investigation Branch at Farnborough.

Some senior aviation experts suggest the cause of the incident was a broken or damaged engine oil seal, which allowed engine fumes to leak into the cabin through the air-conditioning system.

The danger of fumes leaking into the cabin of the BAe 146 was officially acknowledged last year after it was exposed by The Observer. Leaked documents revealed that there have been dozens of suspected leaks, putting at risk thousands of holiday-makers.

On one flight to Sweden toxic fumes made the captain 'dizzy and groggy'. He was forced to use an oxygen mask to continue flying the plane but the symptoms persisted and he prepared to declare an emergency. Many passengers complained that they felt 'like zombies' and could not stay awake. The first officer eventually managed to land the plane safely. Some passengers could not be woken even after landing.

The incident was described by Swedish air safety authorities as 'extremely serious'. They reportedly found that faulty seals allowed engine oil, containing organophosphates, to pollute the cabin.

Following The Observer's revelations last year, the CAA issued an Airworthiness Directive (AD) ordering airlines to investigate the problem. Many major airlines use the plane and the royal family has three.

Some aviation experts believe the jet may have a fundamental design flaw. Chris Winder, head of safety sciences at Australia's University of New South Wales, who has studied the 146, said: 'We call it the Flying Gas Chamber. I can't understand why the authorities let it keep flying. It's an accident looking for a place to happen.'

BAE Systems, the manufacturer, stresses the aircraft is internationally certified as safe by all the major aviation authorities, including the FAA in the United States and the CAA in Britain.

Mike Peters, a spokesman for the company, said he was aware that an incident on 5 November last year but could not discuss it before the investigation had been completed. 'To speculate now on what the cause might have been is totally wrong. The quality of cabin air is an issue across the whole airline industry and BAE Systems has co-operated fully with all investigations into the issue.'

webTitle: Family bid for justice over Anna

fields.headline: Family bid for justice over Anna
fields.standfirst:
Turkish boyfriend may escape murder charge after being granted asylum in Britain

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Turkish boyfriend may escape murder charge after being granted asylum in Britain.
fields.body:
He was a charmer. Quick-witted and handsome, Asur Saribal was popular with British holidaymakers who flocked to Turkey each year. Anna Galliano, 20, a church-goer and special constable from Manchester, was besotted when she met the barman during a trip to the resort of Bodrum six years ago.

The pair went to clubs and parties during the holiday and were soon engaged. But the romance did not last long.

Deciding she had made a mistake and that it was simply a holiday fling, Miss Galliano returned to Istanbul a few months later to break the news that she was calling off the engagement. The pair went for a walk through the city on 18 December, 1995. Within hours Miss Galliano was dead. Now, more than five years later, the Turkish authorities are about to decide whether to prosecute Mr Saribal in absentia for murder, after he was granted asylum in Britain - the country where the Galliano family live and pray each day for justice - because he feared persecution for his political beliefs.

The Galliano family are furious that he may escape prosecution for murder because the British authorities have allowed him to settle here. They are desperate for answers about what happened to their daughter that night.

'The uncertainty and anger have made it harder to move on,' said her mother, Carol, last week. 'We haven't had any answers as to how she came to die. She was bubbly, full of life and quite religious. She was subtle in her approach to people - not the sort of person to provoke a fight.'

Michael Galliano, her father, was at home when a British Embassy official rang to tell him his daughter had been taken seriously ill. A few hours later he rang back to say that she had died of unexplained internal injuries. 'I got on the next flight I could find,' he said.

The next morning in Istanbul he met Mr Saribal and did what he could to tie up the loose ends of his daughter's death. Mr Saribal flew back to the UK with Anna's body to attend her funeral in Eccles, Manchester. He got a temporary visa on compassionate grounds and stayed with the Gallianos, and then with his own friends. Before their daughter was buried, the Gallianos arranged for a post-mortem. It concluded that she died from a violent trauma to her abdomen. There was an 8cm tear in her liver. Soon after this finding, Turkish police issued a warrant for Mr Saribal's arrest.

After the funeral Mr Saribal moved to Essex and his visa expired. He became a hunted man. Police tracked him to a kebab shop in Harlow, Essex. On 21 March 1996, Saribal requested asylum and was refused. He appealed.

In papers delivered to his asylum tribunal, Mr Saribal made a convincing case for refuge in the UK. He claimed he would be persecuted in Turkey because of his involvement in the terrorist group Dev Sol. He said he was a Kurd and that his father had been jailed for activism. He had also avoided conscription and would be punished if he returned. At first his asylum request was refused, but he persisted and in October last year it was granted. He now lives in the south of England with a wife and family.

An investigation by the BBC's Correspondent programme has discovered that Mr Saribal's village near the city of Erzincan is not inhabited by Kurds but by Alawites, an Islamic sect not persecuted by the government. The BBC also found no evidence of his involvement in Dev Sol and found his father, who Mr Saribal claimed had died in jail, alive and well in Istanbul.

The programme also states that Mr Saribal returned to Turkey after he had claimed asylum in the UK. Turkish authorities said he passed back through Turkish immigration on 20 October 1996 on his way back to the UK - not the actions of someone fearing persecution in his homeland.

Mike Galliano, Anna's brother, said last week that he would accompany Mr Saribal back to Turkey and remain by his side to ensure he got a fair trial. 'If he's not guilty, then he should be happy to face the courts,' he said.

In a statement to The Observer , Mr Saribal stood by the reasons for his asylum claim. He denied he had returned to Turkey and said he was innocent of murder. 'Naturally I am extremely upset by the death of my former girlfriend, Anna Galliano,' he said. 'I am also very afraid that the current allegations against me may endanger my British wife and two young children in the UK.'

MPs last week called for the Home Office to review the granting of asylum to Mr Saribal. 'I know there are cases where an asylum decision has been reviewed as a result of representations that are made later on,' said Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat spokesman on home affairs. 'These are highly exceptional circumstances, and I would not want to see the asylum process devalued by a decision that fails to take into account natural justice.'

The Galliano family refuse to give up until they see justice. 'It's been five years since she died,' said Mike. 'I just want to see an end to it.'

nick.walsh@observer.co.uk

 'Correspondent' is on BBC2 tonight at 7.20pm.

webTitle: Bigger and better? Try slower and dearer

fields.headline: Bigger and better? Try slower and dearer
fields.standfirst:
Railtrack's broken promises of a shiny new railway show the limitations of the private sector, says Joanna Walters

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack's broken promises of a shiny new railway show the limitations of the private sector, says Joanna Walters
fields.body:
Gone are the days when Railtrack promised passengers a spending programme that was the 'biggest since Brunel's', and 'the best commercial railway in the world' within 10 years.

These boasts were made as recently as three years ago but they now sound like fantasy as the network's reputation lies in tatters after a series of crashes and crises.

The chief worries of many passengers are whether their train will turn up at all, if so how late, will it crash and will fares have gone up by the time they get to their destination?

But while the basic service will eventually recover, the key question for the future is: will Britain ever get that bigger, better, shiny, new railway capable of carrying 50 per cent more passengers than today's record 1 billion a year? If so, when and who will pay for it?

Railtrack has admitted it is in no position to deliver on its promises, with its value decimated after it ignored the broken rail that caused last year's Hatfield crash.

Keith Ludeman, chief executive of Go-Ahead rail, which runs the Thames Trains and Thameslink routes and has just won the London south-central franchise from the despised Connex, said: 'The pace of developing this shiny new railway will be a lot slower than anticipated 18 months ago. And there is a logic that suggests the Strategic Rail Authority will backstop some of the risk.'

In other words, forget those early promises and also assume that the taxpayer will supply a greater proportion of the money needed by the industry, via the Government and its agent, the SRA.

Ludeman believes that it will take up to 10 years before the public sees the high-speed Channel Tunnel Rail Link, upgrades of the west and east coast lines linking Glasgow and Edinburgh with London, the north-south Thameslink project across the capital, some improvements in the Home Counties and automatic safety systems. Hopefully. And that's it.

Everything else, such as modernising the great western line, an east-west link across London, and big expansions around Manchester and Birmingham are on the back burner - perhaps permanently.

Even the most likely projects will come at the cost of major disruption to travel and a much greater level of subsidy than previously anticipated as private-sector investors take fright at the sight of Railtrack disintegrating and huge cost overruns and delays on many major projects.

But, crucially, Ludeman believes that a new kind of investment vehicle being devised by the SRA to take on these projects can be made to work and this is what will deliver an improved railway - better late and more expensive than never.

GoVia, the partnership between Go-Ahead and a subsidiary of the French national railway, SNCF, plans to invest in new trains and infrastructure to produce better services in return for a 20-year contract.

But GoVia will also spend the coming months with US construction firm Bechtel, its fellow investor, Railtrack, and the SRA working out everyone's stakes in a £1.5 billion investment vehicle designed to cost, finance and produce the project.

If a deal can be done, the SRA is expected to contribute grants and agree guaranteed rates of return with GoVia - rumoured to be up to 15 per cent - or underwrite a certain level of risk as the taxpayer's part in the venture.

Ludeman said: 'There is no model yet but we are developing one. It could be a template for the way forward in the industry and at the moment it's the only show in town.'

However, others are less optimistic. One leading City analyst described efforts to find new ways of funding projects in the industry as 'the blind leading the blind' and said he could not see businesses and institutions 'queuing up' to invest in what was now seen as a risky industry.

Stephen Glaister, professor of transport and infrastructure at London's Imperial College, said that the Government must be extremely worried that it will have to pick up the bill if it wants an expanded modern railway to take pride of place in its transport network of the future.

The Government's 10-year transport plan talks of £60bn of expenditure split equally between the public and private sectors.

But that was before Hatfield exposed the true state of the neglected network, the full cost implications of which have yet to be calculated. The immediate consequences of fixing the tracks and compensating the operators is estimated to be likely to cost Railtrack up to £1.2bn - while it has only offered to stump up £600 million and faces being sued for the rest.

The permanent extra costs of maintaining the tracks in a better state will be revealed by Railtrack, along with a disastrous set of annual results, on 24 May. The company will appeal to rail regulator Tom Winsor for extra money to cover that. In other words, it's back to the taxpayer again.

Glaister said: 'The Government's 10-year plan, with its 50-50 public-private split, was plausible a year ago but it is not now.'

Since 1996 the private sector has put in more funds to the railways than the public sector - £11bn versus £8.4bn.The Exchequer also netted £5.28bn gross from selling off the rail industry.

Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Rail, which is to bring in 53 tilting trains on the west coast line from next year, said private operators had bought a lot more rolling stock than British Rail would have been allowed to do by the Treasury.

But while on paper taxpayers are quids in, the service they have received for their money is pitiful and the cost burden looming in the future could reverse the balance. And that's if the Government puts in the money.

Green concluded: 'The same Treasury that begrudged money for the rail industry 50 years ago is still there.

'There will be only be bits of the bigger, better railway and it will take longer.'

Europeans want to avoid 'doing a Railtrack'

Brussels wants to force other European railways to follow the British example and separate infrastructure management from train operations - but with special safeguards to help them 'avoid doing a Railtrack'.

The European Commission is set to hold meetings with British transport officials to take advice on how not to repeat the mistakes of privatisation in the UK. The EC believes over-fragmentation and poor early regulation sparked conflict and compromised safety in the industry..

The EC wants member states with publicly owned rail monopolies to split the administration of the physical track and signalling network and the running of the train services into 'separate institutional entities' without ownership necessarily passing to the private sector.

This has happened in France, although the industry remain state-owned.

Brussels wants to give rail operators more commercial freedom and believes that splitting the functions will open up more competition so that operators in one country can bid to run train services in another.

An EC source told The Observer : 'We want to learn from the UK - from your mistakes.'

Ludeman believes that it will take up to 10 years before the public sees the high-speed Channel Tunnel Rail Link, upgrades of the west and east coast lines linking Glasgow and Edinburgh with London, the north-south Thameslink project across the capital, some improvements in the Home Counties and automatic safety systems. Hopefully. And that's it. Everything else, such as modernising the great western line, an east-west link across London, and big expansions around Manchester and Birmingham are on the back burner - perhaps permanently. Even the most likely projects will come at the cost of major disruption to travel and a much greater level of subsidy than previously anticipated as private-sector investors take fright at the sight of Railtrack disintegrating and huge cost overruns and delays on many major projects. But, crucially, Ludeman believes that a new kind of investment vehicle being devised by the SRA to take on these projects can be made to work and this is what will deliver an improved railway - better late and more expensive than never. GoVia, the partnership between Go-Ahead and a subsidiary of the French national railway, SNCF, plans to invest in new trains and infrastructure to produce better services in return for a 20-year contract. But GoVia will also spend the coming months with US construction firm Bechtel, its fellow investor, Railtrack, and the SRA working out everyone's stakes in a £1.5 billion investment vehicle designed to cost, finance and produce the project. If a deal can be done, the SRA is expected to contribute grants and agree guaranteed rates of return with GoVia - rumoured to be up to 15 per cent - or underwrite a certain level of risk as the taxpayer's part in the venture. Ludeman said: 'There is no model yet but we are developing one. It could be a template for the way forward in the industry and at the moment it's the only show in town.' However, others are less optimistic. One leading City analyst described efforts to find new ways of funding projects in the industry as 'the blind leading the blind' and said he could not see businesses and institutions 'queuing up' to invest in what was now seen as a risky industry. Stephen Glaister, professor of transport and infrastructure at London's Imperial College, said that the Government must be extremely worried that it will have to pick up the bill if it wants an expanded modern railway to take pride of place in its transport network of the future. The Government's 10-year transport plan talks of £60bn of expenditure split equally between the public and private sectors. But that was before Hatfield exposed the true state of the neglected network, the full cost implications of which have yet to be calculated. The immediate consequences of fixing the tracks and compensating the operators is estimated to be likely to cost Railtrack up to £1.2bn - while it has only offered to stump up £600 million and faces being sued for the rest. The permanent extra costs of maintaining the tracks in a better state will be revealed by Railtrack, along with a disastrous set of annual results, on 24 May. The company will appeal to rail regulator Tom Winsor for extra money to cover that. In other words, it's back to the taxpayer again. Glaister said: 'The Government's 10-year plan, with its 50-50 public-private split, was plausible a year ago but it is not now.' Since 1996 the private sector has put in more funds to the railways than the public sector - £11bn versus £8.4bn.The Exchequer also netted £5.28bn gross from selling off the rail industry. Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Rail, which is to bring in 53 tilting trains on the west coast line from next year, said private operators had bought a lot more rolling stock than British Rail would have been allowed to do by the Treasury. But while on paper taxpayers are quids in, the service they have received for their money is pitiful and the cost burden looming in the future could reverse the balance. And that's if the Government puts in the money. Green concluded: 'The same Treasury that begrudged money for the rail industry 50 years ago is still there. 'There will be only be bits of the bigger, better railway and it will take longer.' Europeans want to avoid 'doing a Railtrack' Brussels wants to force other European railways to follow the British example and separate infrastructure management from train operations - but with special safeguards to help them 'avoid doing a Railtrack'. The European Commission is set to hold meetings with British transport officials to take advice on how not to repeat the mistakes of privatisation in the UK. The EC believes over-fragmentation and poor early regulation sparked conflict and compromised safety in the industry.. The EC wants member states with publicly owned rail monopolies to split the administration of the physical track and signalling network and the running of the train services into 'separate institutional entities' without ownership necessarily passing to the private sector. This has happened in France, although the industry remain state-owned. Brussels wants to give rail operators more commercial freedom and believes that splitting the functions will open up more competition so that operators in one country can bid to run train services in another. An EC source told The Observer : 'We want to learn from the UK - from your mistakes.'

webTitle: Labour set to urge Railtrack takeover

fields.headline: Labour set to urge Railtrack takeover
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Labour is set to tackle the crisis in the rail industry with a major shake-up that will include encouraging a takeover of all or part of Railtrack if it wins the forthcoming general election.
fields.body:
Labour is set to tackle the crisis in the rail industry with a major shake-up that will include encouraging a takeover of all or part of Railtrack if it wins the forthcoming general election.

There is no plan to renationalise the company. But The Observer learnt this weekend that a new Blair government would not 'stand in the way' of worthy candidates and might approach potential buyers itself.

Senior industry sources said companies such as US construction giant Bechtel, Britain's John Laing and the venture capital arm of the Japanese bank Nomura could team up to take over Railtrack and then split it up, or buy part of the business if it was spun off.

There is an increasing prospect that without a takeover approach for the whole firm by the early summer the rail regulator Tom Winsor could break it up, dividing its core maintenance role from the major projects division. The projects business is regarded as lucrative but difficult to value before any discussions with the Government agent, the Strategic Rail Authority, about how much risk the taxpayer would underwrite. The net asset value of Railtrack's core business, after allowing for debt, is £2 billion.

A senior industry source said: 'Nothing will be looked at before the election but straight afterwards the issue will be whether the regulator breaks them up, or it's a takeover of Railtrack.'

The shares closed last week at 438p, having been over £10 in February before the company had to be bailed out with a £1.5bn subsidy.

Railtrack is expected to miss its 21 May target for restoring services disrupted after last year's Hatfield crash. Two days later, company boss Steve Marshall will reveal he needs an extra £3bn from Winsor, on top of the £15bn already agreed, over the next five years to cover higher running costs.

This is likely to prompt Winsor to exercise his right to refer the company to the Competition Commission.

fields.headline: Lawless Zimbabwe 'sliding into anarchy'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: An international mission of lawyers has warned that the rule of law in Zimbabwe is on the point of collapse and the country risks descending into anarchy.
fields.body:
An international mission of lawyers has warned that the rule of law in Zimbabwe is on the point of collapse and the country risks descending into anarchy.

The 10-strong team of legal experts from the International Bar Association visited Zimbabwe last month to investigate press allegations of intimidation and threats of violence against members of the legal profession, including Chief Justice Anthony Gubbay, who later resigned.

Their report, which is to be published tomorrow and a copy of which has been obtained by The Observer, has issued a damning verdict on President Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF regime.

It says: 'The situation disclosed during the visit has, regrettably, not only disclosed the truth of those allegations but an even more serious situation in which the events of the past 12 months have put the rule of law in the gravest peril. The circumstances which have been disclosed show, in our view, conduct committed by government which puts the very fabric of democracy at risk.'

The report is expected to increase pressure for the country to be suspended from the Commonwealth and face international sanctions.

The International Bar Association was alerted to Zimbabwe's crisis when Mugabe's Justice Minister, Patrick Chinamasa, threatened Gubbay. who was eventually forced to resign in February. But the erosion of the rule of law began more than two years ago when the police began acting as a wing of the Zanu-PF.

The report traces the judicial breakdown to the farm seizures beginning in February 2000 by 'war veterans' from Zimbabwe's independence struggle. By mid-March 2000, more than 500 farms had been occupied. The mission was deeply critical of thegovernment's failure to intervene in illegal seizures.

The nine-strong delegation was led by Lord Peter Goldsmith and included lawyers from India, the United States, Africa and the Caribbean. The International Bar Association, whose honorary president is Nelson Mandela, represents lawyers from 183 countries and is not affiliated to any opposition groups in Zimbabwe.

In a meeting with Mugabe, the mission was told that the government had not intervened for fear of increasing the bloodshed. But its report endorsed a judgment of the Zimbabwe Supreme Court, which said: 'Wicked things have been done and continue to be done. They must be stopped. Common law crimes have been, and are being, committed with impunity. The government has flouted laws made by parliament.'

Goldsmith told The Observer: 'The conduct encouraged and conducted by Ministers was leading to a culture of lawlessness.'

He said the delegation was shocked by attacks on judges and the government's refusal to obey orders made by its own courts. Goldsmith also expressed his dismay at an astonishing public attack on the international delegation by Chinamasa and Information Minister Jonathan Moyo on state television. They claimed the trip had been stage-managed by the oppostion Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

Zimbabwe's legal crisis has deteriorated further since the bar association's visit. Tawanda Hondora, chairman of the Zimbabwe Lawyers for Human Rights, was beaten by officers at a police station when he tried to investigate reports that they were intimidating witnesses in a coming trial.

The Zimbabwe Lawyers for Human Rights stated it is 'outraged by the continued brutality, lack of respect for fundamental human rights and political partisanship of the Zimbabwe Republic Police. We condemn police involvement with the vigilante groups of Zanu-PF supporters who are creating a reign of terror in Zimbabwe.'

The breakdown of the rule of law prompted the Assistant Police Commissioner, Em-manuel Chimwanda, to resign from the force after 21 years of service.

In January 1999, two journalists, Mark Chavunduka and Ray Choto, were illegally detained and tortured by army officers and agents of the shadowy Central Intelligence Organisation. Police have not investigated the crimes or arrested any suspects. Mugabe stated publicly that the torturers were justified in their actions.

The politicisation of the police force gathered pace after the defeat of Mugabe's draft constitution in a referendum in February. Determined to win parl-iamentary elections, he unleashed the war veterans on MDC supporters and the police took no action. Police stood by as 300 war veterans attacked a peace march, and beat scores of people. On 18 April last year a white farmer, Martin Olds, was murdered by armed supporters of Mugabe. Police stopped other farmers from going to his rescue anddid not hunt his killers.

A week later David Stevens, a white farmer and MDC supporter, was ab-ducted by the veterans. Five other farmers who went to help him were dragged from the Murewa police station and beaten unconscious. Stevens and his black farm manager were murdered.

Two black MDC campaigners were murdered when their car was firebombed in May 2000. No arrests were made. In June an MDC agent, Patrick Nabanyama, was abducted by Zanu-PF supporters. He is presumed dead. Men identified as responsible were held but released without charge.

fields.headline: Hawk Sharon's wings clipped
fields.standfirst:
He talked tough. He went in hard. Now Israel's leader has been forced to retreat

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: He talked tough. He went in hard. Now Israel's leader has been forced to retreat.
fields.body:
A thick crowd coils through a narrow cobbled street towards Jerusalem's Lion Gate. The Friday prayers are over and the worshippers are leaving the gardens of the Haram al-Sharif shrine complex. Its gardens are green and cool and empty, the Dome of the Rock is gold in the midday sun and the shadows are as black as the crows wheeling above the Mount of Olives.

Suddenly there is shouting. And the crack of stone on stone. From high on the ancient walls a shower of rocks bounces down on to a detachment of Israeli policemen, splintering off the cobbles, scattering worshippers, hawkers, tourists and media alike. For 15 minutes the stones rain down. There are tussles and screamed abuse. An officer fumbles with the pin on a tear gas grenade as a youth a few metres away hurls a brick at him. And then a pause.

A lone teenage boy - a headdress wrapped around his face - runs along the high battlements and ties a Palestinian flag to the barbed wire. And the Israelis level their guns, squint through the sights - and hold their fire.

To observers it was a significant moment. In the past, Israeli troops have not hesitated to use rubber - and often live - bullets to impose their authority. Their tactics have relied on the concentrated use of massive strength. When Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was a soldier, his motto was 'always escalate'. Could it be a sign of a change of heart or at least of tactic?

Last week, it was Sharon and the Israeli hawks who received a short, sharp shock when the 73-year-old premier was forced - largely by international pressure - to order the withdrawal of troops from a stretch of land in the Gaza Strip only a day after sending them in.

Sharon had not thought that occupying land that had been under the control of the fledgling Palestinian government since the beginning of the peace process would spark global outrage. He certainly did not expect direct criticism from the new American administration, which reluctantly made its first significant intervention in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The result was embarrassment for Sharon at home and abroad - and a new chance to end the current fighting that has claimed the lives of 381 Palestinians and seven Israeli Jews since it started seven months ago.

The huge, heavy grindwheel of Israeli-Palestinian violence and counter-violence seems to have turned and, for once, come to an unsteady rest. There are reports of 'discreet contacts' between the two sides - a precursor to peace talks - and Simon Peres, the Israeli Foreign Minister, has expressed hopes for the success of 'quiet diplomacy'.

Yasser Arafat has called for an end to the mortar attacks that so provoked Sharon and has suggested that he and the Israeli leader issue a joint call for a reduction in violence. The daily clashes that used to pit hundreds of Palestinian youths against Israeli soldiers have almost disappeared. But it is unclear if Sharon is chas tened. He rejected Arafat's offer and has told reporters he thinks his tough tactics are working.

Israeli tanks rolled into Gaza once more yesterday to destroy a police station in an area from where they said attacks were being launched. Reaction from the Palestinian side was muted.

'It's still very murky but there is a tiny chink of light,' said one Western diplomat in Jerusalem. 'For optimists this is an opportunity to get back on the road towards a settlement. Pessimists see it as the calm before the storm.'

Either way, the events of last week have significantly altered the political situation. Sharon promised that as an experienced, decisive man unafraid of using force, he would bring peace. His ability to deliver is now being questioned.

'Trust the schlemiel ,' said one newspaper, using the Yiddish word for a cack-handed fool. 'What began as a military campaign, an expression of a new uncompromising policy, ended as an embar rassing shot in the foot which achieved nothing.'

One of the targets for the mortar attacks, claimed by the extremist Islamic group Hamas, was Nir Am, a kibbutz beside the Gaza Strip. On Wednesday five mortars landed a few hundred metres from where 350 people were attending a Holocaust memorial service. But the next morning, even with the dull rattle of Israeli soldiers exchanging automatic fire with Palestinians nearby, the talk was of compromise.

'We can really identify with them. They are frustrated and have to put up with a lot,' said Shaul Mana, 35. 'If we want to live in peace together we both have to make sacrifices.'

Less than a mile away, Ibrahim Abdallah Abud Said, 73, sat in the ruins of his fields. Where once there had been his orange and olive trees there was now chopped up roots and earth. He pointed out his chicken hutch. The Israeli army bulldozers had crushed the birds in their coops, he said.

Abu Said did not deny the mortars had been launched from nearby. He said he did not support the men who had fired them from his fields. 'But how can I stop them?' he said. 'Now I am ruined.'

Although Israeli fingers stayed off the triggers at the Lion's Gate on Friday there was no mistaking the message sent by the operation that followed the clashes there. Scores of heavily armed policemen streamed through the gates of the Haram al-Sharif and took up positions around the Dome of the Rock, the third holiest site in Islam. The last time they were there was when Sharon, then in opposition, walked through the complex. That visit sparked the current uprising.

Then his intention was to demonstrate Israeli sovereignty and the country's unwavering determination and might. Despite the setbacks of last week and the conciliatory moves of moderates on both sides, there is little to indicate that last week's incursion into the grounds of the shrine sought to prove anything different.

webTitle: Comment: A time to build trust in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: A time to build trust
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Last Sunday the ongoing foot-and-mouth crisis meant that there were a limited number of Irish republican marches commemorating the 1916 Easter Rising.
fields.body:
Last Sunday the ongoing foot-and-mouth crisis meant that there were a limited number of Irish republican marches commemorating the 1916 Easter Rising.

The media was interested in the turn-out in Dublin for the 32-County Sovereignty Movement because of its alleged links to the Real IRA (there had been an explosion in London the night before), and to see if it would attract significant numbers (200 people showed up), and if a threatened picket by relatives of the Omagh bomb victims materialised.

But the largest number of commemorations with the highest attendance were those organised by the National Graves Association addressed by Sinn Fein speakers. At these marches were relatives of dead IRA Volunteers, former hunger strikers, ex-escapees, former prisoners, as well as thousands of supporters.

The speaker at the 32-CSM commemoration in Dublin said that they had small numbers and were being vilified just like the men and women of 1916. On other occasions dissidents have likened their splitting from mainstream republicans in Sinn Fein and the IRA as a re-run of the split in 1969. At that time the Republican Movement divided into the 'Officials' and 'the Provisionals' (today's Sinn Fein and IRA).

However, the Real IRA will never be able to replicate the IRA's firepower and thus bring the British to the negotiating table. The 32-CSM has no popular support, has failed to produce a cogent leadership, and lacks a credible political programme.

Whereas the Officials went into decline after the 1972 cease-fire, Sinn Fein's popularity has risen since the IRA's cessation of August 1994, to the extent that they may hold the balance of power after the next election. Dissidents rely on exploiting growing republican disquiet at Britain's mishandling of the peace process, but that anger is unlikely to be directed at the Sinn Fein leadership or be channelled into substantial support for dissidents.

In its constitution, 32-CSM states: 'We hold that all administrations and assemblies purporting to act as lawful government for the Irish people, or otherwise functioning as partitionist entities, to be illegal...' But how can its leaders square this belated purism with the fact that for 11 years (from 1986 until 1997) they were part of the Republican Movement which had dropped its policy of abstentionism towards that 'partitionist' entity, the Dail? At least former president Ruairi O Bradaigh had the honesty to leave and form Republican Sinn Fein.

If the 32-CSM and the Real IRA really believes in the 1916 analogy then they should go back to first principles, contest elections on an abstentionist ticket and set up an all-Ireland assembly in opposition to what the electorates have overwhelmingly voted for - the Good Friday Agreement. Similarly, its members should refuse to recognise the courts. That would be absurd, and they know it.

Those who split from the Republican Movement in 1997 to form the Real IRA and the 32-CSM did so because they refused to go along with or respect the opinion of the majority.

The 32-CSM's principal alternative to the Sinn Fein project of bringing about a new Ireland is remarkably naïve: pressing Ireland's right to sovereignty and independence at the United Nations. Ask the Palestinians about UN Resolution 242 and what it has done for their freedom.

Tragically, the Real IRA will continue with its sporadic campaign, continue to kill innocent people and lose its own volunteers to cemetery and jail until some member has the guts to face up to the futility of the campaign. They and the 32-CSM have no message for the unionist people, do not understand that the building of trust, the normalisation of relations with the unionists, preparatory cross-border social and economic harmonisation, the building of a strong, all-Ireland republican party, are all part of the struggle for Irish re-unification.

 Danny Morrison is a writer and a former director of publicity for Sinn Fein.

At these marches were relatives of dead IRA Volunteers, former hunger strikers, ex-escapees, former prisoners, as well as thousands of supporters. The speaker at the 32-CSM commemoration in Dublin said that they had small numbers and were being vilified just like the men and women of 1916. On other occasions dissidents have likened their splitting from mainstream republicans in Sinn Fein and the IRA as a re-run of the split in 1969. At that time the Republican Movement divided into the 'Officials' and 'the Provisionals' (today's Sinn Fein and IRA). However, the Real IRA will never be able to replicate the IRA's firepower and thus bring the British to the negotiating table. The 32-CSM has no popular support, has failed to produce a cogent leadership, and lacks a credible political programme. Whereas the Officials went into decline after the 1972 cease-fire, Sinn Fein's popularity has risen since the IRA's cessation of August 1994, to the extent that they may hold the balance of power after the next election. Dissidents rely on exploiting growing republican disquiet at Britain's mishandling of the peace process, but that anger is unlikely to be directed at the Sinn Fein leadership or be channelled into substantial support for dissidents. In its constitution, 32-CSM states: 'We hold that all administrations and assemblies purporting to act as lawful government for the Irish people, or otherwise functioning as partitionist entities, to be illegal...' But how can its leaders square this belated purism with the fact that for 11 years (from 1986 until 1997) they were part of the Republican Movement which had dropped its policy of abstentionism towards that 'partitionist' entity, the Dail? At least former president Ruairi O Bradaigh had the honesty to leave and form Republican Sinn Fein. If the 32-CSM and the Real IRA really believes in the 1916 analogy then they should go back to first principles, contest elections on an abstentionist ticket and set up an all-Ireland assembly in opposition to what the electorates have overwhelmingly voted for - the Good Friday Agreement. Similarly, its members should refuse to recognise the courts. That would be absurd, and they know it. Those who split from the Republican Movement in 1997 to form the Real IRA and the 32-CSM did so because they refused to go along with or respect the opinion of the majority. The 32-CSM's principal alternative to the Sinn Fein project of bringing about a new Ireland is remarkably naïve: pressing Ireland's right to sovereignty and independence at the United Nations. Ask the Palestinians about UN Resolution 242 and what it has done for their freedom. Tragically, the Real IRA will continue with its sporadic campaign, continue to kill innocent people and lose its own volunteers to cemetery and jail until some member has the guts to face up to the futility of the campaign. They and the 32-CSM have no message for the unionist people, do not understand that the building of trust, the normalisation of relations with the unionists, preparatory cross-border social and economic harmonisation, the building of a strong, all-Ireland republican party, are all part of the struggle for Irish re-unification.  Danny Morrison is a writer and a former director of publicity for Sinn Fein.

webTitle: 'Heaven' as war families reunite 50 years on

fields.headline: 'Heaven' as war families reunite 50 years on
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: As Israeli and Syrian generals prepare their countries for a possible war, envoys from the two states have taken an unprecedented but unreported step towards peace by reuniting families across enemy lines.
fields.byline: Nick Pelham in Yarmuk Camp, Damascus
fields.body:
As Israeli and Syrian generals prepare their countries for a possible war, envoys from the two states have taken an unprecedented but unreported step towards peace by reuniting families across enemy lines.

Only a day after Israel bombarded Syrian radar positions in Lebanon, The Observer can reveal that a busload of 50 Israeli Palestinians rolled into the Syrian capital, Damascus, in a confidence-building measure to end 52 years of ruptured family relations.

Brother hugged brother, mothers swooned over sons, as hundreds of Palestinian refugees thronged the bus station to greet the arrivals from Israel. Syria had invited the Palestinians, who travelled on Syrian passes rather than their Israeli passports, to rejoin relatives in Syria's refugee camps for a week.

'It's like a wedding, as if our lost brothers had descended from heaven,' said Majid Abu Ras as he hugged his brother, Ibrahim Yassine, a retired builder from across the enemy lines.

Majid, a grocer in Yarmuk Camp, had been only six when he last saw his brother in 1948. Then the Israeli army chased Ibrahim and their parents away from Ailut, a hamlet three miles from Nazareth. Now both men are grandfathers.

Observers hailed the reunification project as more ground- breaking than the reuniting of relatives across the divide between North and South Korea.

For the past 50 years, Israel has banned its citizens from visiting enemy states, fearing it would turn Israeli Arabs into a fifth column, and Syria has banned entry by Palestinians holding Israeli passports.

Azmi Bishara, an Israeli Arab MP who was in Damascus for the arrival of the bus, said the project was 'a credit to the new approach' of the Syrian President, Bashar al-Assad.

Before leaving, Bishara was detained for a time by the Israeli authorities, who warned him that his immunity as an MP did not allow him to flout the ban on visiting enemy states. So far Israel has failed to reciprocate Syria's move, although almost all the 450,000 Palestinian refugees in Syria have close relatives among Israel's 1.2 million Arabs.

Bishara said bringing families together was the culmination of four years of negotiations with Syrian. The first busload of Israeli Palestinians arrived last December. More than 500 have now made the trip. Most have been aged over 70 and wanted to hug sisters, brothers and parents before they die.

The journeys have brought tragedy as well as joy, however. Furaya Abu Ras, who for 52 years had lived in Ailut like a widow, arrived to find that her husband Mohammed had remarried. Hamda Abu Mahdi had cursed herself for most of her life for leaving one of her 12 sons behind when the family fled. When her lost son Abid arrived on the first bus at Ramadan, she was too senile to know who he was.

Yesterday the drone of prayers broadcast over loudspeakers drowned out the ticking of rosaries spreading through mourners' hands as Hamda's body was buried in Yarmuk Camp. She had died still thinking that her son was missing.

Israel remains desperate to prevent the ripple of family reunification turning into a flood of six million Palestinians seeking the right to return.

The reunited families dream of an age when generals no longer rule Israel and the Arab world. 'For now it's only a week together,' said Majid Abu Ras. 'God willing, one day it will be forever.'
