webTitle: Heather Connon: A novel tracker fund

fields.headline: A novel idea for those going off the track
fields.trailText: 'Scottish Value Management is launching a fund to capitalise on variations in performance, while sticking to the familiar names of the FTSE 100 Index.'
fields.body:
Over the last year, shares in Billiton have risen 57 per cent and Shires Pharmaceuticals by 62 per cent. BT and Pearson have moved almost as far in the opposite direction. Choosing which share to buy is crucial and likely to remain so.

Scottish Value Management, the Edinburgh-based fund manager, is launching a fund to capitalise on those huge variations in performance, while sticking to the familiar names of the FTSE 100 Index. It is a novel con cept. A number of trusts track the index, but they would have had to buy BT as well as Billiton. A number of funds specialise in big companies - Merrill Lynch and Aberdeen are among the firms that offer them - but these are international, covering US, European and Japanese companies as well as our home-grown ones. Other funds take hefty bets on particular sectors - think of the style funds from firms like Chase Fleming or Liontrust - but these cover the FTSE 350. SVM UK100 appears to be the only fund that confines itself to the FTSE 100.

It could be an attractive option. Andrew Kelly, who will manage the fund, decided about six months ago that resources companies, like Billiton or Rio Tinto, were attractive but wondered why so many analysts were singing the praises of BT. He has also been keen on food retailers, like Tesco and Safeway, which have performed well in the last 12 months. He has been right. In the year it has been running, the fund's value has fallen by 7.9 per cent - a good performance given that the FTSE 100 has fallen by 12.1 per cent.

SVM is making a determined bid to attract those who would normally invest in trackers by charging a basic management fee of just 0.75 per cent, less than half the average active fund fee. It will also take 10 per cent of any outperformance as an incentive fee but, if it earns that, investors will be gaining too.

It will be high risk. The fund will invest in just 25 to 30 stocks and, if Kelly gets its bets wrong, the underperformance could be dramatic. But, in current markets, those who still want to be in equities have to take big bets. When shares are falling, there is no point in buying into a tracker which will simply follow the market lower, nor in buying a large general fund which is a tracker in all but name.

Instead, investors should look for specialist managers who they trust to take risks. That could mean a smaller companies fund, a corporate bond fund, or a European fund. The attractions of the SVM UK 100 is that the index it tracks is so visible, and the companies are familiar names. Those who want to risk stock market investment should take a look.

webTitle: Phil Hogan: Home alone... with the hamster

fields.headline: Home alone... with the hamster
fields.trailText: 'My wife and children have decided to observe Holy Week this year by driving off to Butlins without me.'
fields.body:
My wife and children have decided to observe Holy Week this year by driving off to Butlins without me, doubtless assuming that I would only ruin it for everybody by being morose and refusing to play on the trampolines and spreading my magic cloak of misery over an innocent fun-packed evening of fancy-dress karaoke on rollerblades or whatever atrocity in the name of entertainment might find itself harnessing the diverse talents of Jim Davidson and 80s-hairstyle comedian Limahl, of Kajagoogoo 'fame'. And OK, I admit to a certain mental struggle gathering together the words 'holiday' and 'camp' under the conceptual banner of enjoyment without opening the concealed trapdoor of my jaundiced imagination to images of barbed wire and ping-pong competitions, notwithstanding today's exciting full-colour brochures promising spacious apartments, complimentary Blue Nun, soap, towels, baths and showers (NB separate toilet in Minehead), but - hey - it would have been nice to be asked. I could have stayed in the chalet with a book and sent out for a box of paracetamol.

And it's not as if it has been one long holiday here on my own, or at least not at this precise moment as I crawl back into bed having found myself leaping out for the second morning running (will I never learn?) to take a large mallet to the seven-year-old's Bart Simpson alarm clock, which is in the habit of barking out 'Eat my Shorts! Eat my Shorts!' at the stroke of God knows when - well, actually, in this case, about 40 winks after I've got myself home and into bed with the traditional one sock still on from an evening out compensating for the cruel absence of my loved ones by getting drunk with Neil. And it's not as if I haven't already staggered to the bathroom once and down to the kitchen in the middle of the night to remind myself how difficult it is to drink milk out of a six-pint carton with only the fridge for illumination. I mean I am sticking to the manual.

I bury myself under the duvet. I have the beginnings of the faintest headache, so obviously I don't think it would be such a controversial idea to get some kip before they all come clamouring back demanding attention at a time when I'm least capable of maintaining an upright position. But I'm no sooner in the land of nod again than the hamster is awake and hammering away in whatever frenzy of thought can be said to go on in a mind small enough to think that running on an exercise wheel for days on end constitutes a life.

Eventually, I am compelled to stomp downstairs and put something in his spokes, which naturally he sees as a cue to come whiskering up to the bars to see me, clearly unembarrassedly oblivious to the difference in sleeping patterns between small rodents and the higher mammals. I notice that at some point during the night he has stuffed all his food and bedding into his cheeks and moved everything into one end of his plastic tube, leaving the floor clear, as if perhaps expecting friends round for a spot of line dancing. Hamsters are born optimists, which is why they don't live very long.

Two hours later I've just got my feet up on the kitchen table after a modest brunch of Fray Bentos corned beef with Heinz Weightwatchers beans on crumpets when my wife rings to say they're on their way, and what a brilliant time they've had, and did I remember to put Lucky out in his run yesterday. 'Yes, of course I did_' Though now I come to think of it I couldn't quite swear to putting him back in his hutch again, which means he may have been eaten by a fox since I last saw him. I make my excuses and dash outside to find the little fellow hopping about in his usual aimless manner. I count his legs. He doesn't look too discommoded but then a rabbit's emotional life is a secret made easier to keep by not having access to the full spectrum of facial expressions. I give him a nice bowl of his favourite warming porridge and leave him to count his blessings. Who knows, they might take him with them next time.

fields.headline: Common knowledge
fields.trailText: 'There it was, the word 'common', being employed self-empoweringly and humourously, and not in an attempt to terrorise the aspirant working classes and keep them down.'
fields.body:
A big thank you to Janet Street-Porter for reclaiming a word I thought had died a shameful death long ago, and was now resting in an unmarked grave, along with the rest of the poisonous terms that the sneaky, snidey middle classes dare not use in polite company any more. In an article detailing her chequered tenure as editor of the Independent on Sunday , Street-Porter announces: 'I accept that I'm loud, larger than life, and common.' There it was, the word 'common', here being employed self-empoweringly and humourously, and not, as was traditional, in an attempt to terrorise the aspirant working classes and keep them down.

As anybody who knows me to any great degree could testify, there's nothing I like better than a bit of class war. Trouble is, those I choose to argue with, both from the middle classes and the working classes (I don't mix with the upper riffraff), seem to share the view that I'm a bit behind the times. In the case of the middle classes, one can only do a Mandy Rice-Davis: 'Well you would say that, wouldn't you?'. Those class-deniers who hail from working-class stock seem to me to be a stranger bunch altogether.

It amazes me how quick working-class people are to argue that the class war, the civil war raged quite literally against them, is over. To me, class prejudice is such a fact of life in Britain that claiming it no longer exists is a bit like saying: 'Sickness and death are so out of date now.' Or: 'In this country, no one cares about being born any more.' Yet still, people tell me, completely straight-faced, that money and merit are the only things that count these days. And that, actually, the whole sorry class-war debacle self-combusted long ago, probably some time back in the 50s, at the very latest the 70s, and all the rest is phantom shrapnel wounds on my part.

Admittedly, maybe I don't want the class war to be over, maybe I think it's a bit suspicious that the whistle is blowing just when it looks like we're getting somewhere. Mostly, though, I just think that people are kidding themselves. Only recently, somebody had the audacity to paint me as the very worst kind of Pomagne Socialist - as in, somebody who pays lip service to her blue-collar roots but still has the scorch marks on her heels from the time she got the hell out of there. What this gentleman failed to realise was that class isn't something you escape from or return to. Class is something you're born with, and which stays with you forever. Indeed, it seems significant that those people who believe it to be at all mutable only tend to see the traffic going one way.

If this was not true, then why is it routine for people to think of working-class people who have done well for themselves as having 'become middle class'? All that garbage about how 'I would never have believed that a daughter of mine would play the piano', as if the working classes had never heard of pianos. No one ever seems to reverse this strange claim by saying that middle-class people who have lost their money have 'become working class', or how sad it is that their daughters would now have to forget how to play the piano. And that may be because, for the middle classes, the thought of 'becoming working class' is just too terrible, as if it would entail them falling off the edge of the civilised world with no hope of getting back.

They needn't worry. There are always exceptions to the rule, but for the main part, the working classes don't want members of the middle class on their team. Think about it: they dress like they're dead, drink like toddlers, and can't even watch football properly (ie, for the sheer joy of it), never mind play it well ('Oh, good shot, I shall put that in my sports-related memoir'). In short, a sudden middle-class influx would only weaken and contaminate good, honest, beautiful peasant stock. The middle classes secretly know this, and that's why they're always getting so nasty and nervous. That's why they were always using words like 'common'.

This is where Street-Porter's comment comes in. For decades, before it felt into disuse, the word had real power, a vicious sting all its own. It was a word the middle classes used to let the working classes know that, whatever they did, wherever they lived, whatever they ate, however they spoke, and however much they accomplished, they would never be quite the ticket. By reclaiming the word 'common' just as feminists reclaimed 'bitch', the working classes could make it a badge of honour. Say it loud: We're common and proud. Even better, think it quietly.

webTitle: Fed up with boom and bust

fields.headline: Fed up with boom and bust
fields.trailText: Between-meetings cuts in interest rates are getting to be a habit with the US Federal Reserve. They are in danger of becoming the rule rather than the exception. It all makes a nonsense of carefully constructed historical procedures. And it prompts the markets to keep asking, 'What does the Fed know that we don't?'
fields.body:
Between-meetings cuts in interest rates are getting to be a habit with the US Federal Reserve. They are in danger of becoming the rule rather than the exception. It all makes a nonsense of carefully constructed historical procedures. And it prompts the markets to keep asking, 'What does the Fed know that we don't?'

I am surprised the markets feel the need to ask this question. For what the Fed and its chairman Alan Greenspan know that the markets do not seem to have cottoned on to is that they (the Fed) got it hopelessly wrong. After years of openly expressed doubts, Greenspan led the Federal Reserve to buy the so called 'New Economy' at its peak.

Despite all his carefully expressed reservations about past booms in new technology and their consequences - and Greenspan, among other things, is a very good economic historian - and despite his regular references to the dangers of 'imbalances', Greenspan allowed himself to be swayed by the markets' desire to believe that the business cycle was either a thing of the past, or that information technology enabled business to respond to stock cycles in more subtle ways than before.

But there is nothing subtle about the daily announcements of lay-offs by US multinationals, both at home and abroad. There seems to be something very old fashioned about this business cycle. As a Keynesian - albeit a very right-wing one - Greenspan has always believed in stabilisation policy, the management of demand. Unfortunately, in recent years the Fed made the classic mistake of being what economists call 'pro-cyclical' - giving the economy an extra boost when it was already firing on all cylinders. It offended the golden central banking rule, enunciated by one of Greenspan's illustrious predecessors, William McChesney Martin, that it is the duty of central bankers to remove the punch-bowl when the party gets going in order not to go around fuelling the intoxicated atmosphere further.

The Fed's recent panic cuts seem to be an admission not only that it was pro-cyclical on the way up, but that it kept rates too high when the US economy had already turned, and was on the way down. Quite what consolation cuts in interest rates will be to businesses that have overinvested and are now issuing dire profit warnings remains to be seen. At least the Fed is not tightening monetary policy to make things worse.

It was acute observation of the linkages between the US and UK economies and financial systems that led the so called 'doves' on the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee to break ranks from the 'don't panic' Basle Consensus of central bankers in January. The 'doves' have led the case for lower interest rates here, and have been joined, at a slower pace, by the others. We now know that the decision to cut rates on 5 April was unanimous, and that three MPC members in fact argued for a half per cent, not the quarter (to 5.5 per cent) that took place.

But the Basle Consensus is alive and well on the Continent, where the European Central Bank has been delighting in not reducing interest rates as the outlook deteriorates. It is not as if the eurozone is in anything like the position of the US economy. The eurozone endured nearly a decade of sluggish growth in order to fit itself into the self-imposed straitjacket of the Maastricht budgetary criteria, and then enjoyed a very minor period of reasonable growth. Now it is being hit by the repercussion of the US slowdown and the increasingly disturbing recession in Japan - and doing nothing about it.

It has to be said that the ECB is stretching the patience of the most pro-European of observers. If ever an institution was playing into the hands of British Eurosceptics, it is the ECB.

So far the ECB has also been 'pro-cyclical', in the sense that it has done nothing to avert unnecessary slowdown that seems to be visible to almost everybody except itself. Has anybody ever told the ECB that there are time-lags in economic policy, and it is better to change direction when you see the chasm opening up in front of you?

I was always suspicious of the extraordinary degree of independence allotted to the ECB. Even the 'independent' Bank of England is subject to more democratic control. As Christopher Allsopp, a relatively new MPC member, has written: 'It seems right that the democratically elected authorities should be responsible for setting the overall goals of monetary policy, while its operation should be delegated to professionals.'

On the day he granted the Bank independence, the Chancellor also emphasised his goals of economic growth and high employment. If he mentioned his aversion to 'boom and bust' once, he mentioned it a thousand times. More recently, there has been a subtle change: his 'stability-oriented' policies are there to protect us from the vagaries of 'boom and bust' elsewhere, notably in the US and Japan. Even our Iron Chancellor cannot eliminate 'boom and bust'.

It was concern about the fallout from the US that prompted Treasury advisers to urge an early election. Having granted independence to the Bank and disclaimed any idea that interest rate cuts should be 'political', the Treasury was nevertheless praying, at the very least, for the kind of interest rate response it has had from the MPC so far this year.

It has been trying to balance the increasingly worse news from overseas and the hitherto strong growth of UK domestic demand.

Thus, most MPC members on 5 April believed that 'final domestic demand growth remained robust. The strength of the housing market would cushion the effects on consumption of falls in equity prices. Nor were there signs of weakness in business investment and Government consumption: indeed, the reverse.'

Nevertheless, even some of the 'hawks' felt 'it might not require much additional downside news to justify a further cut in rates.'

webTitle: Religion gets down to bare bones

fields.headline: Religion gets down to bare bones
fields.standfirst:
The procession of St Thérèse's relics is provoking public fervour and liberal alarm
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The procession of St Thérèse's relics is provoking public fervour and liberal alarm.
fields.body:
Striking scenes of public piety, reminiscent of the Fifties, continue to greet the Irish tour of the bones of St Thérèse of Lisieux, which arrived in the country last Sunday by ferry from France. For the next nine weeks the remains will tour cathedrals and main churches in every Roman Catholic diocese in Ireland as part of a world pilgrimage which, to date, has included the US, South America and Russia.

As the relics, held in a 400lb gold and silver casket, were carried ashore at Rosslare, Co Wexford by an Irish army escort, thousands of people watched the Bishop of Ferns, Dr Brendan Comiskey, bless the remains. Then, as the procession moved to a local church, showers of rose-petals, a flower associated with the saint, were thrown in front of the six-tonne Mercedes transporter, already dubbed the Thérèsemobile.

For the Irish bishops, the events surrounding the St Thérèse tour are intended to recall the 1979 visit of Pope John Paul II, who was enthusiastically greeted by around two million Catholics at venues across Ireland. A similar religious resurgence is now looked for by the current organisers.

But a problem for the Irish church is that the Ireland of today is vastly different to the economically depressed Ireland of the Seventies. In the intervening years, the prosperous 'Celtic Tiger' bred a growing disregard for central Catholic teachings, seen as outmoded by many.

Formal religious observance steadily dwindled in the Nineties: five years ago an Irish Times survey found that only 21 per cent of Catholics followed church teaching on serious moral issues. Allied to that, the Church itself has experienced two nightmare decades of clerical scandals, involving sexual abuse of children by a considerable number of priests and appalling instances of a hierarchy unwilling to accept blame.

Clerical celibacy, long held a sacred value in the Irish Catholic tradition, has increasingly been questioned by laity and some members of the clergy alike. Hardline resistance to any inroads on that issue has been undermined by several high-profile cases of sexually active clergy who fathered children while continuing publicly to uphold church teaching.

They included the former Bishop of Galway, Dr Eamon Casey, who in fled in disgrace to South America after the mother of his then-teenage child went public in 1992, and high-profile showbiz priest, the late Fr Michael Cleary. Ironically, both played a key part in the Pope's 1979 Irish visit, appearing with him at a youth rally in Galway.

Quite apart from popular cynicism at the motives of some clergy, there is also a growing sophistication among liberal sections of the religious and laity, who regard the current Thérèse trip as a sad example of ghoulish bad taste and outdated theology.

They may be the main target of Bishop Comiskey's remarks, as he welcomed the relics to Ireland last Sunday. Criticising 'self-styled intellectuals', concerned about the involvement of the 'peasantry' in events such as the St Thérèse tour, he roundly denied that it was superstition or 'worshipping bones'.

'Listen, us people out in the heartlands, we're not as easily fooled as people who worry about us in ivory towers think,' he declared. 'We're not going to be fooled by clerics, by politicians, by theologians, by liturgists. Those people who worry about relics, they don't mind spending a few thousand pounds for Bono's sweater or glasses.'

It was a message guaranteed to go to the heart of Irish religious traditionalists, for whom St Thérèse, the French Carmelite nun who died of tuberculosis at the age of 24 in 1879 and was canonised in 1925, remains almost on a par with the Virgin Mary. Her claims of the Virgin's appearance to her at the age of 10, curing her of illness, including hallucinations and possibly anorexia nervosa, are widely accepted by the faithful as true.

The recently elevated Cardinal Desmond Connell, an academic rather than a pastoral priest by background, stands for Papal orthodoxy, strictly supporting the humanae vitae ban on artificial contraception, despite widespread public defiance, and currently calling for another Irish referendum to strengthen the law against abortion.

Last week, ordaining students at St Patrick's College, Maynooth, he insisted that church celibacy was 'more fundamental than law', and must be preserved.

Significant numbers of his clergy will find that message unhelpful, as the number of priests ordained nationally continues to decline. During the week it was also reported that in the Diocese of Kerry, which includes part of west Cork and is one of the biggest in Ireland, only two students are preparing for the priesthood.

Meanwhile, however, the Thérèsemobile continues on its Irish tour. There is only one blight on the horizon: foot and mouth disease in the North could disrupt the planned visits there between 20 May and 2 June. But, as Rev Ian Paisley, chair of the NI Assembly Agriculture committee, recently observed on attempts to stop the outbreak: 'Prayer is a great wonder-worker.'

webTitle: Schools forcing children to take drug, parents say

fields.headline: Schools forcing children to take drug, parents say
fields.standfirst: Health fears ignored as Ritalin prescriptions soar
fields.trailText: Health fears ignored as Ritalin prescriptions soar
fields.body:
Parents are being pressured into putting their children on Ritalin, a psychoactive drug that can cause severe side-effects, or face the children's expulsion from school.

An Observer investigation has also discovered that some children have been given the drug by school secretaries, dinner ladies and even some other pupils. An estimated 21,000 children in Britain are taking Ritalin; experts predict that more than one in seven children will be taking the drug by 2007.

Ritalin is prescribed for children with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), which is reputedly on the rise in the UK. Ritalin prescriptions rose from 3,500 in 1993 to 157,000 last year.

Coupled with health fears about possible side-effects, experts are worried that careless administration of the drug is leading to trafficking in the playground. Ritalin has already become a popular and cheap street drug with each pill selling for £1 or £2 each. It is snorted, dissolved and injected as a cheap alternative to cocaine. With a dosage of three to six tablets a day, it makes tempting pocket money for children.

Research by Professor Steve Baldwin, who was investigating the use of Ritalin in schools before he was killed in the Selby train crash in February, has now been released. He studied 100 children using Ritalin.

Baldwin had repeatedly warned of side effects from Ritalin, including cardiovascular problems, psychosis, hallucinations, violent and suicidal behaviour, and stunted growth.

He believed there would be probable long-term consequences on the central nervous systems of minors and wanted it banned in schools.

One of the children in the study, James Grayson, 11, from Manchester, left suicide notes for his parents, drank from puddles and 'barked like a dog' while on Ritalin.

There were also reports of destructive behaviour, self-mutilation, mood disturbance, depression, twitches, sleep loss and visual disturbance.

But for 14-year-old Nicholas, being humiliated when the school secretary would arrive to give him his daily Ritalin in front of his classmates was the least of his problems.

Diagnosed as having ADHD at eight, it was not until Nicholas reached secondary school that he was prescribed Ritalin without, his mother Beverley Croan says, any of the side-effects being explained to her.

'He got to his new school and they said, "Oh this child needs medication, can you get him some?"

'But on Ritalin his behaviour got worse,' she said. 'Jumping out of windows, running in front of traffic and he burnt his face badly one time. I did some research and discovered the drug was a powerful amphetamine, so I took him off it.' The school objected strongly and Nicholas was sent home. He has now been out of school for six months, receiving only three hours' teaching a week from Edinburgh education authority against the 25 hours recommended by the Department of Education. 'It is frankly blackmail,' said Croan. 'Drug your child and he can come to school.'

Last year an eight-year-old boy, Daniel Young - who did not have ADHD - was accidentally given the drug by a temporary teacher at his primary in Edinburgh.

And in Sussex, one special needs teacher told The Observer he had had three children collapse in his classroom after he had given them their Ritalin. 'It is a very frightening experience, and of course I had no idea what to do the first time.

'It turned out they had had too much for their morning dose and the lunchtime dose just overdosed them.

'I am now fighting to get a child off Ritalin that quite frankly I think has just disappeared into a shell since he went on it - how can I reach a child who looks as though they have just come back from a World War One battlefield - shellshocked.'

Janice Hill, who runs Overload Network International, a help group for ADHD-affected families, said: 'The situation is quite horrendous. Ritalin is being kept in school drawers and parents have no idea whether their child is being supervised taking the drug or just given it so they can wander off and hand it to friends.'

Novartis, the company which makes Ritalin, said: 'Ritalin is a mild central nervous system stimulant. Its safety and efficacy is one of the most widely researched areas in child behavioural disorders. Many studies, over the last 40 years, have shown that the use of Ritalin in treating ADHD has a very positive effect.'

But Baldwin was convinced that 'schools have become modern-day prisons with children drugged for purposes of social control'.

He said: 'I would like to see drug-free schools where amphetamines are not allowed on the premises, and children being offered psycho-social alternatives. I would love the police to get interested in this and to properly investigate it.'

webTitle: Murder mystery of the China Rose

fields.headline: Murder mystery of the China Rose
fields.standfirst: Ex-policeman David Sims told his wife employing a hit man was cheaper than getting a divorce.  Tony Thompson reports on a global murder hunt
fields.trailText: Ex-policeman David Sims told his wife employing a hit man was cheaper than getting a divorce.  Tony Thompson reports on a global murder hunt.
fields.body:
A former police officer with a reputation for violence is at the centre of a double-murder mystery, stretching from the clubs of London and Essex to the sleazy sex-and-drugs underworld of Bangkok and Manila.

David Sims, who was kicked out of the Metropolitan Police's controversial Special Patrol Group more than two decades ago - for attacking an inspector during a drunken rage - is now the subject of a massive global manhunt.

His fourth wife, a Filipina by the name of China Rose, has not been seen since February 1993. She vanished shortly after telling her sister, Joy, that her husband was becoming increasingly violent towards her. 'She said he told her he was going to get someone to kill her, because it would be cheaper than getting a divorce,' Joy recalls.

Police are now treating Rose's disappearance as murder. Last week they intensified efforts to track down Sims, 56, after receiving a tip-off that he may be living under a new identity in the Far East. 'Mr Sims could be seen as a suspect,' said Detec tive Constable Fred Simpkins, the officer leading the hunt. 'But they've both officially been missing for years, so we could be talking about a double murder. After seven years a person can be presumed legally dead.'

Sims joined the police in the late Sixties and was a popular, trusted officer. But his personality changed soon after he was appointed to the SPG.

SPG officers are often the first to attend public-order disputes, and have been accused of using excessive force. They were implicated in the death of the London teacher Blair Peach after an anti-National Front demonstration in Southall.

Sims soon began drinking heavily and showing violent tendencies. Three wives divorced him, citing violent temper tantrums.

After leaving the police and failing as a pub landlord, Sims started a second-hand furniture chain. He met and married Rose, 20 years his junior, through an introduction agency during a business trip to the Philippines. The couple were married in February 1988 and returned to the UK.

In 1991 Sims bought a dilapidated house in Southend into which he and his wife moved with their friend Geoffrey Paston and his Filipina girlfriend, Josie. Sims adopted the business name Anthony Peter Lewis and neighbours knew him as Tony.

He spent a year renovating the house, then took Rose to Thailand to buy shop fittings for resale in the UK - a trade that did not go well.

In early 1993 Rose took a part-time job in an old people's home. Soon afterwards she told her sister that she was living in fear of Sims, who had beaten her up on a regular basis. She wanted to leave, but had nowhere to go.

Rose was last seen at a party in February 1993, and the last firm sighting of Sims was alone at their Southend home about a month later.

Although they have yet to find a body, police are convinced that China Rose has been murdered. Despite being devoted to her father, who was very ill when she disappeared and has since died, she has made no attempt to check on his health or to contact her brothers and sisters.

In 1996 officers from Essex police travelled to the home of Geoffrey Paston, who was then living on an island off Manila. Paston said that Sims had, two years earlier, asked him to sell the Southend house and put the proceeds in a new bank account in the name of Anthony Peter Lewis. The money - nearly £40,000 - was collected by a man claiming to represent Sims, who may then have flown to Thailand. Paston - now destitute and living on handouts from his family in the UK - told police that he feared for his life and that 'heavy characters' were involved in the disappearance of both Sims and his wife.

At least £10,000 of the sale proceeds remain in a British bank account in the name of Anthony Peter Lewis. There has been no attempt to access the funds. Police believe this means that Sims is either dead or has found a highly lucrative, alternative source of income - heroin trafficking.

webTitle: Why British women love to say 'I do'

fields.headline: Why British women love to say 'I do'
fields.standfirst: Everybody's doing it:  Report suggests that UK is keener on marriage than the rest of Europe
fields.trailText: Everybody's doing it:  Report suggests that UK is keener on marriage than the rest of Europe.
fields.body:
They are said to be reluctant to forsake the pleasures of single life. But nothing could be further from the truth. British women are much more attached to marriage than their European counterparts. Around 95.1 per cent of British women have married at least once by age 49, the highest figure in the European Union. Only 91.2 per cent of British men have walked up the aisle by the same age.

Meanwhile, the much discussed trend for delaying marriage until later in life - blamed on career women reluctant to have children - may actually reflect a return to the historical norm.

The average age of first marriage in Europe 200 years ago was 28, the same as British brides in 1998, according to a paper for the National Family and Parenting Institute, the independent thinktank set up by Jack Straw to advise on family issues.

'The public conversation about marriage has often been conducted in an atmosphere fraught with anxiety that can easily tip over into what commentators have described as a "moral panic",' the report, comparing European trends in marriage, adds.

'Changes in the marriage rate and in the way people form relationships are part and parcel of a society where change is rapid and individuals feel helpless in the face of new developments. Yet it is vital that these issues can be discussed without blame.'

The paper does not include divorce rates. In 1997 Britain had the highest divorce rate in Europe, although by 1999 the rate had fallen to the level of the late 1980s.

Despite much political consternation about the family, the report suggests British attitudes are more socially conservative than those of many EU counterparts.

Nine out of 10 couples in Britain living with their children are married, compared to half in Finland. And while cohabiting is becoming the norm for European twentysomethings, 'change has happened much more rapidly across the whole of the EU than in the UK', the report finds. Around a third of British under-thirties live with a partner, but it is closer to half in France and 40 per cent in Germany.

'This report is about let's bring a cool head to this debate,' said Gill Keep, head of policy at the institute. 'It is much easier to take the panic out of the discussion if you look at it in a comparative way. Things that you think are destroying your own society are actually common trends and they may not be that destructive.'

She said that despite anxiety over later marriages - the average age of first-time brides rose from 23 in the postwar period to 28 for women and 30 for men by 1999 - historically this would have seemed normal.

Social historian Christina Hardyment said that in the nineteenth century couples would not marry until they could afford to support a household. 'Women below the middle classes would always work in some capacity, mainly in domestic service, and it made sense to save. People think of kings and queens and nobility being married off at 12 but that was highly unusual,' she said.

The institute's report found the Government lagged behind many EU counterparts in spending on families - just over 8.7 per cent of its total welfare spending went on family and child benefits in 2000, putting it joint tenth out of 15 countries, although since then new tax credits have been introduced.

It is also behind on civil registration for unmarried couples, and on some allowances for family life. Six countries even offer paid leave for getting married, of between a day and two weeks.

fields.headline: Epidemic fear as TB spreads
fields.trailText: Dozens of cases of tuberculosis are being missed by doctors who lack experience in diagnosing the disease.
fields.body:
Dozens of cases of tuberculosis are being missed by doctors who lack experience in diagnosing the disease.

Experts, who fear Britain may be on the verge of a TB epidemic, last week called for the number of lung specialists to be doubled. They say control of the disease is being hampered by incorrect diagnosis and long waiting times for proper treatment.

Dr John Moore-Gillon, a TB specialist in London, said: 'The longest delays in TB diagnosis happen in areas where there is a low instance of TB. It takes a while for the penny to drop.

'There has been a nationwide increase in cases of TB of 11 per cent. In London it's as high as 20 per cent. Areas that were once seeing intermediate amounts of TB are now seeing a lot more.'

A recent report from the British Thoracic Society revealed that only six of the 43 areas worst affected by TB in the UK had adequate staffing levels, and that this directly affected control and diagnosis of the disease.

Doctors who are not familiar with the disease are having to deal with it more often, it said.

A study by TB specialists in east London, published by the BTS last year, concluded that stricter monitoring of TB cases should be implemented as 'undernotification [of authorities that patients have the disease] has been shown to be a significant problem'.

Misdiagnosis can have tragic consequences, allowing infected people to spread TB, and the disease to cause irreversible damage.

Last week Britain grew closer to a full-scale TB epidemic when it emerged that eight pupils at Duffryn High School in Newport, Gwent, had contracted the disease. The entire school population of 1,100 is to be screened.

Under 100 miles away, all 1,300 patients admitted to part of Cheltenham General Hospital, Gloucestershire, during the past year are to be screened after a nurse there was diagnosed with TB.

In Leicestershire, where 2,000 pupils are to be screened following an outbreak of TB last month, health authorities have struggled to contain the problem. Forty-nine people have been diagnosed as suffering from full-blown tuberculosis.

Due to a shortage of TB vaccines, the vaccination programme was suspended in schools in England and Wales 18 months ago. It will not be back on track until 2003.

fields.headline: Joy for kidnap man's family
fields.standfirst: Brother speaks of his relief at the news that Scottish oil worker has been seen alive
fields.trailText: The family of a Scottish oil worker held by Colombian kidnappers for nearly two years spoke yesterday of their delight at discovering he is alive.
fields.body:
The family of a Scottish oil worker held by Colombian kidnappers for nearly two years spoke yesterday of their delight at discovering he is alive. Alistair Taylor, 47, is thought to have been abducted by National Liberation Army (ELN) guerrillas on 27 August 1999.

He was working for Weatherford, an oil company based in Houston, Texas, and had been in Colombia since 1995. His brother, Charles, told The Observer yesterday: 'We were delighted to get the news.' A freelance journalist met Mr Taylor, originally from Inverurie, near Aberdeen, at his captors' jungle campsite and said he was well. Charles Taylor said the family did not wish want to discuss the matter in detail until they knew more about the encounter.

Last year their hopes were raised when a newspaper suggested that a Red Cross worker had seen the oil worker and said he was in 'fine health'. The Taylors now believe there was little substance to the claim.

Yesterday a Foreign Office spokesman said: 'We can confirm that a UK freelance journalist has had access to Alistair Taylor and we understand that he found him to be alive and well.'

The spokesman added that the journalist, who was not identified, had not discussed his plans before going to Colombia, or 'we would have advised him of the tremendous risks involved'.

He did not know how the reporter had gained access to Mr Taylor but added: 'We hope to have more details in due course. We have been closely involved and continue to raise Mr Taylor's case at every opportunity with the Colombian government.'

Weatherford has been in contact with the kidnappers and it is understood that a $5 million (£3.5m) ransom is being sought for the release of the oil worker, who was Weatherford's base manager in Yopal. Soon after Mr Taylor was kidnapped, a company spokesman refused to discuss his position with the firm, saying: 'We do not wish to offer any kind of encouragement to the kidnappers.'

False reports of Mr Taylor being an employee of BP Amoco may have led his captors to expect a large payout.

On Thursday, the ELN released 34 hostages from a group of about 100 it kidnapped earlier in the week. They were all Colombian employees of Los Angeles-based Occidental Petroleum. They were seized on Monday in Aracua by guerrillas posing as police officers but turned over to the Red Cross. It is not known whether any ransom was paid.

Colombia's second-largest rebel group, the ELN emerged in the mid-1960s. Founded by intellectuals and students who had studied in Cuba and were influenced by Che Guevara, the group posed a major threat to Colombia's government. In the 1970s, anti-guerrilla offensives reduced the ELN to several hundred combatants but it continued, funding actions through kidnappings and bank robberies.

The ELN's longtime leader, Spanish priest Manuel Perez, died three years ago and its principal role in Colombia's power struggle now seems to be harassing and blackmailing the nation's petroleum and energy industries. In April 1999, the ELN hijacked a domestic Avianca airliner over north-eastern Colombia, forced the plane to land in a remote area, and kidnapped the 46 people on board. One month later ELN fighters raided a church service in Cali and kidnapped more than 100 people. Most of the hostages were released in the weeks following each incident, but as of last July four people from the airliner remained captive.

Colombia is the kidnap capital of the world. Last December two British rare orchid hunters who had been given up for dead were released after being held captive for nine months in the Colombian jungle. In 1999, the year of Mr Taylor's abduction, 2,787 people were kidnapped in the country. Last year more than 3,000 were taken. The ELN is thought to be responsible for around a quarter of these.

webTitle: Modern threat to an ancient game

fields.headline: Modern threat to an ancient game
fields.standfirst: Orkney islanders angry as insurance fears  may end the traditional battle of the Ba
fields.trailText: Orkney islanders angry as insurance fears  may end the traditional battle of the Ba.
fields.body:
As Gary Gibson looks out over the streets that form the pitch for one of the world's oldest remaining ball games, he is a worried man. The sport he loves is an endangered species. Gibson, 66, is a veteran of the Ba, a game peculiar to the Orkney Islands which involves two teams of hundreds of players battling to shift a rock-hard leather ball across Kirkwall. There are no rules.

But fears over liability for personal injury and property damage mean this ancestor of football and rugby may have been played for the final time.

Until now the islands' council has covered the cost of damage to property incurred as a result of the event, played each Christmas Day and New Year's Day. But on Tuesday councillors will vote on whether to cease all involvement in a game steeped in history and legend.

Mr Gibson told The Observer: 'I'm disgusted. There is no doubt that this is a threat to the game if they insist on withdrawing their support.' The Ba's roots are embedded in ancient midwinter sporting celebrations. Similar mass football games were played across Britain for centuries.

Numerous legends surround the Ba's beginnings. The best-known claims it stemmed from the defeat of a mainland tyrant, Tusker, so called because of his protruding canine teeth. A young Orcadian rowed across the Pentland Firth and travelled south on horseback until he met and defeated Tusker.

The boy severed Tusker's head and was taking it back to Orkney tied to his saddle when a tusk punctured his leg. The wound became infected and the boy died, but not before staggering to Kirkwall's Mercat Cross and throwing the head into a crowd of townsfolk, who were so outraged that they kicked it through the streets in anger. A sport was born.

Now the townsfolk's rage is aimed at Orkney Islands Council, which in the past has paid for barricades to protect private and commercial property during the game. David Robertson, the council's director of finance and housing, said insurers would not entertain the idea of allowing claims arising from the Ba.

'The council's involvement has been limited to ex-gratia payments in the event of damage being done to property. The worry is that there could be implied liability on the council,' he said. There is also concern that anyone injured could claim against the council.

'The Ba is like a big rugby game without rules or restrictions on numbers,' added Mr Robertson. 'While we do not believe that the council would be liable for personal injuries sustained during the Ba, we realise that times have changed and that there has been an Americanisation, if you like, of the way people view liability.'

Mr Gibson, who is on the committee responsible for making the Ba, remains unconvinced. He maintains that there are few bad injuries because players wear strong boots and clothing to protect them as they scrape against the walls of the town.

'Most of the injuries come from that and are just cuts and bruises. You get the occasional broken bone, but not frequently. Maybe the odd rib or even ankle is broken.

'The players are all friends, they're not going to really injure one another. OK, you get the odd burst of temper and the odd clout, but they'll be round each other's houses as pals the next day.'

He blames 'outsiders' who fail to appreciate the depth of feeling in Kirkwall for the traditions of the Ba. 'This is about people in officialdom getting weak-kneed. They are scared of getting sued. Nobody playing the game would sue. Everyone is well warned of the dangers.'

The idea of the game, which is open to anyone foolhardy enough to want to take part, is that men are either 'Uppies' or 'Doonies', depending on family loyalty or which end of the town they first entered by. Uppies must touch the Ba against a wall in the south end of the town whereas Doonies must get the Ba into the water of the harbour to the north.

A typical game can last for hours, with a heaving throng of players pushing and pulling to try to gain a few yards. When the crowd breaks, the man with the Ba will try to get as close to the goal as possible before being stopped. Numerous tactics are used. Players have been known to smuggle the Ba through winding lanes and even to attempt to reach their goal via the rooftops. Spectators travel from around the world to watch.

Robert Leslie, of the Orcadian newspaper, said: 'People are really worried about this.

'Every year we bring out a supplement, in conjunction with the committee, which charts the history of the game. It includes a safety warning, but that's mainly for spectators.

'The players tend to know how to look after themselves, but spectators might be inclined to climb on to a wall. They probably cause more damage than players.'

Even then, the costs are minimal - just £1,494 between 1996 and 2000.

Mr Gibson, an Uppie whose two sons take part, warns: 'In the nineteenth century the Ba encountered establishment opposition. Sheriffs were alarmed at this riot in the streets and tried to stop it, yet the game went on.'

Sheriffs were alarmed at this riot in the streets and tried to stop it, yet the game went on.'

fields.headline: Drugs dealer shot in Derry
fields.trailText: A murdered drugs dealer was trying to escape from his killers when they shot him four times in the stomach, it was confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
A murdered drugs dealer was trying to escape from his killers when they shot him four times in the stomach, it was confirmed yesterday.

Christopher O'Kane died in hospital after he was ambushed only 30 yards from his home on the nationalist Currynieran estate in Derry. It is believed three to four men lay in wait in a parked car as he returned from a night out. One of the gunmen is believed to have used a long-barrelled weapon.

Sources in the area say Mr O'Kane was a major player in the drugs trade. Police confirmed that this was one line of inquiry. The Provisional IRA is being linked by local sources to the killing, although RUC Inspector Nicky Thompson said it was too early to speculate.

The IRA, using the cover name Direct Action Against Drugs, has been involved in the murder of a number of drug dealers and is believed to have carried out an earlier attempt on Mr O'Kane's life.

Inspector Thompson has appealed for help from anyone who saw a four-door car speeding away from the scene. The police, who recovered six spent bullet cases, confirmed that Mr O'Kane had a criminal record, but not for drugs offences.

The murder was condemned by Democratic Unionist Assemblyman William Hay. who lives in the Waterside area. 'Nobody has the right to decide who should live or die,' he said.

The murder was also condemned by the Social Democratic and Labour Party Assembly member, Annie Courtney.

webTitle: M&S chief's bonus to be axed

fields.headline: M&S chief's bonus to be axed
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer intends to block a bonus payment of £810,000 to its controversial chairman, Luc Vandevelde, prompting speculation that the Belgian might quit the troubled stores group.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer intends to block a bonus payment of £810,000 to its controversial chairman, Luc Vandevelde, prompting speculation that the Belgian might quit the troubled stores group.

M&S directors have been embarrassed by the public outcry over the bonus, to which Vandevelde claimed he was entitled despite a disastrous commercial performance from M&S, once the British high street's flagship.

His fate will be decided by a meeting of the M&S remuneration committee, headed by former MI5 chief Dame Stella Rimington, early next month. One source close to the board said yesterday: 'The chances that he will get this bonus are zero.'

But the decision to block the bonus payment does not mean that Vandevelde, 48, is down to his last few pounds. He has been paid his annual salary of £650,000, a £2 million 'golden hello' in shares, and stock options exceeding another £10m.

Directors will ask Vandevelde to voluntarily waive the bonus element of his pay, but insiders believe the chairman will refuse, preferring instead to quit the company and seek a bigger payout in the form of compensation, claiming breach of contract.

In his year in charge Vandevelde has seen profits and shares continue to fall. Last month he announced 4,000 job cuts and a complete withdrawal from continental Europe, where M&S had expanded rapidly.

M&S still faces legal action in the French and European courts for alleged breaches of employment law when it announced the sacking of workers on the continent, which prompted nationwide demonstrations in France.

His insistence that he should still be paid the bonus, has enraged M&S middle-management, who have seen their own bonuses scrapped.

fields.headline: Why we're all getting brighter
fields.trailText: Dumbing down? Don't believe it. Scientists have proved we are smarter now than ever before, largely because we watch TV, surf the net, and spend hours chatting to friends.
fields.body:
Dumbing down? Don't believe it. Scientists have proved we are smarter now than ever before, largely because we watch TV, surf the net, and spend hours chatting to friends.

Analyses of IQ tests show that people are getting rapidly more intelligent, or at least getting higher scores. Average scores have risen by 27 points in the UK since 1942 and 24 points in the US since 1918, with comparable gains across the world. This so-called 'Flynn effect', first discovered in 1987, has until now baffled psychologists. However, a study in the Psychological Review of the American Psychological Association claims that a more stimulating environment and genetic inheritance interact in a virtuous circle to make people far smarter. The authors, Bill Dickens and James Flynn (who first discovered the effect), reckon the rise is partly caused by improved education.

But more important is a stimulating environment, which makes people think more, prompting them to choose yet more stimulation. The smarter you are, the more likely you are to enjoy books, puzzles and challenging jobs. That in turn gets your brain working more and you choose even higher levels of stimulation in a virtuous circle of intelligence. 'Higher IQ leads one to better environments, causing still higher IQ,' said the report.

Fewer people are doing repetitive manual work and the average person's job is far more complex. Even people in less skilled jobs use computers. Increased leisure time could also mean people are honing their intelligence by reading, playing games or solving puzzles, and TV and the internet bombard us with information.

Machines such as cars, phones and video-recorders that make you use your brain, while conveniences such as washing machines and dishwashers take out the drudgery that pre-occupied earlier generations. Smaller families may also have helped, with fewer children having more parental time to cater to their natural curiosity.

How smart are you?

Answer true or false to these IQ test questions in under 90 seconds.

1. It is possible to use three colours to paint the sides of a cube in such a way that two sides of the same colour never touch.

2. A bagel-shaped house has three outside doors and three doors to an inner courtyard. It is possible to go through all doors once only and end up at the same place.

3. The following argument is valid: All humans are mortal. Socrates is human. Therefore Socrates is mortal.

4. Gina is faster than Jane, and Jo is slower than Gina. So Jo is faster than Jane.

5. Some ladies sit with their cats. There are 22 heads and 72 feet in total in the room. This means that there are 7 ladies and 15 cats.

Scroll down for answers
Answers to test: 1.T; 2.F; 3.T; 4.F; 5.F. Four correct is a good score.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: REM guitarist arrested after 'air rage assault' aboard London-bound jet
fields.body:
REM guitarist arrested after 'air rage assault' aboard London-bound jet

A guitarist in the rock band, REM, was arrested at Heathrow airport following an alleged 'air rage" incident. Peter Buck was met by police and he was questioned after an alleged assault of two members of the cabin crew - a man and a woman - on a British Airways flight from Seattle.

An airport insider said the millionaire, who was travelling first class, became abusive soon after the plane took off, and his behaviour deteriorated during the flight. Eventually the captain radioed ahead to ask police to meet the plane when it landed. None of the cabin crew or passengers was injured.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said: 'Police were requested to meet a flight from Seattle at Heathrow Airport at 9.50am following reports that a male passenger had assaulted members of the cabin crew. The man was arrested in connection with assault and is in custody at Heathrow police station.'

Two die in street gun drama

A driver and his passenger were killed as they tried to flee a gunman who blasted their sports car, and then crashed into pedestrians, a car and a bus. The men were shot at while travelling in a blue BMW convertible in Clapton, east London, and then careered into three women pedestrians early yesterday. The car continued and eventually smashed into a bus.

Police officers found the driver and his passenger dead in the car. Detectives are investigating the possibility that the passenger was killed by the gunfire before the collision occurred.

The three pedestrians were taken to hospital and two of them were later discharged. The third has been detained, but her condition is not life threatening.

Detective Superintendent John Sweeney, from Operation Trident, which is aimed at tackling gun crime in the city, said it was too early to decide whether the crime was drug-related. He added: 'The inquiry is at the very early stages. We are appealing for information. Any crime involving two young black men on the streets of London is a tragic crime which we are determined to solve.'

He believed that there would be people who might have seen something at that time, including people leaving night clubs. The police refused to disclose further details about the pedestrians or the dead men.

Fowler drops assault claim

Soccer star Robbie Fowler, above, has dropped an allegation of assault after an incident in a Liverpool city centre bar in January. It was claimed to have been prompted by a man taking a photograph of him. A bouncer was arrested but police later established that he had no connection with the incident.

No-hair Noel

TV presenter Noel Edmonds is having his beard shaved off, for the first time in 30 years, on GMTV's breakfast show on Friday to raise money for farmers.

Hygiene alert

More than 100 people were evacuated from a hotel in York after a male guest's 'over- exuberant' use of a deodorant set off smoke detectors.

Loyal smugglers

A family of four jailed at Plymouth for seven years for smuggling tobacco made so many trips to France they earned loyalty cards.

Barton honour

Director John Barton, stalwart of the RSC, has won the Shakespeare Birthday Award.

Paedophile arrests

Two Britons arrested last week in Prague are suspected of having close links with an international paedophile ring. They were detained as part of a massive operation by British and Czech authorities, police sources said.

Man held over killing attempt

A man accused of trying to kill his former wife by dousing her in a flammable liquid and setting her alight was remanded in custody at Ipswich. Terence Abbot, 52, was charged with the attempted murder of Lorraine Baldwin, 42, on Thursday.

Lottery numbers

The winning numbers in last night's National Lottery draw were 12 20 23 26 33 46, bonus 1. Thunderball numbers were 16 17 30 31 34, Thunderball 7. Lottery Extra numbers were 4 11 18 19 31 42.

webTitle: Cricket stress drives players to suicide

fields.headline: Cricket stress drives players to suicide
fields.trailText: English cricketers are almost twice as likely to commit suicide as the average male and have a suicide rate higher than players of any other sport, according to an international study.
fields.body:
English cricketers are almost twice as likely to commit suicide as the average male and have a suicide rate higher than players of any other sport, according to an international study.

Sussex and Somerset, counties whose sweeping grounds have spawned scores of great players including Ted Dexter and current Test bowler Andy Caddick, have the highest suicide rates in the country, according to David Frith, author of Silence of the Heart , an investigation into the phenomenon.

The findings have disturbed Britain's cricketing world and pose the question of whether cricket attracts vulnerable people or whether the game has a unique capacity to destabilise its players.

'Cricket has this dreadful, hidden burden,' said Frith, one of Britain's best-known cricket writers and a former editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly . 'It must now answer the very serious question of whether it gradually transforms unwary cricket-loving boys into brooding, insecure and ultimately self-destructive men.'

The suicide rate among British men is 1.07 per cent, but according to Frith's research, the rate among cricketers here is 1.77 per cent - making them 75 per cent more likely to take their own life.

But the game's toll overseas is even higher. In South Africa 4.12 per cent of players take their own lives. In New Zealand the rate is 3.92 per cent and in Australia 2.75 per cent.

'There is a relative consolation from knowing that Britain's rate is below that of other countries but the worry is that in general, cricket's casualty rate is way above the general average,' said Frith.

Frith believes that, instead of susceptible people being attracted to the game, cricket puts a strain on nerves that can be as destructive as the post-traumatic stress disorder suffered by war veterans.

'It is the uncertainty, day in and day out, that plays a sinister beat on the cricketer's soul,' he said.

'Golfers, footballers, tennis players and boxers all have an assurance that they have a chance to recover from early defeat in the game but cricket embodies uncertainty on the grand scale and on a relentless daily basis.

'The nature of cricket is such that it tears at the nerves. Half-hearted cricketers are extremely rare. This game gets a grip on people such as only religious fanatics might recognise.

'There is a compulsive nature to the game and an inherent uncertainty which could damage the soul.'

The majority of the suicides over the past 30 years took place in the Eighties and Nineties, with the fewest in the Sixties, and were of players aged between 40 and 49 who had been forced into retirement.

Famous cricket suicides include A.E. Stoddart, the most glamorous cricketer of the 1880s and captain of England from 1894, who shot himself in 1915 after his career ended; Albert Shrewsbury, the finest professional batsman of his day; and William Scotton.

Stoddart and Shrewsbury walked out to open the batting for England on 17 July 1893, passing another suicide-to-be, Australia's Billy Bruce, days after the funeral of Scotton, who had killed himself at his home near Lord's.

David Bairstow, the burly, life-loving Yorkshire captain, killed himself in 1998 aged 46, joining sporting heroes Sid Barnes and Jack Iverson. Hansie Cronje, the shamed South African captain, has said he came close to committing suicide after the match-fixing scandal broke.

Frith believes the recent increase in recorded suicides could be the result of a waning in the stigma surrounding the act and a new willingness to identify it as cause of death.

'Logic insists that there must be many other suicides still unrevealed,' he said. 'And many that will always remain so.'

The solution, he believes, is for former players to stay connected with the game through broadcasting, umpiring or coaching, after they have retired.

Mike Brearley, the former England captain, is not sure cricket is to blame for the heavy toll it takes on the lives of its players.

'The uncertainty of cricket is not always glorious or exciting; it can be disillusioning and anxiety-creating,' he said. 'And then, after their career is over, many ex-cricketers feel they have been lured into prostituting their name to fit in with the starstruck desires of others.

'These men lose their authenticity and that humiliation, which contrasts dramatically with the excitement and successes that went before, can be terrible.

'But it is not cricket which causes suicide: people kill themselves for reasons that are internal to themselves and their histories.'

fields.headline: Two more die on 'murder mile'
fields.standfirst: Many have witnessed gangland-style savagery in the London borough of Hackney, yet few will admit it, writes crime correspondent  Tony Thompson
fields.trailText: Many have witnessed gangland-style savagery in the London borough of Hackney, yet few will admit it, writes crime correspondent Tony Thompson.
fields.body:
The shots rang out just after 5am yesterday in London's Lower Clapton Road, punching fist-sized holes into the side of the BMW and hitting both passenger and driver. The car slewed on an angle, ploughing into three pedestrians, smashing a Nissan Micra and finally coming to rest against the side of a night bus.

The Hackney police arrived minutes later to find a 250-metre trail of smashed glass, twisted metal and broken bodies - a scene more reminiscent of Beirut or the Bronx than London.

But when local people woke up to the horrific scene, they simply went about their business. Some people even brought out their children to look at the police cordons.

In the past two years there have been at least six gangland-style executions in streets surrounding Lower and Upper Clapton Roads. There have been many other woundings and countless occasions on which weapons have been produced and fired.

The London borough of Hackney now has the distinction of being the place where you are more likely to hear the sound of gunshots that anywhere else in Britain. Many of the Clapton Road shootings have stood out because of the levels of ruthlessness and brutality involved. Gunmen have pursued their victims in broad daylight, finishing them off at point blank range in front of streets packed with witnesses.

'The bodies were still in the car up until midday,' said one shopkeeper who asked not to be named. 'No one wants the shootings to continue, we would all like to see an end to it. But at the same time, no one is going to say anything. It is all too easy to understand what these people are capable of. No one is going to risk crossing them.'

Hackney Borough Commander Chief Superintendent Peter Robbins told The Observer: 'I fully accept that there are more shots discharged in the area possibly than anywhere else in Britain.'

The area has been synonymous with drug-related crime ever since the term Yardie came into common usage in the late Eighties. The first mass police raid on a crack den took place in nearby Dalston, where Errol 'Rankin' Dread, once dubbed the most dangerous man in Britain and the number one Yardie Godfather, made his home.

Philip Ettienne, a former undercover officer with the Metropolitan Police who documented his experiences of infiltrating Yardie gangs in his book The Infiltrators, said last night: 'It has always been a terrible area. The official number of shooting incidents is high but the reality is higher - a huge number of gun-related incidents go completely unreported. If you look at the call-out records for the ARVs [armed response vehicles], you'll find they go to Hackney more than anywhere else. In fact, if they are at a loose end, they always hang around there because they know that sooner or later, the call will come.'

The shootings started in January 1997 when Guy-Dance Dacres, a 16-year-old black student, was shot dead at a private party at Chimes nightclub, one of the area's most popular venues and the scene of many of the bloodiest encounters.

On 21 August 1999, a 38-year-old black man was shot in nearby Powell Road minutes after leaving Chimes. Four men were seen frantically fleeing from another who was giving chase and firing.

On 16 December last year, Anthony Rose-Windon, 25, was gunned down outside Chimes. Police say he then crawled to Kenning Hall Road, a few hundred yards away, where he was found dead from multiple gunshot wounds to the chest.

In the past two years, the number of incidents appears to have accelerated and moved beyond the black community. On 27 March 2000, a man tried to use a stolen credit card at a Shell petrol station on Lower Clapton road. When staff refused to return it to him, he left, only to return moments later with a handgun. The staff were saved only by the bulletproof glass that deflected his frenzied shots.

On 25 May 2000, Memet Adiguzel, 37, a Turk, was shot six times as he sat in his car on the junction of Upper Clapton Road and Lea Bridge Road. It was 4.45pm, but broad daylight and a host of witnesses did not deter the killers. Several men were arrested for the incident, which is believed to be drug-related. One of them has skipped bail.

On 20 June, a bejewelled man was loitering outside a West Indian Cafe called Too Sweet, a short walk from Lower Clapton Road on nearby Chatsworth Road. A man in an Afro wig walked up and shot him several times. The victim survived.

Five days later, Meneliek Robinson was driving his red BMW convertible along Upper Clapton Road, when two motorbikes, each carrying two black men, drove up behind him. One overtook him and pulled up, screeching to a halt and blocking his way. The other rode up from behind and stopped alongside.

Its passenger dismounted, and walked up to Robinson's side window. He fired several shots, and then the two bikes sped away. Robinson staggered from the car and collapsed on the street. He died of massive blood loss.

The next week, John Nugent, 46, died from another brutal street attack. At 11pm, on the corner of Erswick Street and Lower Clapton Road, he was attacked by a gang of men, beaten unconscious, and then pushed under a bus. He was pronounced dead on arrival at Homerton Hospital.

fields.bodyText: The shots rang out just after 5am yesterday in London's Lower Clapton Road, punching fist-sized holes into the side of the BMW and hitting both passenger and driver. The car slewed on an angle, ploughing into three pedestrians, smashing a Nissan Micra and finally coming to rest against the side of a night bus. The Hackney police arrived minutes later to find a 250-metre trail of smashed glass, twisted metal and broken bodies - a scene more reminiscent of Beirut or the Bronx than London. But when local people woke up to the horrific scene, they simply went about their business. Some people even brought out their children to look at the police cordons. In the past two years there have been at least six gangland-style executions in streets surrounding Lower and Upper Clapton Roads. There have been many other woundings and countless occasions on which weapons have been produced and fired. The London borough of Hackney now has the distinction of being the place where you are more likely to hear the sound of gunshots that anywhere else in Britain. Many of the Clapton Road shootings have stood out because of the levels of ruthlessness and brutality involved. Gunmen have pursued their victims in broad daylight, finishing them off at point blank range in front of streets packed with witnesses. fields.headline: REM star held at Heathrow
fields.trailText: A guitarist in the rock band REM was arrested yesterday after an alleged air rage incident and complaints that he assaulted two flight attendants on a British Airways jet flying the Atlantic.
fields.body:
A guitarist in the rock band REM was arrested yesterday after an alleged air rage incident and complaints that he assaulted two flight attendants on a British Airways jet flying the Atlantic.

Sources at Heathrow airport said Peter Buck was drinking in the first-class section soon after the flight took off from Seattle for London, and quickly became verbally abusive towards staff.

As the flight progressed his behaviour got worse and two flight attendants, who had refused to serve him more drinks, became involved in a 'push and shove' with Buck. The guitarist 'became angry and threw yoghurt' over one steward, one source said.

The captain of the flight, radioed Heathrow to request police to meet the plane.

Buck was arrested when it landed yesterday morning, and he was being held by police. 'We are still questioning him. He could be charged, he could be released or he could be bailed to return for further questions,' said a spokesman for Scotland Yard.

British Airways said its staff were being questioned about the alleged assaults 'We treat all cases of air rage extremely seriously. We do not tolerate it from anyone,' a spokesman said. No one was injured.

REM are due to play at the South Africa Freedom Day concert in London next Sunday in front of former President Nelson Mandela

Buck, who is more than 6ft tall, is seen as the most media-shy band member. He once told an interviewer: 'I'd be very happy if I didn't have to have my picture taken again or be in a video.'

REM, whose hits include 'Losing My Religion' and 'Orange Crush', began in the early Eighties when Buck, then a record store clerk, met student record collector Michael Stipe, who became the lead singer.

fields.headline: Ipswich Wright on
fields.trailText: There is something very wrong at Ipswich. 'There's only one David Sheepshanks,' sang Portman Road. Fans chanting a eulogy to the chairman? It's just not normal.
fields.body:
There is something very wrong at Ipswich. 'There's only one David Sheepshanks,' sang Portman Road. Fans chanting a eulogy to the chairman? It's just not normal.

But then, neither is this season Ipswich Town are having. Yesterday, goals by Martin Reuser and the excellent Jermaine Wright were scant reward for their dominance over a Coventry City side who had been on something of a roll but now look destined for relegation. At the other end, it will be something of a shock if Ipswich, in their first season back in the Premiership, do not now make the Champions League.

Going through the fixtures when they were published last summer, if you looked at Ipswich's kindly last five matches you would have concluded that they would at least have a good chance of saving themselves, with games against potential fellow relegation strugglers in Middlesbrough, Coventry, Charlton, Manchester City and Derby County.

Instead, they will have a significant say in who does go down, they themselves long since safe in riposte to those who expected them to struggle, and - more importantly from their point of view - they now have an astonishing opportunity to grab a Champions League place.

Coventry are one such scrapping for survival - yet again - and came to Portman Road with a splendid recent record. A bank holiday Monday win over Sunderland was amends for a defeat, a plucky one at that, at Manchester United to make it three wins from four games. Ipswich, though, were in excellent order themselves, with four wins from five.

It showed in their approach. With Matt Holland providing the drive and Jim Magilton the subtlety, Ipswich soon wrested control of central midfield. In addition, Jermaine Wright and Martin Reuser were finding space on the flanks and there was a snap to Ipswich's game, a sharpness in the tackle and a slickness to their passing, that made Coventry look ponderous and a shadow of the side of last weekend.

Ipswich served notice of intent when Marcus Stewart supplied Wright with a cross which Holland met with a header, Chris Kirkland grabbing it gratefully. The goalkeeper was beaten soon after, by Alun Armstrong's guided volley from Chris Makin's driven cross, and was relieved to see it fly just wide of his right post.

Then Kirkland was beaten again and this time it counted. In another incisive move, Armstrong found Wright and although Holland missed his low cross, Reuser arrived at the far post, beyond John Eustace, and steered the ball home gleefully.

Little was seen of Coventry as an attacking force, so much were they pinned back. It scarcely mattered to Ipswich, who came close to a second when Kirkland dived to save Wright's low drive, that Richard Wright had injured his back in the pre-match warm-up, giving Keith Branagan a start in goal instead. The huge oversight for Coventry was that they were not getting the ball to John Hartson in any dangerous areas.

It was clearly something Gordon Strachan seized upon at the interval as Coventry came out with new intent for the second half, Hartson at the hub of their work. First he headed on Kirkland's long clearance for Eustace to send in a cross shot, which Branagan had to be sharp to turn away. Then, after Eustace had broken out with the ball, Hartson ferried a pass on to Craig Bellamy, who outstripped Makin before clip ping what was Coventry's best chance just wide.

Their mini-revival was halted in its tracks, however, by sloppy defensive work - and how familiar that has been for them. Gary Breen looked to have tidied up after Kirkland's kick had only half-cleared the lines but he sent his clearance straight to Wright, who sent back a powerful shot from 25 yards that flew past Kirkland off the torso of Breen, who was trying to take evasive action when he might have been better off getting himself in the way of the ball.

Coventry never looked like retrieving the deficit thereafter; Ipswich always looked like increasing it. Holland drove just over and Jamie Clapham, with Kirkland out of his goal, curled a shot inches wide. It is now a compliment to Ipswich to say that this was a routine win for them.
