fields.headline: Ward's a winner
fields.trailText: Brave Bradford postponed the inevitable thanks to an Ashley Ward double. Ward swept home after just 16 minutes and then managed the final touch on a Eoin Jess shot just three minutes from time to ensure that the Bantams live to fight another day. Granted, they won't avoid relegation, but at least they will go down fighting.
fields.body:
Brave Bradford postponed the inevitable thanks to an Ashley Ward double. Ward swept home after just 16 minutes and then managed the final touch on a Eoin Jess shot just three minutes from time to ensure that the Bantams live to fight another day. Granted, they won't avoid relegation, but at least they will go down fighting.

Instead it was Derby who were left staring at a tentative end to the season. Jim Smith's out-of-sorts side had Seth Johnson sent off for a crude 57th minute challenge on Stuart McCall and found the going tough at Valley Parade.

Derby looked a pale shadow of themselves during a first half in which Benito Carbone was outstanding for the Bantams. The Italian was pivotal to everything that was good about battling Bradford. His touch was often sublime and County, looking brittle at the back, struggled to cope.

Strangely enough, Carbone did not have a hand in Bradford's goal on 16 minutes.

Veteran midfielder Stuart McCall set things rolling with a clever delivery into the feet of fast-raiding Jess. The former Scottish international then did exactly the right thing by pulling the ball back across the face of goal and Ward applied the killer touch at the near post.

Robbie Blake twice blazed way over the top as Bradford assumed total control. And it was the crafty Carbone who was pulling the strings.

Following one of the Italian's superlative twists and turns, Blake headed straight into the arms of waiting keeper, Mart Poom. From another of his teasing crosses, Andy Myers did exactly the same.

However, Bradford have not found themselves being cast adrift by playing the beautiful game. And, on occasion, they did tend to revert to type.

They breathed a huge sigh of relief therefore when the unmarked Seth Johnson somehow screwed his shot wide of Gary Walsh's far post just on the stroke of half-time.

Derby also almost forced their way back into it on 56 minutes when Horatio Carbonari's free-kick was fumbled by Walsh. But the keeper then recovered magnificently to deny Rory Delap as the defender pounced on the rebound.

Things went from bad to worse for County when Johnson was sent off for an horrendous challenge on McCall.

Ward made it two with three minutes to go. Carbone crossed from the right, Carbonari headed out towards the edge of the area and when Jess hammered a low drive back in, Ward managed the final, vital touch.

fields.headline: Howey's late lifeline
fields.trailText: Never mind stand up for the champions, how about the champions standing up?
fields.body:
Never mind stand up for the champions, how about the champions standing up?

This week's treat for lunchtime television viewers was the most insipid Manchester derby in recent memory, Roy Keane's horrendous late foul on Alfie Haaland notwithstanding.

Before that X-certificate moment, the cameras had actually managed to miss the most exciting bit, when a fan earned £5,000 and the biggest cheer of the afternoon by scoring from the half-way line during the interval.

It was only to be expected that going out of the Champions League in midweek would take some of the gloss off Manchester United's third consecutive title, but to find their opponents in such half-hearted mood on Old Trafford's first opportunity to celebrate the championship was more than Manchester City supporters had dared hope.

Only a couple of weeks ago the scenario where United were crowned champions and City relegated on the same day had been a real possibility, so for the significant proportion of City fans for whom hatred of United is as great a motivating factor as affection for their own club, arriving at the self-styled Theatre of Dreams on a day when you could hear the prawn sandwiches being munched was almost as welcome as earning a point. 'It's just like being in church,' the visiting fans chorused during the most forgettable of first halves.

For the record, City could have been two goals up inside the first 10 minutes, as Sir Alex Ferguson acknowledged. Wes Brown deflected a Gerard Wiekens shot on to his own bar in the fifth minute, then four minutes later a Phil Neville mistake let in Paulo Wanchope for a perfect shooting opportunity, except the Costa Rican opted to try and make sure by walking the ball around Fabien Barthez. He saw his effort from a narrow angle cleared off the line by Jaap Stam.

United let the first half pass them by, apart from an Ole Gunnar Solskjaer effort in the 44th minute that brought a sharp save from Carlo Nash, and were equally unimpressive in the second until a hesitant defender's run into the opposition penalty box by Brown was stopped by a clumsy, attacker's challenge from Paul Dickov.

This at least allayed suspicions that the teams had agreed on a draw, although when Paul Scholes rolled the spot kick wide the case for a steward's inquiry was on again, or would have been had not City generously coughed up a second penalty 10 minutes layer. This time it was the habitually clumsy Richard Dunne, accidentally catching Solskjaer's heel, and though Barthez ran upfield offering his services United refused to let an important Premiership fixture for the relegation end of the table degenerate into a testimonial-type farce.

The new footballer of the year took the penalty instead, Teddy Sheringham scoring his 21st goal of the season despite Nash's brave attempt to save.

The usual script involves United scoring two or three more before the final whistle to make a pedestrian victory look impressive in the record books, but they took their eye off the ball seven minutes from the end when David Beckham unintentionally glanced on Dickov's corner to allow Steve Howey to sweep in at the far post. 'A draw was fair,' Joe Royle said. 'We haven't had many breaks this season, and I thought when the first penalty was missed it might be our day, but when the second one went in we did well to come back.'

Ferguson was far less pleased with his own team's efforts. 'Sloppiness cost us, we were careless in our passing and finishing,' he said. 'Maybe it was a reaction from Wednesday, but we were lethargic most of the time.'

A humdrum game but praise is due for referee David Elleray, who refereed sensibly and well and made absolutely the right decision in showing Keane a straight red at the end. There is a history between Keane and Elleray, as well as Keane and Haaland, and the United captain has now been dismissed four times by the Harrow official.

Keane is the only one pursuing a feud, however. Elleray could have booked Keane as early as the sixth minute, for a petulant and quite unnecessary assault on Jeff Whitley. Instead, Elleray called him over and told him to calm down, advice Keane was only able to stick to for 85 minutes instead of 90. The whisper being spread none to discreetly by City officials (not Haaland himself) was that Keane had mentioned revenge for his injury at Leeds before leaving the pitch. If true, United's captain has not learned much in the past four years. Now, as then, he can expect his aggression to rebound on him.

fields.headline: Vassell's Villa value
fields.trailText: The destiny and destination of the Premiership title having ceased to be an issue long ago, the competition for European places is at least ensuring there is some post-Easter drama to be wrung out of the current campaign.
fields.body:
The destiny and destination of the Premiership title having ceased to be an issue long ago, the competition for European places is at least ensuring there is some post-Easter drama to be wrung out of the current campaign.

Aston Villa find themselves in the thick of that contest for the sixth-place finish that will guarantee a place in next season's Uefa Cup or, the longer shot, ending in seventh place and trusting Leeds United to win the Champions League and finish out of the Premiership's top three. However, despite stretching their unbeaten run to nine yesterday, not even David Ginola could prevent Villa dropping two points and important ground in the Europe bid.

Ginola has been Villa's resident get out of jail card in recent weeks, contributing goals and verve in short, sharp bursts off the bench. Yesterday, he was given more than 30 minutes to stamp his impression on a contest that was rapidly descending into distinctly end-of-season fare, but to no avail.

He worked hard, even making his annual tackle at one point, and Southampton keeper Paul Jones attempted to assist Ginola by fumbling a 73rd-minute cross which flew beyond the Villa forwards but, ultimately, Villa were undone by too many mediocre individual performances. Absent from the criticism should be forward Darius Vassell, responsible for most of Villa and the game's brighter moments, but unfortunately for the prospects of a goal, the game's best chance fell not to him but partner Dion Dublin.

He was played clean through on Jones by a neat Paul Merson pass nine minutes from time only to shoot over the target from six yards, a piece of finishing that summed up an unsatisfactory afternoon.

At least Southampton's caretaker manager Stuart Gray enjoyed his first point since succeeding Glenn Hoddle and the return might have been even greater. James Beattie had a first half 'goal' ruled offside, a seemingly harsh decision, and the same Saints striker was denied only by David James's sure handling in the 68th minute after Wayne Bridge's through-ball.

fields.headline: Blues draw blank
fields.trailText: The result, in the end, suited neither side. With both teams fretting over play-off places, the single point allowed neither to relax. Birmingham were lucky not to lose after the referee denied Burnley a second-half penalty. Marcelo could have stolen the game with a late header but a draw was probably the fair result.
fields.body:
The result, in the end, suited neither side. With both teams fretting over play-off places, the single point allowed neither to relax. Birmingham were lucky not to lose after the referee denied Burnley a second-half penalty. Marcelo could have stolen the game with a late header but a draw was probably the fair result.

Things have not gone according to plan for Trevor Francis since the disappointment of losing the Worthington Cup final in Cardiff. Birmingham have amassed only four points in their past ten matches - what had recently been a battle for automatic promotion has become a matter of hanging on to a play-off place.

Things have not gone to plan at Burnley, either, given that their aim was to consolidate their position in the division. They have ended up making a pest of themselves.

But if Burnley were hoping to see a malfunctioning Birmingham side, they would have been disappointed in a first half in which the visitors played the best football. With Marcelo their only fit forward, Francis pushed Bryan Hughes into an attacking position and was rewarded with much intelligent use of the ball in the opposition half.

The home defence, however, excelled, with veteran full-back Mitchell Thomas outstanding. It was he who closed the door on Birmingham's best opening, stretching out a leg to steal the ball from Marcelo. Too often, however, having won possession it was immediately wasted.

Burnley huffed and puffed, but they came closer to scoring an opener. Steve Davis headed wide from Glen Little's cross before Paul Weller's stinging volley forced Ian Bennett into a sharp save.

But they should have scored five minutes into the second period, only for the referee to deny them. Ian Moore's header from ten yards was flying goalwards when it appeared to hit one of Michael Johnson's arms, both of which were being waved above his head at the time. Frenzied appeals from players and fans, however, drew no reaction from the referee.

fields.headline: Rio roars on return
fields.trailText: What price success? On this evidence £18million goes a long, long way.
fields.body:
What price success? On this evidence £18million goes a long, long way.

When Rio Ferdinand became the world's most expensive defender, West Ham, the club he left behind, were faring very nicely thank you while his new employers were in a rut. Now Leeds are soaring on all fronts, while his old friends from the East End have spiralled in the opposite direction.

As if to emphasise the change in fortunes, Ferdinand marked the occasion with a goal. Leeds mobbed him. At the same time you could sense thousands of claret and blue hearts sinking.

Once the hurt began to subside the anger set in. 'Where's the money gone?' bellowed the Upton Park faithful. Their reaction to a substitution said it all; Christian Dailly was jeered off, Kaba Diawara booed on. All is not sweetness and light down Upton Park.

Quite the reverse for David O'Leary's extraordinary team. If there was any question about whether the midweek defeat at Deportivo La Coruña would disrupt their momentum, Leeds wasted no time in giving a forceful answer: Only eight minutes on the clock and Shaka Hislop was fetching the ball from the back of his net.

Harry Kewell was the instigator, accelerating to the byline before delivering a teasing cross to Ian Harte at the far post. Although Hislop blocked the defender's header, he could do little to prevent Robbie Keane from gratefully gobbling up the rebound. With his ninth goal of the campaign since arriving from Inter Milan, the young Irishman is proving an efficient deputy for Alan Smith and Mark Viduka - one or the other tends to be rested after Europe - who were both unavailable.

One-nil down, lacking confidence, West Ham's hopes shrivelled even more a couple of minutes later when top scorer Freddie Kanouté, who had been dogged by injury leading up to the game, limped off. Before half-time John Moncur followed suit. Poor old West Ham - as Harry Redknapp has been repeating all season - once again down the bare bones.

It was looking pretty bleak. Paolo Di Canio was having one of those infuriating games when he looked, at best, half-interested and with Leeds in dominant and comfortable mood it was hard to see how West Ham could recover. They were almost handed a lifeline after Danny Mills bizarrely stamped on Di Canio and could easily have been dismissed - but referee Graham Poll rather leniently chose the yellow card.

Whenever Keane and Kewell ran at the home defence with pace and guile there was the smell of goals in the air. Which was more than could be said for West Ham.

Two minutes after the restart, Leeds put themselves in a seemingly unassailable position thanks to the most popular player on the pitch - Ferdinand. There were question marks over the West Ham marking (had Rio still been wearing claret he would have been expected to deal with the danger), but none the less he deserved the plaudits for a beautifully directed header from Harte's floated free-kick. The ball looped over Hislop and Erik Bakke followed it in on the line to make sure.

West Ham were boosted when Leeds were reduced to 10 men a minute later as David Batty was given his marching orders for a vicious lunge at Joe Cole. Nigel Martyn was suddenly busier, but in the end the West Ham applause was reserved for only one man: Rio Ferdinand.

webTitle: Old Crazy Gang take Cardiff up

fields.headline: Old Crazy Gang take Cardiff up
fields.standfirst: League review Jason Tomas
fields.trailText: The old Wimbledon Crazy Gang influence at Cardiff - initiated by chairman, Sam Hamman, Director of Football, Bobby Gould and manager, Alan Cork - led to promotion from the Third Division for the Welsh club yesterday.
fields.body:
The old Wimbledon Crazy Gang influence at Cardiff - initiated by chairman, Sam Hamman, Director of Football, Bobby Gould and manager, Alan Cork - led to promotion from the Third Division for the Welsh club yesterday.

Cardiff did it the hard way, with a 3-3 draw at York after being twice ahead. They seemed to be heading for defeat when Colin Alcide gave York a 3-2 lead, but Lee Fortune-West, the scorer of the first two Cardiff goals, came to their rescue again by clinching a hat-trick. The other helping hand for them came from Mansfield, who beat Leyton Orient 2-0.

Cardiff's achievement reflects particular credit on Cork, whose own playing career as a striker was highlighted by his record as Wimbledon's highest-ever scorer. When he was brought to Cardiff in October, by Gould, the club were 14th in the table.

His celebrations yesterday provided a sad irony for Swansea, the club he managed in the 1997/98 season. They were relegated as a result of their 2-1 home defeat by Oldham.

Tranmere and QPR were also relegated yesterday after Tranmere were held to a 1-1 draw by Crystal Palace and QPR losing at Huddersfield.

Palace took the lead very much against the run of play through a 25-yard shot from David Hopkin but were pegged back by an Andy Parkinson equaliser. Huddersfield were not the only team at the bottom to get a good result, the other were Stockport who beat Crewe.

The League Managers Association incorporates 'football's greatest minds' according to the body's official web-site. They are certainly needed at the bottom of the Third Division, where that managerial skill of building bricks without straw is subjected to its most rigorous test.

This season, it is not just great minds that are needed at this impoverished end of the scale - the high number of teams who have yet to make themselves safe from the drop into the comparative football wilderness of the Conference suggests that nerves of steel would come in quite handy, too.

Of the teams in the deepest trouble, the worst result was that of second from bottom Torquay losing 3-1 at Plymouth. A Richard Kell penalty had given them an early lead, but they were then hit by Khalid Chalqi being sent off.

The best result was unquestionably that of Lincoln in coming from behind to win at Chesterfield, which stopped their opponents from clinching promotion. This was Lincoln's eighth away match among the 11 they have played since the experienced Alan Buckley became their manager. They are away again tomorrow, at Rochdale. But then they have three successive matches at home, two of them against Carlisle and Halifax, and Buckley insists: 'I am not panicking because our survival chances are very much in our own hands.

'I am encouraged by the fact that my ideas on how the game should be played, which differ from what the players have been used to, are being taken on board.

'I would say that the biggest improvement we have made since I came here has been in our football - by that I mean our football on the floor. Wherever, I have been as a manager, I have preached that all the time, and have had people telling me: "Is that wise - wouldn't you be better off with a team that gave the ball a headache?" But any success I have had has been based on pure football, and I am determined to keep going down that road. I like to think that this is what is going to ultimately get us out of trouble.'

Bolton have lost the services of Andy Campbell. The Under-21 international, loaned to them by Middlesbrough, has been recalled to the Premiership club because of their injury crisis.

fields.headline: Rushden hold the edge
fields.trailText: The game that Yeovil's manager Colin Addison insisted his team must win finished goalless, leaving the Nationwide Conference's two title contenders still with everything to play for over the next fortnight.
fields.body:
The game that Yeovil's manager Colin Addison insisted his team must win finished goalless, leaving the Nationwide Conference's two title contenders still with everything to play for over the next fortnight.

Yeovil, whose crowd of 8,868 fell just short of a Conference record, have a game in hand but, crucially, Brian Talbot's Rushden & Diamonds possess a far superior goal difference and will remain marginal favourites to claim a place in the Football League next season.

There had been a perfectly observed minute's silence before the start of the game in honour of Alec Stock, who died last Monday. Even the Diamonds supporters occupying the open terrace behind one goal remained solemn and still in tribute to the late and great manager, who was responsible for Yeovil's rise to prominence as FA Cup giantkilling specialists in the Forties.

The two sides did not stand on ceremony for long though. There was too much at stake for that. The Diamonds are the big-money team, funded by Max Griggs, the multi-millionaire owner of the Dr Martens footwear company. Yeovil, whose budget is far more modest, have nevertheless made the running for most of the season. But they looked tight and tense in the opening stages.

Justin Jackson failed to follow up a promising left-wing surge for the Diamonds with a decent cross. But the forward, whose £180,000 signing last summer was a Conference record, looked more like his usual self with a thundering volley safely held by Tony Pennock, who keeps goal for the Wales semi-professional side.

Unlike Jackson, Andy Burgess is one of the few play ers nurtured by the Diamonds themselves. With his teasing crosses - and a fierce free-kick that forced a fine save from Pennock - he showed great promise on the wing.

Yeovil eventually shed some of their inhibitions to create a few chances. Warren Patmore, who had tested his apparently recovered groin strain with a spot of early ball juggling down the right, later shot sluggishly wide when well placed before suffering an aggravation of his injury that forced him off after 27 minutes.

His replacement, James Bent, was immediately involved in the action. He scooped wastefully wide after the Diamonds goalkeeper Billy Turley had lost possession of a high cross after being challenged by Nick Crittenden.

Yeovil, who had almost scored just before the interval from a Michael McIndoe corner that caused all sorts of alarms, nearly profited through the same routine immediately after the resumption. From another McIndoe kick, the home side's captain Terry Skiverton had a strong header saved.

With McIndoe volleying over, Crittenden firing narrowly wide and Darren Way having a shot blocked, the Yeovil midfielders were certainly beginning to make their presence felt.

The best chance yet, however, fell to Barrington Belgrave who, having rudely barged Tarkan Mustafa off the ball, then lost all sense of composure in his attempt on goal and his lob was far too high.

The Diamonds did not threaten again until the 61st minute when Duane Darby started a move that he also finished, diving to head a Burgess cross that was met by a flying save from Pennock.

fields.headline: Boro breathe again
fields.trailText: The pressure has eased on Terry Venables after this handsome victory gave Middlesbrough some much-needed breathing space. There is still work to be done, but it looks like a continuation of Premiership football at The Riverside next season.
fields.body:
The pressure has eased on Terry Venables after this handsome victory gave Middlesbrough some much-needed breathing space. There is still work to be done, but it looks like a continuation of Premiership football at The Riverside next season.

For Peter Taylor, the problems continue. It was their seventh successive league defeat, equalling the club record. Leicester were given a harsh lesson in the art of taking chances and quite frankly it is difficult to see where their next point might be coming from.

Gerry Taggart returned after a knee injury to captain Leicester in the absence of Matt Elliott, who along with leading scorer Muzzy Izzet is out for the rest of the season.

Taggart - and his fellow defenders, for that matter - might have wished for a more amenable start. They were placed under considerable pressure by first Dean Windass and then Christian Karembeu threatening Simon Royce's goal with long-range efforts.

Middlesbrough looked good for an early goal and it duly arrived after Royce denied Paul Ince at the expense of a corner following good work by Windass and Alen Boksic. The ball was played short by Karembeu to Dean Gordon, whose cross was headed home from inside the six-yard box by Hamilton Ricard.

In their present plight, it was just what Leicester did not need. Chances came their way but were squandered by a team clearly lacking in confidence. After a mistake by Ugo Ehiogu, Ade Akinbiyi was allowed to advance on Mark Schwarzer, with the goalkeeper winning the duel. Steve Guppy had a shot from inside the penalty area deflected for a corner, but that was nothing compared to Akinbiyi's howler.

Approaching half-time. Damien Delaney, making his second Premiership appearance after a £50,000 move from Cork City, struck the underside of the crossbar from 25 yards, and it seemed just a formality for Akinbiyi to convert the rebound. Instead he headed over an open goal.

Not all the chances, however, came at one end. A flowing move involving Ince, Boksic and Karembeu carved open the Leicester defence, but when the ball came wide to Gordon he drove it the wrong side of the near post.

There was plenty of niggle in such an important match for these teams. Windass and Robbie Savage were shown yellow cards after a scuffle in the middle of the field, with cautions for Taggart and Frank Sinclair either side of that incident.

Leicester brought on Arnar Gunnlaugsson for Sturridge for the second half, but promptly conceded two more goals within three minutes.

Boksic won a centre-circle tussle with Taggart before accelerating away unchallenged from the flagging defender to chip Royce with some style from the edge of the penalty area.

Then, a corner delivered by Gordon was half-cleared by Junior Lewis towards Ince, who drove it firmly through a crowd of players into the net with his left foot.

Then, a corner delivered by Gordon was half-cleared by Junior Lewis towards Ince, who drove it firmly through a crowd of players into the net with his left foot.

fields.headline: Barras to the rescue
fields.trailText: For once the double act of Jamie Cureton and Martin Butler could not inspire Reading to victory. Two more strikes from Cureton took his partnership with Butler for the season to 48 league goals, but Walsall came from two down to put a dent in Reading's promotion challenge.
fields.byline: Duncan Mackay at the Madejski Stadium
fields.body:
For once the double act of Jamie Cureton and Martin Butler could not inspire Reading to victory. Two more strikes from Cureton took his partnership with Butler for the season to 48 league goals, but Walsall came from two down to put a dent in Reading's promotion challenge.

Reading have been almost unstoppable since January, a period during which they have lost only once in 17 matches. Their support has grown with their success and there was a wonderful atmosphere inside this magnificent stadium by the side of the M4, which would not look out of place in the Premiership.

Reading tore into their opponents from the opening whistle. It took them only 29 seconds to create their first opportunity, when Butler saw a close-range effort saved well by James Walker.

It was Butler's partner Cureton who put them ahead 14 minutes later. An incisive move stretched the Walsall defence and ended with Keith Jones hitting a low cross which Cureton steered home for his 27th goal of the season.

The next one was not far away as Butler's header in the 24th minute sent Cureton racing through to place the ball past Walker. But, perhaps caught by the celebratory mood of the home fans, Reading threw Walsall a lifeline from the restart when Jorge Leitao rounded Phil Whitehead and placed the ball into the empty net.

The rescue mission was completed when Tony Barras equalised. Barras met Fitzroy Simpson's free-kick with a header which Whitehead pushed away, but the keeper was then powerless to prevent the Walsall man from prodding the rebound over the line. The comeback owed much to Walker, who seconds before the goal had pulled off a double save from Butler. Sammy Igoe blazed over in the 57th minute as Reading tried in vain to regain their lead.

Not even the introduction of Nicky Forster, another prolific goalscorer, could conjure a winner for Reading. Indeed, they might have lost if it had not been for Whitehead who, in the 80th minute, kept out a Simpson free-kick.

webTitle: Keane faces ban after red card

fields.headline: Keane faces ban after red card
fields.trailText: Roy Keane completed a terrible week for the Premiership champions when he was sent off for the eighth time in eight years at Manchester United in the 1-1 draw with Manchester City at Old Trafford. A vicious tackle on opposing captain Alfie Haaland five minutes from the end of one of an otherwise tame game was fully deserving of the straight red card David Elleray produced, and could lead to a lengthy ban.
fields.body:
Roy Keane completed a terrible week for the Premiership champions when he was sent off for the eighth time in eight years at Manchester United in the 1-1 draw with Manchester City at Old Trafford. A vicious tackle on opposing captain Alfie Haaland five minutes from the end of one of an otherwise tame game was fully deserving of the straight red card David Elleray produced, and could lead to a lengthy ban.

Keane, already in the news for his scathing comments on his own team-mates after United's Champions League exit at Bayern Munich on Wednesday, can expect swift punishment from the FA's disciplinary committee, not just because his knee high assault on Haaland constituted one of the clearest examples of violent and dangerous conduct imaginable but because there is a well-documented history between the two players.

It was while attempting to foul Haaland (then a Leeds player) in September 1997 that Keane damaged a cruciate ligament and put himself out for a season. A feud existed even then - 'It was obvious he was after me,' Haaland said at the time - and Keane was clearly seen to shout something at the prone City player before departing the pitch yesterday. City's manager, Joe Royle, said: 'They don't send each other Christmas cards.'

Predictably, Sir Alex Ferguson said he had not seen the tackle. 'I spoke to our secretary, who said the referee was right to send him off,' the United manager said. 'It's not been the best of weeks for us.'

Asked if he was concerned about Keane's disciplinary record, Ferguson turned on the journalist who put the question. 'I'm not even going to answer that,' he said. 'You must have been in the land of nod to say that if you have been watching Keane this season. He's had one yellow card, that's all.'

Actually Keane has had five yellow cards. Elleray has now dismissed Keane four times, but there was no arguing with the red he produced in the 85th minute. Keane went for Haaland's knee in a manner calculated to cause damage. 'Alfie said he was lucky because Keane hit him when his leg was in the air,' said Royle. 'Had it been on the floor we'd probably still be looking for it.'

Better news for United is confirmation that the Ruud van Nistelrooy deal is back on. The club met PSV Eindhoven officials on Friday night and chief executive Peter Kenyon said: 'We would hope to have agreed a fee with PSV by the end of the week.'

webTitle: Were Arsenal a little too keen to sell £10 million Petit?

fields.headline: Were Arsenal a little too keen to sell £10 million Petit?
fields.trailText: With world Cup and European Championships winner Emmanuel Petit spending most of the season warming the Nou Camp bench and only getting a game every once in a while in the absence of other first-teamers, generally at left-back or central-defender, questions have been asked of exactly why Barcelona bothered to buy him.
fields.body:
With world Cup and European Championships winner Emmanuel Petit spending most of the season warming the Nou Camp bench and only getting a game every once in a while in the absence of other first-teamers, generally at left-back or central-defender, questions have been asked of exactly why Barcelona bothered to buy him.

Petit himself has spent much of the season musing the very same thing, his continual outbursts well documented in the Football Unlimited website ever since the flamboyantly-coiffeured one abandoned London for the Catalan capital in that high-profile deal along with Marc Overmars last summer.

The financial details of the transfer, unusually, never emerged and the whole deal has been shrouded in mystery, until now that is, with the 'official' version putting the price at £25 million, whereas in reality Barcelona paid £33m.

Barcelona, it transpires, had no intention of buying Petit, but were told by Arsenal that he would be included in the package if the moneybags Catalans wanted the Dutch winger, according to an anonymous Vice-President at the Nou Camp. By the end of the season there were serious divisions in the players at Highbury with some of the foreign contingent accused of shirking, - most notably Petit and Overmars, with their hearts apparently no longer in the cause.

Recently, it emerged that Petit's name had been on a list of players wanted by former coach Louis van Gaal, who had already had talks with Overmars about the switch early in the 1999-2000 season - which The Observer reported in December 1999 after personal terms were agreed.

Yesterday Petit spoke about his disappointment at Barcelona's defeat at Liverpool in the Uefa Cup and of his fondness for Arsenal. He has been linked with a return to Highbury.

'We [Barcelona] expected to go through to the final - particularly as we don't think we have a chance to win the title this year.

'My year here has not been great because I have met so many troubles. It's not been a very happy year for me.'

Petit also reacted to Patrick Vieira's comments last week when Petit's one-time Highbury partner said neither Overmars nor Petit should have been sold.

Petit continued: 'It's very difficult for me to speak but I'm happy about what Patrick said. But I stil don't have any regrets about leaving Arsenal because when you sign for someone like Barcelona you do expect so many things from that.

'I think 90 per cent of the players in the world would love to play for as big a club as Barca. I don't say Arsenal is not big, but that there are only a few clubs in the world as big as Barca.'

'It hasn't been a disappointment for me to leave Arsenal but on some sides I have some regrets because Arsenal have been a family and they will be a family for me for the rest of my life.'

Incidentally, in 1999 when van Gaal was linked with Overmars - Rivaldo's name was being linked with Manchester United. Sir Alex Ferguson was offered first option on Barca's Brazilian, then playing wide on the left, in the same role van Gaal had earmarked for Overmars.

The controversial Dutch coach was determined to offload the player who then went on to become World Player of the Year. In the end, van Gaal went and Rivaldo remained at the Nou Camp.

webTitle: 'Arrogant' Belgium hand Scots the fax of strife

fields.headline: 'Arrogant' Belgium hand Scots the fax of strife
fields.trailText: Craig Brown is normally about as easily provoked as a tortoise, but he has been uncommonly agitated these past few days by a communique received at SFA headquarters which betrays Belgium's presumption that they will finish ahead of Scotland and Croatia in group six to earn automatic qualification for next year's World Cup finals.
fields.body:
Craig Brown is normally about as easily provoked as a tortoise, but he has been uncommonly agitated these past few days by a communique received at SFA headquarters which betrays Belgium's presumption that they will finish ahead of Scotland and Croatia in group six to earn automatic qualification for next year's World Cup finals.

The offending fax, from Piet Huys of the Royal Belgian Football Association, will have been transmitted to countries throughout Europe, but the non-selective nature of computer databases has ensured that a copy has landed in Glasgow and, it is reasonable to suppose, in Zagreb. Brown clearly infers a gross insult from the opening sentence of circular, which reads: 'We are currently looking for valuable opponents to meet on one of the above dates, in preparation to [sic] our eventual participation at the World Cup 2002.'

Huys goes on to say that they are hoping to bring the Mexican national side to Europe next February and that they would like to defray costs by finding more opponents for the North American team. With Belgium presently three points behind Scotland and fixtures against the Scots in Brussels and Croatia in Zagreb still to be negotiated, Brown feels that his rivals' readiness to formalise friendlies is premature enough to suggest an unseemly arrogance. 'I know it's already been well documented that the Belgians have already made provisional booking of hotel and training facilities in Japan,' said the manager, 'but there's nothing outrageous about that. In fact, it makes sense and is the kind of thing everybody does, including ourselves.

'But arranging prep matches is a different matter. If you conclude a deal with a country as far away as Mexico, it has to be fulfilled, or handsome compensation paid. That really does smack of presumption that you're going to be in the finals. Still, we can use it as a motivator. 'I usually start to get our players up by reminding them of their responsibilities to the thousands of people who follow us. I tell the players what our fans deserve, and they deserve qualification for the great tournaments. Now we have something to give them a little extra edge.'

Brown has to start cranking up the inspiration on Wednesday, when Scotland play Poland in a friendly in Bydgoszcz. It should be less of a chore than usual, given the natural enthusiasm and willingness to impress that should exist among the number of new players he has introduced to the squad, as well as others who are normally on the periphery and are likely to be given an opportunity to establish credentials.Charlie Miller of Dundee United, Gavin Rae of Dundee and John O'Neil of Hibs are the rookies and, since they play in midfield, there is no chance of all three starting the match. But each of them should be seen at some point in the WKS Zawisza Stadium, while the renascent Scott Booth of Twente Enschede in Holland is likely to bring the keenness of a novice to his return to international duty for the first time in almost three years. Brown never fails to experiment in friendlies while trying simultaneously to achieve victory - 'We'll have supporters over there and we can't forget that' - but the outing against the resurgent Poles promises to be a demanding experience.

Under the coaching of the university-educated polyglot, Jerszy Engel, the Poles have streaked to the top of group five with four victories and a draw from five matches, including away wins over Norway (3-2) and Armenia (4-0). Brown has seen several of their games on video and confirms their re-emergence as a formidable force. 'There is great excitement over there now, because it's been quite a while since they have had such a promising national side,' he said. 'It's just the football cycle, it's coming back round Poland's way. They began to show signs of recovery in the qualifying for Euro 2000, when they were just shaded by England for a place in the play-offs.

'You'll remember they went to Sweden needing a draw to knock England out, but lost to late goals. They're maturing nicely now, most of them in their middle to late twenties, although the Panathinaikos striker, Emmanuel Olisadebe - I believe he's the first black player to represent Poland - is just 22 and quite a talent. 'Other countries seem able to enjoy this fallow period while they regroup, while the demands are constant on us to keep reaching the big finals. We have to effect a transition period while trying simultaneously to qualify. We try to maintain standards.

Brown's team have been strongest in central defence and midfield in recent years, and he is hoping that Booth, the former Aberdeen striker who is now operating in a role behind the front two at Twente, has thrown off the difficult times he has had since his last appearance, as a substitute in the France 98 defeat by Morocco. 'Booth had a very good spell with Scotland - his record is still pretty good, with five goals from 17 games - but he seemed to lose his momentum,' said Brown. 'Now, he may have it back and the position he plays now gives me the option of playing either him or Don Hutchison in attack, with one or the other in that slot behind the attack. 'Whatever happens in Poland, the visit will have been worthwhile. These games always are, even if the benefit is a negative one, such as discovering players who are unlikely to cut it at international level.'

webTitle: O'Brien's last word as Tyne-Wear passions boil over

fields.headline: O'Brien's last word as Tyne-Wear passions boil over
fields.trailText: Andy O'Brien, part of a Newcastle defence that can't stop conceding goals claimed an equaliser as a triple substitution paid instant dividends for manager Bobby Robson.
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Andy O'Brien, part of a Newcastle defence that can't stop conceding goals claimed an equaliser as a triple substitution paid instant dividends for manager Bobby Robson.

As the three new boys streamed on in the 76th minute, Carl Cort's mis-kick presented O'Brien with a straightforward chance in front of goal. He snapped up the chance to salvage a point for Newcastle.

Robson decided desperate times needed desperate measures when Shola Ameobi, Daniel Cordone and Andy Griffin went on. Newcastle had been on the back foot for most of a pulsating and passionate derby and trailed from the 67th minute.

Patrice Carteron, on loan from St Etienne until the end of the season, accepted a pass from Don Hutchison and fired in a low, angled shot that means United have not kept a clean sheet for nine games. Five players had been booked in this late kick-off before many fans at other games reached for their car radios as both teams underlined what this game means to the North East.

It may have provided only a post-script to the main Premiership programme yesterday, but Newcastle and Sunderland see it differently - even if most other derbies have greater significance in terms of trophies. Newcastle are destined, at best, for mid-table mediocrity and Sunderland fans fear their recent decline has all but ended their European ambitions.

But, put them in opposition, and both have discovered an extra edge in the past three meetings that have brought only one point for Newcastle.

Newcastle looked determined to put that right and within five minutes Gary Speed sliced a shot wide at the end of a smart build-up and Nikos Dabiza's header almost set up Kevin Gallacher. It was an awkward period for Sun derland, although they went on to create by far the better chances of a first half when the pace simply never slackened.

Kevin Phillips, back to his sharpest after a lean spell, signalled their recovery in the 17th minute when he appeared to be held by Warren Barton before placing a shot within the reach of keeper Shay Given. By then, Barton had already been booked and four more followed him into referee Mike Riley's book by half-time.

Quinn had a header saved by Given but it was a Sunderland defender who went clos est to a breakthrough when Emerson Thome headed Julio Arca's cross against the post in the 37th minute.

Another booking - Hutchison for diving inside the area - was followed by a flare-up that indicated the temperature would not drop in the second half. Also unchanged was Sunderland's ability to keep possession and exert sustained pressure on Given and his defence.

They were still indebted to the excellence of Given, however. He dealt comfortably with efforts from Gavin McCann and Phillips in the opening minutes of the second half before being given a far more severe test by Phillips - turning inside the area after 60 minutes and unleashing a shot that was turned over by the keeper, although it only delayed the breakthrough by seven minutes.

fields.headline: Hibs' flaws resurface
fields.trailText: Hibs fans who had spent the week celebrating their team's place in the Scottish Cup final would have left Easter Road yesterday with their relish for the big day turning to dread.
fields.body:
Hibs fans who had spent the week celebrating their team's place in the Scottish Cup final would have left Easter Road yesterday with their relish for the big day turning to dread.

The result was enough to virtually assure them of third place in the Premier League, but the low level of their performance could hardly be encouraging in terms of the assignment with Celtic at Hampden Park on 26 May. Kilmarnock, striving to retain fourth place and the assurance of Uefa Cup qualification, deserved at least a point after taking the lead through Christophe Cocard.

Hibs' severely disappointing results since the winter break - they now have only one victory from their past seven league fixtures - has coincided with a dip in the form of Russel Latapy, their gifted Trinidadian midfielder.

Even so, his absence yesterday, on international duty, tended to support the argument that, without him, the Easter Road side become even more unbalanced. With Ulrik Laursen, the impressive Dane who operates in the left wing-back position also missing, because of injury, there was a disjointedness about Hibs for most of the time that would encourage the travelling Kilmarnock support to believe their team had arrived in Edinburgh on an opportune day.

This was confirmed early, when Cocard gave them the lead with a goal that was won derfully executed but which betrayed the general uncertainty in the home side. Following a throw from the right, no Hibs defender seemed keen to take possession of the ball and it came to the Frenchman, who completed a little jink to his right before sending a powerful low drive to the right of Nick Colgan from around 22 yards.

What Cocard did next had the home support in an even greater state of panic. Carrying the ball through the middle, Cocard seemed to be invited into the danger area by opponents who seemed reluctant to obstruct his progress. They got lucky when Cocard lost control, but could not take advantage, the ball pin-balling about before it broke back to Andy McLaren. The Kilmarnock winger should have done better than clip his shot over the bar from 16 yards.

The widespread lack of self-belief in the home side ensured that their visitors would hardly be troubled in defence; misplaced passes from every area gave the forwards Tom McManus and Marc Libbra little opportunity to make their mark - until a free-kick was awarded some 25 yards out.

John O'Neil took it quickly, feeding Frederic Arpinon, Latapy's deputy, on the right. The Frenchman delivered a wicked cross, allowing his fellow countryman Libbra to stoop low and head the ball past Colin Meldrum from only six yards.

It was an unexpected set-back for a Kilmarnock side who had looked the more assured and relaxed, a curious aspect of a match in which they were expected to be the more pressured. On the contrary, Antonio Calderon, Alan Mahood and Ally Mitchell spent most of the time, especially in the first half, in possession and looking more likely to carry a threat than their opposite numbers.

Yet they should have been behind early in the second half, when Hibs gave an overdue glimpse of the movement and passing that had made them Celtic's main challengers for much of the season. It was their misfortune that the finishing was more typical of their recent form.

Arpinon supplied Libbra on the right and ran forward to receive the return from a compatriot who had found good space. The ball duly arrived, but Arpinon, who faced an untended goal as Meldrum had been teased from his line in anticipation of a scoring attempt from Libbra, scooped the ball over the bar.

Even if Kilmarnock escaped here, the moment seemed to unsettle them, and thereafter the visitors were less self-assured than in the first half. Still, neither side were ever likely to cause spectators to recall the match with any great fondness.

What few half-chances did arise thereafter came to Hibs, but Meldrum blocked Paul Fenwick's hooked volley - from a long free-kick from Franck Sauzee - at the far post and had little trouble in smothering a low drive from O'Neil when the latter cut in from the right, having been released by Arpinon's pass.

Even the late arrival of Ally McCoist from the Kilmarnock bench was never likely to be enough to fan the embers of this one.

fields.headline: Gers get Champions League spot
fields.trailText: Rangers had no difficulty in brushing Dundee aside to confirm their European Champions League spot - partly because of the number of times Dundee let them off the hook through poor finishing.
fields.body:
Rangers had no difficulty in brushing Dundee aside to confirm their European Champions League spot - partly because of the number of times Dundee let them off the hook through poor finishing.

The home team were given an early lesson in the art when Rod Wallace fastened on to a Bert Konterman punt over the top of their defence to put Rangers ahead after four minutes.

But Dundee then wasted three chances to equalise. The most glaring miss came from Girogi Nemsadze, who with only the keeper, Stefan Klos, to beat shot straight at him.

Tore Andre Flo increased Rangers' lead after 16 minutes, and following further Dundee misses - notably by Juan Sara - Jorg Albertz made it 3-0 from 25 yards just before half time.

Motherwell also missed good chances at home to St Johnstone, and were punished for it when the latter's Mohammed Sylla scored the only goal.

It was one of the few highlights in a dull match, as was Arild Stavrum's goal - his 14th of the season - in Aberdeen's 1-0 win against Dunfermline.

The Scottish FA are to reconsider their criteria for entry into their international football Hall of Fame.

At present, players need to gain at least 50 caps to be included. However, one notable omission is that of Jim Baxter, who died last week and was only capped 34 times.

It is not difficult to appreciate why the SFA are considering moving the goalposts. As Scotland's coach, Craig Brown, said: 'In the old days before substitutes, only 11 players would get a cap for a match and there were fewer matches. For example, I am allowed seven substitutes in next week's friendly ion Poland. That means that there could be as many as 18 caps awarded. In the old days, you probably would not get that many in a whole season.'

But one player unlikely to take part in the Poland game is the Rangers captain, Barry Ferguson, who is poised to withdraw from the squad because of rib injury.

webTitle: Don't shoot them - they're just trying to manage

fields.headline: Don't shoot them - they're just trying to manage
fields.trailText: 'Who'd be a football manager?' John Motson once famously asked in a commentary, and the question has spawned a whole fantasy industry. Eyes light up. We all fancy it, after all, don't we? Quite apart from the financial rewards on offer these days, the intrigue of buying and selling players, deciding on tactics, brings out the control freak in all of us. Given the slings and arrows hurled their way last week, though, you wonder if even the obsessively vocational Sir Alex Ferguson and Arsène Wenger entertained the doubt implied in the question themselves. One respected, experienced writer argued that Ferguson might be better going now rather than in a year's time. Various critics suggest that Wenger has lost the plot at Arsenal. David O'Leary and Gérard Houllier, meanwhile, are the best things since sliced bread (begging the question, what exactly was the best thing before sliced bread?).

'Who'd be a football manager?' John Motson once famously asked in a commentary, and the question has spawned a whole fantasy industry. Eyes light up. We all fancy it, after all, don't we? Quite apart from the financial rewards on offer these days, the intrigue of buying and selling players, deciding on tactics, brings out the control freak in all of us. Given the slings and arrows hurled their way last week, though, you wonder if even the obsessively vocational Sir Alex Ferguson and Arsène Wenger entertained the doubt implied in the question themselves. One respected, experienced writer argued that Ferguson might be better going now rather than in a year's time. Various critics suggest that Wenger has lost the plot at Arsenal. David O'Leary and Gérard Houllier, meanwhile, are the best things since sliced bread (begging the question, what exactly was the best thing before sliced bread?).

How fickle is football, how long an English season, how short the memories of its devotees, all revealed in the perceptions of its top four managers at the end of a European week that just a few seasons ago this country pined for. No wonder so many managers pin Kipling's If on the wall, no wonder that, when England manager, Bobby Robson kept the Serenity Prayer on his desk. A week ago, if minds stretch back that far, Ferguson was being confirmed as the English game's most successful manager of all time. It was, admittedly, only the mere bauble of a championship, but until a decade ago, Manchester United had seen that as the grail for 26 years.

A week ago, too, Houllier was being castigated on radio phone-ins - the modern phenomenon that reflects perfectly these instant-gratification, what-have-you-done-for-me-lately days - for some negative tactics. No doubt, Seis-zero-Seis was last night swamped with Catalans bemoaning Barcelona's negativity in twice failing to score against Liverpool. Let's go back to pre-Christmas. United were playing the sort of expansive football that is Old Trafford's vibrant trademark. Arsenal had sailed through their opening Champions League phase, beating Lazio in the process. Leeds, though, were languishing and O'Leary was being criticised by mobile phones somewhere on the M1 for his tactical naivety. Thin dividing lines abound in football, from the top to the bottom - as the one beneath which Halifax Town have found themselves show - and they change everything.

There is the width of a crossbar that decides whether one team goes into a European semi-final, as Leeds did, or the sort of miss that Thierry Henry perpetrated in the first leg against Valencia or Andy Cole did more than once against Bayern to provoke the sort of soul-searching now evident with United and Arsenal. Ignoring those dividing lines, however, can prompt the sort of knee-jerk, extreme views that have cursed the English game for so long. Passionate opinion is one thing, reasoned argument another, unfashionable as the latter might be. A little of the humility that comes out of setbacks can even be good for the soul and long-term progress. Only now, after the Euro 2000 humiliation, has reality replaced the chumps-or-champs mentality when it comes to the national team.

So it should be with England's club representatives in international football. Here, expectations differ widely. Leeds are heroes because so little was expected of them; United and Arsenal the villains because so much was. After his side had surrendered to Middlesbrough at Highbury, Wenger was condemned for saying exactly that about them. Such realism did not go down well. But he knows, and we should, that his team are a work in progress. So too are Leeds, Liverpool and, yes, United, even if it was thought that they were the finished-articles exception. Contrary to modern demands, it takes patience and experience to build a high-level team. It took Ferguson five years to win a trophy. It would be a loss to the English game if Wenger, already a Double-winner, decides against staying beyond next season, his reluctance to sign a new contract strengthened by recent reaction.

All four managers will now know what is required. In Wenger's case, he will have to look again at his side's away record and work on how to teach his talented attacking players to defend from the front, as Ian Rush did in Liverpool's halcyon days, which show signs of returning, Emile Heskey proving himself worker as well as goalscorer. In Ferguson's case, it will be about how to refresh his team. The talk is of ripping up and starting again but should it be? Write down United's first-choice XI_ how many are out of their depth in Europe? Perhaps it was a season too soon for Wes Brown; perhaps Mikael Silvestre may not quite cut it. Maybe a new striker - Ruud Van Nistelrooy - would rejuvenate. Otherwise, this remains a potent team, particularly its middle four.

Whatever both Wenger and Ferguson decide, they have earned the right to see their jobs through and one suspects that any doubt about the wisdom of their career choice lasted a few seconds last week. If Ferguson were to go, who would United get at short notice? If it is to be Steve McLaren, better another season at the feet of the master. If not, then it will take another year to get the best man. Besides, after all he's done, Ferguson deserves to name his own departure date.

Neither will be named manager of the year, even though one has a title and the other is in the FA Cup final (though an Arsenal player, in Patrick Vieira is this column's choice as Footballer of the Year for his outstanding skill, drive and consistency). Perhaps, as irony after their early season labours, that honour will go to O'Leary or Houllier (though the strong favourite here is Ipswich Town's George Burley).

Ferguson and Wenger have, though, also earned the right to take their decisions in the sober summer downtime rather than this manufactured let's-have-a-heated-debate period. You don't see it a lot in the modern game, but it is time to put a foot on the ball rather than lump it about willy-nilly as too often in the past.

fields.headline: Mac's golden dividend
fields.trailText: Winners and losers in Europe
fields.body:
Winners and losers in Europe

Gerard Houllier was once an English teacher, and he retains a fondness for some of the language's more concise colloquialisms.

There's no need to go into detail about Steven Gerrard's goal against Manchester United, for instance, suffice to say it was 'a cracker'. Emile Heskey's shooting power? 'Whoof! Incredible.' And Gary McAllister, 36-year-old free transfer, one of the season's most astute signings, architect of the derby win at Goodison on Easter Monday and cool despatcher of Barcelona from the penalty spot four days later? Houllier's eyes briefly glance heavenwards. 'Macca,' he says, 'is a diamond.'

Few could argue. There were one or two sniggers when supposedly ambitious Liverpool picked up the old man of the Coventry midfield last summer, but those doubters now look as foolish as the impatient Scotland supporters who brought McAllister's international career to a premature close. McAllister has featured in more games than even he would have imagined - towards the end of his second game in a week at Anfield he looked positively envious as young Gerrard was hauled off for a rest - and has brought intelligence, experience and composure to Liverpool's successful campaign on four fronts this season.

It is unclear whether such a sizeable contribution was envisaged by Houllier at the start of the season, but it was obvious a few months ago that the manager knew he had landed on his feet. Raving about a typically committed Stuart Pearce performance for West Ham, Houllier expressed surprise and delight that the former England warhorse had just turned 38. 'That is fantastic!' Houllier exclaimed. 'It means if we are lucky we might get another two seasons out of Gary McAllister!'

McAllister, though he really might be tired by then, would be the last to object. He recently admitted he had always harboured a secret desire to play for Liverpool, and to get the chance at such a late stage then score an injury-time winner in a derby at Goodison amounted to a dream come true. After that, merely popping in a penalty against Barcelona, enough to put his side in the Uefa Cup final in Dortmund against Alavés on 16 May, was almost routine, or at least that's the way it looked as McAllister confidently stroked the ball home. 'I fancied myself to score all along, fancied it strongly,' he said. 'Barcelona rubbished us a bit, but over the two legs they didn't score and didn't get many chances.'

Houllier is matter-of-fact about his reasons for bringing McAllister to Anfield. He was aware his team had subsided late last season through inexperience, and was keen to add a few older heads to his youthful mix to prevent Liverpool losing vital points through naivety. Markus Babbel fitted the bill perfectly, as did Nick Barmby, though Houllier specifically wanted a central midfielder as back-up for Gerrard, who would not be able to play in as many games as Liverpool would have liked. Houllier was delighted to find a player of McAllister's ability not only willing but available.

'Macca is very useful because he's got good skill and a cool head,' Houllier said. 'He passes the ball well, doesn't panic or lose his composure, and his experience has come in very handy. That penalty against Barcelona was just what we signed him for, though initially I went for him because I knew Steven Gerrard would not be able to play in all the games. What I didn't know then was what a joy Gary would be to work with. He's still very fit, and his attitude has been superb. He knows he won't play in all the games either, but he doesn't moan and never sulks - he's a real team player.'

As McAllister pointed out, you don't hold Barcelona to two clean sheets by playing as individuals. 'It was a big Liverpool team performance,' he said. Liverpool now need a few more of those in the league, as Leeds, Ipswich and even Chelsea are complicating the race for third position. Because of what happened last season, and because Leeds have done so much with the Champions League place Liverpool tossed so carelessly away, Houllier is haunted by the thought of missing out at the last again. Not even three cups on the sideboard would fully compensate for that eventuality. Houllier would not go as far as Robbie Fowler in suggesting failure to qualify for the Champions League would invalidate the whole season - showing a refreshing reluctance to abandon all dignity in the scramble for Uefa gold, he actually claimed Liverpool might be a little ahead of schedule at the moment - but his voice turned solemn and his expression hardened when he spoke of the absolute necessity of finishing in the top three.

Although it has become the dreariest of clichés, there is no doubt that when Houllier described today's game against Spurs as more important than the Uefa Cup semi-final, he meant it. Liverpool cannot keep watching other people play in Europe. 'The target all season has been to finish higher than we did last year, when we choked at the end,' he said. Houllier laughs at the suggestion Liverpool might be closing the gap on Manchester United - 'How can that be true when they are 20 points ahead of us?' - but is not unduly worried by talk of £50million war chests for team-strengthening at Old Trafford for next season. 'We have to believe in ourselves, to expand and not to shrink,' he said. 'We are a young enough team to do that. I think we need strengthening in certain areas, but we don't need a revolution. Around 80 or 85 per cent of the team is there already, and we will get better as we mature.'

Liverpool did the double over Manchester United this season, but keeping up with the big spenders from down the road is actually the least of Houllier's worries. Keeping up with Liverpool's own traditions, as relentlessly expounded by their legion of former players turned pundits, is far more taxing. 'Managing here is a bit different from managing anywhere else, even when I was manager of France I never felt under the microscope to such an extent,' he said. 'This club must hold the world record for providing pundits, they are on the radio, on the television and in the papers. There are about 20 of them and they all still live in the area. You could field a press team comprised solely of old Liverpool players. That is because of what happened in the past, which everybody knows about, and that is what we have to live up to. And of course we are not good enough, we can never be good enough. But if we can keep improving, which we are, at least we know we are headed in the right direction.

'At this club there will always be the names from the past, but like I keep saying to the boys, it's down to us now to make a name for ourselves.'

'I fancied myself to score all along, fancied it strongly,' he said. 'Barcelona rubbished us a bit, but over the two legs they didn't score and didn't get many chances.' Houllier is matter-of-fact about his reasons for bringing McAllister to Anfield. He was aware his team had subsided late last season through inexperience, and was keen to add a few older heads to his youthful mix to prevent Liverpool losing vital points through naivety. Markus Babbel fitted the bill perfectly, as did Nick Barmby, though Houllier specifically wanted a central midfielder as back-up for Gerrard, who would not be able to play in as many games as Liverpool would have liked. Houllier was delighted to find a player of McAllister's ability not only willing but available. 'Macca is very useful because he's got good skill and a cool head,' Houllier said. 'He passes the ball well, doesn't panic or lose his composure, and his experience has come in very handy. That penalty against Barcelona was just what we signed him for, though initially I went for him because I knew Steven Gerrard would not be able to play in all the games. What I didn't know then was what a joy Gary would be to work with. He's still very fit, and his attitude has been superb. He knows he won't play in all the games either, but he doesn't moan and never sulks - he's a real team player.' As McAllister pointed out, you don't hold Barcelona to two clean sheets by playing as individuals. 'It was a big Liverpool team performance,' he said. Liverpool now need a few more of those in the league, as Leeds, Ipswich and even Chelsea are complicating the race for third position. Because of what happened last season, and because Leeds have done so much with the Champions League place Liverpool tossed so carelessly away, Houllier is haunted by the thought of missing out at the last again. Not even three cups on the sideboard would fully compensate for that eventuality. Houllier would not go as far as Robbie Fowler in suggesting failure to qualify for the Champions League would invalidate the whole season - showing a refreshing reluctance to abandon all dignity in the scramble for Uefa gold, he actually claimed Liverpool might be a little ahead of schedule at the moment - but his voice turned solemn and his expression hardened when he spoke of the absolute necessity of finishing in the top three. Although it has become the dreariest of clichés, there is no doubt that when Houllier described today's game against Spurs as more important than the Uefa Cup semi-final, he meant it. Liverpool cannot keep watching other people play in Europe. 'The target all season has been to finish higher than we did last year, when we choked at the end,' he said. Houllier laughs at the suggestion Liverpool might be closing the gap on Manchester United - 'How can that be true when they are 20 points ahead of us?' - but is not unduly worried by talk of £50million war chests for team-strengthening at Old Trafford for next season. 'We have to believe in ourselves, to expand and not to shrink,' he said. 'We are a young enough team to do that. I think we need strengthening in certain areas, but we don't need a revolution. Around 80 or 85 per cent of the team is there already, and we will get better as we mature.' Liverpool did the double over Manchester United this season, but keeping up with the big spenders from down the road is actually the least of Houllier's worries. Keeping up with Liverpool's own traditions, as relentlessly expounded by their legion of former players turned pundits, is far more taxing. 'Managing here is a bit different from managing anywhere else, even when I was manager of France I never felt under the microscope to such an extent,' he said. 'This club must hold the world record for providing pundits, they are on the radio, on the television and in the papers. There are about 20 of them and they all still live in the area. You could field a press team comprised solely of old Liverpool players. That is because of what happened in the past, which everybody knows about, and that is what we have to live up to. And of course we are not good enough, we can never be good enough. But if we can keep improving, which we are, at least we know we are headed in the right direction. 'At this club there will always be the names from the past, but like I keep saying to the boys, it's down to us now to make a name for ourselves.'

fields.headline: Señor Scouser a Spanish hero
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman's face was a picture of concentration as he offered a few pearls of wisdom about Real Madrid's intention to retain their Champions League crown. With his open-necked shirt and sunny glow, he looked every inch the European footballer. Watching him in his new element, the image of the Liverpool Spice Boy seemed a distant memory... until a question about Real's semi-final opponents allowed the real Macca to emerge. 'Ha-Ha-Ha-Ha!' he hollered, with the deliberate glee of a cartoon villain. While the majority of his team-mates wanted to face Manchester United, he was rooting for Bayern Munich, as any good Liverpudlian would. 'Yeah, I was distraught when I heard the result from Munich,' he said later, with heavy irony.
fields.body:
Steve McManaman's face was a picture of concentration as he offered a few pearls of wisdom about Real Madrid's intention to retain their Champions League crown. With his open-necked shirt and sunny glow, he looked every inch the European footballer. Watching him in his new element, the image of the Liverpool Spice Boy seemed a distant memory... until a question about Real's semi-final opponents allowed the real Macca to emerge. 'Ha-Ha-Ha-Ha!' he hollered, with the deliberate glee of a cartoon villain. While the majority of his team-mates wanted to face Manchester United, he was rooting for Bayern Munich, as any good Liverpudlian would. 'Yeah, I was distraught when I heard the result from Munich,' he said later, with heavy irony.

It was an extraordinarily enjoyable week for McManaman, with results elsewhere, notably Anfield, only enhancing the pure pleasure of being part of the most majestic football team around. European champions twice in the past three years, Real have a tactical sophistication and collective spirit that make the current incarnation even better still. 'We are a lot stronger than last year,' McManaman says. 'We've proved that by doing well in both the league and in Europe. Overall, and especially at home, we are playing very good football and scoring lots and lots of goals.' And how. A half-hour tidal wave of sumptuous attacking play crushed Galatasaray in the Bernabeu last Wednesday. You dared not blink for fear of missing a gorgeous pass or moment of dashing control. At the height of their performance they were simply uncontainable.

Real have developed from the Champions League winners of last May, because their manager, Vicente Del Bosque, has tinkered with the system to excellent effect. Claude Makele, one of the newcomers who has made a tremendous impression, links up with Ivan Helguera to provide a formidable midfield anchor. Thus they are more solid defensively, allowing the free spirits in attack to let rip. And the base is sturdy enough to encourage full-backs Roberto Carlos and Michel Salgado to join in without worrying about being exposed. All in all it's overwhelming.

As far as McManaman is concerned, the manager has almost made life easy for himself. 'His secret is that he just lets the team get on with whatever they want to do. He's right behind the team, and they goes out and play very well.'

What makes Real Madrid so remarkable is that although Luis Figo is regarded as the best player in the world, on their day all his team-mates rise to his level. Raul, who with an exquisite half-volley against the Turks became top scorer in the Champions League - not just in this campaign but in the history of the competition - is one of the most clinical finishers in the business. McManaman on form wreaks havoc in support. Roberto Carlos remains a phenomenon who scares the living daylights out of anyone in his vicinity. The pair combine superbly down the left and the thought occurred that it is little wonder McManaman fails to shine so brightly for England. For any left-sided midfielder, assisting the flank commander from Brazil is a gift of a job.

Sven-Göran Eriksson's European tour last week took him from Valencia to Liverpool via Munich, but had he stopped off in Madrid instead to witness McManaman's electric display the puzzle of how to elicit the same performances in his country's shirt would have given the Swede food for thought. The 29-year-old crafted two of Real's goals with delightfully executed assists. He also demonstrated some leadership skills, showing a mature head when the game degenerated into the unsavoury.

It was a bizarre interlude. Galatasaray's frustration boiled over when Claudio Taffarel threw a tantrum when the crowd wouldn't throw the ball back. He stormed in to fetch it before launching it at them full-pelt. Missiles rained down, Emre chucked some back, Okan collapsed on the turf, and all hell broke loose. Enter Macca and the peacemakers. He approached the fans and convinced them, in true scouse style, to calm down. 'It was a rough game, particularly in the second half when I think Galatasaray were fighting a lost cause really,' McManaman said. 'The tackles were flying in and there was a great deal made of certain things that were thrown on to the pitch. It was a case of calming things down and not doing anything to provoke the referee into any strange decisions.'

At the heart of so many good things for Real on the night, McManaman has surely justified his decision to resist the club's attempt to reduce their wage bill by packing him off at the start of the season. 'I was very cool about it in the early stages,' he says. 'The fact we are doing so well in the League and in the semi-finals of the Champions League just proved everything to me. I always said I wanted to stay here and fight for my place, and if this proves something to other people, well that's fine.'

After excelling and scoring in last year's Champions League final against Valencia, it came as a surprise that Real were so keen to release him. Such is the breakthrough he has made since they would be hard-pressed to try the same trick again.

Madrid have not reigned in Spain since 1996-97 and the league is driving them as much as the chase for European Cup number nine. 'Last year was fantastic but you know we haven't won the league here for four years. So the first thing in everyone's mind was "Let's win the league". We're eight points ahead and ideally we want to win it as soon as possible - not forgetting we've got a very important Champions League date in a couple of weeks' time. It's important we carry on playing well because of the history here. I left one club with a fantastic history at Liverpool and I've joined one with, if anything, an even bigger history.'

So much to look forward to for Macca, a man who is so at home with his Spanish club he can even recommend the traditional venue to celebrate a famous win in Madrid: 'Everywhere!' Intoxicated by the spirit of his renaissance, there is no holding him back.
