webTitle: Wenger must shop if Arsenal are not to droop

fields.headline: Wenger must shop if Arsenal are not to droop
fields.trailText: Arsene Wenger is not looking forward to his summer holidays. Usually a time of blessed rest for your average football manager, Wenger loathes the close season. His past two have been spent locked in frustrating, exhausting and ultimately lost struggles to keep his most coveted talents on board. By the looks of things, he will be embroiled in another web of agents, contracts, dirty tricks and psychological blows all over again come May.
fields.body:
Arsene Wenger is not looking forward to his summer holidays. Usually a time of blessed rest for your average football manager, Wenger loathes the close season. His past two have been spent locked in frustrating, exhausting and ultimately lost struggles to keep his most coveted talents on board. By the looks of things, he will be embroiled in another web of agents, contracts, dirty tricks and psychological blows all over again come May.

Although they tend to get handsomely recompensed, Arsenal prefer top players over top dollar and the thought that the most wanted man in Europe might bid Highbury au revoir at the season's end fills them with dread. If losing Nicolas Anelka was unfortunate, and losing Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit was careless, losing Patrick Vieira would be little short of catastrophic.

Just what the immense midfielder means to Arsenal was strikingly apparent in the grey bowels of the Mestalla Stadium last week. While the media waited for a post mortem on their Champions League exit, the club's senior players drifted silently by. The mood was bleak, the rejection total. That was until Vieira - whose stature as Arsenal's symbol expands by the game - stood strong enough to confront his disappointment and offer his explanations. Controversial they might have been, but at least he was man enough not to hide. With all due respect to Tony Adams, who prefers to deal with his own issues before dealing with his club's, Vieira's aura is such that he is a captain in everything but name.

Once the hard talking was over, he was sporting enough to linger and chew the fat with John Carew, Arsenal's nemesis that night. Vieira, the man whose image was so tarnished when he was red-carded in successive games at the start of the season, cuts an admirable figure these days, off the field as well as on. Arsenal dare not let him go.

They will be praying that Vieira's bons mots were simply an emotional reaction to a sore wound - and he has done this before not too long ago. Remember, at the time of that double dismissal, he stormed off the field and insisted he could not play any more in England, only to recover to such an extent he is in the running for Footballer of the Year.

Fit of pique or no, Arsenal have reached a crossroads. Offloading Vieira would see them spiral further away from the Champion calibre they possessed in 1998; introducing more players who can exert similar influence on a game could help them move onwards and upwards. The Valencia tie was the same old story of the nearly men. Arsenal are second to none when it comes to failing to capitalise from periods of domination. In 1998 they had Vieira, Petit, Overmars, Anelka, Ian Wright and Dennis Bergkamp, who were capable of making it happen with a decisive moment. Today it is hard to look beyond Vieira, Thierry Henry and, on occasions, Robert Pires.

So how to redress the balance? The best teams manage to improve their squads with a mixture of bargains, youth products and big bucks. Arsenal haven't had the right balance lately (the last major star they bought was Bergkamp in 1995 and Ashley Cole is the sole youngster to make the breakthrough). Their policy of signing players for astute fees whose potential is there to be improved - Vieira, Petit, Anelka, Ljungberg, Pires, Lauren, Silvinho, and perhaps Edu all fit into that category - has served them well; now imagine what a Francesco Toldo, Lilian Thuram, Edgar Davids or Mario Jardel would bring to the party? It's time for Arsenal to use the reported £50 million war chest by going flat out for the wish list. They cannot afford to wait for a bunch of Ashley Coles.

When Manchester United required a defender, they broke the bank for Jaap Stam and, although he will be expensive, Thuram's ready-made experience, character and quality could have the same impact. United did the same with Fabien Barthez (Toldo could be a similarly imposing addition at Highbury). United look likely to send for Ruud van Nistelrooy in the summer, and the Brazilian Jardel, who would also cost a fortune, is just the type of striker Arsenal need. Domestically and in Europe, scoring goals away from home has been Arsenal's downfall. What a difference a predator like Jardel could make.

Whether Arsenal remain a shop for luxury goods where Europe's super-rich are keen to drop in and flash their money around, or shift mindset and set about spending some serious money themselves will send out a loaded message. Buying big players will not just appease Vieira but also issue a hands-off warning to his suitors.

Incidentally, it's all very well for Vieira to damn his club's apparent lack of ambition, but perhaps he should consider how his courters barely covered themselves in glory this season. Juventus, Inter and Barcelona would be delighted to call their campaigns 'average'. In reaching the last eight of the Champions League, Arsenal have made considerable progress. Nobody, though, is in any doubt about what is required if they are to be higher still next time around.

webTitle: A big bargain on the never never

fields.headline: A big bargain on the never never
fields.trailText: One moment at Old Trafford last weekend encapsulated what having a centre-forward such as John Hartson has meant to Coventry. I am not referring to either of his two goals against Manchester United, but the reaction of United's Jaap Stam and Wes Brown - arguably the best pair of central defenders in the country - to one of the passes meant for Hartson inside their box. They were so anxious to stop him reaching it that both went for the ball (incidentally, all three players missed it). It is some time since Coventry had a big centre- forward in Hartson's opposition-worrying mould - the last was Dion Dublin, who was transferred to Aston Villa three years ago.
fields.body:
One moment at Old Trafford last weekend encapsulated what having a centre-forward such as John Hartson has meant to Coventry. I am not referring to either of his two goals against Manchester United, but the reaction of United's Jaap Stam and Wes Brown - arguably the best pair of central defenders in the country - to one of the passes meant for Hartson inside their box. They were so anxious to stop him reaching it that both went for the ball (incidentally, all three players missed it). It is some time since Coventry had a big centre- forward in Hartson's opposition-worrying mould - the last was Dion Dublin, who was transferred to Aston Villa three years ago.

The other indication of John's importance to Coventry, of course, can be found in his scoring record. Ten in 23 matches for Wimbledon this season was impressive enough, but in his nine matches for us, his goal average has been even better. This does not surprise me. I have always had a high regard for Hartson, yet a lot of people seem to have the impression that this was a panic buy. The fact is that we would have tried to sign him a lot earlier than we did, but the initial barrier was simply that we could not afford what Rangers and Tottenham had agreed to fork out for him - and what Wimbledon were expecting.

More recently, the next obstacle concerned his old knee problems and the resulting difficulty in securing insurance. It is no secret that we have managed to find a way around that through a sort of hire-purchase deal in which his transfer fee will be paid in instalments linked to his first-team appearances. It is tempting to suggest that his form for us is based on his determination to prove a point to the bigger clubs who ultimately rejected him. There could be some truth in this, but the reality is that Hartson, despite being underrated at various times in his career, does not need to prove anything to anybody. One of the reasons why Hartson might have suffered in comparison with other centre-forwards is his body shape. He's a bit like Paul Gascoigne, in that he is never going to look like a Daley Thompson.

When footballers of his build are playing well, people describe them as being strong and powerful; when they aren't, they are viewed as being fat. In John's case, his weight is something that I have not even thought about. I could not tell you what he weighs, or what his best weight is. All I know is that he is playing superbly. The other reason Hartson has tended to struggle to be recognised as a top-class striker is the perception of him as one of the game's most 'physical' players. His image - endorsed by his former West Ham manager Harry Redknapp's comment that he was like a Welsh rugby union front-row forward - is misleading. It says much about the general perception of him that, in his first couple of matches for Coventry, our players knocked so many speculative high balls in his direction that he must have had an aching neck. I had to tell them: 'John has not come here just to play like this. He can play football, too.'

Since then they have discovered what I already knew: that Hartson is deceptively quick, has an excellent touch and, above all, has a football brain second to none. The best compliment I can pay him is to compare him to Norman Whiteside, my former Manchester United colleague and probably the best of all the big centre-forwards I worked with as a player. Like Hartson, Whiteside had tremendous vision. He was probably slightly the better of the two on the ground - and I stress the word slightly - while Hartson has the edge in the air and in his scoring record. As for his height and power, these are attributes that are as important now as they have always been. The view that the big, traditional-type British centre-forward has become outdated is difficult to sustain when you look at how Liverpool have benefited from the signing of Emile Heskey.

In terms of players who can give teams a strong physical presence in opposing penalty boxes there were a couple of other notable examples in last week's European Champions League quarter-final ties. One was Valencia's Norwegian centre-forward, John Carew, who headed the goal that put Arsenal out of the competition; the other was Bayern Munich's Carsten Jancker, who could easily have scored one or two in the defeat of Manchester United. United might well have wished that they had greater height and power up front than that provided by Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole; a point brought into sharp focus by the fact that they looked at their most dangerous when Teddy Sheringham was on. No doubt, the need for a John Hartson type will not have been lost on Jaap Stam and Wes Brown.

Ten in 23 matches for Wimbledon this season was impressive enough, but in his nine matches for us, his goal average has been even better. This does not surprise me. I have always had a high regard for Hartson, yet a lot of people seem to have the impression that this was a panic buy. The fact is that we would have tried to sign him a lot earlier than we did, but the initial barrier was simply that we could not afford what Rangers and Tottenham had agreed to fork out for him - and what Wimbledon were expecting. More recently, the next obstacle concerned his old knee problems and the resulting difficulty in securing insurance. It is no secret that we have managed to find a way around that through a sort of hire-purchase deal in which his transfer fee will be paid in instalments linked to his first-team appearances. It is tempting to suggest that his form for us is based on his determination to prove a point to the bigger clubs who ultimately rejected him. There could be some truth in this, but the reality is that Hartson, despite being underrated at various times in his career, does not need to prove anything to anybody. One of the reasons why Hartson might have suffered in comparison with other centre-forwards is his body shape. He's a bit like Paul Gascoigne, in that he is never going to look like a Daley Thompson. When footballers of his build are playing well, people describe them as being strong and powerful; when they aren't, they are viewed as being fat. In John's case, his weight is something that I have not even thought about. I could not tell you what he weighs, or what his best weight is. All I know is that he is playing superbly. The other reason Hartson has tended to struggle to be recognised as a top-class striker is the perception of him as one of the game's most 'physical' players. His image - endorsed by his former West Ham manager Harry Redknapp's comment that he was like a Welsh rugby union front-row forward - is misleading. It says much about the general perception of him that, in his first couple of matches for Coventry, our players knocked so many speculative high balls in his direction that he must have had an aching neck. I had to tell them: 'John has not come here just to play like this. He can play football, too.' Since then they have discovered what I already knew: that Hartson is deceptively quick, has an excellent touch and, above all, has a football brain second to none. The best compliment I can pay him is to compare him to Norman Whiteside, my former Manchester United colleague and probably the best of all the big centre-forwards I worked with as a player. Like Hartson, Whiteside had tremendous vision. He was probably slightly the better of the two on the ground - and I stress the word slightly - while Hartson has the edge in the air and in his scoring record. As for his height and power, these are attributes that are as important now as they have always been. The view that the big, traditional-type British centre-forward has become outdated is difficult to sustain when you look at how Liverpool have benefited from the signing of Emile Heskey. In terms of players who can give teams a strong physical presence in opposing penalty boxes there were a couple of other notable examples in last week's European Champions League quarter-final ties. One was Valencia's Norwegian centre-forward, John Carew, who headed the goal that put Arsenal out of the competition; the other was Bayern Munich's Carsten Jancker, who could easily have scored one or two in the defeat of Manchester United. United might well have wished that they had greater height and power up front than that provided by Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole; a point brought into sharp focus by the fact that they looked at their most dangerous when Teddy Sheringham was on. No doubt, the need for a John Hartson type will not have been lost on Jaap Stam and Wes Brown.

fields.headline: Our man in Panama
fields.standfirst: John le Carré's world of seedy spies is brought to vivid life by John Boorman, with a knowing nod to Graham Greene
fields.trailText: John le Carré's world of seedy spies is brought to vivid life by John Boorman, with a knowing nod to Graham Greene
fields.body:
The Tailor of Panama (112 mins, 15) Directed by John Boorman; starring Pierce Brosnan, Geoffrey Rush, Jamie Lee Curtis, Brendan Gleeson

After the critical and commercial failure of his single excursion outside of genre fiction, The Naive and Sentimental Lover, John le Carré returned by popular demand to espionage in 1974 with one of his finest works, Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy. The title gave a deadly twist to a children's playground game and when, more than two decades later, he chose to make his hero a genuine clothier, he gave the novel a deceptively innocent title reminiscent of childhood and Beatrix Potter, The Tailor of Panama.

One doubts if he was consciously thinking of Graham Greene's celebrated, semi-satirical essay on Potter's fiction in which he dismissed the eponymous hero of The Tailor of Gloucester as 'ineffective and too virtuous'. Without doubt, however, le Carré had Our Man in Havana in mind, as he says in his acknowledgements.

Like Greene's novel, The Tailor of Panama is about a British expatriate in an unstable Latin American country put under pressure by British intelligence and inventing, with lethal consequences, a non-existent spy ring and a fictitious political conspiracy. Le Carré's fine book is nearly twice the length of Greene's, denser and less funny, but the movie, of which he is co-scriptwriter with Andrew Davies and director John Boorman, is far superior to, and much tougher than, the film Greene made of Our Man in Havana with Carol Reed in 1960.

Le Carré's equivalents of Jim Wormold, the vacuum-cleaner salesman, and Hawthorne, the very establishment MI6 agent (the characters played by Alec Guinness and Noël Coward in Our Man in Havana) are Harry Pendel (so well played by Geoffrey Rush), the Panama City bespoke tailor, and Andy Osnard (Pierce Brosnan), the maverick MI6 operative who's been posted to the backwater of the Panama embassy as punishment for troublemaking.

Although the comic intrigue in Greene's novel anticipated both the success of Castro's revolution (which followed the book's publication by a few months) and, quite uncannily, the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, Wormold and Hawthorne are figures from farce. Pendel and Osnard have a much greater weight and are altogether, on first acquaintance, less genial.

Both men are frauds and self-deceivers, but their fraudulence and self-deception have a larger political dimension, as we appreciate during the witty courtship between tailor and spy with which the film opens. Pendel, the working-class Londoner who learnt his tailoring in jail, poses as an established Savile Row master and dispenses old- world class to the unscrupulous rich and nouveaux riches of Panama. The spirit of Benny, his late Jewish uncle (an amusing turn by Harold Pinter), hovers over his shoulder giving dubious advice, but Pendel really believes in the snobbish standards and outmoded Englishness that he has espoused.

Osnard, who has seen through Pendel's façade, works for an organisation that, in the post-imperial, post-Cold War world, has become largely redundant. He pretends that Britain has a major role in the world, if one dependent for intelligence operations on US subventions, but his growing cynicism has turned him into an opportunist. When he seduces Pendel - with money and blackmail - into becoming an agent, he wants to believe in 'the silent opposition' of local liberals that the tailor invents, and in a non-existent clandestine scheme to sell the Panama Canal to a Chinese, French and Japanese consortium.

The difference between the two is that Pendel is essentially a decent man, real concern underlying his subservience, while Osnard exists in a moral vacuum. The truly good person, however, is Pendel's American wife, Louisa (Jamie Lee Curtis), a representative of the reality principle. She respects the recently appointed Panamanian executives of the canal company for which she works, and stands in sharp contrast to her half-demented fellow-countrymen plotting against them in the Pentagon.

The film is given a firm sense of reality through the confident handling of authentic locations by Boorman, who has worked in Latin America before in The Emerald Forest and, more recently, in a politically volatile state in Beyond Rangoon. There is no excessive use of local colour and the background is integrated into the dramatic action. Boorman directs with a light touch of a sort that was only to be seen intermittently in his work before his last movie, The General , about the Irish gangster, Martin Cahill. Brendan Gleeson, so superb as Cahill, here immerses himself in the role of a burnt-out ex-revolutionary who becomes Pendel's chief fall guy.

The cleverest trick, which adds to the humour and excitement, as well as underlining the film's meaning, is the casting of Pierce Brosnan, who's never been so good. When he is briefed at MI6's Thamesside HQ by a bland superior, his eyes twinkle evilly at the prospect of easy pickings in corrupt Panama, and we realise that this is a different organisation from that last bastion of patriotism served by James Bond. There have been supposed anti-Bonds on the screen before, but here we have the most confident embodiment of Bond since Connery's day serving himself rather than Her Majesty.

Osnard is suave in the manner of a student of Playboy ; his only piece of advanced technology is a Zippo containing a miniature camera; as a lover, he's violent, sweaty and not irresistible, and his word is not his bond. Just before Osnard arrives at the tailoring shop, Pendel is assuring a corpulent client that the suit he's fitting is the sort Mr Connery wears and that he has the same 'golfer's shoulders'.

webTitle: There's one kind of Congress the President doesn't care for

fields.headline: There's one kind of Congress the President doesn't care for
fields.standfirst: Sexual intrigue in the White House peters out before the end, but Liv Tyler's homicidal beauty goes out in a blaze of gory
fields.trailText: Sexual intrigue in the White House peters out before the end, but Liv Tyler's homicidal beauty goes out in a blaze of gory
fields.body:
The Contender (125 mins, 15) Directed by Rod Lurie; starring Gary Oldman, Joan Allen, Jeff Bridges
Boesman and Lena (89 mins, 12) Directed by John Berry; starring Danny Glover, Angela Bassett, Willie Jonah
Girlfight (112 mins, 15) Directed by Karyn Kusama; starring Michelle Rodriguez, Santiago Douglas
One Night at McCool's (92 mins, 15) Directed by Harald Zwart; starring Matt Dillon, Liv Tyler, John Goodman, Michael Douglas
Under the Sand (95 mins, 15) Directed by François Ozon; starring Charlotte Rampling, Bruno Cremer
The Hole (100 mins, 15) Directed by Nick Hamm; starring Thora Birch, Embeth Davidtz, Desmond Harrington

Most recent movies set in Washington DC have been either political comedies of a fairly farcical nature or thrillers involving high-level malfeasance and cover-ups. So it's pleasing to welcome writer-director Rod Lurie's The Contender, a fairly serious movie dealing with the actual process of politics.

His Vice-President having recently died, Democrat President Jackson Evans (Jeff Bridges), a confident, manipulative Clinton type (but personally uncompromised and seemingly without a wife), nominates Senator Laine Hanson (Joan Allen) as the first female Veep to end his second term with a flourish. He is vociferously opposed by wily right-wing Republican Representative Shelley Runyon (Gary Oldman), chairman of the Congressional committee that will advise and consent in the appointment. Runyon hates Hanson because she's a political turncoat; his preferred candidate is Governor Hathaway of Virginia (William Peterson), a moderate Southern Democrat. So battle commences with wheeling, dealing, mudslinging and FBI investigations. The biggest threat to the confirmation turns out to be the accusation that as a university student Hanson took part in a sex orgy, a matter on which she refuses to comment, believing her private life irrelevant. In fact, the double standard is alive and well in Washington.

The movie is entertaining, plausible, and often very funny, with an outstanding performance from Oldman as a seemingly honest, sincere reactionary. But in the final half-hour or so, the film changes character and direction, losing all sense of balance. A skeleton the size of a dinosaur is dragged from the cupboard of a major character; Senator Hanson states her liberal credo before the committee with accompanying emotional music; and the President makes an impassioned Capraesque address to a joint session of Congress that publicly humiliates his chief opponent and is accompanied by triumphalist chords which threaten to modulate into the 'Ode to Joy'.

Apart from being dramatically phoney and unconvincing, the film ends up misrepresenting the political process, and concludes with the sanctimonious dedication 'For our Daughters'. The Contender is in every way inferior as a piece of filmmaking and as a guide to life in the Capitol to Otto Preminger's 1962 classic, Advise and Consent, which was also a study of a controversial presidential nomination.

Boesman and Lena is about the effects of politics rather than the business of politics - doubly so, in fact. Athol Fugard wrote this, his most Beckettian play in 1969, and his controlled, impassioned assault on apartheid centres on two dispossessed Cape Coloureds, the resilient Lena (Angela Bassett) and her brutalised partner, Boesman (Danny Glover), who drift around the bleak countryside like Vladimir and Estragon. Shot on location in South Africa, the film was directed by the late John Berry, who as a victim of McCarthyism (he was black-listed in 1951 and went into French exile just as his Hollywood career was taking off) was well acquainted with political persecution. I'm not at all sure about his decision to use brief flashbacks showing the characters' earlier lives (including the birth of a short-lived child, a happy township dance, the destruction of their last shantytown hovel), but this is a moving version of an important play.

Writer-director Karyn Kusama's directorial debut Girlfight has elements of every boxing film you ever saw including the Hispanic protagonist's desire to get out of the ghetto via the square ring, the artistic brother who needs help, the weak, unsupportive father, the lover who worries about possible injuries. The difference here is that the protagonist is female, the angry high-school senior Diana Guzman (Michelle Rodriguez) from a Brooklyn project who dons boxing gloves to channel her formidable aggression. However, her boyfriend is also a featherweight contender and due to a new policy of gender-blind matching in New York amateur boxing, the two come up against each other in a climactic bout. This is an engaging, warm-hearted film with a fetching heroine, and with the worst injuries a black eye and a couple of bruises, it's the least violent boxing movie I've seen, and that includes Keaton's Battling Butler and Chaplin's The Champion.

Yet another directorial debut, One Night at McCool's, a very American black comedy, is the work of a Dutch filmmaker Harald Zwart, who began his career in Norway, and the script is by Stan Seidel, an experienced TV writer who died last year before the film was completed. In three complementary overlapping series of flashbacks, naïve bartender Matt Dillon, preening lawyer Paul Reisner and widowed cop John Goodman recall their amorous adventures with the extravagant, homicidal beauty Jewel (Liv Tyler) in a dreary suburb of St. Louis, Missouri. Cleverly, each tells his story to a different listener. The lawyer is on the couch of a highly sceptical female analyst. The cop is making an informal confession to a fascinated priest (Richard Jenkins) who pours them a couple of preparatory whiskies, himself using a communion chalice at the bottom of which he discovers a booze-soaked wafer. The bartender spills his beans to a louche hitman he's hiring to kill Tyler.

The film's climax is casually, lethally violent and there are five deaths in the movie, including a pair of slimy lawyers and - as a radio newscaster says in announcing one of the deaths - 'at least it was a lawyer, not a doctor'.

The film packs an enormous amount of plot into its 92 minutes, but what keeps one watching, apart from the comic detail, is the exuberance of the performances. Liv Tyler relishes the role of Jewel, the ruthless, three-faced accomplice to a criminal low-life, and Michael Douglas, the film's co-producer, has never played anyone as cheesy as the itinerant assassin who chooses a bingo hall for his rendezvous with the bartender. Douglas has an appalling wig with a surf-like quiff resembling that of Johnny Cash, whose 'Wanted Man' is playing in the background when we first see him.

Performance is also what counts in François Ozon's low-voltage Under the Sand, in this case the formidable presence of the handsome 56-year-old Charlotte Rampling as a British widow trying to come to terms with the death of her French husband (Bruno Cremer) after 25 years of marriage. She's a gifted university teacher, though the only time we see her at work she reads a long passage of The Waves to her pupils in English, then ends the class 10 minutes early because she's having an emotional crisis. She communes at length with the very substantial ghost of her late husband, which is rather trying, and has an affair with a pompous publisher, whom she clearly dislikes. Still, Rampling claims our interest and makes a thinly written character compelling.

Nick Hamm's thriller The Hole, opens intriguingly as the dishevelled, blood-stained Liz (Thora Birch) staggers into her expensive co-educational public school in the English countryside to explain how she came to survive an ordeal in which she and three fellow six-formers were trapped for 10 days inside an abandoned civil defence bunker in the woods. Contradictory stories follow as the police and a forensic shrink (Embeth Davidz) investigate.

The horrors of public school life are well attended to, but through a confused narrative and tedious characters, it's the film itself that ends up in a bunker with the director desperate trying to chip it up on to the green.

webTitle: Who was Keane thinking of? Yorke may be only one to go

fields.headline: Who was Keane thinking of? Yorke may be only one to go
fields.trailText: 'The old trees are the real trees,' wrote Hermann Hesse, one of Ottmar Hitzfeld's literary heroes. So it was fitting that the Bayern Munich coach last week invoked the writer in pithy response to criticism that he was in charge of a retirement home for past-it footballers.
fields.body:
'The old trees are the real trees,' wrote Hermann Hesse, one of Ottmar Hitzfeld's literary heroes. So it was fitting that the Bayern Munich coach last week invoked the writer in pithy response to criticism that he was in charge of a retirement home for past-it footballers.

He could afford to. His alleged geriatrics had just beaten the starlets of Manchester United to advance to the semi-finals of the Champions League. Some trees. And standing like an oak in the middle of the Olympiapark on Wednesday night was Hitzfeld's most durable piece of lumber, the 31-year-old Stefan Effenberg.

Hitzfeld's record in Europe, on modest resources, bears comparison with any of his contemporaries, and Effenberg's economy of movement in Bayern's 2-1 win matched the prudence of his manager in the marketplace. So loud off the pitch and calm upon it, the archetypal stroller barely broke sweat and only occasionally left his vantage point in the centre circle as his team protected their 3-1 aggregate lead in the latter stages of an often chaotic second half. He directed traffic and pickpocketed possession when required. It was sublime, artful larceny.

Effenberg would do for Hitzfeld. As would the men who scored the killer goals in the first half, the 30-year-old Mehmet Scholl and Giovane Elber, 28, each of them grateful for the industry on the left-hand side of midfield of the 31-year-old Michael Tarnat. In goal, Oliver Kahn's reflexes were in better shape than any 31-year-old has a right to expect, and everywhere on the park Bayern conveyed a mood of maturity and steel. They played with purpose - as well as total belief that their European experience would prevail.

No such vibe of bravado emanated from United. All week Alex Ferguson had been keen to underline that his players needed to show resolve, a call to arms that might seem redundant in the context of such a big occasion. It was as if he sensed a lingering fragility after a mixed campaign in Europe, and he was reminding his well-paid lovelies that they had better buck up their ideas.

That Beckham was suspended hardly mattered. For a week or more the rumours had bounced around the prints that Ferguson had tired of his superstar's inconsistency and, in the absence of any overnight generosity from the bottom-liners at Old Trafford, was prepared to trade him for Rivaldo. He might even break up the team altogether.

And now he is to sign Ruud van Nistelrooy, it seems, for £18million, half a million less than the sum agreed with PSV a year ago, when the Dutchman broke down with a knee ligament injury that put him out for 10 months. But talk of letting Beckham go, for the moment, is no more than that. Some think it mischievous, or simply indulgent. Eric Harrison, who knows Beckham as well as anyone in football, says it would be 'a backward step' to sell him. Or any of their core stars, for that matter. Harrison, Mark Hughes's assistant with Wales, coached Beckham as a teenager in United's youth team, alongside Ryan Giggs, the Neville brothers, Paul Scholes and Nicky Butt, and says their closeness and understanding is the key to United's success.

'We were very fortunate in that they all came together at the same time and they all helped each other along. They were pals, good pals. And they were determined as a group that they were going to progress together. I'm totally convinced about that. And they have stuck together. I've always said it would be a sad day if one of them split, or if they left for one reason or another, a very sad day for the club.'

What clouds the picture is the curious outburst by the captain in defeat. While the manager was his measured, Scottish self in flat-batting inquiries about new players, Roy Keane charged in with both feet. His assertion that this team might have 'reached the end of the road' and, plainly 'are not good enough', was not merely a rude dismissal of his team-mates. He could have been echoing the sentiments of Ferguson, whose relationship with the board demands more circumspection. Ferguson's admiration of Keane - in this match and generally, as he showed by not criticising his captain after yesterday's sending off - is such that it is inconceivable they have not discussed the rebuilding of a team that, for all its quality, does look in need of peppering up.

Full-scale dismantling, though, would be an over-reaction. And who was Keane thinking of? Surely not Sheringham, 35, the footballer of the year, whom Ferguson has just offered a one-year contract. Or Giggs, who's signed up for five more years, Scholes, the improving Butt, Stam, young Brown, younger Chadwick. Keane himself. One suspects Yorke will be the only sacrifice.

All Ferguson would say was that Real Madrid, Bayern's semi-final opponents, were 'without a doubt' the best team in Europe, particularly so since the purchase of Luis Figo. If that is not an unsubtle hint for more cash, City are the best team in Manchester.

Ferguson is in charge of the richest club in the world - or so we are continually reminded. His task in his farewell season must be to break open the United bank. He's made a decent start.

This month the club revealed extraordinary half-year profits, far removed from the finances of their domestic rivals. In the six months to 31 January, United's turnover was more than £72 million, up 13 per cent; their pre-tax profit was £17.3m, up 42 per cent. Unlike at clubs more reliant on television revenue, the fans have contributed hugely at the turnstiles. Since the seating was expanded from 55,300 to 67,700, gate receipts have risen from £21.4m to £28.4m.

That constitutes considerable terrace pressure for regular success.

United also sealed their partnership with the New York Yankees, as well as agreements with Vodafone and platinum sponsors, worth £11.1m. Then they signed a £303m deal with Nike for 13 years. If they can tiptoe through the football club's rickety wage structure, the money is obviously there to buy players.

What the club also will need in a year's time is a new manager. Of all the speculation swirling about last week, the suggestion that Hitzfeld might replace Ferguson was the most intriguing. And, apparently, the most misguided.

'The fact that my name has been mentioned honours me,' Hitzfeld told Sport Bild , 'but I'm fulfilling my contract here.'

Hitzfeld is an unusual man. His contract runs until 2004 and his commitment is to Germany as much as to Bayern. The Bavarians are Germany's champion, in the old-fashioned sense of the word - and it would be hard to say the same for United, so deep and idiotic is the jealousy they inspire in the country at large.

'The fact that Bayern is the main representative of German football means that one has to identify with the German mentality,' he said. 'First Germany, then Europe and only then South America.'

But then, on Friday, a lumberjack entered the Bavarian forest. Bayern's vice-president, Karl-Heinz Rummenigge, announced that the club were seeking an equity partner to raise £80million for a raid on the world's best footballing talent. The old trees were looking vulnerable. 'I believe that we will see European player earnings reach the levels comparable to US sportsmen,' Rummenigge said.

Goodbye Manchester United, they sang on Wednesday night. Could it be Auf Wiedersehn Scholl, Elber, Tarnat, Effenberg... and hello Rivaldo? Surely not.

fields.headline: Decks and the single girl
fields.standfirst: As Sian Evans transformed herself from cellist to hard house DJ, Amanda Burton became... Amanda Burton
fields.trailText: As Sian Evans transformed herself from cellist to hard house DJ, Amanda Burton became... Amanda Burton
fields.body:
Faking It C4
The Whistleblower BBC1
Your Money or Your Life BBC2
This Is Your Life BBC1

Sian Evans, the star of Channel 4's riveting Faking It, was an improbably sweet, demure 22-year-old classical cellist apparently hired straight from docusoap's central casting: 'Hey, get me a girl with no life but a very big instrument, potentially-pretty-but-deeply-dowdy - glasses, shapeless sweaters, hair scraped back! Y'know - the kinda girl who thinks hard house is chamber music with the volume turned up to 11...'

In TV terms, the delightful Sian was quite obviously a freak, a rare young female of the species for whom Top of the Pops might refer to the first violin in a Boston orchestra. These days, it is no mean feat to be quite so heroically individualistic in a world where every tweenager knows the difference between trance and techno.

Sian's challenge was to take her cello and baggy sweaters to London, where Anne Savage, 'the queen of hard house', would teach her to pass herself off as a club DJ. The baffled, bedazzled outsider ('They're very glamorous,' she said of her mentors, Anne, and fellow DJ, Lottie. 'I did feel intimidated') was immediately hauled off to some West End Club Tropicana where, as a friend of Anne's, the drinks were definitely free and she was taken under the wing of a befeathered transsexual.

Later, as she admitted that 'the music's going to take me a while to like, let alone love', there were mixing lessons on Anne's decks, voice coaching to assist Sian in a necessarily attitudinal method of shouting (the rain in Ibiza falls mainly on the...?), some trendy shopping and groovy primping (tears of joy and a hug for the stylist: 'Oh my God! I can't believe my hair can look like this!') and dancing lessons to give her sheepish shuffle a little Spanish hustle.

There were moments when it all went a bit Pete Tong ('Wrong!' said Sian, chuffed at sussing the lingo), at the party, for example, where Sian tested her skills DJing for some of Anne's cooler-than-thou friends. A Big Boo to the arrogant male guest who made Sian cry by criticising her mixing technique before heading for the door with a shrug - but at least the girls all rallied round for a hug.

Of course, in the end, Sian didn't just pull it off, she triumphed. After playing her set alongside three young female DJs and bullshitting her way through an interview, not one of the (male) professionals picked this confident, knowledgeable, stylish young woman as an imposter in the land of impenetrable hipness, mostly because, as Sian herself observed: 'It's just attitude.'

All-areas access to the cult of coolness is very easily obtained by dressing up your talent in the right trousers and having some influential friends, as one of the judges unwittingly revealed on discovering that Sian had spent just a month in immersion therapy, very convincingly learning his trade: 'It puts me to shame!' I doubt if Sian, surely the only cellist in the Ulster Orchestra who is saving up for her own decks, will ever wear a baggy jumper again.

When it was all over, Anne, Lottie, voice coach Jill ('It was a privilege to watch someone blossom') and Sian all cried, while I snivelled a bit and belatedly realised, with a jolt, that this wouldn't have been half the programme it was - and it was a corker- if the protagonists had all been men. Far from resenting the fact that Sian had super-swiftly faked her way into their world, both Anne and Lottie were fit to burst with maternal pride, which was lovely to watch because, alongside the ability to wear purple nail-varnish and slutty heels, it is the sweet generosity of bonded sisterhood that is one of the very best things about being a girl - and you don't often see it on TV.

In the two-part Easter thriller, The Whistleblower, Amanda Burton faked it as a blonde but she still didn't have much fun. Well, she wouldn't, would she, for fun and Amanda Burton segue about as successfully as a Hear'Say track and a slab of hard house. Still, it was an oddly gripping, if monumentally implausible (and eventually downright silly) drama in which Burton played Laura, the lowlyish employee of a merchant bank who uncovered the laundering of £352 million of South American drug money by her bosses and decided to share this information with the National Criminal Intelligence Service. In short, it was Squealing Witness.

With their lives under threat, Laura and her family dodged murderous Mexicans, bullets and speeding trucks and were rushed into the world's most ineffective witness protection programme. You knew it was all going to go a bit Pete Tong when Burton rejected re-location to Australia (presumably on the grounds of BBC budgetary constraints) with a firm: 'No, we're staying in England!'

Immediately, her husband (Neil Pearson) logged on and started sending emails, the stroppy teenage daughter began ringing her boyfriend from every phone in sight and Laura went off to visit her mother in hospital (Virginia McKenna, with Alzheimer's and about three lines).

I waited - not long, as it turned out - for a scene in which Burton would revisit one of my favourite Sam Ryan moments - a pensive, lip-biting, close-up, preferably in a car. And, lo, it turns out that she can do humourless, secretive and pensively lip-biting as a blonde just as well as she can do it as a brunette. Eventually, after a couple of bloodbaths and a cat's cradle of confusing plot twists, Laura finally ended up as a very silent witness indeed, comatose, but with her roots still in excellent condition. Presumably, just as elaborate reconstructive surgery is offered to US Mafia dons, a full head of highlights is a compensatory perk for those in the British witness protection programme. Not quite enough to tempt you to blow the whistle, though, is it?

In the first of the new series of Your Money or Your Life, US fiscal guru Alvin Hall attempted to give recently separated mother-of-two Wendy a financial makeover. Ostensibly living in the twenty-first century, poor Wendy clearly still believed in fairies and had marooned herself on a fantasy island populated by cloud cuckoos and situated in the middle of a large Egyptian river - yes, she was in denial.

The woman had never opened a bill in her life, much less paid one ('Andy mowed the lawn, did the banking and took the rubbish out'); now that he had left her, she was three months behind with the mortgage repayments but refusing even to consider the possibility of selling the house, working only part-time while filling her wardrobe with new clothes and taking the kids for riding lessons. Get a grip, woman!

I was torn between empathy (I, too, quite desperately, perhaps irrationally, wanted to keep my home when my husband left) and anger (how can any modern thirtysomething woman be so pathetically disabled about opening a bill, for chrissakes, much less reveal herself to be such a smug Hyacinth Bucket: 'I'm quite materialistic. It's a classic suburban lifestyle we lead and I don't want to give it up. It's nice!'). Still, empathy won out - it's a girl thing again - because, in close-up, Wendy was so obviously struggling to put a brave face on things that you could see the tears welling and brimming and then clinging on for dear life to her eyeballs while Hall lectured her about downsizing. Actually, I felt like a complete heel. Poor Wendy.

Six months later, Hall returned to find that Wendy had indeed hung onto her stipply, stencilled house and, apparently, her sanity (which was more than I managed to do), kept off the weight she'd lost on the 'divorce diet' (it's just as effective as high-protein, low-carb) and mastered such essential adult survival skills as how to open an envelope. She was even looking for a full-time job. Just like Sian, Wendy was a woman in the process of learning, albeit rather publicly, that success in most areas of life is often just about attitude. Though it helps if you've got enough money left over each month to get your roots done too. You go, girl!

Finally, for anyone who still fondly remembers last year's This is Your Life with Ian Wright, last week's show was almost a reprise. Actor Patrick Robinson - the RSC, Ash in Casualty - turned out to be Wright's cousin, so here was Ian again, plus the family and friends and all that hugging and matey backslapping and the warm, sincere, loving testimonials. The result was a great deal of touchy-feely, feel-goodery, and probably the best PR Deptford has ever had.

fields.headline: Damned if you do...
fields.standfirst: One in three women has had  an abortion and 92 per cent of us agree with the  right to choose.  So why are we  still ashamed to talk about its  effect on our lives?
fields.trailText: One in three women has had an abortion and 92 per cent of us agree with the right to choose. So why are we still ashamed to talk about its effect on our lives?
fields.body:
'It was as if I had failed somehow.'
'I didn't think it was wrong, but I wish, I really wish, it hadn't happened.'
'I thought: how could I let this happen to me; this kind of thing happens to other people.'
'People think you're careless, irresponsible, immoral - not like them.'
'I couldn't talk.'
'It was a secret.'

In this country between 30 and 40 per cent of women have an abortion; one in three. Two hundred thousand women every year have a pregnancy terminated. They are in their teens, their twenties, their thirties, their forties; they are single women and married ones; childless or with a family.

It is a common experience, although we don't talk of it as common or normal - in fact, we usually don't talk about it at all. It has been legal for over 30 years, and only eight per cent of the population think that it should not be. The site is known as the 'Nuremberg Files' (because, for the anti-abortionists, abortion amounts to a Holocaust of unborn babies); abortions are called 'Satan's food source'. The doctors are 'baby butchers'. Those performing terminations are not just the target of this wrenched, pornographic language but of death threats and physical abuse. Seven have been murdered in the past 10 years.

If David Paintin had lived in the United States, he too would presumably be named butcher and murderer, and his name posted on the site. He is the Emeritus Reader of Obstetrics and Gynaecology at St Mary's, London, a courteous, grey-haired man who for 27 years - until his retirement from the front line in 1990 - performed hundreds, thousands, of terminations. Now he lives in a lovely house in the countryside, reads books about shipbuilding, tends his pretty garden - and remains tirelessly active in the abortion reform campaign and radical in his unblinking commitment to the rights of women to choose.

Paintin's father was a Methodist minister, and he himself used to be a religious man. Now he calls himself an 'almost atheist' and a humanist. In 1956, when he was just starting out as a young and idealistic doctor, he worked with Dougal Baird in Aberdeen, where abortion was only a civil offence. Here they came across the poor and exhausted wives of fishermen, who had more children that they could cope with and who were often at breaking point. 'The women needed abortions,' says Paintin. 'Doctors could do them more safely. It was a utilitarian kind of ethics - no firm, fixed rules, but a practical approach.' He has provided women with terminations ever since. Most of them were early ones (a good 80 per cent of abortions are pre-12 weeks gestation). Some were later. Only a small fraction of one per cent take place after 24 weeks - because a woman had thought she was menopausal, infertile, because she is scared, in denial, in ignorance and terror and swamping panic. 'But yes, I would do those too if a woman requested it and persuaded me that she was justified in her request.'

When I wince at the thought of an abortion this late on, he says firmly: 'In my opinion a foetus is not a person in the way a woman is. Personhood is conferred by the woman giving birth. It is an act. It has no ethical status until it is independent and breathing air.' He smiles dryly, and adds: 'I am well aware that this is a position that some people feel very uncomfortable with.'

I ask him to describe methods of termination, and he does so carefully and unemotionally. There are two basic ways of having an abortion. The first is with drugs, so that labour is induced - an experience much closer, clearly, to giving birth to a baby, and which some women choose precisely in order to participate in the process and to feel a kind of bereavement and closure at the end of it; some even hold the foetus before relinquishing it. The other method is suction. The foetus is pulled out, by a suction canular if it is pre-12 weeks or, later, by dilatation and evacuation. The earlier the easier, both for the doctors and for the woman. 'Some larger foetuses,' says Paintin dispassionately, 'have to be destroyed and pulled out bit by bit; limb by limb.'

He does not gloss over what an abortion consists of, but he does say, unequivocally, that it is actually a good thing. It is the price we pay for women's freedom.

Although it is impossible to know exactly how many women had abortions before the 1967 Act made it legal, it has been reasonably calculated that the Act simply replaced illegal with legal abortions, and serious risk with reason able safety. The graph that shows the rate of abortion over the subsequent years is a pretty steady, gradual increase - with the odd blip here and there, caused by things like the Pill scare and the post-Aids emphasis on condoms (a fallible method of contraception). So, in 1971, there were 94,570 abortions in England and Wales; 10 years later this number had risen to 128,581; in 1999 the number stood at 183,250.

Women are more likely to have abortions in their twenties than teens, thirties and forties. Most women (well over 60 per cent) say they got pregnant because of contraceptive failure. Every form of contraception is unreliable, especially those that require daily management (like the Pill) or are event-led (the slippery cap or splittable condom). If you have regular sex using contraception, then you are not 'irresponsible' if you get pregnant, simply one of the unlucky ones.

Four times more single women than married ones have abortions. Paintin believes this is because married women are more accepting of their role as 'wife'. Single women, he says, are more intolerant of contraceptive failure. And as employment becomes more available for women, the rates of abortion go up. A professional single woman will plan motherhood - and if we have a problem with that image of an ambitious middle-class person ruthlessly putting her career in front of her unborn child, that's because we are still in thrall to the notion of abortion as something which mops up our shameful mistakes.

Abortion is absolutely linked to social conditions. You can see the mirror image of the professional choosing to delay parenthood if you look at the socially and economically deprived. A survey conducted in Tayside recently compared rates of teenage pregnancy and abortion among women ranging from the very poor to the affluent. The most deprived teenagers were a shocking seven times more likely to get pregnant than their privileged peers. But they were several times less likely to have an abortion. Politicians and social commentators may call this behaviour irresponsible and condemn it. But actually these teenagers - who often come from broken families, live in rundown estates, leave school with few or no academic qualifications and have little sense of purpose or hope - are conforming to the adult role models they see around them and behaving in the way that is expected of them. For many girls, becoming a mother makes them into a woman; parenthood is a transition into desired adulthood.

Those who criticise them are really thinking about their own privileged daughters, who have achieved at school and whose life would be thrown off course by having a baby at 16 or 17.

Most women who choose to have a termination are not in extreme circumstances. They are most likely to be in their twenties and to want an abortion for 'social' reasons. There are no 'average' cases, but there are exemplary ones: Louise (let's call her) lives in the north of England. She is a professional single woman in her mid-twenties and two years ago she had an abortion. Eight months later she had a second one. The first pregnancy was a result of a 'one-night thing' with an old friend, shortly after a long-term relationship had ended. She was on the Pill: 'I never considered having it. I didn't tell him, he still doesn't know - but I talked to two friends, who came along with me. I went to the clinic when I was seven or eight weeks pregnant, and had the termination at nine weeks.

'I never thought of it as a baby. I didn't think I was killing my baby and I still don't. I wasn't in a relationship. I couldn't provide the stability I would want to give my children, and that I had myself when I was a child. I didn't feel I was doing anything wrong, but I did feel upset. In the waiting room I sat there with all these other women - I'd thought they'd all be in their late teens, but every kind of woman was there, all of us going through the same thing, and we all sat there and stared at each other, and I wondered what their stories were. It was all done pretty quickly. I was out again after five or six hours. And it was such a relief. But I kept very quiet about it. It's a private thing, and I did feel as if I'd been invaded. I thought of it like cancer - I know it's completely different. But when you really don't want to be pregnant and it's growing inside you, well, I had completely lost control for a while.'

Louise's second pregnancy happened eight months later. 'I was in a relationship. We were using condoms. I never had evidence that it had split; maybe he didn't tell me. It was much worse this time. I said after the first: "It's never going to happen again", and to have it happen again, it was horrendous. I told my boyfriend, and he said: "It's up to you." That made it more difficult, because he was involved, and the decision wasn't so completely obvious. But I didn't want a baby. I wanted my job, my life. I didn't tell my friends about it this time round. I suppose I felt ashamed that it had happened again. At seven weeks I had the termination.

'I didn't have sex for a long time after that. It felt like the end with my boyfriend; I didn't know what to say to him. The door seemed closed. Now - well, I'm never going to be someone who hasn't had an abortion. It's always going to be there. Somehow I felt that these things happen to other women; people who aren't careful, risk-takers. It made the notion of control fragile. Things can happen to you, however careful you are. I know there are some women who experience terrible guilt. I didn't feel that. I think abortions should be available for women like me. I don't think we should feel ashamed. I feel I made the right decision, but I wish it hadn't happened.'

For someone like Louise it was implacably her decision. She had lost control of her life, and by having a termination was regaining it. Every so often a man will try to stop his partner having an abortion, and we enter a jungle of moral issues. Should men have any legal rights over the potential child? Over the bundle of cells inside a woman's body?

A few weeks ago one such case hit the headlines. Stephen Hone claimed the right, as a potential father, to stop his girlfriend, Claire Hansell, having an abortion. He claimed the unborn child as his - his to care for and bring up. But she got to the clinic before he got to the court. There is no middle ground between these two positions, no compromise possible between a woman choosing to be in control of her fertility, body and life, and a man insisting on joint responsibility and rights (ironically, the kind of responsibility that women often urge men to take after the baby is born).

There is a myth that the one-in-three women who have abortions every year don't care, take the decision lightly - that they have casual, unprotected sex and then casual terminations. Women must be made to confront what they've done.

There's no evidence that the decision is reached lightly. I've never met a woman who was casual or light-hearted about it. Ann Furedi, spokesperson for the British Pregnancy Advisory Service, says that many women who assume they would have a termination if the situation arose suddenly find themselves ambivalent when it does; and women who have always sworn they would never have an abortion find they cannot go through with their pregnancy. 'For a woman, it is startling to think that, if nothing is done, in nine months she will have a child and her life will be dramatically changed. Motherhood is no longer an abstract or philosophical idea but a reality. It is hugely important not to dismiss the moral issues of abortion, but yet to put them in the context of a woman's own particular circumstances. Furedi feels that abortion should be easy, the easier the better. The experience should be as forgettable as possible. 'That is not trivialising it. Society should trust women more to make the appropriate choices and moral judgments. Women and their doctors should be trusted a bit more.'

It is a legal and medical requirement to give counselling to a woman seeking an abortion, both to help her consider her options beforehand, and, if she wants, to give her post-abortion counselling. David Paintin says that most women who come to the clinics know already what they want to do, and have already talked to someone (partner, husband, family, friends or doctor). 'There is not a single study that shows that post-abortion counselling helps a woman,' he says. 'Counselling feeds some kind of fantasy we have that the woman should be saved.'

Rachel, who has been a counsellor for several years and has seen 'several thousand' women both before and after their abortions, more or less agrees. Women talk through their options with her beforehand, but usually, she says, they have already decided what it is they want to do. 'Usually they know what they want. They are grown-ups, moral beings. They don't want to sit in front of me explaining themselves in-depth.'

She goes on: 'Quite a lot of women absolutely know what they want, but feel bad about it, or anxious about what social attitudes towards them will be. I am not confident even now, with abortion so widely used, that women feel it's OK to want an abortion without feeling guilty. They say: "Am I some sort of monster that I feel all right about this?" '

'She isn't a monster, of course. She's like all of us. She's Everywoman. Sometimes women come in and say: "I can't believe how many people are out there in the waiting room." It's not a complaint; they feel such relief that they aren't alone.'

Maxine Lattimer is a health worker who sat in on counselling sessions with women seeking abortions over several weeks. The women she listened to were white, black, married, unmarried, middle and working class, articulate and sure, nervous and emotional. One of them had been raped by her husband, who wanted her to give him a child. Several already had children. One was about to return to work after her first baby. One was about to go to college. None of them was 'ready'. Many of them felt the need to justify themselves to the counsellor. They tried to find the right words to explain themselves. They didn't want to feel guilty for something they thought was right.'

People who say 'she should have thought' generally harbour another, puritanical shadow-thought: 'she shouldn't have had sex'. As Ann Furedi says, it is difficult to 'manage' sexuality and 'contain' it. For most of us, sex is spontaneous, passionate and abandoned. Better contraceptive use and more sex education are to be welcomed, but we will continue to take risks and make mistakes.

The English do not deal well with sex; we treat it as both smutty and salacious. Men and women find it hard to negotiate sexual relationships. We tend (no matter how we behaved when we were younger) to think that teenagers really shouldn't be having sex at all.

Moreover, there's a puritanical unease about women's bodies, perhaps a distaste for the messiness of all the female processes. Women bleed, evacuate their eggs monthly, have coils implanted in them; they conceive, their bodies swell, they have foetuses sucked out of their wombs. It's not very natural, is it? Is this why it's kept so quiet, remaining a secret, a guilt, a stigma, a shame: the great A-word, unspoken.

Why I had my abortion

Chantal was 19 when she discovered she was pregnant. When she first found out, she didn't know what to do or how to feel. She told her boyfriend, whom she'd been going out with for about six months, and he simply said it was up to her. 'He didn't cuddle me, though, or tell me everything would be all right.' After a week she built up the courage to tell her parents, who reacted well, discussed it with her, and didn't push her towards her decision. She rang the family planning clinic, told them she wanted an abortion and was booked in for an appointment. She begged her boyfriend to come with her but he refused. He had started to become very distant. Chantal felt she could only really talk to her mother and to her best friend. Her mother went with her to the hospital. Later Chantal split with her boyfriend. She says that without her mother she doesn't know what she would have done. Now she is feeling much more confident about her life, and has a new boyfriend. They are saving up, and want to have a baby together soon.

Liz was 18 when she became pregnant. She had a place at university 'and my whole life was ahead of me'. She and her boyfriend decided not to tell their parents and to arrange an abortion as quickly as possible. But when their friends began to gossip they told their parents. His wanted her to keep the baby. Hers were 'so understanding' about her decision to have an abortion. Looking back, she says she doesn't know 'how I could possibly have thought I'd get through it without them. They agreed with my decision completely and tried to support me.' She was 10 weeks pregnant by the time of the abortion and had 'lots of different feelings about the baby', even though she knew she wasn't going to keep it. She found herself thinking about its sex, what it would look like. Her boyfriend started seeing someone else during this period, 'and everyone apart from my parents seemed to think it was so easy and straightforward to have an abortion. On the day of the operation she was very scared, and 'totally alone. I can honestly say that was the lowest point of my whole life. I felt so lonely, as if no one understood. When I came round from the operation, I thought: "What have I done?" I had such regrets and this terrible pain in my stomach. I was an emotional wreck. My ex-boyfriend and my friends couldn't understand why I was so depressed.' When she started university, however, she felt happy again, although she dreaded relationships for a year. She thinks she made the right decision - 'although it was one of the most awful experiences of my whole life. When I decide to have children I hope I'll be a good mother and that I'll have something to offer them. In the meantime I want to focus on my degree and enjoy being young.'

Carla was 30, with three children, all boys, aged seven, 20 months and 10 months. Carla had miscarried seven times after the eldest. Her husband was going to have a vasectomy after the third child but they had to wait a long time and the hospital kept putting him off. Her eldest son had a heart problem so he needed a lot of attention. The youngest had been in hospital recently with suspected meningitis. Initially Carla thought she had missed her period because of stress. She was very shocked when she found out she was pregnant. At first she decided she would keep the baby, but then thought about the children she had already. The two babies were a lot of work and the eldest would get even less attention if she had another child. It was not fair on them. Carla said she was now feeling positive and would look forward to the future with the three children she has - at least she does have them, she says. Some women can't have children at all.

From case studies conducted by Alison Hadley of Brook and Maxine Lattimer of the British Pregnancy Advisory Service

Abortion in Britain and the USA

1967 Abortion Act passed making abortion legal in England, Wales and Scotland.

1973 The US Supreme Court legalises abortion in the first three months across the US.

1982 Pro-life militant kidnaps an abortion doctor and his wife and holds them for eight days before releasing them unharmed.

1998 Dr Barnett Slepian is shot and killed, bringing the number of abortion doctors murdered in the States to seven.

2000 Abortions in England rise by 20 per cent after Millennium celebrations.

In Britain, abortion is a non-party political issue. The US has 47 pro-life senators and 34 pro-choice senators. Attorney General John Ashcroft is opposed to abortion.

President Bush said in his inaugural speech: 'I will lead our nation toward a culture that values life - the life of the elderly and sick, the life of the young and the life of the unborn.'

Resarch by Kim Bunce and Kirsty Buttfield
