webTitle: St John v St Matthew - and the gospel according to Arnold

fields.headline: St John v St Matthew - and the gospel according to Arnold
fields.trailText:
Polyphony & Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment St John's Smith Square, London SW1
Eightieth Birthday Concert for Sir Malcolm Arnold South Creake, Norfolk
L'amore industrioso Apollo Chamber Orchestra, St John's Smith Square, London SW1
fields.body:
Polyphony & Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment St John's Smith Square, London SW1
Eightieth Birthday Concert for Sir Malcolm Arnold South Creake, Norfolk
L'amore industrioso Apollo Chamber Orchestra, St John's Smith Square, London SW1

The stern clarity of Bach's St John Passion makes it as compelling as any straight theatre. The subject matter may be inherently dramatic, but Bach's complete emotional and empathetic identification with the narrative raises it to new levels of intensity. Compact and sharply etched, oscillating from dark turbulence to radiant serenity, this 1723 setting of St John's Gospel has none of the spacious grandeur of his later St Matthew Passion . Therein lies its strength. No wonder Deborah Warner was persuaded to stage it last year at the Coliseum. That experiment, while not quite convincing in an opera house, renewed our sense of the human drama as well as the devotional purpose in the shorter, and until recently less popular, of Bach's two surviving passion settings.

This year, Polyphony and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment gave a brilliant, supple concert performance conducted by Stephen Layton. It is hard to imagine it done better. They made a strong case for this being the greater work of the pair, as futile a thought to pursue as stating a preference for gold above silver, grass over sky. Yet the power of a great performance is that it banishes in the listener's mind for that moment all possibility of competitive events. The account was not immaculate. Supporting soloists, with the shining exception of the countertenor Robin Blaze, did not seem at ease in their arias, as if they would actually have preferred an opera house to a church-cum-concert hall. But as the Evangelist, James Gilchrist gave one of the most moving and intelligent performances you could want: pure-voiced, expressive, modest and urgent, meticulous but never fussy. Michael George was an ardent and dignified Christus.

In Polyphony, the small, expert choir which Layton formed in 1986, every voice counts. The fewer the number, the more audible any flaw. There were none. Each chorale had its own distinct character. The choruses were immediate and powerful, the whispered interjections of ' Wohin ?' ('Where?') magically certain in their uncertainty. The Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, too, played with springy precision, whether in ensemble or in the numerous solo passages. Special mention must be made of the continuo players. Theirconstant, partly improvised bass line requires special skill and sensitivity, here shown in abundance. At key moments, such as after the Crucifixion, Daniel Yeaden's cello playing had the eloquence of hoarse despair. Organist Gary Cooper's arpeggios and flourishes shaped the music with rigour and subtlety, as if with a wash of colour rather than the full bright pigment preferred by some continuo keyboard players.

Cooper is evidently a rising star in early music. He recently made his solo recording debut with Book I of Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier and appears to be following in the footsteps of an older generation of entrepreneurial keyboard players such as Christopher Hogwood or William Christie. In July, Cooper conducts a new production of Handel's Julius Caesar at South Creake Summer Opera. This as yet little-known Norfolk festival is organised by the Yorke Trust, a small musical charity 'dedicated to helping young musicians gain a foot on the professional ladder'. For their Easter course, students from the Royal Northern College of Music, Manchester, prepared a programme of English choral music, ranging from Byrd to Howells, in honour of Sir Malcolm Arnold's eightieth birthday.

The small vocal ensemble, with many talented young voices in evidence, opened the concert with music from early in Arnold's career, the Two Ceremonial Psalms (1952). The composer, frail but beady-eyed, was present. John Amis paid warm tribute to his old friend who, as he pointed out, has been somewhat neglected by musical opinion because of his self-confessed fondness for tunes, wit and a predominantly conservative idiom. He tends to be known as the composer of nearly 120 film scores, including David Lean's Bridge Over the River Kwai. He would rather be thought of as the creator of nine symphonies, the later ones Mahlerian in ambition. The Proms season is announced this week. Will any be included?

A neglected composer from another era, João de Sousa Carvalho (1745-c1799), only merits a few lines in New Grove II which describes him as 'the foremost Portuguese composer of his generation'. Having heard the Apollo Chamber Orchestra's account of his lively opera buffa, L'amore industrioso, I wonder if this faint praise is not unfairly damning. The conductor, David Chernaik, rediscovered this high-spirited tale of class, marriage and money in the Ajuda Palace Library, Lisbon, together with another 10 operas by the same composer. He considers the piece a 'missing link' between Handel and Mozart. Indeed, the pairs of lovers and the servant dressed up as a notary in order to carry out a hasty marriage ceremony clearly prefigure Cosí fan tutte, showing the tradition from which Mozart borrowed.

Carvalho's effervescent score, given a zestful reading by orchestra and cast, is full of surprise, with a couple of touching arias, some eventful coloratura (for the Countess, Louise Cannon) and much busy tremolando string writing. It felt a touch long. But, if we come clean, how many operas can we mention that do not have their stretches of worthy tedium? My short list can be reduced to Fidelio and Eugene Onegin. Any offers?

webTitle: The legs have it in Wayne's world

fields.headline: The legs have it in Wayne's world
fields.trailText: Duo:logue Linbury Studio Theatre, ROH, London WC2
fields.body:
Duo:logue Linbury Studio Theatre, ROH, London WC2

A beansprout of a leg gleams in the darkness, extending itself towards a light source high in the flies. It could be the antenna of some mutant creature until its owner is revealed as Edward Watson, whose six o'clock arabesque almost rivals Sylvie Guillem's.

In Duo:logue, Wayne McGregor's programme for the Royal Ballet and his company, Random, dancers are fantastic beings. He presents them as contradictions: sexy yet genderless; anonymous and entirely individual. In his creations for Random, he uses digital technology and laser lighting to make flesh and blood seem as insubstantial as computer animations. Here, he lets his performers create their own illusions through the speed and skill with which they move.

The triple bill is a dialogue between ballet and contemporary dancers, brought together by the Artists' Development Initiative programme at the Royal Opera House. McGregor started out last year with seven volunteers from the Royal Ballet, led by ADI's director, Deborah Bull. Their joint choreographic sketches, pulled together as Symbiont(s), first appeared in the Clore Studio Upstairs. Repeated downstairs in the Linbury as the opening section of the evening, the reworked piece has greater coherence.

There are astonishing solos, revealing how well McGregor and the Royal Ballet dancers have understood each other. Watson has a feral elegance as he skies those tendril legs, Bull is naughtily insolent, Jenny Tattersall skitters around like an imp on speed.

The central pas de deux for Bull and Watson is a push-me-pull-you challenge, endearingly ungainly. McGregor's inexperience in dealing with lifts is evident - the dancer in the air looks good, while the handler lurches like Obelix with his menhir.

Symbiont(s) has rough edges, for all its performers' slickness. The choreographic writing isn't joined up: the pas de deux is in capital letters, other fragments in unfinished paragraphs. Lucy Carter's lighting flicks between corps and soloists as though she and McGregor are switching between files on a word-processor: let's have a look at that; remember that bit?; how about this?

Next comes Aeon, the finale of McGregor's millennarian trilogy for his own company. In that context, it is the synthesis of the preceding works, a pure dance celebration to an outpouring of baroque music by Marin Marais. Placed here, Aeon is the antithesis of Symbiont(s).

Random's dancers are less showy than the Royal's, more like unself-conscious children at play. They tumble fluently through space, impelled by the manic bowing of the string quartet. When they combine at the end, they couldn't be less like a corps de ballet. Sleek as seals in shimmering leotards, they remain resolutely themselves.

When the two groups combine for brainstate , their differences are all the more obvious for being played down. Costumed by Ben Maher, everyone looks eerily alike, with no distinction between the sexes. At the start, a gang of men could be women, strutting in stiff-legged poses. Yet when the women do the same thing, their body language is entirely other. It is fascinating to see how the Royal Ballet dancers can fuse, when they choose, into a unit; a star soloist, however, knows how to attract attention away from the troops in a way the Random lot never do.

Although brainstate 's waves of activity are mesmerising, they are less than their component parts. By the end of the evening, McGregor's ingenuity is stretched, his dance idiom familiar. The ADI experiment, however, has helped him probe further into the workings of physical intelligence. He and the dancers are still discovering just how clever they might be.

Yet when the women do the same thing, their body language is entirely other. It is fascinating to see how the Royal Ballet dancers can fuse, when they choose, into a unit; a star soloist, however, knows how to attract attention away from the troops in a way the Random lot never do. Although brainstate 's waves of activity are mesmerising, they are less than their component parts. By the end of the evening, McGregor's ingenuity is stretched, his dance idiom familiar. The ADI experiment, however, has helped him probe further into the workings of physical intelligence. He and the dancers are still discovering just how clever they might be.

fields.headline: Join the celestial host
fields.standfirst: Al Murray's Pub Landlord didn't work on TV but makes a triumphant return to the stage. The same isn't true, however, of Baddiel and Skinner
fields.trailText: Al Murray's Pub Landlord didn't work on TV but makes a triumphant return to the stage. The same isn't true, however, of Baddiel and Skinner
fields.body:
The Pub Landlord: My Gaff, My Rules Playhouse Theatre, London WC2
Baddiel & Skinner Unplanned Shaftesbury Theatre, London WC2

Anyone who may have developed reservations about Al Murray after Time, Gentlemen, Please, Sky's dubious £3 million attempt to turn his award-winning stand-up act into a 22-part sitcom, needs to get themselves down to the Playhouse Theatre for immediate reassurance.

Murray, a triple Perrier Award nominee and eventual winner in 1999, has brought the Pub Landlord back to his rightful context in one of the finest live comedy shows to grace the West End in recent months. Unencumbered by the cast of peripheral 'regulars' necessary to plump the show into sitcom format, but entirely unnecessary to the appeal of the central character, the Pub Landlord returns Murray to form in a new, two-hour show which demonstrates his superlative skill in blending improvisation with prepared anecdote so slickly it's impossible to see the seams.

The Pub Landlord's essentials haven't changed since his origins in Harry Hill's Edinburgh show Pub Internationale, which brought the first Perrier nomination in 1994. All the old riffs echo through the new show - the fierce demagoguery, the neck tics, the unshakable, misplaced pride in his own version of the British Empire, the hatred of all things French and the prurient homophobia - but rather than going for the guaranteed laugh, Murray rations the catchphrases to his fans like sweets to children so they don't get sick of them.

Murray, 32, has always excelled at the confident, off-the-cuff repartee that delights live audiences. The Pub Landlord's endearing bigotry is engineered to exactly this kind of comedy, which was the most obvious weakness in translating the character to television. The reliance on improvised banter, however, must have worked in Murray's favour after the computer containing all the material for this show was stolen from his house last month, leading to a near-cancellation and the rapid rewriting from memory in five weeks of an act that would usually require a year to prepare.

Not that you'd know any of this from the polished professionalism of the delivery. From the moment he steps on to the stage under the shadow of a giant heraldic crest bearing the motto 'Pint for the Fella, Glass of White Wine for the Lady', Murray's speed of thought is stunning. Even an early hiccup with the lighting, which left him stranded in eerie gloom for the first five minutes, was cheerfully acknowledged and dismissed with 'Ah, you found that 50p then, Tony,' when the technicians solved the problem.

Anyone in the first two rows has, knowingly or otherwise, signed up as part of the show, and the audience didn't let him down. Who would imagine so many laughs could be extracted so effortlessly from saying 'Martin' repeatedly in a silly voice? And, given the Pub Landlord's opinion of computers, don't sit within his line of sight if you work in IT, unless you want 600 people to go home remembering you as the bloke whose thrills are found in looking for an elf behind a wall.

So sharp are Murray's responses to whatever his audience throws at him that anyone who hasn't seen him live could be forgiven for thinking at first that he's set plants in the front row, but after a few minutes he pulls a fast one and leaves the stage for the rest of the first half to his support, Jason Freeman. (This is a sneaky trick being employed increasingly by comics and bands alike to get round the perennial problem of the audience remaining steadfastly in the bar throughout the support act - Eminem did it recently.) Freeman, who appears in Time, Gentlemen, Please and has previously worked with Richard Herring, Jenny Eclair and Simon Munnery, works hard at the unenviable task of entertaining an audience who hadn't come to see him and wouldn't remotely have cared if he hadn't been there, but the volume of the laughter plummeted. This was in spite of an energetic delivery and a few one-liners that hit the target, but his slot was just that bit too long to sustain an audience keen to get back to the Pub Landlord.

Murray's uninterrupted, full-throttle second half was a showcase of ruthless stand-up brilliance, keeping the audience closely involved in more convoluted, topical anecdotes and philosophical meanderings with so many quickfire lines - taking you by surprise and making you spray beer over the row in front - that it's impossible to quote them singly.

This kind of improvised comedy requires the co-operation of a politely respectful audience, which is the main difficulty with Baddiel and Skinner moving their Unplanned show from television to the Shaftesbury Theatre. While Murray has his character as a buffer zone, Baddiel and Skinner are so well-known as themselves that it's easy to feel you know them as mates and are not really at the theatre at all. The opening night demonstrated the catch-22 of improvised comedy: you want your audience to be uninhibited enough to join in, but not so much that they want to get on stage and be funnier than you.

The show follows exactly the format of the television series, but without the intervention of the ITV swearing tsars. Left to their own devices, Baddiel and Skinner flashed the witty feed-and-response that made the television show original, but the audience wanted knob gags and after a brave attempt to make a joke that demanded a rudimentary historical knowledge, they gave up and plunged straight down to where the ready laughs could be found.

Of course, no one would go to this show expecting Stoppardian dialogue, and the problem is not in the content - it's what you expect from professional lads making jokes for other lads, and often funny in spite of that - but in the venue. Everyone wanted to be heard, and the theatre is too big for the performers to be aware of what's happening beyond the first few rows of the stalls, but this didn't stop the enthusiastic hecklers at the back. Perhaps Baddiel and Skinner could follow Al Murray's example and confiscate a few pints before they kick off - and not just from the ladies.

fields.headline: The renegade of hip hop
fields.standfirst: Michael Franti has convictions, but not the kind people expect in rap, says  Burhan Wazir
fields.trailText: Michael Franti has convictions, but not the kind people expect in rap, says  Burhan Wazir
fields.body:
In 1991, a rap group called the Disposable Heroes of Hiphoprisy released their debut album, Hypocrisy is the Greatest Luxury. With its seductive, intelligent rhymes, the album marked hip hop's graduation to documenting modern concerns.

With songs like 'Socio-Genetic Experiment', 'Television: the Drug of the Nation' and a cover of the Dead Kennedys' 1989 anti-Republican anthem, 'California Uber Alles', the group inaugurated a new age of literate black music.

The album was acclaimed in The Face, the NME and Rolling Stone, but was dismissed by US urban bibles such as the Source and Vibe magazine. And while the duo subsequently released a spoken-word record with William Burroughs, they soon disbanded.

Disposable Heroes' founder member Tse hasn't entered the studio since his partnership with Michael Franti dissolved. Franti, after a lengthy hiatus, returned with a group called Spearhead which, combining spoken word, poetry, live guitarists, jazz vocalists and DJs, was reminiscent of early Gil Scott-Heron: garrulous, opinionated and passionate. Two albums - 1994's Home and 1997's slightly disappointing Chocolate Supa Highway, while critically praised by the conventional press, were trashed by their black peers.

However, Spearhead's latest effort, Stay Human, sees Franti genuinely stride into musical adventurism. The record, interrupted by news clips and talk-show discussion that debate the nature of the death penalty and black-on-black crime, is, in many ways, as pioneering as all its references, the Watts Prophets and the Last Poets. Franti, realising his country is becoming a harder, less tolerant place, has recorded his own assessment of local social ills.

Sitting in the basement of the Trocadero Centre in Leicester Square, Franti shifts uncomfortably at the mention of political music. 'Politics - that's almost like an offensive word.' He throws his head back and laughs: 'Back in 1992, I used to say that it was impossible to make political music. Now it's nearly impossible to make these records.'

In the US, Franti is releasing Stay Human on his own, independent Six Degrees label. 'With the lack of political conviction around, making music this conscious isn't seen as artistically challenging - but career suicide.'

The rapper has recently been involved in a series of high-profile public protests: Seattle's anti-World Trade Organisation demonstrations, concerts to highlight the case of jailed former Black Panther leader Mumia Abu-Jamal and the campaign to free native American activist Leonard Peltier, once considered pardonable by Bill Clinton.

'People don't take a stand any more,' he says. 'And I've always been interested in the anti-globalisation movement. You see the effects of globalisation whenever you travel to Africa; that's where it's being played out.

'I guess I got bored with making music that was so loud and obnoxious. It was too easy to replicate it live - because it was all pre-programmed; that, I felt, began to limit me as a performer. I'd much rather try to take a song into a completely different direction and fail musically. At least it shows some sense of adventure.'

Stay Human, while undoubtedly a clarion call to hip-hop consciousness, probably won't be picked up by the black publications which still advocate rampant consumerism. And Franti, still only 34, already sounds like a battle-hardened renegade. As I leave the interview room, he shrugs: 'How many rap groups are genuinely saying anything controversial these days? Rap music is becoming the most timid artform of all.'

Having disowned the clattering, machine-driven fury of his past, Franti is now finding it hardest to make himself heard using only the simplest of idioms - the spoken word.

Michael Franti performs at The Scala, King's Cross, London N1 on 1 May. Stay Human is released on Parlophone on 7 May

webTitle: They've found a little Nietzsche for themselves

fields.headline: They've found a little Nietzsche for themselves
fields.standfirst: Papa Roach look horrid, moan about everything and blister eardrums. Not bad, I suppose
fields.trailText: Papa Roach look horrid, moan about everything and blister eardrums. Not bad, I suppose
fields.body:
Papa Roach Brixton Academy, London SW9

I've been suspecting it for some time, but now I know that I'm well and truly past it. When the 12-year-old boy offers me some of his spliff, I don't quite know what to do. What is the etiquette with spliff-toking children at nu-metal concerts? In the end, I opt to tell the truth. 'I don't like it, never have,' I yell above the deafening, grinding din that, in this setting, could only be described as 'musical' if a tram rolling over your head could be described as 'gentle'.

In between greedy tugs on his spliff, and bouncy little movements to the Papa Roach sound, the boy manages to make a pitying 'No way, momma!' face. It's like observing a squat punk in embryo, or a stoned Mouseketeer. However, when I ask him how old he is, he instantly replies: 'Sixteen.' (Lying little git). Then he is gone, and I am left alone with my thoughts, which go something like this:

Should I be 'mum', and go and check if the hyperventilating girl who got trampled in the mosh pit, with teenagers jumping up and down on her chest, is OK? Or should I be 'policewoman', and stand at the side, boxing the ears of hot-faced, spaced-out boys and girls who swarm around the Academy, weaving in out of the grown-ups in an effort to blend in and evade the bouncers? Or should I just be 'music journalist', ignore it all and concentrate on observing the concert, in an attempt to finally make sense of that noise Papa Roach make; the strange, whirling, confusing cacophony that is part simian, horrible, anyone-could-do-this thrash, part beautifully timed, intense, choreographed, not-everyone-could-do-this majesty?

That is the thing with Papa Roach. They are a band of two parts, only one of which is ugly. (Even their mothers would have to admit that Papa Roach - Coby, David B. Tobin, Jerry - look like Henry Rollins after the bomb has dropped.) According to themselves, Papa Roach are individuals, unique, 'out there', man, but really they are one of those American bands who have listened to Faith No More, Guns N' Roses and the Beastie Boys too much, too long and too hard. Now they roam the earth in their horrid baggy knee-length shorts, looking vaguely like people who might skateboard against the Government, and sounding like they've spent their entire lives with society standing on their corns hard, and neglecting to apologise.

Needless to say, Papa Roach songs ('Angels and Insects'; 'Dead Cell'; 'Broken Home'; 'Binge'), from their huge-selling album Infest, are about alienation, despair, how nobody under stands them, and how awful life is. Their hit, 'Last Resort', sounds like Axl Rose moaning to his therapist through a megaphone. One day, a streetwise band will come along and tell the world that they are perfectly happy and having a wonderful time thank you, but that band is not Papa Roach. They are too busy doing their fantastic impersonation of disaffected youth for their fans, old, young and very, very young.

What saves Papa Roach from mediocrity is probably that they were together several years before they 'made it'. Watching singer Coby swaggering around the stage, asking audience members for a spliff, and solemnly intoning that what hadn't killed him had made him stronger (thank you, Mr Nietzsche), you can tell that Papa Roach have worked very hard to get where they are today, put in long hours, sweated buckets of blood and Kool-Aid. Which probably explains why they can really play.

Even as I rubbed the gasping, trampled-on girl's arm and begged her to drink some water, I could hear that Papa Roach were a tight outfit, perfectly in synch with each other, profoundly committed to making a noise. The question is, are Papa Roach talented, or are they Zeitgeist -surfing charlatans? Are their tunes worth the effort it takes to navigate the eardrum-blistering coating they give every song they perform?

As I left the Academy after the show, I realised that I was no wiser than when I went in. Maybe that's the thing with Papa Roach: you don't know where you stand with them. All you know is that you don't want to be standing right in the middle of the mosh pit, where people's heads are used for trampoline practice.

webTitle: The way we live now: Splitting the difference

fields.headline: Splitting the difference
fields.standfirst: The new family
fields.trailText: Splitting the difference.
fields.body:
At last, I can claim membership of an exclusive club. It's not the hip and Moroccan Momo in the West End, nor the Elmwood Tennis Club in Harlesden; this club is the rosy-cheeked, psychologically kosher, alternative to the bust'n'bitter brigade. Cosy, inviting and only a little bit sickening - it's the exes-as-bosom-buddies club.

Of course, Mick is a lifelong, fully paid-up member, whereas I am a mere novice-in-training. He manages to live next door to ex no 2, Jerry, while appearing in publicity pictures for the recently resuscitated Aspreys with Bianca (ex no 1) and daughters, Elizabeth (by ex no 2) and Jade (by ex no 1), while researching new possibilities (Sophie Dahl and a 29-year-old Venezuelan) in between. But then he is a grandfather, and I am only a mother as yet.

And then there's Jerry. Forever heaping praise on her ex (variations on 'he's a fantastic man but a lousy husband'), she appears at parties with him, thus ensuring their four children have a together-through-thick-and-thin image of their parents. Other high-profile members include Fergie and Andy, who share a home and lavish support and compliments on one another whenever the press get within spitting distance.

By comparison, my ex and I are on the gentler slopes of a broken relationship. We were 12 years together, have a son who is now 14 years old, and despite the jagged silences and explosive hurt that threatened our ex-relationship, eventually we both knew we must prioritise our son. Gradually, as our son was exchanged between us, no words became some words, then a whole conversation and then laughter. One day, over a lager at our son's school summer fair, we managed to discuss our new partners. 'What is it?' I asked mischievously, 'that was lacking in our relationship and has been replaced by a mysterious German component?' We couldn't stop laughing. It had turned out that both of us were having relationships with Germans. Mine came from the north (more serious, more melancholic), his originated from the south (lighter and softer). His lasted longer.

And so our relationship as exes stuttered, spluttered and finally guffawed into existence. What's more, I liked his new partner. She even babysat once or twice, whilst we (his parents) were going out, separately, that is. Slowly, my ex and I realised we actually still got on. That a shared history is something that never goes away and is reassuring to dip into, from time to time. The sexual attraction may have expired, but our sense of humour has remained the same.

By this time, I'd got a new flat and his flat was still only 10 minutes away. Our son stayed with me most of the time, but visited them a couple of nights a week. Other people congratulated us on our incredibly easygoing relationship. Amid the horror stories of acrimonious custody battles and financial warfare, our separation was civilised by comparison.

More recently, our ex relationship has deepened. We are both single again and our son is, of course, much older. Last February, I went away with a girlfriend to a wedding in Death Valley which took place during term time. My ex was able to move into my flat for two weeks and look after our son. We were all content. I got to go away and regenerate; they got to hang out together and do 'boy' things without me around. On my return, he cooked me a meal and promptly departed.

Old friends invariably want to see him because they remember and like him. For carnival - which I do my utmost to avoid - an old girlfriend came up from Bristol with her two sons. fields.headline: Sweet and light
fields.standfirst: Jim Ainsworth reviews restaurants with traditional English puds
fields.trailText: Jim Ainsworth reviews restaurants with traditional English puds.
fields.body:
If traditional British puddings are normally associated with heaviness and stodge, that is perfectly understandable. They developed under conditions where an active outdoor life demanded warmth, fuel and richness. Even today, some of the most ardent purveyors of our national pudding heritage are to be found in the Lake District, among them Peter and Sue Dixon at White Moss House (Rydal Water, Grasmere, Cumbria, 01539 435 295). The Dixons' repertoire takes in such steamed classics as Huntsman's and Guardsman's puddings. Peter Dixon also makes bread and butter, Cabinet, sticky toffee, Queen of, and Mrs Beeton's chocolate puddings, though he defers to modern preferences by making them lighter and fluffier than he once did.

Another Lake District classic is the 'icky sticky toffee pudding' that Francis Coulson introduced at Sharrow Bay (Ullswater, 01768 486 301) back in the 60s. Opened in 1948, this was the nation's first real country-house hotel, and a pioneer of fine cooking. Continuity is prized here, so the trend has been for puddings to be lightened a little, to have less sweetness than before, rather than to be ditched in favour of some fusion dessert. There's also Eve's pudding, steamed jam roly-poly, and a revamped bread and butter pudding.

One of the best-known modernisers of British food is Gary Rhodes. His bread and butter pudding is an eggy, vanilla-rich, blowtorched classic, served in all his restaurants, including the two branches of Rhodes & Co (Waters Reach, Trafford Park, Manchester, 0161 868 1900; and 3-15 Rose Street, Edinburgh, 0131 220 9190). Bakewell tart has also been given a makeover, as has rice pudding, where the rice is laid over caramelised and marinated orange segments, drizzled with orange whisky syrup and served with air-dried orange crisps.

Rhodes first came to prominence when he worked at Castle Hotel (Castle Green, Taunton, Somerset, 01823 272 671) which still makes Black Forest gteau, Cabinet pudding, and a cold dish of rhubarb jelly with a top layer of vanilla-speckled cream and thin strands of semi-dried rhubarb. The two branches of owner Kit Chapman's more informal Brazz (Castle Bow, Taunton, 01823 252 000; and 10-12 Palace Gate, Exeter, 01392 252 525) serve sticky toffee pudding with fudge sauce.

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide.

fields.headline: Mind over maternity
fields.standfirst: After three unexplained miscarriages in four years, Hilly Janes turned to hypnotherapy for help
fields.trailText: After three unexplained miscarriages in four years, Hilly Janes turned to hypnotherapy for help.
fields.body:
It was a good job I went on the bus and not in the car. I could barely walk in a straight line after our first session, let alone see straight. One eye refused to focus. I floated down the road to a coffee bar and ordered a strong one. I needed two.

So that was how it felt to be hypnotised - profoundly relaxed, no sense of time passing, my weight sinking into the therapist's couch, his voice gently intoning behind me, rather like when you know you are about to doze off on the sofa in front of the TV. Yet somehow I knew that I would be able to get up if I wanted to.

It is not far as the crow flies from Terry Morris's cosy little consulting room in Shoreditch to the department of reproductive medicine at University College Hospital in Bloomsbury, but the intuitive, therapeutic world of hypnotherapy and the rigours of conventional medicine couldn't be farther apart. I was visiting both for the same reason, however: to help me have another baby.

After my first successful pregnancy I had miscarried within the first 12 weeks three times in four years. Although miscarriage is probably the most common cause of young women being admitted to hospital apart from having a baby, and it is estimated that a quarter of all conceptions end this way, the chances of it happening again and again are much smaller. Only 1 per cent of women lose three consecutive pregnancies. About a third of those aged under 40 will have a successful pregnancy eventually.

Fifty per cent of these recurrent miscarriages are unexplained. My age certainly increased the odds of genetic abnormalities in the foetus causing the losses, but I had our first child at 40 and the pregnancy had been completely trouble-free. Blood tests showed my blood wasn't prone to clotting, which can affect the supply to the placenta; my hormone levels were normal, and there was no sign of an autoimmune disease such as lupus, which can cause miscarriage. Karyotyping, a genetic test of both partners to determine individual chromosome patterns, suggested nothing unusual.

Doctors who treat infertile couples say they are the only patients who are desperate for you to find something wrong with them. If you say everything is normal, they are distraught. Miscarriages create another set of problems.

'Anxiety about the outcome of your next pregnancy means there is a double burden to carry,' says Ruth Bender Atik, national director of the Miscarriage Association, a support group. 'You are worried that worry will make it worse. It helps to do something that makes you feel you have some sort of control - that you are doing everything you can to nurture your baby.'

Which takes us back to Terry Morris. Somewhere I had read an article about hypnotherapy and miscarriage. What could I lose by giving it a try? I certainly needed to relax. The first two miscarriages occurred while I was holding down a 50- hours-a-week, caffeine- and adrenaline-fuelled, high-pressure job. A glass of wine and a cigarette or three were my short cut to switching off at the end of the day. Even the most basic advice for women trying to get pregnant starts off with cutting down on those three. Although I never drank coffee in the evening I had difficulty getting to sleep and I'd wake several times in the night fretting about something or other.

I found some hypnotherapists in my area in the Yellow Pages. I chose Terry because I liked the sound of him most and he claimed to have treated successfully a busy lawyer who had experienced difficulty in getting pregnant. Although I had left my job by then, it was 18 months since I had last conceived and I still wasn't sleeping properly. Our son had started asking when he was going to have a baby sister.

Terry, a former biology teacher and a qualified hypnotherapist with a PhD in psychobiology from London University, spent most of the first session (of six) discussing my reasons for coming and how he thought he could help me.

'I'd stick my neck out and say relaxation is 40 per cent of the way to solving any problem - be that depression, phobias or anxieties,' he says. Hypnotherapy, he explained, is thought to produce endorphins, which are natural tranquillisers, and to access the subconscious, blocking out conscious negative associations. I certainly had plenty of those. My reproductive system was playing lots of nasty tricks on me and I didn't trust it an inch. I was convinced my eggs were stale. In my imagination they were like hard boiled ones, with a grey ring around the yolk.

Terry helped me relax, using breathing and counting techniques. Visualisation exercises followed - imagining sinking further and further into warm sand on a deserted beach, or walking down a spiral staircase into a deeper, calmer place. Terry teaches many of his patients self-hypnosis to reduce their dependence on him. 'And if you don't practise regularly,' he says, 'you get rusty.' I would practise in bed at night, and my insomnia disappeared rapidly.

A couple of months after finishing the course I was pregnant again, but my father had recently died, after years of failing health and a short but upsetting illness - not the least stressful of times. I miscarried again. Enough was enough. The roller coaster of emotions, not to say the psychological and physical set backs, were taking their toll on our marriage. We decided to get on with the rest of our lives and accept that our son would never have his baby sister.

No prizes for guessing what happened next. Physically, this fourth pregnancy was trouble-free. I had been encouraged to return to UCH for early scans, intended to be reassuring, yet now I feared the worse, and would snap the doctor's head off and burst into tears. All was well, but the prospect of more diagnostic scans and tests filled me with dread. My husband suggested that more hypnotherapy might help.

As well as helping me to calm down, Terry now encouraged me to imagine my body, and my womb in particular, as a warm, nurturing place. I was fortunate, too, that my consultant at UCH, Patrick O'Brien, was the gentlest and most reassuring of men. Last October he delivered a perfect baby girl with beautiful blue eyes. Could the stress really have played such a large part, and the hypnotherapy have helped?

Stephen Franks, professor of reproductive endocrinolgy (how the relevant parts talk to each other through hormones) at Imperial College, London, observes that women often miss a couple of periods when they are stressed by revising for exams, moving house or travelling a lot. 'It's not a persistent problem, but it is reasonable to suppose that it's a stress-related phenomenon that interferes with ovulation,' he says. He describes studies conducted by Professor Sarah Berga, at Pittsburgh University, of women whose periods stopped for no obvious reason. They were found to have abnormally high stress levels. 'It seems that the pituitary gland is not sending the right signal to the ovaries. This implies a problem in the brain,' he suggests.

'How stress might interfere with ongoing pregnancy is a bit of a black box,' he continues. 'There are psychological factors, and that stress is an important one can scarcely be doubted, but whether it's to do with stress hormones like cortisol and adrenaline we just don't know.'

Lesley Regan, professor of gynaecology at Imperial, runs a large miscarriage clinic at St Mary's hospital, west London. She has studied what happens to women suffering recurrent unexplained miscarriage who have been offered no medical treatment, but simply 'TLC' - tender loving care.

The results are remarkable. Her former senior research fellow, Katy Clifford, who has an MD in recurrent miscarriage and is now a consultant gynaecologist at St Mary's, explains. 'In one study, 200 women who had experienced recurrent miscarriage were offered TLC - the chance of a weekly visit to a clinic for a chat and a scan, open access to a phone line and a lot of reassurance. Fifty of the women chose not to come, mostly for geographical reasons, and there was a much higher success rate among those who did.'

She also describes a study where half the women were given a hormonal treatment and half were offered a placebo. Both groups were offered TLC, and the expectation was that the group receiving the medical treatment would do better. But the outcome was significantly improved for both groups - around 70 per cent of those under 40 did not miscarry the next time, compared to the usual 30 to 40 per cent. 'We can't explain it,' Clifford says. 'But it is so consistent with other similar studies that it can't be a fluke.'

Further work is underway at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine into the behavioural and lifestyle factors that may be linked to miscarriage, including stress, alcohol, caffeine and tobacco consumption. Quantifying stress is difficult, but research will look at the subjective factors - asking women whether they believe that there is a link and seeing if this relates to the outcome of the pregnancies.

I will probably never know if hypnotherapy was a factor in my happy ending - my own version of TLC. But I won't lose any sleep over it - unless the baby wakes me up, of course.

Aim to find a hypnotherapist who

 Belongs to an organisation with a written code of practice, complaints and disciplinary procedure.

 Has indemnity and liability insurance.

 Holds a suitable qualification.

 Has plenty of experience, preferably in treating your problem.

 Is someone you feel at ease with and can trust with personal information.

 Asks about your medical history and whether you have consulted your GP about the problem.

How much will it cost?

From £25-£60 per consultation. Terry Morris (020 8693 2253) charges around £280 for a course of six 50-minute sessions. Common problems, such as smoking, can be treated in a couple of sessions, others may take longer.

 A new edition of Miscarriage: What Every Woman Needs to Know , by Professor Lesley Regan, is published by Orion Paperbacks, £7.99. The Miscarriage Association helpline is 01924 200 799.

Anybody can call themselves a hypnotherapist and set up in practice. There is no overall statutory governing body, but there are associations which regulate their members. One of the largest is the National Council of Hypnotherapists (0800 952 0545). The British Society for Medical and Dental Hypnosis (020 8905 4342) is open only to qualified doctors and dentists.

fields.headline: Once bitten...
fields.standfirst: How to soothe oral irritations. Plus, attacking menopausal acne, and the impact of binge eating on fertility
fields.trailText: How to soothe oral irritations. Plus, attacking menopausal acne, and the impact of binge eating on fertility.
fields.body:
At the moment I have several patients who are seeing me for dietary advice while undergoing courses of radiation therapy to the mouth. This treatment, while obviously absolutely necessary, is particularly cruel in that when their bodies desperately need nutrients to heal themselves and fight cancer cells, their mouths can become so sore and painful that it is impossible to even think about eating anything. On top of this, while good oral hygiene is vital, people undergoing radiation therapy to the mouth are often unaware that their toothpaste may also help dictate whether or not they can eat; the flouride in conventional toothpaste can make it feel as though they're torturing their mouths with bleach.

It's not just radiation therapy that results in a sore mouth - more mundane causes include dental treatment, tonsillitis, mouth ulcers or simply inflamed gums - but common to all of these conditions is the need to keep the mouth clean and infection-free. A salt toothpaste, either on its own or combined with a gentle balm such as calendula (available from health-food stores), applied on a soft-bristled toothbrush can clean and soothe your mouth.

Foodwise, once your mouth feels less painful, you should be able to tackle such soft, nutrient-packed fruits as the delectable Alphonso mangos that are starting to appear in the shops - they are full of the healing nutrients vitamin C and beta carotene. Enjoy them as they are or combine them with thick, natural yogurt (a creamy variety is better than a sour one) or even with cooled custard.

These are far more appetising alternatives to the 'complete-food' drinks that many 'how-to-eat-with-a-sore-mouth' information leaflets promote. Even if you have a chronic oral or swallowing problem, a host of mouth-watering 'real' foods can make eating a pleasure, not a painful or tasteless chore. As well as soft fruits, try soufflés, soups, omelettes or puréed vegetables mixed with olive oil and finely grated Parmesan cheese.

Nutrition news: Bingeing and infertility

Women who binge on food could be making themselves infertile, according to Dr Morgan, a consultant psychiatrist at St George's Hospital, London, and the author of a study which found that polycystic ovary syndrome (a hormonal imbalance that can lead to infertility) may be triggered by binge eating. Dr Morgan interviewed 87 women who suffered from the syndrome. One-quarter had been binge eating and one-eighth suffered from bulimia, while eating disorders predated the development of the syndrome in most cases.

Many sufferers from binge eating who are overweight find that losing weight can lessen their POS symptoms, especially when they reduce their intake of concentrated-carbohydrate foods. If you are in the grip of binge eating or have weight problems, ask your doctor to refer you either to a dietician who specialises in compulsive eating disorders or a psychologist.

Your questions

I am going through the menopause and have been alarmed to find that for the first time in my life I am suffering from acne-type spots. How can I get rid of them?

Acne vulgaris is primarily a hormonal problem, which is why your skin has erupted now. Although you don't mention whether you're taking hormone-replacement therapy (HRT), it may be that a natural hormonal treatment, such as a yam extract or cream, can stabilise your hormonal levels and clear up your acne. Ask your doctor to refer you to a specialist in natural, plant-based HRT treatments.

Acne tends to strike my patients when they're feeling stressed or depressed, which is often when they reach for fatty and sugary foods. Although I don't agree with the common belief that acne is caused by eating too many of these foods, I would urge you to ensure that it's not at the expense of vitamin C-rich fresh fruits and vegetables, which assist the body to fight the infections that can take hold within blocked pores and repair wounded skin.

My acne-stricken patients often notice a significant improvement in their skin if they boost their intake of foods that are rich in vitamin A, beta carotene and zinc, such as oily fish, eggs, carrots, dark-green, leafy vegetables, leeks, courgettes, lettuce (especially Cos varieties), pumpkins, apricots, peaches, mangos, crumbly cheeses, chicken, nuts and wholegrains. Drinking plenty of water is vital, too, to hydrate the skin and flush away toxins, but above all, to enable the body to glean acne-busting vitamins and minerals from food. In addition, avoid dehydrating your body by eating too many salty foods and drinking too many caffeine-rich or alcoholic drinks.

Many dermatologists prescribe antibiotics for acne, but the trade-off may be such unpleasant side effects as thrush and an irritable bowel. My initial advice would be to improve your diet and reduce your stress levels for a few weeks to see if these measures can clear up your skin.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician. fields.bodyText: At the moment I have several patients who are seeing me for dietary advice while undergoing courses of radiation therapy to the mouth. This treatment, while obviously absolutely necessary, is particularly cruel in that when their bodies desperately need nutrients to heal themselves and fight cancer cells, their mouths can become so sore and painful that it is impossible to even think about eating anything. On top of this, while good oral hygiene is vital, people undergoing radiation therapy to the mouth are often unaware that their toothpaste may also help dictate whether or not they can eat; the flouride in conventional toothpaste can make it feel as though they're torturing their mouths with bleach. It's not just radiation therapy that results in a sore mouth - more mundane causes include dental treatment, tonsillitis, mouth ulcers or simply inflamed gums - but common to all of these conditions is the need to keep the mouth clean and infection-free. A salt toothpaste, either on its own or combined with a gentle balm such as calendula (available from health-food stores), applied on a soft-bristled toothbrush can clean and soothe your mouth. Foodwise, once your mouth feels less painful, you should be able to tackle such soft, nutrient-packed fruits as the delectable Alphonso mangos that are starting to appear in the shops - they are full of the healing nutrients vitamin C and beta carotene. Enjoy them as they are or combine them with thick, natural yogurt (a creamy variety is better than a sour one) or even with cooled custard. These are far more appetising alternatives to the 'complete-food' drinks that many 'how-to-eat-with-a-sore-mouth' information leaflets promote. Even if you have a chronic oral or swallowing problem, a host of mouth-watering 'real' foods can make eating a pleasure, not a painful or tasteless chore. fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: hitting your stride with a regenerative walk, and whether it's possible to contract foot and mouth
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: hitting your stride with a regenerative walk, and whether it's possible to contract foot and mouth.
fields.body:
With summer starting to announce its imminent arrival, it's time to devote some thought to giving your energy a good airing through exercise. Don't groan. As well as feeding yourself correctly, there is no other agent through which health and longevity can be promoted so effectively than regular exercise.

It's not just for the sake of vanity (though looking good is something we all aspire to, and why not be the prettiest flowers we can be?) but for the sake of giving yourself the opportunity of spending truly constructive time with yourself, in order to reconstitute your world view and reposition yourself in relation to that world. And there is no better way to do this than by consciously training your body (in motion) to follow the commands of your mind. Nothing yokes you to yourself in the same way. And though some would say yoga is the mother of all exercise, surely there is nothing more natural and primal than walking.

While it's true that running takes you higher, in endorphin-release terms, it can also easily aggravate chronic joint problems relating to spinal misalignment or knee weakness. Walking, by contrast, provides a perfect opportunity to consciously release bodily and mental tension without jarring your joints, yet still engenders a significantly profound altered state. Walking's benefits on the cardiovascular, digestive and eliminative systems are well documented, but the spiritual, character-building and energetic ones are less well known.

Many myths exist of Taoist masters said to have walked 100 miles a day without effort, which are no doubt exaggerated, though it's true to say that when adhering to the 'flying' rules, you'll startle yourself by how far you can self-propel with ease.

Before starting out, be sure to wear appropriately comfortable, supportive footwear and easily removable and tieable-round-waist layers, as well as suitable chattel-transporters (bags or backpacks) where appropriate. Before your first foot has crossed the threshold into the world of the '10,000 things' outside, however, hold a vision of your destination and your successful arrival there in mind and make a compact with yourself to fulfil that vision honourably, no matter how many buses, trains or available cabs tempt you off your feet and on to your bum. Then say something to yourself along the lines of: 'I can do this. I will do this. I am doing this!' as foot crosses threshold and the door is shut behind you.

Out on the street, your mind will at first tend to wander - stimulated by the energy of cars, road-sign culture, billboards and passers-by - to thoughts of schedules, commitments, resentments, fantasies, hopes and fears. You could instead gather awareness into your body, starting with the soles of your feet, which must be relaxed, toes spread optimally within shoes, arches lifted without strain and a sense of rolling from heel to toe with each forward step. To facilitate the roll, allow your knees to be mildly bent at all times. To accommodate the bent-knee posture, gently tuck your pelvis under and feel your lower back angled perpendicular to the ground. Relax your buttocks completely and let them swing. It is a great misconception that clenching them tones the muscles and makes you look sexier. The muscles in fact get far more exercise and hence circulation through swinging freely than through clenching. At the same time, elongate the back of your neck (using your mind rather than force), allowing your chin to drop slightly and imagine an invisible thread pulling your crown up towards the sky. This is the Taoist version of walking with a book balanced on your head, but is spine-lengthening rather than spine-compressing.

Relax your belly, back, chest and shoulders, so your organs have room to enjoy the walk too. Rest the tip of your tongue on your upper palate. This helps conduct mental energy back down the front of your body into your belly, where it is regenerated as previously stated.

Organise yourself around a point 2in below your navel, known as your tantien, and let this be the centre of the universe within you. Imagine all movement originating here.

Pay attention to your breathing. It helps to synchronise your breath tempo with your footsteps in order to stop breathing becoming random. Start off at an easy pace without forcing anything. This way you don't send your body into revolt. With arms swinging freely, and all the above attended to, you may start to feel a heavy sensation in your palms and fingers, as if they're filling with blood and heat. This is quite natural and is an indication that your chi, or lifeforce, is flowing with more velocity.

There will be some initial resistance from the more mutinous sub-personalities within, and the lure of passing cabs may be strong. This is due to your liver not having released the extra quantity of blood required for a good 'flight'. Overriding this resistance usually coincides with the liver kicking in, however, and is worth the effort of will.

Who needs Kyoto summits?! If enough of us get with this 'flying on land' fad, we may just save the planet yet.

Your questions

Dear Barefoot Doctor, Is it true we can catch foot and mouth from cattle? I know the press says we can't, but there are rumours going around to the contrary. Please advise. Yours, Concerned

As far as I know, and I'm no expert on these things, there has only ever been one case reported back in 1967, but it cleared up on its own after a very short time. Of course there is human 'hand, foot and mouth', a flu-like virus that gives you sore throat, fever and blisters, but it's completely unrelated and passes like 'normal' flu. So I think it's safe to tell you to relax and ignore the rumours (thank goodness).

 If you have any problems you would like answered, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer , 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him at barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk Also, you can visit www.barefootdoctorglobal.com

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Prolific folk singer Ani DiFranco first met legendary storyteller Utah Phillips when she was a shave-headed punk. Ten years on, Utah has performed at her anarchist wedding and the two are now planning a third album together
fields.trailText: Prolific folk singer Ani DiFranco first met legendary storyteller Utah Phillips when she was a shave-headed punk. Ten years on, Utah has performed at her anarchist wedding and the two are now planning a third album together
fields.body:
Ani DiFranco: I met Utah in Philadelphia at a folk festival about 10 years ago and, as is typical of folk-music operations, we were billeted at an acoustic music appreciator's house. I was 20, had a shaved head and I looked like a little punk, which is unusual on the folk scene, and they weren't comfortable with me, so I got an attitude. Then I walked into the kitchen, and there was Utah sitting there and he just cleared the air with his presence and his humour and I fell in love with him immediately.

I was exposed to folk music when I was young, influenced by travelling folk singers who would stay with my family in Buffalo, New York. I'd long been aware of Utah as one of the most respected folk singers and storytellers in the country. As I got to know him, he took on a kind of mentor role. He has been a singer/storyteller for 30 years and I wanted to bring my audience, which is much younger than Utah's, to his work.

One thing we really connect on is this wedding of political rage and humour and joy. He has the ability to sit onstage and start talking and get everybody loosened up and laughing, then bring home political points. I admire his ability to have strong convictions about pacifism (Utah was a soldier during the Korean War), unionism, anti-corporate politics, but also to be fun, and to approach people in an open way.

We have collaborated on two albums. Our second project, Fellow Workers, was an eye opener for us because we were working side by side. He brings his persona off-stage, too - he's always performing, which can be tricky. It was my brainchild so I was directing it, but it's hard when you're 60-odd and you've perfected your craft, and then somebody says, 'Put down all your tools and do something different.' It wasn't easy for either of us, but I learned a lot about opening up to someone, trusting and relating on a more intuitive level.

I'm based in Buffalo and Utah's in Nevada City, California, so he sends me cassette letters and we write. We tend to see each other now and again. I contacted Utah recently about doing a third record and he's up for it, so we'll see what happens!

Utah Phillips: I hadn't been aware of Ani's work before meeting her, though she had released her first album the year before, but I remember thinking she had more energy than I'd ever seen in anyone, and I also realised that she had an extraordinarily powerful intellect. She'd found a recording of one of my performances, and she wrote to me, saying, 'I want my audience to hear your stories', which don't appear on my albums. So she asked me to send as many live tape recordings as I had, and she would do it all. She went into the studio and twisted everything around so it would fit for her audience. When it arrived in the mail, I was knocked out. A lot of my old folkies listened to it and didn't like it, because they didn't understand it, and I said, 'Tough luck, it wasn't made for you.'

I most admire Ani's integrity. She's true to herself and her beliefs - her songs tackle issues such as violence against women, abortion and sexism. The minute she set up her own label, Righteous Babe Records, there was no question it would be profit sharing - the people in that office are like a family. Ani has now released 13 solo albums.

What we do is cross-generational. After that first album, colleges would invite me to sing purely on the strength of the work I'd done with Ani. I was singing these old labour songs and all the young women were singing along - now, that's never happened to me before in my life. She led me towards that young audience and now I hang out with them a lot downtown.

Perhaps the greatest honour for me was being invited to perform at Ani's wedding, at a lake north of Montreal. I was the minister - I'm a lay preacher for the Unitarian Universalists, and I do anarchist weddings. Sadly, I don't see her too much now because she's on the road for 300 days a year, and I've got congestive heart failure, so I can't travel. But we do write - she sent me a letter recently asking me if I'd like to do a third record. And if Ani wants me to do it, I'll do it. I've learned that I can trust her implicitly with anything.

 Ani DiFranco's new album, Revelling/Reckoning, is out now.

fields.headline: Natural habitat
fields.standfirst: From fashion to furniture... Georgina Godley talks to Tamsin Blanchard about her new designs for the home
fields.trailText: From fashion to furniture... Georgina Godley talks to Tamsin Blanchard about her new designs for the home.
fields.body:
Georgina Godley has one of those jobs you can't help but envy. She's in charge of accessories at Habitat, which means that anything other than furniture comes under her beady eye. She oversees the china and glassware, as well as the bedlinen and bathroom towels. Along with head of design Tom Dixon, and head of furniture Matthew Hilton, she forms one-third of the furniture chain's holy trinity, intent on keeping Habitat a step ahead.

Godley trained as a fine artist at Brighton and Chelsea but eventually joined forces with a fellow student, Scott Crolla, in 1981, to open a shop specialising in baroque menswear. She first met Dixon in the mid-80s: 'Tom and I were involved in a nightclub together - The Titanic - and we put on a Day-Glo fashion show.' By the end of the 80s, Godley was doing her own thing with one-off sculptural fashion pieces. Now, as head of home accessories at Habitat, her life appears to have come full circle. Part of the new season's collection is a pink neon tray and a deckchair with a neon stripe, a throwback to the fashion of the mid-80s.

She's quite proud of her new deckchairs. In a way, they are the perfect fusion of fashion and interiors; the idea is that you get a basic wooden frame and then choose a sling to go with it - from a traditional stripe to what Godley calls her sportswear sling, made out of nylon, with neon flash, and even drawstrings and toggles. Each summer, there will be new slings to update your chair.

'I read an article about Terence Conran, when he said that he started Habitat as a furniture store, and home accessories was just styling that was put around the furniture,' she says. 'But the Habitat business grew in home accessories in a way that they had never anticipated. The accessories area is somewhere that one can do something much more fluid and spontaneous - you can restyle and refresh your home reasonably cheaply, and keep up to date with fashion. You can't be as flippant with furniture because you live with it.'

Godley, who recently separated from the product designer Sebastian Conran has had plenty of time to understand the Habitat ethos. To be working for the company that her father-in-law founded in 1964 all seems very natural. 'A great privilege in many respects.' She recalls seeing Habitat product from the first time round in the various Conran homes: 'Still there in a kind of jaded glory. I feel that I completely absorbed the culture,' she says. 'I'm very committed and always was, from the time I was in fashion, to breaking down the elitist boundaries of design.'

Her first memories of the store are as a child in Kingston in the 60s. 'There was nothing like it. It's very difficult to try to explain to young designers who don't remember it then what a powerful, revolutionary place it was. It would be a great achievement to try and build some of that electricity again in Habitat.'

Since joining the company 18 months ago, Godley has been injecting some of her own electricity into everything from bath towels to dinner plates. As part of a 'techno-folk' theme, she has introduced a pixelated floral pattern for china, and has given a slightly vintage look to wine and Champagne glasses. And there's also the Blade Runner neon plastic trays. Her background in fashion is coming in very useful. 'I would say that home accessories and fashion move hand in hand. They follow the same trends. Much like the accessories market in fashion, there are people who would feel too compromised wearing the outfit but are very happy to carry the handbag or wear the shoes. That's very true of home accessories.' People are, perhaps, even more confident about introducing fashion to their homes than to their wardrobe. 'It really is as simple as some cushions and a new rug, and you've got a new living space. My grandmother used to have summer and winter curtains. We're not really far off from that happening again.'

Georgina's own home, a stone's throw from Hampstead Heath, is still in the process of being dressed. She lives with her two sons in a pretty Victorian terrace. In the basement kitchen, there is a mix of clever junk shop finds and comfortable old friends. She has painted one wall with blackboard paint - the family uses it to keep a diary as well as reminders for the shopping list. At New Year, Godley and her friends wrote their resolutions on it. Upstairs, there is a long, narrow lounge, with cupboards built into the walls from floor to ceiling. There are also two distinctive pieces of Habitat furniture: the grey-felt daybed, usually covered in crumbs, bits of melted chocolate and Pikachu left by the kids and their friends, as well as a stunning, if difficult-to-clean, Perspex table called Slot, designed by Seng Watson.

fields.bodyText: Georgina Godley has one of those jobs you can't help but envy. She's in charge of accessories at Habitat, which means that anything other than furniture comes under her beady eye. She oversees the china and glassware, as well as the bedlinen and bathroom towels. Along with head of design Tom Dixon, and head of furniture Matthew Hilton, she forms one-third of the furniture chain's holy trinity, intent on keeping Habitat a step ahead. Godley trained as a fine artist at Brighton and Chelsea but eventually joined forces with a fellow student, Scott Crolla, in 1981, to open a shop specialising in baroque menswear. She first met Dixon in the mid-80s: 'Tom and I were involved in a nightclub together - The Titanic - and we put on a Day-Glo fashion show.' By the end of the 80s, Godley was doing her own thing with one-off sculptural fashion pieces. Now, as head of home accessories at Habitat, her life appears to have come full circle. Part of the new season's collection is a pink neon tray and a deckchair with a neon stripe, a throwback to the fashion of the mid-80s. She's quite proud of her new deckchairs. In a way, they are the perfect fusion of fashion and interiors; the idea is that you get a basic wooden frame and then choose a sling to go with it - from a traditional stripe to what Godley calls her sportswear sling, made out of nylon, with neon flash, and even drawstrings and toggles. Each summer, there will be new slings to update your chair. 'I read an article about Terence Conran, when he said that he started Habitat as a furniture store, and home accessories was just styling that was put around the furniture,' she says. 'But the Habitat business grew in home accessories in a way that they had never anticipated. The accessories area is somewhere that one can do something much more fluid and spontaneous - you can restyle and refresh your home reasonably cheaply, and keep up to date with fashion. You can't be as flippant with furniture because you live with it.' Godley, who recently separated from the product designer Sebastian Conran has had plenty of time to understand the Habitat ethos. To be working for the company that her father-in-law founded in 1964 all seems very natural. 'A great privilege in many respects.' She recalls seeing Habitat product from the first time round in the various Conran homes: 'Still there in a kind of jaded glory. I feel that I completely absorbed the culture,' she says. 'I'm very committed and always was, from the time I was in fashion, to breaking down the elitist boundaries of design.' Her first memories of the store are as a child in Kingston in the 60s. 'There was nothing like it. It's very difficult to try to explain to young designers who don't remember it then what a powerful, revolutionary place it was. It would be a great achievement to try and build some of that electricity again in Habitat.' Since joining the company 18 months ago, Godley has been injecting some of her own electricity into everything from bath towels to dinner plates. As part of a 'techno-folk' theme, she has introduced a pixelated floral pattern for china, and has given a slightly vintage look to wine and Champagne glasses. And there's also the Blade Runner neon plastic trays. Her background in fashion is coming in very useful. 'I would say that home accessories and fashion move hand in hand. They follow the same trends. Much like the accessories market in fashion, there are people who would feel too compromised wearing the outfit but are very happy to carry the handbag or wear the shoes. That's very true of home accessories.' People are, perhaps, even more confident about introducing fashion to their homes than to their wardrobe. 'It really is as simple as some cushions and a new rug, and you've got a new living space. My grandmother used to have summer and winter curtains. We're not really far off from that happening again.' In the basement kitchen, there is a mix of clever junk shop finds and comfortable old friends. She has painted one wall with blackboard paint - the family uses it to keep a diary as well as reminders for the shopping list. At New Year, Godley and her friends wrote their resolutions on it. fields.headline: Israel's crimes
fields.trailText: It is the Israelis who are stealing land. Yet you have the gall to demand that Arafat stops the violence (Leader Comment, last week).
fields.body:
It is the Israelis who are stealing land. It is the Israelis who are bombing and bulldozing the homes of innocent families. It is the Israelis who are besieging the towns of the Palestinians and not the other way round. Yet you have the gall to demand that Arafat stops the violence (Leader Comment, last week).

I would not condone some of what the Palestinians have done, but may I remind you that the current unrest was instigated by Ariel Sharon? May I also remind you that the Israelis not the Palestinians are the occupying power, that the Israelis have been seizing Palestinian territory in contravention of international law, that the Israelis converted the Oslo agreement to little more than a farce, that the Israeli current Prime Minister was behind the massacre in the Sabra and Chatilla refugee camps?

I trust that in the future you will be more balanced and demand that Sharon also stops the violence.
Michael Bishop
Cheltenham, Glos

fields.headline: Lessons in organisation
fields.trailText: Will Hutton has brought some common sense to teacher politics (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
Will Hutton has brought some common sense to teacher politics (Comment, last week). Most of the problems which beset the profession could be solved by a combining of teacher unions similar to the General Medical Council and the Law Society. This would considerably weaken the lunatic fringe and serve as a counter-force to the questionable and hastily conceived reforms of successive governments.

I joined the NUT in 1949 believing that the largest union would absorb the others. Half of my career was as a headmaster, but I would not join a headteachers' association, another form of fragmentation. Unfortunately, through the collective stupidity of my colleagues, for whom I have otherwise the highest respect, a powerful and responsive body of professional people still does not exist.
J.D. Lovell
Richmond, N Yorks

Although Will Hutton has identified several of the problems facing the teaching 'profession', he missed the most important aspect. Unlike the other professions, where membership is predominately masculine, the teaching 'profession' is predominately populated by women. Historically and cross-culturally, any occupation that is predominately carried out by women is subject to lower wages and fewer benefits. Until teachers have the same gender status as lawyers, doctors and accountants they are not going to be paid decently or have the same voice in shaping their profession.
Sue Incledon
Merryoaks, Co Durham

How can the BMA, the Law Society and the Institute of Chartered Accountants be held up as models of professional behaviour? These groups are better known for furthering the interest of their members than acting in the best interests of society. I have no doubt that teachers would love to have the power of those groups to frustrate reform and command excessively large fees but would such power improve education? Hutton's claim that the professional bodies mentioned adequately police standards or regulate those who do not meet the grade hardly gains support from the many recent examples of criminal or incompetent doctors, lawyers and accountants. Bristol? Shipman? Maxwell? Equity Life?
Richard Firn
York

There is a flaw in Will Hutton's reasoning when advocating that teachers 'organise as unified professionals' to raise standards and salaries. Teachers will always remain the recipients of mechanistic, dirigiste strategies by governments terrified of introducing any policy or initiative that has any aim other than that of 'raising standards'. Debate has long been stifled on how to achieve this - the only things that matter are targets and statistics; qualitative judgments about education have become irrelevant. The only 'objective' means of raising standards and salaries is payment by results, and that was discredited in the nineteenth century.
Greg Hetherton
Hove, Sussex

fields.headline: Real increases
fields.trailText: Further to your report on police spending (News, last week), the average annual real terms increase in government-funding support for the police service is 2.5 per cent for the budgets set during the current Parliament (for the four financial years 1998/99 to 2001/02).
fields.body:
Further to your report on police spending (News, last week), the average annual real terms increase in government-funding support for the police service is 2.5 per cent for the budgets set during the current Parliament (for the four financial years 1998/99 to 2001/02). During the current financial year alone, spending will rise by 7.4 per cent in real terms, one of the largest single year increases for 25 years. These increases compare favourably with an average annual real-terms rise of 0.92 per cent in government funding for the police voted for during the five financial years of the previous Parliament (those for 1993/94 to 1997/98).
Jack Straw MP
Home Secretary
London SW1

fields.headline: Letters to the Editor
fields.trailText: UN holiday
fields.body:
UN holiday

I hope the Fawcett Society (Comment, last week) will get lots of support for its proposal that HMG should create more holidays for this country to enjoy. How about 24 October, United Nations' Day, for a start?
Ruth Wenban-Smith
Lymington, Hants

Baby talk

This idea, mentioned by Cristina Odone (Comment, last week), that mothers are automatically selfless while women who choose not to have children are hedonistic monsters really must stop.

You never hear a woman say: I am emotionally equipped to bring another person into the world, I am secure enough not to project all my thwarted desires on to them, I am open-minded enough to love them unconditionally be they gay, straight, born-again Christian or trainspotter. No, what you hear is a woman saying: I WANT a baby.

Personally I think childless women should be a given a government grant. Britain is crowded enough as it is.
Tania Kindersley
Aboyne, Aberdeenshire

Run, rabbit

Richard Holloway (Comment, last week) is right to say that Christian beliefs are not groundless opinions without point. All religious beliefs, being highly improbable, facilitate the intoxicating effects of regular affirmations. One would hardly get hooked affirming the patently obvious. Nevertheless, I found his Easter message quite moving. I nearly crucified my rabbit as a sign of love for my fellow man.
Stephen Park
Chagford, Devon

Character flaws

So Bernard Levin and countless others are to be condemned because they may 'believe that you can be a horrible man and still write beautiful music', says Richard Ingrams (Comment, last week). Does Ingrams think that we should apply this standard to all art? Anonymous work could then be ignored as worthless because origins might be suspect, and judgment of anything new postponed pending satisfactory references. For all we know, Ingrams may be a old curmudgeon, but we don't dismiss his writing for that!
David Wedderburn
Corbridge, Northumberland

Support systems

Colin Cottell is right to highlight the important work carried out by Victim Support in helping the victims of violent crime (Cash, 8 April). However, the criminal injuries compensation scheme supplements action through the courts: it does not replace it. Suing the offender is always an option for victims, but the scheme's existence acknowledges that it is not generally a practical option.
Howard Webber
London EC1

Crazy for trees

Your story that NHS hospitals are planning to plant trees in order to help patients recover better from illness (News, last week) reminded me of the James Thurber story, Interview With a Lemming . A scientist tells a lemming about how puzzled he is that such a species should choose to throw itself en masse off a cliff. The lemming replies that many things amaze him about human beings, including the fact that: 'You cut down elm trees to put up institutions for people driven insane by the cutting down of elm trees.'
Alan Kerr
Bidford-on-Avon, Warks

Top Goon

Harry Secombe was present for all my younger years and I loved The Goon Show, like many millions of others. HRH Prince Charles is quite right in his comments about the sheer rubbish that is supposed to be comedy today (News, last week). I sincerely hope that there might be a national tribute in St Paul's or somewhere fitting for this great man. Goon but never forgotten.
Tony Langham
Salisbury

Howard's way

To the best of my knowledge the media haven't discussed the observations of Sir Albert Howard who maintained, from more than 20 years monitoring his own cattle, that FMD arises solely from poor diet and intensive farming methods and cannot be transmitted to healthy unvaccinated cattle. I refer to his book Farming and Gardening for Health or Disease (Faber & Faber 1945).
John M. Scott
Norwich
