fields.headline: Silent slight
fields.trailText: Peter Conrad's thesis (Review, last week) regarding the BBC's  Art That Shook The World could not have been better illustrated than the actual broadcast of Tom Paulin's eulogy on Joyce's  Ulysses the night before.
fields.body:
Peter Conrad's thesis (Review, last week) regarding the BBC's Art That Shook The World could not have been better illustrated than the actual broadcast of Tom Paulin's eulogy on Joyce's Ulysses the night before. Incredibly, without apparent consideration for an act which undermined Paulin's whole argument and their production investment, in dramatising Molly Bloom's monologue the BBC bleeped out the word 'fuck'!

I can't believe that Paulin allowed this travesty to pass. Every nuance of his case was ridiculed in this split-second mute moment.
Nick Grant
Wembley, Middx

webTitle: Leader: How cruel one's children can be

fields.headline: Birthday blues
fields.standfirst: How cruel one's children can be
fields.trailText: Yesterday, an elderly lady from near Slough in Berkshire spent her seventy-fifth birthday almost alone at home, in spite of having an enormous extended family.
fields.body:
Yesterday, an elderly lady from near Slough in Berkshire spent her seventy-fifth birthday almost alone at home, in spite of having an enormous extended family. Her husband was there, but he was feeling grumpy. So she pottered around a bit in the garden. Just one of their children sent a birthday present. He was in Scotland himself, too busy to visit Mum and no doubt enjoying the company of the girlfriend no one talks about.

Another son did arrive late in the afternoon. But it turned out he had just flown in to Heathrow - and probably needed his washing done. And with all the difficulty he has getting his small business to turn a profit, you always wonder if what he really wants is £20 to help pay for the petrol back to his home in Surrey.

The Observer has always argued that the Windsors should lead a more normal family existence. Yesterday they appeared to be taking our advice.

webTitle: Leader: Join the boycott against Exxon now

fields.headline: Driller killer
fields.standfirst: Join the boycott against Exxon now
fields.trailText: It is time for Britain to drop our softly-softly approach to corporate social responsibility. The public wants better.
fields.body:
Rarely have multinational companies been under such critical global scrutiny as those now trading in pharmaceuticals, chocolate and oil. In South Africa last week, the major drug companies gave up their legal action over the pricing of anti-Aids drugs. Mars, Cadbury and Nestlé have been equally discomfited by reports of the use of child slave labour on cocoa plantations. And oil giant Exxon faces the threat of a worldwide boycott. It has been a leading lobbyist in persuading the Bush administration to abandon limits on carbon-dioxide emissions and reject the Kyoto accords on global warning.

Protesters in Quebec this weekend, and those expected in London next week, are only the most vocal element of a global movement which wants to hold companies to account for their ethical standards. But multinationals all too frequently pay just lip-service to the need for corporate ethics. It is time for Britain to drop our softly-softly approach to corporate social responsibility. The public wants better.

We should have a legal framework in which companies report openly on their ethical, environmental and workplace policies so that consumers and workers can choose those with which they want to be associated. This is already done by some firms, notably BP and Shell. The Observer does not believe that either is perfect, but neither behaves like Exxon, and both support the principle of the Kyoto accords. If Observer readers want to take direct action over climate change, they should buy their petrol from these companies and not from Esso. Don't put a tiger in your tank.

webTitle: Gabon's oasis of oil lures children into slavery

fields.headline: Gabon's oasis of oil lures children into slavery
fields.trailText: The young migrants taken by a Nigerian-registered ship to a prosperous republic where their nightmare just became worse.
fields.body:
'It was 1am, very dark, when we got into the canoes and the shore was a long way off. I don't know how far. Most of of us were still at sea when the police arrived.'

Before trying to sneak into oil-rich Gabon, Youssuf Tamaro had known unremitting poverty in his village in northern Mali. But things were going to get worse.

'The boatmen panicked when they saw the police and started pushing us into the sea,' 19-year-old Tamaro said. 'The waves reached my chest - which was good because I cannot swim.'

Spluttering out of the surf and on to the shore of Gabon came representatives from Benin, Togo, Mali, Guinea and Senegal: a tattered labour battalion from some of the world's poorest countries.

Alerted by the arrival of the Etireno, a ship known to have been used for smuggling and trafficking, the Gabonese police received them.

'They threw me on to the beach and started hitting me in the face with the butt of a gun, they broke my teeth,' said Tamaro, showing the gummy hole where his two front teeth used to be. 'The police were beating everybody, even the women. The children were crying, everyone was screaming and shouting.'

The Etireno's women and children had been the first into the canoes and were ashore by the time the police trucks arrived, said Tamaro. The children were not beaten, he said.

Tamaro says the police snatched his passport and identity card and ripped them up on the spot. He had hoped they would help him get into Gabon even without a visa.

The Etireno's 142 passengers - illegal migrants and 31 suspected child-slaves loaded on to the ship in Cotonou, Benin - were taken to a prison camp outside the capital, Libreville.

This was not how 15-year-old Abubakhar Jabi imagined Gabon would be. Almost everybody had left his village of Joji in northern Mali to look for work in Ivory Coast, Gabon or the Republic of Congo, he said. No one came back. 'There is money in Gabon,' said Abubakhar. His father had already made it there and had sent £30, a fortune, for his travel.

'The prison, Camp Fopi, was very hard,' said Abubakhar. 'We were there for five days. There were no buildings to sleep in, just open ground, and we only had a tin of sardines and a loaf of bread to share between two each day.'

The Etireno returned the migrants to Cotonou on Monday night, after begging fuel in Doula, Cameroon, en route. Its planned four-day voyage had taken nearly three weeks and stores were running perilously low.

'We had some yams and some flour left to eat, that was all,' said Abubakhar. 'There was water, but it was salty and very difficult to drink.' The Etireno's Nigerian crew, at least, made life no harder: 'They were kind to us.'

Abubakhar had left Mali for nearby Benin, where the Etireno sailed from, in a bus filled with children. All of them were going off to work, he said. Now his money was gone and he, too, had lost his passport in Gabon.

Abubakhar is recuperating with 15 other older children and youths from the Etireno at a UN-sponsored transit centre, the SOS Children's Village, in Cotonou. He has no plans: 'I would like to go back to my village, but I'd probably better try to get to Gabon again. At home I have nothing to do.'

The same is true for his fellows, said Arsene Metinhoue, director of the Children's Village. 'They might say they're going home now, to Mali or wherever, but eventually they'll all try again,' he said. 'They were starving when they came here, they were visibly exhausted, but what choice do they have?'

Gabon's oilfields have made it a small oasis of prosperity - albeit woefully unevenly divided - in West Africa. The country's per capita income is around £2,900 compared to about £150 in Benin, Togo and Mali.

The UN Children's Fund believes that failure to regulate the region's illegal migrant workers, combined with worsening poverty, has caused the massive increase in child trafficking throughout West and Central Africa over the past 10 years; 200,000 unaccompanied children are smuggled across the region's borders to work each year, it estimates.

webTitle: How Germany's leader finally found his father

fields.headline: How Germany's leader finally found his father
fields.standfirst: Schröder prepares to visit lost war grave tracked down by his sister
fields.trailText: Schröder prepares to visit lost war grave tracked down by his sister
fields.body:
'I'm delighted for you that this time you have borne a son,' Lance Corporal Fritz Schröder wrote to his wife Erika in April 1944, after learning of the birth of Gerhard Fritz Kurt via the forces postal service. 'In the autumn I will be coming home.' But the Wehrmacht soldier never returned and neither did he ever see his blond-haired boy who went on to become Chancellor of Germany.

The tank engineer was 32 when he fell at the front in Romania, for ' Führer, Volk und Vaterland ' as his wife was informed, just six months after the birth of his only son. He was among troops fighting Russia at the start of the German collapse, who had captured a village in the Carpathian mountains of north-western Romania. Fritz and three of his comrades were shot dead by civilians.

As they grew up, Erika told her children Gerd and his older sister Gunhild very little about their father, a labourer and groom, other than to say, 'He was a good husband and treated me well'.

She would later recall: 'We married on 28 October, 1939, in Detmold. We intended to marry earlier but we had to prove our Aryan backgrounds and that took some time.'

Now, 57 years after his death, the Schröder family chronicle has been reopened, following the discovery of Fritz's resting place in the Transylvanian village of Ceanu Mare, population 4,500, near the city of Cluj.

Gunhild Schröder-Kamp has traced her father's body to a communal grave next to the Orthodox church where Fritz is buried along with three of his comrades. Villagers have tended the grave over the years.

Protected by a concrete wall and decorated with a simple iron crucifix, there is neither an inscription nor a name plate: only the word of 85-year old villager and eye-witness Anica Cu that Fritz Schröder is buried there. She and her neighbour Haberan Procopic collected the German soldiers' bodies on an ox-drawn cart and then placed them in the grave. 'I myself laid them in the open grave,' she told the tabloid Bild am Sonntag. 'Their bodies were shot up and their uniforms were covered in clay. I saw them as they lay there. Then suddenly one of them moved. He was still alive and we took him out again,' she added.

On Friday Chancellor Schröder expressed his 'relief and emotion' on hearing the news that the body of the father he never knew had been found, and pledged to make a private visit to Romania with his sister later this year.

'I'm delighted and moved finally to have discovered the exact whereabouts of my father's grave,' he told the Bild daily on Friday. 'I will visit it soon - in the privacy that I hope will be granted to me.'

Discussions are believed to be under way to have Fritz's remains returned to Germany under a 1997 war graves agreement between the two countries.

If the Chancellor does indeed visit Ceanu he will find it a typical Romanian village: it has a single asphalt street, farm animals run free, most homes are without telephones or electricity, and there is not even a bus connecting it to the next town.

Gunhild, an amusement arcade attendant who shares a three-room flat in Paderborn with her 87-year-old mother, was informed of the whereabouts of her father through a Berlin-based organisation which traces the fate of Wehrmacht soldiers. It wrote to her earlier this month outlining the precise location in Ceanu Mare.

The Orthodox priest of the village, Daniel Crisan, planted a sweet cherry tree where the bodies lie five years ago. 'We looked after Fritz for almost 60 years,' he told visiting reporters, who have thrown this usually sedate village into excited chaos.

The residents of Ceanu Mare, 235 miles north-west of Bucharest, are eager to talk. 'A military truck came with the bodies which had greyish-blue uniforms and there were leaves on the ground,' Marcu Hadarean said this weekend. He was just 14 as he witnessed German soldiers being buried in the churchyard. 'I was about 20 metres away and a Hungarian soldier told me to stand back, "otherwise they'll shoot you," so I moved back,' the 71-year old peasant said. 'Some of the soldiers put a canvas sheet over the bodies. There was no ceremony.'

There has long been much speculation about the effect that being brought up poor and fatherless had on the future Chancellor and the topic has been keenly resurrected since the discovery of Fritz's grave. The premature death of his father, psychologists have suggested, may have given Gerhard the angry drive to reach the top, and may have added to his stormy private life: the Chancellor has been married four times.

'I was born in 1944 and I never knew my father because he died in the war,' he revealed in a 1998 inter view. 'In short, as a soldier he was sent to slaughter and had to sacrifice his body for the criminal regime of Adolf Hitler.'

Gerd, as he was known in childhood, was brought up by his widowed mother who worked as a cleaner, sometimes taking up to six jobs at a time to make ends meet. She married her second husband, Paul Vosseler, in 1947, with whom she had a further three children. Gerhard remains close to her, affectionately calling her 'lion'.

Asked recently if he missed his father, he replied: 'Psychologists would naturally say that to grow up fatherless can have damaging effects. But I have never felt them.'

During her tireless research into the family history, Gunhild also stumbled across relatives whose existence the Schröders had known nothing of. Fritz Schröder's brother Kurt and his daughters Inge Siegel, aged 57, and Heidelinde Munkewitz, aged 59, have been discovered living in Eisenach in the eastern German state of Thuringia. 'We would very much like to invite him if he so desires to meet his cousins,' Inge told newspapers last week.

Gunhild said she was 'thrilled' that her search had been fruitful. 'I saw [my father] all of three times,' she told Bild am Sonntag. 'I can very faintly remember him fixing a parasol to my pushchair.'

Meanwhile in Ceanu Mare, emotions have been put aside by the more pressing practical problems, such as where might the Chancellor stay.

'Where would he sleep? What kind of meal would he enjoy? How would the outside world see our village?' Gavrila Oros, Ceanu's mayor, asked. 'But he is welcome here, and we will offer him chicken soup with homemade noodles, roast chicken or lamb and cozonac, a sweet yeast cake with walnuts.'

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Missionary and baby daughter die as Peruvians down plane
fields.body:
Missionary and baby daughter die as Peruvians down plane

A US surveillance plane monitored the Peruvian air force's downing of a plane carrying American missionaries mistaken for drug smugglers, a US Embassy official said yesterday. A woman and her infant daughter were killed in the shooting over the Amazon.

A survivor was reported to have said a US plane was in the air during the incident. As part of an agreement with Peru, the US provides tracking information on suspected drug planes.

The pilot, a veteran missionary, was shot in the leg, mid-flight. He then lost control of the single-engine plane before managing to guide it into the river, where the survivors were rescued by local villagers.

The Peru air force said the plane entered Peruvian air space from Brazil without filing a flight plan and that it was fired on after the pilot failed to identify himself.

The Rev E.C. Haskell, spokesman for the Baptist Association of New Cumberland, Pennsylvania, said the plane was flying to Iquitos, 625 miles north-east of Lima, when it was attacked. Missionary Veronica Bowers, 35, and her seven-month-old adopted daughter Charity were killed and pilot Kevin Donaldson was wounded, he said.

On board and unhurt were Bowers's husband, Jim, 35, and their six-year-old son Cory. The Bowerses are from Michigan, and the Donaldsons from Pennsylvania.

The missionary group has worked in Peru since 1939. It helps found Baptist churches in the upper Amazon, and sends missionaries into remote areas.

Veronica Bowers was holding her daughter on her lap when a bullet struck her in the back and then hit the child.

Conductor's heart attack

Italian conductor Giuseppe Sinopoli, best known for daring interpretations of Verdi and Puccini, died at 54 after suffering a heart attack while conducting Verdi's Aida at Berlin's Deutsche Opera house.

Greek storm

Strong winds and heavy rain lashed Greece forcing dozens of ships to stay in port and cutting off many Aegean islands.

Phone smog

Italy is assigning about £85,000 from mobile phone licence sales for research into electromagnetic pollution or 'electro-smog'.

Stem cell blow

The Bush administration sent out negative signals about stem cell research, controversial because tissue is taken from aborted foetuses, when it cancelled a meeting to hear scientists' grant applications.

webTitle: Monochrome grip on the rainbow nation

fields.headline: Monochrome grip on the rainbow nation
fields.standfirst:
While London pays tribute to Mandela, David Beresford in South Africa finds worrying evidence in his successor of a tyrant in the making
O, what men dare do: Anthony Sampson on banning Shakespeare
fields.trailText: Londoners will party in Trafalgar Square next Sunday with a rock concert in honour of their favourite statesman, Nelson Mandela, a man who dreamed the democratic dream and lived to see it realised. But in South Africa the festivities will be viewed with a sense of irony, even among many who shared his dream.
fields.body:
Londoners will party in Trafalgar Square next Sunday with a rock concert in honour of their favourite statesman, Nelson Mandela, a man who dreamed the democratic dream and lived to see it realised. But in South Africa the festivities will be viewed with a sense of irony, even among many who shared his dream.

The news last week that a provincial education authority in South Africa had denounced Shakespeare as inappropriate to the syllabus - Hamlet as 'not optimistic' and Lear as 'not exciting' - and the work of Nobel laureate Nadine Gordimer as 'racist' was meat for British editorial writers and columnists. In South Africa the mood was more one of déjà vu than dismay, the incident merely further evidence of a nation which has lost its way.

Disillusionment increasingly haunts even the few triumphs which the country enjoys. Last week, for example, South Africa scored a landmark victory against the international pharmaceutical industry when an alliance of major drugs companies surrendered in a constitutional battle over the primacy of national health over commercial price considerations. But what should have been a famous triumph for Africa and a breakthrough in the battle against HIV/Aids was soured. It was compromised by the knowledge that the country is ruled by a man whose odd belief is that the virus and the disease have no connection, and to whom the pricing of the anti-viral drugs thus has no significance.

Whether or not President Thabo Mbeki is responsible for South Africa's malaise is subject for increasingly vociferous debate. Those closest to him insist he is a man of wisdom. Yet oddities of the sort represented by last week's swingeing judgments on the works of Shakespeare and Nadine Gordimer do seem symptomatic of Mbeki's rule.

The denunciation of Gordimer as 'racist' reflects a political orthodoxy in South Africa which has it that all whites belong in that camp. Recently it was the turn of South Africa's Portuguese community.

The occasion was a peaceful march on government offices - the Union Buildings in Pretoria - to protest against high crime levels. Some might be heard to mutter 'just deserts' where South Africa's Portuguese are concerned, the community having an unfortunate reputation for racism. But this is the 'rainbow nation' where stereotyping is outlawed by the constitution. Yet the government's response was a five-page letter, signed by the Police Minister, denouncing the Portuguese as racists.

The uproar was immediate, and there was talk of a formal breach between Lisbon and Pretoria before hurried behind-the-scenes diplomacy defused the issue. A strange aspect of this episode was that the tone of the letter was out of character for the Police Minister, Steve Tshwete, who also showed no particular interest in defending his position. An apparent explanation was provided by a curious phrase in the letter: 'I would even make bold to say that, in addition to defining yourselves as our political opponents, you hold the government, our President and our continent in contempt.'

The archaic phrase 'make bold to say' is rarely heard nowadays, but it had been used just a few days before by President Mbeki in his 'state of the nation' speech. A search of the ANC website shows the phrase used in 13 speeches delivered by Mbeki, and in one article quoting him.

The implication, that Mbeki wrote the notorious letter to the Portuguese himself (and it is not the only such cabinet Minister's speech he is suspected of covertly writing), opens a line of speculation about the South African President which ties in with his insistence that a virus does not cause HIV/Aids and that the disease is not conveyed through sexual contact. It is that he has an obsession with what he sees as collective white guilt and black victimisation.

His unnecessary provocation of the Portuguese community is, in that respect, tied in with his stand on HIV/Aids - which he sees as a racial smear against African males, representing them as 'rapists', or otherwise sexually irresponsible.

The clever piece of cyber-analysis suggesting Mbeki's authorship of the letter to the Portuguese was the work of a liberal political scientist, James Myburgh, working for the parliamentary opposition, Democratic Alliance. He has followed it up with a chilling piece of political analysis, warning of a broader threat which, he argues, Mbeki poses to democracy in South Africa.

Pointing to the determined centralisation of political power under his leadership - with Mbeki loyalists not only packing the ANC's national working committee, but heading most government departments and key strategic state institutions, including the police and army - Myburgh characterises South Africa's Russian-trained President as being a classic Stalinist.

'He controls directly (or through proxies) all appointments to party structures, and of party members to state structures. There is no one in the inner circle who can challenge him intellectually, and no one in the outer circle who would dare do so. The party apparatus is required to defend and implement the decisions of the leadership.

'There is a continual process of negative selection as blind loyalty is rewarded with promotion, while rivals and independent-minded members of the party are shunted to the periphery of the movement.'

fields.headline: Copyrights and wrongs
fields.standfirst: In the global TV market, great ideas are the key.  Michael Collins finds out how you can stop yours from being stolen
fields.trailText: In the global TV market, great ideas are the key.  Michael Collins finds out how you can stop yours from being stolen.
fields.body:
'Some years ago I decided that the best way to run a TV production company was to run it like an ad agency, and come up with ideas to order,' said Peter Bazalgette, creator of TV's Big Brother. It is a move that has paid off for the UK creative director of the Endemol empire.

Bazalgette has shown that the best way to succeed in broadcasting is to take a simple idea, own it, clone it and make millions. One of his first born, Ready Steady Cook, he gently boasted, has been sold in more than 25 countries. It became a million-selling book, a magazine and a nationwide roadshow. Big Brother is an even greater lesson in the art of how to turn the obvious into a brand that can excel at home and abroad.

Like The Weakest Link - unveiled to US audiences last week complete with Anne Robinson - and Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, Big Brother captured the global imagination with a simple format and nail-biting tension. 'Formats are simply concentrated ideas with rules,' said Bazalgette. 'The key to most of these things is to have the kind of idea that works locally for everyone.'

And ideas like his, in television or any other sphere, are the most valuable commodities in the market today. The world is caught up in an explosion of ideas and inventions. As a testament to the extent to which they are revered, and their status in the global village, they now warrant their own annual celebration.

Thursday marks the first World Intellectual Property Day. The date is a significant one: 26 April is the date the World Intellectual Property Organisation came into being in 1970. The Geneva-based UN agency counts 177 nations as members and is in the business of 'promoting the use and protection of works of the human spirit'.

The day will mark the celebration and protection of intellectual property, from the kind of madcap gadgets that made Heath Robinson famous to the minds that brought us Black & Decker's Workmate and the Human Genome Project.

Laurence Smith-Higgins, of the Department of Trade and Industry's Patent Office, said: 'WIPO had the idea that, because of the growing importance of creativity in our daily lives, they would create a special day to broaden people's knowledge as to the significance of intellectual property.'

WIPO has itself taken centre-stage partly because of the growth in counterfeit goods, such as computer games, videos of latest blockbusters like Julia Robert's new film The Mexican, music CDs and clothes. Piracy accounts for up to 7 per cent of global trade. Protection is the only means by which to curtail it.

The US music industry last week blamed the growth in illegal recordings and inter net downloading as one reason for the first ever drop in music profits. It means that stars such as Metallica, who sued the internet music provider Napster, and former Spice Girl Emma Bunton, despite her new single reaching number one last week, can expect smaller profits if the piracy goes unchecked.

Another major contributory factor has been the IT revolution, resulting in the downloading of software, music, images and text via the internet. World Intellectual Property Day arrives just before the creators of Napster - the software that allows for the free swapping and downloading of music files - go to court for what is expected to be the ultimate showdown with the mighty American music industry.

Experts agree that the understanding of intellectual property has moved beyond the conversations of those that knew and understood it first. Intellectual property covers the intangible assets of a company: the idea, the patent, the copyright, the trademark, the design and the brand.

These are things that Coca-Cola discovered more than a hundred years ago when it created a certain logo on a certain bottle for a certain drink. 'The larger, multi-national companies such as Coke, ICI, McDonald's, Glaxo, have always protected their rights, in all aspects, globally,' said Smith-Higgins.

In recent years there has been a dramatic shift in emphasis, whereby those in the world of showbusiness and beyond have begun to realise the significance of intellectual property. Ma- donna is one of a number of celebrities who sought WIPO's assistance when her her monicker was used as the domain name for a website.

Footballers' agents have even suggested television footage of their clients scoring goals should be their intellectual property, and for each showing of a televised goal they should receive a royalty.

'It's more of a snowball effect,' believes Smith-Higgins. 'There is a growing awareness at every level that ideas are property like any other.'

There will be no red noses or red ribbons to mark World Intellectual Property Day. In Britain, the Patent Office is responsible for raising awareness of the event. Officials have already produced an intellectual property website. Each of the member states of WIPO must come up with its own ideas to educate its citizens with exhibitions that illustrate the significance of intellectual property in our everyday life.

'I invite the peoples of all nations on this first World Intellectual Property Day to join us in recognising the contribution of inventors and creators in making our world a better place', said WIPO director-general Dr Kamil Idris. 'We all share in the fruits of their ideas, their imagination, their talent and hard work.'

To most, his words are a shorthand for reminding us that everything around us emerged from the mind of someone - making it, ultimately, their property, should we consider reproducing or copying it in any way, for profit or not. This alone should be enough to put the term 'intellectual property' further into common usage.

'It's been used within industries such as the pharmaceutical industry for the last 20 years,' said intellectual property specialist Richard Laurence, based at Hewlett-Packard Labs, the heart of the current HP Invent campaign. In its ads, the company points out: 'There's no shortage of celebrities, is there? Even chefs are superstars. But what about the people who are really changing the world? The inventors.'

The legal battle over Napster is not the only thing that has rattled the music industry. David Ferguson is the chairman of the Creator's Rights Alliance, which held its inaugural conference in March. 'Napster of course is theft,' he said. 'It's stealing other people's ideas, by illegally copying them and making money. But this is part of a growing cancer that is a major concern within the creative industries.'

The CRA lobbies on behalf of composers like Ferguson himself, as well as authors. The publishing world was drawn into the the intellectual property argument last week when a US judge was asked to rule on an application by the Margaret Mitchell estate to have the debut novel of US author Alice Randall withdrawn, on the ground that it borrowed heavily from scenes and characters in Gone With The Wind. It is, according to them, a sequel.

But there's another side to the issue, according to David Ferguson. 'Large organisations, such as broadcasters, are responsible for removing royalties from the rights of creatives. Before I do a job, I have to sign a publishing deal with the broadcaster that essentially forces me to waive both my moral and intellectual rights. I could therefore have my music used for, say, a British National Party broadcast and have no control over that.'

Some have pointed to the BBC as as one of the most thorough organisations in protecting global rights and merchandising for shows such as The Weakest Link - its most successful export ever. However, the organisation has for years required those interviewed for production jobs in entertainment to provide several ideas to an interview board, often for vacancies that are filled internally anyway. The applicants have little protection when something resembling their idea materialises on screen.

The dotcom startup TVtoBe was launched in March. Kiaron Finnegan, the company's managing director and a former TV producer, had an idea to create a database for TV proposals, where producers could securely register their ideas.

'We can't say that it is 100 per cent secure,' he said. 'But we do have a record of the broadcasters or commissioning editors that read an idea on file, when, and how long they spent reading it.' Such a concept could not have existed without the internet. The irony is that, although the internet has made many big stars get hot under the collar, it has also emerged as a platform for the registration of ideas, whether is it the absurd concepts that appear on sites such as idea-a-day, Brainflower, Halfbakery, or the sites that offer cash for innovative ideas, such as The Global Ideas Bank.

'Protecting ideas in this way is doomed,' believes Alex Graham of Wall To Wall, the company behind TV's 1900 House . 'Ideas alone are a meaningless piece of intellectual property. Formats are the lifeblood of the creative producer, and these should not be confused with ideas'.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Women warned over pensions | A fine time | Less taxing
fields.body:
Women warned over pensions

Women have been warned by the Financial Services Authority that they should do more to plan for retirement.

Only 27 per cent of married women have a pension compared to 47 per cent of married men, says the FSA.

The report also highlights the necessity of women planning their finances from an early age to cope later with changes such as career breaks.

Women and personal finance: the reality of the gender gap is available on the FSA website or on 0845 608 2372.

A fine time

If you have to pay a magistrate's fine you can now do so with the swipe of a card.

Courts will give you the option of settling the fine using a PayPoint card at one of 7,400 convenience stores, petrol stations and newsagents nationwide.

Less taxing

A new book could help you fill in the dreaded tax return.

Your tax forms made easy tells you what bits to fill in, where to find the information and, just as importantly, which bits you can ignore. You can order a copy, for £4.99, on 01256 329242.

Job loss advice

Losing your job can cause a major upheaval. Changing Employment and Personal Finance is a guide from independent adviser Towry Law that sets out to alleviate the stress involved by explaining some of the key steps that should be taken.

Among the initial actions advised are registering as unemployed to protect national insurance contributions, speaking to the bank manager, alerting the mortgage company and reallocating credit card debts to avoid high interest charges.

For a free copy of Changing Employment and Personal Finance call 0845 788 9933.

Celebrate in style

Money Observer, our sister publication, publishes its 250th issue in May.

To celebrate, it has produced a guide to personal finance entitled Making You Money Through Thick and Thin, which is available free to the first 100 readers who send in their name and address.

Those interested should email their details to money.observer@theguardian.com, or write to Money Observer 250th issue promotion, 3rd Floor, 75 Farringdon Road, London EC1M 3JY.

fields.headline: Swapping Wolverhampton for the wiles of la dolce vita
fields.standfirst: With their children flown the nest, the Gilberts plan to realise their dream - and still keep a foot in the UK, reports  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: With their children flown the nest, the Gilberts plan to realise their dream - and still keep a foot in the UK, reports Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
Keith and Kate Gilbert
Ages Both 49
Live in Wolverhampton
Occupations Primary head teacher and university lecturer
Earn £35,000 each
Mortgage £40,000
Debts None
Investments Isa, endowment
Pensions Teachers' pensions and AVCs
Aims To prepare for moving to Italy

Keith and Kate Gilbert have just taken a life-changing decision. After spending their working lives teaching in the UK, Keith has taken a job in Italy. In August they move to Monza, outside Milan, when Keith starts a three-year contract as principal of the elementary department of an international school.

Keith says they both wanted to experience working abroad and now seems a good time to go: 'The children are grown up and we rattle about in a great big Victorian house.'

They have taken holidays in Italy whenever they could afford it and Keith has been studying Italian. Kate has not, and her limited knowledge of the language is a hurdle. 'I need to learn Italian and so far I have a book and a tape,' she says.

The decision to emigrate came in a spurt: 'We have been talking about it as a pipe dream for a long time and then suddenly, when Keith got the job, it became a reality within six weeks.'

Kate is organising the practical side. 'We have started sorting through our books and deciding what we can live without and what we really need. It is a complete lifestyle change,' she says.

But they have not got to grips with the financial issues: 'Not having lived and worked abroad before, we are not sure what to do about our finances. It is possible that we may never return to live in the UK, but we have to keep our options open.'

Kate, a lecturer in business studies, realises that she might not be able to get work in Italy: 'I am going to look around but we have no assurance that I will find work or how much I will be able to earn. So I assume we will go down from two incomes to one.'

They are confident they can live on Keith's salary because they have been practising living on one salary and using the other to reduce their debts. 'Our cost of living in Italy should go down because food is cheaper, transport to work disappears as Keith will walk, and we will go from two cars to one,' Kate says.

They are moving to smaller accommodation but will pay more in rent than they pay for their mortgage.

An immediate decision is what to do with their house: whether to rent it out, sell it and buy somewhere else to let, or to buy a flat in Italy.

Their Friends Provident endowment is no longer needed to repay the mortgage as they have switched to a repayment. They now want to sort out their pensions, savings and make the most of their income: 'Although we are downshifting, we don't want to be rash.'

Adviser 1: Steve Travis

If Keith works more than one complete tax year overseas, he becomes non-resident for UK tax and, by leaving in August, they can claim a substantial refund. Inland Revenue booklet IR20 has details. Keith can avoid Italian tax by working for a recognised school for less than two years.

If they retire in Italy, their local authority pensions will still be taxed in the UK after UK personal allowances, while overseas income is taxed in Italy. So they gain two sets of allowances but two sets of tax forms.

Keith should join the Italian occupational pension and will pay the Italian equivalent of National Insurance contributions. Kate should make voluntary contributions for the UK state pen sion until she earns enough to join the Italian scheme.

Repaying a mortgage is good but not if the property is let because mortgage interest can be offset against rent. They could sell the house tax free, use a third as deposit with a buy-to-let mortgage and use the balance to buy a home in Italy. They can avoid capital gains tax on a new UK property if they buy after they become non-resident and sell in the tax year before they return. They cannot buy Isas once they are non-resident but can keep existing ones although there is no point in Isas if they stay abroad.

As Keith will be paid in euros, Rothschilds Euro Money Fund in Guernsey is a useful instant access account.

Steve Travis is overseas manager with adviser Wilfred T Fry.

Adviser 2: Neil Wright

The Gilberts are facing a major change. It can take a year to form a clear picture after such an upheaval so they should keep their finances as flexible, accessible and liquid as possible.

As they might return to the UK, and especially if they retain UK property, their base currency is sterling so they should plan around sterling assets and liabilities. If the UK adopts the euro, their base currency would then be the domestic currency of both Italy and the UK.

The Gilberts will be resident in Italy for tax purposes while living there, although a double taxation treaty with Italy protects them from paying tax twice. Retaining a UK home keeps them in the property market but ties up their money.

They might be able to earn higher income from other assets and could keep pace with property prices by investing in a property fund.

The endowment may not be worth retaining. They would get more than the surrender value by selling it second-hand but should do nothing yet if they qualify for Friends Provident's demutualisation windfall.

They should keep a large chunk of cash while their future is uncertain. Collective stock market investments such as open-ended investment companies (Oeics) are suitable for the longer term, and the recent market falls make it a better time to invest than a year ago.

Neil Wright works for PricewaterhouseCoopers.

You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Rathbone Global Companies Fund
fields.trailText: Rathbone Global Companies Fund.
fields.body:
Contact 020 7399 0399

Aim To provide above-average, long-term capital growth from a global equity portfolio.

Bells & whistles The fund will be run by Hugh Priestly, who manages Rathbone's Esk and Technology funds (both of which have been hit by the recent collapse in technology share prices) and formerly managed the Witan investment trust. He says: 'Following major falls in stock markets over the past 13 months we are beginning to see value emerging, which is why we think it's a good time to launch the fund. It will concentrate initially on finding interesting situations in the mid-cap area, especially Europe and Japan.'

How it works The fund will mostly be invested in larger companies but will also include mid and smaller capitalisation stocks. Key sectors are likely to include outsourcing (20 per cent), leisure (10 per cent), financial services (10 per cent) and technology (25 per cent). The fund manager will favour companies with above-average growth or value potential with good prospects on a global basis. The portfolio will hold about 50 stocks, with around 40 per cent invested in continental Europe and 25 per cent in the UK.

Minimum £1,000, monthly savings £100.

Charges Initial 5.5 per cent, annual 1.5 per cent.

Tax Tax-free through an Isa or Pep transfer, otherwise liable to tax.

webTitle: Money writes: Earthquake sent me flying for £200

fields.headline: Earthquake sent me flying for £200
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I was travelling to Gujarat as part of an organised tour at the time of the earthquake last January. Thankfully none of our group was injured but the devastation meant we had to alter our travel arrangements.

We cancelled an overnight train journey and instead organised flights from Gujarat to Bombay and then on to Udaipur to continue our tour. The extra cost was $275 (£198).

We received repeated demands for payment from the travel company while in India. We did not pay and referred it to our travel insurance company, but I wondered whose responsibility are the additional costs and should they be absorbed by the travel firm?
JB, Oxford

Tour operators are contracted to provide the holiday you booked and paid for, and they are responsible for unavoidable extra costs. You are entitled to insist that the local office provides the amended arrangements.

If you had a representative travelling with you, you could have left him or her to sort it out. But, if the travel company absolutely refuses to help, perhaps because the local office does not have the authority or the money to buy extra airline tickets, there is nothing you can do until you get home.

Then you can chase the tour operator's head office or claim on your holiday insurance, although many policies do not cover an itinerary change.

Commonly, there is no compensation if the first leg of a journey leaves on time but is delayed arriving so you miss the second leg: there is cash for a delayed departure but not for delayed arrival.

Policies pay if your holiday is cut short and you have to fly home, but not for a change of travel arrangements or extra hotels to help you continue your trip.

Cover excludes a tour operator's failure to deliver a service you have booked, although if you paid by credit card, you might be able to claim from the card company.

Bill £520 too low: Must I own up?

I booked two flights and hired a car through a no-frills airline last September for a total of £520. On picking up the car, I arranged to include a second driver and there was a 'location charge', together costing £76. On my credit card statement, I was charged only the £76 for extras.

Five months on I have still not been charged for the flights and car hire. Am I under any obligation to notify the airline of its mistake? When they do wake up, am I liable for extra charges or penalties? Should I just keep quiet?
CE, London

You have no legal obligation to bring this to anyone's attention. The airline might have failed to put through the voucher, in which case it has not received the money from the card company.

But possibly the card company forgot to bill you, after reimbursing the airline. If this charge does eventually turn up on your statement, of course you must pay. Whether you sort out the mistake is between you and your conscience.

Car theft cover: Discourtesy car

I have a motor insurance policy with Norwich Union Direct. When my four-door car was stolen, I requested a four-door courtesy car. I have a small child and chose a four-door car for convenience and safety. The company said I was entitled only to a small two-door hatchback. The policy says nothing about it having to be a two-door vehicle.
KM, Ashford

Norwich Union says its policy promises 'small hatchback-type cars', which invariably are two-door. It will allow you a larger car if you pay the difference.

Scottish strife? You can't lose

I have two Scottish Life endowment policies, but feel the firm is trying to exclude me from the windfalls likely when it demutualises. It says I will be compensated for loss of membership for one endowment but that the other has been reassigned. The £500 compensation appears less than I might receive as a windfall. Must I accept this lesser pay-off?
SK, Southport

Unlike other insurers, Scottish Life's deed does not allow it to pay windfalls to customers whose policies have been assigned to a mortgage lender, even if reassigned back to them. But as your other policy was not assigned, you do count as a member and, as you can be counted only once, you will get £500, plus extra bonuses worth on average £3,500. You have lost nothing.

 Let us help you. Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, and please include a telephone number but do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Insurers scramble to make the cap fit

fields.headline: Insurers scramble to make the cap fit
fields.standfirst: Desperate tactics are being used to plug the annuities black hole, finds  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Desperate tactics are being used to plug the annuities black hole, finds Tracey Boles
fields.body:
The life industry, left reeling by a £10bn hit from guaranteed annuities, as reported in The Observer last week, has embarked on a number of strategies to try and lessen the blow.

Most ingenious appears to be Scottish Widows, the Lloyds TSB subsidiary, which has been 'incentivising' policyholders not to exercise their guaranteed annuity options by giving them a juicy top-up if they buy an annuity from another provider.

Equitable Life is trying to cap its guaranteed annuity liability at current levels, estimated to be at the £2bn mark.

But why have annuities become such a horrendous liability, and what are the consequences for the life sector, already under strain from falling stock market returns and the set-up costs of stakeholder pensions?

An annuity is a product designed to generate a pension during retirement once your pension fund has matured. It pays an annual income linked to interest rates. Guaranteed annuities have become a liability because the rate at which the guarantee was set when the policies were sold in the 1970s and 1980s, typically 11 per cent, is much higher than annuity rates being paid in the present interest rate environment, which are more like 7 or 8 per cent.

This has left policyholders who choose to take up the guarantee in the money, while the life industry is out of pocket because it has to set aside sufficient funds to make up the difference.

A turning point in the story came in 1998, when the Government Actuaries' Department (GAD) issued guidance on how life offices did their sums for guaranteed annuities. It instructed the life companies to assume 80 per cent or more of policyholders would choose to exercise their guaranteed annuity option when calculating the reserves need to cover the liability.

Until then companies had been free to decide the likely level of take-up. This precipitated the Equitable crisis, one that saw the UK's oldest mutual forced to shut up shop to new business when it failed to find a buyer late last year.

When GAD's rules came in, Equitable found it did not have the £1.5bn it would require after years of distributing its returns to policyholders in the form of bonuses.

Instead, it used a series of actuarial and accounting devices to bolster its solvency - and it signed a reinsurance deal with a Dublin-based subsidiary of GE Capital, which gave it an extra £800m for its balance sheet.

The problem was that the deal did not cover the mutual should its stance of not honouring the guarantees given to GAR policyholders be overturned in court - which is exactly what happened when a group of policyholders won their right to the guaranteed rates in the House of Lords last July.

The life office's new board now appears to be looking for someone to blame for the sequence of events that led up to its fall. Earlier this month it announced it had hired City law firm Herbert Smith to probe the conduct of the former board and its advisers, including former law firm Denton Wilde Sapte.

Herbert Smith will be collecting evidence with a view to mounting a court case, which could finally see policyholders compensated. Policyholders lost out last year when Equitable suspended bonus payouts to them for seven months.

William Clutterbuck, spokesman for Equitable, says: 'We were asked if we were going to sue at a policyholders meeting, and we vowed to leave no stone unturned. But we will only bring a lawsuit if it is not too expensive and is likely to succeed.

'Building a case is more difficult than arguing that someone made the wrong decision. There's no point spending money on lawyers otherwise.'

Stuart Bayliss, head of the Equitable Life Guaranteed Annuity Action Group, says: 'In terms of understanding where it all went wrong the probe will be helpful. But it will be difficult to gather information for a legal action to prove culpability.

'It might show certain people inside Equitable what they have not admitted yet, that they did something wrong.'

He also believes it will throw light on the actions of Equitable's former solicitors, which gave the life office some 'very heavy advice'.

Some commentators have condemned the move to appoint a law firm as little more than a public relations exercise to appease policyholders when it is crucial that Equitable get them onside.

On Thursday all interested parties will be meeting to thrash out the details of how to cap Equitable's GAR liability. The cap, which the majority of policyholders have to agree to, is necessary if Equitable is to come into the £500m it has been promised as the second part of its rescue package with Halifax.

At the table with Equitable Life will be advisers Schroders and action groups. Some of the issues they will be discussing are the cost of the cap to GAR policyholders - some 78,000 policyholders will see their guarantee docked by 20 per cent if they agree to Bayliss' proposals - and a sweetener to get the non-GAR policyholders to agree to it, perhaps in the form of a special addition to the terminal bonuses.

Bayliss hopes such a sweetener will go some way towards restoring the money that policyholders lost last year when bonuses were suspended.

'Policyholders lost seven-twelfths of their 8 per cent bonus last year. Getting it back will cost more than the £500m that has been put forward by Halifax so far but maybe more money will come from somewhere else. Consenting to capping the liability will strengthen the reserves, which can then be allocated to policies as a terminal bonus.'

Bayliss hopes decisions made at this week's meeting will form the basis of a directional hearing so that the cap can be cleared in the courts and put to members in the autumn.

But the omens are not good. Equitable commissioned pollsters Mori to gauge the feelings of 1,000 policyholders towards the cap. Bayliss says early indications from Mori are that policyholders are decidedly lukewarm towards any such deal, at least until they see more details. 'They don't trust Equitable anymore,' says Bayliss.

Equitable is not the only one with an unwieldy GAR liability on its hands, however. Some 40 life offices are affected. Although some are comfortably reserved others will have to reduce bonuses to policyholders as they struggle to pay their GAR bill. Some may even have to close to new business as a cost-cutting measure while others require a cash injection from shareholders.

As well as caps and bribes, another ruse to limit the exposure to liabilities is to enter into a deal with a counterparty, which ensures protection against falling interest rates. With such a deal interest rate movements that work against one party work for another - but they do not come cheap.

Royal & SunAlliance is understood to have entered into such a contract for £500m. Scottish Widows has also adopted the strategy, forging links with unnamed banks. An analyst says: 'A contract for differences will make the cost of the GARs less painful. Otherwise the exposure could kill you.'

It will be 15 years before we know the full extent of the GAR problem because that is when the majority of people who were sold the policies retire. But one thing is for sure - the life sector is about to experience a frenzy of takeover activity as weakened companies struggle to survive.

'We are in a huge period of change due to the combined effects of the markets, stakeholder and guaranteed annuities,' an analyst said. 'Anyone in the sector could be a takeover target. If I name one I have to name 40.'

The worst hit

Abbey Life has already received hundreds of millions of pounds of shareholders' money from parent Lloyds TSB. It is understood that Lloyds has poured £100m into Abbey Life since 1998 when it had to inject £176m into Abbey because the life office fell below the legal minimum solvency levels due to escalating GAR and pensions mis-selling costs.

Investors in Royal & SunAlliance may be asked to bail out subsidiary SunAlliance & London which has been landed with a £700m annuity bill.

Norwich Union's life and pension fund is facing a £1.1bn hit. It says the liability has been fully accounted for but an industry analyst says the NU fund is 'relatively weak' and will feel the strain.

NATIONAL MUTUAL, which has a £200m liability, is reviewing its mutual status with a view to a sale and it is believed MGM Assurance could follow suit.

webTitle: Talk is cheap. What CMG needs is action

fields.headline: Talk is cheap. What CMG needs is action
fields.trailText: Three weeks ago, we warned you that it was too early to buy into IT services groups such as CMG and Logica. Last week, CMG duly proved us right with a warning that its Wireless Data Solutions (WDS) business - the part that supplies the kit for text messaging on mobiles - was suffering a fall in demand. The shares, 560p when we gave our warning - and £17.78 just 15 months ago - ended last week at 361.5p. The key question is, is it worth buying now?
fields.body:
Three weeks ago, we warned you that it was too early to buy into IT services groups such as CMG and Logica. Last week, CMG duly proved us right with a warning that its Wireless Data Solutions (WDS) business - the part that supplies the kit for text messaging on mobiles - was suffering a fall in demand. The shares, 560p when we gave our warning - and £17.78 just 15 months ago - ended last week at 361.5p. The key question is, is it worth buying now?

CMG is confident that orders are simply being delayed by telecoms companies, which are having to learn to conserve their cash. As text messaging continues to grow they will be forced to upgrade their capacity or risk alienating customers with poor service quality.

To prove its confidence, it is continuing with plans to plough £60 million into research and development to come up with yet more improvements and to ready itself for the switch to third-generation technology.

There is little doubt that text messaging is still enjoying phenomenal growth. The number of messages sent rose from 15 billion in December to 25bn in March, yet, we Brits send less through the four big operators than Germans do through just one.

But the rate of growth must, inevitably, slow - particularly in the more developed areas of Europe, which are CMG's heartland. That will force it to look to emerging markets, where risks are higher, or to unproven technologies such as 3G, where the starting date is uncertain.

CMG warns that the rate of investment means it will lose around £30m on its WDS business this year but analysts think it could generate enough orders in the second half of the year to allow it to break even. However, that is a far cry from the kind of optimistic forecasts being made as recently as two months ago.

Much of CMG's valuation depended on it at least maintaining its phenomenal growth. The multiple has already fallen sharply but so, too, have the earnings forecasts which, at around 5p a share for this year, are less than a third of what they were at the start of the year. Even at the much reduced share price, they still stand on around 50 times earnings. Yet one institutional shareholder believes there could be further profit warnings to come as other parts of the business start to slow. The shares still do not look like a bargain.

Special case

Should shareholders be given the chance to vote on special bonuses for senior executives? Most companies would say no.

But, as one shareholder pointed out, these bonuses are made because of the gratitude of the board for some deal or deed during the year.

Investors may not be equipped to vote on the general run of company bonus schemes, but ex gratia payments are different. Shareholders are able to judge their merits. They should be allowed to do so.

Sitting pretty

DFS Furniture is a class act. The City may have worried about executive chairman Graham Kirkham's warning that progress this year could be more modest than last, but there is little doubt that it is better placed than many retailers to cope should a slowdown happen.

Interim results demonstrated that it has put the hiccups of a couple of years ago firmly behind it. Sales, excluding new openings, rose by 8.5 per cent while profits before tax jumped 10.8 per cent to £8.2m. Margins may have dipped slightly because of new opening costs but, at 12.3 per cent, are still extremely healthy.

True, sales growth is slowing - in the four weeks to Easter, the rate was just 5 per cent - but that is against an extremely buoyant period last year. And, with just two stores in Scotland - both opened within the past six months - and big gaps elsewhere, there is considerable scope for expansion. It is planning a 72 per cent rise in capital spending, to £16.9m, this year.

Some in the City were also concerned that the prospects for another special dividend had been reduced by the likelihood that it will lose its case against Customs & Excise about the payment of VAT on interest-free sales.That is not certain. Losing the case would mean that much of the £61.8m provided would have to be paid out, but it thinks the length of time the case has taken to resolve means it could keep as much as £15m of that from claims which have now exceeded their time limit.

The cash flow remains strong and Richard Ratner of Seymour Pierce thinks it could afford a 10p special dividend at the end of the year. Profits for the full-year are expected to be around £50m, putting the shares on a multiple of 14p and a 5 per cent yield, even without a special dividend. In these uncertain times there are far worse places to be. Buy.

But the rate of growth must, inevitably, slow - particularly in the more developed areas of Europe, which are CMG's heartland. That will force it to look to emerging markets, where risks are higher, or to unproven technologies such as 3G, where the starting date is uncertain. CMG warns that the rate of investment means it will lose around £30m on its WDS business this year but analysts think it could generate enough orders in the second half of the year to allow it to break even. However, that is a far cry from the kind of optimistic forecasts being made as recently as two months ago. Much of CMG's valuation depended on it at least maintaining its phenomenal growth. The multiple has already fallen sharply but so, too, have the earnings forecasts which, at around 5p a share for this year, are less than a third of what they were at the start of the year. Even at the much reduced share price, they still stand on around 50 times earnings. Yet one institutional shareholder believes there could be further profit warnings to come as other parts of the business start to slow. The shares still do not look like a bargain. Special case Should shareholders be given the chance to vote on special bonuses for senior executives? Most companies would say no. But, as one shareholder pointed out, these bonuses are made because of the gratitude of the board for some deal or deed during the year. Investors may not be equipped to vote on the general run of company bonus schemes, but ex gratia payments are different. Shareholders are able to judge their merits. They should be allowed to do so. Sitting pretty DFS Furniture is a class act. The City may have worried about executive chairman Graham Kirkham's warning that progress this year could be more modest than last, but there is little doubt that it is better placed than many retailers to cope should a slowdown happen. Interim results demonstrated that it has put the hiccups of a couple of years ago firmly behind it. Sales, excluding new openings, rose by 8.5 per cent while profits before tax jumped 10.8 per cent to £8.2m. Margins may have dipped slightly because of new opening costs but, at 12.3 per cent, are still extremely healthy. True, sales growth is slowing - in the four weeks to Easter, the rate was just 5 per cent - but that is against an extremely buoyant period last year. And, with just two stores in Scotland - both opened within the past six months - and big gaps elsewhere, there is considerable scope for expansion. It is planning a 72 per cent rise in capital spending, to £16.9m, this year. Some in the City were also concerned that the prospects for another special dividend had been reduced by the likelihood that it will lose its case against Customs & Excise about the payment of VAT on interest-free sales.That is not certain. Losing the case would mean that much of the £61.8m provided would have to be paid out, but it thinks the length of time the case has taken to resolve means it could keep as much as £15m of that from claims which have now exceeded their time limit. The cash flow remains strong and Richard Ratner of Seymour Pierce thinks it could afford a 10p special dividend at the end of the year. Profits for the full-year are expected to be around £50m, putting the shares on a multiple of 14p and a 5 per cent yield, even without a special dividend. In these uncertain times there are far worse places to be. Buy.

webTitle: Fed's fast one leaves everyone guessing

fields.headline: Fed's fast one leaves everyone guessing
fields.trailText: Retail investors and acolytes of financial spread betting could only describe their relationship with global stock markets in the past year as wholly acrimonious or, at best, a state of armed neutrality. Who can blame them?
fields.body:
Retail investors and acolytes of financial spread betting could only describe their relationship with global stock markets in the past year as wholly acrimonious or, at best, a state of armed neutrality. Who can blame them?

The United States experienced a period of enforced inertia during the presidential election last November (and December). Consequently the 'Good Doctor', Alan Greenspan, had his fiscal hands tied behind his back when positive and decisive action was required to stimulate an ailing economy - the state of which was duplicitously being hidden from the public by the outgoing Democrat administration.

Point scoring

The Fed chairman was strongly criticised for tightening too sharply at the turn of the Millennium. Back then, there was a case for introducing preventive legislation on the retail investor, who found terms for borrowing from a very co-operative banking sector keen to fund a rampant stock market irresistible.

Punters felt that they had found a scapegoat to pin the donkey's tail on, but - Lo! and behold - the Fed drops rates 150 basis points in double-quick time, in what appeared to be a hasty response to a venomously trashed Nasdaq.

This, of course, would be officially denied, but the economic 'Messiah' of the last decade is in serious danger of losing some of his credibility. Market operators believe 'Saint Alan' is consistently arriving at the scene of the crime 'a day late and a dollar short'.

Those of us spread betters conversant with pitting our wits against the vagaries of a slowing US economy were just about getting a handle on the bear-trading tack, which had proved so profitable for the enlightened until the end of March.

First cut is deepest

Then at the beginning of the last week, the market waited with bated breath for the expected poor results from the likes of Cisco, Motorola, Texas Instruments, Hewlett-Packard and Gillette, which fell largely in line. Intel, however, surprised those who had pursued a relentless quest to support overvalued tech stocks. And then, like a bolt out of the blue, a further 50 basis points were cut from the Fed rate, to 4.5 per cent.

What are investors and punters supposed to believe? Should they respond positively to the draconian commercial measures, such as cutting staff, now frequently imposed by captains of industry? Is the US economy deep in the mire?

If the US futures market is an accurate guide, there will only be a 25 basis-point cut in the Fed rate at the next open market committee meeting on 11 May. The spread in the market is 23 to -27.

The week's bets

The intrepid punter has had a decent week - richly earned in such trying circumstances. Having availed themselves last Thursday of Cisco ($17.00), JDS Uniphase ($18.50) and Ebay ($38.00), they baled out of the first two on Wednesday night at $18.00 and $22.20. But the wait for Ebay's figures on Thursday night left their cups overflowing at $55.10.

The writing of a covered call on the Nasdaq for 150 points out of the money against buying the index proved a lucrative trade - again terminated on Wednesday afternoon.

Bankable sectors

Where do the Gladiator and his cohorts go 'to get the baby a new coat' this week? A mixed bag of results from Nokia and Ericsson muddied the tech market's waters on Friday, so we will leave that alone.

Last week's skirmish with UK banking shares proved a rewarding occupation. In the hope that the recalcitrant Wim Duisenberg's ECB committee will come into line on interest rates, buyers have sharpened their pencils to buy BNP Paribas, Deutsche Bank and ABN-Amro. In the UK, the banking sector has risen by 14 per cent since 22 March and there is still the temptation to buy this sector of the FTSE Actuaries Indices on a spread of 9,981-10,031, in view of falling interest rates. But it might be a case of going to the well once too often.

Many battle-scarred warriors prefer the comfort of a basket of constituent companies rather than being held to ransom by one stock. Orders have been placed to buy the 'general retailers' sector on a possible spread of 1,833-1,842. There are 41 companies, including M&S, Arcadia, Gus, Boot's and Dixons, and according to stock-market historian David Schwartz, in the past 36 years there has been an 83 per cent success rate in April.

Election candidates

Trading indices look a bit of a lottery this week. So the troops believe that, with the election probably less than two months away, buying construction shares such as Taylor Woodrow, Balfour Beatty and Bovis could pay, in anticipation of more hospitals.

To balance the books a few sell orders in the utility sector, which has performed with considerable aplomb in the last year, will be the order of the day. Why? Because this political mob just loves red tape and regulation with a passion! So without prejudice or discrimination, Scottish Power, Severn Trent and United Utilities will be temporarily thrown to the lions.

The Gladiator is the nom de plume of a professional spread better

fields.headline: Economy 'still at risk'
fields.trailText: The UK economy is still at risk from a US recession, says a respected economic forecaster. Last week's interest rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve may be insufficient to prevent the US economy dragging down the UK, says Professor Peter Spencer, author of the Ernst & Young Item Club report.
fields.body:
The UK economy is still at risk from a US recession, says a respected economic forecaster. Last week's interest rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve may be insufficient to prevent the US economy dragging down the UK, says Professor Peter Spencer, author of the Ernst & Young Item Club report.

'The UK economy is slowing sharply, and the downside risks are more threatening than before,' says the fore cast, which uses the same economic model as the Treasury. The first indication of the impact of the US slowdown and the foot and mouth crisis will come on Friday, when the preliminary figure for first-quarter growth is released.

The US economic situation is also increasing international pressure on the European Central Bank to cut rates on Thursday. Central bankers and finance ministers from around the world will meet next weekend in Washington for the spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund, World Bank, and the Group of Seven.

'There should be a general agreement to cut interest rates internationally by 1 per cent,' says Professor Spencer. 'But I don't think we are going to get it. Europe and the US will be at loggerheads over everything from Kyoto to trade.'

webTitle: Glaxo eyes £150bn bid for US rival

fields.headline: Glaxo eyes £150bn bid for US rival
fields.trailText: British drugs giant GlaxoSmithKline is considering fresh talks about a £150 billion merger with US rival American Home Products to create the world's biggest pharmaceuticals company.
fields.body:
British drugs giant GlaxoSmithKline is considering fresh talks about a £150 billion merger with US rival American Home Products to create the world's biggest pharmaceuticals company.

The news comes only days after GSK - as the group now styles itself - suffered a humiliating defeat in its attempt to stop South Africa importing copies of its best-selling Aids treatments.

Company insiders say GSK's ambitious new chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier has charged a top level 'task force' with finding targets to regain its place as the world number one, a slot now occupied by US rival Pfizer.

AHP, insiders say, remains Garnier's favoured US target for his next big deal, despite the failure of merger talks three years ago.

GSK - formed last December from the £100bn merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham - will announce maiden profits of £1.3bn this week for the first quarter alone. For the UK rivals it was a deal at the second attempt after Glaxo broke up SmithKline's planned merger with AHP in 1998 but then walked away from SmithKline too. Next month, AHP's veteran boss Jack Stafford steps down as chief executive, a move which may smooth the path to an eventual deal, insiders say.

'Garnier still admires AHP greatly from his SmithKline days,' one GSK insider said. 'The two fit like a glove, strong in vaccines and consumer products. AHP also has a good new drugs pipeline while Glaxo and SmithKline's have been relatively weak.'

Apart from the US, expansion in Japan is a top priority. Last year, The Observer can reveal, SmithKline was on the verge of buying the drugs business of Japanese chemicals group Asahi.

The Japanese pulled out, however, on news of the Glaxo talks. Licensing deals were struck instead, but takeover negotiations could be revived, insiders say.

In Europe, the GSK task force - led by worldwide business development head Dr Russell Greig and research and development chairman Tadataka Yamada - is understood to have looked at the Danish leader in diabetes drugs, Novo Nordisk.

Garnier has also been careful to cultivate relations with Sanofi-Synthelabo, the fast-growing French number two, now worth over £25bn.

This weekend, GSK declined official comment on the taskforce's work. 'It's not just us, it's everyone. If the right thing comes along, we'd look at it,' a spokesman said. 'But we are more interested in products and pipelines than just companies.'

Last week's South African defeat is expected to prompt further consolidation, as firms seek to spread the high costs of drug development. GSK, however, faces stiff competition from rivals, including fellow UK group AstraZeneca, which also has strong ambitions to expand in the US and Japan.

fields.headline: HMV steers away from break-up
fields.trailText: A break-up of HMV Media, the record shops-to-bookstore chain whose flagship stores are in London's Oxford Street, will be quashed when the debt-laden, privately owned group agrees new profit targets with its bankers later this month, writes Jamie Doward .
fields.body:
A break-up of HMV Media, the record shops-to-bookstore chain whose flagship stores are in London's Oxford Street, will be quashed when the debt-laden, privately owned group agrees new profit targets with its bankers later this month, writes Jamie Doward .

HMV's future had been uncertain after it failed to meet the targets which were the basis of a series of loan covenants agreed when it was formed in 1998. Its failure to hit the targets raised the possibility that its bankers, led by UBS Warburg and Merrill Lynch, might pull its credit line and force a sale of assets. But HMV, 85 per cent owned by EMI and venture capital firm Advent International, has agreed a revised set of profit targets that will be rubber-stamped this month.

Tim Waterstone, the company's former chairman, recently attempted a buy-out of his old book chain Waterstone's, which would have left the group with just its HMV chain, including the Oxford Street stores. HMV's revised targets mean a renewed bid is unlikely.

webTitle: Public must wait for new mobiles

fields.headline: Public must wait for new mobiles
fields.trailText: Serious technical problems are forcing the UK mobile phone networks to delay - for up to a year - the commercial launch of the crucial next generation wireless internet service.
fields.body:
Serious technical problems are forcing the UK mobile phone networks to delay - for up to a year - the commercial launch of the crucial next generation wireless internet service.

The companies originally wanted to launch General Packet Radio Services (GPRS), which allows users to swap emails and video clips, in the second quarter of this year as a stepping stone to the so-called '3G' high speed wireless internet technology. The industry hopes it will be a major source of revenue. But a series of glitches mean it is unlikely to become widely available until next year.

The phone handset manufacturers are having problems making sure that the new devices work on the British operators' networks. This has forced the mobile companies to extend their test periods and postpone the launches.

John Fletcher, senior consultant with the telecoms consultancy Analysys, said: 'The handset manufacturers have been using their own networks to test the stuff, not their clients' networks.'

A report by banker Credit Suisse First Boston says: 'At least initially, operators will be constrained in the handsets they can offer customers, and they may have to spend a lot of time ironing out wrinkles in the network before being ready to be launched on the mass market.

'This compatibility issue threatens to delay the widespread launch of GPRS.'

GSM, the current technology, suffered launch delays. But the problems of GPRS appear more fundamental,' said Dougal Scott of Spectrum Consulting.

Orange now plans to delay the new system to the third quarter of this year.

A spokesman for One2One, once the most vociferous advocate of GPRS, said: 'We don't want to be specific about a launch date.

'Currently there are technical issues that have to be resolved. That's why we're having the trials.' BT Cellnet, meanwhile, was embarrassed last week when a high-profile presentation of the new technology suffered a very public series of glitches.

The largest mobile network, Vodafone, which has already launched a corporate GPRS service, claims it will launch the system for mass market customers by mid-summer.

The cautious start for GPRS means that the revenue streams sought from it are unlikely to have any impact on the companies' accounts until next year at the earliest.

The CSFB document concluded: 'We do not expect GPRS to sell a sufficient size to make an impact on cashflow and earnings figures for 2001. This suggests to us that GPRS will not lift stock [prices] this year.'
