webTitle: Oppenheimer buyout of De Beers 'on a knife edge'

fields.headline: Oppenheimer buyout of De Beers 'on a knife edge'
fields.trailText: Senior executives of De Beers are flying to South Africa this weekend in a last-ditch attempt to salvage the diamond giant's £12 billion buy-out by the country's Oppenheimer dynasty.
fields.body:
Senior executives of De Beers are flying to South Africa this weekend in a last-ditch attempt to salvage the diamond giant's £12 billion buy-out by the country's Oppenheimer dynasty.

The unprecedented move by the Oppenheimers to lobby South Africa's financial institutions follows a decision late on Friday by two of De Beers' biggest US shareholders to oppose the deal.

This weekend De Beers sources said the buy-out was now 'on a knife-edge'. The US investors - Brandes and Southeastern Asset Management - control 10 per cent of the diamond firm, two thirds of the amount needed to block the Oppenheimers' ambitions under the complex terms of the deal.

The rebels, who have been joined by clients of Johannesburg stockbroker Barnard Jacobs Mellett, are demanding either a higher price or an end to cross-holdings between De Beers and Anglo American, the family's mining company, which would see the diamond giant freed from Oppenheimer control for the first time.

This weekend De Beers rejected both sets of demands, setting up a nail-biting confrontation ahead of the vote by shareholders on 4 May.

'The deal is on a knife-edge,' one source close to De Beers said. 'It's a game of poker and the question is who's going to blink first. It's going to take more investors to tip this over, but the danger is now that more might come out against.'

fields.headline: Widows offers policyholders pension 'bribe'
fields.trailText: Insurer Scottish Widows is effectively bribing policyholders covered by pension guarantees not to take them up, say independent financial advisers. The bait, it is claimed, is extra money if the clients take their pension funds elsewhere.
fields.body:
Insurer Scottish Widows is effectively bribing policyholders covered by pension guarantees not to take them up, say independent financial advisers. The bait, it is claimed, is extra money if the clients take their pension funds elsewhere.

The aim is to limit the £4.1bn guaranteed annuity liability on the firm's books, according to the advisers.

Similar guarantees plunged rival insurer Equitable Life into crisis late last year. They have become a liability because the rate at which the guarantees were set when the policies were sold in the Seventies and Eighties is much higher than current rates.

The Observer revealed last week that life companies are having to stump up £10bn to pay for the annuities, a bill which will help provoke a frenzy of takeover activity in the sector.

Scottish Widows policyholders electing to buy an annuity with another provider will go away with a bigger pension pot than those who opt for the guarantee and stay. The top-up is to reflect the value of the guarantee they relinquish.

'They are doing this for one of two reasons,' says Peter Quinton of the Annuity Bureau, a firm of independent financial advisers. 'They don't want the liability to rain on their book, or they want to make policyholders aware of their options.'

A Scottish Widows official said it did not encourage clients to leave - 'but in line with best market practice [it] tells all pension policyholders at retirement that they are not restricted to taking a Scottish Widows annuity.

'This happens whether or not there is a guaranteed annuity rate option.'

However, advisers say Widows is encouraging the practice by writing to tell its 145,000 policyholders with guarantees about the top-ups.

webTitle: Big... and plotting to become bigger still

fields.headline: Big... and plotting to become bigger still
fields.standfirst: Climbdown will not dent health giants' power, says Paul Farrelly
fields.trailText: Climbdown will not dent health giants' power, says Paul Farrelly
fields.body:
South Africa may have scored a historic victory over some of the world's biggest companies to allow its Aids sufferers access to cheaper drugs but its antagonists are set to become even larger and more powerful.

During the next decade consolidation in the global pharmaceuticals industry will shrink South Africa's 39 court opponents beyond recognition so that multinational drugs giants such as Britain's GlaxoSmithKline and Merck of the US will be more influential in the health systems of developing countries.

The market capitalisation of the top three drugs firms alone is double the $300 billion gross domestic product of South Africa, the continent's richest nation. In the past five years, the leading multi-nationals have notched up deals worth $500bn as they jockey for power through mergers and takeovers.

Because the stakes are so high it is that battle - the survival of the fittest - that preoccupies the industry far more than court disputes in countries far away.

Since a deal-making frenzy just over a year ago the industry has paused, much to the chagrin of City and Wall Street investment bankers. Then Glaxo Wellcome con summated at $160bn merger with SmithKlineBeecham, knocking Merck off its perch as world number one. The triumph was short-lived: Pfizer's $85bn raid on US rival Warner Lambert catapulted the sector's slickest marketing operation into the top spot.

For good measure, US-Swedish Pharmacia & Upjohn confounded critics last year by pulling off a $50bn merger with Monsanto, the controversial GM food company, which makes the world's fastest-growing drug, Celebrex, for osteoarthritis.

'The process will not stop there. The main drivers - spreading the high costs of research and development and marketing muscle - are still the same,' one top industry executive said. 'Besides, a number of firms have been leapfrogged and are really piqued at falling behind.'

Of the top 10 drugs firms, six owe their rankings to recent mega-mergers. Britain's Zeneca tied a $70bn knot with Sweden's Astra in 1998, then Europe's biggest ever deal; Germany's Hoechst Marion Roussel consigned cultural differences to the dustbin in a $50bn merger with France's Rhone Poulenc Rorer; and Swiss numbers two and three Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz joined up in a $30bn deal to form Novartis in 1996.

As a result, two of Europe's best-known names - the sleeping Swiss giant Roche and Germany's Bayer, inventor of aspirin - no longer make the top 10. 'Both have weak drugs pipelines but deep pockets, and are looking avariciously for the right deal,' one industry consultant said.

This year, analysts expect the cash-flush Roche finally to reform its age-old capital structure, ditching the anonymous 'bearer shares', which are useless as deal-making currency. Roche tried unsuccessfully to woo Astra away from Zeneca and has looked at Bayer as well as middle-ranking US firms that have fallen behind, such as Abbott, Schering Plough and Prozac-maker Eli Lilly. An all-Swiss solution, however, involving a tie-up with Novartis, may yet be on the cards.

Bayer, too, has appointed bankers CSFB and Deutsche to advise on a shake-up. The old-fashioned chemicals-to-drugs conglomerate is understood to be in talks with Aventis to buy its $7bn crop science arm and US rival DuPont's drugs operation. Down the line, a break-up is on the cards, freeing Bayer's pharmaceuticals division for a cross-border merger.

While Europe's drug makers have been hopping into bed, so far the US has remained relatively aloof. Indeed, the big three - Merck, Bristol-Meyers Squibb and baby oil maker Johnson & Johnson - have spurned the urge to merge. BSM, however, is now spinning off its Zimmer equipment and Clairol haircare businesses, making it a riper target for the likes of GlaxoSmithKline. But if any big overseas predator came hunting, insiders believe Merck would find it hard to stay on the sidelines.

'Merck has always wrong-footed the industry by doing the opposite of what everyone expected,' a senior executive of a rival firm said. 'If anyone went for a US rival, Merck would rethink, but I expect it would rather do something really clever in biotech.'

Ironically, the one US top 10 firmmost eager to wed - American Home Products - has been left at the altar many times.Warner Lambert was to be AHP's next prize after it failed to clinch deals with SmithKline Beecham and Monsanto.

Pfizer's firepower, however, more than sent AHP packing. The battle for Warner unmasked another deep-pocketed predator: Procter & Gamble, the Fairy Liquid giant. Last year, three-way talks between AHP, Warner and P&G came to nought. If, however, Johnson & Johnson came under siege, America's biggest and most secretive maker of consumer goods might be tempted to declare its hand once more.

webTitle: BA demands an end to airport crush

fields.headline: BA demands an end to airport crush
fields.trailText: British Airways' chief executive Rod Eddington will warn this week that Britain will 'lose its place at the top table' of world air transport unless the Government quickly sanctions more airport capacity in the South-east, writes Joanna Walters.
fields.body:
British Airways' chief executive Rod Eddington will warn this week that Britain will 'lose its place at the top table' of world air transport unless the Government quickly sanctions more airport capacity in the South-east, writes Joanna Walters.

Eddington, a former boss of the Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific, will contrast what he sees as British inertia with the rapid pace of development in the former UK colony, which doubled its aviation capacity in five years during the Nineties by building a massive offshore airport.

He will warn that Heathrow has already been overtaken by the rapidly expanding airports at Frankfurt and Paris Charles de Gaulle in the number of destinations offered, and will soon lose its position as the airport handling the largest number of passengers in Europe, at 63 million a year. BA privately favours a new runway at Heathrow to add to the fifth terminal that is likely to be approved this summer. But in a speech to the Aviation Club on Wednesday, Eddington, who replaced Bob Ayling last year, will urge the Government to make the necessary decision.

fields.headline: Corus braced for strike
fields.trailText: Steel workers at plants threatened with redundancy by Corus are to be balloted on strike action. Leaders of the ISTC union are expected to recommend 'strategic industrial action'.
fields.body:
Steel workers at plants threatened with redundancy by Corus are to be balloted on strike action. Leaders of the ISTC union are expected to recommend 'strategic industrial action'.

The ballot, which will take two weeks to organise, represents a last-ditch protest at the 6,000 job cuts announced in February by Corus, the loss-making quoted Anglo-Dutch giant.

It is expected that workers on Teesside will vote for action. Union officials describe a mass meeting last Friday as 'bitter'.

A strike will cripple Corus's blast furnace operation, which the company relies on for its steel rolling and processing activities at Llanwern in Wales and Corby.

But senior union officials expect Llanwern to reject calls for action. 'The morale in Wales is at such a low ebb, we get the feeling that the workers will take the redundancy packages offered to them by Corus,' said an ISTC insider.

Strike action is a reaction to the rejection of a retraining plan, backed by the Prime Minister's wife, Cherie Blair.

The plan, which relied on state aid and needed European Commission approval, would have reduced hours at threatened plants with workers retrained while they were 'off shift'.

The aim of the plan was to mark time and hope for a change in the low demand that the whole industry has been labouring under for two years. But Corus secretly ditched the plan well before the end-of-March deadline Corus gave the ISTC.

'This systematic sabotage is disgraceful,' said ISTC general secretary Michael Leahy. 'The company is showing no respect or regard for thousands of working people and their families who have made Corus plants the most productive in Europe.'

Corus claims that the ISTC plans involved steel capacity cuts which justified its job-cutting measures. Furthermore, the union plans are £2m more expensive than its closure programme.

Although the stock market greeted the job cuts with a 9 per cent rise in Corus's share price, MPs have called for Corus supremo Sir Brian Moffat to be stripped of his knighthood; the Trade & Industry Select Committee slated the company's business strategy; and Tony Blair has urged the company to reconsider.

webTitle: Dunbar dunces must go back to school

fields.headline: Dunbar dunces must go back to school
fields.trailText: Around 1,200 Allied Dunbar salesmen - a quarter of the insurer's salesforce - have failed exams they were ordered to sit after regulators found serious gaps in their knowledge.
fields.body:
Around 1,200 Allied Dunbar salesmen - a quarter of the insurer's salesforce - have failed exams they were ordered to sit after regulators found serious gaps in their knowledge.

The insurer was forced to put its 4,700 salesmen through a series of tests last month after the Financial Services Authority found many did not meet basic training and competence standards in four key areas - mortgages, pensions, investment and protection.

But a quarter of the salesforce flunked, scoring less than 70 per cent in the four exams.

A Dunbar spokeswoman said: 'We are delighted with the results, 75 per cent of the franchisees [the salesforce] passed first time. The problem arose because salesmen tend to be specialised on one particular area.'

Allied, which used to be notorious for its hard-sell tactics, is the latest of a string of insurers to send its salespeople back to the classroom in a sector which has been dogged by more than its fair share of mis-selling scandals, from pensions to endowments.

All of those Dunbar salesmen who failed now face retraining and another round of exams. Only 60 salesmen have been suspended - they were hauled off the road because they scored less than 35 per cent. Those who scored between 35 and 50 per cent are still selling but under supervision. Those who came in between 50 and 70 per cent - technically a fail - are operating unsupervised.

Dunbar is to test its salesforce once a year. Its 1 million-plus clients are urged to call the firm if they have concerns about the policies they were sold.

webTitle: Gamekeeper turned poacher gets to work

fields.headline: Gamekeeper turned poacher gets to work
fields.standfirst: Nick Mathiason talks to Oxfam's David Earnshaw, a former lobbyist for SmithKline
fields.trailText: Nick Mathiason talks to Oxfam's David Earnshaw, a former lobbyist for SmithKline
fields.body:
David Earnshaw has more reason than most to smile at last week's climbdown by the world's most powerful pharmaceutical companies - until February he was SmithKline's top European government lobbyist.

But last Monday the Rochdale-born gamekeeper turned poacher: Earnshaw, 42, joined Oxfam to spearhead the charity's campaign to ensure the developing countries' access to life-saving drugs.

His salary has halved to about £45,000 after a five-year stint at the world's largest drug manufacturer ended in redundancy following the Glaxo/SmithKline (GSK) merger, which was sealed last January.

He is scathing about the industry he left behind, describing the court case in South Africa over the price of treatments for Aids as a 'public relations disaster'; the delays of the 39 companies in agreeing on whether to drop the case as 'farcical'; and the resulting squabbles as to which drug companies will foot the legal costs, put at over £4 million, as 'complete disarray'.

Earnshaw, who lives and works in Brussels, is a former Labour candidate for the European Parliament. He says the GSK top brass are 'corporate clones afraid to speak their own minds or say what they believe in'.

He believes the industry operates in a 'cocoon' because it does not deal directly with consumers.

Speaking from Brussels, Earnshaw explained last week: 'The industry derives most of its profits from selling drugs to governments through national healthcare systems. As a result, relations between it and governments are bound to be close. It leads to the industry relying on governments.

'Pharmaceuticals operate in a strange cocoon removed from people and the everyday marketplace. Change does not appear in its vocabulary. Executives have a very comfortable life but this can't continue any more.The reality is that this is the most unpopular industry in the world. Its reputation is at its lowest ebb and yet it has so much to offer to the world.'

Earnshaw points the finger at the British Government for placing little pressure on drug firms to come up with innovative aid packages. Prime Minister Tony Blair sided with the industry in a recent report describing patent protection 'as the lifeblood of the pharmaceutical industry'.

Trade Minister Richard Caborn last November refused to sanction African countries circumventing international trade law even though many of them are obviously facing national emergencies.

'A quarter of all research and development in Britain is conducted by the pharmaceutical industry,' Earnshaw said. 'So it's a remarkably important sector to our economy and the Government supports it to the hilt.'

A committed European, he will remain in Brussels. His job now is to cut through narrow commercial and national self-interest and ensure the 25.3 million people with Aids in sub-Saharan Africa receive treatment.

'It was not hard to cross the tracks because I passionately believe compromise and consensus can be reached,' he said.

This issue is more important than politics. And it's time the industry woke up to that reality.'

webTitle: Victory? This outcome will harm us all

fields.headline: Victory? This outcome will harm us all
fields.trailText: Jeremy Paxman abandoned all pretence to impartiality on last Thursday's Newsnight . 'Congratulations, minister' he gushed to the South African health secretary on the court victory over the drugs companies, with a smile almost as big as the minister's. You almost expected Paxman to start dancing round his desk singing 'Nkosi sikelel' iAfrika'.
fields.body:
Jeremy Paxman abandoned all pretence to impartiality on last Thursday's Newsnight . 'Congratulations, minister' he gushed to the South African health secretary on the court victory over the drugs companies, with a smile almost as big as the minister's. You almost expected Paxman to start dancing round his desk singing 'Nkosi sikelel' iAfrika'.

Many viewers will have shared his joy, because on the face of it South Africa's win was a triumph of good over evil. The drugs barons have been obstructing a poor country's efforts to tackle its horrendous Aids problem by pricing it out of the market, and then trying to block, via the courts, Its attempt to get hold of cheap drugs. There seems to be no clearer case of heartless exploitation by a profit-crazed multinational.

But nothing is that simple, and, while applauding the fact that South Africans and others will have greater access to life-saving drugs, it is increasingly apparent that the verdict will have some horrible side-effects, both for the pharmaceutical industry and for consumers in wealthier parts of the world.

The drug companies' stock defence of their pricing and patent system is that they need the profits to re-invest in research and development of new cures. That has become a clichéd mantra from the pharmaceuticals, but it is true nonetheless. Without present profits, the stream of future drugs dries up, plain and simple. The only assets drugs companies have are their patents, which ensure this revenue stream.

Drugs come 'off patent' in the normal course of events anyway, but the Pretoria decision will accelerate the process, potentially throwing the economics of the drugs business into chaos. This is to nobody's benefit. One possible result of this upheaval, as Paul Farrelly describes below, is that big drugs firms will want to get bigger in order to preserve margins and market share. Again, it is difficult to see who benefits from this, especially not Third World countries, which would have to deal with bigger monopolists.

The South Africa verdict paves the way for a flood of cheap, and potentially dangerous, drugs from countries such as India and Thailand, the main non-patent manufacturing centres. Despite their best efforts, these will inevitably be less well regulated than those produced by European and American manufacturers.

It is true that the drugs companies were their own worst enemies in South Africa. Bringing the case in a country with 4.7 million HIV-infected people was insensitive; naming President Mandela, perhaps the world's most respected politician, in the action was crass; and it was a PR disaster to pursue the case to the point where the only way out was 'shame and humiliation', as their climb-down was interpreted.

But it should be noted that some companies had already begun selling drugs cheaper in developing countries. Merck and Bristol Meyers Squibb had offered to sell anti-Aids drugs at manufacturers' cost price ahead of the Pretoria verdict.

And finally, there is a viable alternative being proposed at next weekend's meeting of the IMF by our very own Chancellor. Gordon Brown wants rich nations to set up a fund to encourage the drugs giants to supply cheaper drugs to poorer countries. That makes sense. In a commercial world, there is no reason the drugs giants should not be offered a financial incentive to develop a social conscience.

The drug companies' stock defence of their pricing and patent system is that they need the profits to re-invest in research and development of new cures. That has become a clichéd mantra from the pharmaceuticals, but it is true nonetheless. Without present profits, the stream of future drugs dries up, plain and simple. The only assets drugs companies have are their patents, which ensure this revenue stream. Drugs come 'off patent' in the normal course of events anyway, but the Pretoria decision will accelerate the process, potentially throwing the economics of the drugs business into chaos. This is to nobody's benefit. One possible result of this upheaval, as Paul Farrelly describes below, is that big drugs firms will want to get bigger in order to preserve margins and market share. Again, it is difficult to see who benefits from this, especially not Third World countries, which would have to deal with bigger monopolists. The South Africa verdict paves the way for a flood of cheap, and potentially dangerous, drugs from countries such as India and Thailand, the main non-patent manufacturing centres. Despite their best efforts, these will inevitably be less well regulated than those produced by European and American manufacturers. It is true that the drugs companies were their own worst enemies in South Africa. Bringing the case in a country with 4.7 million HIV-infected people was insensitive; naming President Mandela, perhaps the world's most respected politician, in the action was crass; and it was a PR disaster to pursue the case to the point where the only way out was 'shame and humiliation', as their climb-down was interpreted. But it should be noted that some companies had already begun selling drugs cheaper in developing countries. Merck and Bristol Meyers Squibb had offered to sell anti-Aids drugs at manufacturers' cost price ahead of the Pretoria verdict. And finally, there is a viable alternative being proposed at next weekend's meeting of the IMF by our very own Chancellor. Gordon Brown wants rich nations to set up a fund to encourage the drugs giants to supply cheaper drugs to poorer countries. That makes sense. In a commercial world, there is no reason the drugs giants should not be offered a financial incentive to develop a social conscience. fields.headline: Drugs: Round One to Africa
fields.standfirst: Nick Mathiason explains why the pharmas gave way, and why South Africa's joy may be short-lived
fields.trailText: Nick Mathiason explains why the pharmas gave way, and why South Africa's joy may be short-lived
fields.body:
Fear drove the world's largest drug companies to abandon their legal action against South African laws aimed at getting cheaper medicines to the poor last week - fear of a lingering bully-boy public image and fear of abject defeat.

More fundamentally, what senior executives of multinational pharmaceuticals feared was that the case would expose just how much money the 'pharmas' receive from governments around the world for the research and development of life-saving drugs.

Even worse, had they continued to pursue South Africa, where more than 4 million people have the virus that causes Aids, there was a real possibility that they would have had to disclose the true cost of researching drugs and their international pricing strategies.

The writing was on the wall three weeks ago, when a clutch of senior lawyers in London and New York representing Merck and GlaxoSmithKline saw for the first time the prosecution and defence documents previously confined to Pretoria.

They rapidly concluded that the legal basis for a successful prosecution on 'an away ground' was remote. At the same time, an uncomfortable international chorus of disapproval was getting louder.

Former President Nelson Mandela joined in last weekend, blasting the pharmaceutical companies for taking his country to court. Unsurprisingly, his criticisms made headlines around the world.

Some European Ministers had already pleaded with their respective pharmaceuticals to drop the case. Britain, which had sided with the drug companies, also changed tack. In last week's Observer, Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown urged pharmaceutical companies to 'accept their share of responsibility'.

A week ago South African campaigners got wind of a schism among the companies. The word was that GlaxoSmithKline and Merck were leading the retreat. This proved to be true. Executives from the two companies contacted the United Nations Secretary-General, Kofi Annan, and urged him to broker a compromise.

Last Sunday Annan did just that: he telephoned South African President Thabo Mbeki. Annan told Mbeki that the pharmaceuticals wanted the 1997 Medicines Act, the disputed law that gave South Africa the right to circumvent international patent law, to be amended. Mbeki refused.

Instead, the pharmas agreed to drop the case if a joint working party between the South African government and the industry drew up regulations governing the Act.

Vitally for the pharmas, South Africa agreed to abide by World Trade Organisation rules governing intellectual property - the notorious Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (Trips) agreement. This was what the world's media described as a landmark victory for the developing world.

The case actually opened in the Pretoria High Court at the beginning of March after two years of on-off talks. But an affidavit by a loby group, Treatment Action Campaign, caused the case to be adjourned for six weeks at the request of the 39 pharmaceuticals.

For the pharmas, this affidavit was the straw that broke their case. In it, eminent industry researchers swore on oath that a third of all life-saving drugs developed in the United States received federal aid to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars.

The evidence blew a hole in the argument that multinational pharmaceuticals relied on patent law to produce multimillion-pound profits, which were then siphoned off into expensive research and development.

'If the judge chose, he could have gone on to poke at the companies, asking them about overall pricing strategies across the world,' said one lawyer working on the case. 'We would have definitely encouraged that.'

Amid the widescale euphoria in South Africa last week, a South African news agency headline hit a sombre note: 'Drug court case over, Aids patients to wait'.

If you'd been reading the British press and watched the pictures of South African campaigners uncorking bubbly, you would have the impression that millions of Aids sufferers' lives were about to be saved.

But this is not the case. South Africa will now only be able to buy cheap drugs from countries, such as Thailand and India, where patents have expired. These are typically drugs used to treat malaria and tuberculosis. Combination Aids drug therapies, though, are new. Their patents have an average 14 years to run.

Developing countries, if they are to be Trips-compliant, will have no choice but to broker discount deals with the multinationals and hope these arrangements last for many, many years.They are still at the mercy of commerce - and there is no guarantee that even deep discounts by drug companies will put them within their means.

There is no doubt that the drug industry can afford largesse. Out of total global prescription sales of $354 billion in the last year, the market for Aids drugs was worth $4bn, just over 1 per cent. Africa, too, has been the least important market, accounting for 1 per cent of all world drug sales. Profits ran into tens of billions.

Last Friday Merck, the world's third largest prescription drug seller, posted an 11 per cent rise in first-quarter profits on a net income of £1.2bn. This week analysts expect GlaxoSmithKline pre-tax profits for the first quarter to total around £1.3bn.

Treatment Action Campaign is now determined to negotiate with drugs manufacturers. It says that even drugs sold at cost are virtually out of their financial reach and if no progress is made on sustainable Aids drug prices, it will take the industry to international courts.

It would be well timed. Attention is now shifting to how Trips may be amended to suit developing countries. Clare Short's Department of International Development is co-ordinating a cross-government 'commission' into Trips headed by John Barton, professor of law at Stanford University.

Trips can be circumvented if individual countries cite national emergency as a defence. Lawyers working for campaign groups and developing world governments are poring over it to define what constitutes a national emergency.

Brown's call for an advanced purchase fund of Aids drugs for African nations is also beginning to gain momentum. The only worry is about how long will such a fund last?

But the war on patent infringement by the pharmaceuticals goes on. Under pressure from Roche of Switzerland and Merck of the US, the United States has taken Brazil to the WTO Dispute Settlement Panel. Brazil is proud to be the most flagrant abuser of international patent law. It has just under4 million people infected with HIV. The panel is due to meet next month. Brazil faces trade embargos that would undermine any progress that the South African court case may have achieved.

To adopt such sanctions against what is the engine room of the Latin American economy would send out strong signals to India and China, which would like to adopt similar policies.

Defending themselves, drugs companies cite the lack of robust health care systems in developing countries. 'Even if South Africa manufactured tonnes and tonnes of drugs, they couldn't guarantee that they would reach the people who need them.' Poverty, indeed, kills people with Aids. Poor healthcare systems - and poor access to drugs.

fields.headline: Spotlight is turned on Europe
fields.standfirst: Faisal Islam  looks at whether the European Central Bank is up to the task of staving off financial turmoil
fields.trailText: Faisal Islam looks at whether the European Central Bank is up to the task of staving off financial turmoil
fields.body:
America's shock decision to cut interest rates has put the ball firmly back into Europe's court. All eyes are now on the European Central Bank and its president Wim Duisenberg.

Some clues to his thinking were aired at the recent annual conference of the Royal Economics Society. The erudite gathering proffered sundry theories for the actions, inactions and over-reactions of the world's central bankers. That debate did much to illuminate the actions of the ECB and the Federal Reserve in the two weeks since.

One research paper suggested that Alan Greenspan appeared to prop up New York stock markets because of the assumption he would always bail out investors. Separately an ECB official tried to explain, through reference to a maze-like flow chart, the various processes and pillars of ECB decision-making.

And lo and behold, in the subsequent week the ECB stunned markets by leaving rates unchanged despite giving every impression it would cut, while a surprise rate cut by the Federal Reserve saw a huge rally on the Dow and the Nasdaq.

In contrast to the complex 'reaction function models' of economists, a simplified, pared down version of economic theory is doing the political rounds. This suggests the world economy can exist only in two states - market euphoria and boom, where all central bankers should raise rates to avoid inflation, and global panic and recession, where they have to slash them.

The suggestion that the ECB needs to respond to the Federal Reserve cut seems to follow from this. But, conversely, if the US is cutting rates and dealing with the source of weakness in the global economy, then this could take the pressure off the ECB.

Monetary policy is far more nuanced than such generalisations, however, marrying forensic analysis of statistics with the art of playing high politics. This will be no more apparent than over the next week. As the world's economic and financial leaders prepare to gather in Washington for Group of Seven, International Monetary Fund and World Bank meetings next weekend, the pressure on the ECB to cut on Thursday will mount.

Indeed, one important report out this week will lament the reluctance of the ECB to use monetary policy to 'test the limits of growth' of the euro zone, as Greenspan did for the US in the late 1990s.

Such a scenario could see Europe power the world economy and make progress on its high levels of unemployment. But is this necessary?

'The euro area is not doing badly, and where there are problems they have nothing to do with monetary policy,' says Alison Cottrell, European policy analyst at UBS Warburg.

No less a figure than Charlie Bean, the Bank of England's chief economist, told the conference that the ECB's 'interest rate decisions have been pretty much spot on'. But he was pretty clear on where the ECB could do better.

'The lacuna in the ECB model is that the way its forecasts map into a final decision is not as clear as it might be. If there is a weakness it's in how the inputs are translated into the outputs of decision-making,' he said.

Bean is a member of the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee. Minutes of decision-making meetings are published two weeks afterwards.

City economists are in a position to speculate on issues as detailed as whether the order of voting might influence the eventual decision. The six to three decision revealed in last week's release of April minutes helps to show the markets that the bias is towards further cuts.

The main problem for the ECB is that no one seems to know how it comes to its decisions. Minutes are not released for at least 16 years, and the Bank always likes to give the impression that decisions are unanimous.

'There's a reluctance to be seen to have a spread of views because the ECB wants to be seen as decisive,' says Cottrell. 'But of course there are debates - that's why there are 18 people on the committee.'

Then there's the external pressure from finance ministers in the euro group.

Central bankers are said to earn their spurs by ignoring short-term pressures from politicians. But has the ECB taken this to an extreme where it refuses to cut simply because the politicians want it to?

No, because if it wanted to explain its 'no change yet' stance, there are plenty of figures to back it up. Inflation, the second pillar of ECB monetary policy, remains stubbornly above its 2 per cent target, for example.

But these tactical considerations, can make a difference to the timing of shifts in policy.

'If the ECB finds itself in a corner, it's because it has painted itself into it,' says Cottrell. Because there are no minutes and no voting records, market analysts are oversensitive to the signals sent out by speeches and media interviews.

'The balance of power between different committees, governing bodies, finance ministers and central bankers is still being worked out,' she says.

'Operationally the ECB has done extremely well - none of the horror stories came through. Presentationally, there's a lot to be desired.'

How Ireland could spread the US contagion

The first cracks in the buoyant economy of the Irish Republic are looming, as the country's important computer sector is threatened by the US downturn, writes Nicola Byrne from Dublin.

Several leading employers in the Irish hi-tech industry, including Intel and Ericsson, posted record global losses for the first quarter of the year, prompting fears for the long-term continuation of their operations in the Republic.

Another firm, Gateway Computers, announced plans to lay off 200 staff, in addition to the 122 who were made redundant earlier this year.

Publicly, government officials dismissed the problems as a temporary blip, but analysts believe politicians are extremely concerned.

The Irish economy has been growing faster than any other in the European Union for each of the past four years, averaging between 8 and 10 per cent a year. And much of this has centred on the hi-tech industries.

Low corporation tax, coupled with a highly skilled workforce, has attracted unprecedented investment from multinationals in this sector. One report suggests that almost a third of American investment in the EU is believed to be going to Ireland, most of it into computer-based industries.

Although the industry accounts for over 100,000 jobs in the Republic - about 10 per cent of the country's workforce - the investment in the sector has had an enormously positive impact on wider consumer and business sentiment.

If a company such as Intel were to close its Irish operations, economists believe the knock-on effects would be extremely serious.

Jim Power, director of investments with the pension fund firm Friends First, said: 'OK, it would be tough for the 6,000 or so people who would directly lose their jobs, but the psychological effect on the country as a whole would be just as devastating.'

Since the start of the boom, house prices in parts of Dublin have quadrupled, and many young people are committed to crippling mortgages. A crisis such as the one bubbling in the technological sector would threaten the market.

webTitle: Greenspan at mercy of the markets (pt 2)

fields.headline: Greenspan at mercy of the markets (pt 2)
fields.standfirst: Edward Helmore  looks at rival scenarios for the US economy: fast recovery or a full-blown recession?
fields.trailText: Edward Helmore looks at rival scenarios for the US economy: fast recovery or a full-blown recession?
fields.body:
Like the riddle of the sphinx, interpreting the actions of Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan and the direction of US economy has become a mugs' game.

Although last week's surprise half-point cut in interest rates pleased Wall Street and sent the markets soaring, Greenspan's motives were, as always, open to interpretation. Was he a pawn of Wall Street, or does he still have a semblance of control over an economy that is teetering between temporary slowdown and full-blown recession?

Last Friday, US investors followed the European markets into the red on news of poor earnings and job layoffs at Ericsson and Nortel Networks, despite better earnings news from a couple of US heavyweights, including Microsoft.

The downward trend surprised many observers, given the good news they had received earlier in the week with the Fed's unexpected interest rate cut and a surge in share prices.

Pessimistic economists suggested that the cut - the fourth this year and the second enacted between monthly meetings of the Fed - showed that Greenspan clearly believes a major recession is inevitable this year, if one is not already under way.

The pessimists believe a collapse in capital spending, a meltdown in technology investment, higher energy prices, and declining consumer confidence threaten to push the economy over the edge. Economists say that even with interest rates at 4.5 per cent, the lag between the cuts and their effect often takes months, or perhaps as long as a year, to happen. And that may be what worries the Fed most.

'They are more nervous about the economy than they have been letting on,' said William Dudley, chief US economist at Goldman Sachs. 'The investment boom is turning into a bust.'

Optimists, particularly bullish investors, reject the idea that Greenspan knows something they don't. They maintain that the sense of urgency behind the cuts shows that Greenspan's concern is actually a measure of his confidence and control. In other words, everything is going to work out fine.

Though many analysts say share prices will slide again, what has changed is their confidence: they believe that the economy is starting to improve. They cite the fact that industrial and hi-tech giants such as Boeing, IBM and Microsoft have exceeded their earnings estimates.

Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at SG Cowen Securities, said: 'As far as the kind of devastation we saw in 2000, the worst is over. We might test our lows again, but the free-fall we saw has come to an end.

'This is not the end of the market's problems, but the beginning of its healing process.'

Share prices had been steadily advancing on their own for two weeks before the surge last Wednesday. The reason: earnings reports that were weak but not as bad as expected, and indications from some technology companies, particularly chip maker Intel, that business will pick up later this year.

But the good news remains patchy and the dissonance of opinion between investors and economists is not the only arena of confusion. The disparity between consumer confidence, which has dipped only slightly, and the dour outlook signalled by corporate earnings results and job cuts is striking.

Anirvan Banerji, director of the Economic Cycle Research Institute in New York, said: 'It's too late to prevent a recession. The process that leads to job losses is already under way.'

The Fed's vice-chairman, Roger Ferguson, said last Thursday that it was still too early to see an end to the economic slowdown that trig gered the round of interest rate reductions. He indicated that another cut may follow next month.

Until recently the Fed's public comments had focused on the idea that economic weakness was largely a mat ter of excess manufacturing inventories that could be corrected with relative ease. But a series of reports from the hi-tech sector suggest a plunge in demand far more severe than was at first thought.

Last week, the giant Cisco Systems compared the plunge to a '100-year flood'. The company was announcing that 8,500 of its workers would be laid off and $2.5bn of inventory written-off.

Cisco's announcement followed similarly grim news from Intel, Hewlett-Packard, Nortel, Lucent Technologies and Motorola.

Many economists suggest the interest rate cuts were too late for companies that invested heavily in new equipment during the bull market years. They already own too much and even if new equipment is needed, the collapse of the dotcoms has flooded the market with cheaper, secondhand systems.

The Cisco lay-offs are widely regarded as the trigger that prompted Greenspan's latest move. One Wall Street analyst said the firm's announcement suggested that the 'tech sector is falling off a cliff'.

In theory, the rate cuts will help to increase demand, production will grow, and investment will pick up. But the analysts added: 'It is doubtful whether monetary policy can have any real dampening effect on what is happening in the tech sector. Over-investment is over-investment, no matter how low the cost of borrowing.'

Capital spending may be the weakest sector in the economy but it is one that Greenspan can do the least about. Lower interest rate help the car and housing markets, but many companies, especially in the telecoms sector, are no longer considered creditworthy. 'You can offer really great interest rates, but if no one qualifies it does not make much difference,' said Martin Fridson, Merrill Lynch's junk bond expert.

The big question is how the American consumer will react, and a summer of negative economic headlines and rising unemployment is likely to further erode consumer confidence. New claims for unemployment benefit are running more than 40 per cent ahead of the levels a year ago, the first such increase since the last recession in 1991.

How long it will take consumers to react is uncertain. According to opinion polls, Americans are far less confident about the economy, yet they have continued to spend as the markets have fallen and personal debt, already at record levels, has increased. The housing market - the backbone of the economy - is holding up. New cars are still being driven out of the showroom by happy owners and goods are leaving the shops.

Last year, economists were divided between those who expected a soft landing and those who forecast a hard one. The latter proved correct. The debate now is between those who predict a sharp downturn and a sharp recovery and others who think the US economy is in for a long period of difficulties.

Too much optimism and the markets are in danger of becoming frothy again; too much pessimism and domestic consumption will collapse, making a full-blown recession a certainty.

Although last week's surprise half-point cut in interest rates pleased Wall Street and sent the markets soaring, Greenspan's motives were, as always, open to interpretation. Was he a pawn of Wall Street, or does he still have a semblance of control over an economy that is teetering between temporary slowdown and full-blown recession? Last Friday, US investors followed the European markets into the red on news of poor earnings and job layoffs at Ericsson and Nortel Networks, despite better earnings news from a couple of US heavyweights, including Microsoft. fields.headline: Show and tell
fields.standfirst: Her tent, her bed, her lovers... more than with any other modern artist, it is impossible to separate Tracey Emin from her work. Here, Britain's supreme art exhibitionist talks to Lynn Barber about families, fear of failure and why one condom is never enough
fields.trailText: Her tent, her bed, her lovers... more than with any other modern artist, it is impossible to separate Tracey Emin from her work. Here, Britain's supreme art exhibitionist talks to Lynn Barber about families, fear of failure and why one condom is never enough.
fields.body:
Even in an interview, Tracey Emin wants to show you things, wants to spread her whole life out before you. Her studio in Brick Lane in London is anyway full of things to look at - the blankets she is making for her new White Cube show, the wedding dress she wears in her Beck’s Futures film, dozens of drawings on the floor waiting for the framers. But that is not enough for her, she wants to show you more, much more - and she has filing cabinets full, vast archives of her life. When I asked whether her twin brother Paul looked like her (‘No, he’s built like a brick house. Massive’), she had to show me a photograph to prove it; when she mentions the letters she used to write telling people they could invest in her creative potential for £10, she actually digs out the file.

It is as if all the time she needs proof - proof of her existence, or maybe proof that she’s telling the truth?

When we met the first time, she said it had to be at her studio because her house was off-limits to journalists. But the second time, she wanted to show me her new studio (she is moving to a new studio round the corner, next to Gary Hume’s), and somehow from there we gravitated to her house. It was surprisingly neat and smart and immaculate. Naturally, I wanted to see her bed to see if it was like My Bed, the one Charles Saatchi bought for £150,000, but she said I couldn’t because Mat (Collishaw, her boyfriend) was still asleep in it - it was five in the afternoon but they’d had a heavy night. So I was wandering rather disconsolately round this house thinking it was a bit characterless, a bit un-Tracey, until I noticed a white squidgy thing on the sofa. ‘Tracey!’ I squeaked, ‘there’s a used condom!’ ‘Oh dear,’ she said. ‘I knew I should have tidied up.’

Now truly it is strange to find a used condom lying on the sofa in an otherwise immaculate house. I even wondered if she planted it, but then decided she couldn’t have because I was first into the room. What does it mean, Tracey, I nagged - was it because she couldn’t bear to throw good sperm away? No, she huffed, she just hadn’t got round to tidying up. But most people throw them away at the time, I told her in my new guise as expert on the nation’s condom habits. ‘Do they? Where?’ ‘Down the loo.’ ‘Well, I’m more the sort of person that will clean them all up in the morning. And like some people use just one condom, right? But we use tons.’

Next day, Tracey rang to say she needed to see me again. She’d had a dream in which she was a sparrow and I was a bumble bee and she was flying with one wing trying to show me something. Maybe the bed, I thought, or more details of her fascinating condom habits, but no, she wanted to meet in her local, the Golden Heart. I wondered what she could possibly show me in a pub, but the answer was waiting for me when I got there - her father, Enver Emin. He is 80 but totally compos mentis and still with a flash of the ladykiller he must once have been. But I was surprised to meet a Turkish Cypriot who looked so African. He explained that his father was jet black - he says there were lots of Sudanese slaves in the Ottoman Empire and he thinks his family must be descended from them.

Anyway, Mr Emin was sitting placidly in the pub nursing a cup of tea, waiting to collect his wife Rose from Tracey’s studio, where she was sewing blankets for Tracey’s new show. I asked what he thought of Tracey’s work and he said, ‘I love it, but I don’t understand it. She creates her own ideas, and it keeps her on her toes and keeps her happy.’ He particularly likes the appliqué pieces, like the blankets, because they remind him of his mother. He said he was off to Cyprus on Sunday to finalise the purchase of some land to build a holiday house for Tracey and his other children. ‘How many children have you got?’ I asked, but when he said five, Tracey jumped on him, ‘No, Dad, come on!’ Apparently, he usually admits to 11 children, but he once told Tracey 23 - they range in age from 18 to 63. Then she started arguing with him about his having two families, and I was once more pitched into the boiling high drama that is her life (and art).

Tracey and her twin brother Paul were Enver’s ‘second family’ in Margate. He already had a wife and family in London when he met Tracey’s mother Pam, but instead of divorcing, he simply maintained two households and commuted between them. Both sides knew about each other: ‘My late wife used to adore Tracey.’ When the twins were four, he drove them and their mother and aunt and grandmother across Europe to Turkey, installed them in a hotel on the Black Sea, then drove back to London to collect his other family, installed them in another hotel and spent two months shuttling between them.

So it was all open and above board? Yes, he agrees, but Tracey butts in furiously: ‘It was never above board, Dad! It’s not above board to have two families, right?’ She obviously picks this fight every time she sees him, she won’t ever let things be. That is why her childhood pain is always so fresh and available to her art. If a wound shows any signs of healing, she’ll pick the scab until it starts bleeding again. This is an incredible strength in her art - the way she can call up old emotions, feel old pains - but it must be quite a drawback in her life.

With other artists, such as Rachel Whiteread, or Damien Hirst, you can hate the work and like the person, or vice versa, but with Tracey no such split is possible. Her art demands a sort of subservience to an Eminocentric vision of the world that feels like surrender. That is why, I think, people often resist her art for a long time and then suddenly fall for it, as Charles Saatchi did (and I did).

The best account of Tracey’s life is her video Curriculum Vitae in Tate Modern, which is so good I don’t want to spoil it. But the key facts are that she was born in Margate in 1963, and lived at first ‘like a princess’ - her parents ran the Hotel International and all the staff spoilt her rotten. But then the business crashed when she was seven, ‘And suddenly we had nothing, and we were squatting in a cottage which used to be the staff cottage’. At that point her parents split up - she recalls her mum shouting, ‘Oh go back and fuck your wife’ - and from then on the little princess was just one of Margate’s ordinary mob of deprived single-parent kids.

She had no front teeth (she lost them all to calcium deficiency, the result, she says, of being a twin - she has incredibly complicated bridgework now) and no boobs till she was 13 - ‘They grew really quickly. One minute I didn’t have any tits and the next I had the biggest tits in the world.’ At 13 she was raped. For the next six months she avoided boys, but then she became ‘a slag’ - her word - and started sleeping with half the boys in Margate. ‘It was a power trip, definitely. And also I had this kind of idea - why go to another country, why not just sleep with someone to get experience? In Margate, you see, underage sex was definitely the thing to do - breaking into girls. If you hadn’t lost it by the time you were 16 there was something wrong with you. It wasn’t like middle England. And also, being by the sea is brilliant because there’s loads of places to have sex!’

Her film Why I Never Became a Dancer - one of her three favourite pieces, along with her tent and her bed - recounts her going in for a dance competition as a teenager and all the boys shouting ‘Slag, slag!’ And so she resolved, ‘I’m out of here, I’m better than all of you.’ Despite having no O levels, she managed to get on a fashion diploma course and parlayed that into an art degree course at Maidstone. She got a first and went on to the Royal College - which she hated, but says it was her own fault for expecting too much of the college and not enough of herself.

Meanwhile, Tracey’s love life was a mess. At Maidstone she had a long affair with a fellow artist, Billy Childish, which ‘did her head in’. Then she had another bad affair, after the Royal College, which resulted in two abortions. Up till then she thought she couldn’t get pregnant because she’d had very bad gonorrhoea as a teenager and the doctor said she would be sterile. The first abortion, in 1990, was horrendously bodged because no one realised she was carrying twins: the second abortion, she says, was ‘revenge’ for the first.

At this point she destroyed all her work and gave up art. ‘I felt isolated, insecure, unloved, unwanted and pretty crazy, mad. I don’t think I felt mad because I’d had an abortion, I think I felt mad because I was angry, and because I was living on £12 a week.’ She got a job as a youth tutor for Southwark council and took a philosophy course at Birkbeck, ‘And suddenly my brain - it was like doing exercises in a gym and your muscles waking up. It was brilliant.’

But she spent two years making no art at all - it was Sarah Lucas who got her back into art. They met at Sarah’s City Racing show in 1992 and became instant friends. ‘It was wild, brilliant, really love without sex, but totally passionate - it was almost like how girls are at school, that inseparable kind of thing.’ Sarah said they should get a studio together, but Tracey said she wasn’t interested in making art. OK, said Sarah, they’d get a shop and make merchandise. It was an old shop in Bethnal Green Road, and they took it for six months and called themselves the Birds and made T-shirts saying things like ‘I’m so fucky’. ‘What was brilliant about the shop,’ Tracey recalls, ‘was it gave me a platform to find what I was good at - and what I was good at was ideas, and being un- precious about them and having an audience. Sarah was very encouraging in all this.’

Then they went to Geneva together - ‘our Swiss convalescence’ - and made loads more stuff and Jay Jopling offered Tracey an exhibition at White Cube. ‘I thought it would be my one and only exhibition so I decided to call it My Major Retrospective. Two weeks before the show, Jay came to my tiny flat in Waterloo and apparently he left going ‘Ohmigod, what have I done’, because all I could show him was this crap, smelly old ancient things like my old passport or bits of fabric from my sofa when I was three years old. There was nothing that looked like an exhibition, so Jay left thinking he’d made a big mistake.’ But anyway it was a success, and 400 people turned up for the opening.

After Sarah Lucas, her next big influence was Carl Freedman, an art curator she went out with for three years. He said if she wanted to be in his 1995 mixed show Minky Manky she had to produce something big - up till then she’d only done small - and so she produced her famous tent, Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 1963-95 . Then she had a big solo exhibition at the South London Gallery called I Need Art Like I Need God, and, ‘On the opening night there were a couple of thousand people and three television crews. And I walked in and thought, “Ohmigod, I’ve arrived!’ Her arrival was confirmed by her notorious appearance on a Channel 4 debate at the 1997 Turner Prize, pissed out of her mind and terribly funny - afterwards, she said, she didn’t even know she’d been on television, she thought she was round at some boring dinner party. And then her friend Vivienne Westwood started dressing her, which gave her a whole new audience in the fashion magazines. Westwood actually doesn’t think much of Emin’s art (but then she doesn’t like any modern art), but she admires her style. And as Tracey says, the collaboration works to their mutual advantage, ‘It’s symbiotic. And it’s fantastic for a woman of my age, 37, to be like this muse and this glamour thing - we’re having fun with it.’

In 1999, Tracey hogged all the publicity for the Turner Prize with her notorious bed, and then she didn’t win. She thinks it was a plot, she thinks the Tate just used her for publicity and never seriously considered giving her the prize. She is quite bitter about it, still. When I said I’d forgotten who did win, she crowed, ‘Exactly! People don’t remember - it was Steve McQueen. But all the papers had my photograph, not his. Revenge is sweet.’ She forced herself to keep smiling at the time, but she cried bitterly afterwards. And she blames that disappointment for the kidney infection which put her in hospital a few months later. Her health has always been precarious - one of the first things she did when she started making money was to take out private health insurance. ‘I’m sickly and I get run down and I have very bad herpes, and I like knowing that the doctor’s there.’

Of course, in the past, her sickliness was exacerbated by her non-stop drinking, progressing from beer to wine to brandy through the day. ‘When I went out, I had a brilliant bag that could hold four beers, half a bottle of brandy and cigarettes all the way round, and also I was sponsored by Bombay Sapphire Gin, so I used to always take a bottle of gin as well. And even when I didn’t go out, I’d be sitting round drinking.’ Why this abuse? ‘I don’t think it was abuse. It was more like rock’n’roll !’ she cackles. Her drinking got so bad about three years ago, she had constant diarrhoea and her weight went down to six-and-half stone. She also got really boringly aggressive at parties, till finally Mat and her friends said pack it in or they’d leave her. So in September 1999, she gave up spirits - she still drinks wine and gets pissed at parties, but not to the same annihilating degree.

Nowadays, she says, she looks after herself - she goes to the gym and is learning to box. And she has a good solid relationship with her fellow artist Mat Collishaw, now in its fourth year. Moreover, she is faithful - ‘but of course I think probably no one else is!’ She and Mat could afford to have children but she says she’s too old and also, ‘We have a really good life, we like it the way it is. If I keep fit and healthy, and in shape, I do actually have a few good years.’

But clearly the question of having children is preying on her mind - she’s just made a film with her mother which is ‘basically me asking her why she won’t let me have children. My mum has never wanted me to have children. She thinks I would be destroying my life, even now. I asked, “Is it because she thinks I’m so mentally unstable she’d be frightened for me?” and she said, “Yes, that’s one of the reasons”. The fact that I’ve got over so much, she wouldn’t want anything to come into my life that would make me fragile again.’

How fragile is she? She seems cheerful and robust at present, but she has had plenty of brushes with madness in the past and at least one suicide attempt, when she threw herself off a cliff, aged 20 - ‘But I’m a really good swimmer!’ There was another very bad patch around her abortion in 1990, and one three years ago - perhaps the period of self-neglect commemorated in My Bed . When she goes down, she says, it’s like a spiral in which one failure reminds her of every other failure in her life - that’s why she could never face taking her driving test, because if she failed it would be like failing to win the Turner Prize and every other failure before that. But now she is determined to take her driving test and keep on taking it till she passes.

At least now she seems to have got out of the habit of destructive relationships that was such a feature of her teens and twenties. In those days, she says, she was so nihilistic she thought, ‘I am shit, and that is why I am treated like shit.’ Was success as good as she expected? ‘Better! I’m happier. I look after myself more. I’m kinder to myself. I’ve got a nice house. And if I didn’t want to work for a couple of years I wouldn’t have to - it’s a great feeling, to know I’m doing it because I want to do it. The downside is I get terrible stress and my mind goes blank and I lose concentration because there are people on my case all the time for all kinds of shit. People try constantly to use me and I hate it’

I must say that her life, what I saw of it, is incredibly pressured. The phone in her studio rings non-stop, and although she has a brilliant PA, Gemma, she has to keep making decisions. While I was there, she was having a great row with the ICA about the Beck’s Futures exhibition because they were planning to show her new film in the bar and she wanted it in the cinema. She told Gemma to relay the news that she wouldn’t be attending the opening party after all - and suddenly the director of the ICA was on the phone grovelling, saying of course she could have the cinema. ‘The wheel that squeaks gets the oil!’ she crowed as she put the phone down.

I was amazed to see that a fortnight before her White Cube opening, half the work was still incomplete. Her stepmother was busy sewing the blankets, her assistant was building the 17ft tower, Helter Skelter , which will be the centrepiece of the show, but she hadn’t even started the four paintings she had promised to make. All this, I’d have thought, was panic enough, but she had also agreed to appear on Have I Got News For You and said she ought to try and read the newspapers - though her main preparation would be choosing her lowest-cleavage outfit to frighten Ian Hislop.

She is also supposed to be writing a novel - she says it will have to be a novel rather than an autobiography because ‘one thing that success has taught me is censorship’. But why does she want to write? Are there things she can’t say in her art? ‘Yes, because - I should be careful what I say here, but I don’t think I’m visually the best artist in the world, right? I’ve got to be honest about this. But when it comes to words, I have a uniqueness that I find almost impossible in terms of art - and it’s my words that actually make my art quite unique.’

Aha! This used to be my own theory about Tracey, that she was a great writer and a merely so-so artist. If you see her drawings or her blankets from a distance, without reading the words, you think pretty but not much more. It is the words that give them their edge. That is why My Bed was such a breakthrough, because it didn’t rely on words - but I suspect it relied on our knowing stuff about her history which we only knew from her previous words. But I’ve now revised my theory because there is a piece of hers in the Tate that is only words, For Joseph Samuels, 1981 , and although it is vividly written, it is pretty tame by her standards. So she needs both - the fierceness of the words playing off the delicacy of the art - to really make her point.

Finally, I asked about this habit of hoarding things, the way she keeps archives of her life, never lets the past go. ‘Perhaps it’s because I never grew up.’ Or is it because she needs proof - as a teenager, did people call her a liar? ‘ Yes . And not just as a teenage girl but even as a woman. That’s a good theory, I like that. And maybe I don’t believe things myself, as well. Truth is such a transient thing... it’s like with my work, people say, “Oh, the honesty and the truth behind it” - but it’s all edited, it’s all calculated, it’s all decided. I decide to show this or that part of the truth, which isn’t necessarily the whole story, it’s just what I decide to give you.’ So with this interview - honest as far as it goes, I hope, but only a fragment of the whole Tracey.

• Tracey Emin’s show, You Forgot to Kiss My Soul, is at White Cube, 48 Hoxton Square, London N1 from 27 April.
