That is why her childhood pain is always so fresh and available to her art. If a wound shows any signs of healing, she’ll pick the scab until it starts bleeding again. This is an incredible strength in her art - the way she can call up old emotions, feel old pains - but it must be quite a drawback in her life. With other artists, such as Rachel Whiteread, or Damien Hirst, you can hate the work and like the person, or vice versa, but with Tracey no such split is possible. Her art demands a sort of subservience to an Eminocentric vision of the world that feels like surrender. That is why, I think, people often resist her art for a long time and then suddenly fall for it, as Charles Saatchi did (and I did). The best account of Tracey’s life is her video Curriculum Vitae in Tate Modern, which is so good I don’t want to spoil it. But the key facts are that she was born in Margate in 1963, and lived at first ‘like a princess’ - her parents ran the Hotel International and all the staff spoilt her rotten. But then the business crashed when she was seven, ‘And suddenly we had nothing, and we were squatting in a cottage which used to be the staff cottage’. At that point her parents split up - she recalls her mum shouting, ‘Oh go back and fuck your wife’ - and from then on the little princess was just one of Margate’s ordinary mob of deprived single-parent kids. She had no front teeth (she lost them all to calcium deficiency, the result, she says, of being a twin - she has incredibly complicated bridgework now) and no boobs till she was 13 - ‘They grew really quickly. One minute I didn’t have any tits and the next I had the biggest tits in the world.’ At 13 she was raped. For the next six months she avoided boys, but then she became ‘a slag’ - her word - and started sleeping with half the boys in Margate. ‘It was a power trip, definitely. And also I had this kind of idea - why go to another country, why not just sleep with someone to get experience? In Margate, you see, underage sex was definitely the thing to do - breaking into girls. If you hadn’t lost it by the time you were 16 there was something wrong with you. It wasn’t like middle England. And also, being by the sea is brilliant because there’s loads of places to have sex!’ Her film Why I Never Became a Dancer - one of her three favourite pieces, along with her tent and her bed - recounts her going in for a dance competition as a teenager and all the boys shouting ‘Slag, slag!’ And so she resolved, ‘I’m out of here, I’m better than all of you.’ Despite having no O levels, she managed to get on a fashion diploma course and parlayed that into an art degree course at Maidstone. She got a first and went on to the Royal College - which she hated, but says it was her own fault for expecting too much of the college and not enough of herself. Meanwhile, Tracey’s love life was a mess. At Maidstone she had a long affair with a fellow artist, Billy Childish, which ‘did her head in’. Then she had another bad affair, after the Royal College, which resulted in two abortions. Up till then she thought she couldn’t get pregnant because she’d had very bad gonorrhoea as a teenager and the doctor said she would be sterile. The first abortion, in 1990, was horrendously bodged because no one realised she was carrying twins: the second abortion, she says, was ‘revenge’ for the first. At this point she destroyed all her work and gave up art. ‘I felt isolated, insecure, unloved, unwanted and pretty crazy, mad. I don’t think I felt mad because I’d had an abortion, I think I felt mad because I was angry, and because I was living on £12 a week.’ She got a job as a youth tutor for Southwark council and took a philosophy course at Birkbeck, ‘And suddenly my brain - it was like doing exercises in a gym and your muscles waking up. It was brilliant.’ But she spent two years making no art at all - it was Sarah Lucas who got her back into art. They met at Sarah’s City Racing show in 1992 and became instant friends. ‘It was wild, brilliant, really love without sex, but totally passionate - it was almost like how girls are at school, that inseparable kind of thing.’ Sarah said they should get a studio together, but Tracey said she wasn’t interested in making art. OK, said Sarah, they’d get a shop and make merchandise. It was an old shop in Bethnal Green Road, and they took it for six months and called themselves the Birds and made T-shirts saying things like ‘I’m so fucky’. ‘What was brilliant about the shop,’ Tracey recalls, ‘was it gave me a platform to find what I was good at - and what I was good at was ideas, and being un- precious about them and having an audience. Sarah was very encouraging in all this.’ Then they went to Geneva together - ‘our Swiss convalescence’ - and made loads more stuff and Jay Jopling offered Tracey an exhibition at White Cube. ‘I thought it would be my one and only exhibition so I decided to call it My Major Retrospective. Two weeks before the show, Jay came to my tiny flat in Waterloo and apparently he left going ‘Ohmigod, what have I done’, because all I could show him was this crap, smelly old ancient things like my old passport or bits of fabric from my sofa when I was three years old. There was nothing that looked like an exhibition, so Jay left thinking he’d made a big mistake.’ But anyway it was a success, and 400 people turned up for the opening. After Sarah Lucas, her next big influence was Carl Freedman, an art curator she went out with for three years. He said if she wanted to be in his 1995 mixed show Minky Manky she had to produce something big - up till then she’d only done small - and so she produced her famous tent, Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 1963-95 . Then she had a big solo exhibition at the South London Gallery called I Need Art Like I Need God, and, ‘On the opening night there were a couple of thousand people and three television crews. And I walked in and thought, “Ohmigod, I’ve arrived!’ Her arrival was confirmed by her notorious appearance on a Channel 4 debate at the 1997 Turner Prize, pissed out of her mind and terribly funny - afterwards, she said, she didn’t even know she’d been on television, she thought she was round at some boring dinner party. And then her friend Vivienne Westwood started dressing her, which gave her a whole new audience in the fashion magazines. Westwood actually doesn’t think much of Emin’s art (but then she doesn’t like any modern art), but she admires her style. And as Tracey says, the collaboration works to their mutual advantage, ‘It’s symbiotic. And it’s fantastic for a woman of my age, 37, to be like this muse and this glamour thing - we’re having fun with it.’ In 1999, Tracey hogged all the publicity for the Turner Prize with her notorious bed, and then she didn’t win. She thinks it was a plot, she thinks the Tate just used her for publicity and never seriously considered giving her the prize. She is quite bitter about it, still. When I said I’d forgotten who did win, she crowed, ‘Exactly! People don’t remember - it was Steve McQueen. But all the papers had my photograph, not his. Revenge is sweet.’ She forced herself to keep smiling at the time, but she cried bitterly afterwards. And she blames that disappointment for the kidney infection which put her in hospital a few months later. Her health has always been precarious - one of the first things she did when she started making money was to take out private health insurance. ‘I’m sickly and I get run down and I have very bad herpes, and I like knowing that the doctor’s there.’ Of course, in the past, her sickliness was exacerbated by her non-stop drinking, progressing from beer to wine to brandy through the day. ‘When I went out, I had a brilliant bag that could hold four beers, half a bottle of brandy and cigarettes all the way round, and also I was sponsored by Bombay Sapphire Gin, so I used to always take a bottle of gin as well. And even when I didn’t go out, I’d be sitting round drinking.’ Why this abuse? ‘I don’t think it was abuse. It was more like rock’n’roll !’ she cackles. Her drinking got so bad about three years ago, she had constant diarrhoea and her weight went down to six-and-half stone. She also got really boringly aggressive at parties, till finally Mat and her friends said pack it in or they’d leave her. So in September 1999, she gave up spirits - she still drinks wine and gets pissed at parties, but not to the same annihilating degree. Nowadays, she says, she looks after herself - she goes to the gym and is learning to box. And she has a good solid relationship with her fellow artist Mat Collishaw, now in its fourth year. Moreover, she is faithful - ‘but of course I think probably no one else is!’ She and Mat could afford to have children but she says she’s too old and also, ‘We have a really good life, we like it the way it is. If I keep fit and healthy, and in shape, I do actually have a few good years.’ But clearly the question of having children is preying on her mind - she’s just made a film with her mother which is ‘basically me asking her why she won’t let me have children. My mum has never wanted me to have children. She thinks I would be destroying my life, even now. I asked, “Is it because she thinks I’m so mentally unstable she’d be frightened for me?” and she said, “Yes, that’s one of the reasons”. The fact that I’ve got over so much, she wouldn’t want anything to come into my life that would make me fragile again.’ How fragile is she? She seems cheerful and robust at present, but she has had plenty of brushes with madness in the past and at least one suicide attempt, when she threw herself off a cliff, aged 20 - ‘But I’m a really good swimmer!’ There was another very bad patch around her abortion in 1990, and one three years ago - perhaps the period of self-neglect commemorated in My Bed . When she goes down, she says, it’s like a spiral in which one failure reminds her of every other failure in her life - that’s why she could never face taking her driving test, because if she failed it would be like failing to win the Turner Prize and every other failure before that. But now she is determined to take her driving test and keep on taking it till she passes. At least now she seems to have got out of the habit of destructive relationships that was such a feature of her teens and twenties. In those days, she says, she was so nihilistic she thought, ‘I am shit, and that is why I am treated like shit.’ Was success as good as she expected? ‘Better! I’m happier. I look after myself more. I’m kinder to myself. I’ve got a nice house. And if I didn’t want to work for a couple of years I wouldn’t have to - it’s a great feeling, to know I’m doing it because I want to do it. The downside is I get terrible stress and my mind goes blank and I lose concentration because there are people on my case all the time for all kinds of shit. People try constantly to use me and I hate it’ I must say that her life, what I saw of it, is incredibly pressured. The phone in her studio rings non-stop, and although she has a brilliant PA, Gemma, she has to keep making decisions. While I was there, she was having a great row with the ICA about the Beck’s Futures exhibition because they were planning to show her new film in the bar and she wanted it in the cinema. She told Gemma to relay the news that she wouldn’t be attending the opening party after all - and suddenly the director of the ICA was on the phone grovelling, saying of course she could have the cinema. ‘The wheel that squeaks gets the oil!’ she crowed as she put the phone down. I was amazed to see that a fortnight before her White Cube opening, half the work was still incomplete. Her stepmother was busy sewing the blankets, her assistant was building the 17ft tower, Helter Skelter , which will be the centrepiece of the show, but she hadn’t even started the four paintings she had promised to make. All this, I’d have thought, was panic enough, but she had also agreed to appear on Have I Got News For You and said she ought to try and read the newspapers - though her main preparation would be choosing her lowest-cleavage outfit to frighten Ian Hislop. She is also supposed to be writing a novel - she says it will have to be a novel rather than an autobiography because ‘one thing that success has taught me is censorship’. But why does she want to write? Are there things she can’t say in her art? ‘Yes, because - I should be careful what I say here, but I don’t think I’m visually the best artist in the world, right? I’ve got to be honest about this. But when it comes to words, I have a uniqueness that I find almost impossible in terms of art - and it’s my words that actually make my art quite unique.’ Aha! This used to be my own theory about Tracey, that she was a great writer and a merely so-so artist. If you see her drawings or her blankets from a distance, without reading the words, you think pretty but not much more. It is the words that give them their edge. That is why My Bed was such a breakthrough, because it didn’t rely on words - but I suspect it relied on our knowing stuff about her history which we only knew from her previous words. But I’ve now revised my theory because there is a piece of hers in the Tate that is only words, For Joseph Samuels, 1981 , and although it is vividly written, it is pretty tame by her standards. So she needs both - the fierceness of the words playing off the delicacy of the art - to really make her point. Finally, I asked about this habit of hoarding things, the way she keeps archives of her life, never lets the past go. ‘Perhaps it’s because I never grew up.’ Or is it because she needs proof - as a teenager, did people call her a liar? ‘ Yes . And not just as a teenage girl but even as a woman. That’s a good theory, I like that. And maybe I don’t believe things myself, as well. Truth is such a transient thing... it’s like with my work, people say, “Oh, the honesty and the truth behind it” - but it’s all edited, it’s all calculated, it’s all decided. I decide to show this or that part of the truth, which isn’t necessarily the whole story, it’s just what I decide to give you.’ So with this interview - honest as far as it goes, I hope, but only a fragment of the whole Tracey. • Tracey Emin’s show, You Forgot to Kiss My Soul, is at White Cube, 48 Hoxton Square, London N1 from 27 April.

webTitle: Pop: Nana Mouskouri dons her big specs

fields.headline: Nana Mouskouri dons her big specs
fields.standfirst:
Nana Mouskouri
Barbican Centre, York
***
fields.trailText:
Nana Mouskouri
Barbican Centre, York
***
fields.body:
The big glasses are back! In a style era dominated by perfectly sighted celebrities sporting specs for no reason at all, it is surely time to salute the myopic Greek songbird who made her name when glasses were considered an affliction rather than the latest must-have accessory, though Liam Gallagher wouldn't be seen dead in the big, black-rimmed bottle-ends she sports for her first British concert in 12 years.

Mouskouri's favourite subject is love, which, in the manner of an entertainer proficient in six European languages, she pronounces "hlov". Perfectly preserved in what appear to be a set of sparkly pyjamas, she explains that she is here to thank her British fans for 40 years of loyalty and hlov; and launches into a souped-up, cabaret arrangement of Hlov Changes Everything. Her multinational approach has sold more than 200m albums worldwide, recorded in over a dozen languages, including Corsican and Hebrew. Recently she has been busy as an ambassador for Unicef and as Greek deputy to the European Parliament, for which she drafted a report on artists' royalties and the internet.

After the absence of a decade, the singer, whose remarkably inclusive repertoire stretches from Bizet to the Beatles, is back to find out if we still need her now she's 64. The answer, from a packed hall of expectant Nana-raks, is resoundingly affirmative, though they must be transported as much by memories as her performance.

Though still revealing flashes of radiance, the voice is really a bit of a ruin, wandering uncertainly through its various registers like a badly tuned radio. None the less, now that Andy Williams, Dean Martin and other doyens of easy listening have been rebranded as cool for consumption by an audience young enough to be their grandchildren, there must be a place for Nana's insouciant brand of music to watch guys by.

After three hours on stage - what astonishing stamina! - she concludes the show, surreally, with Beethoven's Ode to Joy. She basks in her audience's undiminished hlov. And the scrum of well-wishers attempting to get backstage finally proves the adage: "Men do wave passes at girls who wear glasses."

 At Nottingham Royal Concert Hall (0115-989 5555), tonight, then touring.

fields.headline: Keeping your marbles
fields.standfirst: For collectors, those glass balls are far from child's play, writes  John Windsor
fields.trailText: For collectors, those glass balls are far from child's play, writes John Windsor.
fields.body:
You may remember alleys and cats' eyes from your childhood days playing marbles, but would you recognise an indian, an onionskin, a Joseph's coat, a hard core swirl, a Christensen agate tricolour flame or a hermaphrodite?

Sam McCarthy-Fox would. The 56-year-old printer paid 40p for half a dozen indians in an antique shop in his home town, Worthing in East Sussex. The little hoard of hand-made glass marbles, earthy-coloured with orange and blue swirls overlaid on the surface, would fetch £200 among collectors. They are now among 40,000 marbles neatly arrayed in his attic on rings of sea shell or in printers' trays.

He says: 'I love marbles because they are so tactile. You can run them around your hand and admire their beautiful colours.'

At Phillips' saleroom in Knowle, West Midlands, in February, 35 glass marbles dating from the turn of the century, together with a Solitaire board, fetched £736. Phillips knows its marbles and was able to catalogue the varieties - 'multi-lobed core swirl... white latticinio...'

In the United States, hand-made glass marbles - which originated in Lauscha, in the German province of Thüringen in the late 1840s and were exported until the First World War and the advent of American marble-making machinery - can fetch up to $4,000, the price paid recently for a coveted Sulphide, a marble with a clay figure inside. This one had a figure of Teddy Roosevelt. For ancient Roman clay marbles and ancient Egyptian glass marbles, prices are in five figures.

Marbles are big business in the United States. Since the Sixties, American contemporary glass-making, using studio-size kilns, has enjoyed a revival. A single glass sculpture can fetch over $1m. There are now scores of American glass artists making big, studio-quality marbles with fantastic swirls and ribbons.

When I spoke to McCarthy-Fox, who is secretary of the British Marbles Board of Control - for people who actually play the game - he had just returned from the annual Good Friday British and World Championships at Tinsley Green, West Sussex. There, a crowd of 500 had watched 20 teams of six players shooting marbles into 6ft rings, trying to knock other marbles out.

Marble contests have taken place at Tinsley Green since Elizabethan times, when, the story has it, a young man from Surrey and a young man from Sussex competed for the hand of a maiden from Tinsley, which is on the border of the two counties. They were judged equal at archery, at falconry and at wrestling. To decide a winner, they resorted to marbles. Since the game is played with an odd number of marbles, a champion emerged. History does not record his name.

Back in 1922 in Jersey City, US, a 14-year-old boy was declared 'first world marbles champion' by his sponsors, who were evidently unaware of the three-centuries old tradition at Tinsley. In those days, marbles was as big a craze among kids as baseball. It had become a form of gambling, since many youngsters played for keeps.

City chiefs in Jersey City, eager to turn it into a good clean sport, organised a championship for children.. The winner, Charles 'Buster' Rech, was carried shoulder high in front of 10,000 fans and a 50-piece brass band.

Since 1994, America has had an adult marbles tournament, the Mason Cup. Its sponsors made up for having had marbles rejected as an Olympic sport by organising a grand inauguration of the tournament at which the sheriff's department of Frederick County, Maryland.

Somehow, America's adult marbles stars, even Bob 'Radar' Darr and Megan Winkelman, four times Mason Cup winner, seem to lack the earthiness of the oldsters who have competed at Tinsley over the years. There was wiry Jim 'Atom Thumb' Longhurst, born 1893, who could flick his 'tolley' (the marble you shoot) at an old-fashioned thick-glass pint mug 4ft away and smash it. He advised young players to keep flicking their thumbs to keep them in training and to roughen new glass tolleys with a brick to give them a better grip.

'Wee Willie' Wright, a 5ft 2in Welshman, five times winner of the individual title in the Fifties, used to sew a hot water bottle inside his coat to keep his thumb warm.

Players never shoot with collectable hand-made marbles. The marbles are worth most in mint condition.

You can tell a hand-made marble by its 'pontil' (pronounced: punty) marks on opposite sides of the marble. The marks were made by glass scissors snipping the glass rod as its molten end was pushed into a spherical marble mould. Glass scissors were invented around 1846 by the Lauscha glassmaker Elias Greiner.

The rod would have been an amalgam of coloured glass rods rolled together, re-heated, then stretched to 20 or 30ft before being cut into manageable lengths.

The American website Alan's Marble Collection offers hand-made indians at between $25 and $150 (for a near-mint pair). There are onionskins, clear marbles containing flecks of coloured glass, at $15- $500, and latticinios, with a latticed twist, at $7.50-$40.

Connoisseurs of machine-made marbles know their company history. The American Alley Agate company (1929-1949) still trades as Marble King.

By coincidence, the founder's name was Lawrence Alley and alleys were originally made from alabaster.

Prized Christensen marbles first rolled out of Martin Christensen's glass marble making machine in 1902. His company folded in 1917. An offshoot company, Akro Agate, produced Aggies.

Christensen marbles on Alan's Marble website range from $2.50 to $650 depending on design. Akro Agates are $5-$100. Another website offering marbles is www.blocksite.com. The American collectors' main website is www.marblemuseum.org.

In this country, the House of Marbles in Bovey Tracey, Devon, invites visitors to watch marbles being made.

For stockists and the Pocket Book of Marbles phone 01626-835358, website www.houseofmarbles.com.

McCarthy-Fox is forming a British marbles collectors club; his address is Ham Road, Worthing, West Sussex BN11 2QX.

Tolley good show

The Tinsley Green championship game is called ring taw, equivalent to the American ringer play. The British game uses 49 marbles within a 6ft diameter ring - compared with10ft in the US - raised 3ins above the ground and covered with sharp sand. Other games use a hole instead of a ring or are chasing games, with players trying to hit and take each other's marbles.

Players shoot tolleys - marbles three-quarters of an inch in diameter - into half-inch marbles in the centre of the ring. A point is scored for each marble knocked out of the ring by the tolley. If, after scoring, a tolley remains in the ring, the player is entitled to shoot it again from the same position when his turn comes again. If a tolley remains in the ring without scoring, other players can knock it out of the ring, eliminating the player. A score of 25 points wins.

To shoot, cradle the tolley in the index finger, placing the thumb behind it. Then 'knuckle down' by flicking the marble with the thumb.

Cheating is possible by 'fudging' - moving the hand while shooting - or 'cabbaging', shooting within the ring from a point other than where the tolley came to rest. Then there is blocking: interfering with marbles at rest or in flight.

McCarthy-Fox is forming a British marbles collectors club; his address is Ham Road, Worthing, West Sussex BN11 2QX. Tolley good show The Tinsley Green championship game is called ring taw, equivalent to the American ringer play. The British game uses 49 marbles within a 6ft diameter ring - compared with10ft in the US - raised 3ins above the ground and covered with sharp sand. Other games use a hole instead of a ring or are chasing games, with players trying to hit and take each other's marbles. Players shoot tolleys - marbles three-quarters of an inch in diameter - into half-inch marbles in the centre of the ring. A point is scored for each marble knocked out of the ring by the tolley. If, after scoring, a tolley remains in the ring, the player is entitled to shoot it again from the same position when his turn comes again. If a tolley remains in the ring without scoring, other players can knock it out of the ring, eliminating the player. A score of 25 points wins. To shoot, cradle the tolley in the index finger, placing the thumb behind it. Then 'knuckle down' by flicking the marble with the thumb. Cheating is possible by 'fudging' - moving the hand while shooting - or 'cabbaging', shooting within the ring from a point other than where the tolley came to rest. Then there is blocking: interfering with marbles at rest or in flight.

fields.headline: There's a lot at stake
fields.standfirst: Providers aren't making it easy to switch, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Providers aren't making it easy to switch, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
If you are one of the 7 million people estimated to be paying into a personal pension, you may be wondering if you should switch into a stakeholder plan instead.

The stakeholders - a form of personal pension - came into being on 6 April with some big attractions for people who can afford to make the contributions. The maximum annual charge is 1 per cent - an alluring prospect for people stuck in traditional plans, which charge more. There is a ban on other types of charges - initial charges and penalties for stopping or starting contributions or transferring to or from another provider.

But, as so often in issues involving pensions, the pros and cons of transferring from an ordinary personal pension to a stakeholder will depend on the type of charges levied on your personal pension.

'In certain circumstances, it will be fantastic to transfer,' says Nigel Ranger of the Massow Rainbow Group, independent financial advisers. 'For other people, it will be totally the wrong thing to do.' This is because charges on traditional personal pensions have been made so complicated that it is difficult to know what you are being charged. Product providers have obscured the process with initial charges, flat-rate charges, penalties for stopping and starting, varying allocation rates and bid-offer spreads.

Hidden charges were a major spur for the introduction of stakeholder plans. But some people will find that, having had high charges deducted at the start of their personal pension plan, they are now getting the benefit of lower charges and should stay put. Legal & General is writing to all personal pension account holders with calculations showing if they would be better off staying put or moving into a stakeholder.

Norwich Union is writing to its 900,000 existing personal pension holders, telling them about the changes and saying that the maximum charges they will face in future will also meet the stakeholder criterion.

But not all insurers are taking this approach, and you may need to do your own detective work. Tom McPhail of adviser Torquil Clark says: 'You've got to talk to your existing pension company. Tell them that you are paying £x per month and askfor a projection on the growth of your fund between now and retirement.'

You should also ask for a transfer value on your fund now, and a projection on the value of your fund if you do not pay any more in until retirement. You then go to a stakeholder provider and get quotes on your projected fund on the same contribution rates: a projection including the transfer of your existing fund and a projection excluding it.

fields.headline: When double spells trouble
fields.standfirst:
Juggling two incompatible objectives can be disastrous, says Professor Enid Mumford

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Juggling two incompatible objectives can be disastrous, says Professor Enid Mumford
fields.body:
What do executives of the rail and nuclear industries, coal mine supervisors, doctors and teachers have in common? They are all 'double-bind' managers - that is, people whose job involves juggling two work objectives that are not compatible with each other. Success in one may well cause failure in the other. There are many such individuals about these days and they are not happy. Most suffer from stress; some, if the word is used loosely, may even be schizophrenic.

Goals that often conflict are safety versus production, quality versus profits and caring versus economising. Double-bind managers spend their lives trying to keep two balls in the air. Sometimes one or the other is dropped. And they have no way of escape. They are often in senior management positions, but similarly stressed individuals are pre sent at every level in the work hierarchy.

The worst cases are usually to be found in industries where major disasters are a possibility. Here the conflict is between safety and profits or cost cutting.

A classic example is the senior management of Railtrack. The Hatfield rail disaster, in which four people were killed and many other passengers injured, shows that it made a poor job of reconciling its twin goals. Managers took a risk decision and decided to give priority to one goal over the other. But they did not judge the risks correctly.

Another company that was caught in a double bind was British Nuclear Fuels. Senior executives wanted to sell the company, so they had to show that it was potentially profitable. But, by focusing on profitability, the company neglected its other critically important goal of ensuring product quality and safety. In consequence, below-spec fuel rods were sent to Japanese customers who furiously ordered BNFL to take the rods back and pay for their passage.

I experienced a third example when working in the coal industry. Here the pit deputy, who supervised the work of each coalface, was the person in the firing line. He was directly responsible for both safety and production. In a pit with faces that were hard to work and subject to roof falls, flooding and methane gas, paying attention to safety meant lower coal output.

The deputy could not escape having to grapple with this dilemma. Colliery senior management was more remote and very much the servant of the area coal board, which set production targets. So managers took the risk that a neglect of safety would not lead to a disaster.

Interestingly, in all three situations there was an external regulatory authority whose job was to ensure that safety standards were met. Yet too often these bodies were not prepared to use their powers. The Inspector of Mines would visit the colliery regularly and send back pages of criticism and instructions for improvement. These were always ignored because priority was given to coal production.

A countervailing factor in the past but often absent today was the monitoring of safety by trade unions. Some shopfloor workers, miners and process operatives would also be trade union officials prepared to keep a watchful eye out for potential safety threats to their members. If these occurred there would be an immediate protest until they were rectified. Today many of these unions no longer exist or are much weaker.

These examples come from obviously dangerous industries, but the problem of double-bind managers and employees can occur anywhere. People have to walk tightropes because they are given incompatible responsibilities and goals.

Many teachers and doctors would see themselves as in this situation. Teachers are under pressure because they are told to improve exam results while not being able to exclude disruptive children. Doctors, in turn, are under pressure to reduce patient waiting time while providing a decent service. Additionally, both groups are increasingly subject to litigation when things go wrong.

Can anything be done? Here are some suggestions.

A major source of the neglect of important factors is today's concentration on short-term goals, especially financial ones. Yet there are many benefits from paying attention to long-term goals such as safety. The firm can gain a valuable reputation for having a careful and caring management and for doing the right thing.

Cultures can be changed if an effort is made. For example, an effective top management can ensure that good safety practice is the organisational norm, sending an unmistakable message from the top that 'this is how we do things here and we expect all our employees to conform'. Good training can always achieve results: 'Knowing what to do and how to do it'. The most important knowledge for a miner was not how to get coal out of the ground but what to do when the underground environment became dangerous.

Many of these problems can be reduced by insightful behaviour at the top. Improvement requires senior managers to recognise when they and their subordinates are in double-bind situations and to make sure that both sets of goals are achievable. There is also the problem of the single bind. This is the overpowering pressure experienced by the unfortunate individual who is given impossible targets to meet by senior executives who do not understand the complexity of the problem they are handing over. As the government has discovered to its cost this route to disaster is common when new systems or new technology is being introduced.

The hard truth is that it is difficult to achieve improvements in both areas at the same time because the mindsets necessary for each are different. Normally it will be necessary to adopt one target - safety in the case of railways or airlines - as the superordinate condition for meeting the challenge of the other. There are a number of rail systems in continental Europe and Japan that are outstandingly safe and reliable, but very few that are profitable.

Enid Mumford, Emeritus Professor at Manchester University, is author of Dangerous Decisions: Problem Solving in Tomorrow's World (Kluwer Academic/Plenum 1999)

webTitle: How to get a summer job abroad

fields.headline: How to get a summer job abroad
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: 1 Start early. Prince William's work in Chile has highlighted to parents the benefits of packing their children off for a gap year or the summer. So if you want to get beyond Ramsgate, you should be making those job applications, visa requests and agency enrolments now.
fields.body:
1 Start early. Prince William's work in Chile has highlighted to parents the benefits of packing their children off for a gap year or the summer. So if you want to get beyond Ramsgate, you should be making those job applications, visa requests and agency enrolments now.

2 Consider voluntary work if you have not been abroad before or are feeling nervous about the experience. 'It's a bit of a cocooned environment,' says David Woodworth, editor of Summer Jobs Abroad 2001 (£9.99, Vacation Work Publications, www.vacationwork.co.uk). You will probably get a lot of help with the paperwork, have your accommodation arranged for you, be met at the airport and be working with other English speakers. Contact details of Willing Workers on Organic Farms and other organisations are available in books such as Summer Jobs Abroad 2001 .

3 Recognise that tourism and agriculture are the biggest recruiters of seasonal summer jobs. Tour guides, catering staff and chambermaids are recruited in large numbers - and then there are the more demanding roles such as karaoke night organisers in Greece and disc jockeys on cruise ships.

4 Understand that France is probably the easiest EU country to find work in. Used to Britons coming over for camping holidays, for instance, it needs English-speaking staff to cater for these tourists. It is also a good place for novice travellers to spend their first summer - since it will not take you long to return home for a weekend if you are homesick.

5 Think of gaining a job on the spot if you leave it too late and can cope with the possibility that you will not find something. Building sites are an obvious source of work for men.

6 Remember that, if you are applying in advance, you probably make yourself more attractive if you can work the whole season. The internet is making it far easier to send CVs to businesses abroad.

7 Appreciate the advantages of a summer on a turtle conservation project in Greece. 'It stands out on your CV and is far better than being captain of the school hockey team,' says Woodworth. 'It shows that you have stamina and can organise yourself.' Living abroad changes most people - making them more confident, less dependent on families and more broad-minded. Most people who want a post abroad should be able to get one if they try hard enough.

Next week: how to get a summer job in the UK

webTitle: If in doubt, don't get out of your existing pension scheme

fields.headline: If in doubt, don't get out of your existing pension scheme
fields.trailText: Take care before rushing to transfer funds built up in a personal pension to a stakeholder plan.
fields.body:
Take care before rushing to transfer funds built up in a personal pension to a stakeholder plan.

There are three main issues to consider:

 Transfer penalties

 Charges

 Features of the funds such as ability to switch into different types of investment, like fixed interest stocks or global equities.

If you are in any doubt, it's best to leave your cash where it is when you open a stakeholder pension, says Tom McPhail of adviser Torquil Clark. 'Moving money costs money. You'll usually lose a percentage here or there when you transfer funds.'

One advantage of keeping your existing pension is that you will spread your risk. You will now have two different pension providers looking after your money. If one makes some poor investment decisions, chances are the other one will produce better returns.

High transfer penalties could be another reason not to move. 'Most personal pensions bought in the last five years will have pretty good transfer values,' says McPhail.

This means that if you have built up a £20,000 fund, your transfer value is likely to be £19,000 or £20,000. But some providers levy hefty penalties, and you could see a 25 per cent penalty put on your fund, leaving you with just £15,000 in this instance.

Another issue is annual management charges. If your new stakeholder provider undercuts your present provider by 0.25 per cent, this will make you more inclined to move.

These are probably the main two considerations. But there could be others, such as the investment choice both providers offer.

If your old provider makes it cheap and easy to switch money between different types of investment you might want to leave your money where it is. This could give you a different approach to risk in your two pension plans - another way of spreading your risk if you are interested in watching over your investments this closely.

fields.headline: Holding Nazis to account
fields.standfirst: Holocaust victims must move quickly to reclaim assets, says  Andrew Bibby
fields.trailText: Holocaust victims must move quickly to reclaim assets, says Andrew Bibby.
fields.body:
The list of 21,000 dormant bank accounts, posted on the internet earlier this year, goes on for page after page. They have assets sitting waiting, unclaimed for the past 60 or so years.

All the accounts are with Swiss banks and all, without exception, belonged to victims of Nazi persecution who perished in the Holocaust. In most cases, the list gives nothing more than each account holder's first name, surname and the town or country where they lived, but it makes sombre reading: Paul Abel from Vienna, Anna Bach from Nuremburg, Marthe Cabanes from Paris. This is a detail of recent European history that some might prefer to forget.

Nevertheless, the publication of the list at last provides an opportunity, albeit a limited one, for the assets held in the accounts to be reunited with family members. The Swiss banks, which for all the post-war period controversially sat on the money, have now agreed to put aside $800 million for claimants.

The deal is part of the broader $1.25 billion settlement agreed by the banks last July at the end of a long court hearing in New York over the victims' assets.

However their families have only a short time to file claims. A six- month deadline has been imposed, and the countdown started the moment the list of accounts was posted online, on 5 February.So after more than half a century of inertia, there are now less than four months left for them to obtain an application form, complete it and return it to the central administrative office in New York.

Quite apart from the emotional issues that may be involved in making such a claim, the practicalities are not necessarily easy, as Lee Comer, a freelance trainer living in West Yorkshire, dis covered when she telephone for a form. 'I rang up the 0800 number I had been given, and got short shrift. They said, "We've run out of forms, they're being reprinted." I was told that there would be a minimum delay of four weeks, probably five weeks,' she says.

Application forms for claims can be ordered via the freephone number Comer rang, 0800 096 4513. It is answered in a call centre in the United States. Staff there are now claiming that the printing delays on the forms are resolved, and that the waiting time is down to two weeks.

What she was not told, however, is that the easiest way to obtain a form is to download it direct from the internet, from the main website, www.dormantaccounts.ch.

Comer, whose mother escaped to Britain from Czechoslovakia as a refugee in 1938, found out about the dormant accounts claims process through her aunt in Prague, who survived Auschwitz and is now in her seventies. A cousin's name is among those on the Swiss bank list.

Lee argues that survivors of the Holocaust, given their age, may easily be discouraged from making claims. 'There's a very tight deadline which has to be met, and the form is not easy to complete. A lot of people will just give up,' she says.

In Britain, an advisory service is being offered by the Central Office for Holocaust Claims. Michael Newman, its director, says that hundreds of calls have come in since February, and that at least a dozen people in Britain have been identified who are likely to have very strong claims against dormant accounts.

'The deadline is looming. If people have any reason to suspect they might be eligible, I would always say to them to fill in a claim form,' he says.

Claims need not be restricted to one of the 21,000 accounts on the list published in February. Another 15,000 or so dormant accounts have been identified as being probably or possibly linked to victims of Nazi persecution, and the banks have agreed to search a further database of 4 million names. While most account holders were Jewish, relatives of others who died at the hands of the Nazis (including Romanies, Jehovah's Witnesses and gays) can also make claims.

Swiss accounts were opened in the immediate pre-war period by many people who saw Switzerland as a relatively safe haven for their assets.

'They tended to be people from Austria, Germany and further west. Lots of people were merchants or traders who travelled to Switzerland,' says Newman.

As well as the individual accounts identified on the dormant accounts website, a small number of business accounts are also listed.

Claims will be judged by an international tribunal. Successful claimants will receive balances adjusted for inflation and interest. There are procedures for making assessments where the sum in the dormant account is no longer known.

As well as the individual accounts identified on the dormant accounts website, a small number of business accounts are also listed. Claims will be judged by an international tribunal. Successful claimants will receive balances adjusted for inflation and interest. There are procedures for making assessments where the sum in the dormant account is no longer known.

fields.headline: Aristocrat dressed by Oxfam
fields.standfirst: Tracy Worcester, enemy of global greed, talks to Terry Slavin
fields.trailText: Tracy Worcester, enemy of global greed, talks to Terry Slavin.
fields.body:
When you have the word Marchioness before your name, and are heir to 52,000 acres of prime Gloucestershire countryside, you wouldn't think money is something you need worry much about.

But Tracy Worcester frets a great deal about the damage money does at the hands of global capitalism.

You would never think it from her Oxfam shop wardrobe, but the former Tracy Ward, who married into aristocracy when she became Harry Worcester's bride in 1987, has never wanted for much in financial terms. The former It girl was raised by nannies and attended boarding schools, before going to Paris as a model at 17 and following her sister, the Thornbirds actress Rachel, on to the stage - acting in Cats Eye's and Cluedo.

Her marriage to the future Duke of Beaufort changed her life. 'I loved my work, but I didn't need to do it. I wanted to be with my children, so I gave it up.'

Attracted to the environmental movement she took the advice of a friend, the ecologist Teddy Goldsmith, and began stuffing envelopes for Friends of the Earth. Thus began her Damascene conversion to the cause that now rules her life.

With money and time at her disposal, Worcester has thrown any spare energies left from raising three children into building what she hopes will be a safer world.

A roads protest veteran dedicated to the overthrow of global capitalism she is a trustee and patron of several charities, including Friends of the Earth. But her biggest commitment is as associate director of the International Society for Ecology and Culture, a small Devon charity that promotes the local trading of food as an antidote to global agribusiness.

'My work is to do with how we've become enslaved to money, rather than money being our servant,' she says. 'I don't live an extravagant life. I go to second-hand shops. I don't support global label-dominated fashions.'

She uses any spare money to promote her causes. She is just back from a self-financed month in Ethiopia, where she investigated the causes of starvation.

She was struck by how Ethiopians in one community had worked together for a week to build a house for a family, who had only to provide food and drink in exchange for their labour.

Worcester thought of that 'magnificent' house, with its thatched roof and garden, when she went to the dentist shortly after her return and found the receptionist in tears because she'd had to put her 16-week-old baby in a nursery to return to work after maternity leave. She had to work to help pay off the mortgage on her £90,000 two-bedroom flat.

'Tell me, whose economic system is stronger: one based on exchange and barter, as in Ethiopia, or one like ours, where the average couple are indebted for their entire lives to pay for a basic need like a roof over their head?' asks Worcester.

She takes her children, aged five, nine and 12, on her travels as often as she can, trying to expose them to cultures not dominated by Coca-Cola and McDonald's.

'The [globalisation] propaganda machine has its tentacles everywhere, in the schools, newspapers, magazines, television. All I can offer is the alternatives, for them to question for whose benefit this rampant consumer culture is for. Hopefully they will see for themselves it doesn't bring contentment. It just stokes up greed.'

webTitle: A fine time to be underinsured...

fields.headline: A fine time to be underinsured...
fields.standfirst: Valuing the contents of your own home could cost you dear, writes  Virginia Wallis
fields.trailText: Valuing the contents of your own home could cost you dear, writes Virginia Wallis.
fields.body:
Some things are best left to an expert, and calculating the value of your home and its contents for insurance purposes is one of them.

There are two reasons for this. If you attempt to do it yourself, there is no guarantee that you will get it right, and you probably have better things to do with your time.

You could have a stab at working out the rebuilding cost - or 'reinstatement value' - of your home by using the free information sheet Buildings Insurance for Home Owners 2000, published by the Association of British Insurers (ABI).

But this will give you only a general idea, and as the ABI points out: 'You must calculate an adequate sum insured to avoid claim pay ments being reduced because of underinsurance.' If you overestimate the rebuilding cost, which can happen if you wrongly assume this is the same as what you could sell the property for, you will waste money on unnecessarily high premiums.

The ABI itself warns against doing your own sums if your home is in the Channel Islands or Northern Ireland or does not fall into one of five standard house types. Those needing special attention include:

 flats;

 unusually large houses;

 buildings not made of brick;

 homes more than three storeys high;

 houses with cellars or basements, or special design features;

 buildings of historic interest.

The trouble with valuing your own contents is that unless your home is brimming with antiques and other readily saleable objects, you are unlikely to find an expert to take on this tedious task. It involves going from room to room drawing up a detailed inventory of all moveable belongings, and estimating what they would cost to buy new. Given that most people's idea of fun does not include counting CDs and paperbacks or researching the prices of electrical goods and furniture, it is hardly surprising that, according to research by the Henley Centre, an estimated 60 per cent of homeowners are unsure how much cover they need.

Some insurance companies have gone part of the way to solving the problem by offering to estimate the value of contents, based on the number of bedrooms you have.

Most impose a maximum on what they will pay out. According to a survey in Which? magazine, the upper limit for the 'bedroom-rated' contents policies it listed as best buys ranges from £30,000 to £180,000; and from £250,000 to £500,000 for buildings cover.

Unfortunately, you won't know whether your insurer's upper limit is adequate - or unnecessarily generous - unless you have worked out what your home and contents would actually cost to replace. So there is still a risk of under- or over-insurance.

However, a handful of policies, such as those from AA Insurance, Abbey National, the Halifax, Lloyds TSB and the Prudential, provide unlimited buildings cover; and both Abbey National and the Halifax offer unlimited cover for contents.

But cover is unlimited only up to a point. With the buildings policies, unlimited cover does not apply to claims for damages related to your legal liability as owner of the property. And there may be a limit on what you can claim for the cost of alternative accommodation if your home is so badly damaged that you can't live in it.

Genuinely limit-free contents insurance doesn't exist either. While there may be no overall limit on what will be paid in the event of a total loss, nearly all contents policies - whether bedroom-rated or not - impose separate maximum limits for certain individual items or may exclude them altogether.

In common with many others, the Halifax policy, for example, limits to £2,000 what it will pay towards repairing or replacing anything it considers a high risk. It won't pay more than £500 for lost, stolen or dam aged bicycles. The majority of insurers usually apply this sort of limit to cash, office equipment kept at home, food in the freezer, garden furniture and plants, visitors' belongings, and personal possessions taken out with you.

The unlimited-cover policy from Marks & Spencer Financial Services is different. With the exception of a £500 limit for lost or stolen cash, there are no other limits and all valid claims are guaranteed to be paid in full, whatever they are for and whatever their amount. And unless the policyholder chooses otherwise, there is no excess to pay.

So what's the catch? There isn't one says Peter Longstaff, its head of personal lines.

Close scrutiny of the policy largely bears this out. Keen gardeners may be disappointed to find that garden plants aren't covered - as they can be with other policies - but apart from the usual exclusions for loss or damage as a result of radioactive contamination, deliberate acts, war risks, vermin, gradually operating causes and so on, everything else is.

'If it doesn't say it's not covered, then it is,' adds Longstaff.

But doesn't this make the insurance expensive?

A lot depends on personal circumstances. A 40-year-old living in a two-bedroom house in Essex, for example, could pay £242 a year for a policy with Lloyds TSB, compared with £291 for an M&S policy. However, a man of 55 living in a three-bedroom house in Yorkshire would find that at £148, the M&S cover was cheaper than the £163 charged by Direct Line.

In common with other insurers, the price comes down if you qualify for discounts because you have been claim-free for several years, have a burglar alarm or you volunteer to pay more towards any claim than the minimum excess required by the insurer.

M&S is unusual in allowing customers to choose an excess of up to £1,000, which cuts 35 per cent off the premium.

Help is at hand

For a copy of the information sheet, Buildings Insurance for Homeowners 2000, write to the Association of British Insurers, 51 Gresham Street, London EC2A 4SS, or go to www.abi.org.uk.

A list of local surveyors able to provide rebuilding valuations is available from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' information centre (tel: 020 7222 7000).

For a quote for M&S Financial Services insurance, phone 0800 38 999 88.

fields.headline: Insurers run for cover
fields.standfirst: People in flood-risk postcodes are being redlined, reports  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: People in flood-risk postcodes are being redlined, reports Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
Bills for flood damage have forced up homeowners' premiums for buildings and contents insurance for the first time in four years, the new AA quarterly British Insurance Premium Index reveals.

The AA expects most premiums to go up by between 5 and 10 per cent in the next 12 months no matter where you live, and by as much as 20 per cent for homeowners in areas where the flood risk is high.

Rises averaging 1.62 per cent for buildings cover and 1.44 per cent for contents have already been imposed since January.

The average buildings premium is now £134 a year and the average contents policy costs £107. However, a policyholder in a two-bedroom semi in Islington has seen the contents premiums inch up by 2.15 per cent so far this year, from £239.75 to £244.89. The owners of a three-bedroom semi in East Sussex will have to pay £322.11 instead of £314.47, an increase of 2.34 per cent.

Shopping around can still transform rises into reductions - premiums can fall to as little as £92 for buildings and to £70 for contents, says AA Insurance Services.

But managing director Kerry Richardson warns: 'These premium rises are the first sign that home insurers are starting to pass on losses from bad weather over winter to their customers. We expect further quarterly increases to raise premiums by at least 5 per cent by the end of the year.'

The news comes as car insurance premiums ratchet up again. Third party, fire and theft cover has risen by 6.21 per cent over the past three months, while comprehensive policies went up by 4.40 per cent.

Home claims following last autumn's storms and floods totalled almost £700 million, according to the Association of British Insurers (ABI). More than half of them, totalling £389m, resulted from damage to homes. The final bills are set to rise higher, as many buildings are still being repaired.

Mary Francis, director general of the ABI, says: 'Not surprisingly, last autumn's floods have produced a very substantial repair bill: this type of natural disaster demonstrates the true value of insurance.

'But if floods like this become more commonplace in the future, as some scientists suggest, the Government must play its part in providing adequate flood defences and enforcing planning controls.

'We have had very useful discussions with Ministers on these issues, particularly where planning regulations are concerned. We hope that better planning, improved flood defences, and perhaps even new ideas for building design will help minimise the risk - and the cost of insurance - in vulnerable areas.'

Yet fears are growing that thousands of households in these risky areas will not be able to obtain new home insurance, and that those who are covered will face much heftier premiums and excess charges. Some 2 million British households are in flood risk areas, the Environment Agency estimates.

Research by online broker Screentrade says insurers are already refusing new business from the areas hardest hit by last year's floods after having to make pay-outs as high as £100,000 a time. Companies can turn people away because insurance is drawn up annually, and either party can walk away once it has expired.

Screentrade says the major insurers Norwich Union, Direct Line and Eagle Star are refusing to take on new customers in certain parts of Kent, Yorkshire, Cornwall and Devon if they have made recent flood claims of more than £5,000. Even people who have made no claim at all may have problems getting cover if their postcode shows that their homes are are 'at risk'.

The broker says areas covered by the following postcodes have been classified by companies as being among those where the risk is greatest:

 OX16 0SX, in Banbury, Oxfordshire.

 DN6 9DG, in Norton, South Yorkshire.

 TQ5 9EG, in Brixham, Devon.

 OL14 5BZ, in Todmorden, West Yorkshire.

 YO41 1PX, in Stamford Bridge, York.

 PL15 8BA, in Launceston, Cornwall.

 ME18 6JS, in Yalding, Kent.

Direct Line says it decides on a case-by-case basis whether people in these flood-prone areas should have insurance denied or their premiums increased.

The questions it asks prospective customers include: 'How long ago was any flooding?', 'How far away was it from your home?', 'Is the property on higher ground?' and 'What preventative measures have been taken?'

A Direct Line spokeswoman says: 'If someone comes to us as a new-business customer and their home has been subject to flood damage we would probably not be able to offer terms.' She insists, however, that existing customers in these areas are not being penalised.

Norwich Union admits it will probably not take on new customers who have previously been flooded, but promises to look at each case individually. It removes flood cover from existing customers only as a 'last resort' if their homes have repeatedly been under water.

Royal and SunAlliance and Churchill, which were not included in the research, say they would provide cover in risky areas, though new customers could be subject to higher premiums and excess charges.

The policy towards customers in risky areas comes despite reassurances from the ABI that its members would try not to exclude anyone from cover. It also says existing customers should always be able to renew their policies.

Screentrade says shopping around for the best deal won't work if you have been flooded out. 'It is a Catch 22 - you have to stick with your current company on a higher premium or face being without insurance,' said an official of the broker.

Your best course of action is to negotiate with your existing insurer, according to both Screentrade and the AA. This is because it is obliged to give you cover of some sort or another, while other providers may simply turn you away.

If the insurer decides to put the rate up, ask it instead to to change the excess on the policy - the amount of a claim to be paid by the client before the insurer chips in. This is typically £50. Raising it to £250 should keep premiums down and work out cheaper in the long run.

The AA says: 'They will be happy to put it up because it means you are taking on some of the risk of living on a flood plain.'

Unfortunately, it looks as though the higher premiums are here to stay for flood victims and those in high risk areas. 'Statistics from the Met Office show flooding is going to get worse,' Screentrade says. 'Last autumn's were just the start.'

The Environment Agency has warned that homeowners face a tenfold rise in the risk of flooding and other weather-related damage to their property over the next century.

Even if your home has never previously been affected, there is no guarantee you will remain safe.

How to find high ground

 Record the damage as soon as possible by making a video or taking photographs while the water is still inside your home.

 Keep all your policy documents and passport on the first floor or higher.

 Contact your insurer as quickly as possible and keep all receipts for all work carried out.

 Retain receipts for any meals you have to buy because you can't cook at home. The insurer should pay part of your food bill.

 Record the contents of your freezer.

 Don't throw anything away. Your insurer or its loss adjuster may insist on inspecting water-damaged furniture. Keep a piece of any damaged carpet.

 Use a builder approved by your insurer.

 Keep a note of promises by the company, including the dates they were made.

 Consider hiring a loss assessor who will act for you, independently of the company's adjuster.

... and how to stay there

In general there are some simple ways to minimise your insurance bill.

 Fit new window and door locks but make sure they are approved by the insurer.

 Reduce the amount insured - many people overestimate the value of their home contents by thousands of pounds. The average flood damage claim is for between £6,000 and £7,000.

 If the house is occupied during the day, tell your insurer

 Break away from your mortgage provider's cover. Lenders frequently bundle insurance into the mortgage deal - 70 per cent of homeowners are insured like that - but it can cost you £100 more than the best deal on the market.

 If you shop around don't just go for the cheapest price. Check what you are getting for your money in terms and conditions.

Keep a piece of any damaged carpet.  Use a builder approved by your insurer.  Keep a note of promises by the company, including the dates they were made.  Consider hiring a loss assessor who will act for you, independently of the company's adjuster. ... and how to stay there In general there are some simple ways to minimise your insurance bill.  Fit new window and door locks but make sure they are approved by the insurer.  Reduce the amount insured - many people overestimate the value of their home contents by thousands of pounds. The average flood damage claim is for between £6,000 and £7,000.  If the house is occupied during the day, tell your insurer  Break away from your mortgage provider's cover. Lenders frequently bundle insurance into the mortgage deal - 70 per cent of homeowners are insured like that - but it can cost you £100 more than the best deal on the market.  If you shop around don't just go for the cheapest price. Check what you are getting for your money in terms and conditions.

fields.headline: Satisfaction no longer guaranteed
fields.standfirst:
Public sector staff are increasingly suffering from stress and depression, writes Tracey Boles

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Public sector staff are increasingly suffering from stress and depression, writes Tracey Boles
fields.body:
If you are unhappy in your work, you are not alone. Job satisfaction among Britain's 6 million public sector workers has plummeted over the past decade - and stress is to blame, says a new study from Warwick University.

The study by Andrew Oswald and Jonathan Gardner found that an increase in depression, strain, sleep loss and unhappiness during the 1990s had made employment in the public sector more pressurised and less enjoyable.

However, despite the discontent, most people in the public sector are almost completely satisfied with their job. On a scale of one (completely dissatisfied) to seven (completely satisfied), 41 per cent of the population gave their answer as six and 18 per cent went for 7. Only 2 per cent answered one.

The sample of 5,000 workers from both the public and private sector was re-interviewed each year through the 1990s, with stress levels assessed by the answers to 12 questions used to measure mental distress and psychological ill health such as 'Can you concentrate on your work?', and 'Are you losing confidence?'.

While public-sector workers began the 1990s with far higher levels of job satisfaction than those in the private sector, the research showed that this gap had been virtually eroded by 1998, a year of tightly controlled government spending.

Rising stress due to a substantial increase in workload had caused the decline in job satisfaction, Oswald says. The workers, which include doctors, teachers, lecturers and civil servants, now have to face extra bureaucracy, pressure to meet targets and the introduction of working practices from the private sector. The latter was more stressful than in 1990, but not much.

As well as an increasingly heavy workload, public-sector workers have been subjected to much evaluation, inspection and public humiliation. Oswald says: 'Public humiliation is not found in any other job. Who, apart from teachers and doctors, gets their name published all over the papers saying they are second rate?'

This process of holding people to account has made the public sector very unpleasant to work in because human beings are not equipped to cope with it, according to Oswald.

All groups of public-sector workers have become less satisfied at work over the past decade. But the slump in satisfaction was particularly evident in the NHS, higher education, and among those working for local government. 'Local government has been the poor relation of the public sector,' says Unison, the union that represents public-sector workers. It says the worst affected are those at the lower end of the pay scale in local government, such as cleaners and caterers.

Unison does not find the report's conclusions surprising. It says low morale is the result of years of under-investment, both in staff and the workplace. 'The lack of pay awards and training have lead to loss of job satisfaction,' says a spokeswoman. 'Managing on a day-to-day level is stressful after years of cutbacks.'

It also blames the threat of violence and the effects of privatisation for the poor morale. 'When a service is privatised employees are guaranteed work - at first. The prospect of restructuring hangs over them.'

Can anything be done to turn round this unsatisfactory state of affairs?

It has become a matter for public policy, Oswald believes. 'As a nation we have to decide how important our public services are to us. We have to offer good jobs or hand them over to the private sector. At the moment we are not in equilibrium.'

Unison believes services should be run in-house. 'We are against privatisation and contracting out.'

Decent pay awards and further investment are also needed to remedy the situation. A spokeswoman says: 'In the health service the amount of money that has gone in has made a difference. Investment has been at all levels. Individual learning accounts are available to all staff. They have recognised that staff at all levels are important.'

Bad management practices also need to be eliminated, Unison says.

The Cabinet Office thinks the civil service reform programme, launched in 1999, is helping. A spokeswoman says: 'There may be issues of motivation and stress in the public sector due to the pace of change. But our own research indicates we are investing in the right kind of personnel policies such as a family friendly environment and training.'

But Oswald is not convinced that anything is about to change. He says: 'We expect these trends to continue. I think this is very serious for Britain.'

Other findings of the research were that job satisfaction was u-shaped in age, with initial contentment at work during teenage years disappearing by the age of 25. Job satisfaction was discovered to be lowest when people were in their 20s and 30s and highest among staff in their 50s and 60s.

Oswald explains: 'It is a process of adaptation. Young people just finishing university have very high expectations then they go through a very painful period which involves coming to terms with their limitations. Once they have gone through this they are happy in their work again.' This pattern is true for all types of occupations and among all nationalities. 'It is something very deep in human nature,' Oswald says. 'It is nothing to do with balancing work and home commitments as some people have reported.'

The theory also explains why Britons with university degrees report the lowest levels of satisfaction at work. Workers with no qualifications are the happiest, the study found.

Job satisfaction was found to be higher among women than among men, lower among blacks than whites, slightly lower in union workplaces than non-union ones, high in small workplaces, and highest of all in not-for-profit organisations.

Women were more satisfied no matter where they came from. Oswald says two theories have been proposed to explain this. One is that women have low expectations and are more pleased with any level of achievement. The second is that they knuckle down more than men - they throw themselves into work rather than worry about external factors such as hierarchy and advancing their own status.

So be nice next time you have to deal with a man working in the public sector.

webTitle: A less taxing return from the Revenue

fields.headline: A less taxing return from the Revenue
fields.standfirst: Hector wants to keep it simple for many, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Hector wants to keep it simple for many, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Many taxpayers who leave it to the last minute to send in their tax returns have been given a helping hand by the Inland Revenue. It has produced a simplified tax calculation guide, which has gone out with about half of the 8.6 million tax returns it mailed earlier this month.

Anyone who has received one of 2000-01 returns must return them by 31 January 2002 or face a £100 fine. Many people who leave this chore until January end up computing their own tax bill because they may need to make a tax payment on 31 January 2002 or face paying interest at 8.5 per cent on late tax.

So the Inland Revenue is easing the process. Last year, the same calculation guide, running to 29 pages, was sent to everyone who got a tax return. This year, about half of taxpayers will get the complicated version - 32 pages - and the other half will get the simplified 15-pager.

Tax experts welcome the move - but still feel for ordinary people going through these procedures. John Whiting of accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers says: 'I still struggle to find a 15-page calculation easy. I'm glad that I've got a computer programme to work it out.'

Ian Johnson of Grant Thornton says: 'You've got to leave yourself plenty of time and go through it simply and carefully. With patience and care, you probably can do it.' He estimates that someone who has gathered all the necessary informationcould probably fill in a tax return and a simple tax calculation 'in a morning or so'.

The different versions of the tax calculation are being sent out by reference to the supplementary pages that people get. Someone who gets the basic return and the self-employed supplementary pages, for instance, will get the 15-page version. But complicated returns go to those with capital gains, income from abroad, partnership income and membership of share schemes. Some people may have been sent the simple version but need the complicated one - if, for example, you had capital gains but have not yet notified the Revenue.

People with complicated tax affairs are best advised to get their tax return back by 30 September, the last date on which the Revenue will guarantee that it can process a tax calculation in time to notify the recipient of any payments due on 31 January.

Perhaps the nastiest area in the calculation is capital gains. A simple purchase and sale of a block of shares may not cause a problem, but anything more tricky, such as a partial sale, can become a hideous mess. Chancellor Gordon Brown intended to simplify CGT when he introduced tapering relief from April 1998 - but instead brought in a nightmare calculation that can involve all or some of the following: identification of assets sold, indexation for periods up to April 1998, aggregation and disaggregation of purchases, and one (or sometimes two) tapering exercises. Whiting says that many people could be hit by this: 'There are a good few people playing the stock market and making disposals every week.'

Nevertheless, he thinks it is possible that the calmest, clear-headed taxpayers could successfully get through the 32-page calculation: 'You have to be prepared to take it carefully and not to jump to conclusions or skip bits.'

If you do your own calculation, you do not send back your workings but merely slot in the figure in box 18.3 on page seven of the return. The Inland Revenue will then input all the figures on your return and come up separately with a tax liability amount. This is a safety net for people who think they might over-state the tax due through their kitchen table calculation.

Most of the tax return itself is similar to last year's return. This means that people completing their own can use last year's form as a starting point. Only people who get a return are obliged to fill one in, but you are under a duty to let the Revenue know if you have new, untaxed sources of income. Between now and the end of the tax year another 500,000 tax returns are expected to be sent out to people who realise they need one. You will definitely need one if you are a higher rate taxpayer or if you have self-employed income.

Getting your tax return in early has advantages. If you are owed a refund, you will get it more quickly. If a mistake is spotted, there will be more time to deal with it. If you have underpaid tax and get the form back by the end of September you can get the tax due taken from you in installments through your tax coding rather than in one lump sum.

If you employ an accountant you may be able to negotiate cheaper rates by doing it early. Whiting says: 'One of the popular arguments used to be that if you put it in early it gave the Inland Revenue more time to look at it and pick you for investigation. I've never bought that. Most investigations are done on the basis of things that go wrong.'

 The Revenue is no longer giving a £10 discount to people who file their return through the internet. Last year 38,000 people did this, a much lower number than hoped for. The system proved to be bug-ridden in the early stages and incapable of dealing with some more complicated tax situations. The Revenue software is also not Mac-compatible.

fields.headline: Malone Dies
fields.standfirst:
Andrews Lane Studio, Dublin
****
fields.trailText: Actor Conor Lovett's companion piece to his award-winning adaptation of Samuel Beckett's Molloy sees him marching further into Beckett's trilogy of novels with this slim, wise little solo performance.
fields.body:
Actor Conor Lovett's companion piece to his award-winning adaptation of Samuel Beckett's Molloy sees him marching further into Beckett's trilogy of novels with this slim, wise little solo performance.

One has to suspend one's image of the terminally bedbound Malone in the institutional home, unable to die. Lovett stands before you, almost apologetically, talking you through the relentless churning of thoughts, as Malone's mind, "flayed alive by memory", spools out fragments of tales both remembered and invented.

The staging feeds off Beckett's own pared-back stagework, with Lovett dressed in brown layers of coats and a foolish, sawn-off trilby. Trained in the Jacque Lecoq school in Paris, he brings something of the absurdist clown to this tense, nervy incarnation. He also uses a vivid natural shorthand to signal movement, landscape or characters, but there is also quite a bit of old-fashioned storytelling in his polished Cork tones.

This is a mainly comic Malone: the lip-curling contempt occasionally breaking through the hauteur; the ugly, self-congratulatary little smirks; the impotent misanthropy.

Lovett makes much from the dismaying description of ancient sex ("like trying to put a pillow into a pillow-case, having it bend in two"); and supporting shadow characters, such as Big Lambert, the bleeder of pigs, and Lemuel the psychopathic little orderly who steals fat from the soup. The piece truly darkens and engages here, as Lemuel leads his frightful crew of inmates out on their murderous excursion.

Lovett has played larger theatres with this material, but it is a pleasure to examine him in this tiny studio, his wary eyes raking people's faces like a haunted stand-up. Directed by Judy Hegarty, it's a very clever, enjoyable, even moving piece. But maybe Lovett will have to age into greater decrepitude truly to impart Beckett's deep drone of mortal tedium, or his distant allegories of the disaster that befell Europe when Beckett was in his prime.

 Until Saturday. Box office: 00 353 1 6795720
