webTitle: 'The games were war. You didn't dare lose'

fields.headline: 'The games were war. You didn't dare lose'
fields.standfirst: George Best remembers the glory and gory days of red and blue rumbles.
fields.trailText: George Best always did live and play by his own rules, which is how he and his best mate, Mike Summerbee, came to choreograph some moves for the first minutes of Manchester derbies. The idea was to dilute some of the ferocity that traditionally accompanies the occasion.
fields.body:
George Best always did live and play by his own rules, which is how he and his best mate, Mike Summerbee, came to choreograph some moves for the first minutes of Manchester derbies. The idea was to dilute some of the ferocity that traditionally accompanies the occasion.

Best, 54 and recovering at home in Ireland after having Antabuse tablets sewn into his stomach as part of his latest attempt to beat the booze, says: "Mike and I would plan beforehand for one of us to beat the other and vice versa which would make both sets of fans happy. After that, of course, it was every man for himself."

One could not imagine Roy Keane plotting for Paul Dickov to nutmeg him in the opening minute at Old Trafford today. After the week Keane has had he is more likely to launch his opponent towards the prawn sandwiches in the executive boxes.

Some might wonder whether Keane can find the enthusiasm to do even that, given the depression that has settled on Old Trafford since Wednesday's exit from the Champions League in Munich. While today's game is life and death to City, both in terms of local pride and their Premiership status, one might have assumed it would seem like kleine bier to United, especially as the Premiership has already been won.

Best, however, believes the fixture as tribal warfare could mean more to United, with their greater number of locally born players, than to City. United's fans might be from all over the world but Wes Brown, Paul Scholes and Nicky Butt are Manchester-born, and Phil and Gary Neville are from neighbouring Bury while City are unlikely to field a single local.

"It's still an enormous match," Best says, "though it's probably not as intense as in my day because of all the foreigners and the fact that even the English lads in the two sides come from all over the place.

"When I played, nearly all United's fans were locals too. So, taking that into account and the large number of Manchester lads in each team, the games were real warfare. And you didn't dare lose or you would have to go into hiding for a week."

Best discovered the passion, not to mention hatred, that exists between the two clubs when he was part of the United team that won the 1964 youth cup final after seeing off City in a two-legged semi-final.

He says: "City were supposed to have the best crop of youngsters in the country and Mike Doyle, who was in that side, was a real United-hater. He was shouting his mouth off about what they were going to do to us before the game but we beat them 4-1 at Old Trafford and 4-3 at Maine Road, with a total of 50,000 fans watching the two games."

Best played, even though, at 18, he was already an established first-team player, and says: "I wanted to play. Players today moan about the number of games but, when you're young, you can't play enough."

He came face to face with the emotional Doyle, sometimes literally, many more times during his United career, most notably in the Manchester derby of 1970-71. "It was the saddest derby I ever played in because I inadvertently ended the career of their full-back, Glyn Pardoe, who'd also played in that youth cup semi-final," Best recalls.

"I ran halfway across the pitch to close down a Pardoe run and went in with a sliding tackle, which was one of my specialities. But it was a slippery pitch, which carried me in faster than I thought. I heard the crack and knew immediately that he'd broken his leg.

"I felt sick. I just wanted to get off the pitch but there was Doyle, giving me a mouthful, as though I'd done Glyn deliberately. Afterwards, though, the City lads said it was just an accident."

Best, whose several previous retirements had prompted comparisons with Frank Sinatra, had walked out of Old Trafford for good a few months before City won the derby that gave their fans the most joy, and the match- winner his most depressing scoring moment, in 1973-74.

Denis Law, having returned to Maine Road from Old Trafford the previous summer, backheeled the goal that relegated United. Best, great friends with Law, says: "He used to complain that I didn't pass to him enough. But for the only time in his career he wished someone else had scored that one."

United fans had hoped today would find them in a position to trump that humiliation. Their ideal, if sick, scenario would have seen their side go into the match requiring three points for the Premiership title, with City needing to avoid defeat to stay up.

Arsenal's surprise defeat at home to Middlesbrough last weekend ruined that, though a United win will still give City an enormous shove towards the Nationwide league. Best, taking a more sympathetic view, thinks that would be a crying shame.

He feels United should be more concerned about rebuilding their own side as a vehicle capable of meeting European road standards following a disappointing, if predictable, defeat in Munich. Echoing the words of the United captain Keane, he says: "It is no good winning the Premiership every year if they can't compete better than that against European sides."

Like Ferguson, Best believes the ease with which United have turned the Premiership into a one-team league in the past two seasons may have affected their edge against sides like Bayern, who are themselves in a state of reorganisation.

He says: "The gap between top and bottom has become enormous and I bet that this year the points between them is bigger than ever before. When I was playing, there were always lots of teams in contention for the league - Arsenal, Manchester City, Liverpool, Leeds. Every week was a big game and a big battle. Now only a handful of teams can even give United a game and most are beaten before they get on to the pitch."

Ferguson's mistake, Best reckons, may have been in believing that the only vital area of his team that needed strengthening last summer was the goalkeeper, buying just the Frenchman Fabien Barthez.

"Fergie has done that before, buying in one big-name player, and Barthez has proved a good purchase, despite the occasional error. When I first saw him, I wasn't sure because he is so unorthodox and he was making saves that seemed to be flukey. But he makes those saves over and over again and you realise that there's no fluke about them. He's absolutely top drawer.

"Jaap Stam was another critical buy for Fergie," Best says, "not just because of his quickness and confidence on the ball but because he has become the voice in the defence. United had lacked that in the back four since Steve Bruce was there and, though Peter Schmeichel did a similar job, it is much better coming from an outfield player."

After the week Keane has had he is more likely to launch his opponent towards the prawn sandwiches in the executive boxes. Some might wonder whether Keane can find the enthusiasm to do even that, given the depression that has settled on Old Trafford since Wednesday's exit from the Champions League in Munich. Best, however, believes the fixture as tribal warfare could mean more to United, with their greater number of locally born players, than to City. United's fans might be from all over the world but Wes Brown, Paul Scholes and Nicky Butt are Manchester-born, and Phil and Gary Neville are from neighbouring Bury while City are unlikely to field a single local. "It's still an enormous match," Best says, "though it's probably not as intense as in my day because of all the foreigners and the fact that even the English lads in the two sides come from all over the place. "When I played, nearly all United's fans were locals too. So, taking that into account and the large number of Manchester lads in each team, the games were real warfare. webTitle: Sheringham award fails to lift United gloom

fields.headline: Sheringham award fails to lift United gloom
fields.trailText: The announcement that Teddy Sheringham has been named the Football Writers' Association's player of the year could not lift the pall of depression hanging over Old Trafford.
fields.body:
It has been a bad week at Manchester United. Try as they might, yesterday's announcement that Teddy Sheringham has been named the Football Writers' Association's player of the year could go only so far in lifting the pall of depression over Old Trafford.

"I'm extremely proud to be associated with this award," said Sheringham. Was this the time for champagne celebrations? "No," he said, "the entire season has gone very flat indeed in the last week."

That United had seven players nominated - Sheringham pipping David Beckham by two votes with Arsenal's Patrick Vieira third - would usually be an excuse for the bunting to come out at Old Trafford. Wednesday night's defeat away to Bayern Munich, however, has created a funereal air.

Sheringham, 35, is United's leading scorer with 20 goals but there remains the threat that his finest season at Old Trafford could be his last.

Contract negotiations have reached an impasse, with United reluctant to discuss anything longer than 12 months. In the striker's words, he is not "very happy" with the offer.

Sheringham is also favourite for the Professional Footballer's Association award. The six-man shortlist includes two other United players - Roy Keane and Ryan Giggs, but not David Beckham - while Thierry Henry is included though Vieira is not. Marcus Stewart and Emile Heskey are also in contention.

webTitle: Venables the saviour on verge of disaster

fields.headline: Venables the saviour on verge of disaster
fields.trailText: The renewed threat of relegation is chilling bones at Boro where reputations are on the line, but not that of Terry Venables, as a coach at least.
fields.body:
A chill wind is blowing across Rockliffe Park. Well, no change there; there aren't too many shirt-sleeve days at Middlesbrough's splendidly equipped but exposed training ground.

Even so, it's not the temperature that is sending shivers down the spines of the morose knot of supporters, relatives mostly, watching the first-team squad go through their paces. Coventry's resurgence and Boro's own inability to perform in front of their own fans means that the threat of relegation, apparently receding after Terry Venables took over first-team affairs from the hapless Bryan Robson, is again a very real possibility.

The consequences need no spelling out. Even with the parachute payment, the club will measure it in tens of millions of pounds, the fans in terms of trips to Blundell Park and Gresty Road instead of Old Trafford and Highbury. They know they would also be watching a very different team.

"Some supporters think we need to go down to ensure there is root-and-branch change," said Rob Nichols, editor of the fanzine Fly Me To The Moon. "The problem is last time we went down we sold Juninho for £12m, which gave us money to rebuild and we got Paul Merson for £5m. This time the best players would move but with the exception of [the goalkeeper] Mark Schwarzer they're over 30 and wouldn't bring in anything like that amount. It would be a disaster."

No one at the club would disagree. "It is very, very important that we stay up. I can't say more than that," said Venables this week.

The "we" is instructive. His future may be uncertain but no one can deny that the quintessential Londoner has not poured heart, soul and a huge amount of time into saving the Teessiders. Yet when he took on the job in December after nine defeats in their previous 10 games, the anti-Venables faction scoffed loud and long.

Anyone doubting his commitment now need only witness a training session, and watch the familiar baggy-shorted figure, possibly a little less stocky than of late, constantly shouting, pointing, urging and encouraging.

He admits he works as much on countering the strengths of the coming opposition as on developing those of his own side. "It has to be that way because from the day I came the job's always been about the short term, about matching and patching; it's about an immediate fix all the time."

Boro have played 17 Premiership matches since he took over, having played 17 beforehand. Under Robson, who in his five years in control spent £78m on 45 players, the record this season was won two, drawn five, lost 10, points 11. Under Venables they have won five, drawn nine, lost three, points 24; and he has spent just £;600,000, on the combative striker Dean Windass.

Whether he would have liked to bring in more players is beside the point. "It's not been a matter of what I might want, it's been a matter of working with what I've got. The reaction of the players has been excellent, I can't fault their attitude at all. Since Bryan and I began working together the record's been pretty good."

This is admirably diplomatic given that during training Robson appears a painfully peripheral figure. The idea of him picking up the reins again when, as now seems certain, Venables departs at the end of the season, seems ludicrous.

According to Nichols, the supporters want to see a tactically aware manager such as Preston's David Moyes, or the Ipswich coach and former Boro stalwart Tony Mowbray being tempted to the Riverside. In the meantime Venables continues to wave away questions on his future, insisting the next four games are all that are on his mind, starting today at Leicester.

With Boro happier away from home, where Venables accepts they get edgy, and Leicester having lost their last seven games, three points would give them a buffer, not least because their next visitors are Manchester United.

Reputations are on the line at Boro, but not that of Terry Venables, as a coach at least.

fields.headline: City crash engulfs Kanchelskis
fields.trailText: Daniel Taylor meets the man who has swapped the Theatre of Dreams for the stuff of nightmares at the Theatre of Base Comedy.
fields.body:
It may be a German rather than Ukrainian concept but Andrei Kanchelskis has spent enough time in Manchester to be well acquainted with the meaning of schadenfreude .

From his days at Old Trafford the nomadic winger can remember the crowd's amusement whenever City lost and, having joined the select number to play for both clubs, he has not taken long to detect the malicious sense of pleasure around Moss Side at United's intermittent misfortunes. The souvenir stalls around Maine Road have done a brisk business in Bayern Munich memorabilia of late

"Of course I understand," he says. "It is just - how I can say this? - I doubt United really care that much about City these days."

It is six years since Kanchelskis left United and this afternoon, in the 136th Manchester derby, he could be excused for feeling like an aristocrat fallen on hard times. The queasy possibility of United winning the title while relegating their neighbours - something that, in their weaker moments, most City fans will confess has consumed them with dread ever since the fixtures were announced - is no longer on.

But, if Kanchelskis's new employers capitulate at Old Trafford, he is realistic enough to accept, however grudgingly, that the first relegation of his career will be little more than a formality.

Given that City are stuck in the quicksand, with West Ham, Ipswich and Chelsea still to play, it is scarcely conceivable that another season of tragi-comedy at Maine Road will lead anywhere but a slough of depression. As Rodney Marsh observed recently: "I don't want to speak poorly of them but they are crap, aren't they?"

Kanchelskis is somewhat more skilled in the art of diplomacy but, after only two wins since joining on loan from Rangers almost three months ago, he too cannot have liked what he has seen.

"It has been a difficult time for everybody," he says. "It's especially been hard for Joe Royle but it is not fair to blame him, not fair at all. He is a great manager and he has got the club two promotions. It's just such a big jump to the Premiership, a huge jump.

"People must remember that City were a Second Division club only two years ago and that it takes time to be of Premiership quality. This club is still learning really and that is why we are down towards the bottom of the table. The Premiership can be a hard place for a newcomer.

"In my time away there has been a huge improvement. There are a lot more top quality players from all over the world and English football seems to have taken a massive step forward. Along with Serie A it is the best in the world now.

"Back in 1991, when I first arrived, it was much more physical, 90 minutes of almost non-stop football. Now teams are more tactical and technically it is much better. Look how United have improved over the last 10 years. They are a fantastic team."

Kanchelskis gives the impression that, even with a gun held to his temple, he would not have a bad word to say about his old club. "I could never criticise them. United gave me four excellent seasons and nothing will ever change that."

That is fair enough but there is no disguising that his departure from Old Trafford in 1995 was laced with acrimony. According to Sir Alex Ferguson, Kanchelskis's agent Grigory Essaoulenko warned United's chairman Martin Edwards he "would not be around much longer" if the protracted £5m transfer to Everton did not go through. But what really galled Ferguson was the player's attitude during his final months at the club.

"Where was that lovely smile and graciousness and gratitude he had brought to Old Trafford?" he wrote in his autobiography. "This was not the boy we had lifted out of the Ukraine where his weekly wage was £6. This was a scowling, discontented young man."

Kanchelskis chooses his words carefully. "I have not spoken to Alex Ferguson since, not once. Sometimes in football there is a problem between the manager and the players. That's life; that's football. But it's not my problem; it's his problem. He is entitled to his opinions but I have never wanted to get into a public argument. For me it's history. Every day is a new day and I'm not one to look back and criticise people in public. Other people can do that, not me."

Even so the 32-year-old - who will become the only player to have featured in the Manchester, Merseyside and Old Firm derbies - is realistic enough to expect a hostile reception. "I remember going back to Old Trafford with Everton and it wasn't good. Now I am with City and I know the feelings these derbies provoke. But I am looking forward to it. So much has changed since I last played this game."

A lot may have changed but, as long as there are two clubs in Manchester, there will inevitably be schadenfreude .

A few weeks ago United fans hired a suite at Maine Road for a silver jubilee party marking the 25th anniversary since City last won a trophy. They were rumbled, eventually. Never slow to get their retaliation in, City supporters have been making inquiries about obtaining air space over Old Trafford this afternoon to fly a banner paying tribute to Bayern. Yet it must be difficult for any self-respecting Blue, knowing that after today the next side they face in red and white may well be Rotherham.

"Going down would be terrible for this club," says Kanchelskis. "Absolutely terrible." From the Theatre of Dreams to the stuff of nightmares - it is hardly worth contemplating.

"Going down would be terrible for this club," says Kanchelskis. "Absolutely terrible." From the Theatre of Dreams to the stuff of nightmares - it is hardly worth contemplating.

webTitle: Talbot bullish over Rushden's judgment day

fields.headline: Talbot bullish over Rushden's judgment day
fields.trailText: The Rushden manager is facing the biggest game of his career as the Conference's two horse-race reaches its climax.
fields.body:
"Look around you," says Brian Talbot, making no effort to hide the irritation in his voice. "Does this look like an unsuccessful club?"

Any visitor to Nene Park, home of Rushden and Diamonds Football Club, can only shake his head. In material terms, the £20m-plus spent by Max Griggs, the head of the Dr Marten's footwear empire, in establishing the young club in a superb stadium and sports complex in the Northamptonshire countryside has produced a marvellous return. The place reeks of money well spent but no one knows better than Talbot, the old Ipswich and Arsenal warrior, that football clubs are judged on one criteria alone.

Today as Rushden's manager he sends out his team to play the most important game of his four-year tenure. If they beat Yeovil at Huish Park, the Diamonds will be six points clear in the Conference with three games to play. The only team with a realistic chance of catching them are Yeovil, three points behind with a game in hand.

While the Conference, with the support of the FA, make an unanswerable case to increase the number of promotion places, change may be several seasons away, and having lost out in a similar two horse-race against Kidderminster last season, Talbot probably cannot afford to fail again.

While he rails against such a simplistic definition of success, he knows that is how the fans will see it. "It's a terrible shame; there's so much more to this football club than 3pm to 4.45pm on Saturday.

"So much has been built, so much developed. Look at the kids who are beginning to come through the youth system we've set up. Win the Conference or not, we won't need to bring in a single player over the summer.

"When I arrived they were seven points adrift of safety. We survived, and since then have finished fourth, fourth and second. Now it looks as though we'll finish top two again. I would say that's not a bad record.

"But others say all that money and they haven't won it. They don't realise that, money or not, it is difficult to attract good League players because there's still a stigma about non-league."

You don't doubt him for a moment, but football supporters are not renowned for objectivity. Talbot shrugs. "Whether we finish first or second I'm not going to be a different person, though some people will treat me differently; the same people who wanted me out at Christmas when Yeovil beat us here and looked to be running away with it. This is the wrong time to say it but there are far more important things in life."

An admirable perspective. Unfortunately for Talbot, it is unlikely to be shared by many of the record 9,000 crowd at Huish Park this afternoon.

webTitle: Boot deal kicks Beckham up rich list

fields.headline: Boot deal kicks Beckham up rich list
fields.trailText: Although dwarfed by the massive earnings of Lennox Lewis, the England captain's new contracts will bring untold wealth for a footballer.
fields.body:
This year's British sporting rich list is a tale of two superstars and one sportswear manufacturer. In money terms, this is the year that David Beckham finally began to arrive. Though ranked only fourth in the 2000 list - with barely a quarter of Lennox Lewis's earnings - in December last, Beckham and Adidas signed the biggest boot deal ever by a British player. Next summer that will surely be matched by the highest wage deal in British sport.

His rising status contrasts sharply with Naseem Hamed, who earned twice as much as Beckham during 2000, but has lost his Adidas deal and his last fight. Next year Beckham could well be earning twice his income.

Interest from the major shoe and boot companies acts as an acute barometer in the wealth stakes and it was in 1995 that Adidas took on Hamed, seeing in the publicity conscious young boxer an athlete at the cutting edge, who would enhance their profile in the coveted youth market. The deal, on a fight-by-fight basis, would last over five years. At the end of 1996, a year in which he made his first three defences of the WBO featherweight title (none went the distance), Adidas rated Hamed the brightest of their three stars; Tim Henman was second, Beckham third.

In the light of Hamed's defeat to Marco Antonio Barrera, Adidas's decision not to continue with Hamed looks almost prescient, but it did not take much of an insight to see that the boxer's marketing success story has foundered.

Alienation of large parts of the media has contributed, but Hamed's problem is that he has failed to live up to his own hype, rather than anyone else's.

Nobody need ask who is Adidas's main player now. Just two British sports stars rate 'global' status with the company; Beckham and Henman, the latter hardly short-changed with a contract that will bring him in excess of £750,000 during the current year. Beckham, though, is some way clear. For 2001, Adidas will pay around £1.25m for the services of the highest-profile star in Britain. It wasn't so long ago that people thought Reebok were mad to take on Robbie Fowler (now with Nike) at £300,000 a year.

Nor would it be unreasonable to suggest (as many have) that this summer Beckham's agents, SFX, could conclude a new deal with Manchester United that may hit the £5m-mark. Certainly the comparisons are there; Roy Keane's well-publicised £2.6m deal is one, and in December Ryan Giggs kicked off his new deal with the club, and that is surely worth even more.

Beckham may still take a few years to match Lennox Lewis, who has now figured in the British top 10 for every year since the lists were introduced into the Oddball Sports Yearbook in 1993, and who tops last year's list with £15.5m. Lewis has accumulated £;65m in fight and endorsement earnings since he took his first world title belt from a dustbin (courtesy of Riddick Bowe, who put it there).

The majority of Lewis's money has been earned in dollars, the US sports market having experienced sustained recent growth. Baseball and basketball are the wealthiest of the sports (and Britain's John Amaechi could be a beneficiary if his new deal with Orlando Magic goes through in August), but golf produces the world's biggest single earner, Tiger Woods, with estimated income of £35m for 2000, his £6m ($9m) in prize money dwarfed by his endorsement value. The Nike deal alone is estimated to be worth £66m ($100m) over five years.

Top 10 earners

Lennox Lewis Boxing £15.5m

Lewis has made it into the top 10 in eight straight years and this is his second successive year at No1. But the British-born, Canadian-educated, Jamaican resident knows that a fight with Tyson would fetch him more in one payday than he's made in his last six.

Naseem Hamed Boxing £7.5m

HBO television were not too happy when Hamed lined up the lowly-rated Augie Sanchez as the third match in his six-fight deal. Hamed won, but the WBO title was lost outside the ring.

Eddie Irvine Motor Racing £5.8m

Irvine parted with Ferrari for a deal with Jaguar estimated to be worth £15m over three years. For their money, the British team will want a large chunk of the Ulsterman, but Irvine is shrewd enough to generate a bit extra.

David Beckham Football £3.6m

With a new contract at Man Utd (or elsewhere?) likely in the close season and a new deal with adidas starting this year, Beckham's star is still rising, as is his income.

Michael Owen Football £3.5m

Owen, Beckham and Shearer are all managed by the SFX Group, which puts them in a powerful position. Owen's current Liverpool contract was negotiated after the last World Cup and, if he makes an impact in the next one, it could go through the roof.

David Coulthard Motor Racing £3.4m

Coulthard negotiated a new deal from the 2001 season which, with win bonuses, will see him top £4m. For 2000, though, even third in the championship will not have taken him that high.

Lee Westwood Golf £3.1m

After a dodgy start to the season, Westwood came good in style, topping the European lists with almost £2m in prize money. Endorsements are plentiful and the Worksop player has replaced Colin Montgomerie at the top of the pile in golf.

Steve McManaman Football £3.0m

After helping Real Madrid to win the European Cup, he fell out of favour last summer, but has since re-established himself and could be back for the final in May.

Alan Shearer Football £2.9m

Retirement from international football is bound to affect Shearer's future earnings, but 2000 was yet another profitable year for football's Mr Endorsement.

Tim Henman Tennis £2.8m

Endured seven straight ATP final defeats in 1999 and 2000 before he pulled it round at Vienna and Brighton. There is a very serious contribution from adidas, but the heavens would open and rain money if Henman ever won anything significant.

webTitle: Pompey in need of Rix quick fix

fields.headline: Pompey in need of Rix quick fix
fields.trailText: With Portsmouth only three points clear of the relegation zone Fratton Park is shrouded in gloom, but their struggling manager is still smiling despite the pressure.
fields.body:
When Graham Rix headed for the Wembley dressing-rooms in August, the idea that he would end the season fighting to keep Portsmouth in the First Division seemed laughable. Chelsea had just hammered Manchester United in the Charity Shield and it was Premiership titles the coach was dreaming of. "I walked off that pitch," Rix says, "thinking: 'This is the season we're going to push them to the limit'."

Instead Gianluca Vialli was sacked as manager five games later and by November Rix had followed. The journey from the superstars of SW6 to the struggles of Pompey has been difficult, but as Rix puffs a cigar at the training ground he insists he does not miss the old job.

"In a way I enjoy it more here," says the man whose coaching was crucial to Chelsea's success. "That's no disrespect to the Chelsea boys, but what am I going to teach [Gianfranco] Zola or [Marcel] Desailly? Not a lot. Here the players want to get better and there's been a great response."

With Pompey only three points clear of relegation, the table hardly shows that. But Rix, who inherited a similar situation from Steve Claridge two months ago, senses things are looking up. He talks of the ambition and potential which attracted him, and is delighted to be coaching.

If his dismissal by Chelsea was disappointing, the passages either side were more painful. Once Claudio Ranieri arrived, Rix would turn up for training and find himself redundant - "That was the toughest bit; I would put my kit on, sit on a ball and watch" - and going three months without work was even harder.

"That was the worst part of my life, and I've had a few bad parts," he says. "Not feeling wanted was hard, and all of a sudden not having a match to go to or a reason to get out on the training ground was tough. I was very, very unhappy.

"I was dying to get back into the game at whatever level, but nothing came up. I'm not naive enough to think it was anything to do with football. It was other things that were probably holding me back."

By "other things" Rix means the six-month prison sentence he served in 1999 for having sex with an under-age girl. The experience was tough but made him appreciate his work like never before.

"I learned not to take anything for granted," he says. "Every day I come in and work with the lads is a bonus. Every time I'm at a match and get that excitement before, during and after it's a bonus. It sorts out in your head what are the most important things in life."

In prison the 43-year-old was sent a huge poster which said "Keep Smiling". The message is dear to the Yorkshireman, as Pompey's players learned before his first game in charge. Having announced the team, Rix moved to his flip-chart.

"I turned the sheet over and there was a big smiley face on it," he says. "The lads couldn't believe it. They were expecting arrows pointing here and there and I just said: 'That's how I want you to play.'" Rix is smiling now, though life is not easy. Fulham at home today is followed by Blackburn away, and then come visits from Crystal Palace and Barnsley. Not even assisting Ruud Gullit and Vialli, with whom Rix speaks every week, prepared him for management.

"It's tough, Jesus Christ," he says. "I used to see Luca coming in every day stressed and think: 'What's he got to worry about?' But now I realise you've got to think of everyone and everything at the club 24 hours a day, from the chairman down to Kev the kitman.

"They've all got problems and they come to you. When I was assistant to Luca I would do my football and advise him, but when we were finished at training that was it. Now my phone can go any time of day or night, and people don't tend just to call for a chat."

fields.headline: Morton's hopes raised by offers
fields.trailText: Hopes are high that Morton Football Club will be saved from extinction after the club received at least two offers by a five o'clock deadline set by the administrators.
fields.body:
Hopes are high that Morton Football Club will be saved from extinction after the club received at least two offers by a five o'clock deadline set by the administrators.

A spokesperson for the administrators, however, declined to say whether the club's chances of survival had been improved by the receipt of the offers. "I cannot make any comment until we have the chance to review what has come in," said Liz MacKay, a manager at Kroll Buchler Phillips. "A statement will be issued over the next few days."

Any new owner would be required to take on a minimum debt of £200,000. Offers were invited for the club alone and the club and its dilapidated Cappielow stadium.

Uefa revealed yesterday that it is owed $11.8m (£8.2m) by the beleaguered sports marketing firm ISL Worldwide for a deal to market the Euro 2000 finals. The debt spells further problems for the company that is owned by the ISMM Group, which recently became bankrupt after analysts claimed that it had paid too much for the television rights to the 2002 and 2006 World Cup finals.

Mike Lee, the Uefa communications director, said that the money owed by ISL was for additional revenues generated by their deal to market Euro 2000 and that the basic terms of the contract had been fulfilled. Lee said the game's European governing body was taking steps to recover the debt from ISMM, which faces liquidation after being ordered to start bankruptcy proceedings by a court in Switzerland earlier this week.

"They owe us money and we would like that back," Lee said. "We are keeping an open mind [for the marketing rights deal] for Euro 2004. Clearly the ISL situation is not totally resolved."

Barcelona's Rivaldo, fresh from his disappointment at Anfield on Thursday night, has been dropped from his national squad.

The Brazil coach Emerson Leao has included only three foreign-based players for Wednesday's World Cup qualifier against Peru in Sao Paulo as he rings the changes after last month's embarrassing defeat in Ecuador.

fields.headline: El Tel left to eat his words
fields.trailText: The Diary takes no pleasure at all in revisiting some of the experts' predictions as the season reaches its climax, but then again...
fields.body:
It has come to that time of year when carping critics with a malicious cast of mind like to look back at predictions made before the start of the season and compare them with actual events since August. The Diary is in no such position, having tipped (among others) Bristol Rovers and Luton to fight it out in the Second Division play-offs. So we will take no pleasure at all in revisiting some of the experts' views over the last few weeks of the season.

First up, the Premiership relegation battle. "Ipswich will struggle because of their lack of financial clout," Mark Lawrenson pointed out. Terry Venables shared his view: "I expect Manchester City to stay up but I fear for Ipswich and Charlton," he boldly asserted. One team not in danger, he thought, was Middlesbrough. "There always seems to be a bit of grumbling from fans at the Riverside. I don't understand it - they're established in the Premiership. In Bryan Robson they have an outstanding manager and Steve Gibson is a great chairman. I am confident they will progress." Almost spooky.

Great European excuses No1, from the Galatasaray coach Mircea Lucescu after his side's 3-0 defeat in Madrid: "I think the referee was influenced by the atmosphere in the stadium." A totally new experience for the Istanbul club, then.

Great European excuses No2, from Barcelona's coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer: "We were the superior side and Barcelona's greatness does not depend on a single result." Not so much an excuse, more a denial.

Gerard Houllier should complain (well, he shouldn't, but that's another story). Ryman League Canvey Island played three league games this week - all won. Today they host Aldershot. On Monday it's the Essex Senior Cup final, then follow league games on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday, Sunday and Tuesday, all away, before the season ends with three in three days. If they win them all, they could be in the Conference. Or hospital.

It is traditional for managers to battle on while promotion or safety is still mathematically possible, but Danny Wilson seems determined to do so even after that. Asked on local radio whether Bristol City's play-off hopes had gone after Monday's home defeat by Wycombe, he inisisted: "There are still three games to go - we can get another 15 points."

Oh, go on then, just one more pre-season prediction from the men in the know. Here's Joe Royle on Man City's prospects: "We are going into the Premiership on a good basis and quite honestly in four years I think this club has got to be pushing for major honours. We are too big to go up and struggle. I'm not going to burden us with predictions but I don't see us as a struggling side. We're not trying to kid or con anybody that we are going to go straight to the top of this division . . . but then again, it wouldn't surprise me!" More uncanny forecasts next week (contributions welcome).

Terry Venables shared his view: "I expect Manchester City to stay up but I fear for Ipswich and Charlton," he boldly asserted. One team not in danger, he thought, was Middlesbrough. "There always seems to be a bit of grumbling from fans at the Riverside. I don't understand it - they're established in the Premiership. In Bryan Robson they have an outstanding manager and Steve Gibson is a great chairman. I am confident they will progress." Almost spooky. Great European excuses No1, from the Galatasaray coach Mircea Lucescu after his side's 3-0 defeat in Madrid: "I think the referee was influenced by the atmosphere in the stadium." A totally new experience for the Istanbul club, then. Great European excuses No2, from Barcelona's coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer: "We were the superior side and Barcelona's greatness does not depend on a single result." Not so much an excuse, more a denial. Gerard Houllier should complain (well, he shouldn't, but that's another story). Ryman League Canvey Island played three league games this week - all won. Today they host Aldershot. On Monday it's the Essex Senior Cup final, then follow league games on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday, Sunday and Tuesday, all away, before the season ends with three in three days. If they win them all, they could be in the Conference. Or hospital. It is traditional for managers to battle on while promotion or safety is still mathematically possible, but Danny Wilson seems determined to do so even after that. Asked on local radio whether Bristol City's play-off hopes had gone after Monday's home defeat by Wycombe, he inisisted: "There are still three games to go - we can get another 15 points." Oh, go on then, just one more pre-season prediction from the men in the know. Here's Joe Royle on Man City's prospects: "We are going into the Premiership on a good basis and quite honestly in four years I think this club has got to be pushing for major honours. We are too big to go up and struggle. I'm not going to burden us with predictions but I don't see us as a struggling side. We're not trying to kid or con anybody that we are going to go straight to the top of this division . . . but then again, it wouldn't surprise me!" More uncanny forecasts next week (contributions welcome). mike.ticher@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Grand ideas
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor finds out that it's frighteningly easy to blow £1,000 on a weekend, especially on the web.
fields.body:
Just how easy is it to blow £1,000 on a weekend? Well, since you ask it is frighteningly easy - especially on the web. But don't get any delusions of grandeur about flying first class. For example, an Upper Class return to New York on Virgin Atlantic typically costs just under £4,000. But a grand will buy you rooms in some of the world's most enjoyable hotels. Try visiting Luxury Hotels of the World for ideas.

Four days at the Four Seasons Hotel, New York
Those with plenty to spend should go straight to Unmissable.com: its holidays can cost as much as an obscene £166,000 (that's for the hire of a yacht to sail around Antigua). It makes £1,040 for a long weekend in New York look positively cheap. Flights are included, fortunately.

Three days' hire of Dundas Castle in Scotland
The castle actually costs £5,000 to hire in total, but assuming that you happen to have four or five equally wealthy friends available at the time, you should be able to club together without too much difficulty. A private staff together with a thousand-acre estate will be at your disposal.

Two nights at Le Manoir aux Quat'Saisons
With a superior room (£395 at the weekend) and two nights spent sampling the seven-course Menu Gourmand (£89) within your price range, you could take a partner to Raymond Blanc's two Michelin-starred Oxfordshire retreat for two nights and still have £32 left to put towards the cost of petrol.

A master suite at La Posta Vecchia, Rome
Current exchange rates mean that the room will set you back £767. Go has returns to Rome from £120, which leaves more than £100 to spend at Prada.

Three nights at the Grand Hotel Villa Serbellini, Lake Como, Italy
The price of a stay at this 18th-century hotel, with a private beach, two pools and a spa, varies between £855 and £980. It includes flights.

A night in the Coco Chanel suite at the Paris Ritz
A night in one of the Ritz's 10 "named apartments" costs at least Fr9,300 per night. (As well as Coco's, which overlooks the Place Vendme, there are rooms associated with the Duke of Windsor, Hemingway, and Proust.) That leaves you about £70 to spend on the Leisure Apex Return on Eurostar. Alternatively, you could stay at one of the Crillon's deluxe suites, which will cost about the same amount.

Two nights in Dubai
Flying to the United Arab Emirates takes about seven hours, and flynow.com has weekend returns in May for £410. The cheapest rooms at the Jumeirah Beach Hotel resort which resembles a 100-metre-high, 300 metre-long wave, cost £265 per night, leaving £60 to cover your bar bill.

Email Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Five Quarters of the Orange by Joanne Harris

fields.headline: Five Quarters of the Orange by Joanne Harris
fields.standfirst:
Doubleday, £12.99
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at a discount at BOL
fields.trailText: After Chocolat, a pick'n'mix of characters collaborate on a slightly darker small-town French confection
fields.body:
When my mother died she left the farm to Cassis, the wine cellar to Reine-Claude, and to me she left her recipe album and a truffle. As Cassis always said, I was the favourite. I am now widowed with two daughters, Noisette and Pistache, whom I barely see, while fat Cassis has a son, Yannick, who married Laure Dessanges, the food writer, and they own a restaurant in Angers.

My name is Framboise Dartigen, although no one knows my real name now I have returned to Les Laveuses on the banks of the Loire, where the story began. Here I am Francoise Simon. Get on with it, I hear you say, but bear with me as the style of the telling is as important as the story itself.

I was nine years old in 1942. Father had died in the war and Maman was unpredictable. "I can smell oranges," she would say and rage furiously as she disappeared to her room with a migraine. Cassis, Reine and I would then go to Angers, where we exchanged information with the Germans for sweets.

My creperie was a huge success. Yannick and Laure begged me for Maman's recipes. I refused, naturellement. Then a mobile burger bar opened opposite and my customers stopped coming.

I loved Tomas Leibniz. He never used the information we gave him and we all just had a lot of fun. One night he told us to meet him outside La Mauvaise Reputation, but things went wrong. Reine-Claude was raped and old Gustave was killed. We saw less of Tomas after that.

Old Paul found out that the burger man, Laure's brother, was seeing the gendarme's 15-year-old daughter. The burger bar soon rolled. "I'll go public unless you cooperate," shouted Laure, encore une fois. "You will be ruined."

Now we near the end. I was fishing for pike when Tomas pulled up. "Help me," I cried. He jumped in and drowned. Cassis pulled him out. "What shall we do?" he whimpered pathetically. "Shoot him with his pistol to make it look like the Resistance was involved."

His body was soon found, and 20 villagers were shot. Signs went up accusing us of collaborating, and our house was surrounded. "Oui, I was his whore," screamed Maman. "I needed pills for my headaches. I shot him."

There, the story is out. I am now a celebrity, and Noisette and Pistache are talking to me again.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested After Chocolat, a pick'n'mix of characters collaborate on a slightly darker small-town French confection

fields.trailText: Germany | Botswana | Cuba
fields.body:
Europe

Germany: Two-night breaks in Bach's home city of Leipzig cost £209 per person (based on two sharing) and are inclusive of return flights, rail transfers and three-star B&B accommodation through Moswin's Germany (0116 271 9922). A similar package to Dresden costs £219 per person.

Italy: Invitation to Tuscany (0121-429 5016) has five properties near Siena available from now until the end of May, sleeping from two to seven people with a shared swimming pool. The smallest house costs £258 per week until May 12, £375 until May 31; the largest £328 (£422). Price excludes flights.

Mediterranean: The Cruise Line (01273 835252) is offering a seven-night fly-cruise on the Crown odyssey, departing April 28, reduced from £1,250 to £669 per person. The cruise takes in Cannes, Civitavecchia, Sorrento, Valetta, Santorini and Athens. The package includes return flights, and transfers.

Africa

Botswana: Spend seven nights in the company of zebra, wildebeest and migratory birds in the Selinda Reserve between the Okavango Delta and Chobe National Park. The package through Aardvark Safaris (01980 849160) costs £1,495 per person in May (standard price £2,860). The price includes both international and internal flights, accommodation, all meals and activities and the services of a trained guide.

Kenya: Tropical Places (0800 0836662) has seven nights on the shores of the Indian ocean for £499 per person, for departures from either Gatwick or Manchester on April 22 and 29. The price includes accommodation, meals and a range of land and water sports.

Caribbean

Cuba: Seven nights' all-inclusive accommodation at the four-star Coralia Club Playa de Oro, 8km from Varadero, costs £399 per person through Distant Dreams (0870 2412400). The price includes return flights from Gatwick with Monarch Airlines, departing April 25.

Jamaica: Get fit at the four-star Swept Away resort and spa, which offers treatments such as body scrubs as well as yoga, kickboxing and body sculpting. The seven-night package through Caribbean Journeys (0870 709 3020) costs £1,299pp for departures between now and June 30.

North America

Canada: A three-night city break in Toronto costs from £316 per person (based on two sharing) through Travelbag (0870 7377860). The price includes return flights from Heathrow with British Airways and room-only, three-star hotel accommodation. For departures on April 26 and 27.

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.standfirst: Beyond Foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Beyond Foot and mouth.
fields.body:
Will the foot-and-mouth crisis prompt a stampede for foreign holidays this summer? The knee-jerk view among commentators is that a slump in domestic bookings means sold-out signs will soon be going up everywhere else. Don't panic. The idea that people deprived of fell walking in Cumbria are besieging travel agencies in pursuit of sun, sea and scorched skin on the Spanish Costas is patently absurd, as is the notion that last-minute discounts from tour operators will be in particularly short supply.

Britain's biggest tour operator, Thomson, still has around one million packages left to sell - about the same number available at this point last spring - and the firm says there is no evidence that the epidemic has produced a major upswing in business.

Logic suggests that if there is to be a significant beneficiary, it will be France. However, most operators specialising in French holidays say they have seen no major upsurge in business yet. One view is that people are waiting to see how the crisis develops here. This is corroborated by ferry operator Hoverspeed, which reports a sharp rise in last-minute bookings.

Owen Davies, marketing director of The Individual Travellers Company, which offers self-catering properties in France, Spain, Italy, Portugal and New England, reports an increase of around 10% in enquiries compared with this time last year. "France is definitely the leading contender but in general people are asking what there is to do in particular areas rather than committing themselves. We had a surge of last-minute interest from people trying to get away for Easter, and I suspect that if the foot-and-mouth crisis continues, the same could happen in June."

His firm has French properties still available for the school summer holidays in Normandy, Brittany, Charente and the Vendee and even some in the Dordogne.

With so many footpaths closed, increased demand for overseas walking holidays is inevitable. Frank McCready, managing director of Sherpa Expeditions, says: "Areas such as Tuscany and Umbria are filling very quickly. The easiest country for flights and accommodation at present is Switzerland."

However, Headwater says it has French walking packages available in Alsace, Creuse, Tarn and the Cevennes, and Richard Hearn, managing director of Inntravel, reports a surge of interest in French, Italian, Spanish and Norwegian walking holidays until the end of June, but says bookings remain at normal levels from July onward.

 A list of tour operators to France can be found at www.holidayfrance.org.uk.

webTitle: Portrait of a Man in Armour, Francesco Granacci (c1510)

fields.headline: Portrait of a Man in Armour, Francesco Granacci (c1510)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Attributed to Francesco Granacci (1469/70-1543). According to his friend and biographer Vasari, Granacci was glad to stand in the shadow of genius - of Michelangelo (1475-1564). Granacci and Michelangelo met as teenagers, and Granacci, "recognising, boy as he was, the great genius of Michelangelo. . . strove with incredible attention and humility to be always following that great brain, insomuch that Michelangelo was constrained to love him more than all his other friends".

Granacci and Michelangelo trained together under Ghirlandaio. Granacci stayed close to Michelangelo - even working briefly in the Sistine Chapel - and worked all his life in Florence.

Subject: The man in armour has not been identified; but this is also a depiction of someone who certainly can be identified, albeit as a tiny white figure in the background: Michelangelo's David.

Distinguishing features: This is a celebration of Florence, manhood and Michelangelo. The man in armour, gripping his sword to defend his city, is an embodiment of courage and readiness - positively phallic in his reduction to the hardness of armour and the sword across his crotch.

His armour is beautiful in its decorative, engraved lines. His face is sensitive and cultured, the beard finely trimmed, the eyes grave. He is a soldier for the city of the arts, whose symbolic heart, the Piazza della Signoria, is seen behind him. Here, men of importance debate politics and culture on the big coral-coloured grid of a square. The new Florentine republic, established after the downfall of the religious zealot Savonarola at the end of the 15th century, was a people's government, with a Grand Council of more than 3,000 men. It took the biblical giant-killer David as its hero and commissioned its most exciting young artist, Michelangelo, to make a colossal statue of him.

This was a major public event, and the committee responsible for deciding where to place the statue on its completion in 1504 included Leonardo and Botticelli. During the two days it took to move David - on wooden rollers - to the Piazza della Signoria, stones were thrown at it, probably by supporters of the Medici, who hated the Republic.

This painting is a portrait of a man embodying Florence and taking upon himself the martial qualities of David, whose statue stands guarding the Palazzo Vecchio. Standing in front of the Piazza - with David at his right arm - this man has taken on the qualities of the biblical hero: he is youthful, strong and wise. His cold, unyielding armour perhaps also evokes Michelangelo's marble - steel and stone protecting the Republic.

Inspirations and influences: War was relished in Renaissance Florence, and this portrait's taste for cold steel has antecedents that stretch from Uccello's ecstatic, hallucinatory painting The Battle of San Romano (1450-60) - which was commissioned by Cosimo de' Medici and is now in the National Gallery - with its robotic knights lightly hacking each other to pieces, to Leonardo's drawings of grotesque armour and designs for lethal war machines.

Where is it? National Gallery, Trafalgar Square, London WC2 (020-7747 2885).

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Scandinavia | Egypt | Dubai
fields.body:
Europe

Scandinavia: See the Midnight Sun on a three-night twin-centre break and cruise combination available through Short Breaks Direct (0870 7893338) between June 13 and August 31. The package, which includes return flight from Heathrow and B&B hotel accommodation in Copenhagen and Oslo, costs £399 per person

France: Explore the biggest beech forest in Europe as part of the "Spanish Border Trails" package available on August 18 and 25 through Pyrenees Adventures (01433 621498). The land-only price is £595 based on twin share, which includes seven nights' full board, refreshments and a programme of guided walks.

Turkey: Take in the International Istanbul Jazz Festival (July 4-18) with a three-night break available through Metak Holidays (020-7935 6961) The price per person based on twin share is £389 and includes return scheduled flights from Heathrow or Manchester, transfers and B&B accommodation.

Africa

Egypt: An eight-day tour including four-day Nile cruise, flights, tour guide and transfers costs from £1,220pp based on twin share through Trafalgar Tours (020-7574 7444). Package available until December

South Africa : Sardine fever hits the South African coast in June each year when the annual migration occurs. Feeding on the sardines are game fish such as shad, garrick, sharks and dolphin. The six-day Sardine Run & Dive package costs £798 per person (twin share B&B), and includes dives at Aliwal Shoal, Protea Banks & Mkambati. Flights not included. www.ifyoudive.com

Asia

Dubai: A five-night break at the five-star Le Meridien costs from £479 per person (based on twin share: one child under 12 sharing with parents qualifies for a 50% reduction) for departures between June 1 and September 15 through Just Dubai (020-7258 2001). The package includes Emirates flights from Gatwick, Heathrow, Birmingham and Manchester, and complimentary daily transfer to the hotel's beach resort and spa.

North America

Colorado: Cosmos America Reservations (020-8466 9661) is offering a 16-day tour of national parks and canyon country for departures in June from Heathrow (free connecting flights from selected UK airports) for £1,365pp. Highlights include the Black Hills, Mount Rushmore, Yellowstone, the Grand Canyon and Las Vegas.

fields.headline: Arpege, Paris
fields.trailText:
Telephone: 00 33 1 45 51 47 33
Address: 84 rue Varenne, Paris 7e
Rating: 15/20
fields.body:
Telephone: 00 33 1 45 51 47 33
Address: 84 rue Varenne, Paris 7e
Rating: 15/20

Monsieur Alain Passard, chef and proprietor of Arp¿ge, refined three- star gaff in Paris, recently garnered a lot of column inches in this country, and even more in France, by declaring that his menu was going vegetarian. He could no longer rely, he said, on the quality and provenance of meat products, and so out they would go from his kitchen. It is easy to understand such sentiments in Britain, ravaged by foot and mouth, BSE, E coli and the rest, but in France ..?

Anyway, a quick glance at the menu as I waited for Delphine suggested that M. Passard's conversion to the vegetarian cause had been slightly exaggerated. There were loads of vegetables, sure - leeks, red onions, potatoes and asparagus all had starring roles - but so, too, did sea urchins, scallops, lobsters, soles and pigeons. In fact, had I or Delphine been lured there by the exotic promise of three-star vegetarian menus, we would have been disappointed, because both the fixed-price lunch time menu (at Ffr690, or around £67) and the Menu D¿gustation (at Ffr1,400. Yes, that's right, Ffr1,400), had fish dishes on them. In fact, the big menu had at least three dishes - sea urchins, lobster and ravioli of leek with a fennel consomm¿ heavily pepped up with langoustine stock - that would not have found favour in certain quarters I know .

None of this would have mattered much to either Delphine or myself had the individual dishes been more interesting. No, I'll be fair. Out of eight dishes, three were outstanding: the ravioli of leek with the fennel/langoustine consomm¿ was compelling - pure, delicate and penetrating. There was an exquisite crisp tart of a blue cheese, Forme d'Ambert, with thin slices of winter pear laid on top - simple, clever, direct. And a version of gauffrette, a kind of waffle, of such ethereal lightness it was astonishing that it remained anchored to the plate.

But what of the rest of our dishes? At best, they were disappointing, at worst misconceived. What do you make of roasted lobster with red onions that, although cooked, still retain a savage degree of unrepentant rawness. It didn't help that the lobster had all the tenderness of a piece of Manila rope, but the onion was like a drunken yob shouting in church.

There was another dish of trumpeted vegetables splashed with a sauce of argon oil, this year's Gucci ingredient (ie, expensive and exotic), which, apparently, is made in Morocco from the stones of the fruit of the argon tree that have passed through the digestive tract of a goat. On this showing I am not sure that argon oil is going to be tomorrow's balsamic vinegar. Its subtle virtues did little to liven up a rather dull heap of mostly root veg, which, for some incomprehensible reason, had been liberally sprinkled with couscous.

It was as light as a thistledown, and about as exciting to eat. I could go on enumerating the shortcomings of dishes that weren't so much bad as just plain dull.

All in all, M. Passard is going to have to work a great deal harder at the vegetable alchemy to convince me, or Delphine for that matter, that leguminous lunching is any substitute for carnivorous consumption. His staff will have to work a sight harder, too. When you are paying Ffr1,400 for lunch, I think even I deserve better than unconsidered, sloppy, incompetence. I waited five minutes after I had sat down before someone asked whether or not I wanted a drink, another five minutes before I got a menu, although I was on my own at that point. Dishes were plonked down in front of us with little ceremony, the formal explanations cutting across our cheerful conversation. And, in spite of several attempts to encourage the front of house team to bring the bill, they continued in an irritating, languorous fashion. And when I tell you that said bill was Ffr3,000, including a bottle of not-too-bad burgundy at Ffr680 and two glasses of champagne, I expect to hear a sharp intake of breath (particularly from my expenses controller).

You may think that I have been generous in my marking, but a restaurant with three stars should rate 19, or thereabouts, out of 20. I could not have been happier to while away a lunch with Delphine. I just wish it had been somewhere with rather more charm and rather tastier food.

· Open Lunch, Mon-Fri, 12 noon-2.30pm; dinner, 7-11pm. Menus: Lunch, FFr690 for six courses; Menu D¿gustation, FFr1,400 for 10 courses. All major credit cards.

fields.headline: High society
fields.standfirst: It's close, but about as different from Europe as you can get.  Lisa Sykes walks through the High Atlas with Berbers and soaks up the atmosphere Marrakech's souks
fields.trailText: It's close, but about as different from Europe as you can get. Lisa Sykes walks through the High Atlas with Berbers and soaks up the atmosphere Marrakech's souks
fields.body:
The man chasing me is brandishing a big stick. He's dressed in a suit made of animal skins and has a blackened face topped by a helmet adorned with goat horns. When he gets close enough he roars and throws a bag of ash over me. A little girl scrambles, crying, on to the flat roof of her home. She is frightened of the man with the big stick. I know how she feels.

In the Berber villages of the Toubkal region in Morocco's High Atlas mountains, this unorthodox game of tag is the aftermath of the Tafaska - the feast of the lamb - which commemorates Abraham's sacrifice of a sheep in place of his son and is held 60 days after Ramadan. Sheep and goats are slaughtered for feasting, and the skins are stitched into suits, worn for four pungent days.

Just 24 hours after leaving London, I am dashing about the terraced fields of apple trees with the village boys and men who are old enough to know better. Even my guide, Mohammed Elaamri, also a Berber, thinks it's all a little strange. Above us in the village of Aremd, every rooftop and street corner is filled with people swaying, jigging, dancing, chanting, clapping or banging a tambourine-style drum. By dusk, the goat-skinned men - there are up to eight of them each day - are knackered. The game ends with the muezzin's wailing call to prayer echoing around the surrounding mountains.

Morocco has all the advantages of being just 14km from Gibraltar, at the tip of southern Spain. It's close, but as different from a European break as you could wish for. And there's no visa documents or health precautions to worry about.

My flight arrived in Marrakech at about 11pm. The airport is only 4km from the medina - the peach-walled old town - and by 11.30pm I was in a different world. A succession of strong-smelling alleyways snaked through the city leading, unikely though it seemed, to the door of my hotel, Riad Les Cigognes.

Moorish architecture looks inwards; behind anonymous doors and walls is a hidden world of tiled courtyards with flourishing citrus trees, palms, bougainvillaea and fountains. I was staying in a riad or maison d'hte , a kind of upmarket B&B. Old properties in the medina and the neighbouring kasbah, the fortified town, are being bought and restored, providing beautiful, peaceful and intimate accommodation in the heart of the city. There are usually fewer than six rooms and rates are very affordable - between £25 and £70 for a double room with breakfast.

My plan was to spend two days hiking in the High Atlas mountains, then return to explore Marrakech for an evening and morning before the flight home on Sunday afternoon.

Topping out at over 4,000 metres, the Toubkal is the country's highest massif, although I was only trekking at around the 2,000m. The treeline peters out at the village of Imlil at around 1,500m, where there's a clutch of small hotels, cafés and shops selling everything from Mars bars to guttering.

Imlil is an hour and a half by road from Marrakech, the last 20 minutes on a swaying mountain dirt track clinging to the contours. The villagers have voted not to have it paved as they like their semi-isolation at the head of the valley and are worried about being inundated by Moroccan tourists in their cars.

With my pack strapped to a mule, we walked for 45 minutes over the pass to Aremd, Considering this is the closest village to the country's highest mountain, it is surprisingly free of tourist trappings. The Gte d'Omar in Aremd can accommodate 20 or so people, several to a room. The facilities are basic, but there is a shower - cold water is free, hot water costs 10 dirhams (70p). Fatima, Omar's wife, and her daughter-in-law bake fresh bread daily and cook delicious tajines - meat and vegetable stews cooked in earthenware pots with conical lids.

On my first day of walking we climbed to the tizi (mountain pass) that gave us a spectacular view into the neighbouring Tacheddirt valley. Walking at a steady pace that still left me breathless on the steepest parts, we saw few other tourists. It was quiet in early March, the beginning of the season in the High Atlas, but the sun was already strong, burning my face before I realised it. In the late afternoons, the temperature began to fall, and by the evening I was wearing two fleeces, jacket, thermal underwear, hat and gloves.

Descending through the sweet-smelling pines and gnarled junipers we saw the summit of Toubkal in the distance, a faint triangular point against the blue sky. Below were well-kept terraces of fruit trees covered in spring blossom. Boulders and scree covered the valley floor, the aftermath of dangerous flash floods that had been caused by summer storms.

Later, the first star of the evening, the Etoile de berger or shepherd's star, rose in the sky and, on cue, dark blobs on the mountainside began moving across and down the slopes. The flocks were coming home.

Returning to Marrakech after two days in the mountains was a culture shock - the sheer numbers of people, the rapidly changing smells, sounds and sights, but I discovered that the trick is to go with the flow. Be prepared to wander; if you follow the crowds, sooner or later you will end up in the huge square that is Djemaa El Fna.

On Saturday nights, the medina seems to draw everyone in the city. Get your bearings over a glass of fresh orange juice from the stalls ringing the edges of the square. Then it's time to check out the entertainment. There is something for everyone; fire eaters and snake charmers, musicians, magicians and monkey tamers, storytellers and scribes. Café de France has the best terrace panoramique .

Marrakech has four distinct parts - the fortified kasbah, the medina, the Jew ish mellah, and Gueliz, the new part of town built by the French early in the last century. There are many historical monuments but with just a half-day of exploration open to me, I picked out a few places to visit. Bahia Palace has ornate plasterwork and painted ceilings that have survived the city's dry desert climate. A dynasty of sultans and their many wives are buried in opulence in the 16th-century Saadian tombs, the walls decorated with marble and gilded cedar wood. The serene Majorelle Gardens, now owned by Yves Saint Laurent, offer a shady retreat if the bustle of the medina gets too much.

Finally, I made for the souks, where there are more than 2,800 shops selling Berber jewellery, slippers, leather goods and carpets that can be "DHL-ed to your home". I even passed a shop selling thrones. I saw carpets being woven and wool being dyed using pomegranate and saffron. I learned that the leather of goats and gazelles is much better quality than sheep or camels.

I spent the flight home bemoaning what I had not had the time to do, such as having a henna design painted on my hands, paying a visit to a hammam (public bath), or riding a camel. But, of course, it gives me the perfect excuse to make a return trip.

Way to go

Lisa Sykes travelled with Tribes (01728 685971) and flew to Marrakech with Royal Air Maroc (020-7439 4361). Tribes can tailor-make trips to Marrakech and the High Atlas Mountains. A four-night trip with two nights' B&B at a riad and two nights' full board in Aremd, with transport, a mountain guide and a city guide costs £645pp including flights. A long weekend in Marrakech, without the trekking, is cheaper. Royal Air Maroc flies direct to Marrakech three times a week from Stansted and daily via Casablanca from Heathrow. Return fares from £280 including taxes.

In Marrakech, Riad Les Cigognes, (00 212 44 384791) has doubles from 400 dirhams (£26), including breakfast. There are three double rooms plus a suite with two doubles and a lounge. Dinner is available for a minimum of four people. Other riads include: Riad Kaiss (440141), Riad El Arsat (387567), Dar Mouassine (445287), Dar Zina (385242), Dar Sara (385858).

When to go

March to May and late September to November are the best times to visit; avoid July and August, when Marrakech is very hot, and in the winter when the High Atlas are covered in snow.

Reading

Visit www.booktailor.com where you can put together your own customised guidebook for Marrakech and the mountains, for under £20, choosing the best bits from guidebook publishers and travel writers. Morocco National Tourist Office (020-7437 0073).

Ultimate weekends

Dream tickets
The Ice Hotel in Lapland, shopping in Dubai, or perhaps touring Britain in an Aston Martin DB6. Charlotte Atkins suggests something a little more adventurous for the weekend

Game on
What are you up to this weekend? Follow our examples and you could make your free time go a lot further. Charles Burgess swaps his civvies for a safari suit

All in the best possible taste
A 12-course feast prepared by a chef who has been awarded three Michelin stars followed by bed in a five-star hotel. It doesn't get much better, does it? Mike Kiely indulges himself in Lombardy

Comfort zone
Katharine Viner dons regulation robe and slippers, and destresses in style in the Chilterns

Horse power
Fancy some sunny days at the races? Former jockey Thomas Rees recommends a spectacular new course on the Costa del Sol

Fatima, Omar's wife, and her daughter-in-law bake fresh bread daily and cook delicious tajines - meat and vegetable stews cooked in earthenware pots with conical lids. On my first day of walking we climbed to the tizi (mountain pass) that gave us a spectacular view into the neighbouring Tacheddirt valley. Walking at a steady pace that still left me breathless on the steepest parts, we saw few other tourists. It was quiet in early March, the beginning of the season in the High Atlas, but the sun was already strong, burning my face before I realised it. In the late afternoons, the temperature began to fall, and by the evening I was wearing two fleeces, jacket, thermal underwear, hat and gloves. Descending through the sweet-smelling pines and gnarled junipers we saw the summit of Toubkal in the distance, a faint triangular point against the blue sky. Below were well-kept terraces of fruit trees covered in spring blossom. Boulders and scree covered the valley floor, the aftermath of dangerous flash floods that had been caused by summer storms. Later, the first star of the evening, the Etoile de berger or shepherd's star, rose in the sky and, on cue, dark blobs on the mountainside began moving across and down the slopes. The flocks were coming home. Returning to Marrakech after two days in the mountains was a culture shock - the sheer numbers of people, the rapidly changing smells, sounds and sights, but I discovered that the trick is to go with the flow. Be prepared to wander; if you follow the crowds, sooner or later you will end up in the huge square that is Djemaa El Fna. On Saturday nights, the medina seems to draw everyone in the city. Get your bearings over a glass of fresh orange juice from the stalls ringing the edges of the square. Then it's time to check out the entertainment. There is something for everyone; fire eaters and snake charmers, musicians, magicians and monkey tamers, storytellers and scribes. Café de France has the best terrace panoramique . Marrakech has four distinct parts - the fortified kasbah, the medina, the Jew ish mellah, and Gueliz, the new part of town built by the French early in the last century. There are many historical monuments but with just a half-day of exploration open to me, I picked out a few places to visit. Bahia Palace has ornate plasterwork and painted ceilings that have survived the city's dry desert climate. A dynasty of sultans and their many wives are buried in opulence in the 16th-century Saadian tombs, the walls decorated with marble and gilded cedar wood. The serene Majorelle Gardens, now owned by Yves Saint Laurent, offer a shady retreat if the bustle of the medina gets too much. Finally, I made for the souks, where there are more than 2,800 shops selling Berber jewellery, slippers, leather goods and carpets that can be "DHL-ed to your home". I even passed a shop selling thrones. I saw carpets being woven and wool being dyed using pomegranate and saffron. I learned that the leather of goats and gazelles is much better quality than sheep or camels. I spent the flight home bemoaning what I had not had the time to do, such as having a henna design painted on my hands, paying a visit to a hammam (public bath), or riding a camel. But, of course, it gives me the perfect excuse to make a return trip. Way to go Lisa Sykes travelled with Tribes (01728 685971) and flew to Marrakech with Royal Air Maroc (020-7439 4361). Tribes can tailor-make trips to Marrakech and the High Atlas Mountains. A four-night trip with two nights' B&B at a riad and two nights' full board in Aremd, with transport, a mountain guide and a city guide costs £645pp including flights. A long weekend in Marrakech, without the trekking, is cheaper. Royal Air Maroc flies direct to Marrakech three times a week from Stansted and daily via Casablanca from Heathrow. Return fares from £280 including taxes. In Marrakech, Riad Les Cigognes, (00 212 44 384791) has doubles from 400 dirhams (£26), including breakfast. There are three double rooms plus a suite with two doubles and a lounge. Dinner is available for a minimum of four people. Other riads include: Riad Kaiss (440141), Riad El Arsat (387567), Dar Mouassine (445287), Dar Zina (385242), Dar Sara (385858). When to go March to May and late September to November are the best times to visit; avoid July and August, when Marrakech is very hot, and in the winter when the High Atlas are covered in snow.
