fields.headline: This month
fields.standfirst: The greenest shoots, the tiniest Jerseys, the coolest mint, the broadest beans, the nippiest lobster, the shiniest mackerel, the gamiest duck. Oh and don't forget the rhubarb. Nigel Slater picks what's fresh for spring
fields.trailText: The greenest shoots, the tiniest Jerseys, the coolest mint, the broadest beans, the nippiest lobster, the shiniest mackerel, the gamiest duck. Oh and don't forget the rhubarb. Nigel Slater picks what's fresh for spring
fields.body:
Suddenly there is a new energy. Paper bundles of English asparagus, so fresh and perky they could be still growing, have replaced the boxes of wizened roots at the greengrocers. Brussels sprouts have stunk their last until next Christmas. Great green shoots of purple sprouting broccoli are the hippest veg right now. Treat them as you would asparagus and don't even think of using a fork. This is what we mean now when we talk about finger food. Get everything into boiling water as quick as you can, asparagus and purple sprouting wait for no one.

Learn to make the perfect hollandaise, you'll need it for dunking all the season's green shoots and for the wild salmon too. But if beating egg yolks and butter over hot water till thick enough to stand on the end of your asparagus sounds like too much work, try this instead; while your vegetables boil in deep, salted water, finely grate hard pecorino or Parmesan onto warm plates. You'll need a small mound on each. Drain the purple sprouting and asparagus, then lay them tenderly on the plates. Remember how fragile those tips are. Shower them with fruity, emerald olive oil(this is the time to use the expensive stuff) then gently turn the shoots over in the oil and cheese. Squeeze a lemon over and eat.

The tiny Jersey potato, barely bigger than a jelly bean has come to save us from another month of baked and mash. Go for the smallest. anything larger than a pebble will need scraping. Push off the loose skins with your thumb, give them a decent scrubbing then wrap them in baking parchment with a sprig or three of mint and a spray of mineral water. Bake them at 200°c/Gas 6 till they will take the point of a knife. Tear the paper apart and breathe in pure earthy potato and cool mint. Spear your potatoes on your fork and dunk them in crème fraîche, or better, put pots of thick, live sheep's yoghurt on the table instead. Its smart flavour flatters rather than smothers.

Italian green produce, a month or more ahead of ours, is irresistible. The broad beans the size of a baby's thumbnail and baby peas can be boiled briefly, then scattered over soft, milky ricotta and drizzled with olive oil and torn mint leaves. I have had this as a light supper twice recently, scooping up the cheese and beans with hunks of warm and fluffy ciabatta. The oil was Wolfango Jezek's startlingly grassy U Trappitu - and the intenso pressing at that - from esperya.com. An oil so emphatically lush I reserve it for dipping my bread, yet the warmth from the freshly cooked little beans made it even more creamy and grassy. You could throw the little beans in a salad too, perhaps one with Little Gem and a lemony dressing.

Wild salmon should be the fish of the month. But seriously, who can afford it? We have a choice: either inhale deeply and shell out now or wait a few weeks and hope the price comes within reach. We must get our fill, though. The April to August season is all too short. Crab is in fine shape right now: try it with cucumber sliced so thinly you could read this paper through it, and a dressing of very light olive oil, coriander and lime juice. Be delicate with the juicy white flesh, chopping the herbs finely and meticulously shaving the cucumber. Look out too for crawfish, salmon trout, lobster and mackerel.

Meat eaters look forward to the pale flesh and crisp white fat of jelly-textured spring lamb, but it has never done it for me. It is fine line between delicate and insipid and the first lamb of the season crosses the line. Why not wait till later in the season, when this meat has a denser grain and actually has something to say.

Chicken is in good supply right now, and organic free-range birds are getting easier to track down. But chicken is far from the only bird. It is tempting to leave cooking duck to restaurants. Their repertoire: the time-honoured caneton a l'orange; the perennially popular Peking roast with plum sauce and pancakes and the gooey French confit is something better left to professional hands. (It must be said they can also get it wrong. Restaurants are the sole perpetrators of the disgusting, tepid fan of almost-raw duck breast and its accompanying mange tout garnish.) Where we home cooks excel is in a good old-fashioned roast duck, properly cooked and stuffed with sage and onion. Okay, the smell lingers a bit, but the juicy, verging-on-the-gamey meat is worth it. Forget everything you have ever read about this bird being served rare. This is one meat that only tastes of anything when its flesh is brown and its flesh crisp. Treat it as the feast it is and offer up a whole bird between two.

And don't forget to save the fat (I pour some of it off as the bird is cooking) for roasting potatoes. So good are they that last Wednesday I sat down to a supper of nothing more than potatoes roasted in duck fat and a bowl of green salad. The crucial bit was being generous with the salt on the hot, sticky potatoes and the fact that the salad was full of hot rocket - currently from Italy but the British crop will be along soon - and juicy, crunchy Little Gem lettuces.

Outdoor-grown rhubarb is the only indigenous fruit till the gooseberries and very early strawberries show their faces next month. We can, and should, make a crumble. If only to remind ourselves of just how well this sharp fruit marries with the sweet butter, flour and sugar topping. Bake a rhubarb cake to eat warm with thick yellow cream. Or roast the stalks, cut into stubby lengths, in orange juice and a little sugar. You will open the oven after half an hour and find melting rhubarb and copious crimson juice. Eat hot with warm sponge cake or madeleines or eat thoroughly chilled aside a little mound of equal quantities of thick yoghurt and whipped cream.

Rhubarb apart, this is a dodgy time for pudding lovers. Too warm for spotted dick, too early for strawberries. Now is the time to dig out classic recipes for forgotten puddings such as treacle tart, Eve's pudding, lemon Meringue pie and Bakewell tart. Best recipes are probably in your mother's battered Constance Spry. My money is on rice pudding. Make it by simmering 100g short-grain rice to 500ml water, 500ml milk and 50g sugar(I really think the fashion for using double cream here is quite unneccesary) till the rice is puffed and tender. Shake over a little rosewater and the finely ground seeds of 3 or 4 green cardamons while it is still simmering. Then cool and tuck in to the scented, creamy, soporific grains. A quiet and reflective moment in a month of renewed, raw energy.

webTitle: OFM five of the best: Chicken

fields.headline: Nigel Slater's  fast food
fields.standfirst: 30-minute recipes: this month chicken
fields.trailText: 30-minute recipes: this month chicken
fields.body:
Mozzarella chicken with pesto

I have given two methods for the same dish. The first gives a neater result, while the second, which I think the more interesting, is not for the fainthearted. It includes turning the chicken over in the pan so that the cheese topping melts into the pan juices, resulting in a deeply savoury finish. For 2, as a main dish with salad.

2 large boneless chicken breasts

50g butter

100g mozzarella cheese, cut into 5mm slices

2 tbsps groundnut or vegetable oil

3 tbsps pesto from the jar

freshly ground black pepper

Cut each breast in half lengthways and flatten with a rolling pin between two sheets of clingfilm, until they are 5mm thick. Be gentle, you don't want a purée. Cook the chicken in the melted butter and oil in a shallow pan for 1-2 minutes on each side.

Without removing the chicken from the pan, spread each piece with a tablespoon pesto sauce, place a slice of mozzarella on top of the pesto and sprinkle with pepper. Now, EITHER: pick up the chicken with a fish slice and place it in a grill pan. Flash under a preheated hot grill till the mozzarella melts. Add the remaining pesto to the pan with 2 tablespoons water and stir.

Remove the chicken from the grill and pour over the pan juices, OR: turn the chicken over with a palette knife so that the cheese is on the bottom. As soon as it starts to melt and sizzle, scoop each piece up with a fish slice, making sure that the melted cheese is not left behind. Turn the chicken over, the cheese and pesto now tantalisingly melted, and place in a warm serving dish, easing the cheese from the slice with a palette knife. Add the remaining pesto and 2 tbsps water to the pan, in which some of the pesto and cheese will be left behind, and stir, scraping up all the crusty bits in the pan. Pour the pesto pan juices over the chicken and eat immediately.

Chilli chicken pitta

A wonderful snack, spicy and substantial, of chicken pieces with chilli, dribbled with mint-flecked yoghurt, then stuffed into Middle Eastern pitta bread. Don't be put off by the long list of ingredients, you will probably have most of them.
For 2 pittas

1 small onion or 4 spring onions, chopped

4 cloves of garlic, crushed

3 tbsps groundnut oil

juice of 1 lemon

1/2 tsp salt

1 tbsp runny honey

1 tsp paprika

? tsp mild chilli powder

1 small fresh red chilli pepper, seeded and finely chopped

225g boneless chicken

For the sauce

6 tablespoons plain natural yoghurt

1 tbsp chopped fresh mint

1 tsp paprika

2 spring onions, trimmed and chopped

crisp lettuce and hot pitta bread or baps, to serve

Mix together the onion, garlic, oil and lemon juice. Add the salt, honey, paprika and chilli, dried and fresh. Cut the chicken into lumps about 2.5cm square, and stir into the above ingredients. Leave as long as you can, but at least for 20 minutes. Mix the ingredients for the yoghurt sauce.

Heat the grill, which should be red hot. Scatter the chicken over the grill pan and cook till the pieces are crisp and shining golden brown on the outside, yet still juicy within - about 8 minutes, turning once. Cram the lumps of chicken into hot pitta bread with the spiced yoghurt and some shredded crisp lettuce.

Chicken with spices and cream

Nothing raises purist eyebrows quite like the mention of curry powder. I will say in its defence that I have eaten some delicious meals where the main dish was spiced with a commercially-blended powder. I prefer to toast and grind my own spices but when short of time I use a 'proprietary' powder, then add a few spices of my own. For 4

4 chicken pieces, breasts or thighs

salt

freshly ground black pepper

25g butter

1 tbsp groundnut oil

2 medium onions, roughly chopped

3 plump cloves of garlic, crushed

2 tbsps curry powder, from a recently-opened tin

1/2 tsp ground cinnamon

4 medium tomatoes, seeded and chopped

250ml chicken stock

100ml double cream

juice of 1/2 lemon

Rub salt and pepper into the chicken. Heat the butter and oil in a shallow pan, add the chicken and cook till the skin is golden. Add the onions and garlic and cook over a medium heat until soft, about 7 or 8 minutes.

Stir in the curry powder and cinnamon. Cook for 4 minutes until the spices are cooked. Add the tomatoes and the stock, then simmer until the chicken pieces are tender and cooked right through, about 15 minutes.

Stir in the cream. Taste the sauce. Add salt and pepper and the lemon juice, a little at a time, tasting as you go. Simmer for 1 minute, then serve hot, with basmati rice.

Chicken with orange and black olives

This simple supper uses kitchen staples to brighten up a plate of chicken pieces. Use any cut of chicken you like, though I have also tried this recipe with duck breasts and found it even better. Sautéing the chicken pieces till golden brown before adding the stock is essential to the flavour and character of the dish. It looks smart served on a plain white plate with a deep rim. For 2

2 tbsps olive oil

50g butter

2 whole chicken legs

225ml chicken stock

1 tsp dried thyme leaves

12 black olives, stoned

1 orange, cut in half then into thin slices

1 tbsp freshly chopped parsley

salt

freshly ground black pepper

Heat the oil and half the butter in a shallow pan. Brown the chicken pieces on both sides, then add the chicken stock. Stir in the thyme, olives and the orange slices. Cover and simmer gently for 20 minutes.

Check that the chicken is cooked - when pierced with the point of a knife the juices should run clear - then remove the pieces to a warm serving plate. Taste the sauce, add the parsley and season it with pepper, and very carefully, if at all, with salt. Turn up the heat, reduce the liquid by bubbling down to 150ml, then whisk in the remaining butter. The sauce will be shiny and slightly thickened when it is ready. Plate the chicken pieces and pour over the sauce. Serve with a starchy accessory, such as wide noodles or steamed potatoes.

Chicken with watercress and mushroom sandwich

Slice a boneless chicken breast into thin strips about 1cm wide. Season with salt and pepper and sauté in butter in a frying pan. Remove the chicken when it starts to brown, after about one minute, and set aside to keep warm. (On a plate with a glass bowl on top will do.) Add a little more butter or a drop more oil to the pan, then cook a handful of sliced mushrooms until softened, about 2 minutes. Lift them out with a draining spoon and add to the chicken. Soften a few shredded lettuce or watercress leaves and stems in the butter left in the pan, lift them out and stir in a couple of tablespoons of mayonnaise. Spread two soft baps or crusty rolls, split and toasted, with the mayonnaise and then pile on the chicken, mushrooms and leaves.

fields.headline: r.town Narita trolley bag
fields.trailText:
There's no shortage of carry-on luggage bags with wheels that are strong, attractive and practical, but many of them are very heavy. Is there anything that is light and durable?
The mechanics of producing a bag with a retractable handle and wheels often results in a heavy metal framework, but for short business or weekend trips try the r.town Narita hand-luggage size trolley bag. It weighs only 2.5 kilos and has wheels and a retractable handle.
fields.body:
There's no shortage of carry-on luggage bags with wheels that are strong, attractive and practical, but many of them are very heavy. Is there anything that is light and durable?
The mechanics of producing a bag with a retractable handle and wheels often results in a heavy metal framework, but for short business or weekend trips try the r.town Narita hand-luggage size trolley bag. It weighs only 2.5 kilos and has wheels and a retractable handle.

If it's so light, is it durable enough to handle the rigours of travel?
It's made out of 100% rip-stop nylon and is tear-proof and waterproof. It has handles on two sides, zip-up compartments and interior mesh pockets.

What is r.town?
It stands for "our" town, a French company specialising in urban travel accessories that are fashionable and practical. That's why many of the travel bags are named after city airports.

How big is the trolley bag?
Height: 54cm, width 34cm, depth 23cm, and 99cm long with the handle extended. Two other bags, the Schiphol £35 and Linate £25 can be attached to the trolley bag. The Narita trolley bag costs £60.

Where do I get it?
For stockists, tel: 0116 2440880, or visit www.r-town.com.

fields.headline: Passion play
fields.standfirst: Adrian mole, aged 34
fields.trailText: Pamela gave an erotic Easter egg, the centre of which contained a pair of edible knickers. She was keen for me to break it open and retrieve them.
fields.body:
Friday, April 13, Good Friday

Why do banks close on bank holidays? They should be open when so many are free to use them. I wished to query a statement saying I had spent £104.49 on Belgian chocolates at a shop in Lewes, so rang a call centre in Southend. I told a youth called Gary that I never bought chocolate due to the effect it has on my skin, and had never been to Lewes.

He said, "Perhaps it was an internet transaction." I repeated testily that I could not tolerate chocolate. He said, "Perhaps you bought it for someone else - it is Easter." I said angrily, "I am a poor man: £104.49 exceeds my weekly income." He snapped, "The standing order to your newsagent could keep an African village in food for a month." At this moment, Glenn shouted from the toilet that there was no paper. I put Gary on hold. When I came back, Greensleeves was playing, so I went to my bank, only to find the doors locked.

Glenn was miserable all day. He asked if he could paint his bedroom black. When I asked what was wrong, he said, " Why do they call it Good Friday? It weren't for poor Jesus, were it?"

He explained that he had trodden on a drawing pin this morning: "It brung it 'ome to me what it must 'ave been like on the cross." He then asked if he could have a Heroes Easter egg. William's egg of choice is Barbie. Worrying.

Saturday, April 14

Had an email from Hamish Mancini: "Yo, Adi, I'm FedExing a 100lb bag of Idaho's finest potatoes, because you don't got none in England, cos of the floods and plagues. We are praying for you and your family."

Sunday, April 15, Easter Day

Pamela came round with an egg-decorating kit. William's eggs were a riot of primary colours; Glenn's depicted Jesus on the cross. He wrote a bubble out of Jesus's mouth, "Father, why hast thou forsaken me?", which disturbed Pamela: "For God's sake, Glenn lighten up. It's Easter!"

Later, while William played with the packing of his Barbie egg and Glenn watched The Greatest Story Ever Told, she led me to my room and gave an erotic Easter egg, the centre of which contained a pair of edible knickers. She was keen for me to break it open and retrieve them. I was less keen: a glance at the ingredients told me they were choc-a-bloc with obscure chemicals and multisyllable flavourings.

fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: www.avro.co.uk
fields.trailText: www.avro.co.uk.
fields.body:
Why do you always assume that everyone wants to fly from a London airport?

Several readers have asked me this. No excuse, I'm afraid. None at all, particularly given that rail travel is so difficult. Hold on. I'm trying to make amends this week. Avro, which launched its website last week, specialises in flights from regional airports to the Mediterranean.

Charter flights?

Yes, but they claim that the majority of departures are during the day. Flights leave from Leeds Bradford, Newcastle, East Midlands. Glasgow, Cardiff, Birmingham, Manchester and Bristol for the Canaries, southern Spain, Greece, Crete and Mallorca. Most use Monarch Airlines.

In other words, it's aimed at filling the seats that package tour operators haven't sold?

webTitle: Sharp rise in unfilled teacher posts

fields.headline: Sharp rise in unfilled teacher posts
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Teachers' leaders yesterday accused the government of painting a "false picture" of the extent of teacher shortages, after new figures showed a steep rise in the number of empty posts over the past year.
fields.body:
Teachers' leaders yesterday accused the government of painting a "false picture" of the extent of teacher shortages, after new figures showed a steep rise in the number of empty posts over the past year.

Department for Education statistics showed that the number of permanent teachers in England rose by 5,600 over the past 12 months, to 410,300 in January 2001. Overall, there were 11,000 more teachers working in state schools than in May 1997.

But the number of jobs lying empty sharply increased: the rise in new posts meant that vacancies rose from 1,450 to 2,110 in primary schools and from 1,290 to 2,580 in secondary schools. Overall, this represents an increase of 75% in unfilled jobs. At the same time, the number of supply teachers working in schools increased.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, said: "Today's figures from schools and education authorities show a rather more rounded picture than the one-sided presentation we have had in recent months. They indicate that the extra money, including the first year of direct funding, has enabled schools to create around 7,700 more teaching posts than they had last year."

But teachers' leaders said the government was being complacent about the problems. Members of the National Union of Teachers and the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers have taken industrial action over the shortages, with their members refusing to cover for vacancies.

The action is likely to be formally suspended next week when leaders start negotiations with the government and employers over workload.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, said at the close of its annual conference in Jersey: "This shows a dramatic increase of 75% in teacher shortages. The false picture the government continues to try to portray is based upon a hopelessly one-sided view of the problems, looking at vacancy rates only from the supply side. It completely ignores all of the huge additional demands made upon the system which requires thousands and thousands of extra teachers, so we do have a genuinely massive shortage."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads' Association, said: "Headteachers have had to work miracles in order to find teachers to put in front of classes. The present gap between supply and demand has been caused by the year-on-year failure to meet teacher training and meet recruitment targets."

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said: "This is yet more spin from the government. Schools have got vacancies because they cannot get teachers."

The Liberal Democrat education spokesman, Phil Willis, said: "How can the government talk about raising numeracy standards when the vacancy rates for maths teachers has increased five-fold under Labour?

Professor John Howson, of Education Data Surveys, said: "The government's mismanagement of the teacher supply process, leaving more than 12,000 places empty on secondary training courses and not training enough primary teachers in London and the south-east, are the root causes of a problem that was waiting to happen as soon as schools were given more money."

webTitle: Unions hail cut in Ofsted checks

fields.headline: Unions hail cut in Ofsted checks
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Ofsted inspections of schools could be reduced to just once every 10 years, it emerged yesterday, as part of a radical shake-up being planned by the education watchdog.
fields.body:
Ofsted inspections of schools could be reduced to just once every 10 years, it emerged yesterday, as part of a radical shake-up being planned by the education watchdog.

The second largest teaching union, the National Union of School Masters Union of Women Teachers, heard at its annual conference in Jersey yesterday that the change was "on the cards" as a result of a consultation between the office for standards in education and teachers' representatives.

Signalling a new era of cooperation with Ofsted - and in particular with the new chief inspector of schools, Mike Tomlinson - the NASUWT's outgoing president, Martin Johnson, told delegates that "salvation" was in sight.

Speakers had described how teachers' lives had been ruined by the stress and trauma of regular Ofsted inspections.

Most schools face inspection every six years, or every four when they cause concern.

A motion drawn up nearly a year ago - before the departure of Chris Woodhead, the controversial former inspector, last November - recommended industrial action pending "fundamental reform" negotiated with the NASUWT.

But yesterday Mr Johnson told delegates any protest must be ruled out because of the changes signalled by Mr Tomlinson, who took over from Mr Woodhead in a one-year appointment.

A consultation document is expected to be published after the general election. Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, welcomed the new spirit of cooperation.

"Mike Tomlinson has brought a positive attitude to the job," he said. "Chris Woodhead would have his feet up on the desk and tell you to 'push off'. His body language was openly insulting."

A spokeswoman for Ofsted said: "We are preparing a consultation document but have made no decisions on the length of inspection cycles."

 A 16-year old boy who lost a high court attempt to force his teachers to teach him was yesterday given the right to appeal.

The boy's mother took the NASUWT to court after staff refused to teach him because of alleged disruptive and violent behaviour.

webTitle: New TB outbreak hits Welsh school

fields.headline: New TB outbreak hits Welsh school
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A further outbreak of TB emerged yesterday when it was revealed that eight pupils at a school in South Wales had been infected. The children, all between 14 and 15, are pupils at Duffryn high school, Newport. The source of the outbreak is not known.
fields.body:
A further outbreak of TB emerged yesterday when it was revealed that eight pupils at a school in South Wales had been infected. The children, all between 14 and 15, are pupils at Duffryn high school, Newport. The source of the outbreak is not known.

An initial outbreak in Leicester has resulted in more than 50 people being diagnosed with the disease. Earlier this week, public health officials confirmed that there had been 18 new cases.

The Newport school headmaster, David Snashall, said the disease was initially diagnosed in one pupil in year 10. The whole year was screened and seven other pupils were found to have contracted the disease. Gwent health authority is to carry out a mass screening programme among the 1,100 pupils at the school.

Mr Snashall said: "The school will remain open as normal. The chances of cross-infection now are extremely low."

Dr Eddie Coyle, the director of public health at Gwent health authority, said infections between children were unusual. He also assured parents that the illness could be effectively treated with antibiotics.

The screening programme at the school was to be extended as a precautionary measure.

"Letters have been sent to parents of all pupils at the school offering screening and giving advice and information about this condition," he said.

The NHS trust is to resume a comprehensive programme of BCG vaccination to protect against TB in all secondary schools in the area from September.

A nationwide shortage of vaccine led to routine immunisation programmes against the illness being shelved during 1999/2000. However, immunisation has been available for "at risk" and "contact" groups.

The Welsh cases emerged on the same day that health managers in Gloucestershire said 1,300 former hospital patients are to be tested for TB after a nurse contracted the infectious disease.

Officials at Cheltenham general hospital said that although the chances of the nurse passing on the disease were rare, they were taking precautionary measures to protect patients.

Most of the Leicester cases have connections with Crown Hills community college in the Evington area of the city. Forty students have also shown early signs of TB and have been put on antibiotics, Leicestershire health authority said this week.

The outbreaks could be the biggest in the UK since the disease was brought under control in the 1980s. The Leicester outbreak began when one child developed TB last August and it is suspected that the disease was contracted while the child was travelling in India where the disease is endemic.

webTitle: Rise of the wealthy Oxford scientists

fields.headline: Rise of the wealthy Oxford scientists
fields.standfirst:
University boasts 30 multimillionaires as dons see benefits of exploiting their own breakthroughs

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: University boasts 30 multimillionaires as dons see benefits of exploiting their own breakthroughs.
fields.body:
A new breed of academic is joining the ranks of the super-rich as universities embrace the commercial benefits of going into business. More than 30 of Oxford University's dons are now multimillionaires and rival academic institutions are gearing up to follow suit.

Professors Alan and Susan Kingsman, a husband and wife team of biochemists, are thought to be Oxford's wealthiest academics in business. They hold more than 18.8m shares in Oxford BioMedica, a biotechnology group they founded which specialises in the use of genetics to fight disease. Their holding is worth more than £10m.

While many dons have fortunes on paper, thanks to the boom in biotechnology stocks last year, some have cashed in their stakes in the firms they launched.

Stephen Davies, professor of organic chemistry, made more than £5m last year when he sold shares in Oxford Asymmetry, a chemical services company.

Oxford has a share in more than 32 companies which were founded to profit from ideas by academics. Their value is estimated at £1.4bn.

The government is encouraging academics to turn entrepreneur. Ministers are keen for enterprise to become the "third arm" of university activity alongside teaching and research.

Academics are equally keen not to see their research being exploited by others; one example being the development of penicillin by Oxford and its subsequent patenting by an American company. But there is also concern that the purity of research will be compromised.

Universities have set up dedicated departments, in some cases split off as wholly owned companies, to attract research funding from commerce, find buyers for academics' inventions and help scientists set up their own ventures.

Dr Bob Smailes, of Edinburgh Research and Innovation, said: "It would be fair to say there's a mixture of views. The overall reception has been very positive. When academic colleagues see positive results of effective exploitation this is the best selling point for others."

Secrecy

But there is concern about the restrictions companies seek to place on their work. Openness is a central tenet of science, which advances by academics building on the work of their peers. Secrecy is the City's watchword; protecting commercially sensitive information is crucial to fighting off competitors.

Universities also fight to keep intellectual property rights, which companies routinely seek to have granted to them. The institutions prefer to grant licences for a particular use of their invention, reserving the right to revoke them if a company fails to exploit their idea effectively.

Some universities' commercial directors look with envy at the US, where the 1980 Bayh-Dole Act protects the intellectual property rights of universities and bars firms from placing restrictions on the publication of findings. There is also a view that the business climate in Britain is less encouraging than the US, especially for the possibly unworldly don. Dr Smailes said: "The nature of the general culture here is risk-averse ... If you fail in the US it's a battle scar. If you fail here they're likely to cut your Visa card up."

There is evidence of a gap between the money being made at Oxford and at other universities. But the really prickly topic is the gap between Oxford and Cambridge. According to one study, in the past three years Oxford's academics have set up 20 companies worth £9.5m. Cambridge has a share in eight companies worth around £5m. David Secher, Cambridge's director of research services, conceded that the university might have been lax in securing the rights to inventions by its academics.

But he added: "This is something we've been looking at in the university, and we've recently agreed new rules that have clarified the ownership of much if not most of the research within the university.

"At the same time I think it's terribly important that if profits are made from that research it is shared fairly with the individual as well as the department of the university."

When brain power brings big bucks

Dennis Gillings, worth £120m, made fortune in pharmaceuticals

Fishmonger's son from East End of London. Became professor of biostatistics, University of North Carolina. Founded Quintiles - research, sales, marketing advice for drug companies

Henry Beker, £59m, internet technology

Chairman of Baltimore Technologies and visiting professor of IT, Royal Holloway, University of London

Chris Evans, £120m, biotechnology

Started his career as a microbiologist after studying at Imperial College, London, and Hull University, before taking up a research fellowship in the US

David Potter and family, £575m, computers

Former physics professor. Founder of the mobile computer company Psion

David Rhodes and family, £85m, telecommunications

Former professor of electronic engineering at Leeds University, founded a group of electronics companies

webTitle: Melvyn Bragg  explains the novelist's call to arms

fields.headline: Behind the lines
fields.standfirst: Melvyn Bragg explains the novelist's call to arms
fields.trailText: Melvyn Bragg explains the novelist's call to arms
fields.body:
Give me the boy until he is seven, the Jesuits said, and I will give you the man. I got the war until I was seven, and then came the man: my father, a stranger, the icon in uniform in the nightly kissed photograph. I had grown without him. When he died six years ago, I found myself pulled into a novel that revolved around that absent father, the mother who had changed through enforced independence and the son so painfully supplanted by the daddy for whom he had been educated to pray. The Soldier's Return is fiction fleshed, nerved and dreamt up from a few bones of autobiography. The underpinning is the second world war. It surprises me now that I did not face up to it sooner.

I was born in 1939 and have gone back to the few decades before and after that in several books, but it took the death of my father to release or perhaps legitimise an imaginative examination, through fiction, of what the second world war did to lives. Perhaps a certain diffidence had stood in the way. The story of my northern family, like that of millions of others in this country - the majority, I expect - was not on the surface the dramatic and terrible stuff of war. It was not the Holocaust. It was not the atom bomb. These are now seen as the two great markers of world war two; they blot out the rest of it.

My father lived, my town was not blitzed, and we were not eliminated. Perhaps unconsciously along the years, I thought that a passing and occasional reference was all that was merited by our average British contribution. I had scarcely more than mentioned it in a previous novel set in the 1940s.

It seemed, after all, my father's life, not mine. And the abundance of the telling central images of the first world war, in which my grandfather and several of his brothers had served, seemed to have bled dry our great national pictures of warfare. They were Homeric pictures, clear individual tragedies in trench facing trench. On archive film and in its contemporary poetry, world war one was mythic, the last "hand to hand" stand of the European warrior peoples. So what was left for us, for me as a novelist, in the second world war?

For me and millions of others in this country and for at least 900 years, the deep ruptures of warring absence, fatherless children and forsaken wives were related in a common net of pain. Following my father's death I understood that the wounds of that war, though in my case in no measure as dramatic or globally significant as the experiences of others, were nevertheless wounds - our wounds. The pain was our pain, fully ready to be fictionalised through the daily conduct of "ordinary" lives that were yet, like all ordinary lives, full of cliffs and chasms that can match any of the more flagrant and spectacular events in lives at the extreme.

So The Soldier's Return began in that death. The soldier had served in the Burmese campaign, which to the thousands of young men who went there from Cumberland and Westmorland was exotic and exciting but brutal, inhuman and completely off their scale of reference in its barbarity. What he had seen and done over those years had to be locked away when he returned, because there was no way to express it in his nature and in his culture at that time save through a breakdown; and his first job was not to break down.

The centre of the novel was not the war, but through my father's return I hoped to bring the second world war into an imaginative work that could encompass it. I would have been too nervous to write a sustained account about war even if I had wanted to.

Maybe that nervousness will go, but Tolstoy had been in war, as had Norman Mailer, Evelyn Waugh, Anthony Powell and the first world war poets. Their work is firm, I believe, in the authority of that directly felt experience. My experience was of fallout: of blackouts and rationing, soldiers drilling in the town and aeroplanes hedge-hopping to local airfields to be patched up before returning south; of listening to the nightly news and perhaps fearing an announcement that my father was dead; of the gossip of death and defeat and my mother's resourcefulness tempering her anxiety. The war had to come into the novel in the shape of a small Cumbrian town that was far from the battle lines, though deep in the war through its loss of men and its industrial focus on the war effort.

The pain of the soldier was the key. I imagined him straitjacketed in that recent past - unpitying, amoral, yet demanding a response of disciplined rectitude; savage, yet provoking unexpected tender feelings of companionship. I could see how the second world war seized people like us, wrenching us from roots of certainty and place and old narratives of life. The Soldier's Return covers the six months following that return. From the beginning I had intended to take it on, and A Son of War drives the project through the next eight years. One of its purposes is to imagine the effects on family, on society and on the mind, of that mid-century crack-up.

At this distance it is possible to begin to see it for what it was. No, we were not Auschwitz, nor were we Hiroshima; and our heads are rightly bowed in their directions. But we were some part of the causes, and certainly included in the consequences of both. Alongside that, though, was a second world war that millions of British families fought through, in which they served and feared, that ripped a hole in the century still not mended and perhaps never to be. It was a war that shook and shaped minds, not only of those involved but also of those in the wings, children most of all. For me that war is being freed up to imagination through time and curiosity, and, perhaps, through need.

Melvyn Bragg's novel The Soldier's Return is out in paperback (Hodder, £6.99). His new novel, A Son of War , is published in June (Hodder, £8.99).

Following my father's death I understood that the wounds of that war, though in my case in no measure as dramatic or globally significant as the experiences of others, were nevertheless wounds - our wounds. The pain was our pain, fully ready to be fictionalised through the daily conduct of "ordinary" lives that were yet, like all ordinary lives, full of cliffs and chasms that can match any of the more flagrant and spectacular events in lives at the extreme. So The Soldier's Return began in that death. The soldier had served in the Burmese campaign, which to the thousands of young men who went there from Cumberland and Westmorland was exotic and exciting but brutal, inhuman and completely off their scale of reference in its barbarity. What he had seen and done over those years had to be locked away when he returned, because there was no way to express it in his nature and in his culture at that time save through a breakdown; and his first job was not to break down. The centre of the novel was not the war, but through my father's return I hoped to bring the second world war into an imaginative work that could encompass it. I would have been too nervous to write a sustained account about war even if I had wanted to. Maybe that nervousness will go, but Tolstoy had been in war, as had Norman Mailer, Evelyn Waugh, Anthony Powell and the first world war poets. Their work is firm, I believe, in the authority of that directly felt experience. My experience was of fallout: of blackouts and rationing, soldiers drilling in the town and aeroplanes hedge-hopping to local airfields to be patched up before returning south; of listening to the nightly news and perhaps fearing an announcement that my father was dead; of the gossip of death and defeat and my mother's resourcefulness tempering her anxiety. The war had to come into the novel in the shape of a small Cumbrian town that was far from the battle lines, though deep in the war through its loss of men and its industrial focus on the war effort. The pain of the soldier was the key. I imagined him straitjacketed in that recent past - unpitying, amoral, yet demanding a response of disciplined rectitude; savage, yet provoking unexpected tender feelings of companionship. I could see how the second world war seized people like us, wrenching us from roots of certainty and place and old narratives of life. The Soldier's Return covers the six months following that return. From the beginning I had intended to take it on, and A Son of War drives the project through the next eight years. One of its purposes is to imagine the effects on family, on society and on the mind, of that mid-century crack-up. At this distance it is possible to begin to see it for what it was. No, we were not Auschwitz, nor were we Hiroshima; and our heads are rightly bowed in their directions. But we were some part of the causes, and certainly included in the consequences of both. Alongside that, though, was a second world war that millions of British families fought through, in which they served and feared, that ripped a hole in the century still not mended and perhaps never to be. It was a war that shook and shaped minds, not only of those involved but also of those in the wings, children most of all. For me that war is being freed up to imagination through time and curiosity, and, perhaps, through need. Melvyn Bragg's novel The Soldier's Return is out in paperback (Hodder, £6.99). His new novel, A Son of War , is published in June (Hodder, £8.99).

webTitle: David Horspool  surveys the revival of military history

fields.headline: Back to battle stations
fields.standfirst: David Horspool  surveys the revival of military history
fields.trailText: David Horspool surveys the revival of military history
fields.body:
In bookshops and universities as little as 10 years ago, military history was a poor relation, looked down on as a boy-scoutish activity best left to those who, like Uncle Toby in Tristram Shandy , would like to fight miniature battles over the ravelins and ramparts of the vegetable patch. Battles were what history had been about a long time ago, but now the study had moved on to fresher pastures: from past politics to past economics, past sociology, past talking, eating, drinking and loving. At the more popular end, what the public appeared to want was revisionist history, which argued that everything you had learned about, say, Churchill, was wrong. It's difficult to persuade readers that, actually, Napoleon won the battle of Waterloo; so military history remained the province of retired generals, and of those who wished they had been generals, because they would have fought Waterloo completely differently, and wrote books to tell you how.

A look around any bookshop today will demonstrate how things have changed. Piles of books about war are massed and serried in the vanguard of any history section. When a commercial publisher asks me to recommend some historians to look out for, he or she will inevitably ask for military historians, who are far easier to sell than the trendier social, postcolonial or gender historians that academic departments (and publications) concentrate on.

Partly this is because, like all good marauders, military historians have overrun and adopted their fellows' provinces and techniques. They are the Normans of the historians' world, adapting the most up-to-date ways and appropriating them for themselves. You want social history? Try Antony Beevor's Stalingrad , which analyses the bloodiest battle of the second world war from each side and every rank. Oral history? Lyn Macdonald's many books on the first world war, or Stephen Ambrose or Studs Terkel on the second, provide just a few of the dozens of studies that record the reactions and memories of those who were there. And the controversialists have also moved in, from Niall Ferguson, who argues in The Pity of War that the conventional view of trench warfare is misguided and that the British were just as much to blame for the first world war as anyone else, to those who reconsider our most cherished myths of the second world war (see Angus Calder's The Myth of the Blitz or Richard Overy's recent little book on the Battle of Britain, The Battle ).

Even historians of gender have taken up military history. One of the most acclaimed military histories of recent years (though not without its critics) has been Joanna Bourke's An Intimate History of Killing , which argued that "the characteristic act of men at war is not dying, it is killing", and discussed masculinity and mayhem in the world wars. Recently, Gary Mead's study The Doughboys has looked at male bonding in the American first world war army.

The success of this more inclusive strain of military history can also be attributed to the changing tastes of the public. First-world- war poetry has become almost the definition of poetry in schools, and novelists have carried on reimagining the wars even as they recede further into the past. After years of neglect, war films are being made again, from Saving Private Ryan to the forthcoming Captain Corelli's Mandolin (May) and Pearl Harbor (June). The recent U-571 did a little quiet revisionism of its own by substituting American submariners for British. The continuing popularity of fictional and poetic representations naturally feeds popular desire to find out the facts, especially when they are as liberally treated as in the last example. Military historians are thus the beneficiaries of the movie industry's capriciousness (though, like courtiers at a tyrant's table, they should not expect to sit with the film-makers long).

The coming weeks and months show no sign of any exhaustion of the military historians' resources. At the more serious end of the market, there is the first volume of Hew Strachan's massive Oxford history of the first world war ( To Arms , published in May), which looks likely to answer his colleagues' scepticism about "yet another history of the war", while Sven Lindqvist's idiosyncratic A History of Bombing (Granta) and Henry Chancellor's Colditz (Hodder) are also to be published this summer. When a publishing trend shows no indication of letting up, it is probably about to disappear - remember lads' novels? - but while there are still inches of the battlefield to examine, this one will last. When the military historians of the world wars move on, it will only be a generation or so before new ones come along to dig it all up again and set off a few still unexploded shells.

David Horspool is history editor of the Times Literary Supplement

webTitle: Review: Spike Island: The Memory of a Military Hospital by Philip Hoare

fields.headline: The English patients
fields.standfirst: Andy Beckett  finds a microcosm of empire in Spike Island: The Memory of a Military Hospital  by Philip Hoare
fields.trailText: Andy Beckett finds a microcosm of empire in Spike Island: The Memory of a Military Hospital by Philip Hoare
fields.body:
Spike Island: The Memory of a Military Hospital
Philip Hoare
417pp, Fourth Estate, £17.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

As the British empire and the khaki culture that supported it grow fainter in the national memory, so it becomes less awkward for writers of liberal inclination to study such muscular things. With no conscription to fret about and few colonial actions to oppose, there has been a quietly growing fashion in recent years for clever authors to treat the military as a subject for cultural studies, as if servicemen were just another social tribe to be neutrally analysed, like football fans or nightclubbers. Geoff Dyer's The Missing of the Somme and Patrick Wright's Tank , for example, are both revealing and thoughtful books, but are also more reverent - even excited in places - about men in uniform than anything you can imagine being published by such writers during, say, Vietnam.

Philip Hoare's previous books have been about Noel Coward, Oscar Wilde and the fizzy appeal of "decadence" to centuries of British fops and avant-gardists. He is an ex-punk, he frequently and proudly reminds us, with his own substantial history of bohemian activities. Yet here he has written 400 pages about a Victorian military hospital. This passage comes from his depiction of the day in May 1856 when Queen Victoria came to lay the foundation stone: "These were glorious times, and it seemed the whole country was en f te . Basking in the mid-century glow of empire, England was the cynosure of the civilised world . . ."

Hoare has always been a slightly excitable writer, with a weakness for the grand assertion. And much of what follows is far more critical of Victorian Britain than the above passage suggests - investigations of hospitals rarely show a society in a flattering light. Nevertheless, an intriguing seam of admiration for the sheer scale and confidence of Victorian ambitions runs through this book. It begins with a lovingly extended description of the Royal Victoria Military Hospital as it rose along the estuary shore at Netley, near Southampton. The building was a quarter of a mile long; 1m bricks were used; the facade was hundreds of windows across; it was then the biggest hospital ever constructed. As the slow, guide-bookish sentences tour the hospital and its grounds, you wonder whether size alone will be enough.

But more subtle and interesting reasons for devoting a whole thick volume to Netley soon emerge. Hoare makes the compound a microcosm of imperial Britain in all its rationalism and irrationalism. The hospital's south-facing grassy site was chosen in the first place, after much debate, for its healing sea breezes and mild climate. Yet the building's design, after much further debate, stubbornly placed a wide corridor running right along the front of the hospital, between the wards and the sunshine. Convalescing soldiers alternately sweated and froze in this long and draughty glass-fronted space; those confined to bed endured perpetual autumn in the gloomy, north-facing rooms behind. Florence Nightingale called the new building "a very expensive mistake".

Yet during the later decades of the 19th century, as the global business of defending and expanding the empire sent shiploads of damaged men back to Netley, it quickly became central to the life of the nation. Queen Victoria visited regularly; the hospital's railway station was the third busiest in the country. New medical practices were pioneered, enlightened and otherwise. And the compound as a whole - with its patients from every colony, its imported exotic plants and wicker furniture from the Raj, its armed guards and its pier jutting out into in the grey Solent - grew into a mixture of Victorian seaside resort, military encampment and even a prototype of the multicultural Britain of the distant future. A special funeral pyre was built in the nearby woods for deceased Hindu servicemen.

All these teeming details justify Hoare's hyperventilating sen tences. His efforts to prise insights about the past from a headland in Hampshire where only the hospital's chapel and screens of trees now stand achieve a similar suggestiveness - a sense of lost worlds dragged back into view - to that of W G Sebald's spooky criss-crossing of Suffolk in The Rings of Saturn . However, once the story of Netley begins to cool, with the hospital's slow decline beginning from around the end of the first world war, the book starts to try too hard. A page of speculation that experiments may have been conducted on a wounded German prisoner ends like a voice-over from a bad horror film scripted by a passing academic: "Whatever the truth of Otto Schulz's fate, its mysteries reinforced the hospital's associative power, its impenetrable tree- surrounded site able to contain any number of gothic narratives."

There is a long digression about nearby Netley Abbey, a medieval ruin long prized by local aesthetes for its dripping atmospheres (you sense the melodramatic Hoare of earlier books reasserting himself). There is also an unconvincing thread of memoir about growing up in a Southampton suburb next door to Netley. Hoare is good on the bomb-flattened blandness of the rest of the city, at least as it appeared to him as a teenager, yet has to admit that he has no clear memory of the hospital itself. It was demolished in 1966, after being damaged in a fire and standing empty for years; virtually all the hospital's records disappeared with the rubble. Hoare hints at conspiracy, but simple neglect of an unused government building seems just as likely. The book peters out in a thicket of personal musings about history and memory.

For all the flaws, though, the account of the actual life of the hospital lingers. The rows of temporary huts that shortened and lengthened like a bar graph of each war's progress; the darkened, drugged psychiatric wards where the young R D Laing worked and plotted his famous revolt against such treatments; the almost instant corrosion of the hospital's proud bricks and stone by the damp air of the Solent . . . A restless amateur like Hoare may deal slightly too quickly with such vivid discoveries. But he may also be less likely to take official claims to orderliness at face value than professional military historians; and more likely to make you want to go straight down to Southampton.

webTitle: DJ Taylor on the war novel

fields.headline: Echoes of war
fields.standfirst:
Ten years ago, military history was a backwater. Now it drives a good deal of publishing, cinema and television. From novels such as Captain Corelli's Mandolin (out as a film next month) to non-fiction blockbusters such as Stalingrad, war is everywhere - and the trend is increasing. D J Taylor discusses the development of the war novel
Melvyn Bragg explains the novelist's call to arms
David Horspool surveys the revival of military history
A reading list of war fiction
Review: Spike Island: The Memory of a Military Hospital by Philip Hoare
fields.trailText: Ten years ago, military history was a backwater. Now it drives a good deal of publishing, cinema and television. From novels such as Captain Corelli's Mandolin (out as a film next month) to non-fiction blockbusters such as Stalingrad, war is everywhere - and the trend is increasing. D J Taylor discusses the development of the war novel
fields.body:
What is a war novel? Well, to start with the obvious ones, War and Peace is a war novel, and so is Stephen Crane's The Red Badge of Courage (American civil war) and Norman Mailer's The Naked and the Dead (second world war). But so, too, is Vanity Fair , a survey of early-19th century English society that has Waterloo as its pivot; and so, curiously enough, is Alec Waugh's The Loom of Youth , published in 1917 when the first world war was at its height, but set in the unmartial domain of an English public school.

Outwardly, the connection between Mailer's dispatches from the US-Japanese conflict and Waugh's schoolboy rugby players is not very great, but it is there. Mailer's novel is, among other things, an eyewitness account of battle. The Loom of Youth , with its rebel hero itching to defy reactionary officialdom, reflects a deep frustration with the forces administering national life. Appearing at a time when the Flanders campaign was drifting into calamitous stalemate, its attack on the institution that had produced the British officer class saw its author denounced in print and from the pulpit.

Whether set in a Somme trench or at a removed historical vantage point - Vanity Fair was published more than 30 years after the military events it purports to describe - the war novel is one of the most pervasive modern literary genres, all the more so when it deals with conflict obliquely. Certainly, most of the significant English fiction of the immediate post-war era falls into this category. Nineteen Eighty Four (1949), for example, takes place in a dingy environment of ration cards, falling bombs and the awful feeling of there never being enough to eat - essentially the London Blitz atmosphere of 1940-41. Even Lucky Jim (1954) languishes in the war's long shadow, with Jim Dixon, Kingsley Amis's harassed academic, keeping his lecture notes in an old RAF file and feeling class unease in the presence of an ex-officer student who fought at Anzio. Running through Amis's novel, too, is a tremendous feeling of there being good times ahead - a kind of vista of girls' faces, beer, books and jazz - a metaphorical shutter slammed down over the emotional upsets of 1939-45.

But as Amis and his contemporaries soon discovered, the shutter was not so easily closed. The post-war romans-fleuves - Anthony Powell's A Dance to the Music of Time , say, or Simon Raven's Alms for Oblivion sequence - were consistently absorbed by the idea of personal and social change brought about by conflict. The first two novels in A S Byatt's post-war series, The Virgin in the Garden (1978) and Still Life (1985), are studies of 1950s adolescents who are keenly aware of the privations of a wartime childhood. Even today, over half a century since the end of the second world war, the old imperatives endure: a great deal that happens in modern British fiction takes place in that ever more expansive hinterland, After the War (itself the title of a panoramic novel by Frederic Raphael).

This spring's publishing catalogues contain an even larger number of war novels than usual, notably John Lawton's Riptide ; Rodney Hall's The Day We Had Hitler Home ; Francis Cottam's The Fire Fighter ; Stevie Davies's The Element of Water and A Son of War , Melvyn Bragg's forthcoming sequel to his award-winning The Soldier's Return . With the exception of Bragg, born in 1939, none of these writers possesses even childhood memories of war, yet the imaginative lure remains.

Questioned over their motivation, fortysomething novelists who write about war usually murmur something about a mixture of guilt and relief at not having had to fight themselves. This was Sebastian Faulks's line on the origins of Birdsong (first world war) and Charlotte Gray (second world war). George Orwell said something similar about his guilt as a teenage schoolboy, hearing of the deaths of boys only a few years senior to him. Rising above it, though, is the awareness not only of war's profound importance for the society we now inhabit - a world that was formed in the crucible of 1939-45 - but of the aesthetic scope this offers to the novelist.

Like a Gladstone bag, which always has the capacity to yield up an extra compartment, the British war novel is no longer a single genre but a series of genres, many of them interconnecting. Most obviously there is the physical description of warfare, whether played out in military engagements or witnessed by civilians (for example, Henry Green's accounts of the London Auxiliary Fire Service). Then there are the books about life on the home front - Monica Dickens's The Fancy (1942), which surveys a group of operatives in an aircraft factory, or Patrick Hamilton's The Slaves of Solitude (1947), a fabulously gloomy portrait of the denizens of a wartime Thames Valley boarding house. The "spoof" war novel goes back as far as Peter Fleming's The Flying Visit (1940), which gets a mention in Riptide . In this book Hitler, wishing to gloat over the Luftwaffe attacks, has himself flown over England, survives a plane crash and wanders around the countryside for a while before turning up at a village fancy-dress competition where he is awarded first prize. Equally enduring is the tale of the warrior's return to unpromising postwar reality; The Soldier's Return can be interestingly compared to Warwick Deeping's 1920s bestseller Sorrell and Son . Finally there is that huge corpus of books dealing with war's aftermath, often surreptitiously and by means of doctored representations of the war itself.

This last category - representative examples might be Anthony Powell's three war novels and Evelyn Waugh's Sword of Honour trilogy - offers a reminder of the great shift in perspective that has taken place in the past 30 years. The novels of the immediate postwar era, many of them written by former serving soldiers whose political views inclined to the right, were often exercises in retrospective fixing. In the 1950s Evelyn Waugh genuinely believed that he inhabited a kind of socialist holiday camp. His response was to project his dissatisfactions back onto the conduct of the war, mocking the idea of a "people's war" and detecting in it the seeds of the phantom socialism that he imagined was ruining contemporary Britain. Powell's angle is more subtle, but a novel such as The Military Philosophers , set amid the Whitehall intelligence units, is full of loaded prefigurative remarks about a series of post-war social arrangements that, one gathers, were not much to Powell's taste.

Three decades and more on, this kind of ideology has all but disappeared. Detached from the immediate politics of the war and its aftermath, a modern novelist is likely to be interested in more elemental themes of loss, betrayal and divided loyalty or questions of national identity - as in Captain Corelli's Mandolin . Stevie Davies's The Element of Water (Women's Press, £9.99) features a Welsh-reared refugee who, returning to her native Germany in the late 1950s, comes across the son of her Nazi father's greatest friend. The hero of Francis Cottam's excellent debut The Fire Fighter (Chatto & Windus, £15.99), commissioned to preserve key buildings in the City of London, gets entangled with a doubtfully loyal love interest. John Lawton's Riptide (Weidenfield & Nicolson, £16.99) takes in the search for a highly placed Nazi double agent who has supposedly fled to England. The "spoof", it turns out, is still going strong. With its cameo appearances by famous names, Riptide falls into this category, while Rodney Hall's The Day We Had Hitler Home (Granta, £15.99) fills in Hitler's "lost" year of 1919 with an account of him turning up in New South Wales, mistakenly included in a batch of returning Australian soldiers. Hall shows that ideological purpose is alive and well, pointing out that the first national act of fledgling Australia was to sign the Treaty of Versailles, thereby creating the conditions in which nazism grew and prospered.

Each of these novels raises a fundamental procedural question: how does a writer convey, realistically, the second world war, a six-year period of carnage regularly pronounced to be "beyond words"? How do you describe an air raid, a tank battle or an explosion on a submarine? This problem exercised creative writers who wanted to record their own experiences of world war two almost from the start. Henry Green's fire-service pieces are done in sharp, impressionist fragments. The opening scene of Waugh's Officers and Gentlemen - an air raid on the West End of London viewed from the steps of a gentleman's club - looks to art ("'Pure Turner,' said Guy Crouchback enthusiastically"). Almost as compelling is the problem of idiom - reproducing or approximating speech without descending into stereotype. The solutions on display here are varied: in Francis Cottam's novel, some punctilious descriptions of scene and incident; in John Lawton's, a knowingness that an American general blazing away at a German bomber with a sporting rifle from the roof of Claridges comes very close to burlesque.

Inevitably, throughout these varied takes on warfare and our responses to it, symbolism lurks. Practically the only false note in Stevie Davies's absorbing account of cross-generational conflict comes when a war veteran talks to his son aboutthe SS and then carries on cooking supper. "He put in the steak, turning up the flame. Blood spat in the hot butter and filled the kitchen with the smell of charring meat." There are other kinds of charring meat not too far away, and it would be a very placid reader who wasn't reminded of human corpses sizzling in the Buchenwald ovens. The modern war novel, in all its myriad variants, is full of these kind of echoes - resonant voices shouting back across time, made more, not less, compelling by distance.

DJ Taylor's most recent novel is The Comedy Man (Duck Editions, £9.99).
fields.bodyText: What is a war novel? Well, to start with the obvious ones, War and Peace is a war novel, and so is Stephen Crane's The Red Badge of Courage (American civil war) and Norman Mailer's The Naked and the Dead (second world war). But so, too, is Vanity Fair , a survey of early-19th century English society that has Waterloo as its pivot; and so, curiously enough, is Alec Waugh's The Loom of Youth , published in 1917 when the first world war was at its height, but set in the unmartial domain of an English public school. Outwardly, the connection between Mailer's dispatches from the US-Japanese conflict and Waugh's schoolboy rugby players is not very great, but it is there. Mailer's novel is, among other things, an eyewitness account of battle. The Loom of Youth , with its rebel hero itching to defy reactionary officialdom, reflects a deep frustration with the forces administering national life. Appearing at a time when the Flanders campaign was drifting into calamitous stalemate, its attack on the institution that had produced the British officer class saw its author denounced in print and from the pulpit. Whether set in a Somme trench or at a removed historical vantage point - Vanity Fair was published more than 30 years after the military events it purports to describe - the war novel is one of the most pervasive modern literary genres, all the more so when it deals with conflict obliquely. Certainly, most of the significant English fiction of the immediate post-war era falls into this category. Nineteen Eighty Four (1949), for example, takes place in a dingy environment of ration cards, falling bombs and the awful feeling of there never being enough to eat - essentially the London Blitz atmosphere of 1940-41. Even Lucky Jim (1954) languishes in the war's long shadow, with Jim Dixon, Kingsley Amis's harassed academic, keeping his lecture notes in an old RAF file and feeling class unease in the presence of an ex-officer student who fought at Anzio. Running through Amis's novel, too, is a tremendous feeling of there being good times ahead - a kind of vista of girls' faces, beer, books and jazz - a metaphorical shutter slammed down over the emotional upsets of 1939-45. But as Amis and his contemporaries soon discovered, the shutter was not so easily closed. The post-war romans-fleuves - Anthony Powell's A Dance to the Music of Time , say, or Simon Raven's Alms for Oblivion sequence - were consistently absorbed by the idea of personal and social change brought about by conflict. The first two novels in A S Byatt's post-war series, The Virgin in the Garden (1978) and Still Life (1985), are studies of 1950s adolescents who are keenly aware of the privations of a wartime childhood. Even today, over half a century since the end of the second world war, the old imperatives endure: a great deal that happens in modern British fiction takes place in that ever more expansive hinterland, After the War (itself the title of a panoramic novel by Frederic Raphael). This spring's publishing catalogues contain an even larger number of war novels than usual, notably John Lawton's Riptide ; Rodney Hall's The Day We Had Hitler Home ; Francis Cottam's The Fire Fighter ; Stevie Davies's The Element of Water and A Son of War , Melvyn Bragg's forthcoming sequel to his award-winning The Soldier's Return . With the exception of Bragg, born in 1939, none of these writers possesses even childhood memories of war, yet the imaginative lure remains. Questioned over their motivation, fortysomething novelists who write about war usually murmur something about a mixture of guilt and relief at not having had to fight themselves. This was Sebastian Faulks's line on the origins of Birdsong (first world war) and Charlotte Gray (second world war). George Orwell said something similar about his guilt as a teenage schoolboy, hearing of the deaths of boys only a few years senior to him. Rising above it, though, is the awareness not only of war's profound importance for the society we now inhabit - a world that was formed in the crucible of 1939-45 - but of the aesthetic scope this offers to the novelist. Like a Gladstone bag, which always has the capacity to yield up an extra compartment, the British war novel is no longer a single genre but a series of genres, many of them interconnecting. Most obviously there is the physical description of warfare, whether played out in military engagements or witnessed by civilians (for example, Henry Green's accounts of the London Auxiliary Fire Service). Then there are the books about life on the home front - Monica Dickens's The Fancy (1942), which surveys a group of operatives in an aircraft factory, or Patrick Hamilton's The Slaves of Solitude (1947), a fabulously gloomy portrait of the denizens of a wartime Thames Valley boarding house. The "spoof" war novel goes back as far as Peter Fleming's The Flying Visit (1940), which gets a mention in Riptide . In this book Hitler, wishing to gloat over the Luftwaffe attacks, has himself flown over England, survives a plane crash and wanders around the countryside for a while before turning up at a village fancy-dress competition where he is awarded first prize. Equally enduring is the tale of the warrior's return to unpromising postwar reality; The Soldier's Return can be interestingly compared to Warwick Deeping's 1920s bestseller Sorrell and Son . Finally there is that huge corpus of books dealing with war's aftermath, often surreptitiously and by means of doctored representations of the war itself. This last category - representative examples might be Anthony Powell's three war novels and Evelyn Waugh's Sword of Honour trilogy - offers a reminder of the great shift in perspective that has taken place in the past 30 years. The novels of the immediate postwar era, many of them written by former serving soldiers whose political views inclined to the right, were often exercises in retrospective fixing. In the 1950s Evelyn Waugh genuinely believed that he inhabited a kind of socialist holiday camp. His response was to project his dissatisfactions back onto the conduct of the war, mocking the idea of a "people's war" and detecting in it the seeds of the phantom socialism that he imagined was ruining contemporary Britain. Powell's angle is more subtle, but a novel such as The Military Philosophers , set amid the Whitehall intelligence units, is full of loaded prefigurative remarks about a series of post-war social arrangements that, one gathers, were not much to Powell's taste. Three decades and more on, this kind of ideology has all but disappeared. Detached from the immediate politics of the war and its aftermath, a modern novelist is likely to be interested in more elemental themes of loss, betrayal and divided loyalty or questions of national identity - as in Captain Corelli's Mandolin . Stevie Davies's The Element of Water (Women's Press, £9.99) features a Welsh-reared refugee who, returning to her native Germany in the late 1950s, comes across the son of her Nazi father's greatest friend. The hero of Francis Cottam's excellent debut The Fire Fighter (Chatto & Windus, £15.99), commissioned to preserve key buildings in the City of London, gets entangled with a doubtfully loyal love interest. John Lawton's Riptide (Weidenfield & Nicolson, £16.99) takes in the search for a highly placed Nazi double agent who has supposedly fled to England. The "spoof", it turns out, is still going strong. With its cameo appearances by famous names, Riptide falls into this category, while Rodney Hall's The Day We Had Hitler Home (Granta, £15.99) fills in Hitler's "lost" year of 1919 with an account of him turning up in New South Wales, mistakenly included in a batch of returning Australian soldiers. webTitle: Review: Curiosity: A Cultural History of Early Modern Inquiry by Barbara M Benedict

fields.headline: Weird and wonderful
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom  pokes his nose into Curiosity: A Cultural History of Early Modern Inquiry by Barbara M Benedict
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom pokes his nose into Curiosity: A Cultural History of Early Modern Inquiry by Barbara M Benedict
fields.body:
Curiosity: A Cultural History of Early Modern Inquiry
Barbara M Benedict
296pp, University of Chicago Press, £28.50

In this history of curiosity from the late 17th to the early 19th centuries, Barbara M Benedict assembles her own gorgeous literary curiosity cabinet crammed with excerpts from novels, poems, journalism, travel narratives, trial transcripts and pornography. Every nook and cranny is stuffed full of oddities and exquisites: stories about witches and harlots and the history of hot-air ballooning, all of which serve to illustrate Benedict's central claim that curiosity, during the early-modern period, was considered an act of transgression.

Benedict argues that throughout the history of western culture, curiosity has been seen as a vice (consider Eve). She then shows how during the Restoration curious people, and scientists in particular, began to be regarded as objects of curiosity, and traces curiosity as a phenomenon through certain 18th-century cultural practices: collecting and connoisseurship, scientific research, philosophy, consumption, spectatorship and gossip.

What motivates all of these activities, according to Benedict, is the spirit of inquiry. And what drives inquiry, she argues, is ambition. The thesis seems correct, and is certainly compelling. If one considers only one's own family and friends, it is clear that humility breeds contentment, while curiosity gives you itchy feet, bad breath and a big head. The incurious prefer to stay at home; the curious go abroad, keep journals and cause trouble. The boast of the curious is the same as that of Inigo Jones, scribbling after Petrarch in Rome in 1614: Altro diletto che imparar non provo . (The more curious may wish to consult a dictionary for a translation. Oh, all right then: "There is no greater pleasure for me than in learning.")

The object of our inquiries is irrelevant: wall coverings, curries, the sex life of the rhinoceros, the insides of dogs. Everyone is curious about something, and everyone collects: things, ideas, people. When Albrecht Dürer visited the Netherlands, he bought a tortoiseshell shield, an elk's foot and an ox horn. Which of us does not have our own little hoard tucked away somewhere, in attic, loft or box under the bed: old jigsaws, biros, snowstorms, cigarette cards, the titbits that make life worth living? One is reminded of Samuel Johnson - "it is by studying little things that we attain the great art of having as little misery and as much happiness as possible" - or perhaps Julie Andrews ("When the dog bites / When the bee stings / When I'm feeling sad / I simply remember my favourite things / And then I don't feel so bad").

All of us are bores, then, all of us pompous and embarrassing, inclined to give forth on some curi ous subject. George I liked cutting out paper figures, Nabokov had his butterflies and David Beckham is clearly very interested in fashion, popular music and interior design. We are all eyeing up some hobby horse, like the poor beasts in Stella Gibbons's Cold Comfort Farm . "The beasts stood with head lowered, dejectedly against the wooden hoof-pieces of their stalls. Graceless, Pointless, Feckless and Aimless awaited their turn to be milked."

The curious mind is restless, then; has wandering hands and a wayward eye; and is ambitious not so much to succeed as to know. This may explain why it is not usually found these days within universities, and certainly not within humanities faculties, where appointment depends upon specialisation and the production of pale, complacent articles. Professionalism, one might argue, is the enemy of ruddy curiosity. The curious mind strives after freedom, the academic strives after a professorship. (Benedict is a professor of English at Trinity College, Connecticut.)

The book is teeming with big questions and fine distinctions. Does sexual discovery motivate the pleasure of curiosity, or does curiosity sexualise discovery? What is the relationship between curiosity and appetite? Curiosity and the occult? Curiosity and power? The examples threaten - as examples always do - to usurp the argument. The strange history of exhibition animals, for example, or of micrographia, museum guidebooks, gossip or the story of The Universal Magazine are all far more interesting than anything Benedict has to say about them. The facts are Technicolor, while the theory is grey. Benedict is quick to distinguish between curiosity and wonder - wonder "reverses the novelty it encounters", while curiosity seeks to explain it - but it is difficult to see how one can exist without the other. The book's unstated purpose, and its paradox, is to turn curiosities into applied knowledge.

Benedict clicks her cabinet shut with a few remarks on the 20th century. She singles out cop shows on TV - Ironside "trapped in a wheelchair", Cannon "almost too fat to walk" - as examples of human curiosities who "revisit the historical charge that scientific investigators must have something wrong with them, some vital masculine impulse diverted, some inadequacy". The principle clearly applies also to DIY and gardening programmes. Alan Titchmarsh and Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen are our contemporary curiosities, freaks and sports of nature. They burlesque intelligence. One could probably push the argument even further, to cover game-show hosts, politicians and literary critics.
