fields.headline: My favourite table
fields.standfirst: Meera Syal at Tamarind
fields.trailText: Meera Syal at Tamarind.
fields.byline: Interview and research by Chloe Diski
fields.body:
I associate this restaurant with family for two reasons: the dishes are very authentic Punjab, which is where my family comes from in north west India, and because it is literally in the family - my brother-in-law, Jajesh Suri, manages it. Tamarind has successfully got away from the image of Indian restaurants as the sort of place that you stumble into, pissed, and have everything with lager. It is quite a dressy restaurant and sumptuously decorated, and there are always a lot of Indians eating here which is a good sign.

Fancy restaurants like this are common all over India, especially in the big cities, but there are still very few in Britain. I often dress up and come with my family on special occasions and we've had quite a few charity events here. That is part of the pleasure of this restaurant; when we need a venue we always know that we can use it, but mainly I love it because it feels like eating at home. I grew up eating Punjab cuisine, and the Tamarind menu is filled with dishes that my mother cooks like Paneer Makhani and Pini Chana. Food is quite an emotional experience: when you're feeling homesick or a bit low, then what you want is to recreate the flavour that you associate with security, and I can have that here.

Tamarind also has dishes that are European in style. Jalpari Chaat tandoori (prawn and scallops, with mint, and grapes) is a fusion of Mediterranean and Indian influences, and they have quite a few dishes that would straddle that. I've had that a few times, but I often end up having Paneer Machani, a Punjab Indian cheese dish. I'm not a purist, but sometimes only the pure stuff will do. Because I was brought up as mainly vegetarian I will always choose a vegetable over a fish dish. Punjab cuisine was mainly vegetarian, I didn't see a prawn until I was 18. The first time I had one I ate it with the feelers on and was very, very sick. I very occasionally eat chicken but I would never touch red meat. Food is an essential part of Indian family life. My home cooking is pure Punjab cooking and I'm teaching my daughter to cook the way I learnt from my mother - not because I feel that as she is a woman she has to learn to cook, but because it is a great emotional connection back to who we are.

Indians take their food very seriously. People tend to lump Indian food together and there are so many types of cuisine within the country itself. For instance, rice-based dishes are more common in the south and breads are very important in northern Punjab cooking. The Tamarind has an open window at the back of the restaurant so you can see the chefs cooking all the different kinds of nan in the Tandoor oven, fresh in front of you.

People usually associate curry with hotness, which is completely false, it is fairly spicy but in a layered way. At Tamarind and in many Indian homes the cooks might use up to eight or nine different spices and they have to put them in at certain times to get the best flavour from them. It is all about creating layers of flavour, and when you see somebody cook you realise why. Some high street restaurants will have pre-made sauces which they will use as the base for many of their dishes. That is okay food, but you can't compare pizza with going to the Ivy.

Tamarind tips

Location
Tamarind occupies the Mayfair site once occupied by the legendary Tiberio - an old rat-pack haunt of the Sixties, at 20 Queen Street, Mayfair, London W1X 7PJ.

Awards
Michelin star in 2001/2002 Best Indian Chef in UK 1999 Best in Britain Award 2000 (Real Curry Guide)

Reviews
'Food to die for' New York Times
'The tandoori gear is seriously good...I was impressed' Andrew Lloyd Webber
'Expertise is evident...beautifully presented' Time Out

Most popular dishes
Starter: Shammi Kebab (ground lamb, coriander and mint)
Main Course: Hare Maslae Ki Machchi (pan-fried salmon with green spices and crispy spinach)
Dessert: Kulfi (Indian ice cream)

How much
Set menus range from £32.00 to £45.00 per person. Dishes are from £4.95 to £17.75 and the wine is £14 to £260

Famous regulars
Wesley Snipes, Mick Jagger, Andrew Lloyd Webber and Robert De Niro

Ordinary regulars
Tamarind is in the centre of Mayfair and so it is full of businessmen: 70% of their clients are corporate

To reserve a table
Ring 020 7629 3561 or fax 020 499 5034. Website at www.tamarindrestaurant.com

webTitle: John Humphrys on the organic revoution (part two)

fields.headline: Why the organic revolution had to happen (part two)
fields.standfirst: When British people farmed simply and ate plainly there was no need for organic produce. But fears over  pollution, pesticides, synthetic fertilisers,mad cow disease, growth-hormone injections, swine fever, salmonella, GM food and foot and mouth changed all that. Gradually we lost our faith in food
fields.trailText: Since the middle of the 1980s we had watched those disturbing pictures on our television screens of cows slipping and sliding drunkenly across their farmyards. Now we were to watch their destruction. Not only the obviously sick cows but millions of their apparently healthy sisters were to be incinerated. The photographs of their grotesque funeral pyres began appearing in the newspapers. In the years that followed 170,000 cows were to become infected and 4.7 million slaughtered. British beef was banned around the world. No meat could be sold from cows that were more than 30 months old. We began to count the cost in taxpayers' money of compensating the farmers and paying the meat renderers. As I write these words the total is approaching five billion pounds and it is not over yet. Replacing surgical instruments that might possibly carry the vCJD infection will add hugely to the bill.
fields.body:
Since the middle of the 1980s we had watched those disturbing pictures on our television screens of cows slipping and sliding drunkenly across their farmyards. Now we were to watch their destruction. Not only the obviously sick cows but millions of their apparently healthy sisters were to be incinerated. The photographs of their grotesque funeral pyres began appearing in the newspapers. In the years that followed 170,000 cows were to become infected and 4.7 million slaughtered. British beef was banned around the world. No meat could be sold from cows that were more than 30 months old. We began to count the cost in taxpayers' money of compensating the farmers and paying the meat renderers. As I write these words the total is approaching five billion pounds and it is not over yet. Replacing surgical instruments that might possibly carry the vCJD infection will add hugely to the bill.

But worse - infinitely worse than all that - we began to share the grief of parents whose children fell victim to the hideous disease. And we began to worry for our own. Pictures of bright young teenagers began appearing in the newspapers and the text always told the same tragic story. Our beloved daughter had been full of life, full of fun, full of hope for the future. Then strange things started to happen. She could no longer concentrate. She grew irritable and angry. She became a different person. She lost control of her movements and her bodily functions. She became blind. She could no longer hear or speak. And then - with awful and absolute inevitability - she died.

When I presented a special programme for Panorama on the BSE crisis Stephen Dorrell was desperate to assure me that the government had acted as soon as it 'had the evidence'. Who could quarrel with that? Well, the Livestock Standards Committee of the Soil Association had warned in 1983 that there were serious risks in feeding animal protein to ruminants and banned it for all organic farmers. They had no firm evidence, but every ounce of their intuition and common sense told them it was a stupid thing to do. They were ignored. The problem with waiting for the evidence is that by the time you get it, it may be too late.

The politicians, advised by their experts, also wanted to reassure us that every step is now being taken to ensure that we will run no more similar risks. When a few questions were raised about the safety of beef on the bone, even from animals deemed to be entirely free from risk, butchers were immediately banned from selling it and T-bone steaks disappeared from restaurant menus. But still doubts remain in the minds of many people. The most persistent is this: BSE and other, lesser, food scares such as salmonella in eggs were the result of an approach to farming and food production that placed quantity above quality at every step in the chain and yet that approach has never been seriously questioned.

If a chicken could be forced to grow faster to knock a few pence off the cost of producing it, we did it. And never mind that it lived in disgusting conditions that invited disease. If a cow could be forced to produce twice as much milk by feeding it ground-up meat and bonemeal, we did it. If a field of carrots could be forced to deliver a bigger yield by spraying the plants with pesticides and the weeds with herbicides, we did it. And never mind that the Department of Health had to warn the people who ate those carrots to peel them carefully and throw away the top inch because of pesticide residues.

As so often before, many ordinary people with no great knowledge and no 'expert' advice to rely on were asking questions for themselves and reaching conclusions for themselves. One of those conclusions was that many of them wanted their food produced differently. They wanted less factory farming. They wanted food produced by less intensive methods. The supermarkets got the message. The revolution was born.

We are endlessly told - usually by the supermarkets themselves - that we have the best food retailers in the world and we should be grateful for what they have done for us. Not everyone is persuaded. Some of us regret the disappearance of so many small butchers and bakers and greengrocers and chemists. Some of us mourn the destruction of so many high streets and town centres. When the supermarket chains tell us they are not to blame we do not believe them. We prefer the evidence of our own eyes and the application of our own common sense. But in at least one respect the supermarkets cannot be faulted.

They are, by and large, run by brilliant marketing people who can spot a selling opportunity at a thousand paces and exploit it in less time than it takes to fill a trolley. It took them a very short time to recognise that their customers were scared at the thought of genetically modified food and they dumped it from their shelves before the biotech companies and the politicians knew what had hit them. Nothing sounds louder in the ear of a supermarket executive than a customer's threat to take her business to a competitor. Now the sound of customers demanding organic food was becoming deafening. All those supermarkets which had so recently scorned the idea of the so-called beard-and-sandal brigade were suddenly fighting each other for every organic carrot and tomato they could lay their hands on.

Marks & Spencer had once loftily declared that it would not be bothering with organic food because there was not enough demand and the quality could not be guaranteed. When they finally realised what was happening they changed their minds in a hurry. Sainsbury's and Waitrose were stocking close to a thousand lines by the middle of 2000 and Tesco was catching up fast. Asda launched its own brand of organic food. By the middle of the Nineties sales of organic food were growing at a rate of more than 40 per cent year on year. In 1999 we bought about £550 million worth of the stuff.

At this point you might expect the men and women who run the organic movement in this country to be jumping up and down with delight and - for the large part - they are. But there are problems. One serious concern is how the supermarkets will behave in the next few years. So long as organic produce accounted for no more than a tiny niche market none of the big chains had been terribly interested. They sold the food at higher prices but paid the producers more for it, so their profits on the whole enterprise were relatively modest. They didn't worry too much about that. The main reason for stocking the stuff in the first place was to make sure that customers who wanted it did not go elsewhere. But now things are different. Organic food has become seriously big business and every supermarket chain wants more of it.

Tesco, for instance, said they would sell many of their organic products at the same price as conventional food. Worries about the reckless use of antibiotics may be yet another. But there's something else too. Is organic food better for us? Surveys of public opinion and increasing sales in the supermarkets suggest that most people think it is. Hard scientific proof is less easy to come by.

Critics of organic farming are not persuaded by any of this. The thoughtful sceptics say there is not enough evidence. They have a point; much more research needs to be done.

But there is a powerful lobby opposed to organic farming who have no interest in evidence or research. That lobby includes vested interests: the agrochemical companies who sell the pesticides and the synthetic fertilisers; the biotech companies who want to sell their genetically modified seeds; the barley barons who have made small fortunes farming for subsidies; the politicians who are afraid to admit that they may have got it wrong over the years and are afraid to upset the big vested interests.

We have had one agricultural revolution in living memory. It began in the 1950s and its effects - for good and ill - are with us still. It gave us bigger harvests. It also gave us environmental destruction and pesticide residues and antibiotic resistance and the horrors of mad cow disease. The more we have learnt about the food on our plate, the way it is grown and processed, the less we have come to trust it. Now we are being invited to embark on another revolution - genetic modification - with consequences we can only wonder at.

With the benefit of two generations of experience it is easy to see why intensive agriculture went wrong. It was never more than a knee-jerk reaction to the fear of food shortages: produce it cheap and make sure there's lots of it. None of us paused to think about the long-term consequences of what we were doing. We must not make the same mistake again. We must think seriously about what we expect from food and the way it is produced. And our starting point should be that agriculture is, in effect, the nation's primary health service.

So this is about more than the merits of one group of farmers over another and apportioning blame and praise. We should be moving on from that. We should be less arrogant and accept that good agriculture should not simply be battling against nature. If we allowed nature to have its way entirely most of us would starve, but it is possible to farm in harmony with it and not always in conflict. We should also acknowledge that good food is about more than calories and vitamins.

You don't have to live in a yurt and wear rope sandals to accept all of that. It is possible both to accept the basic scientific principles of cause and effect and also to believe in the holistic view of the world as a living organism. What is impossible to believe in is the arrogant notion that we can do what we damned well like and to hell with the consequences. That's what we have been doing for the past half-century. It is time to stop.

'Kite's Nest Farm is an old-fashioned farm - well-run and beautiful'

Richard Young runs Kite's Nest Farm in Worcestershire. It lies on the northern escarpment of the Cotswold Hills, most of which are covered these days in regimented rows of cereals. In many respects Kite's Nest is a time warp. It is a mixed farm, as were most half a century ago before subsidies dictated farming methods.

The cows have names rather than numbers. They live in families and suckle their young. The calves are never removed forcibly from their mothers. When her milk dries up the calf is weaned away naturally and when the new calf comes he moves aside. But he will stay with his mother. They graze in pastures filled with the sort of plants that would have been killed off long ago if they had been plastered with synthetic nitrogen. They are rich in herbs, which the cows select carefully. The farm is a botanist's dream. There are rare plants, including the yellow-flowered Dyer's greenweed, pyramid orchids and clustered bellflower and other species that have long since vanished from most of Britain. You do not see all this on a modern efficient farm.

But who is to say that this is not efficient? The cows live longer and are healthier because they are under no stress. When you approach them they do not back away as they have been treated with care and affection all their lives. But they must earn their keep and when their youngsters reach the right age they are slaughtered locally. The Youngs sell the meat in the farm shop where it fetches a premium price and there is no shortage of buyers. When other farmers were forced to slaughter their precious livestock and watch their life's work being destroyed by BSE, the Youngs had no fears. Richard's mother had stopped buying compound feed in 1974 when she discovered that it contained chicken carcasses. The Youngs have never had a case of BSE.

So this is a thoroughly old fashioned farm. It survives because its costs are low and it caters to a specific market. On a spring day there is a real sense of nature in harmony with itself. The blind worshippers will say that this is romantic twaddle. There is, they will say, no such thing as 'nature', that nature is to be controlled, managed, manipulated. If we relied on farms like this we would all starve. It follows, therefore, that Richard Young is a crank. Well, let me invite you to spend an hour in his office.

It is a big office, the first floor of an old barn. Computer screens glow, fax machines stutter out reams of paper and the filing cabinets which line every wall bulge with thousands of documents. Few of them have anything to do with the farm. Most are scientific papers, the sort that have been published by clever men and women with enough degrees to paper their walls. They are concerned with the world of microbiology and, more specifically, the effect on bacteria of antibiotics .Young may not have an academic letter to his name but he spotted the devastating assault being made on the front line of our medical defences long before many of the people who wrote these papers.

For 15 years he has been assembling a powerful argument and trying to get people to listen. He is not qualified to stare into a microscope and write up the results, but ge does opossess an inquiring mind, an ability to absorb, understand and analyse information, a capacity for hard work and a lifetime of studying the way animals respond when they are treated in certain ways. But he is not a scientist. I leave you to judge whether his concerns over antibiotic resistance were well founded or whether he is just a crank.

webTitle: John Humphrys on the organic revoution

fields.headline: Why the organic revolution had to happen
fields.standfirst: When British people farmed simply and ate plainly there was no need for organic produce. But fears over  pollution, pesticides, synthetic fertilisers,mad cow disease, growth-hormone injections, swine fever, salmonella, GM food and foot and mouth changed all that. Gradually we lost our faith in food
fields.trailText: In this extract from his compelling new book John Humphrys reveals how Britain's eating habits have been transformed by our mistrust of intensive farming and why a safe supper doesn't have to cost more than the one that might kill you
fields.body:
In this extract from his compelling new book John Humphrys reveals how Britain's eating habits have been transformed by our mistrust of intensive farming and why a safe supper doesn't have to cost more than the one that might kill you.

In the early Nineties when the full horror of BSE was becoming apparent many people were beginning to ask serious questions about the food on our tables and to worry about food in a way we had not done in our recent history. I thought then that we needed a proper national debate which addressed the most fundamental questions. Sadly, it took another great farming crisis to bring that debate about and it is unfolding now.

That crisis is, of course, the foot and mouth epidemic. The question on which it has focused attention - and which should have been addressed a long time ago - goes to the heart of Britain's food policy since the Second World War. Has the relentless drive for more and more cheap food proved to be a mistake?

The most powerful voices in the food industry scoff at even a hint of doubt. They tell us it is naive to raise the question. They remind us that choice is more varied and shopping for food has never been more convenient. Above all, they say, food is cheaper than it has ever been. The only alternative to the way we have been farming, producing and distributing our food for half a century is to return to some primitive form of agriculture and food production that would lead to desperate shortages, sky-high prices and disease-ridden animals. We would be back in the Middle Ages. Some talk darkly of malnourished children, even the return of diseases such as rickets.

Most of that is hysterical, self-serving nonsense. Malnutrition is a function of poverty or ignorance or both, not of the availability of food. I have spoken to doctors who worry about some of their young patients because they are fed a diet of junk food. Their parents have never cooked them a meal of fresh meat and vegetables in their short lives. That has nothing to do with the price of food. On the contrary, processed food is invariably more expensive than fresh vegetables. It is, to use the jargon of the day, a 'lifestyle' choice and one that is encouraged by the industry. Quite simply, there is more profit in a bag of crisps than in a pound of potatoes.

Nor is a return to 'primitive' farming practices the only alternative to factory farming and highly intensive agriculture. That is a gross insult to all those farmers who care deeply for the welfare of their animals and do not regard them as mere units of production. It also ignores the advances made in less intensive farming technologies. A growing number of farmers are finding ways of achieving good yields without tearing open yet another drum of chemicals or bag of synthetic fertiliser.

But the big question the industry and most politicians have been so reluctant to address is whether 'cheap' food is really cheap. To do so is to raise doubts about their judgment or even their motives. What price, for instance, should society put on the destruction of so much of our rural heritage, the loss of our water meadows and ancient hedges, the disappearance of so many songbirds?

It may be impossible to calculate that sort of thing in hard cash, but much else can be quantified. There are the taxes we pay to finance farming subsidies. There is the cost of cleaning chemical pollution from our drinking water. There are the consequences for the National Health Service of factory farmers abusing antibiotics. There is the possible impact on our health of chemical residues in our food.

There are the long-term effects of soil erosion and declining soil fertility. There is the terrible impact and vast cost of a tragedy such as BSE. And now, as I write, we are in the midst of another epidemic, foot and mouth disease. It would not be fair to say it is the direct result of intensive agriculture. But modern practices of food production and supply have enabled it to spread at a terrifying speed across the entire country.

Is it naive to raise questions about a food policy that has created such a legacy? I think not. But this is not a counsel of despair. There are many farmers and food producers and even politicians who accept that mistakes have been made and are searching for better ways of doing things. I believe the British people will insist on it. We are no longer prepared to take our food for granted. The nation wants a serious debate and there is no way of stopping it.

When the Chinese leader, Chou En-lai (1898-1976), was asked for his assessment of the effect of the French Revolution he paused for a moment and then said: 'It's too early to tell.' He may have been a shade too cautious, but you can see his point; history takes a long time to settle down. We think a particular action will have a particular consequence and years later, for a hundred reasons we had not even considered at the time, we discover we were wrong. There was a revolution in agriculture after the war - the birth of factory farming and industrial agriculture - and we are still assessing its effects because they continue to this day. But there has also been a counter-revolution of sorts in the past 15 years in the food industry. It is going to take a very long time before we can be sure of its effects because it, too, is still in progress. It is the organic revolution.

In 1981 it was just about possible to buy organic food in a Safeway supermarket - assuming you knew there was such a thing and assuming you wanted it very badly indeed. Four years later if you looked hard enough in one or two Sainsbury's or Waitrose stores you might find a few bruised apples or limp carrots with bits of soil still clinging to them on sale at silly prices. You wondered why the supermarket bothered and you wondered who would dream of buying the stuff.

Most supermarket managers looked on with a mixture of amusement and contempt. They said the days of muck and mystery had disappeared a long time ago and shoppers wanted their fruit and vegetables to be pristine, uniform and cheap. They did not want their apples to have blemishes on their skin; they had to be clean and shiny. Some supermarket bosses said sniffily that the quality of organic food could not be guaranteed. But 10 years later all the supermarkets were taking a serious interest. Within another five years they were fighting each other for a share of a market that was growing faster than any other sector in the industry. So what had happened to change things so dramatically?

It's easy enough to say what did not happen. There was no encouragement from our political leaders. They either did not know what was beginning to happen or they did not care. There was no great marketing drive by the big retailers. Any marketing expert will tell you that it's not difficult to persuade us to buy things if the budget is big enough. Not until many years later did the retailers start using organic food in their advertisements to tempt fickle shoppers. In terms of marketing, this was the quiet revolution.

As even Chou En-lai would concede, revolutions can succeed only if they have the support of a significant section of the population. They do not receive that support unless the people are unhappy with the status quo. So it was with food. There were enough people becoming a little uneasy about the quality and safety of the food they were buying from the supermarkets to spot that something was starting to happen. The reasons for the unease were mixed. Some people were worried about the use of pesticides. Some were offended by the worst excesses of factory farming and the effects it was having on the animals who suffered under it. Some were nervous about the growing number of food scares. And when those people saw organic food being offered in the supermarkets they winced at the higher cost but took a few apples or carrots home with them.

But they were still relatively few. Organic food had yet to break out of its niche market. It was growing, but it was still only for the more eccentric customers. It was hardly a subject that dominated the board meetings at Tesco or Sainsbury's. And then, one March afternoon in 1996, the Secretary of State for Health, Stephen Dorrell, stood up in the House of Commons to make a statement which would shatter the nation's confidence in our food. This was to prove the turning point. The quiet revolution was about to explode.

Four months earlier Mr Dorrell had been asked on television whether there was any connection between BSE and a new variant of an old disease, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease or CJD. He had said no there was no conceivable risk from eating British beef. Almost five years later Mr Dorrell was to tell me on the Today programme that he regretted ever having given that interview because he'd got it wrong. The message he delivered on that spring afternoon was a very different one indeed.

He told a packed and worried House that the 'most likely explanation' for the cases of CJD was indeed a link to BSE. MPs had been expecting bad news, but this was devastating. The implication was immediately obvious to everyone who heard him. Not only was mad cow disease wreaking havoc in the nation's dairy herds; there was a human equivalent of the disease and it was even more terrible. Every time we had eaten British beef in the past 10 years or more we had been putting our health at risk. There was no cure for the disease and it was always fatal. CJD could lie dormant in our unsuspecting bodies for a very long time. It might take 10, 15, 20 years or even longer to make its malignant presence felt. No one could predict how many people were already infected. It might be a handful. It might be a million.

Even now, all these years later, it is hard to forget the impact of that statement. Many of us remembered with a shudder the steaks we had grilled or the Sunday joints we had enjoyed. Far worse, we looked at our children and thought of the mincemeat we had made into sauces for their spaghetti or the hamburgers we had treated them to on a Saturday afternoon shopping expedition. Could we really have been poisoning our own children, condemning them to die from some hideous disease that we had never even known existed? It was scarcely credible.

The initial reaction was anger. We cursed the farmers who had forced their cows to behave like cannibals, then we cursed the arrogance and greed of the feed manufacturers and the renderers who had turned nature on its head by producing the wretched feed and not even telling the farmers what was in it unless they asked. Then we cursed the politicians and their civil servants who had been either uncaring or incompetent or secretive or all three.

It was at that point that many people decided they could no longer trust the food they were buying. Connections were made between cost and quality. There was one reason and one reason only for feeding ruminants on the ground-up brains and spines and bones of other animals. It was profit. The left-over bits of slaughtered animals cost the manufacturers relatively little and contained lots of protein. A cow fed on only her natural diet of grass and cereals produced nothing like as much milk as one fed on the concentrated food made from the left-overs of an abattoir. The manufacturers made more money and the farmers sold more milk and the price of food kept falling.

fields.bodyText: In this extract from his compelling new book John Humphrys reveals how Britain's eating habits have been transformed by our mistrust of intensive farming and why a safe supper doesn't have to cost more than the one that might kill you. In the early Nineties when the full horror of BSE was becoming apparent many people were beginning to ask serious questions about the food on our tables and to worry about food in a way we had not done in our recent history. I thought then that we needed a proper national debate which addressed the most fundamental questions. Sadly, it took another great farming crisis to bring that debate about and it is unfolding now. That crisis is, of course, the foot and mouth epidemic. The question on which it has focused attention - and which should have been addressed a long time ago - goes to the heart of Britain's food policy since the Second World War. Has the relentless drive for more and more cheap food proved to be a mistake? The most powerful voices in the food industry scoff at even a hint of doubt. They tell us it is naive to raise the question. They remind us that choice is more varied and shopping for food has never been more convenient. Above all, they say, food is cheaper than it has ever been. The only alternative to the way we have been farming, producing and distributing our food for half a century is to return to some primitive form of agriculture and food production that would lead to desperate shortages, sky-high prices and disease-ridden animals. We would be back in the Middle Ages. Some talk darkly of malnourished children, even the return of diseases such as rickets. Most of that is hysterical, self-serving nonsense. Malnutrition is a function of poverty or ignorance or both, not of the availability of food. I have spoken to doctors who worry about some of their young patients because they are fed a diet of junk food. Their parents have never cooked them a meal of fresh meat and vegetables in their short lives. That has nothing to do with the price of food. On the contrary, processed food is invariably more expensive than fresh vegetables. It is, to use the jargon of the day, a 'lifestyle' choice and one that is encouraged by the industry. Quite simply, there is more profit in a bag of crisps than in a pound of potatoes. Nor is a return to 'primitive' farming practices the only alternative to factory farming and highly intensive agriculture. That is a gross insult to all those farmers who care deeply for the welfare of their animals and do not regard them as mere units of production. It also ignores the advances made in less intensive farming technologies. A growing number of farmers are finding ways of achieving good yields without tearing open yet another drum of chemicals or bag of synthetic fertiliser. But the big question the industry and most politicians have been so reluctant to address is whether 'cheap' food is really cheap. To do so is to raise doubts about their judgment or even their motives. What price, for instance, should society put on the destruction of so much of our rural heritage, the loss of our water meadows and ancient hedges, the disappearance of so many songbirds? It may be impossible to calculate that sort of thing in hard cash, but much else can be quantified. There are the taxes we pay to finance farming subsidies. There is the cost of cleaning chemical pollution from our drinking water. There are the consequences for the National Health Service of factory farmers abusing antibiotics. There is the possible impact on our health of chemical residues in our food. There are the long-term effects of soil erosion and declining soil fertility. There is the terrible impact and vast cost of a tragedy such as BSE. And now, as I write, we are in the midst of another epidemic, foot and mouth disease. It would not be fair to say it is the direct result of intensive agriculture. But modern practices of food production and supply have enabled it to spread at a terrifying speed across the entire country. Is it naive to raise questions about a food policy that has created such a legacy? I think not. But this is not a counsel of despair. There are many farmers and food producers and even politicians who accept that mistakes have been made and are searching for better ways of doing things. I believe the British people will insist on it. We are no longer prepared to take our food for granted. The nation wants a serious debate and there is no way of stopping it. When the Chinese leader, Chou En-lai (1898-1976), was asked for his assessment of the effect of the French Revolution he paused for a moment and then said: 'It's too early to tell.' He may have been a shade too cautious, but you can see his point; history takes a long time to settle down. We think a particular action will have a particular consequence and years later, for a hundred reasons we had not even considered at the time, we discover we were wrong. There was a revolution in agriculture after the war - the birth of factory farming and industrial agriculture - and we are still assessing its effects because they continue to this day. But there has also been a counter-revolution of sorts in the past 15 years in the food industry. It is going to take a very long time before we can be sure of its effects because it, too, is still in progress. It is the organic revolution. In 1981 it was just about possible to buy organic food in a Safeway supermarket - assuming you knew there was such a thing and assuming you wanted it very badly indeed. Four years later if you looked hard enough in one or two Sainsbury's or Waitrose stores you might find a few bruised apples or limp carrots with bits of soil still clinging to them on sale at silly prices. You wondered why the supermarket bothered and you wondered who would dream of buying the stuff. Most supermarket managers looked on with a mixture of amusement and contempt. They said the days of muck and mystery had disappeared a long time ago and shoppers wanted their fruit and vegetables to be pristine, uniform and cheap. They did not want their apples to have blemishes on their skin; they had to be clean and shiny. Some supermarket bosses said sniffily that the quality of organic food could not be guaranteed. But 10 years later all the supermarkets were taking a serious interest. Within another five years they were fighting each other for a share of a market that was growing faster than any other sector in the industry. So what had happened to change things so dramatically? It's easy enough to say what did not happen. There was no encouragement from our political leaders. They either did not know what was beginning to happen or they did not care. There was no great marketing drive by the big retailers. Any marketing expert will tell you that it's not difficult to persuade us to buy things if the budget is big enough. Not until many years later did the retailers start using organic food in their advertisements to tempt fickle shoppers. In terms of marketing, this was the quiet revolution. As even Chou En-lai would concede, revolutions can succeed only if they have the support of a significant section of the population. They do not receive that support unless the people are unhappy with the status quo. So it was with food. There were enough people becoming a little uneasy about the quality and safety of the food they were buying from the supermarkets to spot that something was starting to happen. The reasons for the unease were mixed. Some people were worried about the use of pesticides. Some were offended by the worst excesses of factory farming and the effects it was having on the animals who suffered under it. Some were nervous about the growing number of food scares. And when those people saw organic food being offered in the supermarkets they winced at the higher cost but took a few apples or carrots home with them. But they were still relatively few. Organic food had yet to break out of its niche market. It was growing, but it was still only for the more eccentric customers. It was hardly a subject that dominated the board meetings at Tesco or Sainsbury's. And then, one March afternoon in 1996, the Secretary of State for Health, Stephen Dorrell, stood up in the House of Commons to make a statement which would shatter the nation's confidence in our food. This was to prove the turning point. The quiet revolution was about to explode. Four months earlier Mr Dorrell had been asked on television whether there was any connection between BSE and a new variant of an old disease, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease or CJD. He had said no there was no conceivable risk from eating British beef. Almost five years later Mr Dorrell was to tell me on the Today programme that he regretted ever having given that interview because he'd got it wrong. The message he delivered on that spring afternoon was a very different one indeed. He told a packed and worried House that the 'most likely explanation' for the cases of CJD was indeed a link to BSE. MPs had been expecting bad news, but this was devastating. The implication was immediately obvious to everyone who heard him. Not only was mad cow disease wreaking havoc in the nation's dairy herds; there was a human equivalent of the disease and it was even more terrible. Every time we had eaten British beef in the past 10 years or more we had been putting our health at risk. There was no cure for the disease and it was always fatal. CJD could lie dormant in our unsuspecting bodies for a very long time. It might take 10, 15, 20 years or even longer to make its malignant presence felt. Could we really have been poisoning our own children, condemning them to die from some hideous disease that we had never even known existed? It was scarcely credible. The initial reaction was anger. We cursed the farmers who had forced their cows to behave like cannibals, then we cursed the arrogance and greed of the feed manufacturers and the renderers who had turned nature on its head by producing the wretched feed and not even telling the farmers what was in it unless they asked. Then we cursed the politicians and their civil servants who had been either uncaring or incompetent or secretive or all three. It was at that point that many people decided they could no longer trust the food they were buying. Connections were made between cost and quality. There was one reason and one reason only for feeding ruminants on the ground-up brains and spines and bones of other animals. It was profit. The left-over bits of slaughtered animals cost the manufacturers relatively little and contained lots of protein. webTitle: OFM Interview: Marco Pierre White (part two)

fields.headline: Marco: Man and boy (part two)
fields.standfirst: OK, there were the raging tantrums, the womanising, the celebrity bust-ups. But that vintage Marco Pierre White was  the fruit of a  miserable childhood. Now, he says, he's all grown up, a father, a faithful husband, happy to be back in the kitchen teaching fresh-faced recruits - and it's ages since he's had to throw anyone out for wearing bicycle clips

fields.body:
Then we move on to class, and the types of people he occasionally stalks and fishes with. 'I like them, why not? I just like people. Mind you, some of your nobs can be truly thick, can't they? I was with one recently, very nice guy, but we started talking about Di and Dodi and Al-Fayed and that mob, and he suddenly asks, "Yeees and what's old Dodi up to these days anyway?" I thought I'd misheard, so got him to ask again; same thing, what's old Dodi knocking about at. Well, I said, I don't really know. I mean, I think the fucker's still dead, isn't he?'

And genuine fun, too, on food, about which he could probably talk forever. Memories of his childhood, growing up on a council estate in Leeds, and the crab sandwiches in Whitley, and the proper, whorled, purple meat you could buy and bone, and the eight types of bacon in the butcher's in Bridlington, and his first real meal out, with a date, to Oliver's in Harrogate, in 1980. 'Dublin Bay prawns, as they were called then, and Beef Wellington in madeira sauce. It was £69, which was a lot of money then. It was fantastic.' And the nonsense talked about food in Britain over the past 20 years. 'Cuisine nouvelle was just a concept, and one which, crucially, the English managed to get wrong. I mean, if you run a restaurant, you've got to feed people, not make pretty little pictures on plates to make up for your lack of ability.'

What, I wonder, would his own favourite meal be, if he'd just come from a year on a desert island? 'Easy: I'd have roast chicken. To start, a delicious bowl of soup; actually, a bowl of butter-bean broth that Mati's mother makes. You peel off the fat of belly-pork and spread it on toast, like butter. It's delicious, and fairly bad for you. Then roast chicken with bread sauce, chipolatas, bacon. And a crumble to finish. Heaven.'

And the diet-fad bollocks and the over-fancy presentation bollocks. He remembers being asked by a reader of his Sunday Mirror cooking column how to make low-fat pastry (pastry is, he says incidentally, the hardest thing for a chef to make; 'you've actually got to know a good bit about chemistry to get it truly right'). His reply, which was printed, still sends him into mild paroxysms of delight: 'First, make normal pastry. Then, roll it out really thin'

'I mean, it's not all that hard, none of it. Attention to detail. Good ingredients. Simply cooked. I'm a classicist. Something being simple should never stop it being really good.

'I massively object, for instance, to your Café Rouge and Café Flo and Chez Gerard. I mean, they're appalling. It honestly isn't that hard to serve good food at affordable prices. But they're an insult to all of us - because they're run by accountants, not restaurateurs. In fact, that's the third bit of the recipe. Good ingredients, cooked simply - and kept as far away as humanly possible from the fucking accountants.'

And, on cue, his waiters arrive to allow him to illustrate his point. One with water, and a shimmer of glasses; one with bread in all its baskets; one with new ashtrays; and he waves them away quietly, and with a certain courtesy. 'Just pour the water. We don't want bread. Ashtray's fine. Please leave space on the table. For us to talk, and smoke, and drink. Many thanks.' They melt away obligingly: paid enough, tipped enough, respected enough; sanguine with all the wants of the customer if these are expressed with sufficient grace.

And I remember those dour nights in Café Whatever, the £74.50 bill clacking out insultingly loudly at 11.10pm for something you can't remember on a tiny round table for two crammed with seven glasses and a welter of plastic butter pats and an awkward Franglais menu in a holder designed to be knocked ever sideways across your stupidly vast bowl of chips by the hassled sleeve of the underpaid waitress, and 'Femmes' et 'Hommes' with their niggling job-lot corporate taps and deeply unFrench Cif, and finally getting up to fetch your own ashtray from beside the payphone after asking only nine times; and I get, wholly, his point.

It's simply about control. Control, and respect. From the customer. From the restaurateur, the waiter, the chef. This, Marco says, is a contract. One of us is paying hard, one of us is working hard; so let's respect each other, and let's each enjoy it as much as possible: which is, when it works, rather a lot.

'Control, and respect.'

Marco shrugs as he says the words. It is a week earlier, and we are fishing, down on a private stretch of the River Test by Southampton, with his youngest son, also Marco, 5, nearby. He is talking about restaurants. He might as easily be talking about his fishing. He might as easily be talking about his anything, for control is a huge part of Marco's life. I see it in the tiniest things. In the way he took control of the huge cooked breakfast an hour earlier, insisting we try the black pudding, ladling out baked beans with a care normally reserved for caviar. I see it, later in the restaurant, when he creases his napkin just-so, sideways, in two, and places it on the edge of the table, under his plate, to catch crumbs and keep the table-linen clean, and simply makes sure he doesn't drop anything on his clothes. Which he wears with control: the hat, from Lock's of St James (naturally), placed with slow attention on his shaggy mane before he walks to ask the birthdaying ladies if they've enjoyed their meal (and, incidentally, had they heard the one about).

Control of design: of the little fish-shaped ashtrays in the Mirabelle, and the huge coral and the Venetian glass bowls he found on the Fulham Road for the Belvedere, and how they'll blend exactly with the chinoiserie he's planning to bring in ('He sees it all before it happens,' says Mati. 'I can't see it at all. But he just gets it somehow right'). Control over the smallest things. 'See,' he whispers as our food arrives - 'we lay it down with both hands, hands under the plate, so you get no thumbprints on the top.' Even during his honeymoon, he explains, he was thinking of the little things: being taken round the kitchens of famous Harry's Bar he noticed the peach-juice sachets defrosting in the sink and made a note of the local supplier: these are now flown in to London to make his Bellinis. Whether boning a side of venison or threading hooks through bait, his every action is soft, secure, measured.

We watch him fish. He has set up four lines. He has watched them for six hours. Not a twitch, not a judder, not a flick. Not from the water, nor from Marco. Quietly, resolutely, fascinatingly, his stubble grew on. The fish, it turned out, were spawning.

The only movement came when we would wander half-hourly, silently, the ten yards back to the Merc for yet another cigarette. There was more dynamism from the water beetles, and the occasional splash from fish with much else on their minds. The highlight of the day, in terms of action, had come when Marco junior, now five, fell into a wash of nettles and tried, bravely but in vain, not to cry. We chased dock leaves. Marco senior cooed over his youngest - 'Marrrrrcoo!', with the warmest Italian burr, or even 'darrrling!' - but he cooed quietly, not to disturb the shagging fish. We caught nothing, all day. But Marco was elated: he knew it was because the fish were spawning that day, and he'd never seen them spawning before.

'So I've learnt something else. We should never stop learning, ever.' Okay, I concede over another cigarette, as young Marco, his knees lovingly cleaned and patched, pores over his GameBoy in the front of the car, strangely bored with the uncatchable shagging nonexistent fish. What should the customer learn? What are Marco's lessons to the customer?

'The majority of customers are smart, nice, well-behaved, knowledgeable. There's only a few who want to take advantage of the situation. So. If you don't like your table, say so. If you want your steak well done, just say so. Tell them things. Tell them what's wrong with the table, or that it's your wife's birthday. As long as you do it with courtesy, and respect, the restaurant should respect you back. Things do go wrong, of course they go wrong. And we can try but we can't cover everything; it's sometimes up to the customer to point things out. Far better that than they have their night spoilt and go away moaning. The only thing that truly annoys me is people turning up very late or very early that's a different thing. Spare a thought: I mean, we've got something like 200 meals being prepared that night, all to be served just-so; timing gets a bit crucial. Do I complain in restaurants? Well, actually, no, not now. I just don't go back.

'I like all sets of customers, though they're all different. The Jews, for instance, always ask for the same table. Never mind if there's only two when they were six last week, they still want the same table. The Japs want the bill instantly, soon as they nod for it. The Americans well, they're just children, aren't they! The best, in a way, are the Arabs. They love to feel attended to, and they're polite in themselves, and they reward good service; there are boys in my restaurants who have lifted £1,000 tips at the end of a night.

'But, wait, that gives the wrong impression the thing about my restaurants is that they're mean to be about affordable luxury. That's the future of dining. Everyone should be able to go. All I'm trying to do is give people something special, appeal to that side of them that loves good things. I've got them myself now. I didn't set out to; I only started making good money a few years ago. Until 34 I was pretty broke, I used to put everything back into the business; the food was always the thing.

'But now, I don't have to prove anything any more. I can give something back. You should never forget where you've come from, and if you've been lucky you should give some back.' A rudely plopping fish interrupts his reverie just before he anoints himself with Papal infallibility.

He handed back his Michelin stars when he stopped cooking. He does work in his kitchens now, but only intermittently, popping in unannounced to check consistency or teach new recruits; his greatest skill, he says, his favourite, is boning. Did it hurt, giving the stars back?

'Achieving three stars is exciting. Maintaining three stars is pretty boring. The menu doesn't change, for instance. But the fear is still there, because to lose a star would just be just devastating. So it didn't really hurt, not in the end. Also, Michelin are changing. They lost their old inspector in Britain, a marvellous man, and some of their judgments these days well, Michelin like the frills as much as the food, and I think that's missing the point . A lot more restaurants in this town should in my opinion have at least one Michelin star. And yet they'd given one to the Oriental at the Dorchester - actually it lost it this year - when there's far better Oriental food, really well sourced, at some little places in Chinatown. They've now devalued their entire currency. Part of the reason I gave my three stars back was that they didn't mean that much any more. I won Chef of the Decade five years ago: voted by 1,800 chefs, all starred, and that was worth it, that meant something. But a lot of the Michelin and Egon Ronay stuff is bollocks, it's just PR for them.'

And little Marco is back with us, tugging at sleeves. His father coos his name, and he answers back, grinning, 'It's not Marco. It's Mark.' His father smiles; it's a conversation they've had before, as he had himself with his own parents. I look down at little Marco, and ask him, 'Okay, if you're just Mark, then what's Daddy's name? He beams back, proudly.

'That's easy. Marco Pierre White.'

Graham, Clive, Marco Pierre, Craig. Four sons of an alcoholic chef called Frank White and an Italian beauty called Maria Rosa, growing up on a Leeds council estate. Maria had been allowed to name just one of the boys. Guess which one.

He hated the name at the time, he says, but knows it's done him good. We are in his car, post-Belvedere, replete, being driven to the Mirabelle, and we are finally getting to the nub of things, to the 'stuff' he mentioned earlier, the stuff he hadn't dealt with. His driver and aide-de-camp, Mr Ishi, fiddles with the stereo to put on Marco's favourite CD and the music wafts in fittingly with the Yquem fumes and the confessions. It is 'The Immigrant' by Nino Rota. Better known, perhaps, as the theme music to The Godfather.

He lost his mother when he was six. She was 38 (the same age as Marco when he stopped cooking). 'And I spent the next three decades confused. I thought I was my father's son alone, and did everything to try to impress him, and nothing was ever enough. He just wanted the best, I suppose, but he had a hard Yorkshire way of showing it. As a child, I just took it as rejection, of course. And an awful lot of my motivation - all those early years, my twenties, this reputation I've got - came about because I was trying to prove myself to him, to prove a point.' He stops talking for a little. Earlier, he had made one allusion to those times, while we were discussing whisky, recalling, very quietly, 'It was after whisky my father would beat us, just after the whisky'.

In the end, it was too late: his father was dying of cancer when Marco won his first star, and couldn't really take in the news. And Marco was, finally, changing anyway, coming out of his shadow. 'Towards the end, I remember saying to him, "Now I no longer fear you I can enjoy your company".

'And then, I began to realise things. I started, at 31, to want to know who my mother was, for instance.' He dug out relatives, he travelled to Italy, he asked questions. 'And I found out enough to realise some things. She was so young, so tragic - but she was also a fantastic cook, with a love of art. She sounded wonderful. And I suddenly realised something, something huge. I am my mother's son, not my father's. That is what I'd been getting wrong all those years. And that's what changed me, calmed me. It was like seeing a light. It's not just coming out of the kitchen, or growing older, or fatherhood well, it's all of them, but that was the big, big change. That's what you have to understand if you want to know who the real Marco is now.'

The music has begun swelling towards its thematic, tearful climax. 'Had my father been Italian and my mother English it wouldn't have been the same. It's like being a Jew.' The strings are two seconds from bursting in. Marco pauses, for half a beat, thinking deeply. 'It's as they say: you only have one mother in life; you can have a thousand fathers.' And in the music sweeps: music of death, and loss, and love, and food, and Italy, and ambition, and control, and rebirth. Thank you, Marco. You couldn't have timed it better yourself.

Marco: a life in words

'I have learnt three things in my life. I have learnt that self-control is true power. I have learnt that a clear conscience is true strength. And that good friends and family are true wealth'

'I believe in taking advantage of other people's misfortunes'

'I never make the first move but if someone even hurts me a little, I will descend on them'

'I didn't want to be a chef, I simply wanted the freedom and a good time'

'It was ten months before I threw out my first customer. But I was like a serial killer. Once I'd got the taste for it, I couldn't stop'

Marco's calf's liver and bacon

Calf's liver is fine and delicate in flavour, and much used in Italian cooking (particularly Fegato alla veneziana). Here is a more traditionally English way of serving it. Serves 4

vegetable oil
12 sage leaves
salt and freshly ground white pepper
4 small lettuces, Cos or Baby Gem
carrot, celeriac, onion and celery stalk, peeled and finely diced
25g unsalted butter
250ml veal stock
8 very thin slices streaky bacon
plain flour
4 x 150g thin slices calf's liver
4 portions pomme purée

1. Deep-fry the sage leaves in hot vegetable oil, then drain well on kitchen paper. Season with a little salt.

2. Make the braised lettuce: halve the lettuces and blanch them quickly in boiling salted water, then refresh in cold water and drain well. Sweat the vegetable dice in the butter until they colour. Place the lettuce and diced vegetables in a pot and add the stock and some seasoning. Bring to the boil, cover, and braise for 10 to 15 minutes until tender.

3. Lightly grill the bacon without colouring.

4. Season and flour the liver, dusting off any excess. Pan-fry in 100ml hot oil until pink, a minute or so on each side depending on the thickness.

5. To serve, place the liver on a heap of braised lettuce, with two slices of bacon on top , and decorate with the sage. Serve with pomme purée.

 This recipe was taken from The Mirabelle Cookbook, Ebury Press.
