His reply, which was printed, still sends him into mild paroxysms of delight: 'First, make normal pastry. Then, roll it out really thin' 'I mean, it's not all that hard, none of it. Attention to detail. Good ingredients. Simply cooked. I'm a classicist. Something being simple should never stop it being really good. 'I massively object, for instance, to your Café Rouge and Café Flo and Chez Gerard. I mean, they're appalling. It honestly isn't that hard to serve good food at affordable prices. But they're an insult to all of us - because they're run by accountants, not restaurateurs. In fact, that's the third bit of the recipe. Good ingredients, cooked simply - and kept as far away as humanly possible from the fucking accountants.' And, on cue, his waiters arrive to allow him to illustrate his point. One with water, and a shimmer of glasses; one with bread in all its baskets; one with new ashtrays; and he waves them away quietly, and with a certain courtesy. 'Just pour the water. We don't want bread. Ashtray's fine. Please leave space on the table. For us to talk, and smoke, and drink. Many thanks.' They melt away obligingly: paid enough, tipped enough, respected enough; sanguine with all the wants of the customer if these are expressed with sufficient grace. And I remember those dour nights in Café Whatever, the £74.50 bill clacking out insultingly loudly at 11.10pm for something you can't remember on a tiny round table for two crammed with seven glasses and a welter of plastic butter pats and an awkward Franglais menu in a holder designed to be knocked ever sideways across your stupidly vast bowl of chips by the hassled sleeve of the underpaid waitress, and 'Femmes' et 'Hommes' with their niggling job-lot corporate taps and deeply unFrench Cif, and finally getting up to fetch your own ashtray from beside the payphone after asking only nine times; and I get, wholly, his point. It's simply about control. Control, and respect. From the customer. From the restaurateur, the waiter, the chef. This, Marco says, is a contract. One of us is paying hard, one of us is working hard; so let's respect each other, and let's each enjoy it as much as possible: which is, when it works, rather a lot. 'Control, and respect.' Marco shrugs as he says the words. It is a week earlier, and we are fishing, down on a private stretch of the River Test by Southampton, with his youngest son, also Marco, 5, nearby. He is talking about restaurants. He might as easily be talking about his fishing. He might as easily be talking about his anything, for control is a huge part of Marco's life. I see it in the tiniest things. In the way he took control of the huge cooked breakfast an hour earlier, insisting we try the black pudding, ladling out baked beans with a care normally reserved for caviar. I see it, later in the restaurant, when he creases his napkin just-so, sideways, in two, and places it on the edge of the table, under his plate, to catch crumbs and keep the table-linen clean, and simply makes sure he doesn't drop anything on his clothes. Which he wears with control: the hat, from Lock's of St James (naturally), placed with slow attention on his shaggy mane before he walks to ask the birthdaying ladies if they've enjoyed their meal (and, incidentally, had they heard the one about). Control of design: of the little fish-shaped ashtrays in the Mirabelle, and the huge coral and the Venetian glass bowls he found on the Fulham Road for the Belvedere, and how they'll blend exactly with the chinoiserie he's planning to bring in ('He sees it all before it happens,' says Mati. 'I can't see it at all. But he just gets it somehow right'). Control over the smallest things. 'See,' he whispers as our food arrives - 'we lay it down with both hands, hands under the plate, so you get no thumbprints on the top.' Even during his honeymoon, he explains, he was thinking of the little things: being taken round the kitchens of famous Harry's Bar he noticed the peach-juice sachets defrosting in the sink and made a note of the local supplier: these are now flown in to London to make his Bellinis. Whether boning a side of venison or threading hooks through bait, his every action is soft, secure, measured. We watch him fish. He has set up four lines. He has watched them for six hours. Not a twitch, not a judder, not a flick. Not from the water, nor from Marco. Quietly, resolutely, fascinatingly, his stubble grew on. The fish, it turned out, were spawning. The only movement came when we would wander half-hourly, silently, the ten yards back to the Merc for yet another cigarette. There was more dynamism from the water beetles, and the occasional splash from fish with much else on their minds. The highlight of the day, in terms of action, had come when Marco junior, now five, fell into a wash of nettles and tried, bravely but in vain, not to cry. We chased dock leaves. Marco senior cooed over his youngest - 'Marrrrrcoo!', with the warmest Italian burr, or even 'darrrling!' - but he cooed quietly, not to disturb the shagging fish. We caught nothing, all day. But Marco was elated: he knew it was because the fish were spawning that day, and he'd never seen them spawning before. 'So I've learnt something else. We should never stop learning, ever.' Okay, I concede over another cigarette, as young Marco, his knees lovingly cleaned and patched, pores over his GameBoy in the front of the car, strangely bored with the uncatchable shagging nonexistent fish. What should the customer learn? What are Marco's lessons to the customer? 'The majority of customers are smart, nice, well-behaved, knowledgeable. There's only a few who want to take advantage of the situation. So. If you don't like your table, say so. If you want your steak well done, just say so. Tell them things. Tell them what's wrong with the table, or that it's your wife's birthday. As long as you do it with courtesy, and respect, the restaurant should respect you back. Things do go wrong, of course they go wrong. And we can try but we can't cover everything; it's sometimes up to the customer to point things out. Far better that than they have their night spoilt and go away moaning. The only thing that truly annoys me is people turning up very late or very early that's a different thing. Spare a thought: I mean, we've got something like 200 meals being prepared that night, all to be served just-so; timing gets a bit crucial. Do I complain in restaurants? Well, actually, no, not now. I just don't go back. 'I like all sets of customers, though they're all different. The Jews, for instance, always ask for the same table. Never mind if there's only two when they were six last week, they still want the same table. The Japs want the bill instantly, soon as they nod for it. The Americans well, they're just children, aren't they! The best, in a way, are the Arabs. They love to feel attended to, and they're polite in themselves, and they reward good service; there are boys in my restaurants who have lifted £1,000 tips at the end of a night. 'But, wait, that gives the wrong impression the thing about my restaurants is that they're mean to be about affordable luxury. That's the future of dining. Everyone should be able to go. All I'm trying to do is give people something special, appeal to that side of them that loves good things. I've got them myself now. I didn't set out to; I only started making good money a few years ago. Until 34 I was pretty broke, I used to put everything back into the business; the food was always the thing. 'But now, I don't have to prove anything any more. I can give something back. You should never forget where you've come from, and if you've been lucky you should give some back.' A rudely plopping fish interrupts his reverie just before he anoints himself with Papal infallibility. He handed back his Michelin stars when he stopped cooking. He does work in his kitchens now, but only intermittently, popping in unannounced to check consistency or teach new recruits; his greatest skill, he says, his favourite, is boning. Did it hurt, giving the stars back? 'Achieving three stars is exciting. Maintaining three stars is pretty boring. The menu doesn't change, for instance. But the fear is still there, because to lose a star would just be just devastating. So it didn't really hurt, not in the end. Also, Michelin are changing. They lost their old inspector in Britain, a marvellous man, and some of their judgments these days well, Michelin like the frills as much as the food, and I think that's missing the point . A lot more restaurants in this town should in my opinion have at least one Michelin star. And yet they'd given one to the Oriental at the Dorchester - actually it lost it this year - when there's far better Oriental food, really well sourced, at some little places in Chinatown. They've now devalued their entire currency. Part of the reason I gave my three stars back was that they didn't mean that much any more. I won Chef of the Decade five years ago: voted by 1,800 chefs, all starred, and that was worth it, that meant something. But a lot of the Michelin and Egon Ronay stuff is bollocks, it's just PR for them.' And little Marco is back with us, tugging at sleeves. His father coos his name, and he answers back, grinning, 'It's not Marco. It's Mark.' His father smiles; it's a conversation they've had before, as he had himself with his own parents. I look down at little Marco, and ask him, 'Okay, if you're just Mark, then what's Daddy's name? He beams back, proudly. 'That's easy. Marco Pierre White.' Graham, Clive, Marco Pierre, Craig. Four sons of an alcoholic chef called Frank White and an Italian beauty called Maria Rosa, growing up on a Leeds council estate. Maria had been allowed to name just one of the boys. Guess which one. He hated the name at the time, he says, but knows it's done him good. We are in his car, post-Belvedere, replete, being driven to the Mirabelle, and we are finally getting to the nub of things, to the 'stuff' he mentioned earlier, the stuff he hadn't dealt with. His driver and aide-de-camp, Mr Ishi, fiddles with the stereo to put on Marco's favourite CD and the music wafts in fittingly with the Yquem fumes and the confessions. It is 'The Immigrant' by Nino Rota. Better known, perhaps, as the theme music to The Godfather. He lost his mother when he was six. She was 38 (the same age as Marco when he stopped cooking). 'And I spent the next three decades confused. I thought I was my father's son alone, and did everything to try to impress him, and nothing was ever enough. He just wanted the best, I suppose, but he had a hard Yorkshire way of showing it. As a child, I just took it as rejection, of course. And an awful lot of my motivation - all those early years, my twenties, this reputation I've got - came about because I was trying to prove myself to him, to prove a point.' He stops talking for a little. Earlier, he had made one allusion to those times, while we were discussing whisky, recalling, very quietly, 'It was after whisky my father would beat us, just after the whisky'. In the end, it was too late: his father was dying of cancer when Marco won his first star, and couldn't really take in the news. And Marco was, finally, changing anyway, coming out of his shadow. 'Towards the end, I remember saying to him, "Now I no longer fear you I can enjoy your company". 'And then, I began to realise things. I started, at 31, to want to know who my mother was, for instance.' He dug out relatives, he travelled to Italy, he asked questions. 'And I found out enough to realise some things. She was so young, so tragic - but she was also a fantastic cook, with a love of art. She sounded wonderful. And I suddenly realised something, something huge. I am my mother's son, not my father's. That is what I'd been getting wrong all those years. And that's what changed me, calmed me. It was like seeing a light. It's not just coming out of the kitchen, or growing older, or fatherhood well, it's all of them, but that was the big, big change. That's what you have to understand if you want to know who the real Marco is now.' The music has begun swelling towards its thematic, tearful climax. 'Had my father been Italian and my mother English it wouldn't have been the same. It's like being a Jew.' The strings are two seconds from bursting in. Marco pauses, for half a beat, thinking deeply. 'It's as they say: you only have one mother in life; you can have a thousand fathers.' And in the music sweeps: music of death, and loss, and love, and food, and Italy, and ambition, and control, and rebirth. Thank you, Marco. You couldn't have timed it better yourself. Marco: a life in words 'I have learnt three things in my life. I have learnt that self-control is true power. I have learnt that a clear conscience is true strength. And that good friends and family are true wealth' 'I believe in taking advantage of other people's misfortunes' 'I never make the first move but if someone even hurts me a little, I will descend on them' 'I didn't want to be a chef, I simply wanted the freedom and a good time' 'It was ten months before I threw out my first customer. But I was like a serial killer. Once I'd got the taste for it, I couldn't stop' Marco's calf's liver and bacon Calf's liver is fine and delicate in flavour, and much used in Italian cooking (particularly Fegato alla veneziana). Here is a more traditionally English way of serving it. Serves 4 vegetable oil 12 sage leaves salt and freshly ground white pepper 4 small lettuces, Cos or Baby Gem carrot, celeriac, onion and celery stalk, peeled and finely diced 25g unsalted butter 250ml veal stock 8 very thin slices streaky bacon plain flour 4 x 150g thin slices calf's liver 4 portions pomme purée 1. Deep-fry the sage leaves in hot vegetable oil, then drain well on kitchen paper. Season with a little salt. 2. Make the braised lettuce: halve the lettuces and blanch them quickly in boiling salted water, then refresh in cold water and drain well. Sweat the vegetable dice in the butter until they colour. Place the lettuce and diced vegetables in a pot and add the stock and some seasoning. Bring to the boil, cover, and braise for 10 to 15 minutes until tender. 3. Lightly grill the bacon without colouring. 4. Season and flour the liver, dusting off any excess. Pan-fry in 100ml hot oil until pink, a minute or so on each side depending on the thickness. 5. To serve, place the liver on a heap of braised lettuce, with two slices of bacon on top , and decorate with the sage. Serve with pomme purée.  This recipe was taken from The Mirabelle Cookbook, Ebury Press.

fields.headline: What's in your basket?
fields.standfirst: Josie Lawrence, this month's guest shopper, reveals her favourite food fads while  nutritionist Jane Clarke gives it the once-over
fields.trailText: Josie Lawrence, this month's guest shopper, reveals her favourite food fads while nutritionist Jane Clarke gives it the once-over
fields.body:
Every morning I have porridge oats. I like it really thick, almost like a slab. I spread Marmite on toast as thick as jam. My mum used to love Marmite, but I couldn't even stand the smell. I grew to like it when I went through puberty. I always buy honey, the clear runny type. Sometimes I put it on my face to soften and refresh it but I mainly buy it to have in my herb tea - camomile really relaxes me, and I drink it all day.

I always have salmon in any form really - smoked, tinned, grilled. I marinade it in a little teriyaki sauce and then cook it in foil. I also like to cook a roast chicken and then I pick at it all week. I'm also mad about peas, especially tinned mushy peas. My favorite carbohydrate is oven chips, - I get the healthy ones with only 5% fat. I usually keep a few cans of Mackeson's stout in the fridge. I love to have a little half pint with my dinner. It's sweeter than Guinness and it feels medicinal. I've always loved apples, any sort, as long as they're crunchy. I've discovered Benecol Light cheese spread. I slap it on a baked potato or spread it on Ryvita. For comfort food I don't think anything can beat a good old plain Cadbury's chocolate bar. I get very suspect about all these products that advertise themselves as being 'fat free' when, if you look at the ingredients they are stuffed with sugar. I think that if you are going to have sugar you might as well have a bar of chocolate. I also love wine, strong fruity wines where only a glass or two and you feel very relaxed.

Red wine
Red wine can keep the heart healthy by increasing the body's production of 'good' cholesterol and providing it with such antioxidants as quercitin and procyanidin, which inhibit two of the steps in the chain of events that leads to the production of fatty plaques and hence blocked blood vessels. Too much alcohol, however, can send your energy levels crashing, upset your mood, disrupt your sleep and increase your risk of developing liver disease.

Benecol cheese spread
Many people buy Benecol products because of the evidence that their plant esters can slightly improve the blood-fat profiles of people who have cholesterol problems. Yet not only are they expensive, but I prefer other nutritional ways of reducing your risk of developing heart disease. One of the best is to ensure that your intake of monounsaturated fats is high by regularly eating oily fish, peanuts, almonds and walnuts, as well as using olive oil or other vegetable oils. If, like Josie, you crave the taste of cheese, top a slice of fibre-rich, wholemeal bread with a sliver of naturally lower-fat cheese like Gouda.

Chicken
In common with all protein-rich foods, chicken contains amino acids that can stimulate the body to generate endorphins like serotonin that make you feel happier (a useful quality in Josie's profession) and more energetic. As well as being naturally low in fat and protein-packed, chicken doesn't prompt the body to produce 'bad' cholesterol, making it a healthy choice for people who are trying to lose weight. Chicken also contains high levels of zinc, the mineral that is vital for the maintenance of an efficient immune system and robust libido. I would urge everyone to buy organic, free-range chicken, which usually tastes far better than chicken that has been intensively farmed.

Mackeson stout
A point in stout's favour is that it frequently contains half the alcohol content of wine. Stout contains a few B vitamins and a little iron, giving credence to the old wives' tale that a glass of stout is a good tonic.

Porridge oats
Oats are extremely high in fibre, making them one of the healthiest foods you could eat. They also contain a prebiotic agent called beta glucan, which encourages the growth of probiotic(healthy) bacteria which in turn stimulates the production of cancer-fighting substances. Because oats have a lower gluten content than wheat, people who have a gluten intolerance can safely enjoy a bowl of porridge or biscuits made with oats rather than flour.

Mushy peas
Although fresh peas contain some vitamins and minerals, by the time they've been processed, few nutrients are left other than fibre. Fibre, however, plays an important role in keeping your digestive system healthy, and since mushy peas are soft, they're usually better for people who have digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome, ulcerative colitis and diverticulitis, than fresh peas.

Herbal teas
You're probably tired of hearing that your body needs 2.5 litres water a day, but it's nevertheless true. Brewing herbal teas can be one of the best ways of jazzing up water and they often have inherent healing properties. Camomile acts as an effective destresser and sleep-inducer, while mint soothes an acidic gut and aids digestion.

Marmite
Marmite-lovers, particularly vegetarians and vegans, benefit from its high vitamin B content, vitamins that are mainly found in foods of animal origin. Because it contains high levels of salt, Josie should eat potassium-rich foods, such as fresh fruits and vegetables, as well as drink lots of water.

Low-fat oven chips
Low-fat oven chips are both less hassle to cook and significantly lower in calories than conventional, deep-fried chips. Despite their 5 per cent fat content, they still contain more calories than jacket potatoes and other non-fried foods, however, so think twice before piling them onto your plate.

Cox's eating apples
Although an apple contains only 6mg of vitamin C per 100g, it can pack as much antioxidant punch as three 500mg vitamin C tablets because, unlike the tablets, it contains plant (or phyto-) nutrients and other powerful antioxidants. Its fibre can kick-start a lazy gut, while its nutrients can stimulate the body to produce substances that are particularly effective in reducing incidences of cancer of the digestive system. If eaten as part of the same meal, an apple can cushion the body's absorption of animal fats (in cheese, for instance), as well as providing a quick, convenient and energising snack.

Organic honey
Although organic honey provides your body with a generous dose of energy-raising sugar, it has the same potential downsides as all types of refined sugar, including weight gain and dental cares. When consumed on an empty stomach, honey can send your energy levels soaring, at the same time, however, stimulating your pancreas to produce insulin, the hormone that will bring them rapidly down again, making you feel shaky. It's therefore best eaten with a fibre-containing food, like wholemeal, rather than white, toast.

 Josie Lawrence is to replace Elaine Paige as Anna in The London Palladium's The King and I from 24 April.

fields.headline: She came, she saw...
fields.standfirst: When Annie Hawes stumbled upon a  wrecked cottage in the Italian hills, she upped sticks  from her Shepherd's Bush flat to pursue a rustic fantasy of  sundrenched views, wild asparagus and grow-your-own olives. Fifteen years later, she's written a book about life, love, the locals - and of course lunch  - in Liguria
fields.trailText: When Annie Hawes stumbled upon a wrecked cottage in the Italian hills, she upped sticks from her Shepherd's Bush flat to pursue a rustic fantasy of sundrenched views, wild asparagus and grow-your-own olives. Fifteen years later, she's written a book about life, love, the locals - and of course lunch - in Liguria.
fields.body:
It was the English obsession with going for a walk that landed Annie Hawes in trouble. She and her sister Lucy were scrambling up a Ligurian hillside under the broiling Italian sun when they spotted a tumbledown house. While Lucy ate cherries off the tree on the terrace, Annie climbed in through a loose shutter to explore. Her immediate reaction was inevitable: 'I want it very badly. It ought to be mine.'

Unbeknown to the girls they had been observed by a neighbour tending his olives. Frank the Knife rightly surmised they must be the English girls employed down in the valley to graft Pattrucho's roses; after all nobody but an English or German would go for a walk in the middle of the day making quite so much noise. Ever the wheeler-dealer, Frank knew his neighbour Pompeo had little use for his old rustica, so he stepped in to introduce himself...

Thus it came about that 15 years ago, despite their genuine protestations at being broke, Annie and Lucy acquired a house, two wells and an olive grove for £2,000. 'After all,' argued Frank, 'Pattrucho has just paid you your month's wages and that could be the deposit.' They were helpless in the teeth of such persuasion. This week Annie's glorious tale of gradually being assimilated into the small, close community that she now considers home - Extra Virgin: Amongst the Olive Groves of Liguria - is published.

A visit is like stepping into the book. I am sitting on a terrace that was already familiar, looking across a valley terraced with olive groves mid-harvest, and I know the names and characters of many of the people rolling up their olive nets. Annie has collected me and Andy the photographer from the coastal sin city, Diano de Marina, and driven in the style of a true Italian up through the little village of San Pietro where she and Lucy first lodged (sleeping in 59-minute bursts between the earsplitting tolling of the campanile clock) past the olive mill where a German crashed through the roof after trying to commit suicide off the motorway bridge above but landed in a lorryful of olives, and round the 12 sick-making hairpin bends. There is so much affectionate detail about the place and its people in the book that there are countless things to look out for, not least the 48-year-old author herself. When you've really, really enjoyed a book you so desperately want to like the writer, you dread them turning out to be a complete monster. Annie, thankfully, is no disappointment. Her car is chaos, she is a whirlwind of apology for being late, for not having had time to wash her hair for the photographs. She is warm, funny, idiosyncratic and a dedicated people watcher. Everybody knows her and honks and waves as we reverse down the precipitous road to let each other past.

The book grew out of the stories she would tell her friends when she was forced to return to her flat in Shepherd's Bush to earn some more money. Annie embraced Italian life wholeheartedly from the word go. With an aptitude for languages and a smattering of Italian, she'd chatter away to people, gradually getting the hang of the Liguarian dialect. In fact the book - which took her three years - was considerably longer originally: 'I couldn't find the word count thing on the laptop so I just kept on going. When I finally printed it out at my brother's house in Cardiff, it took the whole day. I'd written 600 pages.' She did her homework by reading Bill Bryson, Peter Mayle and Frances Mayes.

Wasn't she worried she'd absorb their style, I ask?

No, says Annie with characteristic certainty. And anyway neither Bryson nor Mayle are properly interested in people. No danger of that with Annie's narrative; local personalities leap off the page, invariably cooking, eating and discussing the digestion, usually ticking the girls off for drinking too much coffee before lunch, eating food in the wrong order (surely everybody everywhere must eat antipasto, primo piatto and secondo?), chopping and dressing salads incorrectly.

She ran away to Portugal and married her Irish/Jamaican boyfriend at 16 'because my mother said he wasn't intelligent enough for me, which I took to be a code word for blackness'. The relationship collapsed almost at once, but Annie stayed on in Portugal for a year (she speaks that fluently too) and never bothered to divorce him which deeply concerns her new accountant. Her parents were teachers, Lucy is also one, and all the boys have written, or are writing, books. 'Lucy', who features constantly and hilariously throughout the book, usually referred to as 'the evil sister', is not her real name.

'She got very angry that I had included her in the book,' says Annie. 'She hates the idea that somebody might recognise her, particularly one of the children at her school, she's very odd.'

This does seem peculiar because Lucy spends chunks of the books at the various village festa dancing mazurkas badly when sufficiently fortified by local wine.

'Yes, and then she goes into a long fit of depression at how badly she behaved. I know she's odd because she can't write cheques in front of people.'

One is Annie's 20-year-old son, Tom, an art student in Bourne-mouth, whom she left out from tact but he's miffed. There's a hint at the very end of the book that a relationship might have started, but it's very subtle. His parents grow olives on the other side of the valley, the red roof of their house clearly visible from the terrace.

'Ciccio was always my favourite person here, but I'm not really sure how the romance started,' muses Annie. 'I gave him the key years ago so he could use the house to play poker with his friends, and then when our neighbour Domenico died Ciccio started looking after the olives for me, so really he crept up on the terrain before he crept up on me. He has nipped across the valley to his mother's larder (quite acceptable behaviour apparently from an Italian son) and returned with a treasure trove of small green tomatoes, anchovies, pasta, a demi-john of their own white wine ('very strong,' he warned, and how right he was). 'We had a little trouble after about seven years,' he says, 'but now we're fine. At the beginning it was difficult letting my father know I was involved with a woman with a child, but now he is okay with it. He was always more difficult to approach about it than my mother, something about being the only son. And anyway all my sisters have got divorced.'

The gas fridge came from an abandoned German camper van, Ciccio found the huge wood-burning cooker when it was being discarded by an old lady. The solar panel was buried under vines in a bush nearby, and generates sufficient electricity to provide power for either television and music or Annie's laptop - a good excuse, she found, to stop writing. Annie and Ciccio have now bought themselves another house further up the valley. 'Nobody reads books in Italy anyway,' she says. 'They're all far too busy talking, spreading gossip, scandal and innuendo. There was a review on satellite usage recently and they're mainly used for mobile phones - nobody bothers with the internet because it would involve reading.

'I do love all the talking up to a point, but the huge gatherings can get me down. Particularly as you have to drive around collecting people in a huge car convoy and then going to the place - they won't hear of meeting you there. I'm gregarious up to a point and then I have to have total solitude for at least two days.'

Frank the Knife, who posed for the handsome diary Penguin have produced has already declared himself offended by a picture that he considers makes him look old rather than one with his horse, particularly as he is famed throughout the area for riding it into a bar one day to avenge his sister. Ciccio has so far read only five chapters and Annie is confident he will get no further.

And now? Annie quite fancies writing a thriller and there's already enough material that didn't get into Extra Virgin for a sequel, and doing up another house will be a whole new story. But why hurry? There's the terrace, the view, and Ciccio's wine and cooking.

webTitle: Observer Classic: Jane Grigson's Venison en croute

fields.headline: Observer Classic
fields.standfirst: Jane Grigson was the Observer's distinguished food writer for many years. Here is a recipe that was first printed in this paper in August 1970
fields.trailText: Jane Grigson was the Observer's distinguished food writer for many years. Here is a recipe that was first printed in this paper in August 1970.
fields.body:
In the past, noble lords and rich men - when they could get a licence from the Crown - built themselves a living larder in the shape of a deer park with high fences and walls. They went out and formally hunted the deer inside. Then they pigged on the venison. Now some of them are glad to sell the venison to the people, you and me, who used to poach it - if we could. Most of the venison comes from fallow deer, the kind that drop their horns in April and May in the park at Richmond; these are the usual inhabitants of deer parks. At Richmond, too, one may see red deer, which also provide venison, though more particularly in Scotland.

French chefs often used to complain that they could get nothing but venison from roe deer. The flesh, said Escoffier, was 'very often mediocre in quality' and he thought that the fallow deer from an English park 'has no equal as far as delicacy and tenderness are concerned'. They devised very good recipes all the same.

When you eat venison, reflect that in the Middle Ages it was an integral part of living it up. The menu survives of a feast given in 1443 at the inauguration of John Stafford, Archbishop of Canterbury. The game - strange list - included pheasant, swan, heron, crane, curlew, partridge, plover, rails and quails, but also three different dishes of venison.

They knew, the cooks of those days, that venison was a rich and gamey meat which needed tempering. They served it with frumenty, the wet ancestor of the packeted breakfast cereal, and with an early version of poivrade sauce. Sometimes it was enclosed in pastry. Venison cooking by the Victorian age had multiplied accompaniments of fruit and berries - pears, apples, oranges, cherries, juniper berries, even bananas. In this country port was as essential as redcurrant jelly, the two being combined in Francatelli's delicious sauce for venison.

Venison is no problem to cook. The trouble may be to buy it. Persist. The venison is there on the hoof. The sad thing is that three-quarters of it goes abroad (like our best scallops, pigs, horsemeat and lobsters). It seems, though, that our producers are beginning to meet tough competition from Russia and New Zealand, and may have to consider new markets. They might, who knows, consider us. With intelligent and patient publicity - think of the avocado pear and chicory campaigns - venison could soon become part of our normal choice of meat. It is not, after all, an exotic, but an old item of our national diet with a ready-made niche in our minds.

Venison en croute (for 4)

Venison steaks (or a boned roasting joint) may be encased in puff or shortcrust pastry, in the same way as fillet of beef.

340g short or puff pastry

4 loin or rump steaks of venison

113g chopped mushrooms

clove garlic, crushed

85g butter

about 57g breadcrumbs

egg yolk

Roll out the pastry and cut four oblong pieces large enough to enclose the steaks. Cook mushrooms and garlic in the butter gently, adding enough breadcrumbs to make a dampish stuffing. Sear the steaks quickly on both sides in a heavy pan which has been rubbed over with lard. Put some stuffing in the middle of a piece of pastry, then a steak, and some more stuffing. Repeat with the other steaks. Brush the pastry edges with beaten egg yolk and form turnovers. Brush the top, and bake for 20 minutes at gas-mark 6.

fields.headline: Top 10 war non-fiction
fields.trailText: chart
fields.body:
This week's war special affords us the chance to check which war non-fiction is selling. Anthony Beevor's book about the siege of Stalingrad is on its way to becoming a classic. William Craig's The Enemy at the Gates shares his subject (tying in to the film of that name). Also look out for The Siege , Helen Dunmore's novel about the German attack on Leningrad in the winter of 1941(Viking, June). If this were a fiction chart you can bet Patrick O'Brian's Napoleonic war novels would be up there too. Revisionism is a common theme in those that are: Double Standards reveals a cover-up about the flight of Hitler's deputy Rudolf Hess; The Pity of War explodes myths about "the Great War". Then there's the trend-mixer, Hugh Montefiore's Enigma: The Battle for the Code, marrying Simon "The Code Book" Singh with Robert "Enigma" Harris. Faber has just signed up a Napoleonic code book. So the game goes on . . .

Top 10 war non-fiction

1 Stalingrad by Antony Beevor (Penguin, £12.99)

2 The Somme by Lyn Macdonald (Penguin, £10.99)

3 The Pity of War by Niall Ferguson (Penguin, £9.99)

4 Enigma: The Battle for the Code by Hugh Montefiore (Pheonix, £7.99)

5 Finest Hour by Phil Craig and Tim Clayton (Coronet, £7.99)

6 The Enemy at the Gates by William Craig (Penguin, £5.99)

7 Double Standards: The Rudolf Hess Cover-up by Lynn Picknett and Clive Prince (Little, Brown, £20)

8 The Forgotten Soldier by Guy Sajer (Cassell, £6.99)

9 Seven Pillars of Wisdom by T E Lawrence (Penguin, £9.99)

10 First Day on the Somme by Martin Middlebrook (Penguin, £5.99)

webTitle: Pub landlord goes to Europe for right to buy

fields.headline: Whitbread pub landlord goes to Europe for right to buy
fields.trailText: On Monday morning, Cumbrian pub landlord Gary McClure will be relaxing in a luxurious nine-seat limousine on a mission to Luxembourg to persuade the European court to hear his long-running fight against Whitbread.
fields.body:
On Monday morning, Cumbrian pub landlord Gary McClure will be relaxing in a luxurious nine-seat limousine on a mission to Luxembourg to persuade the European court to hear his long-running fight against Whitbread.

Yesterday, his venue for protest was a hard plastic seat in a splendid former brewery in the heart of the City - which was once the headquarters of the newly invented leisure group, where shareholders endorsed plans to sell off the 3,000 pubs to the German-owned financier, Morgan Grenfell Private Equity.

Mr McClure wants the right to buy his pub, the Old King's Head in Broughton-in-Furness, where the foot and mouth epidemic has knocked turnover by some 45%.

He told the extraordinary general meeting yesterday, attended by some 50 shareholders, that by backing the £1.6bn sale to Morgan Grenfell they were allowing their board to "sell us out".

Refusing to be deterred by shareholders' 97% endorsement of the sale, Mr McClure insists that at Whitbread's next annual meeting he will be asking for a vote of no confidence in the board. The decision to allow Mr McClure and any other tenanted landlords to buy their pubs rests with the new owner, Morgan Grenfell, which has indicated that it has no intention of doing so. While the company's board apparently remained unmoved by Mr McClure's stance yesterday, octogenarian former Whitbread chairman Sir Charles Tidbury - an old friend of Lady Thatcher's and a survivor of an IRA bomb attack - offered his support.

He made a plea for the 7% of the 1,700 tenanted landlords to have the right to buy.

Sir John Banham - who also faced calls from shareholders to clean up the "pig-sty" Features pub in Ealing, said the slimmed down Whitbread would provide a good "classic defensive growth stock" for investors.

With the banner "Enjoy! Whitbread" emblazoned on the wall above his head, chief executive David Thomas - whose resignation has been called for by Mr McClure - assured the attendees of the annual meeting that they would "certainly be able to enjoy Future Whitbread" even though its pubs and brewing interests had been passed on to new owners.

Refusing to be deterred by shareholders' 97% endorsement of the sale, Mr McClure insists that at Whitbread's next annual meeting he will be asking for a vote of no confidence in the board. The decision to allow Mr McClure and any other tenanted landlords to buy their pubs rests with the new owner, Morgan Grenfell, which has indicated that it has no intention of doing so. While the company's board apparently remained unmoved by Mr McClure's stance yesterday, octogenarian former Whitbread chairman Sir Charles Tidbury - an old friend of Lady Thatcher's and a survivor of an IRA bomb attack - offered his support. He made a plea for the 7% of the 1,700 tenanted landlords to have the right to buy. Sir John Banham - who also faced calls from shareholders to clean up the "pig-sty" Features pub in Ealing, said the slimmed down Whitbread would provide a good "classic defensive growth stock" for investors. With the banner "Enjoy! Whitbread" emblazoned on the wall above his head, chief executive David Thomas - whose resignation has been called for by Mr McClure - assured the attendees of the annual meeting that they would "certainly be able to enjoy Future Whitbread" even though its pubs and brewing interests had been passed on to new owners.

webTitle: Things my girlfriend and I argue about

fields.headline: Things my girlfriend and I argue about
fields.trailText: 'Nothing keeps a relationship on its toes so much as lively debate. Fortunate, then, that my girlfriend and I agree on absolutely nothing.'
fields.body:
Nothing keeps a relationship on its toes so much as lively debate. Fortunate, then, that my girlfriend and I agree on absolutely nothing. At all. Combine utter, polar disagreement on everything, ever, with the fact that I am a textbook Only Child, and she is a teeteringly unstable psychopath, and we're warming up. Then factor in my being English and she German - which not only makes each one of us personally and absolutely responsible for both the history and the social and cultural mores of our respective countries, but also opens up a whole field of sub-arguments grounded in grammatical and semantic disputes - and, well, just try saying anything and walking away. Margret and I can weave an argument out of the air itself; the warm, curling, ribbons of our own breath are all the material we need.

You doubt me? Okey-dokey. We have argued about...

The way one should cut a kiwi fruit in half (along its length or across the middle).

Leaving the kitchen door open. (Three times a day, that one. Minimum.)

The best way to hang up washing.

Those little toothpaste speckles you make when you brush your teeth in front of the mirror.

I eat two-fingered Kit-Kats like I'd eat any other chocolate bar of that size - ie, without feeling the need to snap them into two individual fingers first. Margret accused me of doing this 'deliberately to annoy' her.

Stick with me, there's more. Oh yes...

fields.headline: The actor's cut
fields.standfirst: Hollywood star Christopher Walken may have the face of an assassin but cooking is in his blood. Just give him a decent piece of fish, olive oil and a bunch of garlic, and his New Delhi Salmon is to die for. Just watch out for those knives
fields.trailText: Hollywood star Christopher Walken may have the face of an assassin but cooking is in his blood. Just give him a decent piece of fish, olive oil and a bunch of garlic, and his New Delhi Salmon is to die for. Just watch out for those knives
fields.body:
At 1:50 p.m. on 7 September last year, actor Christopher Walken sat in the driver's seat of his black Cadillac Seville sedan, in a parking space on the street in front of his second residence, a ground-floor apartment on West 80th Street, New York. He was wearing a black T-shirt and faded black cotton pants with an elastic waistband. A pair of tortoise-shell reading glasses hung from his shirt.

He entered his apartment, a duplex that is mostly utilised by his wife of over 30 years, Georgianne, who works in Manhattan as a casting agent. To the right, in the spacious living room, were two enormous canvases painted by his good friend, Julian Schnabel. To the left, with a breakfast nook looking out onto the street, was the kitchen. Pottery bowls with chopped vegetables - zucchini, summer squash, and onion - sat on the counter, above which, on a shelf, was an old cigar box painted with the word 'Smile' next to a photograph of a cute cat, who, he explained, crestfallen, succumbed to 'that feline leukemia'. In the corner, near a telephone was a black-and-white print of Jerry Lewis, doing his signature drinking-glass-in-the-mouth bit, taken at the Tony Awards.

Walken crushed a whole bulb of garlic with alarming force on the counter top, and began chopping with a menacing looking butcher's knife. He pulled out a frying pan, put it down on the white Whirlpool electric stove and began rummaging through the drawers for a spatula, which he seemed unable to find.

'It's a long time since I was cooking here' he said. My wife uses this place. She buys this stuff. I have gas in Connecticut, which is much nicer. This is hard. An electric oven isn't bad, but a gas top is much better. In Connecticut I have an electric oven with a gas top. This is hard. I don't know what's going to happen. You don't look very comfortable. Why don't you sit down? Oh, great, I forgot to turn the burner on.

'Cooking is like the family business. My father was a baker all his life. He comes from a big family in Germany. His father was a baker. His brothers are bakers. He came to America and opened a bakery in Queens and had it for 60 years. That's where I came from this morning. My mother broke her hip. It's a drag, because they live in a house and suddenly they can't go up and down stairs.'

Walken began his first dish, Zucchini Linguine, by heating olive oil in the skillet.

'I'm putting some garlic in. New York is great for produce. Those Korean markets always have very fresh stuff.

'My brothers and I were in show business when we were kids, but we also worked in the bakery. I used to deliver cakes in a station wagon and work in the back of the bakery. I was the guy that put the jelly in the doughnuts. In those days, you'd have a huge can with a plunger on it. It had these two really big needles sticking out each side. You'd take two doughnuts - they'd already be cooked - stick them on those needle things. Then you push the plunger down, and you feel them fill up. There'd usually be a little dribble of jelly on the end. Actually, it was rather sensual.'

He added onion, then red pepper, then the zucchini and summer squash to the sizzling pan.

'My mother wasn't much of a cook. I mean she was okay. She used to overcook everything. She came over from Scotland and used to make interesting things, things that I never see any more, like oxtails - you know, real I guess the word is "peasant" food. Things like the linings of things.

'My father likes that German food. He used to drink sauerkraut juice. He's 97 years old and he eats this incredibly high-cholesterol stuff. All those big sausages. He eats knockwurst and washes it down with beer. And he eats head cheese, which is basically these big chunks of fat in gelatin made into a loaf. It's like eating solid fat. And he's a skinny guy. My cholesterol is good. Every time I go to the doctor, he swoons in ecstasy over my blood pressure. I've got some incredible blood pressure. When I was a kid, I'd pass out sometimes, because I'd get real slow. The blood, you know. But when you get older, that's good.'

Walken tossed vegetables, added dill and juiced a lemon into the pan, picking out the seeds afterwards. He immersed dry pasta in boiling water.

'At one point I had a pasta machine. I tried that. They make it look easy. But it's not. Making your own pasta is not easy.

'Now I could put some olives here. You like olives? I put some lemon juice in there, too.

'When I was a kid, every day in the house there was cake, cookies, chocolate cream pies. Every week, the cleaning lady would take home a huge bag of stuff. You'd think it'd be great. In the bakery, I used to make these big vats of melted chocolate. The smell of sugar in that quantity is overwhelming. It's almost too much.

'Now, I never eat dessert. I eat sweets very rarely. I don't eat sugar. In the morning, when I have coffee, I put molasses in it. It's very good. When I go to a restaurant, people always have dessert, and I always skip it. I might have some cheese or something like that.'

Walken poured the sautéed vegetables into a bowl and put them aside, then tasted the pasta, which was not yet done. He reached into the refrigerator and emerged with a white-paper-wrapped package, which he began to unwrap.

'On pasta, they say 12 minutes,' he said, 'but I always try to keep an eye on it. This is salmon from Citarella. There's one right down the street. I was just working in Nova Scotia and Halifax. You get the most incredible fish there. Mussels that don't really taste like mussels you ever had before. The salmon, it's unbelievable. Chilean sea bass, you know you don't get it a lot here, but when I go to California, they have it all the time. It's such a gorgeous thing. You get a great big chunk of it and you bake it. It's just fabulous. In California they have all these great things like abalone [shellfish]. It's fabulous. But it's very expensive.

'For me, cooking is something that I do when I'm studying scripts. I put the script on the counter and I cook and study my lines at the same time. It's the power of distraction, I find. I've read that a lot of people do one thing while there's something that they're doing at the same time. Some people play cards or garden. I cook. My wife doesn't cook. That's actually common. I think more men cook than women cook.'

Walken laid the salmon on the counter and began cutting into it.

'I don't cut through the skin,' he said. 'I just score it in portion sizes and leave the skin hanging off.

'You need to watch your weight in the movie business. It's just a practical thing. Actors are always on some sort of diet. There's a lot of sitting around on movie sets and actors are always sitting on their chairs and talking about food. It may be because they're on a diet and thinking about it a lot. It's true that the camera is very cruel. It makes you look heavier than you are. And movie food is generally very good, because they have to make sure the technicians are happy. They like a nice big lunch with dessert. It's tempting. You've got to watch yourself.

'Buffets are very dangerous. A lot of actors I know gain 15 pounds when they make a movie. I was in a movie once - I don't want to say which - that took eight months to make. Movies are not shot in sequence, so you could watch it and see the people in the movie getting bigger and smaller. Sometimes I go to these movie events, and there'll be a buffet with very good food. You'll see all these important, wealthy people standing on line getting huge plates of it. They don't need it. But psychologically, I guess it's some primitive thing. Somebody's got to eat it.

'I try to keep the icebox fairly empty, and just buy things as I want them. I only eat once a day. Usually about seven o'clock. If I have things to do, eating slows me down. I feel like I'm underwater.'

Walken left the fish for a moment, and ripped open a paper-wrapped jar, the dark, gelatinous contents of which he spooned into a mixing bowl.

'That's chutney, and I'm going to put a big thing of it in there. And I have some garlic that's already chopped. And sea salt. I'm going to put a little lemon in there and mix it up. I have some coriander here. People don't use coriander much, but it's really good.

'I eat slowly. It takes me a long time. I usually watch TV, just flip around and find these great movies that I didn't know even existed. That's the best thing about that cable. I just saw an incredible musical with a lot of black performers called Stormy Weather. The last 20 minutes of that are as good as any musical I ever saw. Then I fall right asleep.

'I don't go out to eat much. Occasionally I go to these very fancy restaurants on an anniversary or a birthday or something. I don't want to name any names, but I haven't really been knocked out in the last few years. In the old days - this is 20 years ago - I used to take my wife to Lutèce [an old established restaurant on the Upper Eastside] on her anniversary or birthday. That used to be wonderful. It probably still is. But I went to one of the big ones recently. The bill was unbelievable. For three people it was like 300 bucks apiece. I had duck or something like that. Anyway, it was good. But I make a tremendous duck. You have to steam a duck first. I don't think many people do that. This amazing amount of fat comes off. Then you put it on a rack. You stuff it with garlic and oranges, you know, salt, pepper, some herb, whatever that might be. And you put it on the rack and roast it, and it comes out really crispy. I got that from the Julia Child Cookbook. Her cookbooks are wonderful, Julia Child.'

After tossing the linguini into a colander, Walken brought the chutney sauce over to the salmon fillet and began massaging the sauce into the fish.

'Oh, incidentally,' he said, 'my hands may look dirty, but that's paint on them. I was painting. I'm going to take this sauce and put this on the top. You scored it, so it kind of gets down into the holes.

'I love Mexican cooking. It's so much more than people know. Here it's, you know, guacamole and enchiladas. I like eating spaghetti. I could eat it every day and I have to watch that. I like French food but sometimes it's very rich. I was in Japan once, and I said to the people I was with, you know, "I love Japanese food, so I would like to have some real authentic Japanese food". And they took me to this restaurant and gave me a bowl of what looked like some pasta. I looked at it. There were all these little eyes, and the whole thing was moving. I think they were little white eels. I did have some of it to be polite. That was tough. I had to take it down with some beer.'

Walken carried the fish over to where a baking tray is arrayed with a bed of onions, and slapped the fish, sauce-side down, onto the onions.

'All right now,' he said. 'I have this pan with all these onions I did. I sautéed them a little bit.

'During movies, I bring my own food. I have various Tupperware containers. And every time I go away for any extended time, I'll stay in an apartment or a hotel that has a kitchen. When I was a kid, I was in musicals, and there'd be the dancers, you know, these crazy gypsies. They'd show up in the little hotel with a suitcase, open it up, and it had every kind of cooking utensil. They would cook these incredible dinners from nothing. Thanksgiving would come and they'd cook this huge turkey in the room. I don't know how they did it.'

Walken popped the salmon into the oven. 'It's on broil,' he said. 'I don't time it. You can sort of tell by touching it.

'I've had to stay in places where there only was a microwave. It's not recommended, but you can actually cook certain fish in a microwave. Salmon you can cook practically anywhere. And if you're living like a hobo in a hotel room, you can make amazing things in crockpots. You can stick a chicken in there with some vegetables. Turn it on real low and just leave it there all day. And when you come back it's fabulous.'

Walken pulled out a package of jumbo prawns from the refrigerator and, grasping them in his hands, cut through them with the butcher knife, then ran them under water.

'This is a little dangerous,' he said. 'You know you're never supposed to cut like this. You can cut your hand off. You see, you butterfly it. And then there's this vein in there. You want to get rid of that. It's guts, I guess. You want to get those nice and clean.

'I almost did a cooking show. I went to Bravo and MTV and the Comedy Channel. I had meetings with these people and I was going to do this show. It was either 10 or 12 segments. I can't remember. I was going to have some sort of kitchen set-up. I wanted it to be a little like Pee-wee's Playhouse. I love that show. And I'd have maybe a showgirl, you know, with a little thing on, chopping my vegetables. Maybe some musicians. And an audience. Some people to talk to.'

Walken laid the prawns into a sizzling frying pan, in which he had sautéed some chopped garlic in olive oil. He squeezed an orange into a coffee mug that read 'Notre Dame High School, 25th Class Reunion, Class of 1967'.

'I'm going to throw a little more garlic in there,' he said. 'You want a little more coriander in the shrimp. You put them in shell down in the hot oil - but the next part is a little tricky, some say dangerous. What I've got here is some rum, and I'm squeezing a little bit of orange juice in the rum. You got to wait until these shrimps get a little white. These are big, so they're taking a while.

'I remember Dean Martin's old shows, when he had the Gold Diggers. It was a fabulous show. They say they had the whole thing set up and he'd get in his car and drive from his house, park the car, walk into the studio and do it completely off the cuff. You'd watch it and you could tell that he didn't really know what was going on. And every time things got a little rough, these showgirls called the Gold Diggers - these gorgeous girls - would come on and do this dance number. That's sort of what I had in mind.'

Satisfied the prawns were sufficiently opaque, Walken grabbed the rum, turned the burner up and tossed the rum into the pan, then quickly covered it with a lid. It sizzled loudly.

'This top isn't quite tight enough, but it works,' he said. 'It's like a big sudden steam bath.

'With the cable, the thing was, when it got down to it, every one of them wanted something much more precise. They wanted it to be much more planned. Much more of a pragmatic, fabricated thing that could be repeated. They wanted to have a comic actor with me. They wanted to have a script. Jokes. I like jokes. But I wouldn't want to have to say the jokes, you know. Because certain times things are funny anyway. I mean, funny people are funny. And I said to them I wouldn't be able to do that. I wanted it to be like the Dean Martin show.'

The meal was done. Walken tossed the vegetables and pasta together, pulled out some small wine glasses, a couple of plates and a half bottle of 1998 Corvo, a white Italian table wine. He carried a canister of sour cream over to the table for the pasta.

'I usually put some sour cream on that,' he said. 'It's up to you. I'll tell you a really simple thing if you're going to have people over. It's expensive, but you get a thing of caviar - you can use the red caviar. But one of the best things in the world is linguine, a big thing of sour cream in the middle and a big scoop of caviar. With some pepper. It's like the best. Anybody can make it. Piece of bread? It's nice bread. Just a little corner? I'll get you a napkin. I'm gonna give you food. I'm not going to eat today. I'll eat later.'

Afterwards Walken washed the dishes. He cleaned the sink with a sponge. He put the leftovers in Tupperware. Then he tossed a few paper towels on the ground and wiped the floor by skating around on top of the towel with a stockinged foot.

'Coriander is very hard to clean,' he said. 'All these little green things.

'If I wasn't so lazy, I'll tell you what I would do. I saw this thing on television. This whole thing with people putting cameras in their house, for the net. I understand that people outfit their houses with these things, and some guy's girlfriend finds out that she's been naked all over the Internet. You hear about that. If everybody can do it, it can't be that hard. You just need to figure out where to tune in, right? I would need some help with this. I don't quite understand how the Internet works. I don't have a computer. You know, 12-year-old kids know all about that.

'I thought I'd get a couple of those cameras and put them in my kitchen in Connecticut and just, you know, turn them on whenever I felt like it. Maybe I would have a particular time of day I would do it, or something like that. You could charge people to take hits, or something like that. And it would just be me cooking. And I thought to make it amusing, I thought I would have a hotline - you know, a red telephone. And they could call and I could give them advice about their love life. I mean silly stuff, personal questions, about them, you know, "What should I do?" In the old days, there used to be these things - I can't remember what they're called, but it's a Spanish word. Like a bodega, but something else. They'd be on street corners. You could buy a love potion. You could buy, you know, something, if you were mad at somebody, you could buy a hex. They even had aerosol, I remember - you could spray somebody to get them to fall in love with you or something. I could provide services like that. Or just talk while I'm cooking.'

Walken sat down at the kitchen table.

'And you remember a programme called This Is Your Life? I thought I'd have a curtain over to one side and once in a while I'd have a mystery guest. You know, actors are always coming over to my house. Maybe Joe Pesci comes over and makes his tomato sauce. Everybody makes something, you know what I mean. Don't you think that might be amusing?

'Or I could do restaurant reviews. Like Ruth Reichl, I could walk in with a big disguise. Like a great big wig. Like everybody would know, they'd be like, "Oh, here comes Chris with a big wig. Who's he kidding with those big dark glasses?" Or I could dress up like a woman. Get dressed up with a big fur coat, and I could pretend it's not me.'

Christopher Walken said he would eat later.

Christopher Walken's TNT Prawn Appetizer
Serves four

1 cup dark rum
juice of 1 orange
4 jumbo prawn, fresh, with shells left on
salt and pepper
2 cloves garlic, finely chopped
2 tablespoons olive oil

Combine the rum and orange juice. Leaving the shell on, butterfly the prawns by slicing them with a sharp knife, cutting from back to legs, so that they lie flat, shell-side down, and the two halves approximate the shape of a heart. Wash and gut them under cold water. Salt and pepper the prawns liberally. In a skillet over medium heat, brown the garlic. Arrange the prawns in the pan, shell-side down, and sauté for about four minutes, or until most of the body has become opaque. Turn the heat to high. When the skillet begins to sizzle, add the rum and orange juice mixture and immediately slam a tight cover on the skillet, pressing down firmly so that very little steam can escape. Keep the cover pressed down for about 3 minutes. Remove from heat, and uncover. The prawns should look fat, blackened and engorged. Serve from the pan, shell-side down, covering the prawns with the remaining rum sauce.

Christopher Walken's Courgette Linguine
Serves four

3 cloves garlic, minced
3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
1 onion, diced
2 red bell peppers, diced
2 courgette, cut into 1/2-inch half-wheels
2 summer squash, cut similarly
salt and pepper
1/2 cup fresh dill, chopped
10 large kalamata olives, sliced (optional)
juice of 1 lemon
450g linguine (Walken uses De Cecco)
4 tbsp sour cream

Lightly brown the garlic in the olive oil in a large skillet, on medium heat. Add the onion and red peppers, and sauté until soft. Add the courgettes and summer squash, and sauté until soft but not wilted. Salt and pepper to taste. Finally, add the dill, lemon juice and olives. Toss together and remove from heat. Toss the mixture with al dente linguine. Garnish with sour cream.

Christopher Walken's New Delhi Salmon
Serves four

750g fresh salmon fillet, skin left on
2 tbsp olive oil
1 tbsp sea salt
1 onion, chopped into 1/2-inch segments
1 jar chutney (Walken used Major Grey's, you could substitute a mild mango)
3 cloves garlic, finely chopped
1/2 cup fresh coriander, chopped
juice of one lemon

Preheat the grill. With a sharp knife, cut the salmon fillet crosswise into four portions, but do not break the salmon skin. Rub about two tablespoons of olive oil on the scored piece of salmon and into its crevices, then rub in about a tablespoon of sea salt. Put aside. In a saucepan, lightly brown the onion slices. Pile the browned onion onto greaseproof paper or Pyrex plate, forming a bed of onions with the approximate area as the salmon fillet. In a small mixing bowl, combine the chutney, garlic, coriander and lemon juice. Massage this mixture onto the top of the salmon fillet, making sure that some sauce falls into the crevices. Then take the salmon fillet and slam it down on top of the onion bed, so that the skin is facing up and the sauce side is down. Place the pan under a medium grill for about 20 minutes, or until the skin is burnt and the middle of the fillet is hot to the touch and dark pink. Remove the skin and serve from the pan, sauce- and-onion-side down.
