fields.headline: To die for
fields.trailText: 'That minimalist mantra - less is more - well, it's being said with a snort of raucous irony in certain circles.'
fields.body:
I hope you haven't just laid your last square of cool, clean plywood flooring. Best not read on, perhaps. The pendulum is swinging again, you see. That minimalist mantra - less is more - well, it's being said with a snort of raucous irony in certain circles.

Fashions in interior tastes didn't used to change this dramatically, or maybe they just didn't reach so many people. We had neither the time, nor the available media, to become quite so obsessed with our homes. We didn't travel so much, or read so much, or watch so much TV, so we didn't waste as much time pondering those variables: curtains or blinds? blankets or duvet? carpets or floorboards? There was interior decoration before Changing Rooms (in the same way that, though it's hard to believe, Brazilian architecture actually pre-dates the publication of Wallpaper*) but it was mercifully devoid of table-tops that people had mosaiced themselves (although I do recall my mother making lampshades from wool - please don't try that one at home).

The new maximalism, as it is doubtless being called, has crept up stealthily. I'd put its earliest blossoming down to an adoption of exotic details (think eastern touches) before it really gathered speed, exploding into a hard-to-believe retro voluptuousness. And as with all good interior trends, it has been observed best and first in the restaurants and bars of London, New York and Paris.

First off, there was Hotel Costes in Paris, gussied up Second-Empire style to within an inch of its life by Jacques Garcia. Then the Plaza Athenée, now a vision of Louis XV and XVI gilded splendour on floors one to six, with the excesses of Art Deco on floors seven and eight. The latter is all the fault of one man, Pierre Court, who obviously takes his history seriously. Not to be outdone, New York got him in (anything Paris can have...) to lavish attention on the Villard Bar and Lounge, in the New York Palace Hotel. There, among various decorating coups, he has lined one room in lavender silk and placed a vast portrait of Queen Victoria in another. Think this will never catch on? Then cast your mind back to this year's Brit Awards ceremony on TV, in which Madonna was shown at home in front of a portrait of the present Queen. This vogue for royal portraiture is worrying: everyone knows that what Madonna does, we all slavishly do a year later.

Court hasn't made it to London (for which we should, perhaps, be thankful). Instead, we have Miguel Cancio Martins, who has treated Opium, a Soho basement, to a bit of posh Saigon bordello chic. And Philippe Starck, who has filled the Purple Bar at the Sanderson Hotel with lashings of Venetian glass. Now, Christian Liaigre has done a turn at a new Asian restaurant called Hakkasan (see Grub Street, page 108): all intricate fretwork, carving and embroidered-backed chairs. The men named above have all come from Paris, mind, which means we maybe shouldn't take this too much to heart. But should this old-world opulence really start filtering into the domestic mainstream, you won't be able to shift an Eames chair at a car-boot sale full of students. A portrait of Queen Vic, however, could fetch a small fortune. Start looking now.

 Caroline Roux on design appears weekly.

fields.headline: How to wear clothes
fields.trailText: 'Hemlines are set to soar this summer. To most women, this is unwelcome news. What most of us like is a simple knee-length skirt.'
fields.body:
The kind of women who really like wearing miniskirts tend to be quite irritating. Posh Spice, Victoria Hervey, Celine Dion: the type who get their smug carrot-stick thighs out at every opportunity.

And now they have every excuse, because hemlines are set to soar this summer. To most women, this is unwelcome news. What most of us like is a simple knee-length skirt: grown up, versatile and safe from unintentional knicker-flashing. And for the past two years, we've been spoilt.

But the lady is dead. The new hemline is closer to your knickers than your knees. And before you dismiss the idea, consider this: miniskirts are much, much sexier. Face it. You might look in the mirror and marvel at the chic sex appeal of your demure knee-length skirt, but to the non-Vogue-reading population you look like a librarian.

In winter, miniskirts are easy - a pair of opaque tights, boots, a polo-neck and a coat are sufficient to ward off that feeling of overexposure. But going short in summer is trickier. The combination of bare legs and a vest top is tantamount to a T-shirt declaring "Drivers: Wind The Window Down And Shout Things That Make Me Go Bright Red!" You might be doing it for fashion, but people are still going to look up your skirt.

The key to warding off sharks is to wear your mini with a dishevelled, punky edge. Neat-and-girly looks too twee; think Scary rather than Posh. Take last year's denim knee-length skirt, hack off a few inches, and wear with a man's style shirt. No tottering on spindly ankle-breakers: court shoes look suitably hard; or trainers are good, if you have the legs for them.

How short is short enough? The briefer the better, naturally, but a shirt or jacket that finishes at the hips will make the skirt beneath look shorter, so you can get the look without sharing your upper thighs with the world.

fields.headline: The new black
fields.trailText: 'Women's magazines will have plenty of beauty news and pictures of how to wear the current looks, but they will all be modelled on skins in varying degrees of white.'
fields.body:
I want to update my make-up.

I want to move seamlessly from the 80s retro look to a fresh spring face. The easy thing to do would be to buy a couple of women's magazines and see what they suggest. But there's a problem. As a black woman, I can be sure that none will be able to advise me. Yes, they will have plenty of beauty news and pictures of how to wear the current looks, but they will all be modelled on skins in varying degrees of white. Black women spend five times more than their white counterparts on hair products, and three times more on cosmetics, according to the organisers of the Afro Hair And Beauty show. Ignoring black women isn't just annoying, it's bad business.

This month's Vogue doesn't feature one black model - unless you count a rogue Benetton ad and a snapshot of an unnamed woman backstage at the latest round of fashion shows. Vogue doesn't carry the strapline "for white women" - but it might as well.

Of course, the fashion bible isn't the only culprit - every women's magazine and most weekend supplements have beauty pages. They all ignore the black woman. No powders in our shades. No hairstyles for our hair. No creams for our skin. Yes, I know we're all the same on the inside, but on the outside we're just not. My hair is not the same as a white person with "curly hair just like an Afro", my skin is not "just like yours when you go abroad". I'm different.

I know I can turn to magazines such as Pride, or Black Beauty, but why should I have to? I want to be in the mainstream. I want to see myself in the magazines I buy. Sure, I might get a picture of Naomi Campbell or Alek Wek, but come on... I doubt Naomi has problems finding trousers to fit, and Alek is so stunning she is rarely made up at all. These two are hardly examples of the average black woman - and why should they be? Black skin, like white, comes in many different shades - blue-black,brown with red undertones, or brown with orange undertones. This is a column about those different skin tones, hair types and body shapes. I can't promise to find the perfect jeans, shampoo or powder, but I'll try.

 Hannah Pool's column on black beauty appears weekly.

webTitle: One year on: The industrial designer

fields.headline: One year on: The industrial designer
fields.standfirst: Simon Cran, who did an MA in new product development at Sheffield Hallam, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Simon Cran, who did an MA in new product development at Sheffield Hallam, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
Although I had always thought I would like to do an MA, it rather fell into my lap. I applied for a job and was told by my prospective employer that it had won government funding to sponsor a candidate and that part of the job would include doing the course. My wages would be partly funded by the Department of Trade and Industry and the rest by the company. Not surprisingly I jumped at it.

The company specialised in manufacturing hard-wearing telecoms equipment for outdoor use and I was brought in to design its new range - much of which formed my projects for the MA.

At the end of my two-year contract I was released after it was hinted that I had designed myself out of a job, but that was fine. I had an MA and the experience and my employer had a new range of products. I like to think we both gained.

Today I am the design studio manager for Adtranz, DaimlerChrysler's train building division in Derby. We design and build rolling stock for railways across the world. Our work tends to divide into vehicles for larger, long distance trains or rolling stock for urban rail systems similar to the London Underground.

Over the past few years we have moved over to a platform approach of design and manufacture similar to that adopted by the car industry.

While the trains can look very different both on the outside and internally, they now share the same running gear and structure, in the same way Audi and VW cars do.

For example, at the moment we are designing rapid transit vehicles that will run in Guangzhou in China, and although they are basically very similar to trains running in London, local conditions demand that they look quite different. The flexibility of a platform-based approach allows us to design and build a prototype train in as little as five weeks and at a significantly reduced risk to the business. All our work is done on computer-based CAD systems and we now present our ideas in virtual reality. I head a team of ten designers and the work is hectic.

I actually started work here after my degree in Edinburgh and returned following the MA. I think the most important thing the MA gave me was a better commercial understanding of how design fits into the bigger picture.

The days of designers sitting at drawing boards letting others worry about the commercial viability of a project have gone. Today, design is an integral part of the business strategy.

webTitle: Lifelong learning that can teach you how to juggle

fields.headline: Lifelong learning that can teach you how to juggle
fields.standfirst: Initiative aims to keep MBA graduates on top
fields.trailText: Initiative aims to keep MBA graduates on top
fields.body:
It is a truth universally acknowledged that our society is changing into a knowledge and information society where even young managers face challenges that demand constant updating of their skills.

Whether it is learning to grasp the intricacies of a new software package or brushing up on the latest people-management technique, unless they spend time acquiring new knowledge their management careers could be over before they've really begun.

And those with freshly minted MBAs are not immune to the pressures of constantly updating their learning. Even those who gained their MBAs just a couple of years ago will almost certainly need to refresh their knowledge of commercial imperatives like e-commerce and knowledge management.

The good news is that it no longer needs to be a case of burning the midnight oil, thumbing hefty text books. The Association of MBAs has just launched the MBAcademy, a 'lifelong learning' initiative that will enable MBA graduates to refresh their management thinking and boost their competence.

The MBAcademy, a partnership of several business schools and management consultant KPMG, aims to meet the needs of senior managers seeking to sharpen their key skills and share knowledge and ideas with like-minded business chiefs.

Using small groups, interactive discussion and learning via shared experiences and case studies it will enable MBA graduates to enhance and prolong the value of their qualifications. The short courses and online learning packages are aimed at managers at different stages of their career as well as those seeking a new understanding of current business practices.

The continuing upheavals in stock markets and brief boom-and-bust histories of new economy firms are indicative of the dangers of guessing your way into the future where industry structures, technology and marketing opportunities are constantly changing.

So the academy's one-day workshop entitled Dynamics of Strategy is aimed at managers with a degree of strategic responsibility in their organisation.

The workshop promises a new set of tools for understanding the dynamic problems in forging a competitive strategy and designing powerful corporate initiatives that everyone in the organisation can understand and buy into.

The workshop, led by Kim Warren, teaching fellow at London Business School and Rod Brown, of Barclays Bank, uses the Egg savings bank as a case study and unwraps the practical experience from Barclays' own internet bank.

Companies delivering service through today's new media face many challenges. E-business is no longer about how to deliver on the web, but how and where to deliver service in a multi-channel environment. Another major challenge is defining what constitutes service in a web environment, and how it can be measured, delivered and used to gain advantage.

The MBAcademy's e-service workshop - Beyond Clicks and Mortar - is a half-day taught by Chris Voss, professor of operations management at London Business School which focuses on building a successful business by sustaining a reputation for excellent customer service.

Voss analyses UK service performance over recent years and outlines the steps companies need to take to deliver outstanding service on the web, using latest research into second generation e-businesses.

The workshop scheduled for this autumn is a must for senior managers looking to add value to service within their firms and seeking an understanding of what makes an outstanding web-enabled business.

Increasingly, managers are finding it inappropriate to rely on position or status as the basis for influence. Instead, they realise that taking responsibility for their continuous professional development is essential for to stay on the highway to success. So the MBAcademy is also offering a four-day personal skills development programme in July that addresses the styles and behaviours of effective leaders and provides an individual self-development plan.

Recognising that busy executives often find it difficult to spare the time to attend conferences and seminars, the academy has teamed up with an online outfit, Original Thought, to offer its members access to interactive forums.

Original Thought puts together panels of specialists for discussion sessions which are filmed and distributed. For booking details and costs of these and other workshops, seminars or online training sessions organised by the MBAcademy, visit www.mba.org.uk

For further information on Original Thought and forthcoming forums telephone Sarah Hughes on 01235 462 020 or email her at sarah.hughes@otclub.com

webTitle: How to... be a diplomat and avoid foot-in-mouth outbreaks

fields.headline: How to... be a diplomat and avoid foot-in-mouth outbreaks
fields.standfirst: Build a network of contacts, use top intelligence and conceal emotions
fields.trailText: Build a network of contacts, use top intelligence and conceal emotions
fields.body:
Last month Rise revealed that the Foreign Office has become UK graduates' ideal employer. So we'd all like to be diplomats? I've got news for you: whether your days are spent in negotiations with the Chinese security services or with Tracey on reception (who won't let you in without your security pass), being a diplomat is now essential if you want to progress in any career.

And, contrary to the impression given by a certain advert, it's got very little to do with 'spoiling' your colleagues by handing round a certain brand of chocolates.

We can all learn a lot from the example of those who've taken the fast track into the diplomatic service. Take Dawn McKen, who's worked for the Foreign Office for the past five-and-a-half years. Now based in London, working in the Maltese and Cypriot policy section, she put her masters degree in Russian to good use when she was posted to Moscow to work as second political secretary at the British Embassy.

While there, she managed to secure the release of second world war papers from the archives and defuse an argument between a Russian civilian and a British tourist (which had led to the latter's arrest). She also successfully co-ordinated a visit by the then newly appointed prime minister, Tony Blair - which meant persuading the nervous Russian security services to allow him to hobnob with the Muscovite public on the Metro.

What skills does Dawn use in her job? "Accuracy is vital," she explains. "You need to have good analysis and judgment skills and be able to think through all the angles on a problem. You can't make any decisions in isolation - you always have to see two steps ahead, looking at the broader picture and working out the implications of your idea for everyone involved. Then you have to be able to justify your decisions. You have to know when to consult and when to use your own initiative. You also need to be approachable and friendly, build up a network of contacts and be able to put yourself in someone else's skin."

Qualities which, Dawn is the first to admit, we all need, whatever arena we work in. According to Rob Yeung, business psychologist and senior consultant at Kiddy & Partners, diplomacy is a key skill in managing office politics, working with colleagues and achieving promotion.

It's essential if you're going to a meeting with new clients or dealing with a partner firm. After all, people who don't know you won't be impressed by your track record. They'll take you at face value: the way you act and behave, the words you use. Get it wrong and you won't have time to backtrack.

Rob defines workplace diplomacy as "having tact and sensitivity to the needs of others". This doesn't mean biting your tongue and saying nothing - you still have to express your own ideas. "First," says Rob, "you must listen to the ideas of others, then put forward your own case in an assertive but not aggressive manner. When you're trying to argue a case people can get very emotionally involved. Put down someone's idea and they'll feel that you're also putting them down."

The earlier you learn diplomacy skills, the better. "Diplomacy becomes more critical the higher up you go," says Rob. "When you reach the top of an organisation and are dealing with shareholders, one wrong phrase could knock millions of pounds off the share price of your company."

As anyone who has witnessed the ongoing fracas between Robbie Williams and Liam Gallagher will know, charm beats aggression every time. Likewise, being an office diplomat means keeping your Neanderthal tendencies under control. The trick is to plan.

"If you're going into a difficult meeting, set yourself objectives. Try to foresee any problems that might arise - and the difficult people you might encounter - and work out how you'll deal with them calmly and effectively. Then, review your behaviour after the event and ask for feedback. Remember and learn from any negative criticism."

Rob says it's useful to identify your diplomatic heroes and villains and use them as role models. "Who is calm, empathetic and inspiring? What do they actually do? Watch their body language, their tone of voice and the types of words they use. Try to adopt these behaviours for yourself. On the other hand, who constantly offends people and puts their foot in their mouth? Do you make any of the same mistakes? If so, you'll need to change your behaviour."

If you don't remember anything else...

Globalisation means diplomacy is now more important than ever. Even those of us who don't work for the Foreign Office now have to deal with, for example, Japanese bankers or American lawyers - each of whom will have very different ways of working. You'll have to learn what's acceptable not only in your own company culture, but also in the cultures of other organisations and nationalities. If all else fails, you can always hand round the chocolates. Just check that no one has a nut allergy first.

fields.headline: Get personal with your workspace
fields.standfirst: What does the state of your desk say about you?
fields.trailText: What does the state of your desk say about you?
fields.body:
It's official: personalising your workspace improves your job satisfaction. The photo on your desk of a recent - although it seems like a lifetime away - holiday is more than just decoration or memory of happy times. It can actually improve your wellbeing and job satisfaction at work, according to a recent study by researchers at Eastern Kentucky University. The researchers found that when office workers were allowed to personalise their space, a greater level of wellbeing was reported.

Why? And what does your workspace say about you? Personalising the workspace is a way for people to mark out their territory and is their own identifiable and defensible space. After all how many people would rummage around someone's desk without asking, says Ben Williams, an Edinburgh-based chartered corporate psychologist.

Perhaps that's why many of us are so precious about our desks. The US survey of 1,008 office workers found that 85% personalised their workplace and 68% of those who did so said that it improved their overall attitude at work. As to reasons why, 60% said that they liked having their creature comforts around them and 39% said that they wanted people to have a peek at their individuality.

And why not, given that in today's workplace, downsizing has led to people feeling insecure at work? By surrounding themselves with personal effects, employees may be trying to create a sense of security and stability.

However, there are differences in how men and women view their workspaces. The study at Eastern Kentucky University found that women tend to personalise their workspace more than men and that they tend to use symbols of their family, friends and pets as well as trinkets and plants.

On the other hand, men tend to personalise their workspace with symbols of their achievement and sports paraphernalia.

Although it's important not to generalise, it's suggested that the reasons for this gender difference could be that on the whole women like to personalise their workspace as a way of expressing their identities and emotions, whereas men personalise to parade their status within the company.

Whether it's showing your sensitive side or showing how well you've done, the items used to personalise your workspace say something about you. Projecting an image by what you display on your desk can be deliberate and quite contrived - for example, displaying trophies that you have won in competition tells people that you're not just sporty, but successful as well.

"Photos of big houses and expensive cars are about telling people that you've done well and are wealthy," explains Ben.

While your sporting trophies or photos of your cat may make you feel better, only around half of office workers surveyed (47%) felt that their employers actually encouraged workers to decorate their workspace and 42% indicated that their company did not encourage this. Some employees reckoned their company viewed it as unprofessional, others were concerned about damage to the walls while some of the offices employees worked in adhered to a strict design code.

However, employers should think twice about imposing restrictions on employees who want to stamp their own identity on their workspace. Personalising the workplace gives employees ownership over their working environment. Imposing restrictions can lead to disgruntled employees and dissatisfaction.

Employers can have a direct impact on effectiveness in the workplace if they give employees some freedom, not just in the way they work but also in how they personalise their workspace, says Nigel Corlett retired professor of production engineering at Nottingham University.

So, if you're feeling stressed out, demoralised or uninspired, having familiar items around which mean a lot to you, can improve your mood and productivity. Most of us are working longer hours and spending more time at work, so having personal effects around the office whether photos of your family or postcards from your friends can help you remember what's important when the going gets tough.

Likewise, evidence of achievements or sporting prowess can give you a boost if you're having a bad day or are suffering from a lack of confidence.

But a note of caution: even though your workspace may be a reflection of your personality, be aware of how this may affect others and ensure that you don't personalise with items which may offend.

Any form of pornography like nude calendars, is a no-no. Similarly, symbols or signs of affiliation to extreme groups is not advisable, explains Ben Williams. Although there are no legal guidelines about what items can and cannot be displayed, it's important that you show sensitivity to your colleagues at work.

fields.headline: Deloitte Consulting
fields.trailText: Cool companies No 54
fields.body:
Most people's image of a management consultant is a chap in sharply tailored suit walking around the office with a faint air of superiority. But the Management Consultancies Association prefers to define a consultant as someone whose role is to show the client organisation how to relieve its managerial problems and identify new business opportunities.

Deloitte Consulting is capitalising on the growth of e-commerce to provide services to transform entire businesses - from their strategy and processes to their information technology and human resources policies. The consultancy says it is focused on making real, sustainable change, empowering its clients to deliver results that won't unravel at the first sign of trouble.

The firm believes it can do the same for your career. Chris Longhran, the partner responsible for graduate recruitment, says: "Our mission is to help our clients and our people excel." In October, Deloitte will be visiting campuses around the country to hire between 100 and150 graduates via two types of interviews: a behavioural event interview and a case study interview.

In a behavioural event interview, you are prompted to discuss situations from your past and your feelings and observations about them, providing an understanding of your ability to manage the 'people dimensions' of organisational change.

A case study interview presents a hypothetical or actual business scenario and you are asked to not only structure the problem, but deliver an effective solution. This line of questioning helps to highlight your analytical skills, business acumen and logic.

Tom Spellman, who joined last September with a degree in aeronautical engineering, says: "I wanted to join Deloitte Consulting as I was impressed by the oneness and honesty of all the senior people I came into contact with during the recruitment process and by its reputation on the campus.

"The company has created an environment where people are treated as individuals and fostered a corporate culture that values creativity and respects diversity."

As they progress, working on project teams alongside senior colleagues and clients, recruits will find themselves working for leading organisations, such as Microsoft, Honda , Boeing, Prudential, Nestlé and BP Amoco. Little wonder than that the firm has, for the last three years, made it into Fortune magazine's list of the 100 Best Companies to Work For.

For more details write to: Irene Oldham, Graduate Recruitment, Deloitte Consulting, Stonecutter Court, 1 Stonecutter Street, London EC4A 4TR.

webTitle: Brands which put graduates in control

fields.headline: Brands which put graduates in control
fields.standfirst: Are you being nurtured or processed?
fields.trailText: Are you being nurtured or processed?
fields.body:
What would you rather be seen as - a product or a customer, a part to be processed or a client to be cherished? Traditionally, human resources has viewed graduate recruitment and training as a service function. You were the product, and the end-user in the system (the manager of the department you ended up working in) was the customer. But the theory of employer branding (see panel) is beginning to place the boot on the other foot.

Instead of seeing graduates as product, employer branding puts you in the position of a customer with the end-user becoming more like a shareholder. You choose your company in much the same way as a customer selects a service, and stick with that company for as long as it keeps to its promises.

One of the first companies to have fully implemented employer branding in the context of its graduate recruitment and training is Reuters. "We regard the graduate programme as a product which graduates buy into," says Ivan Newman, head of global graduate recruitment and employee brand. "They are our customers, and from when they are still at university to the point where they come off the programme, we deliver a series of products to them and develop a customer relationship.

"Just like a consumer brand, if we want to keep our customers, we have to deliver on our promises. If we promise challenge and the graduates find they are sitting around bored all day then we are not delivering that product, and of course we wouldn't want that!"

Cynics might of course see this as just a clever spin on what happens anyway. Companies have always sold themselves to graduates who could leave if they didn't like what they were getting.

However, by reorienting itself as a customer-focused rather than a sales-driven, product-centred organisation, the Reuters graduate function is doing something very new, and, just like consumer branding, much of the effect is subtle, implicit, and goes unnoticed by the graduate-customer.

To implement employer branding Reuters has taken the core principles which underpin all of its business (speed, accuracy and impartiality) and applied them to the graduate programmes.

In this way, students and graduates experience implicitly the core values of the company. For example, speed is actualised through the rapid response times for queries posted to the website; the importance of accuracy is demonstrated through the involvement of senior management in graduate assessment; impartiality is shown in the wide range of personnel who attend university presentations.

These implicit experiences when added to explicit promises to "challenge, develop and reward" have made the programme's graduate-customers very aware of how well the product has lived up to and exceeded their expectations.

"They said we would be working with cutting-edge technology, which was true," says Sarah Hext who graduated with a BSc in physics from Durham University and joined Reuters last year.

"I was told that I would have on-the-job training as well as being sent on a range of training programmes that were non-job specific, and that's definitely happened. They promised a real job rather than just being told what to do, and that's been my experience. And it's certainly a challenge, which was what they said at the beginning."

"I know that other companies have training programmes where people have to sign contracts which stop them leaving for a specific amount of time," adds Kathelijne Alers, an Erasmus graduate who joined Reuters in 1998 and who now works in London.

"Reuters doesn't bind you into the organisation by having you sign up for three years. The thing is, you don't really want to leave because they give you so many opportunities."

"There are four placements on the graduate programme," explains Anita Liu who joined last year having graduated from the London School of Economics with a BSc in government and international history.

"But instead of somebody else deciding what you will be doing next, you actually get a lot of control over how you would like to develop.

"I'm going to New York in a couple of weeks because I argued that I was ready for the assignment abroad, and they agreed with me. It is not just somebody else deciding your future - you actually get quite a big say in what happens."

What is interesting is the way these graduates report how well the company has kept its explicit promises. But just like consumers accepting that the branding is part of the product, none of them were aware how employer branding had affected their perceptions. This does not mean however that their positive experience hasn't been genuine.

"It's just my personal view," says Ivan Newman, "but I think there is some basic psychology at work here. Individuals have needs which they want to fulfil, and it's up to organisations to identify those needs and fulfil them.

"The difference between consumer branding and employer branding is that the former generates and reinforces needs that you might not even know you have, while in the latter the need for challenge, development and reward is more innate. Employer branding is therefore more of a genuine expression of need than consumer branding."

webTitle: An ABC guide to knowing your worth at work

fields.headline: An ABC guide to knowing your worth at work
fields.trailText: Moving on up
fields.body:
A. Money matters

Money alone does not guarantee job satisfaction. However lack of it is a major cause of dissatisfaction. If you adore your work but can't afford to live on what it pays it's not going to hold you. More demoralising is the discovery that others doing the same job are better rewarded. But the real killer is finding that those doing less than you are paid more. That's why

discussion of comparative pay is discouraged by employers - raising money for Comic Relief by letting colleagues look at his payslip led to one employee being threatened with disciplinary action.

B. Cheap deals

It's not usually easy to find out if you are being underpaid. Where discrepancies exist it's in the interest of the better paid to keep quiet. But it's even harder to decide what to do if you find you are being treated unfairly. Once your suspicions are confirmed you have three options: confrontation, persuasion or defection. If you're so aggrieved that nothing less than a fight would appease you, get legal advice or join a trade union.

C. Good buy

Persuasion means having to be nice when you least feel like it. It's hard to have to work at proving your added value in a pleasant way when you know you're being ripped off. If you enjoy the work and see a future there give this a go. It will make for a better atmosphere than confrontation. The third way, defection, is the most satisfying: you land a cheap employer with a staffing problem while you go on to better things.

If you adore your work but can't afford to live on what it pays it's not going to hold you. More demoralising is the discovery that others doing the same job are better rewarded. But the real killer is finding that those doing less than you are paid more. That's why discussion of comparative pay is discouraged by employers - raising money for Comic Relief by letting colleagues look at his payslip led to one employee being threatened with disciplinary action. B. Cheap deals It's not usually easy to find out if you are being underpaid. Where discrepancies exist it's in the interest of the better paid to keep quiet. But it's even harder to decide what to do if you find you are being treated unfairly. Once your suspicions are confirmed you have three options: confrontation, persuasion or defection. If you're so aggrieved that nothing less than a fight would appease you, get legal advice or join a trade union. C. Good buy Persuasion means having to be nice when you least feel like it. It's hard to have to work at proving your added value in a pleasant way when you know you're being ripped off. If you enjoy the work and see a future there give this a go. It will make for a better atmosphere than confrontation. The third way, defection, is the most satisfying: you land a cheap employer with a staffing problem while you go on to better things.

webTitle: At this price?  United Business Media

fields.headline: At this price?  United Business Media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Lord Hollick has not had an easy ride over the past 12 months. The chief executive of the now renamed United Business Media lost his planned merger with Carlton Communications and his place at the ITV table.
fields.body:
Lord Hollick has not had an easy ride over the past 12 months. The chief executive of the now renamed United Business Media lost his planned merger with Carlton Communications and his place at the ITV table. He then suffered brickbats for the sale of Express Newspapers to a soft-porn merchant and is having his compensation package dragged through the mud by the National Association of Pension Funds.

Yesterday, thowever he must have afforded himself a smile as United's shares were upgraded by three investment banks. As Lord Hollick will tell you, this business is not about sentiment but shareholder value.

Goldman Sachs picked United as one of a handful of its favourite stocks in the European media sector. Morgan Stanley upgraded the stock to "outperform" from "neutral" and set a target of 800p. HSBC upgraded from "add" to "buy" and set a target of 820p.

As the advertising market falls away from ITV, United's decision to get out last year is looking smart. United minus ITV franchises and the Express is a far more focused group. Despite its exposure to the US technology market through its business magazine portfolio, trade titles are a safer haven in tough times.

United also has a strong balance sheet, £1bn still in the bank after the return of £1.25bn to shareholders, and there are plenty of bargains to be had. Lord Hollick has proved himself a shrewd dealmaker and the company should emerge from the current tough trading conditions with a stronger competitive position in its core markets of business publishing, market research and news distribution.

It is also in the process of selling its remaining internet assets with a deal expected to be announced on the sale of its largest operation, LineOne, in the next few weeks.

As for the US tech magazines, advertising will return and when it does United is sitting on many of the leading titles. The shares yesterday climbed 13p to 713p. Buy.

fields.headline: Car hoax backfires
fields.standfirst:
Woman wins £8,000 in place of 8cm model

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Size matters, say the adverts for the Renault Clio. It certainly did to Catherine McGowan, a single mother from Derbyshire, who thought she had won one in a competition on Radio Buxton last year.
fields.body:
Size matters, say the adverts for the Renault Clio. It certainly did to Catherine McGowan, a single mother from Derbyshire, who thought she had won one in a competition on Radio Buxton last year. When she arrived at the station to collect her prize, however, she was handed an 8cm model of the car and told she had been the victim of a hoax by DJ Chris Constantine.

But unlike other victims of Constantine's sense of humour (previously he had listeners competing for a model Ferrari F50 and a real bag of chips) Ms McGowan, a video shop manager, did not see the funny side. She sued.

Yesterday Derby county court ruled that she was entitled to the car and ordered that she receive £8,000 to cover the cost. The court has yet to decide who is liable to pay the money.

Attempts to stave off the suit failed. Steve Jenner, the station manager, offered Ms McGowan four tickets for a children's performance at the Buxton opera house and a meal for four to no avail.

Ms McGowan said yesterday: "I'm pleased it's all over because this has been going on for so long.

"They used me as a gimmick and to try to get more listeners. I think they have learnt their lesson after this."

Ms McGowan added: "I am not making plans for what I am going to do with the money until I have it in my hands, but I certainly won't be entering any more competitions."

Mr Jenner has insisted that Ms McGowan was misguided in believing the competition was genuine: "If people believed a car was to be given away, we would have got more than 23 calls, especially when a prize of a bag of chips got 17 the previous day."

Constantine was sacked for the hoax and the station was censured by the radio authority for breaching rules governing the way competitions are run. The station has been given another temporary licence for 28 days starting on May 31.

Ms McGowan's mother, Pauline, who encouraged her daughter to enter the competition, said today: "It was the principle more than anything. Why should this station be allowed to get away with gags like this at people's expense?"

fields.headline: Secombe's send-off
fields.standfirst:
Massed choir and clowns' prayer at Goon's funeral

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Sir Harry Secombe, manic and good-hearted voice of Neddie Seagoon in the Goon Show, was sung into eternity yesterday by a male voice choir of 70 fellow-Welsh exiles and by a clowns' prayer.
fields.body:
Sir Harry Secombe, manic and good-hearted voice of Neddie Seagoon in the Goon Show, was sung into eternity yesterday by a male voice choir of 70 fellow-Welsh exiles and by a clowns' prayer which asked, "help me to remember that your foolishness is wiser than other men's wisdom".

More than 200 mourners, with 50 others standing outside, crowded into St Nicholas' church, Cranleigh, Surrey, for the funeral of the most upbeat of the Goons.

The last surviving Goon, Spike Milligan, 83, was too frail to attend the ceremony. His wreath was inscribed with the message "Love, light and peace".

Among scores of wreaths was one from the Prince of Wales, saying, "For Harry, with profound admiration and great affection from Charles."

Secombe's coffin - as he might cheerfully have forecast - was so heavy that it could not be manoeuvred up the church steps and had to be brought in through the west door.

Waiting inside was the London Welsh Choir, friends from his years as presenter of the BBC's Songs of Praise, and fellow comedians including Bruce Forsyth, Jimmy Tarbuck and Barry Cryer.

The Rev Nigel Nicolson called Secombe "a fool for Christ". The way Secombe put it, in a joke obituary which he once wrote about himself, was, "He suffered fools gladly because he was one of them."

His 18-year-old grandson Sam Stock ended the service with a version of the traditional clowns' prayer.

Secombe was later cremated in a private ceremony. A public memorial service is planned for later this year.

webTitle: Europe and the media: the issue that just will not go away

fields.headline: The issue that just will not go away
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: A letter to the Financial Times from GM Simon of Moreton in Marsh drew attention to the favourable comment in the paper on the view of the former US ambassador to the United Nations, Richard Holbrooke, that "the EU is mind-numbing in its bureaucracy, arrogant, undemocratic and unaccountable".
fields.body:
A letter to the Financial Times from GM Simon of Moreton in Marsh drew attention to the favourable comment in the paper on the view of the former US ambassador to the United Nations, Richard Holbrooke, that "the EU is mind-numbing in its bureaucracy, arrogant, undemocratic and unaccountable".

Mr Simon responded: "Those of us who say much the same have been described in the Financial Times as xenophobic Little Englanders and generally unwashed, at least intellectually."

Not all readers of the FT are Europhiles, despite the stance of the newspaper. The Conservatives might take heart, were they not distracted by contemplating their own navels.

The election campaign that isn't, because the election has not been called, rolls on, with Labour in some indecision about policy over foot and mouth disease and the Conservatives in some disarray about who leads the party, or whether it is being led at all.

It is a true test of the robustness of the issue, even its importance, that Europe and the euro will not go away, come bank holiday or disease, parliamentary recess or phoney election campaign.

With the institutions of Europe quiet over Easter, and little opportunity for the Eurosceptic media to parade further examples of European intrusiveness, silliness or creeping federalism, the Tories on the one hand and the heavyweight Europhile commentators on the other have made the running.

The FT, again, pointed to the Tories' inability to avoid filling the news vacuum so deliberately created by the government. "While Labour ministers have headed off for unscheduled holidays, the Tories have dominated the news," the paper reported.

Labour had largely closed down its media operation and simply stood aside to "avoid distracting attention from their opponents' misfortunes". These had in cluded renewed leadership speculation, failure to find a brand that could win back voters, warnings to candidates against using racist language and disputes over political strategy.

And yes, Europe does lie at the heart of all this. Senior Tories, most notably the friends of Michael Portillo, were already sorting out the succession to William Hague in anticipation of an ignominious election defeat, and suggesting the unlikely alliance of Kenneth Clarke and Mr Portillo to create a broad Tory coalition with a more electable face.

Donald Macintyre, in the Independent expected Mr Hague to fight a "risky campaign even more focused on the euro than previously thought". It would be an overt "save the pound election". The attraction of this, according to Macintyre, was that opposition to the euro was more popular than the Tory party, and the approach "could embarrass a Labour party sworn to keep the single currency as low profile as possible".

If Mr Hague did better than expected, he might be secure, but if not, the strategy of narrowly focusing on the euro would have been shown not to have worked. A euro referendum would thus be more likely. And Macintyre pointed out that no longer could it be assumed that the referendum would kill the single currency as an issue, because there was now a growing band of Tories determined to fight on to reverse a referendum result that went against them.

Put all this together and the impact on the euro debate of the Tories' election strategy - or Mr Hague's survival tactics - becomes highly significant. As Macintyre said: "If there is another rout, it will be a defeat not only for a leader but for a strategy. And that will change a great deal in politics, not least the prospects for British entry into the single currency."

Hugo Young in the Guardian, describing the Conservative party as out of control and "careering into the far blue yonder", also considered the alleged Portillo-Clarke alliance and the impact for the EU of present disarray. The only hope for a political future for the present Tory party lay in a "no" vote in the euro referendum, said Young. Like Macintyre, he has discerned the growing number of Tories who would reject a referendum "yes" and engage in "an unending struggle to repudiate it". These Tories were also in favour of further referendums to "realign the entire British membership of the EU".

This could lead to legitimising an exit from the EU if the British did not get what they want, said Young, and some in the shadow cabinet were happy to contemplate this. He was uncertain how far Mr Portillo would go along with this strategy, but he "seems to loathe the EU" and is "obviously not to be trusted".

Young advised pro-Europe Tories to ignore Mr Portillo and run their own candidate in a future leadership election. "They owe it to their own conviction to the case they are about to make, that Hague lost the 2001 election because his Euroscepticism helped ruin his credibility as a national leader. They also owe it to the referendum result they want." For all those reasons, said Young, Tory pro-Euros should not help a party led by Mr Portillo, but leave, and thus destroy one led by Iain Duncan Smith.

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

webTitle: Rules for Tory runners and riders

fields.headline: Rules for Tory runners and riders
fields.standfirst:
It's my party but I'll quit if I have to

Special report: economic and monetary union

Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Under the new Conservative party leadership rules, introduced by William Hague in 1998, the chairman of the 1922 Committee would order a vote of confidence in Mr Hague only if he was petitioned to do so by 15% of the parliamentary party - currently 25 MPs.
fields.body:
Under the new Conservative party leadership rules, introduced by William Hague in 1998, the chairman of the 1922 Committee would order a vote of confidence in Mr Hague only if he was petitioned to do so by 15% of the parliamentary party - currently 25 MPs.

The rules state: "The chairman, without disclosing the names of any of the signatories, shall inform the leader of the party that a vote of confidence is to be held."

The chairman, after consultation with Mr Hague, would decide the date for the vote. If Mr Hague secured a simple majority, he would remain leader and a further confidence vote would be banned for 12 months. However, "if the leader fails to obtain a majority of the votes cast, he shall resign as leader of the party and shall not be permitted to stand in the election which follows".

If Mr Hague were ousted, any Tory MP, with two others as proposer and seconder, could stand. MPs vote for one of the candidates in a secret ballot. If there are more than three contenders, the candidate with the fewest votes drops out. Two days later, a second ballot is held for remaining candidates. The process is repeated until only three candidates remain, after which the one with the fewest votes drops out.

The two survivors go forward to a postal ballot of all Tory members "of good standing" who have been members for at least three months before the confidence vote - around 300,000. The candidates can spend up to £100,000 each on their campaigns, but cannot spend their own money: it must all come from donations.

Nothing prevents one of the two candidates withdrawing at this stage. MPs could in effect fix the result so that the second most popular candidate stands down "for the sake of party unity" or a senior shadow cabinet role. This would mean that only one candidate would be offered to the grassroots membership.

fields.headline: Keeping up with the Joneses
fields.trailText: A wise writer said the other day that the sub-text of British news about America is usually "they're all crazy" whereas the subtext of such British news as appears in American papers is "how are the mighty fallen".
fields.body:
 A wise writer said the other day that the sub-text of British news about America is usually "they're all crazy" whereas the subtext of such British news as appears in American papers is "how are the mighty fallen". Hence the demented coverage of foot and mouth, with American network reporters prancing around in protective clothing, like that scene in Annie Hall where Woody Allen asks: "Are we driving through plutonium?" But in spite of thinking that they're all demented, we desperately crave American approval. Look at the blanket coverage of The Weakest Link's debut on TV there. We are even proud of the fact that Anne Robinson has been given a 24-hour security guard. Our shows are so infuriating, they've stirred up America's most lethal nutcases! We must be doing something right!

And now, oh bliss, Bridget Jones's Diary has done fairly well in its opening weekend there, and will probably do better when it opens in more cinemas. Bridget Jones is British, you see! (Or at least was British: Bridget is played by a Texan, but with a faultless British accent. And her two boyfriends are definitely British.) But we're so worried Americans won't love us as we are that we set all those romantic comedies in a strange, sanitised place I think of as Londonland, a historical theme park, Cool Britannia meets A Christmas Carol, where only white people live, shops twinkle festively in the dusk, packed restaurants sell delectable food in designer settings, and the snow flurries winsomely around, landing like sequins on people's hair. In real life, the first hint of snow brings London to a messy, slushy, grinding halt and is as charming as an urban version of foot and mouth.

 Someone who is off to the States soon is my friend Christopher Matthew. Months ago I wrote about his book Now We Are Sixty, a pastiche of AA Milne's verses, recast for those of a certain age. ("They're changing sex at Buckingham Palace ...") It's been in and out of the hardback top 10, and this weekend the official sales should hit 100,000, which means that the real sales are nearer 130,000. So we have as a nation coughed up £1.3m for this slim volume, a pretty incredible sum. He hears from people who have been given up to a dozen copies on their 50th birthday. Now it's the Americans' turn, though I doubt that Christopher will need a 24-hour guard while he's there to plug the US edition.

The book is very funny and very clever, but it had virtually no publicity and Christopher didn't see any reviews. Even in this celebrity-crazed country, no magazine has gone to interview him; Hello and OK! have not stopped by to photograph his lovely home. He is not invited to speak at charity dinners, and reporters with long lenses don't lurk outside his house. Nobody has taken out full-page ads to promote his next work (Knocking On, volume 5 of the Diary of a Somebody, published in October).

I asked why, in view of this total lack of interest in him and the book, it had been such an astonishing popular success. He said it was the right size to sit by the cash register in bookshops. "It gets bought on impulse. If it was wider and fatter it wouldn't go there, and a lot fewer people would buy it." This is wise advice, which some of our heavily publicised and gravely reviewed authors might heed.

 As a wine writer, I am now, so to speak, an officially registered wine snob. It's rather like the way people register as alcoholics in some Scandinavian countries in order to be allowed to buy booze. I expect to have a badge made up. When I say something like "Mmm, I detect burnt toast, damp undergrowth and top-notes of cinammon," and people make jokey retching noises, I'll just wave it at them. In the meantime, I've been thrilled to see that while the New Scientist reports that while aromatherapy only works "if you want it to" - in other words, it's useless - red wine can help treat a wide variety of illnesses, including heart disease and Aids. (Admittedly the conference that announced this fact was held in Bordeaux, but then something must explain the great longevity of French red wine drinkers.)

How marvellous to know for sure what most of us already understood, that we can drop all this jasmine and ylang ylang nonsense, and get stuck into a really good Chilean cabernet. With top-notes of vanilla and wet leather.

 I learned in the States that there is now a huge market in creating fake grassroots opinion. Pressure groups will organise phone-ins, write-in campaigns, email blizzards - all cunningly constructed to look as if they come from real people with real concerns. The result is that politicians don't get thousands of postcards all using identical phrases. Since the communications look genuine, and since most polls assume that one letter equals the views of approximately 2,000 voters, they can be very effective. Being phoney grassroots they are known in the trade as "Astroturf".

During a conference session on jokes, I was reminded of a favourite old gag which I had long forgotten. Chap buys an old lamp, rubs it, and a genie appears offering him three wishes.

"I know about you genies," says the man. "You always twist people's requests. But you can't cheat me on mine because they are so simple. All I want is to be rich, to be royal, and married to a gorgeous woman."

"No problem," says the genie. "And I won't fiddle you."

There's a whumph noise, and suddenly he wakes up on silk sheets, in a four-poster, a crown at the foot of the bed, and, lying next to him, a stunningly beautiful woman, who turns to him and says: "Time to get up, Franz Ferdinand, we have to be in Sarajevo this morning .."

Hence the demented coverage of foot and mouth, with American network reporters prancing around in protective clothing, like that scene in Annie Hall where Woody Allen asks: "Are we driving through plutonium?" We are even proud of the fact that Anne Robinson has been given a 24-hour security guard. Our shows are so infuriating, they've stirred up America's most lethal nutcases! We must be doing something right! And now, oh bliss, Bridget Jones's Diary has done fairly well in its opening weekend there, and will probably do better when it opens in more cinemas. Bridget Jones is British, you see! (Or at least was British: Bridget is played by a Texan, but with a faultless British accent. And her two boyfriends are definitely British.) But we're so worried Americans won't love us as we are that we set all those romantic comedies in a strange, sanitised place I think of as Londonland, a historical theme park, Cool Britannia meets A Christmas Carol, where only white people live, shops twinkle festively in the dusk, packed restaurants sell delectable food in designer settings, and the snow flurries winsomely around, landing like sequins on people's hair. In real life, the first hint of snow brings London to a messy, slushy, grinding halt and is as charming as an urban version of foot and mouth.  Someone who is off to the States soon is my friend Christopher Matthew. Months ago I wrote about his book Now We Are Sixty, a pastiche of AA Milne's verses, recast for those of a certain age. ("They're changing sex at Buckingham Palace ...") It's been in and out of the hardback top 10, and this weekend the official sales should hit 100,000, which means that the real sales are nearer 130,000. So we have as a nation coughed up £1.3m for this slim volume, a pretty incredible sum. He hears from people who have been given up to a dozen copies on their 50th birthday. Now it's the Americans' turn, though I doubt that Christopher will need a 24-hour guard while he's there to plug the US edition. The book is very funny and very clever, but it had virtually no publicity and Christopher didn't see any reviews. Even in this celebrity-crazed country, no magazine has gone to interview him; Hello and OK! have not stopped by to photograph his lovely home. He is not invited to speak at charity dinners, and reporters with long lenses don't lurk outside his house. Nobody has taken out full-page ads to promote his next work (Knocking On, volume 5 of the Diary of a Somebody, published in October). I asked why, in view of this total lack of interest in him and the book, it had been such an astonishing popular success. He said it was the right size to sit by the cash register in bookshops. "It gets bought on impulse. If it was wider and fatter it wouldn't go there, and a lot fewer people would buy it." This is wise advice, which some of our heavily publicised and gravely reviewed authors might heed.  As a wine writer, I am now, so to speak, an officially registered wine snob. It's rather like the way people register as alcoholics in some Scandinavian countries in order to be allowed to buy booze. I expect to have a badge made up. When I say something like "Mmm, I detect burnt toast, damp undergrowth and top-notes of cinammon," and people make jokey retching noises, I'll just wave it at them. In the meantime, I've been thrilled to see that while the New Scientist reports that while aromatherapy only works "if you want it to" - in other words, it's useless - red wine can help treat a wide variety of illnesses, including heart disease and Aids. (Admittedly the conference that announced this fact was held in Bordeaux, but then something must explain the great longevity of French red wine drinkers.) How marvellous to know for sure what most of us already understood, that we can drop all this jasmine and ylang ylang nonsense, and get stuck into a really good Chilean cabernet. With top-notes of vanilla and wet leather.  I learned in the States that there is now a huge market in creating fake grassroots opinion. Pressure groups will organise phone-ins, write-in campaigns, email blizzards - all cunningly constructed to look as if they come from real people with real concerns. The result is that politicians don't get thousands of postcards all using identical phrases. Since the communications look genuine, and since most polls assume that one letter equals the views of approximately 2,000 voters, they can be very effective. Being phoney grassroots they are known in the trade as "Astroturf". During a conference session on jokes, I was reminded of a favourite old gag which I had long forgotten. Chap buys an old lamp, rubs it, and a genie appears offering him three wishes. "I know about you genies," says the man. "You always twist people's requests. But you can't cheat me on mine because they are so simple. All I want is to be rich, to be royal, and married to a gorgeous woman." "No problem," says the genie. "And I won't fiddle you." There's a whumph noise, and suddenly he wakes up on silk sheets, in a four-poster, a crown at the foot of the bed, and, lying next to him, a stunningly beautiful woman, who turns to him and says: "Time to get up, Franz Ferdinand, we have to be in Sarajevo this morning .."

webTitle: Leader: Hague pays for fleeing middle ground

fields.headline: Racing to defeat
fields.standfirst: Hague pays for fleeing the middle ground
fields.trailText: William Hague may now be wishing the election had gone ahead on May 3 after all. At least then the inevitable pain and anguish would soon be over.
fields.body:
William Hague may now be wishing the election had gone ahead on May 3 after all. At least then the inevitable pain and anguish would soon be over. Instead he will have to wait for judgment day. The delay has also created a vacuum, which politics abhors. Bored Tories have turned to the activity they know best: fighting each other. Aided and abetted by their surrogates in the media, the Conservative factions have spent the past week plotting the post-election battle ahead.

Their misery has been compounded by an attack from the foreign secretary, Robin Cook. In a welcome defence of immigration and multiculturalism, Mr Cook laid into the rightwing "fantasy" that Britain was ever a racially homogeneous nation, arguing instead that it was waves of newcomers which made Britain the rich, successful nation it is.

These developments, the Tories' internal feuding and the row over race, are related but it is useful to start with the latter. Much has been made of the refusal of several Conservative MPs, now including Michael Portillo, to sign a pledge issued by the Commission for Racial Equality committing politicians to refrain from campaign rhetoric likely to stir up prejudice. The inference is that these "refuseniks" must have some kind of racist convictions they refuse to repress. That seems plausible enough in the case of the outgoing John Townend, who recently blamed "commonwealth immigration" for undermining Britain's "homogeneous Anglo-Saxon society". But it may be unfair to put that gloss on every non-signature. Some recalcitrants, including Mr Portillo, have explained their refusal on libertarian grounds, insisting they are bound only to their consciences and their electorates and need make no extra pledge to anyone else. That view is coherent: there is indeed something vaguely McCarthyite about demanding every candidate sign a pledge lest they be denounced. The signatures of the party leaders should be good enough.

Still, that does not let Mr Hague off the Cook hook completely. The foreign secretary is right that the Tory leader has failed to set an example in this area. His speech warning of a "foreign land" was a horrible throwback to the intolerant past. Central Office claims that Mr Hague was only referring to Brussels meddling are disingenuous: Tory briefers were only too happy for journalists to link the phrase to immigration.

The Conservatives need to address this criticism - not least because it helps explain their current internecine fight. The split in Tory ranks is between those who advocate a more inclusive Conservatism - personified by Steve Norris and grouped around Mr Portillo - and hardcore social conservatives, embodied by Ann Widdecombe and reconciled to Mr Hague. Mr Portillo may now be trying to have his cake and eat it: appealing to the Tory right by refusing to sign the CRE pledge. But that is a risky game. What headway he has made has come by advocating inclusion, the very centrist territory Mr Hague has vacated. Both men need to understand that it is here, in the middle, that elections are won. Mr Hague's aggressive populism defies that logic - and will surely bring one, if not two, defeats before June is out.

webTitle: Council pair jailed for huge poll scam

fields.headline: Council pair jailed for huge poll scam
fields.trailText: Two councillors who masterminded what is believed to be the biggest voting fraud in British electoral history were yesterday sent to prison.
fields.body:
Two councillors who masterminded what is believed to be the biggest voting fraud in British electoral history were yesterday sent to prison.

The plot by Isaac Leibowitz, 36, a Conservative, and Zev Lieberman, 29, a Liberal Democrat, robbed Labour of retaining control of Hackney council in east London two years ago by tricking pensioners and creating phantom voters.

Judge Jeremy Connor jailed Leibowitz for six months and Lieberman for four months after Wood Green crown court heard detectives describe "the largest attempt to subvert the democratic process".

Lieberman, a school administrator of Stoke Newington, north London, and Leibowitz, a child carer from Clapton, east London, were each convicted last month of two counts of forgery and one of conspiracy to defraud Hackney's deputy returning officer between May 6 1994 and May 7 1998, by fraudulently placing names on the electoral roll.

Leibowitz was also found guilty of a second conspiracy charge involving bogus voters.

Defence counsel told the court that both men had resigned as councillors.

In his letter of resignation, Leibowitz expressed his "bitter regret and deep remorse" and apologised to the people of Hackney.

webTitle: Going for a song: Lighthouse Family gets Labour vote

fields.headline: Lighthouse Family gets Labour vote
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: After months of speculation, the wait is over: the official theme song for the Labour Party's general election campaign will be Lifted by the Lighthouse Family, a song used to advertise the Nissan Primera.
fields.body:
When it all gets darker then

The whole thing falls apart again

I guess it doesn't really matter about the rain

'Cause we'll get through anyway

Some of the most finely tuned political minds in the Labour party have been agonising over the decision. Now, after months of speculation, the wait is over: the official theme song for the party's general election campaign will be Lifted by the Lighthouse Family (above), a song used to advertise the Nissan Primera.

With the Liberal Democrats opting for a cover version of Stephen Gately's New Beginning, only the Tories are yet to unveil their entry in the battle of the election anthems, although speculation is rife that the party has commissioned a song from Mike Batt, who wrote music for the 1970s children's TV show The Wombles.

A Labour spokesman said Lifted, a number four hit in 1996, reflects the party's optimism for the future. But musicians and critics were less complimentary.

Singer Billy Bragg, who was behind the Red Wedge anti-Thatcherism pop movement of the 1980s, said the song had connotations with "watered-down Conservatism". He added: "So much of New Labour is about presentation rather than detail. They are hoping we won't listen to the verse and just hear the chorus - it's style over content."

It is understood that party officials opted for Lifted after the other main contender, Movin' On Up by Primal Scream, was declared too radical, considering the band's reputation for drug use and anti-Blair rhetoric.

webTitle: Labelling for drugs to be reviewed

fields.headline: Labelling for drugs to be reviewed
fields.trailText: The government's drug safety watchdogs have ordered an urgent review of the packaging and labelling of medicines in an effort to reduce mistakes which are putting patients' lives at risk.
fields.body:
The government's drug safety watchdogs have ordered an urgent review of the packaging and labelling of medicines in an effort to reduce mistakes which are putting patients' lives at risk.

Officials believe that emphasising the differences between types of drug and giving clearer descriptions and instructions are a key factor in reducing errors.

They are also drawing up plans to improve training of pharmacists and doctors to ensure prescriptions are properly prepared and to tighten rules on storage and access to medication.

The government said medication errors could be cut by 40% within five years although the Department of Health could not say last night on what figures that target was based.

Officials said some of the most serious incidents have happened as a result of the wrong drugs being administered, often because very different ones are presented to doctors in almost identical packaging. Lookalike and sound-alike trademarks are also causing concern.

The overall standard of prescribing is said to be "generally high" but it is inevitable that errors will occur. "When this happens, patients can be harmed, sometimes seriously," said an official document on improving patients' safety.

The Medical Defence Union said 25% of all indemnity paid out after litigation claims results from drug mistakes by GPs, who write 1.5m prescriptions daily in England alone.

NHS advisers think hospital mistakes, where a further 500,000 prescriptions are written every day, are likely to be even more serious because of the complexity of the treatments.

The government is already reviewing the administration of chemotherapy treatments for cancer after the accidental death of Wayne Jowett, who died in a Nottingham hospital in February after an intravenous drug was injected into his spine. But it has now emerged that the review is far wider than previously thought.

The committee on safety of medicines, which reports to the medicines control agency, has set up a working group to provide recommendations to ministers on improving packaging by July. The committee's chairman, Professor Alasdair Breckenridge, said it took "very seriously its role in advising on the information presented in medicines labelling and will play its part in tackling the problem of medication errors by ensuring medicines labelling supports safety in use".

The Association for the British Pharmaceutical Industry said there was no evidence that unclear packaging or labelling was responsible for errors and all products had to be approved by the medicines control agency.

Dispensing errors can also have fatal consequences. Recent cases include the death of a patient taking slow-release morphine capsules because the pharmacist provided medication at 10 times the prescribed dose.

The development of a national reporting system for medication errors is now under way.

webTitle: Thatcher's remains to light up the night sky

fields.headline: Thatcher's remains to light up the night sky
fields.trailText: Late revellers or early risers could see the oldest known meteor shower - the Lyrids - trace lines of fire across the sky before dawn tomorrow.
fields.body:
Late revellers or early risers could see the oldest known meteor shower - the Lyrids - trace lines of fire across the sky before dawn tomorrow.

Chinese astronomers recorded a night of "stars that fell like rain" in 687 BC, the first known observation of the Lyrids. In 1803 an observer in Virginia saw "starry meteors that seemed to fall from every point in the heavens". But the spectacle tonight and early tomorrow will probably be much less dramatic, providing around 10 shooting stars an hour.

Meteor showers happen predictably, as the Earth - during its year-long orbit around the sun - passes through trails of gravel and snow left behind by comets. The particles rain into the atmosphere at about 30 miles a second, and burn up in a sudden bright blaze. The Lyrids sometimes leave smoke trails.

The Lyrids are linked to a comet called Thatcher - named after a long dead astronomer - which last circled the sun in 1861, and is not expected to return for another three centuries.

Astronomers say the best time to watch is between 2am and 5am, when the shower is at its peak.

Observers should see meteors appearing to stream from a point high in the sky near the star Vega, in the constellation of Lyra.
