webTitle: Turmoil leaves Hague's future in peril

fields.headline: Turmoil leaves Hague's future in peril
fields.standfirst:
Tories in crisis Talk of leadership challenges, plots and intrigue gets louder by the day

Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Hardly anyone - not even leading Conservative thinkers - expects to see Mr Hague in Downing Street on June 8.
fields.body:
The mood around the cramped lunch table on the fourth floor offices of the Conservative thinktank Politea in Charing Cross Road, central London, was gloomy, and it was not just the cold salmon and mayonnaise. The discussion, involving a high-calibre set of rightwing economists, thinkers and MPs, took a second-term Labour government as its assumed starting point.

Therein lies the problem for William Hague. Hardly anyone - not even leading Conservative thinkers - expects to see Mr Hague in Downing Street on June 8.

Not even the foot and mouth crisis, in which the Tory leader has clearly performed well, has boosted his poll ratings. This week it again left him exposed to the Westminster parlour game of judging how many seats he needs to save his political skin. He faced the same speculation before the 1998 local elections and the 1999 European elections.

But this time the talk of challenges, plots and intrigue is getting louder. Despite efforts to claim the whole thing is pure fiction dreamt up by "postmodern journalists" filling an Easter vacuum, Mr Hague's future is once again perilous. A textbook Millbank-inspired operation painting parts of the Tory party as racist only strengthened the image of a leader unwilling or unable to control extremism in his party.

The shadow chancellor Michael Portillo's intervention yesterday, in effect rubbishing the idea of a commission for racial equality code of conduct to which Mr Hague has publicly signed up the party, deepened the sense of internal party disarray and opened the way to further Labour accusations of disunity.

Mr Portillo stated he had no intention of signing the declaration - not because he disagreed with its aims but because he was "bedevilled" with too many such declarations - only a day after publicly volunteering a pledge of loyalty to Mr Hague.

Only weeks after the party chairman Michael Ancram wrote to MPs stressing that it would not tolerate racism, the Conservatives have been split into signatories and non-signatories. The damage will reverberate, and with only eight weeks to reclaim ground, this has been seven badly lost days. Not surprisingly Labour plans to exploit the Tory chaos with a mass telephone canvass this weekend.

Yet the immediate cause of the latest travails lies in a more individual phone call on February 15. John Stevens, the millionaire leader of the tiny Pro-Euro Conservative party, phoned the former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke. He has always refused to back Mr Stevens' breakaway party, and the two men had not spoken for months.

They differ over the detail of the call. Mr Stevens undoubtedly canvassed Mr Clarke to issue a public statement urging him not to stand against Michael Portillo in Kensington and Chelsea. Mr Stevens was facing a split within his own tiny ranks, and privately did not want to put up a lot of candidates, especially against Mr Portillo.

Mr Clarke declined the offer, even though he had never favoured the idea of Mr Stevens challenging Mr Portillo, just as he had not supported the breakaway tactic. Mr Stevens had long nourished the hope that the breakaway could provoke a split in the Tory party on Europe. In this he has long been disappointed by Mr Clarke.

Mr Stevens still thinks a Tory split is the best way to ensure that the biggest challenge of democratic politics - a euro referendum victory - can be met.

The Stevens-Clarke conversation then turned to something less arcane. Mr Clarke expressed a belief that Mr Portillo was shifting ground and having a genuine rethink, now a common observation in the reduced ranks of the Tory left. In Mr Stevens' recollection, Mr Clarke suggested that Mr Portillo, if he won the party leadership, would not demand that his frontbench oppose the euro either in a referendum campaign or, more importantly, in its run-up.

Mr Clarke almost certainly did not mean to imply he had swung behind Mr Portillo, let alone a leadership challenge. And if Mr Portillo did remove the frontbench from collective responsibility on the euro, he would be doing something quite extraordinary, betraying his past and risking a confrontation within his party.

However, the general thesis that the left is looking again at Mr Portillo and that he is delicately reaching out to them is undeniable. They may need each other, and as the fault lines inside the Tory party evolve, an alliance is more possible. Mr Portillo's social liberalism, and admitted homosexual past, have alienated some but not all Thatcherites. Many, such as John Bercow, have travelled with him on the journey, but his base has narrowed. Some sceptics also fear Mr Portillo may be losing the stomach for the battle over the euro. They worry he will fight the euro in a referendum but, if defeated, accept the result as final.

The left, for its part, is a rump in the parliamentary party and is reluctantly discounting Mr Clarke's chances.

Figures such as Stephen Dorrell and Damian Green recognise the substance of the Portillo political cum cultural journey. They know he took a huge personal risk when he told his party conference in Bournemouth he was for people "regardless of sexual orientation".

In the autumn, after months of introspection induced by the inevitable party backlash, Mr Portillo picked himself up and decided to focus on the job of shadow chancellor, working on the details of the Tories' proposed £8m tax cut. He only once more formally genuflected to his new constituency by speaking to a meeting of the centre-left Mainstream group at the Tory spring conference. The speech was innocuous but the symbolism important.

But there is no sign that Mr Portillo and his immediate aides are now plotting. He has no personal motive to do so, at this stage.

Ready to strike

This does not stop others, especially those who fear Mr Portillo will again dither, from preparing to ensure there is a challenge. The key date in the mind of the diverse anti-Hague alliance is June 8. They are determined in the wake of the election not to let Mr Hague's allies move quicker than them. They do not want a repeat of the John Major ploy in 1995 when he got his message out that he had won the vote of confidence. Hagueites will not be allowed to dominate the networks with claims that by gaining 30 to 50 seats, Mr Hague has shown he is credibly one election away from the premiership, or at the very least the man to lead the fight to save the pound in a euro referendum. Names are already being suggested to declare that Mr Hague must go. The potential names are substantial: Chris Patten, Steve Norris, Lord Cranborne, possibly David Davis.

Mr Hague potentially faces a strong triumvirate of diverse forces ready to strike against him - social liberals like Stephen Dorrell, Steve Norris, independent rightwingers such as David Davis and Eric Forth, pro-Europeans such as Ian Taylor. From within that nexus, someone will emerge to find the 15% of Tory MPs required to mount a vote of no confidence.

For in the short space of his leadership, Mr Hague has made enemies. He has sacked John Redwood, let down Michael Howard, dismissed Lord Cranborne, upended Ann Widdecombe, and infuriated Francis Maude.

On June 8 and the feverish days thereafter, everyone will make their own calculation, and it is possible the election result will be clear enough to make the decision for everyone.

But Mr Hague's survival will not depend just on the mathematics. It will depend on his performance in the campaign and whether he can produce a strategy to show he can credibly broaden his appeal. He will also need to "take out" his potential challengers by offering promotion. It is widely expected that the talented sceptic Iain Duncan Smith will be made foreign secretary. But some Tory MPs believe Mr Hague must, and will, go further. They say he may offer a more conciliatory style, widening his field of advice, shedding some unpopular aides and vowing a return to the more socially inclusive politics of his first two leadership years.

It may be too late. As one shadow cab inet member complained recently: "We seem to have reversed the normal electoral cycle. Instead of starting by resecuring our core support and then broadening the appeal to the centre, we began with a wide appeal and spent the last two years narrowing it."

The narrowing of the appeal, and the failure to find much distinctive to say on health and education, has lost Mr Hague many natural friends. His often refreshing and thoughtful speeches of the first two years of his leadership were laced with talk of compassion and the need to move on from the economic agenda of the 1980s.

He daringly tried to symbolise the conversion in April 1999 by sanctioning his then deputy Peter Lilley to reject Thatcherism and abandon attempts to find private sector solutions to the problems of education and health. It was a clumsy piece of repositioning, made worse by the accompanying spin operation. The Daily Mail trailed the speech as the most spectacular policy switch since the second world war.

It was the turning point in the Hague leadership. The backlash led to Mr Lilley's dismissal, and the departure of some innovative but disaffected central office staff, such as Andrew Cooper and Michael Simmonds. A harder edged, less socially liberal group including the MPs Tim Collins and Andrew Lansley grew in influence. The discussion, involving a high-calibre set of rightwing economists, thinkers and MPs, took a second-term Labour government as its assumed starting point. Therein lies the problem for William Hague. Hardly anyone - not even leading Conservative thinkers - expects to see Mr Hague in Downing Street on June 8. Not even the foot and mouth crisis, in which the Tory leader has clearly performed well, has boosted his poll ratings. This week it again left him exposed to the Westminster parlour game of judging how many seats he needs to save his political skin. He faced the same speculation before the 1998 local elections and the 1999 European elections. But this time the talk of challenges, plots and intrigue is getting louder. Despite efforts to claim the whole thing is pure fiction dreamt up by "postmodern journalists" filling an Easter vacuum, Mr Hague's future is once again perilous. A textbook Millbank-inspired operation painting parts of the Tory party as racist only strengthened the image of a leader unwilling or unable to control extremism in his party. The shadow chancellor Michael Portillo's intervention yesterday, in effect rubbishing the idea of a commission for racial equality code of conduct to which Mr Hague has publicly signed up the party, deepened the sense of internal party disarray and opened the way to further Labour accusations of disunity. Mr Portillo stated he had no intention of signing the declaration - not because he disagreed with its aims but because he was "bedevilled" with too many such declarations - only a day after publicly volunteering a pledge of loyalty to Mr Hague. Only weeks after the party chairman Michael Ancram wrote to MPs stressing that it would not tolerate racism, the Conservatives have been split into signatories and non-signatories. The damage will reverberate, and with only eight weeks to reclaim ground, this has been seven badly lost days. Not surprisingly Labour plans to exploit the Tory chaos with a mass telephone canvass this weekend. Yet the immediate cause of the latest travails lies in a more individual phone call on February 15. John Stevens, the millionaire leader of the tiny Pro-Euro Conservative party, phoned the former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke. He has always refused to back Mr Stevens' breakaway party, and the two men had not spoken for months. They differ over the detail of the call. Mr Stevens undoubtedly canvassed Mr Clarke to issue a public statement urging him not to stand against Michael Portillo in Kensington and Chelsea. Mr Stevens was facing a split within his own tiny ranks, and privately did not want to put up a lot of candidates, especially against Mr Portillo. Mr Clarke declined the offer, even though he had never favoured the idea of Mr Stevens challenging Mr Portillo, just as he had not supported the breakaway tactic. Mr Stevens had long nourished the hope that the breakaway could provoke a split in the Tory party on Europe. In this he has long been disappointed by Mr Clarke. Mr Stevens still thinks a Tory split is the best way to ensure that the biggest challenge of democratic politics - a euro referendum victory - can be met. The Stevens-Clarke conversation then turned to something less arcane. Mr Clarke expressed a belief that Mr Portillo was shifting ground and having a genuine rethink, now a common observation in the reduced ranks of the Tory left. In Mr Stevens' recollection, Mr Clarke suggested that Mr Portillo, if he won the party leadership, would not demand that his frontbench oppose the euro either in a referendum campaign or, more importantly, in its run-up. Mr Clarke almost certainly did not mean to imply he had swung behind Mr Portillo, let alone a leadership challenge. And if Mr Portillo did remove the frontbench from collective responsibility on the euro, he would be doing something quite extraordinary, betraying his past and risking a confrontation within his party. However, the general thesis that the left is looking again at Mr Portillo and that he is delicately reaching out to them is undeniable. They may need each other, and as the fault lines inside the Tory party evolve, an alliance is more possible. Mr Portillo's social liberalism, and admitted homosexual past, have alienated some but not all Thatcherites. Many, such as John Bercow, have travelled with him on the journey, but his base has narrowed. Some sceptics also fear Mr Portillo may be losing the stomach for the battle over the euro. They worry he will fight the euro in a referendum but, if defeated, accept the result as final. The left, for its part, is a rump in the parliamentary party and is reluctantly discounting Mr Clarke's chances. Figures such as Stephen Dorrell and Damian Green recognise the substance of the Portillo political cum cultural journey. They know he took a huge personal risk when he told his party conference in Bournemouth he was for people "regardless of sexual orientation". The speech was innocuous but the symbolism important. But there is no sign that Mr Portillo and his immediate aides are now plotting. He has no personal motive to do so, at this stage. Ready to strike This does not stop others, especially those who fear Mr Portillo will again dither, from preparing to ensure there is a challenge. The key date in the mind of the diverse anti-Hague alliance is June 8. They are determined in the wake of the election not to let Mr Hague's allies move quicker than them. They do not want a repeat of the John Major ploy in 1995 when he got his message out that he had won the vote of confidence. Hagueites will not be allowed to dominate the networks with claims that by gaining 30 to 50 seats, Mr Hague has shown he is credibly one election away from the premiership, or at the very least the man to lead the fight to save the pound in a euro referendum. Names are already being suggested to declare that Mr Hague must go. The potential names are substantial: Chris Patten, Steve Norris, Lord Cranborne, possibly David Davis. From within that nexus, someone will emerge to find the 15% of Tory MPs required to mount a vote of no confidence. For in the short space of his leadership, Mr Hague has made enemies. On June 8 and the feverish days thereafter, everyone will make their own calculation, and it is possible the election result will be clear enough to make the decision for everyone. webTitle: Time for Bush to show his China hand

fields.headline: Time for Bush to show his China hand
fields.standfirst:
Decision on Taiwan arms sales will give the answer

Special report: Taiwan and China
Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Taiwan staged a symbolic show of armed force yesterday, repelling a mock Chinese invasion by land, sea and air just days before the US takes the crucial decision whether to sell it advanced weaponry.
fields.body:
Taiwan staged a symbolic show of armed force yesterday, repelling a mock Chinese invasion by land, sea and air just days before the US takes the crucial decision whether to sell it advanced weaponry.

Fighter jets and attack helicopters armed with US-made missiles attacked targets in the Taiwan Strait as the annual Han Kuang (Chinese glory) manoeuvres involving 3,400 troops began at an acutely sensitive time in Sino-US relations.

Early next week US foreign and defence policy chiefs will meet a Taiwanese military delegation in Washington to answer the most urgent international security question since George Bush succeeded Bill Clinton three months ago.

Every year, under the vaguely worded 1978 Taiwan Relations Act, Washington is obliged to make an announcement about possible arms sales to Taiwan, the island which China regards as a renegade province and is inexorably becoming the West Berlin of Washington's embryonic new cold war with Beijing.

With a conservative Republican back in the White House and Republicans narrowly in control of both houses of Congress, Taiwan has been hoping for a weapons windfall that will bolster its defences and boost its attempt to edge itself back in from the international cold.

Well before his election Mr Bush hinted that he was prepared to lend steel to Taiwan's defiance of its more powerful neighbour on the mainland.

Now it is crunch time. Analysts on both sides of the Pacific regard next week's decision as the litmus test of the China policy the administration has put at the centre of its strategic vision.

It will go a long way towards showing whether Mr Bush is the ideologue he sometimes hints at or the pragmatist that conservatives have always feared him to be.

The events surrounding the EP-3 spy plane incident have added spice to the decision.

As Republicans return to Washington on Monday from the two-week Easter break they will be looking for proof that the man in the White House is prepared to stand up for Taiwan.

But Mr Bush has other considerations. As he repeatedly said during the spy plane crisis, he seeks a "constructive" relationship with Beijing.

As a free trader he wants American capital to go on flowing into the Chinese market. Any need he feels to face down China on security issues will always be tempered by the desire to keep its markets open to the US companies which finance his party.

China has 2.5m people under arms, compared with Taiwan's 400,000; nearly 10 times as many tanks; and, more significantly, more than 30 times the number of fighter planes, although most of them are old. Its navy dwarfs Taiwan's, and the gap is widening all the time.

That is why Taiwan went to Washington last year with the longest and costliest armaments shopping list in its history.

Most of the weapons President Chen Shui-bian wants are to equip Taiwan's defences against China's increasing naval and missile build-up.

At the top of the list are four Arleigh-Burke class destroyers - not yet built - equipped with the Aegis battle management and radar system.

They have acquired immense political significance to both China and Taiwan, because they could provide Taiwan with the platform for a regional missile defence system, the Patriot PAC-3, which is also still under development.

Aegis can track more than 100 hostile ships, aircraft or missiles at one time and, in theory at least, could give Taiwan the means to resist the 300-odd short-range missiles that comprise China's primary strike weapon.

Almost as significant are the eight diesel-powered submarines that Taiwan has repeatedly tried to obtain. German designed but US-built, they - together with the P-3 surveillance planes it also wants - would give Taiwan a powerful edge in the increasingly confrontational waters of the South China Sea.

Recent reports in Washington suggest that Mr Bush is looking for a compromise package that would significantly improve Taiwan's defences and satisfy the powerful Taiwan lobby in Congress while stopping short of a rearmament programme that would alarm and humiliate Beijing.

Most analysts believe therefore that Mr Bush will deny Taiwan the Aegis-equipped ships and the PAC-3 system. He is tipped to offer Kidd-class destroyers and press ahead with building Aegis-equipped Arleigh-Burkes, giving him a bargaining chip if Beijing concludes that the US has gone back on its ambiguous vows to support Taiwan.

If this is what the administration has chosen to do, then there have been other signs this week that Mr Bush is creeping closer towards a more robust de facto recognition of Taiwan.

President Chen is likely to get a visa to stop off in the US on his way to Latin America next month, an act that Beijing regards as a breach of the "one China" shibboleth.

Mr Chen may even be allowed to meet his supporters in Congress, such as the House Republican whip Tom DeLay, a militant friend of Taiwan. That would make China apoplectic.

Materially, giving Mr Chen a visa would not be the kind of threat to China that submarines, planes or destroyers present.

But the diplomatic snub would be very great. Even without the Aegis destroyers, Taiwan is on the verge of taking bigger strides to end its isolation now than anything it has achieved in the past 20 years.

Shopping list

4 Arleigh-Burke class destroyers with Aegis radar

(Possible alternative: 4 Kidd-class destroyers)

8 to10 diesel-powered submarines

P-3 Orion submarine surveillance aircraft

M-1 tanks

Apache helicopters

HARM anti-radiation missiles

Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile interceptors

webTitle: Japanese party members upset leadership designs

fields.headline: Japanese party members upset leadership designs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: For the first time in decades the contest for the leadership of the Liberal Democratic party, which almost automatically carries with it the premiership of Japan, is too close to predict.
fields.body:
For the first time in decades the contest for the leadership of the Liberal Democratic party, which almost automatically carries with it the premiership of Japan, is too close to predict.

As the 2.4m party members vote this weekend in primary elections, a division between the urban young and their elderly country counterparts is undermining the dogged factional loyalty that has kept this political machine together and in power for all but one of the past 46 years.

Final voting and results are expected on Tuesday.

According to the opinion polls the favourite, the former prime minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, is unlikely to win a clear lead in the first round, so he will be forced to either stand down or to undergo a damaging run-off against his more popular and reform-minded rival Junichiro Koizumi.

The outcome is expected to be decided in the second round, when the two weaker candidates, Shizuka Kamei, a former construction minister, and Taro Aso, the economics minister, are expected to drop out of the running.

This was not supposed to happen. Mr Hashimoto heads the LDP's Keiseikai faction - the biggest of the parties-within-a-party among whom the spoils of power have traditionally been shared.

The Keiseikai is backed by lobbies representing postal workers, war veterans, doctors and the construction industry, which account for 65% of the LDP membership and an even greater share of its funds.

No candidate from the Keiseikai has ever failed to win the party presidency. Usually, he receives promises of support from other faction leaders before the election begins, which then becomes a rubber stamp for the decisions of a handful of elderly men in smoke-filled rooms.

This time the party gerontocracy appears to be losing its grip. For the first time it faces a mini-rebellion by MPs, as well as an unusually democratic and unpredictable poll of the broader membership, which will decide more than a quarter of the 487 votes.

Many of the LDP MPs, who account for 346 votes, are worried that Mr Hashimoto will be little better than the outgoing Yoshiro Mori in terms of popularity.

In a poll by the Asahi Shimbun this week, only 12% of voters favoured the outgoing prime minister while 51% thought Mr Koizumi was the best of the four candidates.

With an upper house election in July, this consideration has prompted younger members to think the unthinkable.

"I refuse to simply obey faction leaders," said Hideaki Omura, a member of the Hashimoto faction from the city of Nagoya.

"It's time that we were given the freedom to decide for ourselves who is the most suitable candidate, based on policies and talent, not just loyalty."

While few other faction members have been brave enough to make such declarations of independence in public, the degree of discontent was evident at a meeting to formalise Mr Hashimoto's candidacy, which 20 of the group's 101 MPs failed to attend.

In the regions, too, the leadership's weakening control over the rank and file has prompted desperate measures. Rather than trust members from the postal lobby to vote according to instruction, party elders have ordered them to hand in blank ballot sheets so that they can be filled in en-masse by loyalists.

Such dirty tactics go unpunished because LDP polls are not covered by electoral law.

Elsewhere, however, disgruntled regional bosses have made the rare decision to give their members a free vote. This has led to confusion among loyalists who have grown used to doing what they are told.

fields.headline: Foot and mouth hits sales
fields.standfirst:
Epidemic causes sharp rises in food prices but consumers resist temptation to hoard

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Epidemic causes sharp rises in food prices but consumers resist temptation to hoard
fields.body:
British shops and stores suffered a consumer backlash against foot and mouth-induced price rises last month, bringing retail sales growth to an abrupt halt.

Sales volumes stagnated in March, according to figures released by the office for national statistics - the weakest performance for nearly a year - and a sharp slowdown from the surging sales recorded in January and February.

Food sales rose just 0.1% over the month, to the surprise of City analysts, who had been expecting bumper sales after reports last month that households were stockpiling food.

But while the amount consumers bought remained the same, they paid more because of soaring prices. The average value of weekly sales in March was £3.9bn, a 5.8% rise on March 2000.

"Although volume growth has slowed, price increases pushed up the value of retail sales last month," an ONS statistician said.

"You don't need to be a Maff vet to diagnose the impact of foot and mouth disease in March's retail sales data," said Ross Walker, UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland. "In effect, the higher cash spend was siphoned off into higher prices."

The so-called retail sales deflator - a measure of inflation on the high street - surged to 1% in the 12 months to March, from 0.2% the previous month, the highest in over two years. Food prices increased by 3.7%, mainly driven by higher meat and seasonal vegetable prices, according to the ONS.

This is unlikely to trouble the Bank of England's rate-setting monetary policy committee because the wider measure of retail price inflation released on Thursday showed prices rising at their slowest rate in a year. While food stores managed an anaemic 0.1% increase in sales volumes, non-food retailers suffered a 0.4% fall. Chemists and newsagents were hardest hit, with volumes falling by 1.4% over the month.

City analysts seized on the figures as giving the green light for further rate cuts. The Bank of England has been scrutinising the retail sales figures for signs that consumers have begun tightening their belts to make room for higher government spending to come.

"This morning's report clearly provided some dovish news for the market, and certainly helps the cause for a May rate cut," said George Buckley, UK economist at Deutsche Bank.

But other analysts warned it was too soon to declare the consumer boom over.

"The UK consumer is still in good shape and may just have paused for breath in May," said Mr Walker.

Although the Bank has lowered borrowing costs twice since February, some members of the MPC have been wary about the risk of robust demand reigniting inflation.

But the minutes of its latest meeting released this week suggest the MPC has switched focus from the domestic economy to the deteriorating global economic outlook.

 EU finance ministers last night piled pressure on the ECB to join global efforts to ward off recession. "A rate cut is long overdue," said Austrian finance minister Karl-Heinz Grasser, at a meeting of finance ministers and central bank governors.

fields.bodyText: British shops and stores suffered a consumer backlash against foot and mouth-induced price rises last month, bringing retail sales growth to an abrupt halt. Sales volumes stagnated in March, according to figures released by the office for national statistics - the weakest performance for nearly a year - and a sharp slowdown from the surging sales recorded in January and February. Food sales rose just 0.1% over the month, to the surprise of City analysts, who had been expecting bumper sales after reports last month that households were stockpiling food. But while the amount consumers bought remained the same, they paid more because of soaring prices. The average value of weekly sales in March was £3.9bn, a 5.8% rise on March 2000. "Although volume growth has slowed, price increases pushed up the value of retail sales last month," an ONS statistician said. "You don't need to be a Maff vet to diagnose the impact of foot and mouth disease in March's retail sales data," said Ross Walker, UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland. "In effect, the higher cash spend was siphoned off into higher prices." The so-called retail sales deflator - a measure of inflation on the high street - surged to 1% in the 12 months to March, from 0.2% the previous month, the highest in over two years. Food prices increased by 3.7%, mainly driven by higher meat and seasonal vegetable prices, according to the ONS. This is unlikely to trouble the Bank of England's rate-setting monetary policy committee because the wider measure of retail price inflation released on Thursday showed prices rising at their slowest rate in a year. While food stores managed an anaemic 0.1% increase in sales volumes, non-food retailers suffered a 0.4% fall. Chemists and newsagents were hardest hit, with volumes falling by 1.4% over the month. City analysts seized on the figures as giving the green light for further rate cuts. The Bank of England has been scrutinising the retail sales figures for signs that consumers have begun tightening their belts to make room for higher government spending to come. "This morning's report clearly provided some dovish news for the market, and certainly helps the cause for a May rate cut," said George Buckley, UK economist at Deutsche Bank. But other analysts warned it was too soon to declare the consumer boom over. "The UK consumer is still in good shape and may just have paused for breath in May," said Mr Walker. Although the Bank has lowered borrowing costs twice since February, some members of the MPC have been wary about the risk of robust demand reigniting inflation. But the minutes of its latest meeting released this week suggest the MPC has switched focus from the domestic economy to the deteriorating global economic outlook.  EU finance ministers last night piled pressure on the ECB to join global efforts to ward off recession. "A rate cut is long overdue," said Austrian finance minister Karl-Heinz Grasser, at a meeting of finance ministers and central bank governors. The ECB is the only big central bank not to have cut rates since the global outlook deteriorated. Its next meeting is on Thursday. webTitle: Foot and mouth: is the worst really over?

fields.headline: Can we really believe the worst is over?
fields.standfirst:
The government's chief scientist has claimed the epidemic is under control. Others disagree

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The government's chief scientist has claimed the epidemic is under control. Others disagree.
fields.byline: Max Houghton and Faisal al Yafai
fields.body:
Patrick Holden, director of the Soil Association

"You cannot define 20 new cases as under control; if we had had that in the early stages we would have been desperately alarmed. It's about half the maximum rate, which means that the outbreak may not be quite as out of control as it was. But if you talk to people on the ground in Devon and Cumbria and south west Scotland, there is still a major problem.

"We all hope it will be brought under control. But I think whether or not the disease is in decline and has reached a point where it can be controlled by slaughter, it doesn't remove the question of whether culling is the best strategy either in the tail end of this outbreak or in a new one.

"If you bring the disease under control by killing all the livestock in the area it's a pyrrhic victory."

Martin Haworth, director of policy, National Farmers' Union

"We're certainly not going to use the phrase 'under control' because it's capable of misinterpretation. It's under control in the sense that all the evidence is that the outbreak has hit its peak and is on the way down, but we will not accept we have defeated the disease until we have seen the last case.

"Complacency would be a danger. The mechanisms in place are having an effect, but if people think it's been defeated when it hasn't and become lax and start moving animals against the rules, or not being so assiduous with disinfecting themselves or vehicles, there's the risk of a new outbreak in an area where we haven't had one so far. That would be a disaster."

Harold Armstrong, farmer, Bromfield, Cumbria

"Around here we're on target, slaughtering animals within 10 days of reporting the infection, but that doesn't mean it's under control. Nationally the number of farms infected is falling, but the percentage of cases in some areas like Cumbria is rising.

"From here, I can see 12 farms around me that have been infected, and only four that are left. Two-thirds of farms have been infected, and those that are left are on their own, so if they're saying the number is falling, that's because there aren't many farms left."

Peter Vasey, pedigree cattle breeder, Cumbria

"There do seem to be less cases, but there's also less cattle left to infect in Cumbria. There's a good chance the worst is over, but farmers have suffered badly."

Paul Ashley, north-west representative for Farmers for Action

"There are smaller numbers of reported cases at the moment, and we are improving the immediate cull. If you look at what was happening at the start of the outbreak, after each reported case there would be an outbreak on a neighbouring farm 10 to 12 days later. Now they are removing the infected animals almost within 24 hours. It is improving.

"If Maff and the army can get on top of the disposal of carcasses, then maybe the timing goals will be achieved and if that happens then we will see a significant reduction in the number of cases."

Lieutenant-Colonel Barry Hawgood, spokesman for the army's operation in Cumbria

"It's a very dangerous thing to say that the epidemic is now under control. We're confident that we are in control of the situation as it is now, but if we have a flare-up, a new outbreak that we didn't anticipate, it could lead our resources to a level we don't wish to use. We have 250 personnel deployed in Cumbria, and we are capable of culling and clearance under present conditions."

Professor Mark Woolhouse, veterinary epidemiologist, University of Edinburgh

"If the rate at which each outbreak is generating new outbreaks is greater than one, you are in a period of increase. That was the basis on which we reported the epidemic was out of control. By our estimation it has fallen below one and if it stays there the epidemic is in a declining phase. As long as control measures are maintained, the rate should remain below one. I hope the report will encourage those on the ground that their efforts are working and they should continue with them, in particular focusing on 24-hour culling, which has had a real effect. Relaxation of the measures could allow the rate to rise."

Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food

"The epidemic is under control on two counts: the slaughter is being effectively managed, and the expansion of daily figures is flattening out. There were 16 new cases confirmed yesterday; it was 40 to 50 a day at the height of the epidemic. Had it not been tackled in the way it has been, with the vigorous culling policy for infected animals and those on contiguous premises, then it would have spread completely out of control by now."

webTitle: Five women take on the Maff vets

fields.headline: Five women take on the Maff vets
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Out by Birdworld, one of Anglesey's long suffering tourist attractions, the dozen squaddies have spent an hour trying to round up six sheep for slaughter. No one knows whose animals they are but they have been found in a cull area and the army's on the job, falling over, cursing and running about in the fields.
fields.body:
Out by Birdworld, one of Anglesey's long suffering tourist attractions, the dozen squaddies have spent an hour trying to round up six sheep for slaughter. No one knows whose animals they are but they have been found in a cull area and the army's on the job, falling over, cursing and running about in the fields.

The Anglesey six are finally cornered, shot and bagged up. A Mercedes carts them off to the landfill site on a trailer.

Two miles away at Brynsiencyn, there is also cursing: the army and ministry vets are due at the smallholding of Fiona Cowie and her partner, David Chadwick. The couple are fighting to the end to save their five sheep and eight lambs. "We want the authorities to apply some decency, common sense and science," says Ms Cowie, a college lecturer.

There's not been much of that in south Anglesey since foot and mouth was confirmed, say the locals. A massive cull of 47,000 animals was ordered and Ms Cowie's place is one of the last farms to be visited.

It has been almost seven weeks since they received a "D" notice telling them not to move their animals. Twelve days ago the vets came and Ms Cowie sent them packing. "I've been told twice by Maff head office that this was a voluntary cull and we didn't have to have our animals slaughtered. Now the vets are saying they have to be killed on moral grounds because it wouldn't be fair for ours to escape when the other farmers have had theirs killed."

Ms Cowie is one of five Anglesey women smallholders holding out against the ministry and forcing their cases to be heard in London at the high court. They say they have been caught up in a bureaucratic nightmare with the machine of the Welsh assembly rolling forward.

Ms Cowie's partner understands the official mind. He is a Welsh assembly executive officer in the agriculture department. Because of a potential conflict of interest, he is taking two weeks off.

The five women include an academic, a teacher, a nurse and an animal rescuer. "The authorities seem to be trying to prove a point," says Ann Lympany, who lives nearby. "I've got four rescued sheep, I don't see the point of taking them. The last outbreak anywhere near here was on March 9. We've volunteered to have them tested but I think it's just stubbornness."

"I feel threatened," says June Clucas, who also has rescued animals. "They have threatened me with the law. It's got nothing to do with science anymore. It's vindictive and political."

The women's cases were adjourned yesterday until next week.

webTitle: Battle ahead over burial trench pyre, vow villagers

fields.headline: Battle ahead over burial trench pyre, vow villagers
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Protesters yesterday welcomed an announcement that no more culled sheep will be buried in a pit 1,500ft up a Welsh mountain facing the Brecon Beacons.
fields.body:
Protesters yesterday welcomed an announcement that no more culled sheep will be buried in a pit 1,500ft up a Welsh mountain facing the Brecon Beacons.

But they reacted angrily to news that burning of carcasses will continue not just on an existing pyre but also in the redundant 2,000ft burial trench on the army's Epynt ranges west of Brecon.

"We've won one battle but now a much bigger battle is about to start," said Liz Maclean, who lives in the village of Sennybridge at the foot of the mountain.

Carwyn Jones, rural affairs minister in the Welsh assembly, announced that burials would stop because an expected cull of sheep on the Black Mountains on the English border would not now go ahead.

But members of Epynt action group say Mr Jones has halted burials because of fears that local streams which supply the rivers Usk and Towy will be polluted. An assembly spokeswoman rejected the charge.

The Epynt pit was prepared earlier this month and more than 15,000 carcasses have been buried in it. But the operation stopped after the environment agency in Wales found that water in a nearby monitoring borehole had been contaminated with ammonia. The pit was then lined with plastic, which helped to reduce contamination.

The theatre director Michael Bogdanov, whose farmhouse home lies on the flanks of the mountain, described the operation as a shambles.

fields.bodyText: Protesters yesterday welcomed an announcement that no more culled sheep will be buried in a pit 1,500ft up a Welsh mountain facing the Brecon Beacons. But they reacted angrily to news that burning of carcasses will continue not just on an existing pyre but also in the redundant 2,000ft burial trench on the army's Epynt ranges west of Brecon. "We've won one battle but now a much bigger battle is about to start," said Liz Maclean, who lives in the village of Sennybridge at the foot of the mountain. Carwyn Jones, rural affairs minister in the Welsh assembly, announced that burials would stop because an expected cull of sheep on the Black Mountains on the English border would not now go ahead. But members of Epynt action group say Mr Jones has halted burials because of fears that local streams which supply the rivers Usk and Towy will be polluted. An assembly spokeswoman rejected the charge. The Epynt pit was prepared earlier this month and more than 15,000 carcasses have been buried in it. But the operation stopped after the environment agency in Wales found that water in a nearby monitoring borehole had been contaminated with ammonia. The pit was then lined with plastic, which helped to reduce contamination. The theatre director Michael Bogdanov, whose farmhouse home lies on the flanks of the mountain, described the operation as a shambles. fields.headline: Bush arrives for summit debut
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: George Bush arrived at his first international summit as US president yesterday vowing to push for a free trade deal covering the whole of the Americas in spite of objections from thousands of anti-globalisation protesters.
fields.body:
George Bush arrived at his first international summit as US president yesterday vowing to push for a free trade deal covering the whole of the Americas in spite of objections from thousands of anti-globalisation protesters.

His arrival at the Summit of the Americas, which will be attended by 33 other leaders this weekend, coincided with a day of action designed to derail the meetings yesterday.

Thousands of people staged a series of demonstrations against plans to create the world's largest common market, stretching from Alaska to Argentina and including 800m people. Their protests prompted a police crackdown with more than 7,000 officers and a steel-and-concrete fence in the fortress-like old city.

Ahead of the official meetings which kick off today, several leaders downplayed the controversial free trade aspects of the deal and said they were working to support democracy and human rights.

Mr Bush made it clear, however, that the agreement was a top priority. "I'm going to be very aggressive about pushing a free trade agenda," he said.

The only incident in yesterday's demonstrations came when several members of Greenpeace violated the security cordon in a hot-air balloon. Local shops and offices, however, were boarded up in preparation for the weekend.

webTitle: Leader: Quebec protesters are missing the point

fields.headline: New battle of Quebec
fields.standfirst:
But the protesters are missing the point

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Like veterans from a war, anti-globalisation protesters will win another campaign medal this weekend. But they are missing the point.
fields.body:
Like veterans from a war, anti-globalisation protesters will win another campaign medal this weekend. The army won its spurs at Seattle in December 1999, laid siege to Prague last September and has now moved on to Quebec, the scene of another battle for global mastery, between the British and the French in 1759. Barricades have been erected, both sides claim they are fit and ready for action, the TV cameras are ready to roll.

The fact that between 10,000 and 40,000 protesters are likely to turn up this weekend in a bid to stop a summit designed to pave the way for a free-trade area stretching from the Arctic Circle to Cape Horn, is an indication of how hot an issue globalisation has become over the past decade. In 1993, when the last trade liberalisation talks ended in Geneva, there was barely a non-governmental body in sight, let alone a balaclava-clad anarchist. Now, attempts to create a free trade area of the Americas (FTAA) can attract demonstrators in their tens of thousands and persuade the Canadians to build a 3m-high concrete and chain-link wall around the convention centre.

Some of those inside the compound believe the protests are subject to a law of diminishing returns and will eventually peter out. With some justification, they argue that the protesters are either naive rich kids or professional trouble-makers who are good at highlighting the defects of the global market but less convincing when describing their own vision. The alternative to a world in which countries trade with each other in a rules-based multilateral system is not the sort of pre-industrial idyll that some of the protesters imagine, but a law of the jungle in which the richest nations use their power to impose their will on the weak and poor. The idea that trade is intrinsically bad is economic nonsense, and dangerous nonsense at that.

But this misses the main point. The protests in Quebec are not going to halt trade, let alone bring about the demise of global capitalism. What they will do is help create space for those with constructive ideas on debt relief, the environment, trade and global economic governance, to influence the world for the better. It is no longer possible for a new round of trade liberalisation talks to be launched by the World Trade Organisation in Qatar this autumn without the needs of developing countries being taken into account. And as the world's biggest drugs companies found when they were forced to drop their court case against South Africa this week, the mobilisation of global protest can change the way corporations operate.

This is all to the good, provided that the burden of reform is not just left to non-governmental organisations but shouldered by progressive governments as well. The decade since the collapse of communism has hardly been the triumphal march of let-them-rip markets that the champions of laissez-faire promised, so it is high time that the parties of the centre-left stopped feeling so defensive. The world economy is in a state of flux, with the model of self regulating markets and all-powerful corporations rapidly going out of fashion. Governments have found they have power, particularly when prodded by consumers concerned about the food they eat, the air they breathe and the world they live in. For some of those manning the barricades in Quebec, this will be irrelevant. After all, if capitalism really is about to collapse, then one more heave should do it. But the history of the past 200 years suggests otherwise and, for the rest of us, the idea that interventionism is back in fashion can only be welcomed.

webTitle: Public inquiry into death of abused child

fields.headline: Public inquiry into death of abused child
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The government yesterday ordered public hearings of evidence about the death of Anna Climbie, the eight-year-old murdered in London last year, after months of sustained and horrific child abuse went unheeded by the child protection authorities.
fields.body:
The government yesterday ordered public hearings of evidence about the death of Anna Climbie, the eight-year-old murdered in London last year, after months of sustained and horrific child abuse went unheeded by the child protection authorities.

John Hutton, the health minister responsible for children's services, said an independent inquiry into failings by social workers, police and NHS staff would start work shortly to learn lessons from the tragedy and strengthen safeguards for vulnerable children.

He surprised the agencies under investigation by announcing terms of reference requiring details of their mistakes to be paraded in public. Senior managers had been expecting a private inquiry that would concentrate as much on general standards of child protection in England as the circumstances of Anna's murder.

The girl died at the hands of her aunt, Marie Therese Kouao, 44, and her lover, Carl Manning, 28, who were convicted of murder and cruelty at the Old Bailey in January and jailed for life.

She had been brought to the attention of social services three times and was discharged from hospital twice since coming to Britain from the Ivory Coast in 1999. After her death, the marks of 128 separate injuries were found on her body.

The judge said Anna had been repeatedly assaulted "by hand and implement", "covered from head to toe in injuries and open sores", "bound by ankle and wrist in packing tape" and "placed overnight naked in a bag in the bath, sometimes for 24 hours". He said: "What she endured was truly unimaginable."

Mr Hutton said the inquiry into her death would be the first "tripartite" investigation using powers under the Children Act, the NHS Act and Police Act. In effect there will be three parallel inquiries, conducted simultaneously, but producing a single report in spring next year to the health secretary and the home secretary.

Lord Laming, the inquiry chairman, will be assisted by a team of expert advisers, including specialists in paediatric medicine, nursing, child protection and the police.

He said: "The difficult issue of whether or not to hold the inquiry in public or private needed to be considered very carefully. I believe a public inquiry will be both more effective and fair, and will ensure that matters are dealt with in an open and honest manner."

The terms of reference instruct Lord Laming to:

 establish the circumstances surrounding the girl's death;

 identify which services were requested or required for her;

 examine the way local authorities, health bodies and police responded to those needs and how well they co-operated with each other and other services such as education and housing; and

 reach conclusions about the circumstances of her death and "make recommendations as to how such an event may, as far as possible, be avoided in the future".

Rob Hutchinson, of the Association of Directors of Social Services, welcomed the decision to take evidence in public.

The Department of Health said agencies involved in the case included the London boroughs of Ealing, Brent, Haringey and Enfield, Brent and Harrow health authority, Enfield and Haringey health authority, North West London Hospitals NHS trust (covering Central Middlesex hospital), North Middlesex hospital NHS trust, and the Metropolitan police.

fields.headline: Egg loses less
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Egg, the online bank 80% owned by the Prudential, reduced its losses by almost £500,000 to £38m in the first three months of the year and insisted it was on track to break even in six months.
fields.body:
Egg, the online bank 80% owned by the Prudential, reduced its losses by almost £500,000 to £38m in the first three months of the year and insisted it was on track to break even in six months.

But, while more customers took out products with Egg during the quarter, deposits worth £394m were withdrawn as savers chased better rates.

Stacey Cartwright, Egg's finance director, said it was becoming easier to attract new customers to Egg as people became accustomed to new technology.

Egg is aiming to reach 3m customers, including those recruited through its venture with Boots, and so far has attracted half that number.

To reach break-even, it needs to sell as many products as possible to each of its customers and so far its average is 1.33.

While Egg started out with a market-beating savings product, it has now expanded to offer mortgages, loans, credit cards and insurance products.

Its shares rose 2p to 149p but remained below the 160p at which they made their debut on the market last June.

fields.headline: Bloody  bequest
fields.standfirst: It is a family affair, the war of independence for the Basques. As ETA issues a warning to tourists visiting Spain, Dominic Ridley talks to the new generation who face a future of prison, sacrifice and violence
fields.trailText: It is a family affair, the war of independence for the Basques. As ETA issues a warning to tourists visiting Spain, Dominic Ridley talks to the new generation who face a future of prison, sacrifice and violence.
fields.body:
The Basques have been renowned for centuries as fishermen and sailors; it's thought they landed in America long before Columbus. They have defended themselves from invasion by the Romans, Vikings, Visigoths and Moors. They are the longest established people in Europe, and have their own language, Euskera. What the Basques have never had is an independent state of their own.

And their rumbling war of independence, which has cost more than 800 lives over the past 30 years, is not - as many Europeans had begun to think - fading away. On the contrary, after the regional elections next month, the conflict is likely to intensify. There are now 2.2 million people living in the northern region of Spain, bordering France, that makes up the Basque country. It was here that some of the bloodiest fighting against Franco took place in the civil war of 1936. And it was in defence of the Basque way of life, under attack from Franco, that ETA - Euskadi Ta Askatasuna or Basque Fatherland and Freedom - was formed in 1959. What began as clandestine meetings of a few scholars, grew quickly into a protest organisation. Franco suppressed the Basques with violence, imprisoning intellectuals, torturing dissidents and outlawing the language. ETA was the only visible opposition to his dictatorship and so enjoyed support from large swathes of Spanish society. In 1968, ETA carried out its first killing, Melton Manzanas, a secret police officer known for his liberal use of torture. It was a popular choice. However, when Franco died and democracy returned in the late 70s, enthusiasm ebbed away; many hoped ETA would lay down its arms. It was not to be. Last year's toll of ETA victims stood at 23, dozens injured, 46 acts of terrorism.

The Basque separatists have only one objective - independence. This is despite the fact that Spain is now one of the most devolved federal systems in Europe. The Basque country has its own president and parliament, collects its own taxes, has a police force (the Ertzaintza) and controls education. Approximately 30% of the Basque people speak Euskera and schools now teach in the language. Radio and TV stations broadcast in Euskera. A moderate nationalist party, PNV, is in power in the regional parliament; PNV's leader, Xavier Arzalluz, has never condemned ETA or its killings. Of ETA's first victim in 2001, a military cook from San Sebastian, Arzalluz remarked merely that ETA should select its targets better.

There is an intense feeling of claustrophobia in the company of Basque separatists. It is as if they inhabit a stifling bubble with ETA at its centre. Separatist language is littered with the lexicon of death and war. Posters and graffiti championing the terrorists adorn the buildings. Flags in support of ETA prisoners hang from balconies. Bars sympathetic to the cause flourish. Separatists marry within their community, their friends are of the same ilk. Outside the bubble exists the enemy. Within the bubble, sons and daughters grow up surrounded by the symbolism of ETA, of sacrifice, struggle, murder and martyrdom. A new generation is coming to the fore.

Iker Gallastegi is a life-long member of the political wing of ETA, Euskal Herritarrok (EH) - though he still calls it Herri Batasuna, its original name. His family is a template for the "generational uprising". I met him and his wife Maite in Getxo, a town just outside the capital of the Basque country, Bilbao. This wealthy suburban area, lined with Mercedes and BMWs, is the last place you would expect to be an ETA heartland; nor, to look at them, would you think Iker and Maite were revolutionaries. Yet they sit before me, talking of war and independence. Maite rails against those who think her mad: "A friend of mine said, 'How the hell are you living - this is not reality.' I said, 'Excuse me, this is real. The trips we do [to prison], these are real.' "

Iker has stood and won as an HB candidate in the local elections but refused to take his seat. "Why should I, a Basque, enter a Spanish administration. No, we need our own independent government." Iker's father and grandfather were also Basque separatists, or, as he calls them, nationalists. "Thirty-eight years, more than half my life, have been in exile," he says. "My three children were born in exile, like their father. I was exiled in Biarritz where all the Basque nationalist exiles were ETA." Within this bubble it is no surprise that his daughter, Osune, had been in prison for collaboration and his niece, Irantzu, is currently imprisoned for membership of the Donosti Commando - one of the oldest and strongest active units in Spain.

When I asked how they felt about their daughter's imprisonment, Iker replied matter of factly, "Obviously it means a lot of suffering for the family. You don't know how you are going to find them, but there, they are great!" He shrugs. "So you say to yourself, 'That's all right, they are going to be out in four or five years.' " Maite explains, "After talking with her [Osune], I didn't feel relief but very proud. Proud of her strength, and I received strength from her courage." Prison, it seems, was a rite of passage for Osune.

Iker explained to me how his daughter and others become involved in the war: "ETA need information, need safe houses. So around them they have eight or 10 groups. Eventually, members of these groups become part of the commando cells." He adds, casually: "Some of them are put in jail or are killed. Well that is the chain." Personal sacrifice is expected. As Iker, now in his 70s, says: "If you're a nationalist it is part of your life." His declaration that "the only battle you lose is the battle you don't fight - if you keep fighting you haven't lost" strikes a chilling note for those hoping for peace.

On May 13, Basque regional elections will be held and, for the first time since democracy returned to Spain, control of the Basque government may well pass from PNV to PP, the Spanish national centre-right party (led by the Spanish president, Jose Maria Aznar), if the latter succeeds in establishing a strange coalition with PSOE, a Socialist party. In contrast, support for EH is down, mainly because of the resumption of the terrorist campaign.

EH has for some time been under attack from the Spanish government. In December 1997, when named HB, all 23 of its national committee were sentenced to seven years' imprisonment for collaboration with ETA (released on appeal two years later). Eventually, HB was closed down by the government, hence the renaming and re-emergence as EH. The separatists can generally reckon to win about 20% of the 75 seats in the regional parliament. But they know they would have little chance of winning a referendum on independence for the Basque country.

Three years ago there was an attempt to make peace, the "Tregua". ETA declared an indefinite end to armed struggle and began talks with the Spanish government in September 1998. For 14 months, terrorist activities ceased. However, the beginning of the talks coincided with a shift to the right in Spain. The new PP-led Spanish government arrested 66 people for ETA collaboration, including one of the peace negotiators. The arrests not only enraged nationalists but moderates within Spain looking for an end to violence.

A peace deal without agreement on a separate Basque state would never have satisfied the hard core, but concessions on ETA prisoners might well have appeased the majority. Since then, the government has tightened the screws on Basque nationalism, making numerous arrests. Separatists feel that their backs are against the wall. If PP does gain power in May's regional elections, it is likely ETA will react violently. No longer will the enemy be at the gates, but inside their "limited" government. There would be nothing to lose.

Waiting in the wings to carry the torch of independence are members of Kale Borroka (Urban Fight). They are the next generation, aged 16-25. Those who excel within Kale Borroka are marked out as future ETA commandos. Urcko Manzisidor, now 23, was the head of the Vizcaya Kale Borroka until he was arrested during the third year of an engineering degree. He explains that Kale Borroka looks to Northern Ireland for inspiration. Every night incidents are linked to the group; cars and cashpoints are burned and homes of the Ertzaintza are attacked. webTitle: Red Square pilgrims sent round in circles

fields.headline: Red Square pilgrims sent round in circles
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The trees may be stubbornly refusing to burst into leaf. But the endless Russian winter has suddenly melted away. The ash-coloured snow has been shovelled away. Family and friends are showing up to partake of springtime in Moscow.
fields.body:
The trees may be stubbornly refusing to burst into leaf. But the endless Russian winter has suddenly melted away. The ash-coloured snow has been shovelled away. Family and friends are showing up to partake of springtime in Moscow.

At the very centre of Red Square lies the waxy yellowing corpse of Vladimir Lenin, housed in the polished red granite and black marble of the mausoleum.

It is the paramount communist temple, the atmosphere more forbidding and reverential than in St Basil's cathedral across the square. It is a tourist must-see. But be warned. The security is intimidating, the rules bewildering, the access rigorously controlled.

Access to the father of the revolution is admirably free and open to everyone, in theory. But hundreds of confused Japanese and Italians are turned away every day.

The first confusion arises when you find that the biggest public square in Europe is almost deserted. A stroll towards the sepulchral site at the Kremlin wall attracts the attentions of a soldier, who shoos you away.

Most of the square is closed every day for three hours while Lenin is receiving guests. You are advised to leave the square and head round the back: a 15-minute walk to join the queue that gets you within marching distance of the mausoleum. Or maybe not.

"Stop. No cameras," the guard barks. This is tantamount to barring every Japanese tourist. I remonstrate. "So sorry. Can I leave the camera here?" "Nyet. No camera or no access."

The Italians behind me break despondently out of the queue. They are later seen with their Sony digitals leaning on the square's railings, gazing wistfully at the tomb.

Dozens are frustrated every day. "What's the sense in this?" the guard is asked. Harrumph. "There is sense in everything in Russia."

Foreigners are treated with sullen politeness. Russians fare less well. Women have their handbags yanked from their arms and searched without so much as a please or thank-you. Men are manhandled and subjected to electronic body searches.

Down the black steps, inside the dimly-lit and surprisingly small mausoleum, there is a professional silencer. He spends the entire three hours going "shhhh" every 30 seconds.

A glimpse is permitted of the preserved torso - Lenin's lower half is draped in a rubber blanket, provoking fantasies of what lies beneath. A quick round of the glass case and the guards usher you back into the daylight.

Automatically, you go to stroll back the way you came. But the guards won't let you pass. This is the way in, they snarl. The way out is on the other side of the square.

fields.headline: Montenegro at the crossroads
fields.standfirst:
Government parties promise independence referendum

Special report: Serbia
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The final break-up of Yugoslavia will be at stake when voters in Montenegro go to the polls tomorrow in a general election dominated by one issue: whether the mountainous Balkan republic land should declare independence.
fields.body:
The final break-up of Yugoslavia will be at stake when voters in Montenegro go to the polls tomorrow in a general election dominated by one issue: whether the mountainous Balkan republic land should declare independence.

President Milo Djukanovic's Democratic Party of Socialists (DPS) and its coalition partners, the Social Democratic party, say they will call an independence referendum if they win.

Such a move has been fiercely criticised by the international community, which says it would encourage separatist movements in neighbouring Bosnia and Kosovo and prompt further instability in the region.

The contact group on the Balkans -the US, Britain, Germany, France, Italy and Russia - warned Montenegro earlier this week that it would cut off aid to Montenegro if it pursues the goal of independence.

The latest opinion polls suggest that the independence alliance will win.

But another poll focused on voting intentions in a referendum gave a narrow margin of victory to those wishing to remain part of the federal Yugoslavia.

Montenegro and Serbia are the last two republics left inside present-day Yugoslavia, a state which once included Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Macedonia.

Montenegro fought successfully for centuries to keep the Ottoman empire at bay, and its independence was formally recognised at the international Congress of Berlin in 1878. It was absorbed into Yugoslavia in 1918 at the end of the first world war.

Despite the importance of tomorrow's vote, the run-up to the election has been comparatively low key. Apart from a few pro-government posters on advertising hoardings, there is little evidence of political activity on the streets of the capital, Podgorica.

"I think that people's minds have been made up pretty much already, also we no longer have the problem of Milosevic still being in power," said Sreten Bogojgevic, 36, an electronics engineer. "People are taking things seriously, but with a lot less emotion."

The government coalition has presented independence as both "inevitable" and a natural continuation of Montenegro's development since 1998, the year in which it removed itself from federal Yugoslavians institutions in protest against the Milosevic regime's policies.

Since the feud, Montenegro has developed its own customs and banking systems - it has adopted the deutschmark as its own currency and abandoning the Yugoslav dinar.

The government parties have boycotted all federal elections and none of their MPs has attended the federal parliament. The last remaining federal institution with any clout is the Yugoslav army.

The Socialist Democratic deputy prime minister, Dragisa Burzan, says Montenegro's interests can no longer be served in a federation with its neighbour.

"Montenegro would suffer very much, it would not have a direct approach to funds from foreign governments. We would be represented by a federal government which we can not influence in any realistic way," he said.

Anti-independence parties say they will not take part in a referendum on secession. The People's party (NS) and Socialist People's party say they will win 40% of the vote.

"It's very close. The main political battle will be after the election, because there will be no significant majority on either side," said Dragan Soc, the president of the People's party. "I expect high emotions to increase if Mr Djukanovic calls for a referendum without a real consensus."

In an ominous warning to Macedonia's ethnic minorities Mr Soc said that Muslims and ethnic Albanians - who make up roughly a quarter of the population and are mostly expected to vote for independence candidates - to think carefully before making their decision.

"I am strongly against blaming Muslims or Albanians. I don't want to split our country, but in the Balkans this is a very sensitive issue. I don't want to say they can't vote. But people have to think about it very carefully. They should not be seen to tip the balance. That's my advice to them. I cannot exclude that pro-Yugoslav supporters could accuse ethnic minorities of being guilty."

The possibility of a bitter referendum campaign immediately after the general election has raised fears of a knock-on effect through the region, notably in Bosnia, Macedonia and Kosovo.

But international analysts and government officials have played down the danger.

"It's usually mentioned in the context of Kosovo, but we do not add or subtract in anyway to influence those pushing for Kosovo's independence," said Mr Burzan. "Their minds are already made up."

Peter Palmer, an analyst for the International Crisis Group in Podgorica said that the international community's fears were based on its failure to solve the Kosovo question.

"The status of Kosovo is completely separate from the case of Montenegro," he said.

"Montenegro should not be held hostage to the case of Kosovo, and be made a scapegoat to the apparent lack of imagination by the international community in its policy towards Kosovo."

Threats to withdraw aid from Montenegro would make things worse, he said.

"If the international community's overriding responsibility is to maintain stability in the region, I can't imagine anything more unstabalising than threatening to withdraw assistance... Linking assistance to Montenegro's future political status is bordering on the irresponsible."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our report of the 20st, 8ft halibut caught in the waters off Rockall (Hell of a halibut, page 11, April 20) we said it was "hauled ... from the chilly waters of the Antarctic".
fields.body:
In our report of the 20st, 8ft halibut caught in the waters off Rockall (Hell of a halibut, page 11, April 20) we said it was "hauled ... from the chilly waters of the Antarctic". Rockall, being in the north Atlantic ocean, 354km (220 miles) west of the Outer Hebrides, is certainly part of British waters - it was claimed by the UK in 1955 and incorporated as part of Scotland in 1972 - but it is at the opposite end of the world from the Antarctic. In fact the northernmost point of the sea area ends well south even of the Arctic.

We mistakenly referred to the guru made famous by the Beatles in the 60s as the late Maharishi Mahesh Yogi (Jobs & Money, page 25, April 14). In fact he is very much alive and in good health.

A part of Muriel Gray's column (Come in Cardinal Jedi - your church needs you, G2, page 5, April 19), was obliterated by the accompanying illustration. Here is the complete sentence: "So are we to assume then, that if some charming chap gets off with a mere six-month sentence for fiddling with the altar boys, he'll still have the future possibility of gainful employment administering wise words and advice to his eager flock?"

Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Trains (The railwayman's lament, page 28, April 14) is credited with giving a "self-depreciating" account of himself. No financial implication was intended.

A photograph of The Who (You are what you wear, G2, page 11, April 19) was wrongly credited to Michael Ochs/Redferns. The photograph was taken by, and belongs to, Colin Jones.

In the obituary of David Lloyd Owen, page 18, April 16, we said that in later life he was chairman of the Wildflowers Association of Great Britain. This should have read "wildfowlers".

Colin Humphreys (Pass Notes, G2, page3, April 17) is is not Professor of physics at Cambridge University but is Goldsmiths Professor of Materials Science.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number.

webTitle: Mark Lawson: Parody is an art

fields.headline: It's a sin to kill a mocking word
fields.standfirst: Parody is an art. The Wind Done Gone should be published
fields.trailText: Parody is an art. The Wind Done Gone should be published.
fields.body:
One of the April fool spoofs published in the newspapers this year suggested that in future, because of a quirk of European law, impressionists would have to pay royalties to those whose faces and voices they imitated. Only a crazed Europhobic could have been taken in for very long by this because the idea seemed so ridiculous.

And yet now a literary version of this principle is being presented in all seriousness as a legal argument in an American court. Lawyers for the estate of Margaret Mitchell, author of Gone With The Wind, are seeking to prevent the publication of The Wind Done Gone, a novel by Alice Randall due to be published in June. Randall's book is a parody of the American civil war classic, which, through mockery of the plot and characters, tries to highlight what Randall believes to be the racist undertones of the original.

A British celebrity once reportedly consulted a QC about the possibility of sueing for libel over his Spitting Image puppet, which he considered to be an offensively inaccurate representation. He was advised that caricature is usually considered immune to legal action on the basis that "vulgar abuse" is an accepted defence against defamation and that no one was likely to mistake a puppet for the real thing. This has generally been the attitude taken to parody and satire. Cartoonists are assumed to have more licence than columnists; Westminster sketch writers more than political commentators.

The only threat to the freedom of the parodist has lain in the possible area of "passing off". The late Alan Clark MP successfully argued in court that a send-up of his bestselling political Diaries in the London Evening Standard (written by Peter Bradshaw, now the Guardian film critic), might have been taken for the real thing and therefore affected both his copyright and reputation.

But it's in modern visual art - where it is common to "appropriate" existing images for new works - that there has been most debate about the point at which parody violates copyright. When Damien Hirst created Hymn (a work consisting of a giant version of a children's toy), he was required to make a payment to the designer of his inspiration. The Turner-shortlisted artist Glen Brown was similarly criticised for reproducing the cover of a sci-fi novel. In these cases, the argument against the artists was that they had merely borrowed, without substantial personal creativity. The broad equivalent in literature would be if Alice Randall had simply typed out Gone With The Wind in bigger print. But she hasn't. She has used parody for one of its most important purposes: as a form of criticism.

The impending verdict from the Atlanta court in this case matters because - even beyond the work of formal parodists and satirists - more and more art is a double-take. This is partly because of the volume of art already produced, and hence the difficulty of being entirely fresh, and partly because electronic storage and reproduction mean that modern artists have access to more works of the past than any generation of creative talent before them.

Look at the the works opening in the next few days: The Tailor Of Panama is a movie version of a John Le Carré novel which, though it concerns a bespoke clothes-maker in South America, took its inspiration off-the-peg: the novelist has acknowledged that his starting point was Graham Greene's Our Man In Havana, although in this case the inspiration is affectionate and oblique. But John Boorman's film adds another layer of imitation: his movie spoofs James Bond films, even casting Pierce Brosnan, the current cinema 007, as a smooth British secret agent, although an evil one.

Alistair Beaton's comedy Feelgood (which opens in the West End next week) parodies the rhetoric and personnel of the Labour government. Are we now to imagine that an Atlanta precedent might have the attorney general heading to the theatre with an injunction, arguing that members of an administration are the legal owners of their personalities and oratorical tics?

The clinching argument in this matter is that it can be argued that parody is a natural human instinct. Whereas it is not the case that we all have the ability to write, sing, compose, act or invent, imitation is genuinely native to us. Children learn to speak through parody. By adolescence, if not before, that language is often being employed in comic exaggeration. In the classroom - as, later, in the workplace - the words and actions of those in authority are stretched to their ridiculous conclusion.

Bestselling authors are privileged figures with forgiving and often uncritical readerships and they - or their estates - should be able to withstand, from behind their wall of royalties, a little teasing. A small section of the bookshop should always be open to, say, Joanna Bridge's Diary or Colonel Caperelli's Ukelele or, indeed, The Wind Done Gone.

The rules for artistic parody seem simple. There should be no serious risk of a consumer believing that they are getting the original and therefore income being directed to the wrong person. To ensure this, the source material should be significantly transformed (a defence not easily available, for example, to Damien Hirst or Glen Brown). The Wind Done Gone clearly passes on both these counts and so there should be no burning of books at Atlanta.
