webTitle: Face to Faith: Song and dance about music

fields.headline: Song and dance about music
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Square bashing in the RAF was a nightmare for AC2 Holman: I couldn't keep in step, as I am physically uncoordinated, and I could not sing the marching beat as I am completely non-musical.
fields.body:
Square bashing in the RAF was a nightmare for AC2 Holman: I couldn't keep in step, as I am physically uncoordinated, and I could not sing the marching beat as I am completely non-musical. The purple-faced warrant officer finally summoned me. "Holman," he barked. "You can't help it but you are a zombie."

Missing parades was a great skive, but it underlined that I am tone deaf, can't hear rhythm, can't clap in time, can't dance, can't sing. These deficiencies have proved a handicap. In Scotland, where I live, almost every social occasion is accompanied by a ceilidh, in which energetic women drag you to the floor while hearty, kilted men imply that you are a wimp for not enjoying it.

But what has my musical ineptitude to do with religion? The Christian church is obsessed with music. Be it choral masterpieces in abbeys, organs in cathedrals, evensong in rural parishes or Moody and Sankey tunes in non-conformist chapels, the church and music are inseparable. The assumption seems to be that God cannot be publicly worshipped without at least four hymns and a multitude of choruses.

This is fine for the musical zealots. I watch with envy those who are spiritually lifted by clapping their hands and by swaying in time. But it can be a turn-off for the musical zombies. I try to concentrate on the words, but some of the modern Christian songs have only three lines which are repeated until my attention wanders. I must be sounding like a Christian Victor Meldrew, so what do I want as an alternative?

First, humour. Stand-up comics tell jokes which can reveal our prejudices and weaknesses. Jesus sometimes used a sense of the ridiculous to make his point. So why not a slot for Christian comics who could not only bring laughter into worship but also give us insights?

Second, readings. Zombies cannot sing, but they can appreciate words. Poetry can be a source of wisdom and encouragement. Studdert Kennedy was a front line padre in the first world war. His cockney rhymes reflected the doubts, comradeship, and hopes of working-class soldiers. The second verse of Indifference goes: "When Jesus came to Birmingham, they simply passed him by, They never hurt a hair of Him, they only let Him die, For men had grown more tender, and they would not give him pain, They only just passed down the street, and left him in the rain." In his rhymes, I often find experiences with which I can identify: his pain that people can ignore Christ and his teachings; his despair about his own failures; his conviction that Christianity has relevance to all people.

I would welcome readings from Christians whose personal relationship with God became a basis for actions to improve society: Richard Tawney, who so powerfully identified the godlessness of capitalism; Herbert White, who founded a children's home - which still exists - and asked nobody for money except God; Jim Wallis, the American evangelist imprisoned for his anti-war activities; and Martin Luther King, a flawed character, like many of us, but one who moved others to oppose injustice. Their writings could be read in churches as a part of worship.

Third, dialogue. As the three-line songs get repeated ad nauseam , I look around at some of the other worshipers. A middle-aged woman who has overcome drinking problems, a pressurised deputy head doing a fine job in an under-staffed school, a bloke trying to get off drugs. If the church had a spot for public dialogue, we could learn how their faith has helped them in their lives.

Perhaps I will be advised to start a new church - the non-musical Zombie Fellowship. No way. I love the other people in our church, which has an inspirational minister. I have met other non-musical Christians and all we want is less time spent singing and more time worshipping God.

 Bob Holman is the author of George Lansbury: Labour's Neglected Leader, a Christian Socialist Movement pamphlet

webTitle: FSA strikes Archer's son from City register

fields.headline: FSA strikes Archer's son from City register
fields.trailText: Lord Archer's son, James, and his former trading colleagues known as the Flaming Ferraris will find it difficult to work in the City again unless they are successful in any appeal against a financial services authority ruling.
fields.body:
Lord Archer's son, James, and his former trading colleagues known as the Flaming Ferraris will find it difficult to work in the City again unless they are successful in any appeal against a financial services authority ruling.

Mr Archer along with Adrian Ezra and David Crisanti suffered a humiliating fall from grace in 1999 when their employer, the US bank Credit Suisse First Boston, sacked them after details of alleged share manipulation in Sweden were uncovered.

Until then, the three had been regarded as some of the most successful traders in the City, earning upwards of £150,000 a year and rumoured £1m bonuses.

After a two-year investigation, the FSA is understood to have informed the three that it intends to expel them from its register which allows traders to work in the City.

They have until next week to make up their minds on whether they have grounds to appeal against the ruling.

An expulsion would make it difficult for any of the three to work in the City again though Keith Oliver, a partner at law firm Peters & Peters, said yesterday that his client Mr Ezra would reapply for admittance to the register if the ruling stood.

Mr Oliver said that Mr Ezra, a former squash champion, is deciding whether to appeal. Mr Ezra had been cleared of two of three charges against him.

The three were dubbed the Flaming Ferraris after a cocktail sold in upmarket London restaurant Nam Long.

At CSFB they worked in the specialist department known as equity arbitrage, where traders try to make money on anomalous differences in share prices.

The Swedish authorities have completed their investigation into the affair and levied a £150,000 fine on CSFB. fields.headline: Making waves
fields.standfirst: Protest marks 150 workers' last day at shipyard
fields.trailText: A lone figure dressed in a union flag waistcoat stood outside the gates of the Cammell Laird's shipyard in Birkenhead yesterday with a Liver bird perched on his hat.
fields.body:
A lone figure dressed in a union flag waistcoat stood outside the gates of the Cammell Laird's shipyard in Birkenhead yesterday with a Liver bird perched on his hat.

John Bull, or Ray Egan as he is also known, said his grandfather had worked at the shipyard before the war, building submarines. "He would have wanted me to be here," he said. "I have seen dozens of blokes coming out of here carrying their belongings in plastic bags, with tears in their eyes."

Yesterday 150 people at the shipyard walked through the gates for the last time when they were made redundant.

They did so as it emerged that a company owned by Royal Bank of Scotland, which pulled the plug on Cammell Laird, is lining up a bid for the shipbuilder.

A&P Group, a ship repair business bought by the private equity arm of RBS three years ago, has contacted the receivers, PricewaterhouseCoopers.

Three possible bidders have been identified by observers so far : a management buyout team, rival shipbuilder Swan Hunter and Alchemy Partners, the venture capital company - although the last has denied it is interested.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Honeywell's profits fall 92%
fields.body:
Honeywell's profits fall 92%

Honeywell, the American electronics group, added to the gloom surrounding the hi-tech sector with a 92% fall in first-quarter profits as efforts to combat a slowing economy led to charges of nearly $600m (£420m) and plans to axe 6,500 jobs, 5% of its staff.

The manufacturer and defence contractor reported earnings of $41m, after charges for the quarter, compared with $506m a year earlier. The most recent results included $595m in charges related to cost reductions.

Matsushita may shut plant

Japanese electronics giant Matsushita said it was considering shutting a television components plant on the outskirts of Glasgow with the possible loss of 100 jobs.

The company, which owns the Panasonic consumer brand, said increased competition among makers of hi-tech components had forced it to review its operations and find ways to cut costs and increase efficiency.

Closing the East Kilbride plant, which makes flyback transformers for monitors, was a possibility, the company said. Consultation with staff representatives had already started.

Boeing beats expectations

Boeing, the world's largest aircraft maker, posted first-quarter profits of $762m (£529m), beating Wall Street estimates, and said it had almost completely sold out commercial jet deliveries for 2001 and 2002.

The aerospace company, which is quitting its Seattle headquarters, made $418m in the same period a year earlier, when a 40-day engineers' strike slashed jet deliveries.

Boeing said its operating margin, or profits less certain expenses divided by revenues, stood at 9.2%.

Dell overtakes Compaq

American computer manufacturer Dell has overtaken its rival Compaq to become the world's biggest maker of PCs, new research shows.

Gartner Dataquest, a US-based market analyst, said Dell shipped 4.16m PCs - or almost 13% of the global market in the first quarter of this year.

Compaq, another American manufacturer, dropped to second place with 3.9m shipments, its figures show. Dell sells its PCs directly to customers, while Compaq relies on distributors. The company planned to concentrate energies on its Hertz car rental division, which it recently bought.

Downturn hits Sagem's sales

French telecoms equipment and electronics group Sagem suffered a severe jolt to its shares after a slide in first-quarter telecoms sales. The company said a sharp drop in revenues had pushed overall first-quarter sales down 22%.

JAL weathers turbulence

Japan Airlines saw its group net profit in the last year soar 18.8% from a previous estimate on brisk demand, helping it weather turbulent times in the global economy, Asia's biggest carrier said.

JAL said group net profit amounted to ¥38bn (£217m) in 2000/01, exceeding a November forecast of ¥32bn and far beyond a profit of ¥19.74bn the year before.

webTitle: Pubmaster poised to toast takeover victory

fields.headline: Pubmaster poised to toast takeover victory
fields.trailText: Pubmaster is on the brink of winning a nine-month battle for control of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, after submitting a £480m "indicative offer" for the company minutes before yesterday's midday deadline for bids.
fields.body:
Pubmaster is on the brink of winning a nine-month battle for control of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, after submitting a £480m "indicative offer" for the company minutes before yesterday's midday deadline for bids.

The privately owned pub company, which is based in Hartlepool, is understood to have submitted a 510p-a-share proposal, beating a 500p package from leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare.

Wolves & Dudley's board will meet on Monday to examine the offers. One source said: "When the board has given sober and calm consideration to the situation, the directors will make a statement."

Wolves & Dudley is Britain's biggest regional brewer, producing traditional ales such as Marston's and Cameron. The company has four breweries and 1,700 pubs, including the Pitcher & Piano bar chain.

There may yet be another blip in the takeover battle. Industry sources said Wolves & Dudley's directors would assess the "credibility" as well as the "level" of the offers.

The company had hoped that interested parties would submit formal bids, rather than indicative proposals, and directors could argue that the offers lack certainty.

Wolves & Dudley rejected a preliminary offer of 500p-a-share from Mr Breare last August, saying it failed to reflect the value of the business. However, shareholders put pressure on chief executive David Thompson to restart the sale process. Investors are unlikely to tolerate the board rejecting another opportunity to sell the business.

Wolves & Dudley ran into trouble after struggling to integrate two big acquisitions - Mansfield Brewery and Marston, Thompson & Evershed. The firm has been a victim of the declining popularity of community pubs. Its shares jumped 22.5p to 481p.

webTitle: Time for Stella to take on the grande dame

fields.headline: Time for Stella to take on the grande dame
fields.standfirst: M&S chief must sacrifice bonus
fields.trailText: M&S chief must sacrifice bonus
fields.body:
The heat is on at Marks & Spencer. The Association of British Insurers has officially requested a meeting with the ailing but still arrogant retailer to put forward the concerns of its members - not just about Luc Vandevelde's utterly undeserved bonus, it seems, but a whole range of other issues which are causing its insurance company members sleepless nights.

The ABI, we understand, wants to talk about the group's latest cunning plan to win back disaffected customers and why the closure of the group's European stores was so badly mismanaged.

The insurance companies want to know why there is a constant stream of damaging leaks emanating from the most senior levels within the company.

It is unusual territory for the ABI. The association does not normally get involved in issues of company strategy - or, indeed, try to influence the payment of bonuses before they are officially laid out in a company's annual report and accounts.

The ABI is attempting to handle this most sensitive of issues - every move by M&S is now thoroughly scrutinised - behind closed doors.

It says much about the strength of feeling among its members, among them some of M&S's biggest shareholders, that such secret approaches are being made public.

Marks & Spencer must act quickly if the bonus issue is not to escalate into a much larger row about Mr Vandevelde's stewardship in general.

Dame Stella Rimington, chairman of the remuneration committee, must persuade Mr Vandevelde to do the decent thing and give up his payment, for the sake of morale within the company. At the very least he should defer it or take it in shares.

Dame Stella was awarded an additional £16,000 in non-executive fees when she took over the rem committee job - far more than standard, by the way - and it is time she earned it.

The store chain does not want to be seen to cave in to media pressure. Marks & Spencer is still far too grand for that. But now we are in a position where the staff are demoralised and the shareholders are bellowing. The issue is not going away, and M&S cannot ignore it for much longer.

Counter attack

Has foot and mouth spelt the end to deflation on Britain's high streets? While Thursday's headline inflation numbers showed a pleasing half-point fall in March, yesterday the government's number crunchers revealed that the narrower measure of price pressures on the high street, the retail price deflator, is rising at its fastest rate for two years.

Seven months ago, prices on the high street were falling at an annual rate of 0.8%. It has crept upwards since then, hitting positive territory in February with a 0.2% annual rise and then last month leaping by 1%.

Foot and mouth-induced increases in meat prices were part of the story, according to the office for national statistics. Fruit and vegetable prices also jumped after a bad harvest.

Before the supermarkets start pop ping the champagne corks to celebrate the return of pricing power, they should note that consumers appear to be as cost conscious as ever. Shoppers were reluctant to pay higher prices and sales volumes last month stalled.

The fact that the amount consumers spent continues to grow at its fastest rate since mid-1998 suggests that there is plenty of life yet in the customer. Retailers should nevertheless beware of trying their patience with price rises.

Failed ales

So farewell David Thompson, the bouffant-haired, Winchester-educated boss of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries.

Thompson failed to come up with a management buyout proposal in time for yesterday's bid deadline. Although there have been innumerable twists and turns in the nine-month tussle for control of the company, it does look as if this is the finale.

This farcical, drawn-out auction has been a sad end to Thompson's 24-year career at Wolves. Both bidders have complained vigorously about Wolves' reluctance to provide information for their due diligence, and Thompson has been blamed for this reticence.

He has been understandably reluctant to let go of the company which his family established. But his refusal to budge from a vision of real-ale pubs in effect signed the company's death warrant.

Few in the industry believe that regional ales can be anything more than niche products with a local following. The idea of a regional brewer with a national pub estate simply does not add up. Wolves' failure to install a top-name lager in its pubs is typical: instead of Carling or Stella, its drinkers have to make do with Harp. Time, gentlemen from Wolverhampton, please.

webTitle: Pru hits back with record sales

fields.headline: Pru hits back with record sales
fields.trailText: Jonathan Bloomer, the chief executive of Prudential, yesterday hit back at critics of his stalled takeover of American General of the United States by announcing sales of £5bn - the highest yet - in the first three months of this year.
fields.body:
Jonathan Bloomer, the chief executive of Prudential, yesterday hit back at critics of his stalled takeover of American General of the United States by announcing sales of £5bn - the highest yet - in the first three months of this year.

Mr Bloomer, who was on holiday when AIG intervened in the Pru's record-breaking deal with American General, said the company's shareholders were continuing to support him, even though City sources believe his strategy for expansion is in tatters.

"Shareholders had got comfortable with our strategy [with American General] but are also comfortable with these new business figures," Mr Bloomer said.

Pru's shares plunged last month when the deal with Amercian General was announced because investors were concerned it was overpaying. The new sales figures helped the shares rise 27p to £7.99 yesterday.

Mr Bloomer said he main tained a daily dialogue with American General despite the fact that the Texas-based company is also talking to AIG. Pru stands to receive £400m if American General breaks its agreement to combine with the Pru, and Mr Bloomer insisted that even if that happened he would not rush into an alternative deal.

Yesterday's sales figures showed that 40% of the Pru's business is generated in Asia, 20% in the US and the remainder in Britain - where it is in the process of getting rid of its direct sales force which is associated with its "man from the Pru" image.

In Britain, the Pru's sales of insurance were up 10% overall, although in life insurance sales were 16% lower than during the same period last year, with sales of its Prudence bond down 21%.

Its Scottish Amicable insurance operation is to withdraw from the sale of controversial endowment mortgages.

In the US, where the Pru owns Jackson Life, sales were down by some 20%, which the company said was the result of the difficult stock market conditions. The Pru, however, highlighted a 35% rise in sales of annuities in the US.

The record combined sales of insurance and investment products totalling £5bn represented a 29% rise on last year, when the Pru expanded its business in Asia through the acquisition of Orico Life.

webTitle: The inside view: Buy in to nervousness

fields.headline: Buy in to nervousness - but not yet
fields.standfirst: While waiting for things to settle down, spend some time hunting for the next technological marvel
fields.trailText: While waiting for things to settle down, spend some time hunting for the next technological marvel.
fields.body:
Like fireflies, the spirits of investors have flared and died within a day of each American interest rate cut. Until this week, that is. Maybe, just maybe, the US Federal Reserve has managed to get ahead of the game.

The Fed, custodian of America's economic health, is not afraid to act. Where other central bankers move rates only when rhetoric won't suffice, Alan Greenspan and his colleagues often use the two in tandem, or indeed let the words follow as reinforcement to action. Above all, they recognise the value of surprise and, consequently, are notoriously unpredictable.

This week's 0.5-point cut in US interest rates to 4.5% is further proof, if it were needed, that the Fed is a master of its craft; the Bayern Munich of central banks. Mid-morning, mid-week, midway between scheduled policy-setting meetings, no one predicted the "emergency" cut. Its scale, moreover, lent weight to the accompanying gloomy analysis of risks within the economy. No messin'.

The contextual accompaniment contained only one surprise - the first reference to slower growth overseas as a drag on US economic activity. But the language was blunt, and the kiss-off was chilly: "The risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future."

While equity investors fear economic weakness, they fear central banking ostriches even more. Plugging the latest US data into a forecasting model suggests that the US economy is now flat-lining. The Fed cannot know whether the economy will begin to shrink, continue to flatline, or recover. But at least it has shown that it is attuned to the risks of contraction.

Commentators have spouted two streams of "wisdom" about this latest rate cut. First, that the Fed was moved by the slew of profit warnings and accompanying job cuts from America's leading companies, particularly in the technology sector.

Secondly, that there is a risk that the Fed knows something we mortals do not, and that consequently share prices have yet to hit bottom.

I do not subscribe to either view. Although there has indeed been a stack of bad news from corporate America, the Fed is likely to see through the desire of many companies to lower investor expectations at a time when profit downgrades are plentiful. There will rarely be a more forgiving climate in which to slip out bad news.

Jobs will be cut, but many companies are using the smokescreen of the weak economy to implement efficiency programmes that will leave them well placed to exploit the next upturn profitably.

Evidence also shows that redundant US workers continue to find it easy to find re-employment. Sure, this may not last, but one should not underestimate the celebrated "flexibility" of the US labour market.

The Fed may of course know something that we do not. This "something" would most likely lurk somewhere in the financial system. However, America's leading commercial and investment banks have just released first quarter earnings reports - with their own profit warnings and job cuts - and this would have been the time for any skeletons to prise open the cupboard door.

Most likely Alan Greenspan is just plain worried. Which is what he is paid to be. It is unlikely that personally he believes share prices have fallen far enough, but then he has been a very public sceptic about equity valuations for more than four years - thereby missing the mother of all bull markets as well as the current bear snap.

The recovery in US equities from their recent low is four weeks and 14% old. Indeed the Dow Jones industrial average need climb only another 3% to post a high for the year and a further 7% to make a new all time high.

A 10% rise in share prices would be a substantial gain by historical standards, but in the crazy world of investment that has prevailed over the past couple of years it is a move that could happen in the blink of an eye.

The advice in this column over recent weeks has been to buy equities, provided you can draw upon the necessary personal reserves of bravery. Now, though, it is time to hold fire for a very short while. Let the current euphoria subside and then buy into renewed bouts of nervousness. Remember, markets rarely go up in a straight line.

While waiting for a better opportunity to renew buying, one might spend some time in another pursuit - second-guessing the next wave of technology advances.

This week I was privileged to see a glasses-free, 3D television in action. Here was a technological advance whose applications I could understand and foresee. My techie colleagues tell me we should also look out for surging interest in alternative energy technologies, peer- to-peer computing and distributed computing.

I doubt whether these coming technological waves will ever attract the wide-eyed credulity among the investment community that characterised last year's mania. They may nevertheless throw up very profitable investment propositions.

I confess I know little or nothing about these developments yet, but we will only know if homework will pay off after the event.

Another reason, then, to switch off one's screen and not get mesmerised by the market.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

The contextual accompaniment contained only one surprise - the first reference to slower growth overseas as a drag on US economic activity. But the language was blunt, and the kiss-off was chilly: "The risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future." While equity investors fear economic weakness, they fear central banking ostriches even more. Plugging the latest US data into a forecasting model suggests that the US economy is now flat-lining. The Fed cannot know whether the economy will begin to shrink, continue to flatline, or recover. But at least it has shown that it is attuned to the risks of contraction. Commentators have spouted two streams of "wisdom" about this latest rate cut. First, that the Fed was moved by the slew of profit warnings and accompanying job cuts from America's leading companies, particularly in the technology sector. Secondly, that there is a risk that the Fed knows something we mortals do not, and that consequently share prices have yet to hit bottom. I do not subscribe to either view. Although there has indeed been a stack of bad news from corporate America, the Fed is likely to see through the desire of many companies to lower investor expectations at a time when profit downgrades are plentiful. There will rarely be a more forgiving climate in which to slip out bad news. Jobs will be cut, but many companies are using the smokescreen of the weak economy to implement efficiency programmes that will leave them well placed to exploit the next upturn profitably. Evidence also shows that redundant US workers continue to find it easy to find re-employment. Sure, this may not last, but one should not underestimate the celebrated "flexibility" of the US labour market. The Fed may of course know something that we do not. This "something" would most likely lurk somewhere in the financial system. However, America's leading commercial and investment banks have just released first quarter earnings reports - with their own profit warnings and job cuts - and this would have been the time for any skeletons to prise open the cupboard door. Most likely Alan Greenspan is just plain worried. Which is what he is paid to be. It is unlikely that personally he believes share prices have fallen far enough, but then he has been a very public sceptic about equity valuations for more than four years - thereby missing the mother of all bull markets as well as the current bear snap. The recovery in US equities from their recent low is four weeks and 14% old. Indeed the Dow Jones industrial average need climb only another 3% to post a high for the year and a further 7% to make a new all time high. A 10% rise in share prices would be a substantial gain by historical standards, but in the crazy world of investment that has prevailed over the past couple of years it is a move that could happen in the blink of an eye. The advice in this column over recent weeks has been to buy equities, provided you can draw upon the necessary personal reserves of bravery. Now, though, it is time to hold fire for a very short while. Let the current euphoria subside and then buy into renewed bouts of nervousness. Remember, markets rarely go up in a straight line. While waiting for a better opportunity to renew buying, one might spend some time in another pursuit - second-guessing the next wave of technology advances. This week I was privileged to see a glasses-free, 3D television in action. Here was a technological advance whose applications I could understand and foresee. My techie colleagues tell me we should also look out for surging interest in alternative energy technologies, peer- to-peer computing and distributed computing. I doubt whether these coming technological waves will ever attract the wide-eyed credulity among the investment community that characterised last year's mania. They may nevertheless throw up very profitable investment propositions. I confess I know little or nothing about these developments yet, but we will only know if homework will pay off after the event. Another reason, then, to switch off one's screen and not get mesmerised by the market.  Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

fields.headline: Turnstile goes into reverse
fields.trailText: Manchester United, the team that attracts huge crowds of supporters when it is on the field, yesterday had to stand back and watch investors fleeing for the exits.
fields.body:
Manchester United, the team that attracts huge crowds of supporters when it is on the field, yesterday had to stand back and watch investors fleeing for the exits.

The English domestic champions were kicked out of the European competition by Germany's Bayern Munich this week and suffered defeat on the stock exchange yesterday as the company's shares slid to a three-season low. The shares dropped to 164p - also pushed down by captain Roy Keane's comments that United were no longer good enough - before recovering later in the day to close at 173p, down 2p.

Elsewhere, telecoms group Vodafone, a Manchester United sponsor which yesterday denied it was in discussions about sponsoring English Premier League football - became a victim of institutional profit taking. The company has buoyed the FTSE 100 and seen its shares rise by 9% over the past couple of days, but yesterday investors wanted to bank some of the gains.

The shares fell 3% in early trading before closing down 8p at 221p. Investors had piled out on speculation that a big line of stock was being placed.

The FTSE 100 closed 8.2 points up at 5,879.8 as investors wondered which way the market would go after this week's US rate cut and mixed earnings reports from big European and US companies.

Mobile phone maker Nokia reported a rise in first quarter pretax profit to €1.41bn. The figures were above market expectations, but the company cut its sales and profit outlook for 2001 owing to tougher market conditions, particularly the US slowdown.

A gloomy report from Ericsson kept the lid on investor appetite. The company reported earnings in line with market expectations but sales down.

British Telecom bucked the negative trend and its shares surged 13p to 594p on reports that it is poised to sell its 50% stake in Concert to AT&T, which partners BT in international corporate telecoms ventures.

Concert, BT and AT&T's alliance formed in 1998 to manage the companies' large multinational clients, has not been doing as well as expected and a possible resolution of the problem was obviously welcomed by investors. The move could help BT to reduce its £30bn debt burden.

Marconi, the telecoms equipment maker, saw its shares climb 15p to 358.5p. The bounce helped the group to recover some of the losses it suffered in the previous session, but, according to analysts, it represented little more than a technically driven rebound.

Several media and technology shares retreated, including ARM Holdings, down 33p to 362p, and EMI Group, down 20p to 485p. Dimension Data dropped 7p to 292p, despite HSBC raising its rating of the company to "buy".

IT consultancy CMG experienced some respite and saw its shares recover slightly, up 3p to 363p. The Anglo-Dutch group's stock edged up on the back of a broker's note. Effectenbank Stroeve upgraded CMG to "outperformer" from "match" and said it expected a clear recovery in the second half of 2001.

The banking sector had a tough day, with Lloyds TSB down 4p to 706p, Barclays down 10p to £22.90 and Halifax down 13.5p to 732p.

Good news from Prudential provided a slight uplift. The shares rose 27p to 799p as investors jumped in after the company announced a 29% rise in first-quarter sales. Its online bank Egg - 80% owned by Prudential - was also looking bullish and announced a smaller pretax loss for the quarter and a rise in customers. Its shares rose 2.5p to 150p.

Drugs and mining stocks provided some support to the FTSE. Healthcare group Nycomed Amersham rose 4p to 477p.

Small cap Knowledge Management Software jumped 5.5p to 25.5p, up from 17p this month as buyers returned to the intelligent-software producer's depressed stock.

fields.headline: Independent rallies
fields.trailText: Independent Insurance, a former stock market darling that has recently suffered a share price collapse, yesterday saw its stock rise 6p to 137.5p.
fields.body:
Independent Insurance, a former stock market darling that has recently suffered a share price collapse, yesterday saw its stock rise 6p to 137.5p.

Shares in the firm have dropped from above £3.50 in two months but rose yesterday as investors welcomed the news that founder Michael Bright had decided to fall on his sword - prompting speculation that the firm could attract a takeover bid.

The departure of Mr Bright - who resigned with immediate effect and will take up the deputy chairman's post - has been seen by analysts as essentially putting the company up for sale.

It has been rumoured that American insurance company Chubb could be interested in the bsuiness and may be looking to build a strategic stake.

The firm has suffered a decline in its fortunes this year. It issued a profits warning in February and reported a 42% fall in its profits to £40m in March.

webTitle: Green engineers up there with Rolls-Royce and Marconi

fields.headline: Green engineers up there with Rolls-Royce and Marconi
fields.standfirst: Small firms set standards
fields.trailText: Small firms set standards
fields.body:
Leeds Environmental Design Associates is one of 15 firms to win a Queen's Award for Enterprise in the new sustainable development category, writes Simon Bowers.

Matthew Hill, part of the three-man architectural and engineering firm which provides environmentally sensitive design solutions, said he was delighted the awards were going to smaller businesses with innovative ideas.

"We were really surprised when we won," he said. "I'm used to seeing the likes of Rolls-Royce and Marconi getting a Queen's Award, not firms like ours.

"We are still a very young company so we are grateful for the recognition this will bring - it is always frustrating to lose a job to another company just because you're unknown, when you know that you could do it better."

LEDA caught the eye of the the awards panel for its solar-heated swimming pool at a private house in Bradford. Mr Hill said the chlorine-free pool is heated by a 6 sq metre area of solar panels on the roof.

"The panels are so well insulated and efficient that they can heat the pool for most of the year - and even on a cold day in Bradford."

The four-year-old company, which Mr Hill said has a turnover of £150,000 and makes a profit, has developed a number of other environmentally aware solutions, including efficient heating and lighting systems, low energy consumption projects and water treatment solutions.

Under LEDA's water treatment scheme, waste bath and sink water pass into a pond planted with a reed bed. By the time the water overflows, it has been sufficiently treated to return to the water table.

The awards panel said: "The company stands out from its competitors as a micro-enterprise that has achieved excellent results, evidenced by the high calibre of their projects. In addition, LEDA's work has been used to exemplify best practice within the water conservation and recycling industry."

James Haigh, another member of LEDA, said "We're delighted that preserving the planet has achieved mainstream recognition."

Mr Hill said the company had no plans to expand. "We are quite happy being a small firm, perhaps taking on around half a dozen staff in a few years."

Asked if he was happy for LEDA to be associated with the monarch, Mr Hill said: "I'd rather not say - though I can't imagine she spent much time sifting through the entries herself."

fields.headline: Business spurns the royal connection
fields.standfirst: Minister forced to defend 'gimmicky and outmoded' scheme
fields.trailText: Minister forced to defend 'gimmicky and outmoded' scheme
fields.body:
The government has been forced to defend its 35-year-old Queen's Awards for Enterprise scheme following accusations that it is outmoded and no longer pertinent to the promotion of Britain's industries.

The trade minister, Richard Caborn, insisted the award winners, announced today, were "some of the crème de la crème of Britain's businesses". They include Celador, maker of TV hit show, Who Wants to Be a Millionaire, Land Rover (now owned by Ford) and Bettys & Taylors, maker of Yorkshire Tea.

Mr Caborn's stout defence ran in to resistance from Lord Haskins, head of the government's better regulation unit, who said the awards were "gimmicky" and cast serious doubt on some of the royal connotations.

Mr Caborn insisted: "With their enterprising spirit and dynamism, they exemplify the best of UK innovation and creativity. They are the winners in our 'Oscars for Enterprise'."

The awards were established under Harold Wilson as part of his drive to foster the "white heat of the technological revolution". Critics point out that most of Britain's largest firms and many smaller hi-tech and design companies have been increasingly reluctant to be associated with the awards and with the British monarchy in general.

The drop in the number of applications over recent years prompted the DTI to give the awards scheme an overhaul last year, introducing an environmental category, in addition to the innovation and international trade awards, and revamping the logo.

This year's figures show the awards have again failed to draw in the numbers hoped for. "This is something that does concern me," Mr Caborn said. "I will be taking up this issue to see if we can encourage more people to get involved." According to the DTI, the Queen's Awards remain the highest honour government can confer on business.

Mr Caborn said delays in the development of a new logo, above, and publicity setbacks contributed to disappointing figures this year. With only four of the winners employing more than 5,000 workers, many of the 133 companies due to receive awards at Buckingham palace next spring operate on a cottage industry scale - at least 10 of them employ fewer than 10 staff. Businesses that are in part funded by local authorities and universities are also among the winners.

Mr Caborn said the increasing number of smaller businesses winning awards reflected the government's efforts to refocus on "trade development rather than trade promotion". Asked if association with the monarchy was causing many larger companies to give the awards a wide berth, Mr Caborn said: "I don't think so. If it helps sell their products, it helps sell their products."

David Moore, secretary of the Queen's Awards, added: "There is a prestige that is associated with the awards, particularly in markets like the US and the Middle East. If you've got an emblem with a crown on it on your letterhead it can be a very useful marketing tool."

Lord Haskins, government adviser and chairman of Northern Foods, said some of his firm's products benefited from royal warrants but active promotion of British industry by the royal family was fraught with difficulty. "I don't think there is anything wrong with it if it is done well. Princess Anne can do it, for example, but I'm not so sure about some of her relations."

He said the Queen's awards were gimmicky and of limited value as a marketing tool.

"Like all these gimmicky things, they run for a bit and then they have to try something new. The Queen's Awards have been running for ages and really need to try something else."

This month a senior Foreign Office source told the Guardian that Prince Andrew would have to be closely watched to ensure he did not let his personal interests interfere with his official duties as the new ambassador for the British export industry.

Sources said he would be expected to be "much closer to the Duke of Kent model than the Sophie model" in keeping his opinions to himself .

webTitle: Struggling mobile companies gamble on hi-tech handsets

fields.headline: Struggling mobile companies gamble on hi-tech handsets
fields.standfirst: Ericsson cuts 12,000 jobs amid industry fears that buyers will reject new models
fields.trailText: Ericsson cuts 12,000 jobs amid industry fears that buyers will reject new models.
fields.byline: Mark Milner, Stuart Millar  and Stuart McWilliam
fields.body:
Fresh evidence of the savage downturn which has hit the world's mobile phone industry emerged yesterday amid growing signs that a new generation of online handsets may not stem the crisis.

With lower than expected demand wiping billions off share values and thousands of jobs being axed across the industry, Ericsson, the world's third largest mobile phone manufacturer, announced it was planning to cut a further 12,000 jobs worldwide.

Though the Swedish company - which has already revealed it is to halt production at two plants in Britain - has yet to say where the latest jobs will go, there is concern that there could be redundancies among other UK staff at sites in London, Basingstoke, Guildford and near Brighton.

Ericsson said that overall it had lost £350m in the first three months of the year. The mobile phone business, which lost £1.14bn last year, crashed into the red to the tune of more than £400m in the first quarter of 2001. To add to the gloom, the company said there were "no signs of a short-term turnaround".

The news comes on the back of a rising tide of gloom in the industry after Motorola, the world number two, announced last month that 7,000 jobs were being cut worldwide. Nokia, the industry leader, is one of the few optimistic voices. Last year it took 32% of the mobile phone market and is looking to buck the worldwide trend.

A little over six months have passed since everyone in the mobileindustry was just as optimistic: by October last year, more than half the population of Britain owned a mobile, 4m new handsets had flown out of shops in three months and mobile phone companies were regarded as gold dust by investors.

But with the collapse in the handset market, manufacturers and networks are left pinning all their hopes on the success of the next generation of mobile devices. Offering continuous internet access, email and video conferencing, the third generation - known as 3G - networks are due to come on stream in the Isle of Man next month on a trial basis, before appearing across the UK from the end of next year.

Last spring, at the height of the mobile boom, five networks paid £22bn to the Treasury to secure the British licences for 3G networks. But as doubts grow over whether such a massive investment can ever be recouped, evidence is emerging that consumers are yet to be convinced of the need for more advanced mobile communications.

Based on the latest findings of a long-term study on the relationship between consumers and technology, the leading British expert on public attitudes to new technology has warned mobile networks that they face an uphill battle to make 3G a success.

In the latest issue of Mobile News magazine, Michael Svennevig, research director at Leeds university's centre for future communications, accused the networks of allowing themselves to get carried away with the technological possibilities of 3G before establishing whether consumers would be interested in the services on offer.

He said: "The benefits of mobiles are superficially obvious. They enable communication with anyone that is virtually independent of time and location. The benefits of the new technologies are less apparent to the consumer.

"It seems to me that technology has dominated the 3G argument rather than attention having been paid to the users of that technology."

Analysts fear that the 3G devices will be prohibitively expensive as the companies struggle to claw back some of the billions they forked out to purchase the licences.

The networks are so concerned that they will be crippled by the debt that approaches have been made to the government to renegotiate the terms of the licences. Senior politicians are understood to regard this as unlikely.

The latest findings of Leeds' futura.com research project, which has been surveying the same large sample of British adults since 1996, appear to confirm the industry's worst fears: that users are content with existing services and are therefore unlikely to buy new handsets just to use the array of new 3G services.

The study has yet to cover 3G directly, but respondents were asked about their interest in Wap (wireless application protocol) phones, the much-hyped precursor to 3G which have been a sales disaster.

More than 55% of the 1,000-strong panel already had conventional mobile phones, with a further 10% saying they would like to get one. But only 4% had purchased a Wap phone. None of the others said they definitely planned to get one this year, while 83% - an exceptionally high proportion for a survey of this kind - said they were not interested in ever getting a Wap phone.

The panel cannot be dismissed as Luddites. Only 26% said they would not be interested in buying a new technology which would save time and effort, while 22% said they had no interest in technology and 27% said new technology had very little effect on their lives.

"The results suggest that standard digital mobiles have soaked up a great deal of the market out there and a lot of people are going to be quite happy with what they currently have," Mr Svennevig said. "They can talk and send text messages, which is all they want to do and all they are likely to want to do."

Last night, the main British mobile networks defended their investment in 3G.

A spokeswoman for Vodafone, which paid almost £6bn for its licence and which has complained to ministers about the costs involved, said: "As a business we have to realise the opportunities that these technologies will bring and put in the foundations to support the technology.

"Wap was positioned wrongly by certain parties, raising expectations which were not met. That is something we cannot allow to happen again."

A spokesman for BT, which paid £4bn for its licence and which has been hit by a massive debt crisis as a result, said: "These findings contrast sharply with our own research. We have done a lot of work taking samples from both business customers and average users and the results have been very positive."

How they rank

1 Nokia

Market share 32%

Handset sales 128m last year

No lay-offs announced

2 Motorola

Market share around 15%

Handset sales 60m

Seeking 7,000 job losses worldwide. No details yet of where jobs will be lost

3 Ericsson

Market share 10%

Handset sales 41.5m

Already announced 3,300 jobs to go, seeking another 12,000 cuts group-wide

4 Siemens

Market share 6.5%

Handset sales 27m

Announced closure of two German mobile handset lines earlier this month affecting around 2,000 jobs

10 Philips

Market share 3%

Handset sales around 12m

Job losses at mobile phone plants likely as group overall seeks to shed 7,000 jobs

But as doubts grow over whether such a massive investment can ever be recouped, evidence is emerging that consumers are yet to be convinced of the need for more advanced mobile communications. Based on the latest findings of a long-term study on the relationship between consumers and technology, the leading British expert on public attitudes to new technology has warned mobile networks that they face an uphill battle to make 3G a success. In the latest issue of Mobile News magazine, Michael Svennevig, research director at Leeds university's centre for future communications, accused the networks of allowing themselves to get carried away with the technological possibilities of 3G before establishing whether consumers would be interested in the services on offer. He said: "The benefits of mobiles are superficially obvious. They enable communication with anyone that is virtually independent of time and location. The benefits of the new technologies are less apparent to the consumer. "It seems to me that technology has dominated the 3G argument rather than attention having been paid to the users of that technology." Analysts fear that the 3G devices will be prohibitively expensive as the companies struggle to claw back some of the billions they forked out to purchase the licences. The networks are so concerned that they will be crippled by the debt that approaches have been made to the government to renegotiate the terms of the licences. Senior politicians are understood to regard this as unlikely. The latest findings of Leeds' futura.com research project, which has been surveying the same large sample of British adults since 1996, appear to confirm the industry's worst fears: that users are content with existing services and are therefore unlikely to buy new handsets just to use the array of new 3G services. The study has yet to cover 3G directly, but respondents were asked about their interest in Wap (wireless application protocol) phones, the much-hyped precursor to 3G which have been a sales disaster. More than 55% of the 1,000-strong panel already had conventional mobile phones, with a further 10% saying they would like to get one. But only 4% had purchased a Wap phone. None of the others said they definitely planned to get one this year, while 83% - an exceptionally high proportion for a survey of this kind - said they were not interested in ever getting a Wap phone. The panel cannot be dismissed as Luddites. Only 26% said they would not be interested in buying a new technology which would save time and effort, while 22% said they had no interest in technology and 27% said new technology had very little effect on their lives. "The results suggest that standard digital mobiles have soaked up a great deal of the market out there and a lot of people are going to be quite happy with what they currently have," Mr Svennevig said. "They can talk and send text messages, which is all they want to do and all they are likely to want to do." Last night, the main British mobile networks defended their investment in 3G. A spokeswoman for Vodafone, which paid almost £6bn for its licence and which has complained to ministers about the costs involved, said: "As a business we have to realise the opportunities that these technologies will bring and put in the foundations to support the technology. "Wap was positioned wrongly by certain parties, raising expectations which were not met. That is something we cannot allow to happen again." A spokesman for BT, which paid £4bn for its licence and which has been hit by a massive debt crisis as a result, said: "These findings contrast sharply with our own research. We have done a lot of work taking samples from both business customers and average users and the results have been very positive." webTitle: Terrible truth about ship of slaves

fields.headline: The terrible truth about the ship of slaves
fields.trailText: The Etireno rocks gently against the quay; the smallest ship in a small west African port. It chugs around the Gulf of Guinea, carrying cassava and cars, boxes of soap and barrels of hooch, and sometimes children.
fields.body:
The Etireno rocks gently against the quay; the smallest ship in a small west African port. It chugs around the Gulf of Guinea, carrying cassava and cars, boxes of soap and barrels of hooch, and sometimes children.

About this time last week, the government of Benin reported the Nigerian-registered ship missing at sea with 250 child slaves on board. The children looked ill, according to port authorities in Douala, Cameroon where the ship put in for refuelling. The Etireno was a notorious slave ship, the UN children's fund (Unicef) confirmed.

Its captain, a desperate man with a criminal past, might throw the children overboard. And Benin, everyone noted, was where the African slave trade began. At midnight on Tuesday, the 40-metre ship was sighted off Cotonou, Benin's capital, and a crowd of ministers, diplomats and UN officials hastily summoned.

An hour later, the diplomats were off home to bed. There were no chains or shackles aboard the Etireno and few children, all of them apparently accompanied by their parents. Someone had made a big mistake, said Lawrence Onome, the ship's Nigerian captain. The Etireno had been turned back from the Gabonese capital of Libreville because its 114 adult passengers had no papers to enter the region's richest country. The ship was carrying illegal migrants, not unaccompanied children, he said.

Etireno, coincidentally, means "end of story".

But it was not quite finished. Unicef took 31 children off the ship to be interviewed. Five days later, they are still in transit centres for distressed children. The adults first thought to be their parents had disappeared and just one child has been claimed. It seems the Etireno was carrying child slaves after all.

"These were unaccompanied children," Esther Guluma, an Israeli who is Unicef's representative in Benin, said yesterday. "Sorry - they are very highly suspected unaccompanied children," she added, conscious of having jumped the gun once already this week.

The truth about the Etireno may be less dramatic than first suggested, but far more typical of west and central Africa's exploding trade in children - and far more insidious for that.

Benin's child protection police have been called in to confirm that the children were being trafficked from their village homes to slavery in oil-rich Gabon. Until they do, Terre des Hommes, a Swiss organisation caring for the 24 youngest, is guarding them jealously. But the evidence is already persuasive.

The children at Terre des Hommes are aged between four and 14. They include two four-year old boys from Mali, six children from Togo and 16 from Benin, according to Ms Guluma. These countries are the three biggest providers of the 200,000 children that Unicef estimates are trafficked across the region's borders each year. Gabon and Ivory Coast are the biggest receivers.

Emilie Kpadanou, a child psychologist, interviewed the children. "The older children said they were going to work. The little ones didn't know where they were going," she said. "They all want to go home to their mothers."

It is not unusual for ships to traffic children across the Gulf of Guinea. Over the past 10 years, as a result of poverty and as an abuse of Africa's extended family tradition, whereby poor children are placed with wealthier family friends, child slavery has become endemic. It is rare for a slave ship to be turned away.

Morris Landlord, 36, the Etireno's second-in-command, was the only man on board the ship yesterday: Mr Onome and seven of the 12 Nigerian crew members were being interviewed by police. The 40-metre ship's cargo, mainly a palm-gin called ogogoro, was still on board; the small galley smelled faintly of the 142 bodies that crowded it for more than two weeks. Mr Landlord said there had been no unaccompanied children on board. Otherwise, his version of what happened in Libreville is close to Ms Kpadanou's.

On April 4, two days after the ship docked, the passengers disembarked. But when Gabonese police saw most had no papers, they very aggressively ordered everyone back, he said.

Ms Kpadanou said policemen threw some children off the quay into the water, forcing adult passengers to dive in after them. The Etireno was put to sea without refuelling or taking on water, and with a police gunboat on either side, Mr Landlord said. He says he does not know why the police reacted so violently.

Ms Kpadanou thinks it was because the ship was trying to unload too many children, risking a scandal. "Four or five, they can get away with," she said. More than 40, including 10 youths, was too many.

On April 8, the ship docked at Douala, Cameroon, for refuelling. During its five-day voyage from there to Cotonou - the passengers sharing a tin of sardines and a loaf of bread a day among six - the Beninois rumour mill inflated the number of children. As they neared Cotonou, the crew listened to the BBC World Service in horror, said Mr Landlord.

He says the Etireno will soon be back in business - "there's no better ship for ferrying people in Africa". At 7am, he was tucking into the ogogoro. "It's good for fever and nerves," he said. He was expecting the police any minute.

Cotonou is the busiest port in Benin and Togo. A well-maintained highway, courtesy of the World Bank, runs northwards, towards impoverished Mali and Burkina Faso. The unusual combination of a good infrastructure linking desperately poor rural areas is the dynamic that makes Benin a trafficker's paradise.

Isaac, 10, was brought to Terre des Hommes a week ago, after being stopped at the Ghanaian border. A friend of his father said he could get Isaac a job making cooking pots in Ivory Coast. So Isaac left his village in Benin's southern Za-Kpota region at night in a car packed with five other children, including his elder sister, and seven adults.

One of his six brothers and most of his friends had already left for Ivory Coast and he was happy to go too. "It was normal," said Isaac, his head barely reaching above the back of his chair. "In Ivory Coast you can learn a trade; if I'd stayed I'd have done nothing."

Isaac crossed into Togo without a hitch and was met at the Ghanaian border by a woman who was to take him on to Ivory Coast, before they were stopped by police. "They were fierce and asked a lot of questions I couldn't understand," said Isaac, scratching at the eczema on his arms. Isaac is not afraid his father will be angry to see him when he goes home; but he still wants to learn to make pots.

According to Alfonso Gonzalez-Jaggli, Terre des Homme's Togo and Benin delegate, Isaac's story is typical, down to his insistence that his parents were paid nothing. "It's usually too hard for them to think their fathers could put a price on them," he said.

Anti-slavery International estimates children are bought in villages for as little as £10. Increasing sums then change hands as they are passed along a chain of intermediaries, transporters and border smugglers - such as the woman Isaac described. The children are finally sold, typically to cocoa plantation owners in Ivory Coast or as domestics in Gabon, for up to £300 a head.

The Pied Piper who leads the children away with their parents' blessing - Isaac's father's friend - is the key to this modern slavery. Often one of the child's own relatives, he is commissioned to take full advantage of the extended family, and of the poor man's assumption that anywhere is better than here.

"Once people were taken from here in chains. The tragedy now is that they go willingly looking for a better future - they all learn the truth eventually," said Mr Gonzalez-Jaggli, whose office is decorated with photographs documenting malnourished children, scarred by flogging.

"Slavery is the scourge of west and central Africa, and it could spread," said Rima Sala, Unicef regional director in the Ivory Coast capital, Abidjan.

"For Africa, with its history, it is the final humiliation."

webTitle: French arms scandal nets another top politician

fields.headline: French arms scandal nets another top politician
fields.trailText: France's "Angolagate" arms and corruption scandal collected another high-ranking official yesterday when investigators opened two separate inquiries into Charles Pasqua, a former interior minister and a possible candidate in next year's presidential election.
fields.body:
France's "Angolagate" arms and corruption scandal collected another high-ranking official yesterday when investigators opened two separate inquiries into Charles Pasqua, a former interior minister and a possible candidate in next year's presidential election.

Judges investigating the affair in which the eldest son of the late President François Mitterrand was jailed on suspicion of arms-trafficking and money-laundering last year believe Mr Pasqua and his Rally for France (RPF) may have received kickbacks from the multimillion-pound deals.

Mr Pasqua, a leading figures in President Jacques Chirac's Rally for the Republic (RPR) movement before be created the anti-European RPF, is one of France's most senior and influential politicians.

He has heatedly denied the judges' allegations that the party and its 1999 European election campaign were funded illegally.

"The accounts of the RPF are completely clean, as are those of its campaign for the 1999 European elections," he said.

"This is an attempt to destabilise democracy. These investigations and accusations are trumped-up rubbish," he said.

"I make a nice target, but I await the evidence."

The judges, Philippe Courroye and Isabelle Prevost-Deprez, are investigating the illicit sale of Russian arms worth £350m to the Angolan government in the 1990s by Brenco International.

The company was owned by the imprisoned businessman Pierre Falcone and advised by Jean-Christophe Mitterrand.

Mr Mitterrand, who built up a big network of high-level African contacts serving for six years as his father's special adviser on African affairs, was released on £500,000 bail in January.

But he remains under investigation for influence peddling, complicity in arms trafficking and abuse of funds in relation to the arms sales.

The investigating judges suspect that the illicit arms deals may have been part of high-level Franco-Angolan accords negotiated by Mr Pasqua, then France's interior minister, and the Angolan president, Edouardo dos Santos.

They also suspect that some of Mr Falcone's money may have found its way into the coffers of the RPF.

As interior minister for two terms under President Mitterrand in the 1990s, Mr Pasqua oversaw arms export licences and he was ultimately in charge of the state arms export company, for which Mr Falcone acted as a consultant and whose former director, Bernard Poussier, is now under arrest.

The judges already know that Brenco paid £1.3m into a numbered Swiss bank account in Mr Mitterrand's name.

They have also found that the company paid £300,000 to Mr Pasqua's chief Africa aide, Jean-Charles Marchiani, and £150,000 to France Africa Orient, an organisation jointly headed by the former interior minister and his diplomatic adviser, Bernard Guillet, who is also under arrest.

Questioned by the judges about the RPF's financing, Philippe de Villiers, a former deputy leader of the party who has broken off all contact with Mr Pasqua, said earlier this year: "The Mitterrand-Pasqua affair is very major, an affair of state with intercontinental ramifications and barely imaginable future developments".

Part of the judges' investigations will focus on a controversial "loan" of £750,000 to the RPF by Marthe Mondoloni, the boss of the betting industry in Gabon.

Ms Mondoloni's father, Michel Tomi, a close friend of Mr Pasqua who runs a string of casinos throughout west Africa, is under investigation in Monaco on suspicion of money-laundering.

The news of the inquiries into the affairs of Mr Pasqua, a portly, plain-speaking Corsican, came just days after one of Mr Guillet's assistants, Sabine de la Laurencie, told the newspaper Le Figaro that she made several visits to Geneva and Luxembourg in the 1990s to collect mysterious locked briefcases stuffed with cash for her boss, who at the time was Mr Pasqua's adviser at the interior ministry.

Ms De la Laurencie said this arrangement continued until very recently.

Among the Pasqua donors she allegedly met on her trips abroad was Nasir Abid, an Iraqi billionaire who is wanted under an international arrest warrant for his alleged involvement in another major French corruption case, the Elf scandal

Mr Pasqua's name has also been linked to that affair.

"Mr Guillet is one of the kingpins of the RPF's foreign financing," Ms De la Laurencie said.

"It is clear that Mr Pasqua is aware of that and of this method of party funding."

fields.headline: Turks mourn prison 'martyr'
fields.standfirst: Reforms aim at ending jail crisis as 14th funeral foments sympathy for hunger strike
fields.trailText: Reforms aim at ending jail crisis as 14th funeral foments sympathy for hunger strike
fields.body:
With red banners and revolutionary slogans, Ender Can Yildiz was buried in Istanbul yesterday - the 14th victim of a hunger strike against prison conditions which shows no sign of coming to an end.

The government has announced legal reforms to ease the regime of isolation which has been imposed on hundreds of prisoners for months. But it insists that there will be no negotiations with the extreme leftwing groups behind the hunger strike.

"We will not allow the prisons to become the headquarters of terrorism again," the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said on Thursday. "The state will not give in to pressure from people who are forcing their friends to die."

Yildiz died in an Ankara hospital on Wednesday. Doctors say dozens of other prisoners are in a critical condition, and the death toll is likely to rise at any time.

Yildiz's mother, Hanife, led the funeral procession yesterday. On a red ribbon wrapped around her head the words "Ender Can is immortal" were carefully written in black.

Leaning on a stick, but speaking clearly, she said: "My son didn't lose this fight. He won and I'm proud of him. We will keep fighting until victory".

Hundreds of mourners chanting slogans and pumping their fists in the air were closely shadowed by an even larger number of heavily armed paramilitaries.

On the other side of Istanbul another tragedy is unfolding. Five prisoners' relatives are on hunger strike in a small house overlooking the Bosporus. Two women have so far starved to death.

Zehra Kulaksiz has been refusing solid food for five months. She takes sugared water and high-energy drinks, but she is getting weaker. Her sister Canan starved to death last week, aged 19.

"Our prisoners are isolated and tortured," Ms Kulaksiz whispered. "It may be hard for you to understand, but that is why we have to die".

Her father said he supports her protest, and is ready to lose another daughter. It has become an ideological struggle in which martyrdom is the primary aim. Individuals are of secondary concern.

Most of the criticism, however, is being directed at the government.

Yesterday a group of leading artists and writers appealed for action. Even the association which represents Turkey's main business leaders has said that ministers are not doing enough.

The justice minister, Hikmet Sami Turk, has announced plans for legal reforms that will allow prisoners held singly or in threes in small cells to meet for educational, social, cultural and sporting activities.

Under current rules prisoners jailed on terrorism charges are isolated in cells and are not allowed to mix.

Mr Sami Turk said the changes would permit civilian inspection of prison conditions and give courts the authority to bring charges against prison officers without the consent of the justice ministry.

Human rights groups say torture is common in Turkish prisons and charges are almost never brought against prison officers. The proposed reforms will need parliamentary approval, and that could take time.

"I have done everything I can," Mr Sami Turk said, "and my conscience is clear."

Nevertheless, pressure from Turkey's western allies is beginning to increase.

European diplomats in Ankara have expressed concern about the death-fast and called on the government to take urgent steps to end it.

They have made it clear that they do not oppose prison reform in itself, but the way it has been forced through by the state has led to a rapidly developing crisis.

They support Ankara's decision to end the old prison system in which leftwing, Kurdish and Islamist groups were housed in dormitory wards which held up to 100 prisoners each. The groups ran the wards themselves, covering the walls in party flags and symbols, and holding military-style roll calls every morning.

Security forces raided jails throughout the country in December to force prisoners out of the dormitories, and transfer more than 1,000 to new high-security jails known as "F-types".

The new prisons have been heavily criticised, however, because, even though they are clean and modern, they do not meet certain international standards. The regime of "small-cell isolation" is a particular focus of complaint.

Mourners at Ender Can Yildiz's funeral dismissed the justice minister's new proposals, and said the hunger strike would continue. They have a long list of demands, including the complete abolition of F-type prisons.

As the dispute drags on, more hospital space is being prepared for dozens of prisoners who are getting weaker by the day. Newspapers say that more than 100 may die.

The government has announced legal reforms to ease the regime of isolation which has been imposed on hundreds of prisoners for months. But it insists that there will be no negotiations with the extreme leftwing groups behind the hunger strike. "We will not allow the prisons to become the headquarters of terrorism again," the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said on Thursday. "The state will not give in to pressure from people who are forcing their friends to die." Yildiz died in an Ankara hospital on Wednesday. Doctors say dozens of other prisoners are in a critical condition, and the death toll is likely to rise at any time. Yildiz's mother, Hanife, led the funeral procession yesterday. On a red ribbon wrapped around her head the words "Ender Can is immortal" were carefully written in black. Leaning on a stick, but speaking clearly, she said: "My son didn't lose this fight. He won and I'm proud of him. We will keep fighting until victory". Hundreds of mourners chanting slogans and pumping their fists in the air were closely shadowed by an even larger number of heavily armed paramilitaries. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 8 farmers die in land dispute
fields.body:
8 farmers die in land dispute

At least eight Indian farmers have been killed in a land dispute with a rival group in Chiapas state.

The eight, affiliated to the former government party, died in the state's worst case of violence since 1998, confirming that political rivalries will dog the new government's efforts to restore peace. Reuters, Guadaulpe Tepeyac

Austria 'will not extradite Nazi'

Austria is refusing to extradite a former Nazi officer wanted in Italy for a massacre of civilians during the second world war, because he is too old and frail to stand trial, a prosecutor said yesterday.

Wilhelm Schubernig, 86, is wanted for his role in the Ardeantine massacre in 1944, in which 335 Italian civilian hostages were shot dead by the Nazis. AFP, Vienna

'Dead' hiker comes to life

An Australian hiker who spent five weeks trekking through a wilderness area in Tasmania emerged on Friday, days after searchers had given him up for dead and his family had held a memorial service. Reuters, Sydney

fields.headline: German daredevil grounded by court
fields.trailText: Mathias Rust, the daredevil teenage pilot who gained world notoriety for landing his single-engine Cessna plane in Moscow's Red Square in 1987, returned to the spotlight this week after years of obscurity when a German court convicted him of shoplifting.
fields.body:
Mathias Rust, the daredevil teenage pilot who gained world notoriety for landing his single-engine Cessna plane in Moscow's Red Square in 1987, returned to the spotlight this week after years of obscurity when a German court convicted him of shoplifting.

Rust was fined £3,300 for the theft last November of a £60 cashmere pullover from a Hamburg department store, in what the judge condemned as a "brazen act".

It marked a new low in the life of the 33-year-old aviation enthusiast who was feted in the west after flying across 500 miles of some of the most heavily guarded parts of the Soviet Union in May 1987 on what he described as a "mission of peace". He was lauded too for his outlandish attempts to broker a peace deal with Soviet leaders.

Curious onlookers gathered outside the court in Pinneberg, close to Hamburg, this week to catch a glimpse of the man who, on a national border guards' holiday, landed his aircraft on the bridge behind St Basil's cathedral before taxiing on to the cobbles of Red Square next to Lenin's mausoleum.

His stunt led to the resignations of both the Soviet defence minister and the air marshal in charge of air defence command.

The judge in this week's trial paid tribute to the German, dubbed the teenage Red Baron, and said he had put on his best tie on the occasion of having "such a prominent person with international court experience" in the dock.

The conviction was the latest disaster to befall Rust since his flying feat. In 1991 he was sentenced by a Hamburg court to two-and-a-half years in prison for stabbing a student nurse who had refused to kiss him at the hospital where he was doing his civil service.

"It was then the truth emerged that he really was crazy," wrote the Hamburger Morgenpost.

Rust was given a lenient sentence for the stabbing because of the traumatic 432 days he had already served in a Russian labour camp for his flying escapade.

He was released early and later returned to Moscow, where he tried and failed to rekindle the attention he had received years before.

False rumours of his death had begun to emerge from Moscow when he reappeared suddenly in 1996 in a court near Hamburg. Although he had allegedly made a fortune from his aviation exploit, he was filing for bankruptcy, claiming he could not pay the costs of a newspaper libel trial he had lost.

Less than five months later, his money problems were apparently solved when he converted to Hinduism and got engaged to the daughter of a rich Indian tea merchant.

Rust now lives in Berlin with his wife, works in a grocery store and thinks often of his Russian adventure.

"It was as if I had reached beyond the borders of reality," he told Stern recently. "It was a once in a lifetime experience."

He no longer flies, however.

"They took my flying licence away and in order to get it back I have to prove that I'm not round the bend," he said. "I'm just not willing to do that."

fields.headline: Nepalese twin battles against infection
fields.trailText: One of the Nepalese twins born joined at the brain and separated last week in a marathon operation in Singapore was fighting for her life yesterday after failing to respond to treatment for a blood and brain infection.
fields.body:
One of the Nepalese twins born joined at the brain and separated last week in a marathon operation in Singapore was fighting for her life yesterday after failing to respond to treatment for a blood and brain infection.

Ganga Shrestha still has a high fever and is receiving additional antibiotics, Dr Vincent Yeow, a plastic surgeon in the team at Singapore general hospital which separated the 11-month-old from her sister, Jamuna, said yesterday.

"We can't do anything but change the dressings [on her head]," he said.

"Cross all your fingers and hope the antibiotics work."

Dr Keith Goh, the neurosurgeon who directed the operation, was slightly more hopeful. "The complication is not unexpected. I think we're winning [but] we have not solved the problem yet," he said.

"Whether she survives or not depends entirely on whether the infection is brought under control. We're bringing her into the operating room tomorrow [Saturday] to see where we stand."

An official hospital statement played down the threat. "Ganga is in stable condition. She is breathing by herself with minimal respiratory support," it said.

The twins were born sharing a brain cavity and were separated in a 96-hour operation. The doctors believe the wound on Ganga's scalp has failed to heal as quickly as Jamuna's because Ganga's brain is bigger and it is therefore harder to stretch the skin grafted from elsewhere on her body over the wound. Both girls remain in intensive care.

The hospital said Jamuna still had a fever but her temperature was dropping.

"Jamuna is feeding and responding very well," the statement said.

Dr Yeow said she was unlikely to suffer brain damage, adding: "She has over a 90% chance of being completely normal."

The girls were brought to Singapore for the surgery from their remote village in the Nepalese mountains. If they survive the initial phase, they are expected to stay in hospital for up to three months.
