webTitle: Yes, composers can get a hand - but only if they don't need it

fields.headline: Yes, composers can get a hand - but only if they don't need it
fields.trailText: Sounding off
fields.body:
What has become Britain's most important showcase for fledgling composers is taking place this weekend on London's South Bank. In State of the Nation, the London Sinfonietta provides an annual opportunity for inexperienced composers to hear their works performed by the leading new-music band in the country. Not all the talents selected will be in the first flush of youth, but all are on the threshold of what they hope will be successful careers.

It's a thoroughly worthwhile event, which nicely complements the Sinfonietta's main high-profile concert series, though inevitably it can only scratch the surface of what is being written. But these days, getting launched as a composer is one thing; staying afloat quite another. Music publishers are increasingly wary of taking on new contracts, especially since the changes in Performing Rights Society revenue are hitting their income from new music so hard. As a result many composers are publishing their music themselves; but they still have to get it performed, and managing to interest orchestras is notoriously hard.

The British orchestras would probably say that they are doing their bit for new music through their composer-in-residence schemes, which seem to be very much in vogue at the moment. Almost all the major British orchestras have some such arrangement in place through which they commission a series of new works from the selected composer and involve him or her in workshops and educational projects throughout the tenancy.

It seems at first sight a totally admirable idea: the composers are able to polish their orchestral craft by working closely with the players, while the orchestras gain more expertise playing unfamiliar and often demanding scores. And when the right composer is matched to the right organisation, it really can be mutually beneficial. When Mark-Anthony Turnage was appointed to the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra in 1989, in one of the first of these schemes to get off the ground, he wrote three major works for the CBSO and his orchestral writing came on in leaps and bounds.

But when Turnage went to Birmingham he was in his 20s and still in the process of establishing himself as a distinctive voice in British music. The arrangement suited him perfectly at the time, just as it should Julian Anderson, now in his early 30s, who joined the CBSO in the same position at the beginning of this year; and also the immensely promising 24-year-old Stuart MacRae, who is currently composer-in-association with the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra. But it is harder to see the justification for the partnership of James MacMillan with the BBC Philharmonic, for instance, or Michael Berkeley with the BBC National Orchestra of Wales. It provides a nice element of security in a freelance world, but both men are well-established composers, experienced in writing orchestral music. Neither is likely to get as much out of the arrangement as a lesser-known figure from a younger generation.

The real reason for this rash of appointments isn't always, I suspect, a selfless desire on the part of the orchestras to do something for new music. By setting up resident-composer schemes, orchestras are able to attract extra money from the Arts Council and its devolved bodies through the maze of funding for new initiatives and outreach programmes that seems designed to make running a major arts organisation as complicated as possible. Cashflow is ever more important to the orchestras - the sums involved can make a significant difference to their budgets.

Though the same amount of cash might be spread much more profitably in artistic terms among a whole range of younger composers, such commissions don't make such a tidy package, and don't fit so comfortably within the Arts Council's inflexible framework. So just one composer it has to be, preferably a high-profile one. In the end, such schemes do very little to enrich the real culture of new music in this country.

As all those tyros take their first steps into the intimidating world of London's music this weekend, they can dream of getting one of these plum posts. But how many of them will be so lucky to be granted one at an age at which they can really benefit?

fields.headline: The billion brain
fields.trailText: Scientists in Chicago have constructed a cyborg. It revolutionises at a stroke our view of the lamprey, a creature which up to now has had the kind of odious reputation which, were it human, would have driven it to summon Max Clifford.
fields.body:
Scientists in Chicago, Smallweed read with a shudder this week, have constructed a cyborg - a half-living, half-robot creature which unites a brain stem from the larva of a lamprey with a robot manufactured in Switzerland. This is a very significant breakthrough. It revolutionises at a stroke our view of the lamprey, a creature which up to now has had the kind of odious reputation which, were it human, would have driven it to summon Max Clifford.

The lamprey belongs to the class known as Agnatha, a type of primitive, fishlike, jawless veterbrate which also includes the hagfish. Out of respect for the hagfish, the two should not be confused. Most live in the sea, though some spend their lives in landlocked lakes. These sinister creatures - I thought of printing a picture, but abstained for fear of frightening you: next week, perhaps, when we're all a week older - prey on innocent fish, to which they attach themselves using a sucking disc and ferocious teeth. They have also been guilty in our own country of regicide.

Lampreys killed Henry I: not because they attacked his plump body as he swam in the Bedfordshire Ouse, but because he ate too many and died, as it used to be said, of "a surfeit of lampreys". In the Great Lakes, where they fasten impartially on to lake trout, salmon, rainbow trout (steelhead), whitefish, chub, walleye and catfish, they have recently been subjected to what the Great Lakes Fishery Commission describes as a programme of integrated lampricide which aims to reduce the population of parasitic lampreys in Lake Huron and Northern Michigan by 85% by the year 2015. Whether the need to collect immature lampreys to power a new race of cyborgs will interfere with this enterprise is not clear, at least not to me.

To those with Smallweed's egalitarian tastes, it would seem only right that the newly discovered talent of this long-despised group ought now to be recognised, perhaps with some kind of financial reward. Let me therefore commend to Max Clifford, or whoever is now looking after their interests, an advertisement in G2 two mornings ago for what is decribed as a universal dental implant. Dr A Di Giulio and Dr D Di Giulio of Wimpole Street, it reveals, are offering safe implants for those with thin, low or hollow jawbones. Their methods could no doubt be swiftly adopted to help those who, like the lamprey, lack any jawbone at all. This kind of cosmetic surgery would in Smallweed's view do almost as much to redeem the lamprey's lacklustre image as anything planned in Chicago.

The psychiatrist Raj Persaud and the Umist psychologist Cary Cooper had better watch out. Their claims to the title Mr Ubiquitous are about to fall to another. The psychologist Richard Wiseman of Hertfordshire University, who superintended the recent ghost-seeking experiment deep under Edinburgh castle, is the same Richard Wiseman recently in the news for flying to Las Vegas to investigate magicians' use of psychology, for probing reported sightings of Catherine Howard at Hampton Court and for staging a challenge in which a four-year-old child made a better fist of investing in the markets than a regular investor, an astrologer and a cat called Jasper. It was also Wiseman who, just before Christmas, attacted a cluster of headlines by claiming that banks had three main types of customer: hedonistic grazers (classic "Bridget Jones" types), material martyrs and steady builders. Persaud and Cooper should know that Wiseman has one important asset they haven't. He is a magician himself.

Next week in Smallweed: Richard Wiseman invents a new classification for distinguishing between the behaviour of competing classes of lamprey.

The Friday night Channel 4 entertainment Frasier, which, apart from the news and sport, is just about the only thing I watch on television nowadays, has recently been disfigured by a subplot involving a Mancunian called Daphne, once some kind of carer/assistant to Frasier Crane's elderly father, but now attached to his brother, Niles. She has started guzzling chocolate and secreting other fattening products around the apartment to snaffle when no one is looking. This is making her amazingly fat. In a recent instalment, Daphne sank to the ground, and it needed the efforts of all three men to pull her back to her feet. This led to a line so sublime that it seemed at last to explain why this otherwise indefensible theme had been introduced. "It has taken three Cranes to lift you!" Frasier's father told her. That line having been spoken, there seemed to be no further need for the subplot, and I hoped it would now be dropped and Daphne returned to her slimline state. Sadly, it has persisted, which presumably means the more boring explanation - that the actor who plays her, Jane Leeves, is pregnant - was true all along, after all.

Unattractive as the TV schedules often are, they are hardly more disappointing than the lists of films advertised by my local popcorn temples, from which everything I am keen to see is ruthlessly excluded. I have finally found a local cinema which is showing The Insider, a much-praised exposé of the tobacco industry which could hardly have been more elusive had tobacco manufacturers bought all the copies up and suppressed them. I also caught up in that underestimated cultural centre, Croydon, with David Mamet's succulently well-written State and Main, which is not to everyone's taste but will enchant all those with distant memories of the 1940s comedy classic recently recollected here, Don't Take it to Heart.

But few such movies linger for long, or even get shown at all, in such local cinemas as advertise in the London Evening Standard. The choice at present seems mainly to be between Bridget Jones's Diary (ABC Barbican, Odeon Marble Arch, UCI Whiteley's, Tricycle Cinema, UGC Ealing), Bridget Jones' Diary (Clapham Picture House, Gate Cinema, Ritzy Brixton, Screen on Baker Street, Screen on Islington Green, UGC Trocadero, Warner Village Finchley Road), Bridget Jones Diary (Odeon Camden Town, UGC West India Quay, UGC Staples Corner) and Bridget Jone's Diary (ABC Chelsea, Screen on the Hill, UCI Empire Leicester Square, UGC Hammersmith, and UGC Fulham Road).

The psychologist Richard Wiseman of Hertfordshire University, who superintended the recent ghost-seeking experiment deep under Edinburgh castle, is the same Richard Wiseman recently in the news for flying to Las Vegas to investigate magicians' use of psychology, for probing reported sightings of Catherine Howard at Hampton Court and for staging a challenge in which a four-year-old child made a better fist of investing in the markets than a regular investor, an astrologer and a cat called Jasper. It was also Wiseman who, just before Christmas, attacted a cluster of headlines by claiming that banks had three main types of customer: hedonistic grazers (classic "Bridget Jones" types), material martyrs and steady builders. Persaud and Cooper should know that Wiseman has one important asset they haven't. He is a magician himself. Next week in Smallweed: Richard Wiseman invents a new classification for distinguishing between the behaviour of competing classes of lamprey. The Friday night Channel 4 entertainment Frasier, which, apart from the news and sport, is just about the only thing I watch on television nowadays, has recently been disfigured by a subplot involving a Mancunian called Daphne, once some kind of carer/assistant to Frasier Crane's elderly father, but now attached to his brother, Niles. She has started guzzling chocolate and secreting other fattening products around the apartment to snaffle when no one is looking. This is making her amazingly fat. In a recent instalment, Daphne sank to the ground, and it needed the efforts of all three men to pull her back to her feet. This led to a line so sublime that it seemed at last to explain why this otherwise indefensible theme had been introduced. "It has taken three Cranes to lift you!" Frasier's father told her. That line having been spoken, there seemed to be no further need for the subplot, and I hoped it would now be dropped and Daphne returned to her slimline state. Sadly, it has persisted, which presumably means the more boring explanation - that the actor who plays her, Jane Leeves, is pregnant - was true all along, after all. Unattractive as the TV schedules often are, they are hardly more disappointing than the lists of films advertised by my local popcorn temples, from which everything I am keen to see is ruthlessly excluded. I have finally found a local cinema which is showing The Insider, a much-praised exposé of the tobacco industry which could hardly have been more elusive had tobacco manufacturers bought all the copies up and suppressed them. I also caught up in that underestimated cultural centre, Croydon, with David Mamet's succulently well-written State and Main, which is not to everyone's taste but will enchant all those with distant memories of the 1940s comedy classic recently recollected here, Don't Take it to Heart. But few such movies linger for long, or even get shown at all, in such local cinemas as advertise in the London Evening Standard. The choice at present seems mainly to be between Bridget Jones's Diary (ABC Barbican, Odeon Marble Arch, UCI Whiteley's, Tricycle Cinema, UGC Ealing), Bridget Jones' Diary (Clapham Picture House, Gate Cinema, Ritzy Brixton, Screen on Baker Street, Screen on Islington Green, UGC Trocadero, Warner Village Finchley Road), Bridget Jones Diary (Odeon Camden Town, UGC West India Quay, UGC Staples Corner) and Bridget Jone's Diary (ABC Chelsea, Screen on the Hill, UCI Empire Leicester Square, UGC Hammersmith, and UGC Fulham Road).  Please note new email address: MrSmallweed@aol.com

fields.headline: Anglesey
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
The flooding of the narrow valley by the sea that caused the isolation of Anglesey from the mainland long, long ago produced one of our islands' loveliest marine landscapes. From the hanging woods west of Beaumaris, where daffodils now glint with primroses above the Menai Bridge road, to the exposed dunes of Abermenai Point (Anglesey's southernmost tip), this sinuous waterway is littered with pretty prospects. Unfortunately there are sections of these Menai Straits where no public footpath exists because large, historic estates come right down to the shore - as at Plas Newydd on the Anglesey side and Vaynol Hall on the mainland opposite.

We may, in normal times, rue the dearth of footways above the tideline here but they would be out of bounds now, anyway. The other day we took the only sensible alternative and climbed the narrow public road beside Beaumaris cemetery to tread the knotted network of hidden lanes that pre-date the coast road created by the Bulkeleys only two centuries ago, between this loveliest of Welsh towns and Menai Bridge.

Gulls were arguing in the air above the tiny lake near Pen-y-parc; a wren lurked in the crannies of a mossy wall as we went by. Further along, new sprouts of wall pennywort brought the promise of pale, bell-shaped flowers in a couple of months. Up here on the crest of the steep drop to the Menai Straits you can catch grand glimpses of flashing blue water, of a white sail here and there near Bangor pier, and away to the green foothills that are the precursors of the high country beyond. And as we went along we got an even better view. As we entered Llandegfan, with its old windmill and towered church 300 feet above the shore, we could see the entire northern flank of Snowdonia, from Penmaenmawr to Yr Eifl in the far off south-west.

With a line of shining fracto-cumulus clouds floating above the high tops of the Carneddau, it seemed that a flock of freshly dipped ewes was wandering there in the palest of blue skies, quite immune to any earthly disease now affecting their mortal sisters and their lambs not far away across these fields. West of the Carneddau the crumpled mountain frieze had no white crown of cloud; Y Wyddfa and her satellites and the Nantlle hills pierced the uncluttered firmament. Roger Redfern.

fields.headline: Who wrote this again?
fields.standfirst: Joe Penhall  loves seeing his plays produced abroad - but he doesn't always recognise them
fields.trailText: Joe Penhall loves seeing his plays produced abroad - but he doesn't always recognise them
fields.body:
A funny thing happened on the way to the West End: my plays became more popular abroad than in Britain. Blue/Orange is about to open in London's Duchess Theatre, but in France my work has already had extended runs in large venues. I have been translated into French, Catalan, Hebrew, Norwegian and Greek. In Athens, the president attended the opening night of Love and Understanding, and a journalist asked me: "What is the difference between you and Harold Pinter?"

Directors have taken me to monasteries and brothels in well-meaning attempts at hospitality, and British ambassadors have thrown open their drinks cabinets. And because these productions were independent of the British theatres in which the plays had premiered, the staging was entirely in the hands of foreigners. Cultural assumptions were batted back and forth, cultural specificity went clean out the window, and time and again I was forced to ask not what could my writing do for the rest of the world, but what could the rest of the world do for it?

By far the most popular of my plays abroad, Love and Understanding, focuses on Richie, a morphine-addicted alcoholic who has returned from a bout of cack-handed globetrotting seemingly to destroy his oldest friend's entire life. In Athens a journalist told me that the writing, and indeed the characters, "have the sun in their hearts". The play was likened to the myth of Odysseus. An elderly lady baked me a vine-leaf pie.

In Britain some reviewers found it implausible that Richie hadn't long ago been thrown out of the house by his strait-laced host. In one foreign country, which had best remain nameless, it was the opposite. They wanted the other two squares thrown out. One person involved in this production lined up a free fix for me on my arrival in town, followed by days of beer-drinking and a trip to a brothel. Were they researching the part? Unlikely - the play was already weeks into its run. They were just pleased to see me.

Meanwhile, in New York, the Village Voice ranted that "mass extermination is the only suitable fate" for the characters of Some Voices. "You wouldn't want to spend eight seconds with these grotty and loathsome folk in reality," the critic informed his Greenwich Village hepcat constituency. In Britain, people seem moved by the plight of Ray, trying to get back on the straight and narrow after being diagnosed schizophrenic; in New York, an elderly audience member explained: "People think he's a bum."

My latest play, Blue/Orange, is about a young black man who claims to be the son of an infamous African dictator. As the ambitious psychiatrists Bruce and Robert argue about his sanity as a result of his "shouting and staring", the cultural assumptions fly. Robert suggests that "perhaps that's just what you do where he comes from". But Christopher comes from Shepherd's Bush. He is, however, of Ugandan descent, and the implication is that Ugandans are intrinsically rowdy. Whether this is racism, cultural assumption, cultural specificity or just bollocks is one of the ensuing arguments.

Which brings me tenuously back to my subject: cultural specificity in the theatre. The orthodoxy is that theatre is a universal language and therefore ripe for local adaptation. Hence, as long as there are men and women, black and white, rich and poor, with or without some form of psychosis, there will always be a show.

It might be unrecognisable though. In Barcelona, there are appallingly few black actors. Nevertheless, the producers of Blau/Taronja found a black man who, although not strictly speaking an actor, was related to one. I discovered that in Catalan there is no single word with the same pejorative force as "nigger". In the play, an accusation of racism hinges on the use of the term "uppity nigger". That, needless to say, became awkward to translate.

More than once I actually jumped when I heard people playfully bandying around the English term "nigger" offstage. But the real surprise was the 400-strong audience - who didn't turn a hair. What had been "coruscating" in London seemed to to be a good-natured exchange of languid witticisms between two rather fey chaps in tweed, an often puzzled-looking amateur and a bowl of oranges - which had played a central part in Britain but here did little more than dress the set.

The problem is that if foreign productions fail to understand the original cultural references, the playwright just looks stupid. The flip-side is that earnest attempts at verisimilitude often result in unimaginably ludicrous peccadillos. When Blue/Orange transferred to Sweden, the Swedish translator wrote to inform me: "Rehearsals are going well. From my collection of postcards, I'm sending some now and then to pep the director. One is a phonebooth offer from London to come spanking & caning (sic) a fair teenager, which supposedly happened to fall out of a bunch of files Robert was carrying when making the rounds." A reference in the text to "dickie bows and putters" led to the assumption that Robert was "an upper-class homosexual". I wrote back: "Pull yourself together, man. He's a psychiatrist, not a pederast."

Maybe something was lost in the translation. Usually, however, much is gained. In the case of Love and Understanding's Greek version, about an hour and a half. I asked the translator how she had rendered the line "Is she Catholic?" and was told the translation meant "Is she Italian?" After further probing, I learned that it was closer to "Is she an Italian woman from across the water with hairy feet?" Of course - a Sicilian.

It didn't escape my notice that the two 28-year-old male leads (ages are specified) were played by two hairy 50-year-olds, while their similarly late-twentysomething female lover was one of the most fresh-faced 21-year-olds I've ever clapped eyes on. Nobody found this unusual.

In New York the Hollywood-bound director of Some Voices also had problems with realism. By the time I arrived for rehearsals, one director and two actresses had been fired for being too miserable. The actress now playing the abused, confused Laura was under siege to "look perky".

I pointed out that Laura's boyfriend had taken to punching her in the mouth but was told without irony by the female producer: "She could smile occasionally. She looks like a dyke." Later, I caught the new director grappling with the tricky "British accent" and even trickier demeanour. "You know what? You be Mick Jagger and you be Ringo Starr," was his expert advice. His reasoning being that Mick is "kinda punky, kinda cheeky" and Ringo... well... Ringo isn't.

In France, Some Voices and Love and Understanding had long runs, and Pale Horse and The Bullet are ready for production. The superb French translator Blandine Pelissier has done everything possible to smooth my path. On tour in Angers, she mentioned the silly film Tintin and the Blue Oranges, inadvertently freeing up a cluster of bottle-necked ideas. Later she sent me Paul Eluard's surreal poem La Terre Est Bleu Comme Une Orange, leading to a new raft of ideas.

This is what the rest of the world did for my writing. In a roundabout way, it gave me a play.

 Joe Penhall's play Blue/Orange previews at the Duchess Theatre, London WC2 (020-7494 5399), from April 24. Pale Horse is at Pentameters Theatre, London NW3 (020-7435 3648), until May 6.

fields.headline: Worlds of his own
fields.standfirst: His first play, written when he was 18, was a West End hit. Then he went to Hollywood and won an Oscar. This former Wunderkind has consolidated his success but admits that a peripatic childhood has left him with a sense of detachment. John O'Mahony reports
fields.trailText: His first play, written when he was 18, was a West End hit. Then he went to Hollywood and won an Oscar. This former Wunderkind has consolidated his success but admits that a peripatic childhood has left him with a sense of detachment. John O'Mahony reports
fields.body:
On a frosty Oxford morning, in the early spring of 1966, a New College porter crossed the main quad and unwittingly set in motion one of the most extraordinary debuts in modern British theatre. Earlier that term, a lanky undergraduate named Christopher Hampton, who had already earned a reputation on campus as a brilliant student of languages and who would graduate with a first-class honours degree in French and German, had submitted his first play to the annual Oxford University Dramatic Society student festival.

A precocious exploration of the angst and self-laceration of adolescent homosexuality, written when he was only 18, When Did You Last See My Mother? had been accepted by OUDS, done decent business and even garnered a favourable review in the Guardian. On the advice of a friend, he had sent the script to Peggy Ramsay, the agent who had chaperoned the careers of such writers as Joe Orton, Robert Bolt and Edward Bond. About a week later, Hampton was pottering around his ground-floor rooms when the doorbell rang.

"I opened the door and there's this porter standing there, telling me that there is a telephone call for me," Hampton remembers. "I immediately thought that someone had died because that was they only time they did this sort of thing. But, needless to say, it was only Peggy, who had browbeaten the poor man into submission over the phone. When I took the call, she said: 'You had better come down to London tomorrow. We have to decide what we are going to do about your play.' "

The next morning, Hampton cut his lectures and went to London, to Ramsay 's rundown office, in a converted brothel off St Martin's Lane. They hit it off almost instantly, the dynamic, overbearing Ramsay finding a favoured son in the intense young playwright, bookish-looking behind his NHS glasses. After treating Hampton to a graphic account of her affair with Ionesco, Ramsay picked up the phone and began to call through her check-list of outlets and venues. At the top was Bill Gaskill, then artistic director of the Royal Court theatre: "She rang up in her very forceful way and said 'You have got to read this play'," Gaskill recalls. "Well, she was rather persuasive and quite formidable, so I did read it. And I liked it very much."

Within three months, the play had progressed to the Royal Court's Theatre Upstairs. A month later it transferred to the Comedy Theatre, propelling the 20-year-old undergraduate into the theatrical history books as the youngest playwright in the modern era to have a production in the West End. To cement Hampton's Wunderkind status, the more delirious notices hailed the play as the most powerful and corrosive to grace any British stage since the war: "I do not care whether Mr Hampton is 18 or 80," gushed the Times, "There are things in his work that would be magnificently moving, beautifully understanding, revealing and compassionate for any age."

The rapidity of his ascent left Hampton bemused, delighted and a little incredulous, as is obvious from his first major interview - with the Daily Mail - conducted on the day after the premiere, when Hampton revealed his ambition to be, one day, the West End's "oldest playwright" and to be accepted into the Académie Francaise. "I was saying all the wrong things in interviews; ie, the first thing that came into my head. So [the publicists] gave me a lady who went round with me. At one stage she gave me a bollocking because she said I didn't seem to realise how extraordinary it all was. And I said, 'What do you mean?' She said: 'People usually struggle for years and write 25 plays before they get this kind of attention.' Peggy had made it so easy."

Thirty five years on, Hampton can look back at this early triumph across a career that has produced a body of work unparalleled in its depth and diversity. Though When Did You Last See My Mother? has now been largely overshadowed (it doesn't even make it into his collection, Plays 1, published by Faber in 1997) the success propelled Hampton to the much superior Total Eclipse, a dramatisation of the destructive relationship between the French poets Rimbaud and Verlaine; The Philanthropist, a spectacularly observed "bourgeois comedy" constructed as a riposte to Molière's Le Misanthrope; Tales From Hollywood, arguably Hampton's masterpiece, to be revived at the Donmar Warehouse on May 1 (previews start this week) and his best known stage work, Les Liaisons Dangereuses which was garlanded with honours, including an Olivier Award for play of the year in 1986, the Evening Standard Award of the same year and the New York Critics Circle Award in 1987. He went on to win an Oscar for his screenplay of the 1988 film version, which starred Glenn Close, John Malkovich and Michelle Pfeiffer. This week, it was announced that Steven Spielberg has hired him to write the screenplay for Tulip Fever, the film of the novel by Deborah Moggach.

In addition to his original theatre work, Hampton has translated more than a dozen works for stage. These range from Tales from the Vienna Woods, by Odon Von Horvath whose repu- tation Hampton has done much to revive, to the extremely successful Art by Yasmina Reza, and her more recent Life x 3. Venturing even deeper into populist territory, he also co-wrote the libretto for Andrew Lloyd Webber's Sunset Boulevard and is currently working on a new musical, Dracula.

While contemporaries such as Hare, Brenton, Frayn and Pinter have ploughed single furrows, Hampton has chosen to wander the length and breadth of his talent and interests. Unwilling to embrace political issues or explore the prevalent class conflicts, he is much less in tune with the British dramatic sensibility than with the 18th and 19th-century European writers who have been his main influences, particularly Flaubert with whom Hampton shares the same limpid objectivity and ironic outlook and tone. "He is uncategorisable," says Richard Eyre, who directed Hampton's autobiographical work, White Chameleon at the National Theatre in 1993. "To his credit, there is no school of Hampton, no loose confederation that you lump him together with. He has always been an absolute original. And his contribution in that sense is four or five really outstanding plays that are architecturally very, very sophisticated and have the denseness of poetry."

By all accounts, Hampton has changed surprisingly little since that early success. Though he has filled out, he retains the boyish smile and gangly demeanour. If he appeared somewhat donnish as a young man, now, with his long mane of ash-grey hair, he looks even more so. There is a modest, gentle quality about him that seems out of its time. His considerable earnings allow him to live in a sumptuous Kensington mansion, each room decorated in a different period theme; the living room is "19th-century Chinese".

His study is a vast, top-floor apartment in another, equally impressive white stucco mansion at the end of the same street. He is a staunch Luddite, flinches at the mention of the word "e-mail" and writes his plays and screenplays in longhand, with a fountain pen.

Given his educational pedigree and the frame of reference of his work, it is not surprising that one of the first things people mention is his intelligence. But in person, there are no intellectual pyrotechnics, no linguistic fireworks. "He doesn't wear it on his sleeve," says Don Black, who worked with him on the libretto of Sunset Boulevard. "Obviously, his terms of reference are wide: he can quote Spinoza or Jung, or Pushkin, off the top of his head and is very well read. But he is down to earth. He fits in with anyone. He's as happy having a chat with the postman."

He also possesses a strong streak of self-deprecating humour: "All his comedy, and all his humour is about haplessness," says David Hare who was at school with him. "Even at 13, 14, it was things going wrong that made him roar with laughter and that was what made other people roar with laughter. He is a brilliant anecdotist. He almost collects humiliation and mishaps, and out of that comedy he has often made his work."

His college girlfriend Joanna Van Heyningen, now an architect, says: "Chris was probably the most indecisive person I have ever come across. Not about his art, but about everything else in life. I used to go round to his mother's flat with him and his mother would say, 'Shall I turn on the television dear?' And Chris would say, 'I don't know, mother. It's up to you.' And she would say, 'No, it's up to you dear.' And he would say, 'No, it's up to you.' And it would go on like that. It was funny in an excruciating sort of way."

Hampton adds: "It's less of a problem now, but deciding which shoes to wear can still be a burden."

His detachment from the world, where the literary figures that populate his imagination seem more tangible than the mortals before his eyes, can also be a barrier: "He is very much a person of boundaries," says his wife, Laura. "He has very strong boundaries and I think that people are initially loath to cross them. But then they realise what a very, very warm person he is. I think it's a writer's thing, this remoteness. That is my only problem with him. He is very remote."

It is a character trait of which Hampton is aware: "I do feel that kind of distance. Just because, from Suez on, my childhood was characterised by a certain amount of ups and downs, it doesn't surprise me that life has continued in that manner. I view things with a certain equanimity."

Christopher James Hampton was born on January 26 1946 in the Azores archipelago, in the north Atlantic ocean 1,000 miles off the coast of Portugal, where his father was stationed as an engineer with Cable and Wireless. Before Christopher's second birthday, the family was posted first to Aden - "A dreadful place, a bit like hell" - and then to Alexandria, "my father's favourite". The latter would provide the setting for his 1991 play White Chameleon, as well as much of the material: the attempt by "ferocious" nuns to force the boy to write with his right hand; and the portrait of a bookish, rather effete, bespectacled child. "He always had glasses, round National Health glasses," recalls his brother, Bob, an accountant. "And he learned to read at an incredibly young age by sitting on his father's knee and demanding to be read to."

In 1956, as the Suez crisis developed, the family was forced to flee Alexandria under cover of darkness, leaving everything behind: "We went to Port Said and there was a liner passing en route from Australia to London," Hampton recalls. "It stopped and we got a launch out and went up the side. It was great, very exciting for a 10-year-old." However, during future postings to Hong Kong and Zanzibar, the young Christopher was left at boarding school in England, first a prep school in Reigate and then Lancing College, a public school: "I loved Egypt. Then when I came back to England where I didn't love it at all, I found it very hard to settle."

However, at Lancing, Hampton proved to be an academic powerhouse: "He was quite simply one of the most brilliant students I ever taught," says his French tutor, Harry Guest. Hampton's background set him apart: "Most of us came from Surrey or Sussex," remembers a school-friend, Roger Dancey, now a schoolmaster at George V School in Birmingham. "And here was this bloom from another world who went home for the holidays to Zanzibar."

He seemed more mature than some: "He had an inner core of certainty and was very calm inside, even as young boy," Hare recalls, "He was preternaturally adult."

At Lancing, Christopher had his first sexual experiences, most of them homosexual: "It was more romantic than anything else," he says. "And the strange thing was that in the holidays you were off trying to find a girlfriend."

His creative impulses also began to blossom. He acted in a number of school productions, including a mammoth production of Goethe's Iphigenie auf Tauris in German, in which he played the lead role of Princess Iphigenie: "Hampton used a subdued brooding presence that suited the greater part of his role and he delivered his lines very well indeed," the school magazine records. He also wrote poetry for the magazine, some of which made its way into an anthology of public- school verse, but his main creative endeavour during this period was a novel, Harry Stone, written in the form of a 300-page suicide note: "It was all fantastically Gothic and gloomy," he says. "The last pages were written as he died after he slashed his wrists."

Earning a fine crop of rejection slips, the novel was never published, due to a fire at Ramsay's office: "There is good news and there is bad news," she told him, breaking the news. "The bad news is that a lot of my archive has been destroyed but the good news is that I think your novel went up as well."

While waiting to take up his place at Oxford, he lived with his brother and friends in Earl's Court in London, and began work on When Did you Last See My Mother? . "We weren't aware of it," says Bob Hampton, "and I don't think I knew it was written there until after it was performed. He stayed in the flat while the rest of us went out to work. I presumed he was lying around in bed."

In 1965, Christopher went up to Oxford, where he chose to study languages rather than English literature. During his first year, his father died of a stroke: "It was so sudden. He had just retired. So much of my life I hadn't seen him. And I had been looking forward to spending more time with him."

When he returned for his second year, Christopher threw himself into the college dramatic society. About this time, he also met Van Heyningen, the daughter of an Oxford don, with whom he was to have a relationship throughout most of his college years: "He was lanky, his skin wasn't that brilliant," she says. "He wasn't obviously much of a catch except when you heard him speak and then he has got a wonderful voice - that was the thing that was so attractive about him. Also, he was so terribly funny."

This was Hampton's first serious heterosexual relationship: "Most of his experiences before me had been homosexual," Van Heyningen says, "So I was quite early on in that side of things.He was thinking that he was almost certainly heterosexual."

Much of this experience had been poured into When Did You Last See My Mother?. After the huge success of the play at the Royal Court and in the West End, Hampton returned again to a homosexual subject for Total Eclipse, which dealt with the destructive relationship between Rimbaud and Verlaine, and also explored the nature of creativity and genius.

The play was written during a study year abroad which began inauspiciously in Hamburg: "It was the only time I remember being really depressed," he recalls. "I was 21. I had no friends. And I was dealing with what had happened with When Did You Last See My Mother? and what seemed to me unmerited success."

When he discovered that the Schauspielhaus, where he was employed as assistant dramaturg, was not willing to pay him, he fled to Paris, finishing the play there before returning to Oxford in the autumn: "Bill Gaskill and Bob Kidd [who had directed When Did you Last See My Mother? ] turned up in my rooms and asked me to read Total Eclipse to them. There were only two chairs. Bill took the large, comfortable chair and Bob took the small chair and I lay on the bed and read them the play. At the end, Bill said: 'Well, I think we'll do it.' Whereupon they left and they did it. It opened the September after I graduated."

Total Eclipse received mixed reviews, (it would do much better when revived in 1981, and was eventually made into a film with Leonardo DiCaprio) but by now Hampton was being accepted as one of the Royal Court writers. When he graduated he was offered the job of literary manager, as well as becoming its first writer-in-residence. "They paid me a pittance and I remember my office was so small that if there were more than two at the meeting, we would have to stand up. I went back recently and noticed that it had been torn down and replaced with a bench."

It was around this time that Hampton met his wife, Laura d'Holesch, a social worker and nurse, who was his landlady in Earl's Court. She had a similarly nomadic background (her father, a Hungarian aristocrat, and mother, a concert pianist, roved from Bucharest to Paris to New York). A relationship developed: "Christopher became my tenant when I lived in a completely horrendous basement in Earl's Court," she remembers. "He was much more self-effacing back then, very unsure of himself. Very, very quiet. I was very impressed not because he had a play on at the Royal Court - Total Eclipse was about to open - but because he had got a first at Oxford. I thought that was completely wonderful."

They went on to marry three years later and now have two daughters. Alice, 26, is training to be a Montessori teacher and Mary, 24, studied music but is now training to be a cabinet-maker.

In his early days at the Royal Court, Hampton began to mix closely with the theatre's hellraising, hard-drinking clique, prominent members of which included the actor Victor Henry, who had been in When Did You Last See My Mother? and Total Eclipse, and Bob Kidd. (Both died young, Henry the victim of a hit-and-run accident aged 29 and Kidd at 37 from pancreatitis.) "I don't think I drank as much as the others, but I kept up," says Hampton. "My doctor tells me that my liver is not what it might be."

His next play, staged at the Royal Court in 1970, would prove so out of synch with the spirit of the times that the theatre hesitated over it for two years. The Philanthropist examines the empty life of a group of college intellectuals. Most memorable is the central character, obviously based on Hampton himself, an anti-hero whose affable nature is as inflammatory to the people around him as is the confrontational malice of Molière's Le Misanthrope. The play proved to be the Royal Court's most successful production to that date, and transferred to the West End for a three-year run: "That didn't go down well," Hampton says. "The Court was much more comfortable with failure than with success so, when I left that year, I left under something of a cloud."

However, he would more than make up for his success with his next two works: Savages, produced in 1973, was inspired by Norman Lewis's famous article, Genocide in Brazil, and received lukewarm notices, and Treats (1976), an airless treatment of a three-way relationship. Perversely, he savoured the scathing reviews: "That is the most extraordinary side of him," says Laura: "He enjoyed it. I said: 'Christopher, are you some sort of masochist?' And he said: 'This is real.'"

In any case, Hampton was considering a concerted move away from the theatre, which he felt was growing too partisan: "His instincts are the instincts of an anarchist not of a socialist," says Hare, "He didn't feel part of the dominant theatre movement of the time because it was all very leftwing and very politically motivated."

Instead, Hampton decamped to Hollywood, where he began work on a film about Dora Carrington, the bisexual Bloomsbury painter and companion of Lytton Strachey. He was also employed to write a screenplay of Nostromo with David Lean, until the director lost interest and abandoned the project. One Hollywood producer asked him to adapt Marlowe's Edward II, only to have the script flung back in his face with the comment: "You wouldn't even get this damn thing on TV."

Though the diversion into film would prove unproductive in the short term (Carrington, which one producer's wife described to Hampton as a film "about a lot of pissy English people" took almost 20 years to reach the screen), events in Los Angeles did provide the material for Tales from Hollywood. The play traces the adventures of a group of displaced European wartime exiles in Hollywood, including Brecht, Heinrich and Thomas Mann. Produced at the National Theatre in 1980, it was a popular success and reviewed more favourably than any of his plays since The Philanthropist.

However, Hampton's greatest critical triumph was still to come. For some years, Ramsay had been nagging him to write an adaptation of Les Liaisons Dangereuses, Choderlos de Laclos's story of love and savagery. However, the National was reluctant to tackle an 18th-century epistolary novel, assuming it would be box-office poison. "I thought that it was impossible," says Howard Davies, who directed the play. "His response was, 'Well, fuck you', which seemed to goad him into action. It was such a negative spur. He delivered the script and it captivated me immediately... It was so simple and cruel, and so shocking."

The resulting production, in 1984, with Alan Rickman as Valmont and Lesley Duncan as Merteuil, was an international sensation, winning a clutch of awards and transferring to Broadway. The film adaptation, directed by Stephen Frears and released in 1988, was nominated for seven Academy awards and won three, including one for Hampton's screenplay.

In many ways, this success has somewhat derailed his career: "I then thought that [making films] might get easier. For the first time I was bombarded with offers. But it didn't [get easier] and I didn't get a film made for five more years."

However, while his bottom drawer bulges with imminent scripts (16 at last count, including the current Tulip Fever) his passion for film has opened up a new career path. When director Mike Newell dropped out of Carrington, Hampton was persuaded to take over: "He loved it so much," says Emma Thompson, who played the lead role. "You mustn't discount the fact that Chris has his own magnetism. His quietness and tolerance brought us all towards him. It was all quite hassle-free, which is unusual for a first-time director."

The film earned Hampton a special jury prize at the Cannes film festival in 1995.

Only one new Hampton play has been produced in the theatre since Les Liaisons Dangereuses, the autobiographical White Chameleon in 1991. But his work has reached the public through translations such as Art. "I miss him," says David Hare. "We lost Christopher to the cinema, and only to get him through the voice of Yasmina Reza is a great deprivation. I find it very strange, his role as the amanuensis for a playwright who isn't one tenth as good as he is."

Hampton, in his defence, pleads his overriding love of cinema, ignited in the tiny movie theatres of Alexandria and then nourished at the Lancing European film club. His willingness to put his talents at the service of others he puts down to his very European aspiration to be a "working playwright", of which Molière was probably the greatest example. But projects on the horizon promise a Hampton renaissance. With Tales from Hollywood at the Donmar Warehouse, he will have three productions on London stages, (albeit two via translations). His adaptation of The Quiet American, directed by Phillip Noyce, is being filmed in Vietnam, and a new original play dealing with the troubled relationship between Jung and Freud, is pencilled in at the National for the end of the year.

"I seem to have turned into something of a workaholic," he says, recalling his youthful ambition to be the West End's oldest playwright. "When I was younger, Peggy Ramsay used to ring me up at eight o' clock in the morning warning me to get out of bed and work. She thought I was very idle. Now I have to force myself to stop."

Life at a glance: Christopher James Hampton

Born: January 26 1948, Azores

Education: Reigate Prep School 1956-59, Lancing College 1959-63, Oxford 1964-68.

Married: Laura d'Holesch 1971; two daughters, Alice and Mary.

Plays: When Did You Last See My Mother? 1966, Total Eclipse 1968, The Philanthropist 1970, Savages 1973, Treats 1976, Tales From Hollywood 1982, Les Liaisons Dangereuses 1985, White Chameleon 1991.

Some films and TV: The Quiet American 2001, Carrington 1995, Tales from Hollywood 1992, Dangerous Liaisons 1988, The Good Father, 1987, Hotel du Lac 1986, The Honorary Consul, 1983, The History Man, 1981.

Some awards: For Tales From Hollywood, Evening Standard best comedy award, 1982; for Les Liaisons Dangereuses, London Theatre Critics best play award 1985, Laurence Olivier play of the year award,1986, Evening Standard award 1986, New York Critics Circle best foreign play 1987; for Dangerous Liaisons, Oscar for best screenplay adapted from another medium, 1989.
fields.bodyText: On a frosty Oxford morning, in the early spring of 1966, a New College porter crossed the main quad and unwittingly set in motion one of the most extraordinary debuts in modern British theatre. Earlier that term, a lanky undergraduate named Christopher Hampton, who had already earned a reputation on campus as a brilliant student of languages and who would graduate with a first-class honours degree in French and German, had submitted his first play to the annual Oxford University Dramatic Society student festival. A precocious exploration of the angst and self-laceration of adolescent homosexuality, written when he was only 18, When Did You Last See My Mother? had been accepted by OUDS, done decent business and even garnered a favourable review in the Guardian. On the advice of a friend, he had sent the script to Peggy Ramsay, the agent who had chaperoned the careers of such writers as Joe Orton, Robert Bolt and Edward Bond. About a week later, Hampton was pottering around his ground-floor rooms when the doorbell rang. "I opened the door and there's this porter standing there, telling me that there is a telephone call for me," Hampton remembers. "I immediately thought that someone had died because that was they only time they did this sort of thing. But, needless to say, it was only Peggy, who had browbeaten the poor man into submission over the phone. When I took the call, she said: 'You had better come down to London tomorrow. We have to decide what we are going to do about your play.' " The next morning, Hampton cut his lectures and went to London, to Ramsay 's rundown office, in a converted brothel off St Martin's Lane. They hit it off almost instantly, the dynamic, overbearing Ramsay finding a favoured son in the intense young playwright, bookish-looking behind his NHS glasses. After treating Hampton to a graphic account of her affair with Ionesco, Ramsay picked up the phone and began to call through her check-list of outlets and venues. At the top was Bill Gaskill, then artistic director of the Royal Court theatre: "She rang up in her very forceful way and said 'You have got to read this play'," Gaskill recalls. "Well, she was rather persuasive and quite formidable, so I did read it. And I liked it very much." Within three months, the play had progressed to the Royal Court's Theatre Upstairs. A month later it transferred to the Comedy Theatre, propelling the 20-year-old undergraduate into the theatrical history books as the youngest playwright in the modern era to have a production in the West End. To cement Hampton's Wunderkind status, the more delirious notices hailed the play as the most powerful and corrosive to grace any British stage since the war: "I do not care whether Mr Hampton is 18 or 80," gushed the Times, "There are things in his work that would be magnificently moving, beautifully understanding, revealing and compassionate for any age." The rapidity of his ascent left Hampton bemused, delighted and a little incredulous, as is obvious from his first major interview - with the Daily Mail - conducted on the day after the premiere, when Hampton revealed his ambition to be, one day, the West End's "oldest playwright" and to be accepted into the Académie Francaise. "I was saying all the wrong things in interviews; ie, the first thing that came into my head. So [the publicists] gave me a lady who went round with me. At one stage she gave me a bollocking because she said I didn't seem to realise how extraordinary it all was. And I said, 'What do you mean?' She said: 'People usually struggle for years and write 25 plays before they get this kind of attention.' Peggy had made it so easy." Thirty five years on, Hampton can look back at this early triumph across a career that has produced a body of work unparalleled in its depth and diversity. Though When Did You Last See My Mother? has now been largely overshadowed (it doesn't even make it into his collection, Plays 1, published by Faber in 1997) the success propelled Hampton to the much superior Total Eclipse, a dramatisation of the destructive relationship between the French poets Rimbaud and Verlaine; The Philanthropist, a spectacularly observed "bourgeois comedy" constructed as a riposte to Molière's Le Misanthrope; Tales From Hollywood, arguably Hampton's masterpiece, to be revived at the Donmar Warehouse on May 1 (previews start this week) and his best known stage work, Les Liaisons Dangereuses which was garlanded with honours, including an Olivier Award for play of the year in 1986, the Evening Standard Award of the same year and the New York Critics Circle Award in 1987. He went on to win an Oscar for his screenplay of the 1988 film version, which starred Glenn Close, John Malkovich and Michelle Pfeiffer. This week, it was announced that Steven Spielberg has hired him to write the screenplay for Tulip Fever, the film of the novel by Deborah Moggach. In addition to his original theatre work, Hampton has translated more than a dozen works for stage. These range from Tales from the Vienna Woods, by Odon Von Horvath whose repu- tation Hampton has done much to revive, to the extremely successful Art by Yasmina Reza, and her more recent Life x 3. Venturing even deeper into populist territory, he also co-wrote the libretto for Andrew Lloyd Webber's Sunset Boulevard and is currently working on a new musical, Dracula. While contemporaries such as Hare, Brenton, Frayn and Pinter have ploughed single furrows, Hampton has chosen to wander the length and breadth of his talent and interests. Unwilling to embrace political issues or explore the prevalent class conflicts, he is much less in tune with the British dramatic sensibility than with the 18th and 19th-century European writers who have been his main influences, particularly Flaubert with whom Hampton shares the same limpid objectivity and ironic outlook and tone. "He is uncategorisable," says Richard Eyre, who directed Hampton's autobiographical work, White Chameleon at the National Theatre in 1993. "To his credit, there is no school of Hampton, no loose confederation that you lump him together with. He has always been an absolute original. And his contribution in that sense is four or five really outstanding plays that are architecturally very, very sophisticated and have the denseness of poetry." By all accounts, Hampton has changed surprisingly little since that early success. Though he has filled out, he retains the boyish smile and gangly demeanour. If he appeared somewhat donnish as a young man, now, with his long mane of ash-grey hair, he looks even more so. There is a modest, gentle quality about him that seems out of its time. His considerable earnings allow him to live in a sumptuous Kensington mansion, each room decorated in a different period theme; the living room is "19th-century Chinese". His study is a vast, top-floor apartment in another, equally impressive white stucco mansion at the end of the same street. He is a staunch Luddite, flinches at the mention of the word "e-mail" and writes his plays and screenplays in longhand, with a fountain pen. Given his educational pedigree and the frame of reference of his work, it is not surprising that one of the first things people mention is his intelligence. But in person, there are no intellectual pyrotechnics, no linguistic fireworks. "He doesn't wear it on his sleeve," says Don Black, who worked with him on the libretto of Sunset Boulevard. "Obviously, his terms of reference are wide: he can quote Spinoza or Jung, or Pushkin, off the top of his head and is very well read. But he is down to earth. He fits in with anyone. He's as happy having a chat with the postman." He also possesses a strong streak of self-deprecating humour: "All his comedy, and all his humour is about haplessness," says David Hare who was at school with him. "Even at 13, 14, it was things going wrong that made him roar with laughter and that was what made other people roar with laughter. He is a brilliant anecdotist. He almost collects humiliation and mishaps, and out of that comedy he has often made his work." His college girlfriend Joanna Van Heyningen, now an architect, says: "Chris was probably the most indecisive person I have ever come across. Not about his art, but about everything else in life. I used to go round to his mother's flat with him and his mother would say, 'Shall I turn on the television dear?' And Chris would say, 'I don't know, mother. It's up to you.' And she would say, 'No, it's up to you dear.' And he would say, 'No, it's up to you.' And it would go on like that. It was funny in an excruciating sort of way." Hampton adds: "It's less of a problem now, but deciding which shoes to wear can still be a burden." His detachment from the world, where the literary figures that populate his imagination seem more tangible than the mortals before his eyes, can also be a barrier: "He is very much a person of boundaries," says his wife, Laura. "He has very strong boundaries and I think that people are initially loath to cross them. But then they realise what a very, very warm person he is. I think it's a writer's thing, this remoteness. That is my only problem with him. He is very remote." It is a character trait of which Hampton is aware: "I do feel that kind of distance. Just because, from Suez on, my childhood was characterised by a certain amount of ups and downs, it doesn't surprise me that life has continued in that manner. I view things with a certain equanimity." One Hollywood producer asked him to adapt Marlowe's Edward II, only to have the script flung back in his face with the comment: "You wouldn't even get this damn thing on TV." Though the diversion into film would prove unproductive in the short term (Carrington, which one producer's wife described to Hampton as a film "about a lot of pissy English people" took almost 20 years to reach the screen), events in Los Angeles did provide the material for Tales from Hollywood. The play traces the adventures of a group of displaced European wartime exiles in Hollywood, including Brecht, Heinrich and Thomas Mann. Produced at the National Theatre in 1980, it was a popular success and reviewed more favourably than any of his plays since The Philanthropist. However, Hampton's greatest critical triumph was still to come. For some years, Ramsay had been nagging him to write an adaptation of Les Liaisons Dangereuses, Choderlos de Laclos's story of love and savagery. However, the National was reluctant to tackle an 18th-century epistolary novel, assuming it would be box-office poison. "I thought that it was impossible," says Howard Davies, who directed the play. "His response was, 'Well, fuck you', which seemed to goad him into action. It was such a negative spur. He delivered the script and it captivated me immediately... It was so simple and cruel, and so shocking." The resulting production, in 1984, with Alan Rickman as Valmont and Lesley Duncan as Merteuil, was an international sensation, winning a clutch of awards and transferring to Broadway. The film adaptation, directed by Stephen Frears and released in 1988, was nominated for seven Academy awards and won three, including one for Hampton's screenplay. In many ways, this success has somewhat derailed his career: "I then thought that [making films] might get easier. For the first time I was bombarded with offers. But it didn't [get easier] and I didn't get a film made for five more years." However, while his bottom drawer bulges with imminent scripts (16 at last count, including the current Tulip Fever) his passion for film has opened up a new career path. When director Mike Newell dropped out of Carrington, Hampton was persuaded to take over: "He loved it so much," says Emma Thompson, who played the lead role. "You mustn't discount the fact that Chris has his own magnetism. His quietness and tolerance brought us all towards him. It was all quite hassle-free, which is unusual for a first-time director." The film earned Hampton a special jury prize at the Cannes film festival in 1995. Only one new Hampton play has been produced in the theatre since Les Liaisons Dangereuses, the autobiographical White Chameleon in 1991. But his work has reached the public through translations such as Art. "I miss him," says David Hare. "We lost Christopher to the cinema, and only to get him through the voice of Yasmina Reza is a great deprivation. I find it very strange, his role as the amanuensis for a playwright who isn't one tenth as good as he is." Hampton, in his defence, pleads his overriding love of cinema, ignited in the tiny movie theatres of Alexandria and then nourished at the Lancing European film club. His willingness to put his talents at the service of others he puts down to his very European aspiration to be a "working playwright", of which Molière was probably the greatest example. But projects on the horizon promise a Hampton renaissance. With Tales from Hollywood at the Donmar Warehouse, he will have three productions on London stages, (albeit two via translations). His adaptation of The Quiet American, directed by Phillip Noyce, is being filmed in Vietnam, and a new original play dealing with the troubled relationship between Jung and Freud, is pencilled in at the National for the end of the year. "I seem to have turned into something of a workaholic," he says, recalling his youthful ambition to be the West End's oldest playwright. "When I was younger, Peggy Ramsay used to ring me up at eight o' clock in the morning warning me to get out of bed and work. She thought I was very idle. Now I have to force myself to stop." Life at a glance: Christopher James Hampton Born: January 26 1948, Azores Education: Reigate Prep School 1956-59, Lancing College 1959-63, Oxford 1964-68. Married: Laura d'Holesch 1971; two daughters, Alice and Mary. Plays: When Did You Last See My Mother? 1966, Total Eclipse 1968, The Philanthropist 1970, Savages 1973, Treats 1976, Tales From Hollywood 1982, Les Liaisons Dangereuses 1985, White Chameleon 1991. Some films and TV: The Quiet American 2001, Carrington 1995, Tales from Hollywood 1992, Dangerous Liaisons 1988, The Good Father, 1987, Hotel du Lac 1986, The Honorary Consul, 1983, The History Man, 1981. Some awards: For Tales From Hollywood, Evening Standard best comedy award, 1982; for Les Liaisons Dangereuses, London Theatre Critics best play award 1985, Laurence Olivier play of the year award,1986, Evening Standard award 1986, New York Critics Circle best foreign play 1987; for Dangerous Liaisons, Oscar for best screenplay adapted from another medium, 1989.

webTitle: This week's theme: How it's hanging at Tate Modern

fields.headline: This week's theme: How it's hanging at Tate Modern
fields.trailText: Justin Cartwright's diary
fields.body:
'The director of Tate Modern, Lars Nittve, discusses his choice of highlights from the collection with Tim Marlow, editor of Tate: The Art Magazine." For a pound, it seemed good value: a quick canter around the best displays, discussed by two experts on a sophisticated audio player. The Shock of the New by Robert Hughes long ago convinced me that where modern art is concerned, I require context.

On my first visit to Tate Modern a year ago, I found myself overwhelmed, first by the huge and wonderful space and second by the bewildering way the contents are displayed. This is, in artspeak, "the hang". The idea is that you wander from gallery to gallery and look at works of art connected in a way determined by the directors. So you get Richard Long and Claude Monet in the same room. You are supposed to make a connection between Long's slate and Monet's water lilies. Both are natural objects, and both have some red in them. I think this is the rationale, but to be frank, I couldn't care less.

So on my second visit this week, it seemed a good idea to listen to the experts as a means of getting my artistic bearings. Mark Rothko is in the gallery on level 3 west, entitled Landscape/Matter/ Environment. You might think that this covers almost every known form of creation, but you would not have made allowances for the sententious language of art galleries. Nittve thinks that the Rothkos are very glamorous, colourful, restful and beautifully displayed. And? And that's about it.

Salvador Dali's Lobster Telephone, 1936, on level 3 east (Still Life/Object/Real Life), suggests to him that there is more to Dali than he once thought. The art establishment has turned against Dali, but Nittve can perceive some virtues in his technique. No mention of Dali's playfulness or perversity. As for Piet Mondrian, Composition B with Red, 1935, level 5 west, History/Memory/Society, Nittve thinks they are very sexual. Apparently Mondrian loved to talk about sex.

I will spare you the other 16 highlights. I once saw a film about Mondrian which suggested that his painting had something to do with the patterns of tulip fields. I was puzzled. A few minutes' research at the London Library told me that Mondrian was interested in the triumph of science and theosophy. No mention of tulips or sex.

He believed, as the theosophists did, that evolution would lead to an ultimate revelation, which would balance opposing forms. He tried to explore this idea in his painting. He said: "The totality of the picture surface has become the picture's very image; we are not looking at imagery within a picture, but rather viewing the entire surface itself, as imagery."

When Mondrian began to paint, before the first world war, the landscape of society was very different. Abstract painting had a context far removed from the Upper East Side, or Tate Modern. It was a serious, if opaque, attempt to come to terms with the emerging world. Rothko wanted to develop abstractionism, to include elements of surrealism, the sublime and the primitive, in keeping with the vastness of the west and the realisation that Native American art was peculiarly American.

It is true, of course, that even people who love abstract painting find it hard to discuss its meaning. It does not yield to naturalistic assumptions; indeed Rothko denied that there was any particular visual experience in his painting. But for all that, it is illuminating to know what ideas link or divide groups and movements of artists, what the historical context was and what developments took place in artist's careers and perceptions.

The way Tate Modern is hung, none of this is possible. Instead you have to follow the thin and patronising themes decided for you. I was suddenly reminded of the sneering comparisons made at the time between Tate Modern and the Dome.

I went to see Simon Gray's play, Japes, as it was nearing the end of its run. It is a story about two brothers, one a charming drunk, without whom the hero and his wife cannot live. It is at times harrowing and often very funny. As the reviewers have said, the acting from Toby Stephens, Jasper Britton and Clare Swinburne is sensational. But the Theatre Royal was less than half full. I wondered if foot and mouth was keeping away Americans or whether the bleakness of the play was the reason. Plays don't come much darker.

Don't read on if you plan to go. Mikey, a writer, betrays his own brother, Japes, by stifling his own literary career. But Japes in turn betrays his brother by sleeping with his wife Anita and probably fathering their daughter.

This is a ménage à trois so destructive that Gray finishes it off with a double suicide, which unfortunately causes the play to destruct in sympathy. But what he captures so well is the false relations between brothers: the unspoken rivalries, the hidden slights, the half- forgotten incidents, sudden resentments and, above all, the question of success.

Brothers have constantly to evaluate themselves against each other. It's a familiar theme, particularly in America, where Philip Roth's Zuckerman brothers are masters of the art of brotherly treachery, and where countless films and novels pose the question of which brother possesses the heroic human qualities.

Yet in real life, brothers are obliged to maintain a cheery camaraderie. They are always reminding themselves of the golden moments of brotherhood - past, of course. If we are to believe Christina Rossetti, sisters are different: "There is no friend like a sister, in calm or stormy weather." I have never had a sister, so I am prepared to believe it.

Welcome Msomi's wonderful Zulu Macbeth returns to the Globe. In Johannesburg five years ago, I went to the opening night. Traditional Zulus were regarded with suspicion by the urbanites - it was the height of the ANC-Inkatha battles - and the sight of 150 Zulus in full tribal dress on their way to the theatre summoned the spectre of Rorke's Drift. That is, until it was explained that beneath the ostrich feathers and cowhide shields were 150 thesps. Panic over.

fields.headline: Robert Moon
fields.standfirst: Post office employee who thought up the idea of postcodes and unleashed a blizzard of junk mail
fields.trailText: Post office employee who thought up the idea of postcodes and unleashed a blizzard of junk mail.
fields.body:
If there was ever a good intention on the road to Hell, it was that of Robert Moon, who has died at the age of 83. His laudable aim, in which he succeeded brilliantly, was to speed the delivery of America's mail. But his deceptively simple scheme rapidly turned the demographic world on its head, brought unheard-of refinement to social discrimination, and unleashed an ever-growing mountain of junk mail. Moon was the man who invented the nationwide postal code.

For the first 50 years of the 20th century, Americans used the post mainly for social letters, carried across the country on 10,000 mail trains and sorted in transit. By the late 1950s, however, two simultaneous developments were bringing the system to its knees. The railways were in precipitate decline, and equipment had been invented which enabled businesses to generate personalised mass mailings. Suddenly millions of pension cheques, electricity bills and mortgage payments arrived by post. By the early 1960s they accounted for 80% of the traffic.

In 1962, President Kennedy appointed an advisory board to cope with what was rapidly turning into a crisis, and Robert Moon was at last able to ride his hobby horse.

At the time, he was a postal inspector in Philadelphia and had been tinkering with various distribution schemes for 20 years. There were already rudimentary post codes in major cities around the world, of course, and Moon had unsuccessfully offered two improved versions to the US postal authorities. However, his final version was grabbed by the advisory board and put into operation on July 1 1963.

His Zoning Improvement Plan was wonderfully simple and organisationally brilliant. The entire United States was broken into 10 zones, starting from 0 on the eastern coast to 9 on the western. To that first digit was added a second for the regional sorting centre, a third for the sectional sub-division, and so on. By the time the Zip code had reached five digits it could define almost any address to within a few city blocks.

It took a while for the public to accept this addition to its addresses, but the scheme hit the marketing world like a bombshell. Detailed census information released by the government could isolate a maximum of 424 households in any given area. Some genius quickly realised that marrying this census material to the areas defined by the Zip code could offer an extraordinarily detailed profile of the population.

Anyone wanting to send material to, say, college-educated whites with above-average incomes, suddenly had a much more precise tool. Rather more sinisterly, insurance companies had been handed a mechanism to "redline" specific high-risk areas (usually poor and black) and to load their premiums accordingly.

The runaway success of Moon's scheme, which allowed each of thousands of machines to sort more than 500 letters a minute, brought widespread imitation around the world. Hard behind, naturally, came the marketeers to ensure that millions more doormats could be littered with unsolicited mail.

America's addition of four further digits has enabled its modern Zip codes to define an address down to a specific building, and it is now possible to classify any postal area according to 62 separate criteria - ethnic composition, median income, mobility, education, spending patterns, and on and on.

None of this was ever, of course, envisaged by poor Moon, who was just trying to do his best by his employers. As a youth, he had won a university scholarship, but could find no work to support him away from home.

Instead, he became a postman in his home town and progressed through the service for the rest of his career. If the marketing industry had any soul it would raise a gold-plated statue to the man who inadvertently gave it the keys to the kingdom.

 Robert Aurand Moon, postal worker, born April 15 1917; died April 10 2001

fields.headline: Willie Stargell
fields.standfirst: The big-hitting baseball star who led the Pittsburgh Pirates during their glory days
fields.trailText: The big-hitting baseball star who led the Pittsburgh Pirates during their glory days.
fields.body:
Baseball star Willie Stargell, who has died aged 61, was the first player to hit a ball out of Dodger Stadium, and did it twice. Stargell, who played for the Pittsburgh Pirates, was also one of only 17 players in baseball history to play more than 20 seasons with the same team.

The term patriarch may seem inappropriate for a sportsman, but the player they called "Pops" was indeed the pater familias of the Pirates organisation, and a positive symbol for the gritty city of Pittsburgh.

He will always be associated with the Pirates' glory days at Three Rivers Stadium, when they won World Series championships in 1971 and 1979.

The image of Stargell, ringed cap balanced precariously atop his bushy afro, bulging out of his doubleknit orange and black Pirates' kit, is for many as enduring as any of the disco era. Stargell chose Sister Sledge's hit We Are Family as the theme song of the 1979 Pirates team, and, as the family's head, 39 years old and limping on chronically sore knees, he led them to the championship.

Pittsburgh were three-one down to the Baltimore Orioles in the best-of-seven World Series, then rallied to win the final three games in a row. Stargell's home run in the decisive seventh game clinched the victory. He had clubbed all three of the Pirates' homers in the Series, and was named the Most Valuable Player, making him the only player in baseball history to win MVP honours for the season, league playoffs and World Series in the same year.

It was a late pinnacle in a career which began when Stargell, born and raised in Oklahoma, was signed by the Pirates as a teenager straight out of junior college in 1959. While playing in the minor leagues in Texas, he was threatened with a gun by racists outside a ballpark, an incident which he later said helped him develop tolerance. "I had an education, being a ballplayer, anyone would envy," he said. "Rubbing shoulders with good folks I learned it all boils down to how you treat people."

When he joined the Pirates in 1962, he became the protege of Roberto Clemente, the Puerto Rican star who was the undisputed team leader. "The things he taught me about the game, and about being a man, were a big part of my life," Stargell later remembered. Together they took Pittsburgh to the 1971 World Series title, with Stargell, then a lanky outfielder, hitting a league-best 48 home runs. When Clemente was killed in a plane crash in December 1972, while delivering relief supplies to victims of an earthquake in Nicaragua, Stargell took over the role of team leader, even rewarding his team mates' play with gold stars for their caps.

He was renowned for the enjoyment he took from the game. "The umpire says 'play ball', he doesn't say 'work ball'," was a favourite Stargell phrase. He hit 475 home runs, and drove in 1,450; at his peak he was as dominant as any player of the era. He was a power swinger, who struck out 1,936 times, second only to Reggie Jackson, but when he connected, his power was awesome. Stargell would approach the plate twirling his bat like it was a baton, inspiring fear in pitchers. "He doesn't just hit pitchers," said the Dodgers' Don Sutton, "he takes away their dignity."

He may have acquired the nickname "Pops" for his resemblance to the singer Pops Staples or simply because he was a father figure who held the Pirates' team together. After his retirement in 1982, drug problems and dissension tore the team apart. The Pirates haven't won a World Series since. "He was our crutch," said former team mate Bill Robinson. "Any problems you had, he took the burden."

Stargell is survived by his wife Margaret, four daughters and a son.
