webTitle: Words that should be banned: G-string

fields.headline: G-string
fields.trailText: G-string.
fields.body:
It is not our intention to ban words that we could do without if we had to - words like 'proactive', and 'collectibles' and 'like'. This is Orwellianly evil. We aim only to ban words that the world would actively benefit from being without. So let's look to 'G-string', and take as read that we include its male peer, the thong.

The word 'G-string' in no way describes the knicker-like garment (how is it a G? And where's the string?). Likewise, nothing could have prepared Victorian Man for the word 'thong'. The names puff up the cultural importance of the garments, asserting a role so axiomatic in the underwear world that, despite their relative newness, we all have so clear an idea about their shape that we don't need names to give us any clues.

Banning the words, therefore, would substantially diminish the status of the pants, and society would resort to the 'items roughly based on the knicker' template, yet with the following design faults:

1) Going right up crack.

2) Accentuating all that appals about the average arse.

3) Top bit always poking over trousers.

This, of course, would be abbreviated to 'knicker-based items with design faults', alerting everyone to the wrongheadedness of wearing them. And Bach's Air On A G-String would no longer cause sniggers, and resume its rightful place in the classical canon.

We aim only to ban words that the world would actively benefit from being without. So let's look to 'G-string', and take as read that we include its male peer, the thong. The word 'G-string' in no way describes the knicker-like garment (how is it a G? And where's the string?). Likewise, nothing could have prepared Victorian Man for the word 'thong'. The names puff up the cultural importance of the garments, asserting a role so axiomatic in the underwear world that, despite their relative newness, we all have so clear an idea about their shape that we don't need names to give us any clues. Banning the words, therefore, would substantially diminish the status of the pants, and society would resort to the 'items roughly based on the knicker' template, yet with the following design faults: 1) Going right up crack. 2) Accentuating all that appals about the average arse. 3) Top bit always poking over trousers. This, of course, would be abbreviated to 'knicker-based items with design faults', alerting everyone to the wrongheadedness of wearing them. And Bach's Air On A G-String would no longer cause sniggers, and resume its rightful place in the classical canon.

webTitle: Julie Burchill: From  pillock  to post

fields.headline: From  pillock  to post
fields.standfirst: Talk to Julie Burchill live online here on Monday 23rd April, 2.30pm
fields.trailText: One of the great things about being 41 as opposed to 14 is that you don't spend your life in a constant sweat about how scary sex and men are.
fields.body:
I've always received kinky letters from people, ever since I was sweet 17 and first had my face printed in the papers - but as my dear departed gran once said when a man on the phone asked for Lana Turner, "Mister, dost thee have the wrong number or summat!" Whatever the gene is for being shocked and alarmed by the warped desires of strangers, it was certainly left out on the day the angels got together and decided to create a dream come true - ie, me.

The last lot of serious mash notes sent to me, were, apparently, so chronically deviant and upsetting that for ages they were kept from me by my kind protectors at this newspaper, and then, when the writer of them made an appearance at the front desk demanding to see me, the police were called. The police! For little me! I was brought up to believe that bothering the police was as shameful as calling the Samaritans - look, I'm not saying this is a good thing, I'm just presenting it as an interesting sociological snippet vis-à-vis working-class life in the latter part of the 20th century - so I was quite upset. "Oooh, what a waste of their time! Oooh,I'll be in trouble!"

But my confusion turned to outright alarm when it was suggested that I get in touch with my local police station, which, as luck would have it, is in the same street as me. "Come now, they can't be that bad!" I chaffed the young person at the Guardian. Then inspiration struck: "Why don't you send them to me?" I wheedled, "and then I might be more scared - and I might feel I had to go to the police..."

"Well... they're really scary... I don't know..."

"Come on, I'm 41 years of age. I've been married twice - once to Tony Parsons! What fresh hell could exist after such dark knowledge? Bring it on!"

Well, as you can imagine, I was like a kiddie at Christmas the next day, eyes full of hope looking out the window for the postie. Finally, I took receipt of my bounty and, over a cup of tea and a nice plate of biccies, I stepped into the Salo-type netherworld that my warped admirer had planned for me. Suffice to say that not one thing was strong enough to make me choke on my Garibaldi, and after 10 minutes I was looking for the TV remote to see if Bergerac was on UK Gold. Frankly, there was nastier stuff than this in the first 50 pages of my novel, Ambition.

This emergency over, the unkindness of strangers struck again when, in the first week of March, a stupid medium wrote to me telling me that I would meet my death on the 23rd. Apparently, I was going to die from head injuries, in a children's playground, and there would be a dog nearby. When I waved this letter gaily at my boyfriend, telling him that on the afternoon of the 23rd I planned to borrow my friend Nadia's barker and go on a long promenade through the foremost playgrounds and under the dodgiest scaffolding in Brighton, for some reason he took a) exception, b) the day off work and c) my front door keys. But, left to my own devices, I would have done it - and I would have lived.

It's because of my own lack of nervousness, I suppose, that I felt quite disappointed last week to read that ladies of the stature of Diana Rigg, Joan Bakewell, Sue MacGregor and Honor Blackman had contacted the police over a series of smutty letters from a man who turns out to be, get this, in his 70s. The language used was described by police as "pornographic, obscene and disgusting", and there has been much talk in the papers of the "trauma" and "blighted lives" of the recipients.

So, basically, after 25 years of frustration, the old perv has finally got what he wanted all along: to feel like a big strong man who scared the hell out of a bunch of famous broads. Doh! I've always believed that one of the great things about being 41 as opposed to 14 is that you don't spend your life in a constant sweat about how scary sex and men are. I honestly don't think I could be shocked now if I tried, and I like the feeling, because I never was the dewy, ingénue type.

I've never done it myself - frankly, I think I must have masturbated so much between the ages of 12 and 15 that I actually wore something away, because the pastime holds no allure whatsoever for me any more - but I've always thought that one of the most original and, yes, empowering things a woman could do would be to take mash letters sent to her with the aim of frightening, and use them as porn for her own ends, even circulating it among her friends! That would be SO MUCH what the writer didn't want - he wanted to scare a woman to death with his letters, and now there's a bunch of babes all over Maida Vale knocking one off over them.

Talk about subversion.

When Germaine Greer said some years back that rape wasn't the worst thing that could happen to a woman - as I recall, she said that this attitude "gives that pathetic little piece of gristle far too much importance and power" - I and the rest of the sisters were on her case before you could say "knob". But I think I see what she meant now. It's good that women feel far freer to report sexual harassment of any sort to the powers that be than they used to. At the same time, we must be careful not to care too much about what men say - or write - as this gives sexual threats exactly the power that the men who use them want them to have. A woman who laughs at a flasher makes him feel a fool; one who screams and runs away makes his day. If feminism is about anything, it is about not giving men what they want, when they want.

So smile - and it'll never happen.

webTitle: Alexander Chancellor: Silence  for the lambs

fields.headline: Silence  for the lambs
fields.trailText: Animal Aid's only response to the foot-and-mouth crisis has been to promote vegetarianism, which is hardly an emotional reaction to dramatic events.
fields.body:
Responding to the government's exhortations not to flee abroad for Easter, but to treat the British countryside as if it were still "open for business" (whatever that may mean), I spent the Easter holiday in Northamptonshire in a house near a field teeming with sheep and newborn lambs. These particular lambs may be permitted to live long enough to provide some families their Sunday roasts. For until Easter, at any rate, there had been only one case of foot-and-mouth in the county, and it is far enough away to stop them having to be massacred.

Another ghastly fate that they have been spared was illustrated on Good Friday on the front pages of the Daily Telegraph and the Daily Mail. Both papers carried the same photograph of a newborn lamb floundering in a quagmire of mud on a Norfolk farm. It would be dead by Easter, they predicted, because its owner was prevented by foot-and-mouth restrictions from moving it to a safe place. Thousands of lambs throughout the country were facing the same slow death, the Daily Mail said.

The paper had done some historical and literary research to underline the poignancy of this situation. "The lamb is an eternal symbol of rebirth, hope, optimism and a new beginning," its reporter explained. "It features in nursery rhymes and holy writings, and the image of the gambolling lamb is deeply embedded in our national consciousness. That such scenes as this are occurring all over Britain on Good Friday is a terrible irony."

Another "terrible irony" is how little Britain's animal-rights activists seem to care about the mass slaughter of livestock, although they routinely resort to acts of violence in their defence of the right of foxes not to be hunted and of rats not to be used for medical research. Last weekend, there were almost two million farm animals on death row, waiting for their sentences to be carried out, but hardly an animal-rights demonstrator in sight.

Last week's New Statesman carried an article about the "eerie silence" of Britain's pro-animal movement in the face of this animal holocaust.

For once, it pointed out, "the consciousness of the masses seems higher than that of the supposed revolutionary vanguard". But why? The explanations garnered by the New Statesman included a claim that the activists are in cahoots with the government over the hunting bill, and don't want to rock the boat at the moment by protesting against the government's "cull". It was also suggested that "fighting Maff's death squads lacked the class-war appeal of the struggles against toff fox-hunters or capitalist drug companies".

That could well be true; but Animal Aid, Britain's largest animal-rights group, maintains that the real reason for its silence is that the cull involves no more cruelty to farm animals than they get from "greedy" farmers in normal times. In fact, in Animal Aid's view, the cull is almost a merciful release from the ordinary rigours of factory farming and the "terrible things" that go on routinely in abattoirs.

"Four million newborn lambs and one million adult sheep succumb each year to the harsh treatment they endure at the hands of farmers," Animal Aid said in a recent press release. "The farmers' response, oft repeated in industry journals, is to shift the blame on to their victims. 'Sheep have a will to die,' they will say."

Animal Aid's only response to the crisis has been to promote vegetarianism, which may be a good idea in itself but is hardly an emotional reaction to dramatic events. Many members of the public have been so troubled by the cull that they have had to stop watching the news on television, but the activists seem quite relaxed about it.

It is not even as if the cull were being conducted with great humanity. The animals can see each other being slaughtered, a distressing experience that they are spared in abattoirs. And according to the New Statesman, there is plenty of evidence that some animals are being tipped into the burial pits while still alive.

My suspicion about the activists is that they believe less in the capacity of animals to feel emotion than most ordinary people do. Whatever else they are, they are not sentimentalists. I go along with the sentimentalists. I think animals do have feelings. For example, the latest genetic research shows that every fruit fly has as many individual characteristics as every human being, and that fruit flies possess all the necessary preconditions for being depressed and getting Alzheimer's disease, though, admittedly, it is not yet proven that they have done either.

webTitle: How to survive in a lifeboat

fields.headline: How to survive in a lifeboat
fields.trailText: 'You may have to consider drinking your own urine. This is not as bad as it sounds, so long as you dilute it with plenty of water.'
fields.body:
Lifeboats will often have emergency rations. Whoever packs these should be set adrift for a while, because they always contain things such as dog biscuits and processed cheese. What you really need is food that makes you feel better - for instance, a decent coffee and some walnut cake. Of course, you can supplement your food by fishing. You can make a useful fishing line from a safety pin and a piece of piano wire, provided, of course, that you are a punk concert pianist who has those kind of things in your pocket in the first place. You'll probably find it's a good three or four days before you catch a fish, but don't be downhearted - that's about the same success rate as anyone who goes fishing normally.

Thirst is the big killer at sea, and eventually you may have to consider drinking your own urine. This is not as bad as it sounds, so long as you dilute it with plenty of water. Navigating by the stars may be your only option. For city dwellers who have never seen stars, however, this can be a bit tricky. The only useful directional thing that stars tell you is which way is up. Or you might prefer simply to look for the brightest star in the sky and follow it. This will lead you in the general direction of Bethlehem and the Middle East.

Making for land is often a priority. If you've got oars, you can row, but do remember that, when you row, you're actually going backwards. This is important if you're in sight of land and it then disappears after two hours at the oars. Alternatively, you can rig up a sail. A good-sized skirt attached to an oar will keep you moving, and you can get a few extra knots-worth of speed if you also rig up your underpants. It's generally at this point that a cruise ship turns up and you are filmed for the world's media minus your skirt and underpants.

Do be careful about taking off your clothes, because it's very easy to get sunburnt in an open boat. Also, don't cool yourself off in salt water, as this has the same effect as rubbing salt on baked potatoes. Shade is vital, so you should either sit in the shade of your sail, put a handkerchief over your head, or, if things get really unbearable, go below to your cabin.

Mental health can deteriorate almost as quickly as physical health. So you may well have a near-death experience in which you are bathed in bright light and surrounded by helpful and welcoming figures in white. This means either that you have, in fact, died, or that you are being welcomed ashore by the Tahitian coastguard.

fields.headline: 101 things we don't miss
fields.standfirst: People talk a lot about things they yearn for from the past - socialism, the pound note, kindly neighbours, the Beatles. But, says Zoe Williams, until about last year, most things in life were a crime against humanity...
fields.trailText: People talk a lot about things they yearn for from the past - socialism, the pound note, kindly neighbours, the Beatles. But, says Zoe Williams, until about last year, most things in life were a crime against humanity...
fields.body:
1 Arctic Roll
Let's take a perfectly good sponge cake, which could make a perfectly good Swiss roll for everyone to enjoy, and instead cover it in perfectly good ice-cream. That way, we'll wind up with a disgusting mush that erroneously attempts to combine cold and room temperature, wet and dry, spongy and slippery... I mean, really, whose idea was that?

2 Smash
You'd think, wouldn't you, that if you were a pointy-head, and someone asked you to come up with a food substitute - and we're not even stipulating tasty food substitute here - that you'd come up with something a bit more challenging than mashed potato. I mean, if you were to sit there for ages, thinking "what do people like very much, but tend to avoid, due to the onerousness of making it?" you might think, oh, stuffed aubergines, or devils on horseback. You wouldn't think mashed potato. Honestly, if it weren't for the dudeish robots that sang in the adverts, someone could justifiably have burnt this company down.

3 The nit nurse

4 Really hard liquorice
What an odd phenomenon - a sweet so hard that it's closer to an industrial substance. Let us not forget, Swedish liquorice contained salt, so it was even worse than the English version.

5 Pickled eggs
In Wales, where pickled eggs are still a foodstuff of choice, they buy them with a bag of prawn cocktail crisps, then they scrunch the egg up in the crisps and eat the offending egg with a carapace of crisp around it, for flavour. If that doesn't say all there is to say about how noxious the things are, I can't think what does.

6 Wine in a box
Well, we say this is a thing of the past, but in fact many people still drink wine in a box, in order to have a silver pillow left over to sleep on when they are finished. These people are derelicts. Not that there's anything wrong with being a derelict.

7 Semolina with a blob of strawberry jam
A pudding so rank that only the English palate could have come up with it, and furthermore, any outsider who had a heart would have stepped in and banned it. Ach, if you've asked it once, you've asked it a million times. Where are the French when you need them?

8 Dream Topping
It's actually quite hard to create a foodstuff with no nutrients in whatsoever. You wouldn't think it, to taste this stuff.

9 Whale meat
Did we ever eat this? Were we informed of it, at the time? What was wrong with all the normal meat? You know, the past really is a foreign country.

10 Thunderbird Peach Wine
I refer you to wine in a box, above - there is nothing wrong with being a derelict. However, manufacturing wine specifically for derelicts, and then giving it girl-type flavours that will attract adolescent girls, and then making it the most disgusting drink ever, which could conceivably put them off alcohol for life. Well, that... that's just evil.

11 Port and lemon

12 Compulsory religious education
There's nothing wrong with Christianity, no, nor Islam, nor Judaism neither. But inculcating tolerance and understanding into young minds was never what these lessons were about. They were devised perniciously to prepare us for undreamt-of boredom, in order that we might go out into our adult lives ready for any level of tedium that the workplace might throw at us. It actually worked quite well, if you think about it.

13 School medicals
School nurses holding your testicles and asking you to cough, although actually this never really happened. In fact, it only ever occurred in a Carry On film.

14 Corporal punishment

15 Blue gym knickers
These, on the other hand, were absolutely essential to the school experience. How else would you realise how much larger your arse was than all your friends'?

16 School blancmange

17 Duffel coats
Did your mum at any stage chase you down the road, waving your duffel coat and shouting "put this on"? Mine did - most of them seem to have done, at some stage. What was this, exercise? Pilates for the baby-boom generation? Or was the duffel coat believed to have some kind of health-giving effect?

18 Snoods
Ew. We thought we looked so stylish.

19 Socks with toes in them
This must say something profound about the 70s zeitgeist, that it was considered amusing to make little glovelets of the sock. Not sure what.

20 Very short football shorts
Many people, especially those who work in advertising, cherish the fantasy that women love to look at men with very short shorts. They think we like it, even when the man in question has an arse so ill-defined that it's almost impossible to tell how his legs connect to the rest of his body. They think we find it saucy, comic and endearing. We don't, you know.

21 Knee-high socks
Conversely, these do have a certain comic appeal. But socks and comedy should never meet (see, socks with toes, above).

22 Nylon underwear
I don't want to get too personal here, but did our forebears actively want thrush?

23 Prog rock
Some would counter that prog rock is still with us, in the form of Radiohead. However, Radiohead generally include on each album a song or two that girls will listen to. True prog rock only appeals to maladjusted males. That's why it has died out, incidentally - because its target audience is now on the internet the whole time, learning how to make bombs.

24 Mr Blobby

25 Hand-me-downs from your older siblings
Have you noticed how people tend to have only one child nowadays, despite the well-documented benefits of siblings to a tot's socialisation and learning? That's because they all remember the astonishing sartorial injustice meted out to second, not to mention third children. In 20 years' time, when all these only-children have grown up, phrases like "Uergh, look at your disgusting velour top" will have virtually no meaning.

26 Skinheads
An eyesore to everyone involved. Handy for Nazi phrenologists, though.

27 Skinny ties with keyboards on them

28 Herbal ecstasy
A completely effectless substance devised for people who urgently wanted to get off their heads, but were so concerned with legality and the state of their insides that they were prepared not to. More to the point, they were prepared to pay a substantial amount not to, and instead just swallow a pellet of grime, and grin for half an hour. What a swizz.

29 Micro scooters
They haven't strictly died out yet, but I believe it's only a matter of days. They're just silly.

30 Badges
I distinctly remember getting on a bus the morning after the 1992 election, to find someone wearing a badge saying "Don't blame me - I voted Labour". And I didn't blame him, I felt a pleasing shiver of ideological fellowship with him, even though I hadn't actually voted at all, because I couldn't be arsed. I blamed him for the bloody badge, though. Ridiculous things.

31 Dusty Bin

32 The Word
There's always a section of society that quite literally cannot believe how unremittingly dim young people are nowadays. Usually, it's the over-60s. For a while, though, as a direct result of this Channel Four television programme, all of us, young and old, were in perfect harmony on the matter.

33 Sanitary towels and their companion sanitary belts
These are always good to remember when you're reading Virginia Woolf, or Iris Murdoch, or Lynne Reid Banks, or Rosamond Lehmann, or any beazel at all pre-1990, and thinking, "Please put a lid on it, it's not actually that bad." It was that bad, it really was.

34 Catweazle

35 Indoor fireworks
Yes, someone missed the point again, didn't they? Fireworks are supposed to be dangerous. That's why children like them. That's why the whole ceremony - which, let's face it, commemorates a religious squabble which nobody can remember, and involves no presents at all - is still current among children, and has not been replaced by National PlayStation Day. Indoor fireworks are like sugar-free easter eggs.

36 Tails of hair on the back of your head

37 Mini Milks
What a sorry excuse for an ice cream, this was. No chocolate, no strawberry, no nuts, no creaminess, no surprises, no chewy centre, no nothing. As a treat, these were about on the same level of cruelty as the mums who made out that when ice-cream vans make that musical noise, it means they're empty.

38 Roland Rat

39 The Krankies
Whenever people try to convey the icy evil of the Victorian age, the freak show is always right up there with the seven-year-old chimney sweep and the starving, almost-dead person. So what exactly were we playing at, with this pair?

40 BBC presenters speaking with received pronunciation
Clearly, it's a sorry kind of country that can't celebrate the diversity of its proud regions by letting them do their voices on the telly. Worse, though, was the fact that received pronunciation tends to sound a little judgmental, a wee bit puritanical, just a smidgen anti-mess, anti-sex, anti-high-fat-foodstuffs, anti-life. And when you're not used to telly, and you still think the people in that little box can see out, imagine how much that messes with your head. Why, people used to have to spring clean before they turned the news on.

41 Monkey
The closest I ever came to adolescent despair, before becoming an adolescent, was turning on the telly to find only Monkey. It was the worst programme this civilisation has ever seen.

42 My Little Pony
It's true, all girls do want a pony. They also all want to be air-hostesses, but do you buy them a purple plastic air-hostess, and encourage them to brush its pink synthetic hair? Of course not, you tell them to pull themselves together and think of a proper job.

43 Stylophones
The first pop use of these crappy sounding hand-held synthesisers was on Space Oddity by David Bowie. A good omen, you might think. Not a bad toy, you might think. Then you take into account that their big-name endorser was Rolf Harris, and you realise just how rubbish and shoddy they were.

44 Rubik's cube
The only people who could ever complete these were the ones who took them apart with a screwdriver and put them back together again. Anyone who tells you any different is lying.

45 Tamagotchis
I believe the idea is this: you give your child, or whoever it is in your household petitioning for a pet, a small electronic device. The device makes noises to indicate that it wants food, exercise or affection, and you press buttons to oblige. Thus, in all respects it resembles a pet, apart from being fluffy, cute, loyal, buoyant or a thing of joy to hold and keep forever.

46 The Barron Knights
The only pop group who managed to be middle-aged before they were 20 and misspell a word as simple as "Baron". They're still going, by the way, on the Butlins circuit. So not missing them is largely a hypothetical concept - after all, we don't know how little we'll miss them when they're really gone.

47 Chas & Dave and other cockney rock
Like socks, music should never have a comic agenda. Therefore, even working on the charitable premise that cockney accents are as funny as Chas & Dave thought they were, the pair still should have been chased from the planet by dogs. Dennis Waterman, however, can do whatever he likes. He's a poppet.

48 The national anthem played at the theatre
More than one million painful student fringe shows, more than one rubbish adaptation too many of Thérèse Raquin, more than mime, Two Gentlemen Of Verona, and seven-hour productions by Polish people speaking in Polish, this simple ritual put the nation off going to the theatre. It managed to convey, with such ease and simplicity, the fact that everyone else there would be a freak in a cummerbund who wanted to bring back hanging.

49 House coats
They're all very well in films, as open invitations to passing trades-men to have a crack at having sex with you, but in real life they make you look like a dinner lady.

50 Swing-Ball
A pitiful excuse for a game, purchased by parents who are simply too idle to take you to the park, play any kind of game with you, or even engage you in simple conversation to relieve your boredom. In a Swing-Ball- owning household, the question: "Why did you bother having me at all?" is not part of the adolescent rebellion phase at all, it's a perfectly reasonable enquiry.

51 Deely-Boppers
On the other hand, if your children insisted on wearing ridiculous bits of plastic which "boinged", would you want to talk to them or play any kind of game with them? I know I wouldn't.

52 Clackers
These were invented as a means of making a horribly loud noise - hence the name - but children soon found that they could make a horribly loud noise in the mornings, and in the afternoons inflict very real and potentially fatal injuries upon one another, using the same simple toy. Brilliant!

53 Artexing
This was invented as a means of making a normal-looking house look grotesque, and adults soon found that if their neighbours opposite were going to have a grotesque house, then they damn well didn't see why they shouldn't have one, too. Which makes a curious kind of sense, since it isn't your own house you have to look at.

54 Stencilling a border
Will people never learn?

55 Cork wall tiles

56 Musical doorbells
When you ring someone's doorbell and there's a tune on it, you know all of the following: 1) The tonic will be flat, and you will not be given enough to drink, however eagerly you approach even the flattest, most unpleasant drink; 2) The cooking will be shocking, up to and including the use of garlic powder; 3) You will be forced to go for a walk after lunch, when all you really want to do is go home. Those aren't the messages you want to give out now, are they?

57 Serving hatches
Yes, we all wanted to be Margot from The Good Life for about five minutes, and then we got over it.

58 Tupperware parties
It's terrible, isn't it - on the one hand, you had all these women campaigning for total gender parity with all their hearts and minds. And on the other hand, you had other women meeting up to drink tea and talk about plastic boxes, with a mind to making the wisest possible purchase for all their storage needs. Which made it difficult to take the first lot seriously, didn't it?

59 Breville snack and sandwich maker
Actually, I tell a lie, I think these are fantastic. I rue the day I left home without stealing my mum's.

60 Tin baths

61 Izal toilet paper
Was it really cheaper, the shiny, scratchy stuff that could actually draw blood if you lost concentration for a moment and became over-vigorous? Or was it some kind of tease campaign, to ready us for Andrex, and teach us to greet it with proper delight?

62 The mangle on the twin-tub washing machine

63 Internment
The law of Innocent Until Proven Irish spawned much noble rhetoric and a couple of decent short films. However, it did undo centuries of the fight for justice, which was a bad thing.

64 Breakfast bars
Just because Cher probably has one doesn't make them okay.

65 Mandrax and Dexedrine
I could be wrong here, but whenever people talk about the olden days of drug-taking, they always had to take 16 or 17 of anything before anything happened. And there always seemed to be a lot of sweating involved. Which makes their drugs sound kind of bogus, doesn't it?

66 Electric frying pan
If you haven't got a cooker, don't cook. Go down the chippie. Surely that should be obvious.

67 Circle-dial telephones
These have a certain olde-worlde charm when you see them now, but at the time they were a nuisance - especially when it was an emergency, and you were forced to dial many nines, which, by some quirk of fate, takes the longest. Apart from noughts.

68 Pictures made with pasta

69 Family photos rendered on canvas, with the youngest boy dressed as a sailor
What were people trying to do, commissioning these eerie portraits? Create a mini-Pinter psycho drama of suppurating familial resentments?

70 Amstrads
The only machine capable of giving you a headache in the four-minute window between starting up and breaking down.

71 Gobbing at gigs
Men are always finding new and innovative ways to express their masculinity and assert themselves as alpha members of their gender. This must have been about the least effective.

72 Brut aftershave
This must have been about the second-least effective.

73 Stars On 45
When you look at frights like Hear'Say, you'd be forgiven for thinking that everything associated with popular music is as rotten as it's ever been. You'd be wrong, however, because you would be failing to factor in these monstrous four-minute medleys.

74 Hair mascara

75 Polio
Poor children of the past - all they wanted was a municipal swim, and they came back permanently crippled.

76 Top Of The Pops albums
The producers of these LPs laboured under the misapprehension that children don't really know the cost of things, and don't realise that getting hold of a cover version of a hit is cheaper than the hit itself. On the contrary, most children can recognise the concept "bargain basement" before they can swallow solids, and laughed in the face of these sorry approximations of popular music. Incidentally, as a direct result of the TOTP albums, when the Now That's What I Call Music! albums arrived, people genuinely did say "Now that's what I call music!"

77 Legs & Co
All tits-'n'-teeth-'n'-rubbish dance routines, the Top Of The Pops dancers added even less to your appreciation of pop than the Top Of The Pops albums.

78 David and Elizabeth Emanuel
There's an absolutely unbroken rule in the world of fashion, and it is that the pricier the garment, the more you want it, even if it really isn't your kind of thing at all - and besides, you've already got a pair of dungarees. A rule unbroken, that is, except by David and Elizabeth Emanuel.

79 The Millennium Dome
As bad as it could possibly have been, short of being tested on animals. Never mind. It's all over now.

80 Old licensing laws
What a quaint idea - as long as you stop people drinking between the lunchtime yardarm and, erm, the dinnertime yardarm, they can't be alcoholic and will have to go to a gallery or something in the afternoon. Ha! They hadn't banked on the dazzling ingenuity of man and the existence of off-licences.

81 Green Shield stamps...
... and having to lick whole books of them for your nan

82 Rickets
Since it's caused by a vitamin D deficiency, people used to blame rickets on the fact that it's always rainy in Britain, and there isn't enough sunlight. In fact, it's because they weren't eating enough vegetables, because chips are nicer.

83 Sweet cigarettes
You thought the whole of life was arranged to stop children smoking? Think again! While nice teachers showed us videos of smoke-related amputations all day, naughty shopkeepers taught us the correct manner in which to handle and appreciate a cigarette. Is it any wonder we're confused? They were quite tasty, though.

84 More cigarettes
Unlike these cigarettes, which weren't tasty at all. This was the kind of thing your friend's mother used to smoke, to stop you pinching them.

85 Biros you can rub out
Except you never could rub them out, all you could do was make a large, childish mess on the page. I think this was in the manner of a conspiracy against children. Did you ever see a grown-up using one?

86 The Ford Edsel

87 Letraset

88 The rhythm method
A fun game involving maths, sex and cunning guesswork. A terrible method of contraception.

89 Actors who pretended to sound like Gerry Adams
Yet another wrong-headed Ireland-based law, this time with the knock-on effect of keeping a lot of mediocre actors in work when they would have been better off accepting that they were never going to get proper parts and therefore should re-train.

90 Cars that spoke instructions to you

91 People who object to the word cunt, yet don't object to any other word for either kind of genitals
Get over it. Just because it makes a cute, Anglo-Saxon explosive noise doesn't mean it's any worse than, say, willy.

92 Your mother spitting on your hanky and wiping your face

93 Puberty
Like childbirth, nobody bothers to tell you just how start-to-finish rotten this experience is going to be. Unlike childbirth, you have nothing to show for it at the end, apart from some excess fat or unwanted back hair, depending on your gender.

94 No sex before marriage
Nobody really stuck to this - they just pretended to, for our amusement.

95 Dymo tape
Once upon a time, this was simple playground fun - a small typing machine with which you could fashion short phrases, such as "Zoe Is Cool" or "Leon Is Wicked". That was all very well, apart from taking ages and being the most criminal waste of time since blowing eggs (which, incidentally, we also don't miss).

96 The cones hotline

97 Colonialism
It's amazing, to think of all those endearing little ideas we used to have. Like, "Hang on a second, I can see brown people over there! What on earth do they think they're doing, going about their business in a perfectly reasonable way in their own country? Why, they're not even speaking English. They're just going to get it all wrong, and break things." If only we'd kept them to ourselves, and not done anything about it.

98 Nuclear Power: No Thanks/Nein Danke
It says everything there is to say about the campaign against nuclear power, that they seriously thought a big red sun, grinning like an idiot on a yellow sticker, asking cheerfully for the termination of a multi-billion-pound industry, was going to make any kind of a difference. I mean, really.

99 People talking about punk, as though it were in any way important
Or nice to listen to...

100 Suss laws
Police, eh? Give 'em an inch and they invent new crimes, such as "failing to deodorise properly" or "being foreign". Bless, they were probably just bored.

101 Goldfish won at fairs that die as soon as you get them home. And then you have to flush them down the loo
It's all very well teaching children how to deal with death, but is it a good idea to concertina the whole lesson into a half-hour period between joy and mourning?

I mean, if you were to sit there for ages, thinking "what do people like very much, but tend to avoid, due to the onerousness of making it?" you might think, oh, stuffed aubergines, or devils on horseback. You wouldn't think mashed potato. Honestly, if it weren't for the dudeish robots that sang in the adverts, someone could justifiably have burnt this company down. 3 The nit nurse 4 Really hard liquorice What an odd phenomenon - a sweet so hard that it's closer to an industrial substance. Incidentally, as a direct result of the TOTP albums, when the Now That's What I Call Music! albums arrived, people genuinely did say "Now that's what I call music!" 77 Legs & Co All tits-'n'-teeth-'n'-rubbish dance routines, the Top Of The Pops dancers added even less to your appreciation of pop than the Top Of The Pops albums. 78 David and Elizabeth Emanuel There's an absolutely unbroken rule in the world of fashion, and it is that the pricier the garment, the more you want it, even if it really isn't your kind of thing at all - and besides, you've already got a pair of dungarees. A rule unbroken, that is, except by David and Elizabeth Emanuel. 79 The Millennium Dome As bad as it could possibly have been, short of being tested on animals. Never mind. It's all over now. 80 Old licensing laws What a quaint idea - as long as you stop people drinking between the lunchtime yardarm and, erm, the dinnertime yardarm, they can't be alcoholic and will have to go to a gallery or something in the afternoon. Ha! They hadn't banked on the dazzling ingenuity of man and the existence of off-licences. 81 Green Shield stamps... ... and having to lick whole books of them for your nan 82 Rickets Since it's caused by a vitamin D deficiency, people used to blame rickets on the fact that it's always rainy in Britain, and there isn't enough sunlight. In fact, it's because they weren't eating enough vegetables, because chips are nicer. 83 Sweet cigarettes You thought the whole of life was arranged to stop children smoking? Think again! While nice teachers showed us videos of smoke-related amputations all day, naughty shopkeepers taught us the correct manner in which to handle and appreciate a cigarette. Is it any wonder we're confused? They were quite tasty, though. 84 More cigarettes Unlike these cigarettes, which weren't tasty at all. This was the kind of thing your friend's mother used to smoke, to stop you pinching them. 85 Biros you can rub out Except you never could rub them out, all you could do was make a large, childish mess on the page. I think this was in the manner of a conspiracy against children. Did you ever see a grown-up using one? 86 The Ford Edsel 87 Letraset 88 The rhythm method A fun game involving maths, sex and cunning guesswork. A terrible method of contraception. 89 Actors who pretended to sound like Gerry Adams Yet another wrong-headed Ireland-based law, this time with the knock-on effect of keeping a lot of mediocre actors in work when they would have been better off accepting that they were never going to get proper parts and therefore should re-train. 90 Cars that spoke instructions to you 91 People who object to the word cunt, yet don't object to any other word for either kind of genitals Get over it. Just because it makes a cute, Anglo-Saxon explosive noise doesn't mean it's any worse than, say, willy. 92 Your mother spitting on your hanky and wiping your face 93 Puberty Like childbirth, nobody bothers to tell you just how start-to-finish rotten this experience is going to be. Unlike childbirth, you have nothing to show for it at the end, apart from some excess fat or unwanted back hair, depending on your gender. 94 No sex before marriage Nobody really stuck to this - they just pretended to, for our amusement. 95 Dymo tape Once upon a time, this was simple playground fun - a small typing machine with which you could fashion short phrases, such as "Zoe Is Cool" or "Leon Is Wicked". That was all very well, apart from taking ages and being the most criminal waste of time since blowing eggs (which, incidentally, we also don't miss). 96 The cones hotline 97 Colonialism It's amazing, to think of all those endearing little ideas we used to have. Like, "Hang on a second, I can see brown people over there! What on earth do they think they're doing, going about their business in a perfectly reasonable way in their own country? Why, they're not even speaking English. They're just going to get it all wrong, and break things." If only we'd kept them to ourselves, and not done anything about it. 98 Nuclear Power: No Thanks/Nein Danke It says everything there is to say about the campaign against nuclear power, that they seriously thought a big red sun, grinning like an idiot on a yellow sticker, asking cheerfully for the termination of a multi-billion-pound industry, was going to make any kind of a difference. I mean, really. 99 People talking about punk, as though it were in any way important Or nice to listen to... 100 Suss laws Police, eh? Give 'em an inch and they invent new crimes, such as "failing to deodorise properly" or "being foreign". Bless, they were probably just bored. 101 Goldfish won at fairs that die as soon as you get them home. And then you have to flush them down the loo It's all very well teaching children how to deal with death, but is it a good idea to concertina the whole lesson into a half-hour period between joy and mourning?

webTitle: The Complete Lyrics by Nick Cave

fields.headline: Love is the drug
fields.standfirst: Like most of us, Nick Cave has fallen in love a fair few times. Unlike most, he writes songs about it: sad, angry, violent songs. For the song to be true, he says, it has to recognise the potential for pain behind every love
fields.trailText: Like most of us, Nick Cave has fallen in love a fair few times. Unlike most, he writes songs about it: sad, angry, violent songs. For the song to be true, he says, it has to recognise the potential for pain behind every love
fields.body:
West Country Girl

With a crooked smile and a heart-shaped face
Comes from the West Country where the birds sing bass
She's got a house-big heart where we all live
And plead and counsel and forgive
Her widow's peak, her lips I've kissed
Her gloves of bone at her wrist
That I have held in my hand
Her Spanish fly and her monkey gland
Her godly body and its fourteen stations
That I have embraced, her palpitations
Her unborn baby crying, Mummy
Amongst the rubble of her body
Her lovely lidded eyes I've sipped
Her fingernails, all pink and chipped
Her accent which I'm told is 'broad'
That I have heard and has been poured
Into my human heart and filled me
With love, up to the brim, and killed me
And rebuilt me back anew
With something to look forward to
Well, who could ask much more than that?
A West Country Girl with a big fat cat
That looks into her eyes of green
And meaows, 'He loves you', then meaows again

That was a song called West Country Girl. It is a love song. It began, in its innocence, as a poem written in Australia, where the sun shines. I wrote it with my heart in my mouth, listing the physical details that drew me towards a particular person . . . the West Country Girl. It set forth my own personal criteria of beauty, my own particular truth about beauty, as angular, cruel and impoverished as it probably was. It was a list of things I loved, and, in truth, a wretched excuse in flattery, designed to win the girl. And it worked and it didn't work. But the peculiar magic of the love song, if it has the heart to do it, is that it endures where the object of the song does not. It attaches itself to you, and together you move through time. But it does more than that, for just as it is our task to move forward, to cast off our past, to change and to grow, in short, to forgive ourselves and each other, the love song holds within it an eerie intelligence all its own - to reinvent the past and to lay it at the feet of the present. West Country Girl began in innocence and in sunshine, as a simple poem about a girl. But it has done what all love songs must do in order to survive: it has demanded the right to its own identity, its own life, its own truth. I've seen it grow and mutate with time. It presents itself now as a cautionary tale, as a list of ingredients in a witches' brew, it reads as a coroner's report, or a message on a sandwich-board worn by a wild-eyed man who states, "The end of the world is at hand." It is a hoarse voice in the dark that croaks, "Beware . . . beware . . . beware." Anyway, I'm getting ahead of myself.

People Ain't No Good

People just ain't no good
I think that's well understood
You can see it everywhere you look
People just ain't no good

We were married under cherry trees
Under blossom we made our vows
All the blossoms came sailing down
Through the streets and through the playgrounds

The sun would stream on the sheets
Awoken by the morning bird
We'd buy the Sunday newspapers
And never read a single word

People they ain't no good
People they ain't no good
People they ain't no good

Seasons came, seasons went
The winter stripped the blossoms bare
A different tree now lines the streets
Shaking its fists in the air

The winter slammed us like a fist
The windows rattling in the gales
To which she drew the curtains
Made out of her wedding veils

People they ain't no good
People they ain't no good
People they ain't no good
To our love send a dozen white lilies
To our love send a coffin of wood
To our love let all the pink-eyed pigeons coo
That people they just ain't no good
To our love send back all the letters
To our love a valentine of blood
To our love let all the jilted lovers cry
That people they just ain't no good

It ain't that in their hearts they're bad
They can comfort you, some even try
They nurse you when your ill of health
They bury you when you go and die
It ain't that in their hearts they're bad
They'd stick by you if they could
But that's just bullshit
People just ain't no good

People they just ain't no good
People they just ain't no good
People they just ain't no good
People they just ain't no good

I performed a more conservative, lo-tech version of this essay at the Poetry Academy in Vienna last year. I was invited to actually teach a group of adult students about songwriting. But first they wanted me to give a public lecture. The subject I chose was the love song, and in doing it - I mean, standing up in front of a crowd of people and teaching, lecturing - I was filled with a host of conflicting feelings. The strongest, most insistent of these was one of abject horror. Horror, because my late father was an English literature teacher at the high school I attended back in Australia - you know, where the sun shines. I have very clear memories of being about 12 and sitting in a classroom watching my father, who would be standing, up here, where I am standing, and thinking to myself, gloomily and miserably - for, in the main, I was a gloomy and miserable child - "It doesn't really matter what I do with my life as long as I don't end up like my father." Now, at 41, it would appear there is virtually no action I can take that does not draw me closer to him, that does not make me more like him. At 41, I have become my father, and here I am, ladies and gentlemen, teaching.

Looking back over the past 20 years, a certain clarity prevails. Amidst the madness and the mayhem, it would seem I have been banging on one particular drum. I see that my artistic life has centred around an attempt to articulate an almost palpable sense of loss that laid claim to my life. A great gaping hole was blasted out of my world by the unexpected death of my father when I was 19. The way I learned to fill this hole, this void, was to write. My father taught me this as if to prepare me for his own passing. Writing allowed me direct access to my imagination, to inspiration and, ultimately, to God.

I found that, through the use of language, I was writing God into existence. Language became the blanket that I threw over the invisible man, which gave him shape and form. The actualisation of God through the medium of the love song remains my prime motivation as an artist. I found that language became a poultice to the wounds incurred by the death of my father. Language became a salve to longing.

The loss of my father created in my life a vacuum, a space in which my words began to float and collect and find their purpose. WH Auden said, "the so-called traumatic experience is not an accident, but the opportunity for which the child has been patiently waiting - had it not occurred, it would have found another - in order that its life became a serious matter". The death of my father was this "traumatic experience" that left the hole for God to fill. How beautiful the notion that we create our own personal catastrophes and that it is the creative forces within us that are instrumental in doing this. Here, our creative impulses lie in ambush at the side of our lives, ready to leap forth and kick holes in it - holes through which inspiration can rise. We each have our need to create, and sorrow itself is a creative act.

Though the love song comes in many guises - songs of exaltation and praise, of rage and of despair, erotic songs, songs of abandonment and loss - they all address God, for it is the haunted premise of longing that the true love song inhabits. It is a howl in the void for love and for comfort, and it lives on the lips of the child crying for his mother. It is the song of the lover in need of their loved one, the raving of the lunatic supplicant petitioning his God. It is the cry of one chained to the earth and craving flight, a flight into inspiration and imagination and divinity. The love song is the sound of our endeavours to become God-like, to rise up and above the earth-bound and the mediocre. I believe the love song to be a sad song. It is the noise of sorrow itself.

We all experience within us what the Portuguese call "saudade", an inexplicable longing, an unnamed and enigmatic yearning of the soul, and it is this feeling that lives in the realms of imagination and inspiration, and is the breeding ground for the sad song, for the love song. Saudade is the desire to be transported from darkness into light, to be touched by the hand of that which is not of this world. The love song is the light of God, deep down, blasting up though our wounds.

In his brilliant lecture, The Theory And Function Of Duende, Frederico Garcia Lorca attempts to shed some light on the eerie and inexplicable sadness that lives at the heart of certain works of art. "All that has dark sounds has 'duende'," he says, "that mysterious power that everyone feels but no philosopher can explain." Contemporary rock music seems less inclined to have at its soul, restless and quivering, the sadness that Lorca talks about. Excitement, often, anger, sometimes - but true sadness, rarely. Bob Dylan has always had it. Leonard Cohen deals specifically with it. It pursues Van Morrison like a black dog and, though he tries to, he cannot escape it. Tom Waits and Neil Young can summon it. My friends The Dirty 3 have it by the bucketload. But, all in all, it would appear that the duende is too fragile to survive the compulsive modernity of the music industry. In the hysterical technocracy of modern music, sorrow is sent to the back of the class, where it sits, pissing its pants in mortal terror. Duende, needs space to breathe. Melancholy hates haste and floats in silence. I feel sorry for sadness, as we jump all over it, denying its voice and muscling it into the outer reaches. No wonder sorrow doesn't smile much. No wonder sadness is so sad.

All love songs must contain "duende", because the love song is never simply happy. It must first embrace the potential for pain. Those songs that speak of love, without having within their lines an ache or a sigh, are not love songs at all, but rather hate songs disguised as love songs, and are not to be trusted. These songs deny us our human-ness and our God-given right to be sad, and the airwaves are littered with them. The love song must resonate with the whispers of sorrow and the echoes of grief. The writer who refuses to explore the darker reaches of the heart will never be able to write convincingly about the wonder, magic and joy of love, for just as goodness cannot be trusted unless it has breathed the same air as evil, so within the fabric of the love song, within its melody, its lyric, one must sense an acknowledgement of its capacity for suffering.

Sad Waters

Down the road I look and there runs Mary
Hair of gold and lips like cherries
We go down to the river where the willows weep
Take a naked root for a lovers' seat
That rose out of the bitten soil
But bound to the ground by creeping ivy coils
O Mary you have seduced my soul
(And I don't know right from wrong)
Forever a hostage of your child's world

And then I ran my tin-cup heart along
The prison of her ribs
And with a toss of her curls
That little girl goes waddling in
Rolling her dress up past her knee
Turning these waters into wine
Then she plaited all the willow vines
Mary in the shallows laughing
Over where the carp dart
Spooked by the new shadows that she cast
Across these sad waters and across my heart

Continued

fields.headline: Dear weekend
fields.standfirst: Over  to you
fields.trailText:
I, too, share the goals of people such as Andrew Lee and others portrayed in Tara Mack's article (We'll Do It Our Way, April 14), showing that we can do it our way, with help. 
But it's not as simple as it appears.
fields.body:
I, too, share the goals of people such as Andrew Lee and others portrayed in Tara Mack's article (We'll Do It Our Way, April 14), showing that we can do it our way, with help. But it's not as simple as it appears.

I am the Secretary of Aphasia Nottingham, a self-help group of 36 members. Aphasia is a chronic communication and language disability that follows a stroke or head injury. We are all aphasic (I suffered a sub-arachnoid haemorrhage nine years ago). We belong to a charity called Speakability, which has about 40 groups across the country. We have a partnership with Nottingham NHS speech and language therapists that is second to none. Yet we are still seen as second-class citizens when it comes to empowerment. We are, apart from a few exceptions, seen as "patients", "clients" - never as people with aphasia with a voice to be heard, inside and outside, charities.

This is so wherever you look - people with fibromyalgia, people with MS, people with cancer, etc, struggling to be heard. So it's not just people with learning disabilities who struggle to get a voice, it's all people with "disabilities". A government minister for disabled people in future could be a disabled person, not solely a learning disabled person, as Mack puts it.
Alan Hewitt
Aphasia Nottingham
10 Cromwell Sreet
Nottingham, NG7 4GL

Being born in 1973, I don't remember much about the Winter of Discontent (Alexander Chancellor, April 14).

In fact, my dominant memory of 1979 is of it being the only year in which I successfully completed a football sticker album. However, neither can I remember a time when the railways were working, the roads were clear, farmers were happy, education wasn't in a shambles and the health service wasn't in a crisis. Despite all this, most of us have spent the past couple of decades managing to get around, learning to read and write, eating and generally staying alive. Come on, Mr Chancellor, clearly we do not live in paradise (who'd want to), but I can't help feeling that most of us never think that things are quite as bad as you fellows whose job it is to sit around worrying about how bad things are.
Paul Warwick
Leeds

Guy Browning made my Easter. In five brief but masterly paragraphs (How To Be Religious, April 14) he said everything about religion that there is to be said. Eat your hearts out Augustine, Aquinas, Descartes and all the others who propagated the Gospel of Double-Think long before Orwell thought he'd first thought of it.
P R Rowland (MSc, PhD, CChem, FRSC)
London SE24

Julie Burchill (April 14) waxes nostalgic over the loss of Soviet communism and says that life there "used to be good". I wonder if the millions of people deported, jailed and/or murdered during the Stalin era would share her sentiment? And didn't the Soviet Union collapse for good reasons, among them the fact that communism doesn't seem to work?
Frank Herlinger
London SE14

I don't think I'll bother with Guardian Weekend any more. With no Dulcie Domum it hardly seems worth the trouble of picking it up from the doormat, where it can remain to mop up the water from a leaky front door. Without Sue Limb's contribution that's about all it's worth.
Ingrid Jennings
Four Roads, Carmarthenshire

What! No more Dulcie Domum? I'm heartbroken - I'll never buy a Saturday Guardian again (well, not for a week at least).
Jonathan Burton
London SE3

This is so wherever you look - people with fibromyalgia, people with MS, people with cancer, etc, struggling to be heard. So it's not just people with learning disabilities who struggle to get a voice, it's all people with "disabilities". A government minister for disabled people in future could be a disabled person, not solely a learning disabled person, as Mack puts it.
