In fact, my dominant memory of 1979 is of it being the only year in which I successfully completed a football sticker album. However, neither can I remember a time when the railways were working, the roads were clear, farmers were happy, education wasn't in a shambles and the health service wasn't in a crisis. Despite all this, most of us have spent the past couple of decades managing to get around, learning to read and write, eating and generally staying alive. Come on, Mr Chancellor, clearly we do not live in paradise (who'd want to), but I can't help feeling that most of us never think that things are quite as bad as you fellows whose job it is to sit around worrying about how bad things are. Paul Warwick Leeds Guy Browning made my Easter. In five brief but masterly paragraphs (How To Be Religious, April 14) he said everything about religion that there is to be said. Eat your hearts out Augustine, Aquinas, Descartes and all the others who propagated the Gospel of Double-Think long before Orwell thought he'd first thought of it. P R Rowland (MSc, PhD, CChem, FRSC) London SE24 Julie Burchill (April 14) waxes nostalgic over the loss of Soviet communism and says that life there "used to be good". I wonder if the millions of people deported, jailed and/or murdered during the Stalin era would share her sentiment? And didn't the Soviet Union collapse for good reasons, among them the fact that communism doesn't seem to work? Frank Herlinger London SE14 I don't think I'll bother with Guardian Weekend any more. With no Dulcie Domum it hardly seems worth the trouble of picking it up from the doormat, where it can remain to mop up the water from a leaky front door. Without Sue Limb's contribution that's about all it's worth. Ingrid Jennings Four Roads, Carmarthenshire What! No more Dulcie Domum? I'm heartbroken - I'll never buy a Saturday Guardian again (well, not for a week at least). Jonathan Burton London SE3

webTitle: The history of the It girl

fields.headline: Got It?
fields.standfirst: Clara Bow was the original  It girl - hedonistic, warm,  earthy, working class. So  how did we end up with  Lady Victoria Hervey?  Lindsay Baker on sex,  money - and what It tells  us about the spirit of the times
fields.trailText: Clara Bow was the original It girl - hedonistic, warm, earthy, working class. So how did we end up with Lady Victoria Hervey? Lindsay Baker on sex, money - and what It tells us about the spirit of the times.
fields.body:
You might think, judging by the current crop, that to be an "It" girl you need to be born in Belgravia with a Cartier spoon in your mouth. Not so. It was a barmaid and a shop assistant who were the notably un-posh, earliest embodiments of "It". Back then, class was beside the point. The point was sex.

Rudyard Kipling, generally regarded as a particularly strait-laced Edwardian imperialist, was the first to use the "It" word in relation to feminine allure. In Mrs Bathhurst, his short story of 1904, Kipling referred to the "special quality" of the eponymous barmaid. "Tisn't beauty, so to speak, nor good talk necessarily. It's just It. Some women'll stay in a man's memory once they walk down the street." For Kipling, "It" was a euphemism for sex appeal. Meanwhile, in the US at the beginning of the century, to be "it" was to be "the ultimate", hinting at the hip, right-time-right-place connotations the phrase went on to evoke.

The romantic novelist Elinor Glyn merged the definitions, actually entitling one of her short novels, It. "To have 'It', the fortunate possessor must have that strange magnetism which attracts both sexes. 'It' is a purely virile quality, belonging to a strong character... There must be physical attraction, but beauty is unnecessary." In the 1927 Paramount movie based on Glyn's book, - also called, simply, It - a department store owner becomes infatuated with one of his "pert and unabashed" employees (played by Clara Bow), a possessor of "It". The imperious Madame Glyn, who appeared in the film as herself, displayed some of the It-girl tendencies that she espoused: she became famous in Hollywood for tea parties where she received guests in silk pyjamas and read them poetry while reclining on a tiger skin.

Clara Bow had already established herself as the flapper par excellence. She had, said F Scott Fitzgerald, "something to stir every pulse in the nation". Whatever the role, she was warm, flirtatious and always vivacious. It was before the Hays Code brought the censors to the cutting room, and Bow was Hollywood's first sex symbol, outselling contemporaries Greta Garbo and Lillian Gish at the box office, and paving the way for the likes of Jean Harlow and Mae West.

The movie took America by storm. The actress and the role became inseparable in the public imagination, and Bow became known as the "It girl". She was the epitome of the Jazz Age - a million miles from the society gels who gained It status in subsequent decades. She was born in a run-down Brooklyn tenement, and her break came when she won a movie magazine's beauty contest; the prize was a film role. At the age of 18, she landed a contract in Hollywood. She famously swore like a trooper in her strong Brooklyn accent - and was completely without airs, graces or any particular regard for etiquette. She was not part of the smart Hollywood set, preferring to play all-night poker with her chauffeur, cook and maid. In her roles as manicurists, waitresses, usherettes, dance hall hostesses and shop girls, she exuded warmth and humour - her public felt that she was one of them. She was an unstoppable exhibitionist, dyed her hair flame red, and was often to be seen driving down Sunset Boulevard in a bright red Packard with her pet chow dyed to match.

If it is the essence of the It girl that she encapsulates the spirit of her times, then Bow was the perfect flighty, hedonistic emblem for the postwar, pre-depression era. A touch too hedonistic and fast living, as it turned out. Society may well be mesmerised by racy, bad-girl beauties, but can, in equal measure, be self-righteously appalled by them. Bow was to provide the blueprint for many an It-girl downfall.

Trouble started when she was cited in a divorce case, by the wife of Dr William Earl Pearson. Then, Daisy DeVoe, Bow's former best friend, went to the press with lurid tales of the star's alleged booze- and drug-fuelled sexual antics. Though most of the rumours proved unfounded, and DeVoe ended up in jail, the mud stuck to Bow. It was the beginning of the end and, with the arrival of the Talkies, she was finished. A nervous breakdown ensued. The first victim of It-girl burnout, her career over at the age of 28, she withdrew to a ranch in Nevada, eventually dying a recluse at the age of 60.

There were other candidates for the title of It girl in the 20s, among them the British "Brunette Bombshell" Chili Bouchier; the sultry Theda Bara; the hard-partying, Algonquin-attending Tallulah Bankhead; hostess-with-the-mostest Nancy Cunard and fashion doyenne Daisy Fellowes. But, as Kenneth Anger put it in his anthology of movie scandal Hollywood Babylon, "The eclipse of Clara Bow, who had been for an entire generation Flaming Youth personified, clinched Holly-wood's reputation as the Place Where Girls Go Wrong."

Over in Britain at the start of the 30s, the famous-for-being-famous phenomenon was emerging, and among the new It-girls were Mona Bismarck, Rose Bingham and Brenda Frazier - so famous that a new word, "celebutante", was coined to describe them. For this new breed, the designer to be seen in was Schiaparelli, with shoes by Ferragamo, and the must-have accessory, a cigarette case by Cartier. Debutante frenzy was at its zenith; as the economic slump deepened, so society sought escapism, fantasy, glamour. The most celebrated deb of them all was Margaret Whigham, whom the public took unresentfully to their hearts.

Born the daughter of a Glasgow apprentice who had made himself a millionaire, Whigham was Debutante of the Year at the age of 18 in 1931. She was engaged to the Earl of Warwick at 20, but instead married the American golfer Charles Sweeney. She was widely acknowledged as one of the world's greatest beauties, and even featured in the Cole Porter song You're The Top, in which "Mrs Sweeney" is singled out along with such examples of human achievement as the Louvre, the Mona Lisa and the sonnets of Shakespeare.

The 30s were her heyday but, in 1963, with her divorce from second husband the Duke of Argyll - the longest and most sensational divorce to occur in Britain - Whigham, now the Duchess of Argyll, entered folklore in a different light. Part of the duke's evidence was two Polaroid photographs, one showing his wife engaged in fellatio. The picture did not show the man's face, and the identity of the "headless man" remained a mystery for years (recently it was confirmed that he was in fact the then Conservative cabinet minister Duncan Sandys; the actor Douglas Fairbanks Jr featured in the second photograph, also headless). The character assassination of the duchess by the judge was merciless.

The duchess lost the admiration of the public and was cast into social purgatory. It was not just her reputation that the divorce cost her, but much of her fortune. She died in 1993 in a nursing home, a few years after being sued over a £20,000 overdraft.

A number of American society girls - Gloria Guinness and Millicent Rogers among them - took up the baton. Babe Paley, along with Daisy Fellowes, remains one of fashion's most revered It girls. Her confidant Truman Capote once commented, "Babe Paley had only one fault: she was perfect; otherwise, she was perfect." Paley was neither outrageous nor controversial, but her influence on fashion has been enduring: her look combined simple clothes (trouser suits, to-the-knee skirts, crisp shirts) and a pristine, obsessive neatness that somehow contrived to look effortless. She was for a time an editor on US Vogue, and the fashion press adored her, running a story every time she so much as changed her hat. Beauty, perfect manners and kindness were the qualities most commonly attributed to her. She was born Barbara Cushing, and though not "of society" she and her two sisters were groomed by their mother to marry wealthy men. Her sisters chose a Rockefeller and an Astor, Babe chose an oil tycoon, Stanley Mortimer. They soon divorced, and Babe married again - this time to William S Paley, chairman of CBS television. The pair were avid art collectors and lived in a bubble of perfection with their several impeccable houses and their yacht, on which Babe lounged picturesquely.

Paley often confided in her friend Capote, a frequent house guest and a regular at their many parties. He was a good listener, and Paley shared with him intimate secrets about her marriage. But Capote betrayed her and many of his other society friends, telling their stories - thinly disguised - in his book Answered Prayers. The book caused a scandal, though in this instance the It girl Paley was not the one who paid the price. The incident united the ranks of New York society against a regretful Capote, and his banishment was believed to be a contributory factor in his later death from chronic alcoholism.

The brand of flamboyant, high-maintenance narcissism that became the trademark of the 90s It girl first took hold of Britain in the 50s. It was an opportune moment: glitz and excess were in short supply, and the royal family, after the prewar abdication, were, with the possible exception of Princess Margaret, cultivating homely ways. Into the breech stepped the models Fiona Campbell-Walter and Barbara Goalen who, when she married, attracted hundreds of spectators at Caxton Hall. The look of the 50s It girl was luxurious and showy: diamonds, mink, show-stopping strapless evening gowns, pearls, evening gloves up to the elbow.

The British public again showed its weakness for a title, and it was Lady Docker, famous for her gold-plated, zebra-upholstered Daimler, who rose to true It-girl status. Known in the press as "naughty Nora", she was exuberant and extravagant. She and Sir Bernard - her third millionaire husband and a chairman of 50 companies, including Daimler - were constantly in the headlines, notably in the summer of 1954, when they threw a party on their 863-tonne luxury yacht for 45 Leeds coalminers. A Daily Mirror columnist reportedly "failed completely" to "squeeze a sneer from these colliers, suddenly cast into circumstances of the most appalling luxury".

Naughty Nora's plain-speaking approach endeared her to the public. When the Monaco royal family omitted the Dockers' son from their invitation to the christening of Prince Albert, an almighty row ensued, culminating in Nora publicly tearing up the principality's flag. She was banned from the country. Much of Lady Docker's appeal lay in her "common touch", an important quality for any successful It girl. She was from a working-class Derby background, and became a hostess at London's Cafe de Paris before her succession of marriages.

Lady Docker faded from the headlines in the 60s, a decade she never much took to. When the Beatles received their MBEs, she commented that it was the end of Britain's "age of elegance". It was also the end, for the time being, of the British preoccupation with blue blood. The new fluidity of the class structure in the Swinging London era meant that the 60s It girl was more democratically elected. Wildly diverse types, such as working-class Christine Keeler, Oscar-winning Julie Christie, model Jean Shrimpton and aristocratic Jane Ormsby-Gore were all granted It status. Each brought her own trademark to the era - kinky boots (Keeler), pale lipstick (Christie), elfin look (Shrimpton), antique dresses (Ormsby-Gore) - which, along with the Mary Quant miniskirts, false eyelashes and gamine fringes sported by other Its, were emulated by thousands.

There was a wildness to the 60s It girls that was new. They were a spontaneous, risk-taking, hedonistic bunch: qualities, it must be said, that make the more recent It girls - every outing planned for optimum exposure - look contrived, and, well, rather bland. But like their flapper predecessor Clara Bow, many of the 60s Its paid a price for their racy behaviour - and the nation's alternating admiration and censoriousness.

The diamond-and-mink-clad It girls of the 30s and 50s prized a titled consort above any other. In the decade that followed, a Jack-Daniel's drinking, acid-dropping rock star was the boyfriend of choice. Anita Pallenberg and Marianne Faithfull, the girlfriends of Rolling Stones Keith Richards and Mick Jagger, respectively, were the quintessential rock chick It girls. If anyone defined the mood of the decade it was Faithfull, especially with her leather-jump-suited film role in Girl On A Motorcycle.

The bad-girl fantasy was all very well, but when the public deemed it too close to reality, moral panic ensued. In the police drug bust at Richards's house in 1967, the headlines focused on Faithfull and a colourful myth involving a sexual act and a Mars bar circulated. By the tail end of the decade, she was perceived as the embodiment of 60s excess, and laid low by heroin addiction. In 1979 she re-emerged, with a dark, husky-voiced album Broken English, a million miles from her 1964 folky pop hit As Tears Go By. "Life has used me as its personal punch bag," she said.

It was bad-girl allure that also drew the press and public to Keeler, another victim of the double-edged nature of It status. In a recent television interview, Keeler said she was "not unlike an It girl in my day.

I mean I was out to have a good time." Although at the time, Mandy Rice-Davies was the folk heroine of the Profumo trial, it was Keeler whose It-girl status endured. The famous photograph of Keeler astride an Arne Jacobsen chair, taken in 1963, did much to imprint her image on the nation's psyche. The photographer, Lewis Morley, recalls a wide-eyed, rather naive woman. Yet the photograph conveys something else - it became an icon of defiance and sexual liberation, parodied by Joe Orton, reconstructed in ads, lads' mags, copied by Kylie Minogue and the Spice Girls. Life wasn't generous to Keeler after the trial. A nine-month stretch in Holloway for perjury and two divorces led to decades of poverty on a run-down council estate."I took on the sins of everybody," she said in the recent interview. "Of a generation, really."

The70s proved incapable of producing a British It girl. Bianca Jagger was, for a time, famous for being famous, and for looking fabulous in Saint Laurent tuxedos and Halston frocks, but she retreated to New York to become the queen of nightclub Studio 54. The 80s, too, were a fallow period for the Brit It girl.

In the mid-90s, however, she was back - with a vengeance. In 1995, not one, but five young women appeared on the cover of Tatler magazine under the It-girl banner. They were all young ladies of "good pedigree", little visible means of income and vast designer wardrobes. In fact, one of the five, Tara Palmer-Tomkinson was already well on her way to It-girl status due to her column in the Sunday Times Style section. Jeremy Langmead, then editor of Style (now editor of Nova), hired her on the strength of an interview she gave to promote Ray-Ban sunglasses. As a friend of the royals and with a propensity for self-mockery, Palmer-Tomkinson was, says Langmead, the perfect candidate for a society gossip column. The column was "heavily edited", as he phrases it. "As Tara always said, she lived the column, which was far more important than writing it." And the readers loved her, he says. "Tara was quite happy to make herself a comedy figure, rather than just blowing her own trumpet. She had the common touch. Because she was genuinely upper class, she didn't have to pretend, she had no airs and graces."

When Palmer-Tomkinson checked into rehab, "the bubble burst", he says. "Suddenly people realised that it wasn't all as glossy and glamorous as it looked, and that it was cocaine that was fuelling that wonderful lifestyle." It should, in theory, have ended there. But just when it looked as if the latest crop of It girls had had their day, and had become the "Post-it"girls, another one cropped up - Lady Victoria Hervey, who has taken over the Tara slot at the Sunday Times.

The fact that It-dom has, in the past few years, once again become a preserve of the upper classes, may seem a bizarrely old-fashioned state of affairs. It was a backlash to a backlash. The early 90s, in contrast to the "me decade" that had gone before, saw a preoccupation in fashion circles with a gritty, grungey realism. "There wasn't much laughing or smiling going on," Langmead recalls. This peculiarly down-at-heel aesthetic crept from the fashion press into the mainstream, and was dubbed heroin chic. "It was uncool to be posh," says Langmead. Essex girls such as Denise van Outen were the stars of the time. Upper-class Notting Hill types slumming it, but on daddy's trust fund, became known as Trustafarians, and public school boys were putting on mockney accents.

Before long, though, the austere sensibility of the early 90s gave way to an economic boom and the re-emergence of party-going. The groomed and unapologetically posh good-time girls Tara, Tamara Beckwith and Normandie Keith were, as Langmead points out, "a reaction to what had come before". As the Gucci/Prada frenzy began to take hold in the glossy mags, it was inevitable that the new It girls would be an incarnation of privilege. Ultimately, the 90s were every bit as obsessed with conspicuous wealth, unabashed luxury and "designer" lifestyles as the 80s had been. The girls soon made it from the pages of the glossies and Hello! into the tabloids, via London's Met Bar - outside which paparazzi gathered night after night. Before long, it wasn't just the fashion houses who embraced the new gang of Its - jeans companies, hosiery brands, high street chains, all clamoured to enlist them.

Now that It-girl saturation has set in, however, Hervey begins to look like an It girl too far. She did herself no favours in a recent Guardian interview, on the one hand boasting of the freebies she receives, and on the other deriding those who get their handouts courtesy of the state. Even the Daily Mail was moved to comment, with its own slant (that she was letting down her class): "Most of us would be hard-put to see the moral distinction between the undeserving poor and the undeserving rich." Hervey is the career It girl par excellence - her clothing boutique Akademi has prospered in line with her rise to fame - and she is not so much a good-time girl, as a party girl with a purpose, the purpose being publicity.

Never before has It been such a money-spinner. With their sponsorship and advertising deals and newspaper columns, Hervey and her ilk are the first Its to have profited so directly from their status. And who can blame them? Even when their It-ness fades, they diversify: Keith has become the beauty editor of a Sunday newspaper; even the beleaguered, post rehab Tara is now a director of a hotel group. None of them is liable to end up destitute - unlike some of their crash-and-burn predecessors.

But somehow it seems improbable that the It girls of the turn of the millennium will be remembered in quite the same way. For all their flaws and all their narcissism, the earlier Its were not cynical or calculating. Cashing in would quite simply have been deemed non-It. They never worked at being It, but rather had It-ness thrust upon them. Like Elinor Glyn's fictional It heroine, Lady Victoria Hervey is a shop girl, of sorts - but the similarity ends there. As Glyn wrote in her It-girl definition: "She must be entirely unselfconscious... indifferent to the effect she is producing. Self-consciousness destroys 'It' immediately."

A Daily Mirror columnist reportedly "failed completely" to "squeeze a sneer from these colliers, suddenly cast into circumstances of the most appalling luxury". Naughty Nora's plain-speaking approach endeared her to the public. When the Monaco royal family omitted the Dockers' son from their invitation to the christening of Prince Albert, an almighty row ensued, culminating in Nora publicly tearing up the principality's flag. She was banned from the country. Much of Lady Docker's appeal lay in her "common touch", an important quality for any successful It girl. She was from a working-class Derby background, and became a hostess at London's Cafe de Paris before her succession of marriages. Lady Docker faded from the headlines in the 60s, a decade she never much took to. When the Beatles received their MBEs, she commented that it was the end of Britain's "age of elegance". It was also the end, for the time being, of the British preoccupation with blue blood. The new fluidity of the class structure in the Swinging London era meant that the 60s It girl was more democratically elected. Wildly diverse types, such as working-class Christine Keeler, Oscar-winning Julie Christie, model Jean Shrimpton and aristocratic Jane Ormsby-Gore were all granted It status. Each brought her own trademark to the era - kinky boots (Keeler), pale lipstick (Christie), elfin look (Shrimpton), antique dresses (Ormsby-Gore) - which, along with the Mary Quant miniskirts, false eyelashes and gamine fringes sported by other Its, were emulated by thousands. There was a wildness to the 60s It girls that was new. They were a spontaneous, risk-taking, hedonistic bunch: qualities, it must be said, that make the more recent It girls - every outing planned for optimum exposure - look contrived, and, well, rather bland. But like their flapper predecessor Clara Bow, many of the 60s Its paid a price for their racy behaviour - and the nation's alternating admiration and censoriousness. The diamond-and-mink-clad It girls of the 30s and 50s prized a titled consort above any other. In the decade that followed, a Jack-Daniel's drinking, acid-dropping rock star was the boyfriend of choice. Anita Pallenberg and Marianne Faithfull, the girlfriends of Rolling Stones Keith Richards and Mick Jagger, respectively, were the quintessential rock chick It girls. If anyone defined the mood of the decade it was Faithfull, especially with her leather-jump-suited film role in Girl On A Motorcycle. The bad-girl fantasy was all very well, but when the public deemed it too close to reality, moral panic ensued. In the police drug bust at Richards's house in 1967, the headlines focused on Faithfull and a colourful myth involving a sexual act and a Mars bar circulated. By the tail end of the decade, she was perceived as the embodiment of 60s excess, and laid low by heroin addiction. In 1979 she re-emerged, with a dark, husky-voiced album Broken English, a million miles from her 1964 folky pop hit As Tears Go By. "Life has used me as its personal punch bag," she said. It was bad-girl allure that also drew the press and public to Keeler, another victim of the double-edged nature of It status. In a recent television interview, Keeler said she was "not unlike an It girl in my day. I mean I was out to have a good time." Although at the time, Mandy Rice-Davies was the folk heroine of the Profumo trial, it was Keeler whose It-girl status endured. The famous photograph of Keeler astride an Arne Jacobsen chair, taken in 1963, did much to imprint her image on the nation's psyche. The photographer, Lewis Morley, recalls a wide-eyed, rather naive woman. Yet the photograph conveys something else - it became an icon of defiance and sexual liberation, parodied by Joe Orton, reconstructed in ads, lads' mags, copied by Kylie Minogue and the Spice Girls. Life wasn't generous to Keeler after the trial. A nine-month stretch in Holloway for perjury and two divorces led to decades of poverty on a run-down council estate."I took on the sins of everybody," she said in the recent interview. "Of a generation, really." The70s proved incapable of producing a British It girl. Bianca Jagger was, for a time, famous for being famous, and for looking fabulous in Saint Laurent tuxedos and Halston frocks, but she retreated to New York to become the queen of nightclub Studio 54. The 80s, too, were a fallow period for the Brit It girl. In the mid-90s, however, she was back - with a vengeance. In 1995, not one, but five young women appeared on the cover of Tatler magazine under the It-girl banner. They were all young ladies of "good pedigree", little visible means of income and vast designer wardrobes. In fact, one of the five, Tara Palmer-Tomkinson was already well on her way to It-girl status due to her column in the Sunday Times Style section. Jeremy Langmead, then editor of Style (now editor of Nova), hired her on the strength of an interview she gave to promote Ray-Ban sunglasses. As a friend of the royals and with a propensity for self-mockery, Palmer-Tomkinson was, says Langmead, the perfect candidate for a society gossip column. The column was "heavily edited", as he phrases it. "As Tara always said, she lived the column, which was far more important than writing it." And the readers loved her, he says. "Tara was quite happy to make herself a comedy figure, rather than just blowing her own trumpet. She had the common touch. Because she was genuinely upper class, she didn't have to pretend, she had no airs and graces." When Palmer-Tomkinson checked into rehab, "the bubble burst", he says. "Suddenly people realised that it wasn't all as glossy and glamorous as it looked, and that it was cocaine that was fuelling that wonderful lifestyle." It should, in theory, have ended there. But just when it looked as if the latest crop of It girls had had their day, and had become the "Post-it"girls, another one cropped up - Lady Victoria Hervey, who has taken over the Tara slot at the Sunday Times. The fact that It-dom has, in the past few years, once again become a preserve of the upper classes, may seem a bizarrely old-fashioned state of affairs. It was a backlash to a backlash. The early 90s, in contrast to the "me decade" that had gone before, saw a preoccupation in fashion circles with a gritty, grungey realism. "There wasn't much laughing or smiling going on," Langmead recalls. This peculiarly down-at-heel aesthetic crept from the fashion press into the mainstream, and was dubbed heroin chic. "It was uncool to be posh," says Langmead. Essex girls such as Denise van Outen were the stars of the time. Upper-class Notting Hill types slumming it, but on daddy's trust fund, became known as Trustafarians, and public school boys were putting on mockney accents. Before long, though, the austere sensibility of the early 90s gave way to an economic boom and the re-emergence of party-going. The groomed and unapologetically posh good-time girls Tara, Tamara Beckwith and Normandie Keith were, as Langmead points out, "a reaction to what had come before". As the Gucci/Prada frenzy began to take hold in the glossy mags, it was inevitable that the new It girls would be an incarnation of privilege. Ultimately, the 90s were every bit as obsessed with conspicuous wealth, unabashed luxury and "designer" lifestyles as the 80s had been. The girls soon made it from the pages of the glossies and Hello! into the tabloids, via London's Met Bar - outside which paparazzi gathered night after night. Before long, it wasn't just the fashion houses who embraced the new gang of Its - jeans companies, hosiery brands, high street chains, all clamoured to enlist them. Now that It-girl saturation has set in, however, Hervey begins to look like an It girl too far. She did herself no favours in a recent Guardian interview, on the one hand boasting of the freebies she receives, and on the other deriding those who get their handouts courtesy of the state. Even the Daily Mail was moved to comment, with its own slant (that she was letting down her class): "Most of us would be hard-put to see the moral distinction between the undeserving poor and the undeserving rich." Hervey is the career It girl par excellence - her clothing boutique Akademi has prospered in line with her rise to fame - and she is not so much a good-time girl, as a party girl with a purpose, the purpose being publicity. Never before has It been such a money-spinner. With their sponsorship and advertising deals and newspaper columns, Hervey and her ilk are the first Its to have profited so directly from their status. And who can blame them? Even when their It-ness fades, they diversify: Keith has become the beauty editor of a Sunday newspaper; even the beleaguered, post rehab Tara is now a director of a hotel group. None of them is liable to end up destitute - unlike some of their crash-and-burn predecessors. But somehow it seems improbable that the It girls of the turn of the millennium will be remembered in quite the same way. For all their flaws and all their narcissism, the earlier Its were not cynical or calculating. Cashing in would quite simply have been deemed non-It. They never worked at being It, but rather had It-ness thrust upon them. Like Elinor Glyn's fictional It heroine, Lady Victoria Hervey is a shop girl, of sorts - but the similarity ends there. As Glyn wrote in her It-girl definition: "She must be entirely unselfconscious... indifferent to the effect she is producing. Self-consciousness destroys 'It' immediately."

fields.headline: In your face
fields.trailText: 'What better way to start my new make-up column than with some high-class glamour? Someone I vaguely know carried out DJ duties at last month's Vanity Fair Oscars party in LA.'
fields.body:
What better way to start my new make-up column than with some high-class glamour? Someone I vaguely know carried out DJ duties at last month's Vanity Fair Oscars party in Los Angeles, and my mission was to turn up looking as good a contender as Julia Roberts, Kate Hudson and Catherine Zeta Jones. By the time I landed in LA, I had only 12 hours to achieve this ridiculous dream.

Acting on a tip-off, I headed for L'Ermitage Hotel in Beverly Hills, where every year those who accessorise the rich and famous showcase their wares. The place is a flurry of harried stylists carrying dazzling frocks and members of the LA royalty making last-minute decisions. In the Bulgari suite, I try on a $2m diamond necklace and inspect a ruby-encrusted clutch bag, but I'm not convinced I can afford the insurance. In the Jimmy Choo suite, one woman is ready to hand-dye bejewelled satin shoes at any moment as most of Hollywood's finest decide on their outfit only hours before they walk the red carpet.

Some shameless namedropping gets me an appointment at Le Prive on Melrose, home to the hairdresser of Gwyneth Paltrow, Sharon Stone and Kate Hudson, for a heavy-duty wash and blow dry. But the highlight of the day's treatments is a Ritas & Rocks pedicure at Paintshop on South Robertson, a favourite of Patricia Arquette, Halle Berry and Melanie Griffith. It's like a cocktail for your feet, or a fiesta pedicure, as Julie, the proprietor, calls it: hot rocks warm the footbath, margarita salt exfoliates the dry skin, and limes are added to the water for increased circulation. Bring your own tequila. This is pedicure nirvana.

After a quick trip to the shops on Rodeo Drive à la Pretty Woman (sadly, without Richard Gere's credit card, so it's just the one purchase for me), I head back to the hotel. Tamara Toomin, "masseuse and aesthetician" (only in LA), provides a much-needed relaxing facial, and Deanna, from cosmetics company Vincent Longo, applies my make up. I throw on my suit and "ting!" (insert sound of microwave bell) I'm done. Perhaps a little overdone

The party is wall-to-wall AA list celebrities. I cut up the dancefloor with Helen Hunt, Ben Affleck and Gillian Anderson, as you do. Puffy and J-Lo discuss her new beau, Calista Flockhart looks stunning in the flesh, and television actress Jenna Elfman tells me I look pretty! But I concede that the night belongs to Julia Roberts, who really does take your breath away and, let's face it, glows with a beauty my traveller's cheques just can't buy.

 Zoe Ball's beauty column appears weekly.

fields.headline: 10 truths about fitness
fields.standfirst: Yes, there's a lot of rubbish spoken about fighting the flab. But the truth is out there. Johanna Sharples addresses some of the most common misconceptions
fields.trailText: Yes, there's a lot of rubbish spoken about fighting the flab. But the truth is out there. Johanna Sharples addresses some of the most common misconceptions.
fields.body:
Myth 1: Muscle turns into fat when you stop exercising
False. Fat and muscle are two different types of tissue, and one cannot turn into the other. But less of one does allow more room for the other, and it's important to keep a high ratio of muscle to fat for several reasons. "Muscle is a heavier tissue than fat, and is more costly for the body to run in terms of calories, so a muscular body burns more," says lifestyle and fitness expert Joanna Hall.

Myth 2: Weight training builds unsightly bulk in women
False. Testosterone is primarily responsible for a muscle's bulk, and women don't have enough to build Popeye-sized bulges. To develop significant size, you need to exhaust your muscles, which only women who are serious about body building tend to do.

Myth 3: There's an ideal 'fat burning zone'
False. "However long it takes you to run a marathon, you burn the same amount of calories," says sports scientist and former Olympic runner Dr Sarah Rowell. "It just hurts more to do it faster." It's not how much fat you burn during exercise, but how much is burned during recovery. When you work harder, your metabolism stays high for longer, so more total fat is burned.

Myth 4: To lose weight, I must eat less
Not necessarily. You'll put on weight if you eat more than you burn off, but using up more energy by increasing your activity level is a better way to balance the equation than eating less. On a very low-calorie diet, the body tucks into lean muscle reserves rather than fat to keep going. When the calorie count goes down, the body goes into preservation mode and is more careful to conserve supplies in case the famine continues, slowing your metabolism further and making a weight gain on return to normal rations certain.

Myth 5: Lots of sit-ups will give me a six-pack
True, but only partly. "You won't get six-pack definition unless you reduce your body fat all over through diet and aerobic exercise," says John Brewer, director of the Lilleshall Human Performance Centre. "But if you've got poor technique, you won't get good results."

Myth 6: I'm too busy to exercise
False. You don't have to work the body's 600-plus muscles separately to gain health benefits. In the gym, try moves that use several muscles at a time - squats, lunges, dips and push-ups. If you still can't make time for the gym, try climbing the stairs rather than taking the lift. At home, gardening or playing football with the kids will burn more calories than a brisk walk for the same duration. If you're perspiring and slightly out of breath, it's working.

Myth 7: Men can't get cellulite
True. But nor can women, because there's no such thing, says Professor Catherine Geissler, head of health sciences at King's College, London. "Cellulite is just ordinary body fat plus gravity. It takes on a different outward appearance in places where the skin sags - around the hips and buttocks - and is more obvious in women because they naturally carry extra fat in those areas." Controlling it is the same as for fat in the rest of the body - reduce dietary fat, and exercise.

Myth 8: If I give up smoking, I'll put on weight
True, unless you adjust your lifestyle accordingly, says director of Action on Smoking and Health, Clive Bates. "The effect of nicotine means that people have a higher metabolic rate and smaller appetite when they smoke, so when they give up they may put on weight. But the amount is usually small and is as much related to behavioural as physiological changes."

Myth 9: I can't help my weight - I've got heavy bones
False. While genes do play a part in body size, the size of the basic human skeleton minus layers of flesh and fat falls within fairly narrow parameters. Indeed, "heavy bones" are a sign of health, says Dr Rowell.

Myth 10: You can sweat weight off in a sauna
True, but it's only water, which must be quickly replaced, not fat. "Anyone who believes this to be a valid way to proper weight loss is living in the dark ages," says Brewer.

fields.headline: The significant other
fields.standfirst: Trouble with your other half? Friends a pain in the neck? You're well and truly on the rocky road of relationships. But don't worry, you are not alone - the same problems have been concerning people across continents and throughout time. So when do they start? From the moment we're born, says Virginia Mallin
fields.trailText: Trouble with your other half? Friends a pain in the neck? You're well and truly on the rocky road of relationships. But don't worry, you are not alone - the same problems have been concerning people across continents and throughout time. So when do they start? From the moment we're born, says Virginia Mallin.
fields.body:
We are fascinated by our relations with others - with what they are and why they go wrong.

We are endlessly curious, and anxious, about the search for nurturing relationships, and the associated trials and tribulations of trying to find this intimacy begin at birth. From the moment we are placed in our parents' arms, we begin to experience our first feelings of love, closeness, and oneness.

Could it be that we spend the rest of our lives chasing those feelings? How is it that some of us manage to achieve good relationships through life, while for many others they go sadly wrong?

Relationships are probably our most psychologically fundamental concern, beginning with the infant's need for nurture and response from its mother to the mature ability to manage our adult sexual, procreative, emotional and intellectual need of another key person in our lives.

Since the Industrial Revolution and the two world wars, enormous social changes came about that affected our ideas of the roles of men and women in society. With the pill came sexual liberation, bringing yet another dimension to the notion of "personal development" and fulfilment within partnerships. We have come to expect a lot more from adult relationships. And falling in love is the way most of us go about trying to get it.

Falling in love gives the glorious illusion that we are not alone, that we have found someone "on our wavelength", we have "met our other half", we are complete. It is an unconscious process; it seems to "just happen", and we get carried away with the magical feeling of it all. The person in love is not willing to acknowledge that being "in love" is likely to involve a distortion and over-valuation of the person who is loved.

Socrates developed this idea in his Symposium, so it's hardly a new concept that the image of the loved one is an expression of what we want to see in them (ie, our subjective view), rather than the reality of the actual person. It is only too easy when chemistry and hormones are raging to imbue the beloved with all the qualities we wish to find in them. There is a longing to rediscover our internal idea of what makes us feel secure, loved and accepted, or how we experienced our very first relationships - with our parents. Or if those relationships have not been secure, to repair and discover the very thing we never had.

Psychological health depends on satisfactory contact with other people. As infants, we obviously require secure nurturing from the parent or adult upon whom we are so utterly dependent. But we continue into adult life being dependent on others to maintain mental health - it is true that no man is an island - and we tend to repeat the psychological mechanisms of relating to others that we learned as children.

Because of our tendency to repeat what we first knew, if what we experienced as we grew up was satisfactory for us, we have a better chance of being able to find this in our choice of adult relationships and having our needs met on a relatively on-going basis.

Psychoanalytic thinking suggests that all our adult relationships will have a root in the earliest experience of relating to others. Which basically means that the child needs to feel that his feelings are valid as he is growing up and that the environment creates about the right amount of containment - ie, not too protected and nottoo neglected.

Things go wrong when, in our longing to find love and to repair our earlier unsatisfactory experiences, we fall in love with the very person who will eventually repeat those unsatisfactory experiences. Few people would employ a personal assistant or someone to look after their children without fairly lengthy interviews and references. Falling in love skips all that, and chemistry and unconscious longing rule the day.

Robin Norwood's brilliant book, Women Who Love Too Much, illustrates only too clearly the desperation of men and women who have tried, and failed, to fit their partner into a mould. She describes the case histories of people who have been unable to develop their own independent personalities and joy for life, and, therefore, cling to unsuitable and destructive partners.

This can apply to friendships as well as lovers. We have all seen examples of the introvert who seeks a social extrovert to help them out of their lonely world. Sometimes it can work, but it's more likely to end in tears when the introvert becomes a burden, or the partying becomes too much. The rose-tinted spectacles are smashed and the duo retreat into bitter disappointment at the loss of their hopes for fulfilment. The special other turns out to have needs and interests that do not at all mirror the narcissistic longing for the perfect other who will be a soul mate and support through life.

 Virginia Mallin is a psychodynamic counsellor at the Foundation for Psychotherapy and Counselling. For information, call 020-7721 7661.

fields.headline: Do I  have to?
fields.trailText: ' The second I walked through the doors of the swanky, state-of-the-art gym to which I have reluctantly enrolled myself, I turned into a truculent teenager.'
fields.body:
'Come on, it's good for you!" my new trainer Roly whoops enthusiastically. "Yeah, so's gruel, and I don't feel much like that either at seven in the morning," I reply grumpily. In spite of my reluctance, Roly has manfully succeeded in getting me on to the treadmill, but I am now doing my best to show him just how badly walking can be done. I determine to take the same attitude I took approaching my O-levels (of which I have a princely two). Roly is not going to get me fit.

I am going to show him. The second I walked through the doors of the swanky, state-of-the-art gym to which I have reluctantly enrolled myself, I turned into a truculent teenager. I don't want to get fit, but I need to.

I am over 30, I have had two children in very quick succession, a number of grey hairs (looking alarmingly like pubes) have begun sprouting out of my scalp and, indeed, chin. I get out of breath brushing my teeth - it's time to get a grip. But I'm locked in a wrestling match with my inner, badly-behaved 14-year-old. She is thin, young, and couldn't care less about osteoporosis, high-blood pressure and the rest of the tasty gamut of body-eroding ailments that lie, skulking, preparing themselves to pounce on her the day she hits... whatever age it is you get those things. Anyway, they are never going to happen to her. But something strange occurs. After a hideous 11 minutes of more vim and vigour than it took me to deliver my babies, I start, dare I say it, enjoying the feelings brought on by this exercising lark. Suddenly I see the light. I am a new convert - I just know I'm going look like Elle Macpherson in only nine minutes' time. It's going to happen!

A rush of guerrilla endorphins swirl around my frame, announcing to all the fat, cellulite and creases hanging around in surly gangs that the game is up! I have found religion... (well, in the shape of Roly) and nothing's going to stop me. At least not until I get off the treadmill. Hey, I think I might re-sit my O-levels. Then I'll go to university and then I'll become a professor of advanced sit-up techniques and then I'll... oh, the treadmill stops after 20 minutes. Perhaps it's time for a coffee and a Danish (pastry, not man - I haven't got the energy for both). After all, I've just walked nowhere for quite a long time.

 Arabella Weir is the author of Does My Bum Look Big In This? Her Get Fit column will appear weekly. She trains at the Laboratory health club, London, 020-8482 3000.

fields.headline: Friends    for   life
fields.standfirst:
The sensual pleasure that pets bring to our lives provides the perfect antidote to the stresses 
of modern society, says Justine Hankins
fields.trailText: The sensual pleasure that pets bring to our lives provides the perfect antidote to the stresses of modern society, says Justine Hankins.
fields.body:
My dogs are spoilt. I leave the heating on for them, cook too much so there are "leftovers" of their favourite titbits (fusilli, couscous, sprouts), take them on outings to the pet superstore and run around the park wearing silly wellies. The only thing stopping me from taking them to the Dog About Town grooming parlour is the shortness of their coats. I even, on occasion, talk to them and have been known to get a bit weepy at the denouement of Vets In Practice. And I know I'm not the only one.

There are 6.5 million dogs and 8 million cats in the UK, many of them cherished and adored by otherwise sensible adults. We tolerate their puking and pooping, their chewing and scratching. We organise our homes, our social lives and holidays around them. And what do we get in return? We get something we lost when we started wearing fig leaves and thinking a lot about everything. To Milan Kundera, time spent sitting with a dog "is to be back in Eden, where doing nothing was not boring - it was peace". This simple innocence is the joy of pets.

Gertrude Stein said, "I am I because my little dog knows me." Our pets release us from some of the affectations and inhibitions of human society; there is no point putting on airs for your pet. Pets have no notion of keeping up appearances and never worry about whether they look cool haring round the park after a Frisbee or frantically pursuing a bag of catnip tied to a door handle. This tendency for carefree abandon often rubs off on their human companions - pets can make even the most strait-laced, austere or sophisticated among us happily give up all propriety and roll around on the carpet or engage in a ferocious tug of war over a squeaky toy.

And while language may have given us many marvellous things, it has made us forget how to speak with our bodies. Pets, on the other hand, are devoted to sensuality. All they ask for is to be stroked, tickled and kept warm. And they feel nice - all soft, satin ears and silky coats, cute little pads and warm bellies.

Pets are also the key to domestic perfection. "I love my cats because I enjoy my home," mused Jean Cocteau. A pet can make the dingiest flat seem warm and welcoming, a guarantee of tucked-up-tight-in-a-duvet cosiness - a fact not lost on Thomas Mann, who described his dog as "my own fireside", the perfect antidote to our frenetic lifestyles. In short, at rest and at play, they're an inspiration.

In truth, we are jealous of our pets. James Thurber suggested that people have a "dog wish"; that is, "a strange and involved compulsion to be as happy and carefree as a dog". There is also a parallel "cat wish", to be as relaxed and contented as a cat. In many ways, the joy of pets is the ideal complement to the joy of people. We love our pets because they allow us a moment's respite from the struggles, strains and challenges that are the very things that make human society so stimulating and rewarding.

There is a tendency to view pets as if they were simply little people trapped in cute, furry, non-speaking bodies. We endow them with human emotions and motivations, such as jealousy and guilt, that they are, in all probability, incapable of feeling. But this anthropomorphism is a mistake for them and for us. They are not like us, but a little part of us is like them. Just as we pretend that our pets are people, we forget that we ourselves are also animals.

Perhaps we have more to gain from "petmorphising" ourselves, discovering the "inner pet". In the midst of our ever-more complicated lives, we may find that a simple joy is not so hard to grasp, after all.

webTitle: All the people I've ever slept with

fields.headline: All the people I've ever slept with
fields.standfirst: The violinist
fields.trailText: The violinist.
fields.body:
I lost it to a violinist. I was 16 and he was 21. Blond, blue-eyed; he looked like he was made out of beech. I met him when he bought me a packet of Wheat Crunchies after orchestra practice. I'd never had them before. He seemed to be offering a world of new experiences.

It was about two weeks into the relationship. We'd taken to heavy petting sessions when his parents were out in the afternoons. I'd never felt particularly involved when he did things to me in the bedroom, but I didn't mind. That afternoon, he was really getting into it. I was staring at his bookshelf and he was shunting about when I felt a digging sensation deep inside, below my stomach. He shuddered, and then rolled...

'We did it,' he said.

'What?'

'We just did it.'

'Really?'

He pulled off a condom, which I hadn't noticed he had put on, and dropped it on to the carpet. I didn't want to stare. I finished with him a week later when I found out that he'd lied to me about his O-level results. He told me he'd got nine straight As, when he actually only got three all together.

Next week: The teacher.

fields.headline: Somewhere for the weekend
fields.standfirst: A semi-derelict mansion that's open to the elements, in a remote corner of Rajasthan - okay, so it's not everyone's idea of rural relaxation, but for one couple it's just perfect.
fields.trailText: A semi-derelict mansion that's open to the elements, in a remote corner of Rajasthan - okay, so it's not everyone's idea of rural relaxation, but for one couple it's just perfect.
fields.body:
Bronwyn and Salim Latif prepare to drive out of town. They load the car with everything to make a short break comfortable: sheets, rugs, plates, table linen, candles and food. The couple's vehicle is crammed with baskets of vegetables, fruit and flowers and, of course, the dog. Nothing uncommon there; a similar weekend routine is undertaken by families across Britain.

Except Bronwyn and Salim undertake a hot, five-hour drive from the suburbs of Delhi into one of the remotest corners of Rajasthan. Their rural retreat is a semi-derelict, ancient mansion, once inhabited by a feudal lord, now patrolled by peacocks.

"I have absolutely no idea why we were mad enough to acquire a derelict haveli with no road, windows, doors, electricity and no running water," says Bronwyn, an Australian by birth.

"But we never tire of being there and slowly making it into a home."

She and Salim, who was brought up in Surrey, abandoned their conventional western environments to settle in India in 1979. Before that, they had been travelling together for six years, had married on a Greek island, but gave up the nomadic lifestyle after the birth of their daughter, Chloe. The Latifs' second home, in a remote valley near the foothills of the Aravalli mountain range, is a little remnant of the couple's wanderlust. "We searched for a long time," Bronwyn remembers, "and when we heard of this crumbling place, used by local people for their livestock, I thought, 'Yes, this is it'."

"Haveli", which literally translates as "enclosure", is more specifically a town house or mansion built around a courtyard in traditional style. Several regions in Rajasthan are punctuated with small forts and havelis that were once owned by feudal barons and maharajas. Many of them date from the 17th century and are decorated with elaborate murals.

On the Latifs' first visit to the 400-year-old house, the only directions they had was a map drawn in the mud. "It was difficult to find, it was so remote. We picked our way through the fields with the village kids. When I saw it, it was a just a ruin - inhabited by buffalo - but my heart wouldn't stop going pitter-patter," says Bronwyn. The house had lain unoccupied for more than 80 years, after a huge flood swept away most of the mud and stone houses in the village.

That first visit was more than five years ago. It took them over a year to buy the haveli, largely thanks to legendary Indian bureaucracy and law, which favours the passing of property from one generation to the next within the same family. Bronwyn describes it as "the year of 1,000 bear traps".

The last hour of that long, hot drive from Delhi out to the mountains, is along rough, dirt roads. When Bronwyn and Salim first arrived at the haveli, there was no road, so they had to build one. The house stands alone, nestling against a small hill, in the middle of fields which are farmed by local villagers. The haveli is three storeys high, with a roof that doubles as a bedroom during the Indian summer. There is a cool darkness inside - the only available light comes from a central courtyard. Neither the ground nor first floor has been restored yet, so the Latifs perform an elaborate kind of camping in the grey, cavernous stone chambers that come off the central courtyard. Narrow stone staircases connect the storeys, and Bronwyn and Salim live on the third floor which leads onto the roof: the lightest and coolest bit.

The haveli is permanently open to the elements: there are no windows (it would get far too hot), and the chambers opening on to the courtyard have no doors. The place is too remote to be looted: caretakers permanently live in one corner of the house, and besides, the Latifs' feel they are part of the little local community, which will keep a watchful eye on the property.

The couple are expert at setting up home within an hour of arrival, and the process of imbuing an empty house with life, of decorating it each time, afresh, is extraordinary to see. The building is ghostly until beds are recovered from a store room. A temporary kitchen is set up and Salim sets up the Calor Gas stove and the primitive air conditioner. Bronwyn creates a living room, this time she decides it's the Tiger Room, with fake tiger-skin rugs set on cotton blue-and-white striped dhurries (woven rugs), cushions are plumped up, a candelabra set with candles, kerosene lamps lit in all the dark alcoves. The table is laid in style, complete with napkins and colourful Rajasthani enamel plates. Vases are filled with flowers, bowls are heaving with fruit, wine glasses are suddenly brimming over.

The first decision is where to sleep for the night. "At the moment, our favourite place is on the roof," says Bronwyn, "under a huge overhanging tree. We tie the mosquito net on to a branch and perform a balancing act to get into bed." She painted the traditional, hand-made beds blue."They were made by the local carpenter, who made them five foot nine inches long, so l had to order new ones to accommodate my tall husband and tall friends. When I painted the legs, the carpenter nearly had a fit - he hadn't seen a woman with a paint pot before."

The most sensual experience in the house is the bathroom, where there is an open view over surrounding fields and the distant, imposing mountain range. Aromatic herbs in tubs of fresh water are ready for the bathing ritual where you sit on a ceramic Khurja stool and pour over the fragrant water. As the day grows hotter, Bronwyn will pour water over the ground which creates an instant cooling effect.

Her training in fine art and ceramics feeds into the decoration of the house, and in corners it has a peculiarly European feel. Before marriage, Bronwyn set up home on the Greek island of Lesbos. She met and married Salim in Greece in 1975. It was a trip back to Australia after Chloe's birth - via India - that changed the course of their lives. They wanted to stay. It was a decision they have never regretted and both now run businesses from Delhi. The connections with Europe, and particularly Britain, continue: Bronwyn buys ancient textiles and embroidery and works on special projects with London interior designers, including Valerie Wade, Tessa Kennedy and Victoria Waymouth. Many projects are for private clients, including Tina Turner's home in the South of France.

The haveli is a world away: the palm trees outside it are festooned like Christmas trees with the nests of exotic birds - parrots partridge and weaverbirds. An exotic garden has been planted among the outlying ruins, now bursting with mangoes, guavas, pink grapefruit, lemons and limes. Although the house is gradually being restored, Bronwyn is not impatient: "Even though we now have electricity, we still prefer the kerosene lamps around the place. The rather grand camping suits us fine for the moment."

fields.headline: To DIY for
fields.standfirst: Sanding floors
fields.trailText: Sanding floors.
fields.body:
Sanding floors isn't rocket science, but it is one of those jobs, like cleaning industrial ovens or doing a shift in an abattoir, that can sap your morale. Anyone who's ever done it swears it's the Devil's work, then they ask if you've thought seriously about the benefits of fitted carpet. It's the sheer violence of the machines that people underestimate.

And the choking dust that stays with you for days. But if you're determined to proceed, the first thing to do is check that your floor is up to it. Examine as big an area as you can before lifting the whole carpet, because half your floor may be beautiful oak parquet, but the rest might have been screeded over by some git in the 70s. Other problems, such as broken or uneven boards, can be solved at the timber merchants or, if yours is pristine wood, phone around for reclaimed material to match. Preparation Take up, or knock in, all protruding nails. Any of these can shred a sanding sheet in seconds, costing many morale-sapping minutes of repair and up to £2.99 a time. Carpet-edging is where things start to get nasty, so get nasty back with a crowbar and rip up all those vicious spiky gripper rails. A crowbar also boosts your psychological campaign.

The sander will mess with your head in so many ways - physical pain, self doubt - but a crowbar will help put you back in charge. The hire shop will have rows of sanders parked like musclebound Hoovers. You will also need an edger. Get a selection of sanding sheets on sale or return. Soon, you'll get the hang of just how powerful and horrible the sander is. It will drag you around your floor, smashing into the skirting boards.

Control the angle of the drum by counterbalancing your weight against it, and only when the sheet is worn can you allow the drum full contact with the floor. If your wood is poor, fit coarse sheets first and work diagonally, and finish off with medium or fine sheets in the direction of the boards.

Soon, you'll get the hang of just how powerful and horrible the sander is. It will drag you around your floor, smashing into the skirting boards. Control the angle of the drum by counterbalancing your weight against it, and only when the sheet is worn can you allow the drum full contact with the floor. If your wood is poor, fit coarse sheets first and work diagonally, and finish off with medium or fine sheets in the direction of the boards.

fields.headline: Twits   of the  trade
fields.standfirst: Estate agents might be prone to smugness, but so are know-it-all homebuyers. Birna Helgadottir on the hell that is the amateur expert
fields.trailText: Estate agents might be prone to smugness, but so are know-it-all homebuyers. Birna Helgadottir on the hell that is the amateur expert.
fields.body:
They are known in the car trade as tyre-kickers: those who know nothing about cars but stroll slowly round the vehicle, kicking the tyres trying to look like a pro. Estate agents, too, have their own phrase for the mug punter trying to cover up his ignorance: the wall-tapper. "Knocking on the walls is one of the all-time classics," says Ed Mead of Douglas & Gordon's Chelsea office.

"It tells you nothing at all." These days, tyre-kickers are a dying breed, but when it comes to buying a property most of us are still tapping away with a hopelessly deluded air of expertise.

And it doesn't stop at scrutinising the plasterwork, either. The shameless amateur is also betrayed by their habit of looking up drainpipes or putting a spirit level on the mantelpiece. Others concentrate on the plumbing: "We get a lot of loo-flushers," says Jay Chitnis, of estate agency HJC in Thames Ditton, Surrey. "I don't know what that's all about." Indeed, the idea of not buying a £300,000 house because of a £10 faulty ball cock is somewhat bizarre.

Another source of amusement for agents is the tap-turner, a character desperately worried about water pressure, specifically the weak dribbles that pass for showers in some parts of the country. "They don't understand how the bath/shower switch works, and invariably end up soaked," says Chitnis.

While wall-tappers and their ilk are regarded with benign tolerance by most agents, the soi-disant price expert is emphatically not. "One thing that is terribly annoying is the applicant talking the property down while viewing it," says Mead. "They might complain that there is no way a double bed will fit in, when it obviously will, or talk about some friend who bought a similar property a couple of doors down for 20% cheaper. As an agent, I need to judge whether they know what they're talking about, or whether they're being completely unrealistic in order to knock the price down."

"You often get clients who march into a property and immediately start saying, 'Oh, it's grossly overpriced'," adds Chitnis. "They're often just doing it to show off to their girlfriends, but they've painted themselves into a corner, and it's very difficult to do business with someone after they've made a confrontational statement like that."

Then there are the gadget freaks. Basic questions about fixtures and fittings are, of course, to be expected, yet Chitnis says that he and his colleagues have been asked, for example, whether the view comes with the property, or if the seller is leaving the double-glazing behind. At the top end of the market, it goes way beyond carpets and curtains, so the agent has to do a lot of homework just to keep up: "They ask about Lutron lighting, surround sound, Linn hi-fi sockets and different makes of plasma screen," says Lulu Egerton, residential director at Lane Fox. This kind of client is also obsessed by security and wardrobe space: "They want to know where they can store the spring collection, the summer ensemble, and so on."

The public's enthusiasm for feng shui is also not matched in the estate agent community: "We get clients insisting on energy-flow diagrams, asking if the property has been dowsed," says Chitnis. Some clients believe that roads at junctions can let in evil spirits, and that walking past bedrooms to get to reception rooms is bad chi. "One client was very insistent that there be no church bells in earshot. Apparently, these are a sign of death," says Egerton. "Unfortunately, South Kensington, where she was looking, is full of churches."

While most of us try hard to appear down-to-earth and sensible when house-hunting, the super-rich don't care how dotty they sound, and can afford the luxury of making preposterous demands. "I recently took a well-known singer around a flat in Notting Hill, who stood staring out the window for about 10 minutes, apparently testing the karma," says Matthew Kaye of Chesterfield, in central London. Most frustrating of all, he says, was the house-hunter who dreamt of good fortune behind a red front door, and so would look only at houses that already had one. Many helpful vendors offered to get the Dulux out, but to no avail. The paintwork had to be old and peeling, as it was in the dream.

fields.headline: Wild thing
fields.standfirst: Some of us don't want subtle gardens - some of us want to turn up the heat with a crazy line-up of bold, brassy plants that compete to create a psychedelic display. The key is the right combination, says Ann-Marie Powell
fields.trailText: Some of us don't want subtle gardens - some of us want to turn up the heat with a crazy line-up of bold, brassy plants that compete to create a psychedelic display. The key is the right combination, says Ann-Marie Powell.
fields.body:
Gaudy, brash, impertinent or just downright weird, some plants don't give a damn what you think of them. Gardeners, though, should salute these nursery renegades: with kitsch such a universally accepted style in the home, surely we can do the same with our gardens?

Next time you drop into your garden centre, look long and hard at the trays of brightly coloured annuals, and ask why so many people sneer and avoid this strangely wonderful, mass-market eye candy. Perhaps they kid themselves that serious gardeners just wouldn't succumb to such easy pleasures. Shame on such pomposity. In the garden, nothing should be ruled out.

The right bedding fellows

Tempting though it is to include as many of these garish plants as your garden will accommodate, this is a surefire way to induce a migraine. To avoid bewildering colour clashes, choose one from each of the groups below and put them together. This will build a crescendo of shape and colour through all the levels in your border, without overkill. Surround the most gregarious blooms with less attention-grabbing plants (every lead needs a good supporting cast) or a generous helping of green as a backdrop.

And if you're still unsure, a set of plant wheels will come in handy. Put your floral phantasmagoria on these and move them in and out of your space, until you find a combination that's wild and witty but doesn't tip over into downright hideous. You'll have great fun trying it out.

Low-growers

Annuals are more rebellious, garish and mesmerisingly weird than ever.

If you can't find what you're looking for at your local garden centre, then you should make the seed companies your new best friends. Who says brown and yellow don't work? Mother Nature does it with surprising success. Viola 'Maroon Picotee' (marketed as a deep maroon that I swear looks brown) is a belter of a plant, which fully embraces 60s chic. Another viola to take notice of, more glam rock than blissed-out hippy, is V. x wittrockiana 'Jolly Joker'. This comedian's clear orange and violently purple outfit seems to work.

Now to the space age. Dorotheanthus bellidiformis 'Magic Carpet' originally hails from sandy or rocky areas of South Africa, and you'd be wise to give it the same kind of lunar landscape. A fantastic low-grower for cracks in paving, its multicoloured flowers (as if sprayed with a fine mist of every shade imaginable) emerge from fleshy leaves that appear dusted with frost.

But annuals are not the only vibrant, low-growing plants. Oxalis versicolor, a frost-tender alpine, packs a mean punch. This small plant's infamy lies not in its blooms or foliage, but its buds. Like old-fashioned barbers' poles, deep pink and white candy-striped buds unfurl with a touch of pure magic. They seem to twist as the blooms are released, creating a bizarre sense of movement that makes them seem like they're dancing. Plant them in pots on tables where they can be the centre of attention (ideal for moving inside when it gets frosty, too).

More and more people are developing a taste for auricula primroses. They come in a fantastic array of colours, but with their thrums, farinas and pins, you'll need a botanical glossary to fully understand them. Vain plants indeed, some even wear what appears to be caked-on white eye shadow. But hands off these dusty ladies; once touched, the phenomenal ring of white (known as the paste) will be forever spoilt. Most of these breeds, for example Primula auricula 'Astolat' and P. auricula 'Warwick', are pampered for shows, so nearly all their hardiness has been bred out. Without the right skill to grow them, they will let you down. Safer bets are 'Janie Hill', with her pouting orange, yellow and red face, or the maroon and ochre 'Lee Paul' alpine auriculas. Traditionally given their own stages to perform on (auricula stands with black backgrounds were all the rage in the 18th century), these plants certainly look their best when displayed individually in their own pots.

Tall and magnificent

Morning glory is a familiar annual climber, but those in search of visceral satisfaction should seek out Ipomoea purpurea 'Star of Yalta'. Seeds are best soaked overnight before planting, to aid germination. Its blooms, as delicate as silk, unfurl in search of the sun to reveal exquisite, cobalt-blue petals streaked with plum, receding into a glowing deep pink throat. Divine.

The common-or-garden Passiflora caerulea has a magnetism all of its own. P. 'Incense', is a more unusual hybrid: exuberant, exquisitely scented and exceptionally vigorous, this exotic lady is hardy, too. Just ensure you keep her roots dry over the winter. Never have I seen a passionflower so purple, so magnificent, and so ravishing.

Mid-height magic

A close encounter with the more hardy foliage of Farfugium tussilagineum 'Aureomaculatum' will make your head spin: strange yellow spots proliferate like an alien virus on plate-sized leathery leaves. Perfect for giving the centre of your borders an eye-catching boost. But the real ruffian of mid-border blooms has to be the dahlia. Splintered into groups, one of the dahlia gangs is bound to appeal. For me Dahlia 'Hillcrest Royal' is top dog: a medium-flowered spiky bloom, its rich, pink, inwardly curving petals have plenty of attitude. D. 'Jescot Julie' is slightly more demure, but she does have a dark side. Burnt orange blooms flower 7.5cm across, but beware of the deep purple undersides. The pompon dahlias are a bit more flaky. Feed dahlias regularly to guarantee the wildest of blooms.

Trad but mad

That's not to say that more run-of-the-mill plants don't walk on the wild side occasionally. Day lilies (Hemerocallis) have steadily become more and more reckless. Look into the faces of 'Pink Attraction' or 'Raspberry Wine' and you might not be able to tear yourself away.

Even roses, usually considered glamorous, and rather demure, garden goddesses, can have a rebellious side. Rosa 'Robin Redbreast' is so bright you may have to reach for your shades, but imagine mixing it up with R. 'Tequila Sunrise' and R. 'Disco Dancer', a disorienting, dangerous combination.

It's all about positioning: place this rose in a sedate setting, and she'll be all blushes and sighs. But set her in a punch-up with a dahlia, or entangle her with a rich passionflower, and your garden will take on an altogether more powerful flavour.
