fields.headline: Pure and simple
fields.standfirst: Everyone has a favourite starter, main course or pudding that never fails to send them into raptures. To kick off a new occasional series on dream menus, Jeremy Lee asks Sir Terence Conran what makes him salivate, and why
fields.trailText: Everyone has a favourite starter, main course or pudding that never fails to send them into raptures. To kick off a new occasional series on dream menus, Jeremy Lee asks Sir Terence Conran what makes him salivate, and why.
fields.body:
'Terence," I said to my boss at the restaurant, Sir Terence Conran, "just think of three dishes or ingredients that are favourites and that best please when placed in front of you or relax you most while preparing them." Such a request was hardly a problem for a man who has eaten very, very well for a very, very long time, and whose thoughts on food are as dogmatic as his thoughts on design. With a wistful smile, he conjured up memories of eating in Paris bistros in the 50s, and of many other best-loved dishes - such as fresh langoustines, a tomato salad, young grouse, late summer Scottish raspberries.

Terence may be designer, restaurateur, entrepreneur and a good many other things besides, but the food that graces his own table is of the simplest, most unassuming and, always, best quality possible. "Chic et simple," as the following menu of his choices shows.

All recipes serve six.

Crab soup

Without a shred of hesitation, Terence wanted to start with very fresh langoustines, simply boiled and served up with a great bowl of mayonnaise. This was easily his most preferred starter: 'Delicious, but hardly a challenge for you,' he said with a grin. Of course, I should have responded that to make a truly great mayonnaise required considerable know-how, but that was not the point. No, he abandoned the idea of langoustines, mooted lobster briefly, before acknowledging that, unless caught off the coast of Scotland, that noble crustacean is rarely worth the money or effort.

So, he thought, maybe crab would make an altogether better choice to kick off his ideal meal, perhaps in a bisque. Or, better still, in a good old proper soup, and invigorated by a richly spiced rouille (the French accompaniment to fish soup made from red chillis, garlic, olive oil, and breadcrumbs or potatoes) and some croutons.

I couldn't have agreed more.

1.2kg live crabs (at least)
3 onions
1 stick celery
1 leek
6 cloves garlic
6 tomatoes
Olive oil
1 tsp tomato purée
300ml white wine
1 bayleaf
1 small sprig fresh thyme, tied
12 black peppercorns
Pinch dried chilli
1 sliver orange zest

Do not kill the crabs until ready to use them. To do so, flip them over on to their backs, pull back the V-shaped flap on their undersides, then drive a metal spike through the exposed hole - the crab will be killed instantly and with the least pain possible. Using a cleaver or some such, violently bash the crab into tiny pieces, taking care to reserve all the liquid that flows from the body as you do so.

Peel and finely chop the vegetables. Heat a generous slick of olive oil in a large, heavy-bottomed pot, and in it fry the vegetables until softened. Stir in the tomato purée and continue to fry gently for five minutes. Add the crab, wine, herbs, spices and orange zest, pour in enough cold water barely to cover the crab, and bring the pot up to a simmer. Leave to cook for half an hour, stirring every now and then.

Place a colander over a bucket or large bowl, and pour in the soup. Let the liquid drip through, squishing the bits of crab down with a spoon, to extract maximum flavour from them. Pass the soup liquid through a fine strainer into a clean pot and return to the boil. Taste the soup for seasoning, and reduce slightly if it seems too thin. Serve piping hot.

Grilled rabbit

The rabbit that is the normal fare of France and Italy is far removed from the all too often tough, wiry scunner that is native to the British Isles. Terence has a house in Provence called Brunellys (brown lilies), where they often cut up a rabbit into pieces, then steep it in a marinade of garlic, olive oil and herbs and leave to soak for a good few days. Then, cometh the cooking hour, a fire is lit, a grill laid on top and, when the flames have died and the embers glow quietly, the pieces of meat are laid on the grill. So good is this dish that it has become something of a fixture on the menu at the house. Served with some roast heads of garlic, some small potatoes, boiled and dressed with a little melted butter, and a salad of soft lettuce leaves dressed lightly in oil and vinegar, it makes for a particularly delightful meal. It's also delightfully simple.

2 large or 3 small rabbits, skinned
Several large sprigs fresh rosemary
1 small sprig fresh thyme
8 cloves garlic
4 bayleaves
1 tsp cracked peppercorns
200ml olive oil

Remove the legs and shoulders from the rabbits and cut each saddle into three equal-sized pieces. Place the rabbit pieces in a bowl. Peel and slice the garlic, and add this to the bowl, along with the herbs, spices and olive oil. Cover the bowl, and place in the fridge for two or three days.

Light the grill, or better still barbecue, and when good and hot, place the pieces of meat on a rack not too close to the fire. Leave to cook slowly until the meat is rich, brown and flecked with black, then turn and continue cooking until done. As each piece is cooked, place to the side of the grill so that it stays warm while the rest is cooking.

Tarte tatin

Terence's chosen pudding was, like all his dishes, a simple classic: tarte tatin, that most famous apple tart of all, in which the apples are baked under a thin pastry crust in a dark, rich toffee that impregnates them fully. However, he was torn between choosing apples and pears for this dessert. 'Pears do not belong in tarte tatin,' he acknowledged. 'Apples are the only fruit to use in that noble tart, and pears are just not welcome.' To Terence, a tarte tatin is a quintessential dessert.

It may have few parts, but it is vital that each is flawless if the tart is to live up to its justified renown. It takes a bold cook to judge the sugar cooked to the correct degree - that is, when it has become a dark, rich caramel but is not scorched. After that, it's a more uncomplicated matter. The moment when the tart is unmoulded should be a moment of triumph: the apples all richly glossed with toffee, which oozes and runs through the fruit and into the pastry.

12 crisp English eating apples
1 lemon, juiced
500g very good puff pastry
85g caster sugar
55g unsalted butter

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. A heavy-bottomed, non-stick frying pan with an ovenproof handle is the best tool for the tart. Peel and core the apples, then pop them in a bowl with the lemon juice and toss them around. Cut off the bases of the apples to square them off, then cut the fruit in half. Put the frying pan over a medium flame, tip in the sugar and cook slowly until it attains a true caramel hue - that is, dark right though but not in the least burnt.

Remove the pan from the heat, carefully swirl the butter into the caramel as it will be very, very hot. Place two halves of apple back together and place them in the middle of the pan. Pack more apples neatly and tightly around this centrepiece. Slice any remaining apple pieces, and use these to fill any gaps.

Roll out the pastry to an even 3mm thickness, and then cut a disc of the pastry that will be large enough comfortably to flop over the sides of the pan. Gently lift up the pastry and let it fall loosely but smoothly over the apples and edges of the pan. Bake for 25-30 minutes, remove from the oven and leave to cool for 15 minutes then invert on to a handsome dish. Serve with some thick cream, if you wish (which I do)

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

Or, better still, in a good old proper soup, and invigorated by a richly spiced rouille (the French accompaniment to fish soup made from red chillis, garlic, olive oil, and breadcrumbs or potatoes) and some croutons. I couldn't have agreed more. 1.2kg live crabs (at least) 3 onions 1 stick celery 1 leek 6 cloves garlic 6 tomatoes Olive oil 1 tsp tomato purée 300ml white wine 1 bayleaf 1 small sprig fresh thyme, tied 12 black peppercorns Pinch dried chilli 1 sliver orange zest Do not kill the crabs until ready to use them. To do so, flip them over on to their backs, pull back the V-shaped flap on their undersides, then drive a metal spike through the exposed hole - the crab will be killed instantly and with the least pain possible. Using a cleaver or some such, violently bash the crab into tiny pieces, taking care to reserve all the liquid that flows from the body as you do so. Peel and finely chop the vegetables. Heat a generous slick of olive oil in a large, heavy-bottomed pot, and in it fry the vegetables until softened. Stir in the tomato purée and continue to fry gently for five minutes. Add the crab, wine, herbs, spices and orange zest, pour in enough cold water barely to cover the crab, and bring the pot up to a simmer. Leave to cook for half an hour, stirring every now and then. Place a colander over a bucket or large bowl, and pour in the soup. Let the liquid drip through, squishing the bits of crab down with a spoon, to extract maximum flavour from them. Pass the soup liquid through a fine strainer into a clean pot and return to the boil. Taste the soup for seasoning, and reduce slightly if it seems too thin. Serve piping hot. Grilled rabbit The rabbit that is the normal fare of France and Italy is far removed from the all too often tough, wiry scunner that is native to the British Isles. Terence has a house in Provence called Brunellys (brown lilies), where they often cut up a rabbit into pieces, then steep it in a marinade of garlic, olive oil and herbs and leave to soak for a good few days. Then, cometh the cooking hour, a fire is lit, a grill laid on top and, when the flames have died and the embers glow quietly, the pieces of meat are laid on the grill. So good is this dish that it has become something of a fixture on the menu at the house. Served with some roast heads of garlic, some small potatoes, boiled and dressed with a little melted butter, and a salad of soft lettuce leaves dressed lightly in oil and vinegar, it makes for a particularly delightful meal. It's also delightfully simple. 2 large or 3 small rabbits, skinned Several large sprigs fresh rosemary 1 small sprig fresh thyme 8 cloves garlic 4 bayleaves 1 tsp cracked peppercorns 200ml olive oil Remove the legs and shoulders from the rabbits and cut each saddle into three equal-sized pieces. Place the rabbit pieces in a bowl. Peel and slice the garlic, and add this to the bowl, along with the herbs, spices and olive oil. Cover the bowl, and place in the fridge for two or three days. Light the grill, or better still barbecue, and when good and hot, place the pieces of meat on a rack not too close to the fire. Leave to cook slowly until the meat is rich, brown and flecked with black, then turn and continue cooking until done. As each piece is cooked, place to the side of the grill so that it stays warm while the rest is cooking. Tarte tatin Terence's chosen pudding was, like all his dishes, a simple classic: tarte tatin, that most famous apple tart of all, in which the apples are baked under a thin pastry crust in a dark, rich toffee that impregnates them fully. However, he was torn between choosing apples and pears for this dessert. 'Pears do not belong in tarte tatin,' he acknowledged. 'Apples are the only fruit to use in that noble tart, and pears are just not welcome.' To Terence, a tarte tatin is a quintessential dessert. It may have few parts, but it is vital that each is flawless if the tart is to live up to its justified renown. It takes a bold cook to judge the sugar cooked to the correct degree - that is, when it has become a dark, rich caramel but is not scorched. After that, it's a more uncomplicated matter. The moment when the tart is unmoulded should be a moment of triumph: the apples all richly glossed with toffee, which oozes and runs through the fruit and into the pastry. 12 crisp English eating apples 1 lemon, juiced 500g very good puff pastry 85g caster sugar 55g unsalted butter Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. A heavy-bottomed, non-stick frying pan with an ovenproof handle is the best tool for the tart. Peel and core the apples, then pop them in a bowl with the lemon juice and toss them around. Cut off the bases of the apples to square them off, then cut the fruit in half. Put the frying pan over a medium flame, tip in the sugar and cook slowly until it attains a true caramel hue - that is, dark right though but not in the least burnt. Remove the pan from the heat, carefully swirl the butter into the caramel as it will be very, very hot. Place two halves of apple back together and place them in the middle of the pan. Pack more apples neatly and tightly around this centrepiece. Slice any remaining apple pieces, and use these to fill any gaps. Roll out the pastry to an even 3mm thickness, and then cut a disc of the pastry that will be large enough comfortably to flop over the sides of the pan. Gently lift up the pastry and let it fall loosely but smoothly over the apples and edges of the pan. Bake for 25-30 minutes, remove from the oven and leave to cool for 15 minutes then invert on to a handsome dish. Serve with some thick cream, if you wish (which I do)  Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: What's new?
fields.trailText: Richard Ehrlich on a new venture from Alan Yau, a new, web-based, anti-industrial Italian food purveyor and a perennial Guardian favourite.
fields.body:
The restaurant/bar

Hakkasan should get lots of juices flowing. This is a new venture from Alan Yau, the founding father of noodle-factory Wagamama, and it has many points of metropolitan merit. Such as: prime location in the West End of London. Such as: the requisite fortune spent on decor. Such as: chef Tong Chee Hwee, imported from the Summer Pavilion, Chinese restaurant at the Ritz Carlton in Singapore, with his sous chef and dim sum chef in tow. Such as: swanky 16m cocktail bar formed under the demanding guidance of cocktail guru Dick Bradsell, who expects every drink he serves to the masses to be something he would drink himself.

Will the masses rush in to find out? I'd put money on it. Hakkasan, 8 Hanway Place, London W1, 020-7927 7000.

The website

Get out your credit card, go online, and type in www.esperya.com. This is an outstanding purveyor of anti-industrial Italian food and drink, including some of the best cured-pork products anywhere, a huge range of oils and vinegars, fantastic cheeses, and the best panettone ('di San Biagio') you've ever eaten - I ate almost half of mine without pausing for breath.

New arrival: Organic Pianogrillo, an extra-virgin olive oil from Sicily (around £7.50 for a 500ml bottle). Welcome arrivals: anything they sell. And all of them delivered by DHL within a mind-blowing 24 hours.

Easily one of the best food-shopping sites online, and so successful they're now thinking of opening a stall in the food mecca of Borough market, southeast London. How do you say 'yum yum' in Italian?

The book

If the term 'gastropub' means anything to you, you've probably heard of The Eagle. Okay, everyone at the Guardian knows it because it's a short hop away from our palatial offices. But the name will ring bells chez farther-flung chow-hounds, too - people who like the idea of a stripped-down pub interior housing food to make the senses reel while keeping the credit card steady on its feet. The Eagle is now 10 years old, and it's celebrating with a tasty little book based on recipes from the multifarious chefs who have worked there. The title says a lot about what's inside. Heaviest emphasis on Italian, Iberian and Brazilian; cheap and hearty; simple and satisfying. Not the biggest collection of bites per buck, but beautiful drawings and a sound, down-to-earth approach. The Eagle has landed on your bookshelf. Big Flavours And Rough Edges: Recipes From The Eagle, by David Eyre and others, Headline, £16.99.

The grater

It's not often that a piece of kitchen equipment can claim to be truly revolutionary.

The Microplane is one of the few. A Canadian inventor, seeking to make better tools for woodworking, came up with the idea of chemically etching metal to make razor-sharp blades. It worked. In fact, it worked so well that someone applied the same technology in the kitchen. Result: the Microplane, which is to ordinary handheld graters what Mercs are to Mondeos. The first models were for fine and coarse grating. Now there's an extra-coarse version, just to complete the Micro-triad. Graters as good as they get. Microplane extra-coarse grater, £18.50, 01603 488 019 for stockists.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: 'Many a reasonable person would be quite exercised at the idea of Campbells Rutherglen Muscat calling itself a wine.'
fields.body:
Now, many a reasonable person would be quite exercised at the idea of Campbells Rutherglen Muscat calling itself a wine. How can it be such a thing as wine, pedants would argue, when the grapes that make it so sweet have been barely fermented? It's certainly not close to the minimum 5% alcohol that classifies the fermented juice of a fruit, any fruit, as a wine rather than a mere alcoholic cordial. Nevertheless, the Rutherglen muscats, fermented by the splendid Campbells (about whom many ribald songs abound in Scotland) in a warm niche of Victoria, Australia, are wines in spite of this oddity - which they share with Moscatel de Valencia - of being made by adding to grape juice that has only just begun to ferment a healthy dose of grape brandy, to bring the alcohol level up from perhaps a mere single degree to around 15.

The resultant elixir, which can age successfully and blissfully for decades (as I have personally experienced, sampling from single- vintage barrels of the stuff that is 40 and 50 years of age), is blended with older vintages to produce a non-vintage conglomeration, which has no precise equal, organoleptically, on the planet. Oddbins is pleased to offer a half-bottle of Campbells Rutherglen Muscat for a penny change out of six quid. The wine - okay, let us, for any pedants listening, call it the balsam - has a texture so thick you could use it on your bicycle chain, but it is better poured down throats or over ice cream. It is an immensely sweet wine, with toffees, baked spices and soft fruits intermingled, and it rates 17 points out of 20. It is extravagant, hedonistic, unabashed.

Oddbins has several other entertaining bottles. Fairview Viognier 2000 (16.5 points, £8.99, also at Waitrose), from South Africa, is an extremely elegant, apricot-scented and fruited white wine of superbly textured wit. Quite gorgeously stacked with subtle surprises, this splendid wine is, alas, at Fine Wine branches only. Côtes du Rhône Clos Petite Bellane 1999 (16.5 points, £5.99) is simple, subtle and utterly French. This makes it a remarkably unpretentious, fruity, gently herby and earthy red of typicity and complexity. Clos Petite Bellane Echalas Valréas Côtes du Rhône Villages 1999 (16.5 points, £8.99) carries more weight in its fruit and more pounds on its price ticket, and offers delicious riches - tannins, acids, fruit, and texture - that slowly coalesce to a memorable finish.

Wirra Wirra W2 Grenache Shiraz Cabernet 1999 (16 points, £5.99), from Australia, is incredibly smooth and rich, has a confident demeanour, and knows it. Xerolithia 1999 (15.5 points, £3.99), from Greece, on the other hand, does not know this, and it certainly has no inkling that it makes a marvellously rich change from chardonnay. Great with food (chicken, grilled tuna, pasta), this textured white wine has real style and substance, as well as bargain buyability. Minervois Alain Grignon 1999 (16 points, £4.29) offers tremendous vibrancy, almost cassis-like, subtle spices and supple tannins, plus a lovely calm finish. Corbières Alain Grignon 1999 (15.5 points, £4.29) has sweet hedgerow fruit, a touch of earth (aka, tannins) and a good firm finish.

Two bargains at Sainsbury on special offer until the 28th of the month are South Africa Gioya Kgeisje Chardonnay/Sauvignon 2000 and that old Aussie warhorse of a brand, Lindemans Bin 65 Chardonnay 2000. The Gioya Kgeisje (15 points, reduced to £2.99) is so fruity it begs for Thai or Chinese food, or, failing that, an unalloyed throat in need of great refreshment. In this latter role, it is a great soother of the troubled mind or a brilliant welcome-home-from-the-coalface-darling bottle.

The Lindemans Bin 65 (16.5 points, down to less than a fiver for this special offer, to £4.99) has acquired a nutty undertone in this vintage, and this has developed in bottle since I last tasted it. Still up there as one of Australia's best-value chardonnays, this is a branded wine that does not get up my nose, as many do. It always shows a degree of character and, in certain vintages, great class - I remember one vintage seven years or so ago that several self-confessed 'experts' thought was premier cru Chablis. This 2000 may well be one such vintage.

 For the latest wine news, and to contact Malcolm Gluck direct, visit www.superplonk.com.

fields.headline: The perfect boiled egg
fields.trailText: Boiling an egg successfully means achieving two things:
fields.body:
Boiling an egg successfully means achieving two things:

1) getting it done the way you want it; and

2) preventing shell-crack. Ideally, eggs should be no more than 24 hours old. (This is the counsel of perfection, but basically, the fresher the egg, the better.)

Here's a technique that guarantees perfection.

Temperature of eggs: irrelevant.

Size of pan: more important - the egg(s) must not be crowded or the timing will go screwy.

The drill: put the egg(s) in a pan of cold water to cover by an inch. Bring the water to a boil as quickly as possible, then reduce to a simmer and set your timer.

Very runny eggs (ie, coddled), perfect for Caesar salad: one minute.

Soft-boiled to most people's view of perfection: two minutes.

Barely hard-boiled, yolk wet at the centre: three minutes.

Perfect hard-boiled: seven minutes.

Over-boiled: yolks brown, whites with texture of Michelin retreads.

It's not rocket science. But you need to set that timer.

Top tip: run hard-boiled eggs under cold water, then crack the shells to let air in while they cool. Makes peeling a doddle.

webTitle: Police given more time to question Euston suspects

fields.headline: Police given more time to question Euston suspects
fields.trailText: Detectives were yesterday granted a further 36 hours to question two suspects in connection with the death of a woman who died after being run over by two handbag thieves, Scotland Yard said.
fields.body:
Detectives were yesterday granted a further 36 hours to question two suspects in connection with the death of a woman who died after being run over by two handbag thieves, Scotland Yard said.

The two suspects - a 35-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman - were arrested in north London on Thursday and are being questioned over the death of costume designer Liz Sherlock, 42.

Mrs Sherlock, of Chiswick, west London, suffered multiple injuries after she chased handbag thieves out of Euston station, London, on Monday. She had leapt on to the bonnet of the thieves' getaway car but slipped beneath the front wheels as it sped off.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said: "We have been granted a further 36 hours by magistrates and will continue to investigate this incident."

Dozens of people rang the investigation hotline to give information about the case.

Press Association

webTitle: Hey dude, gross-out flicks are a turn-off

fields.headline: Hey dude, gross-out flicks are a turn-off
fields.trailText: It's a truism as old as Hollywood itself that no one ever lost money underestimating the intelligence of the public. Except that is exactly what is happening now, as a string of bad taste teenage "gross-out" movies bomb at the box office.
fields.body:
It's a truism as old as Hollywood itself that no one ever lost money underestimating the intelligence of the public. Except that is exactly what is happening now, as a string of bad taste teenage "gross-out" movies bomb at the box office.

Not so long ago, the runaway success of American Pie, Road Trip and the slasher spoof Scary Movie seemed to show the more moronic a movie could be, the more money it made.

Teenagers, who make up nearly half of all cinema audiences, could not get enough toilet humour or the kind of wince-inducing visual jokes in which a sperm sample is mistaken for hair gel.

There seemed to be no end to the trend - which spawned such purposefully sick shows as MTV's Jackass - until the past few weeks, when American adolescents have suddenly grown tired of politically incorrect comic gore, bouncing breasts and single entendres about Viagra that President George Bush has admitted he finds so amusing.

Tomcats, the most heavily promoted teenage film ever - which made great play of its homage to Hannibal over its sad-lad hero eating a testicle - crashed when it opened a fortnight ago in the US, with an opening weekend take of a little over $8m (£5.5m), a fraction of its advertising budget.

Get Over It, starring Kirsten Dunst, and the teenage horror flick Valentine also died, while the slightly more restrained Sugar & Spice sank without trace, too.

Even the kings of the genre, the Farrelly brothers, the self-confessed "warped minds" behind Dumb and Dumber and There's Something About Mary, seem to have lost the knack of turning smut into brass.

Say It Isn't So, a boy-meets-girl story of accidental incest - all done in the worst possible taste, of course - which they produced took a catastrophic $2.9m in its first weekend, hardly enough to pay for the premiere.

But the brothers - who have been trying to make a comedy about conjoined twins called Stuck on You - refused to be cowed by the disaster and have managed to sign up Gwyneth Paltrow for their next film.

This all might have been dismissed as a few isolated flops had the studios not been banking on the relatively cheap and fairly star-free teenage flicks to get them over a summer of threatened strikes by actors and writers. As it turned out, only the below-the-radar release of the small-budget See Spot Run - about a genius police dog with embarrassingly loose bowels - has done better than expected.

The general malaise has even struck some of the young stars who emerged from the late 1990s vogue for slasher flicks and teen romances. Heart-throbs Scott Wolf and James Van Der Beek of Varsity Blues fame have found their careers becalmed, while even the "scream queen" herself, Neve Campbell, is struggling to find a decent role in grown-up films.

Bruce Snyder of 20th Century Fox refuses to see it as a calamity and claims more stringent age guidelines on films have made them harder to sell to teenagers, who have traditionally found sneaking into films made for slightly older audiences part of the fun of going to the cinema.

But Robert Mitchell, of Screen International, regards it more as poetic justice for studios whose cynicism and hunger to cash in on the likes of American Pie has rebounded.

"It is always the way that the second wave of these type of films have to be cruder than the first and often the joke begins to wear thin," he said. "We could be on the verge of the backlash, or it could be that audiences just don't want to see inferior films trying to ape what went before.

"These sort of films have a great attraction for the studios. They are relatively cheap and are aimed squarely at the biggest group who go to films."

Few of the gross-out films that have gone down in flames over the past month are likely to get the big release in Britain they might have been guaranteed last year.

But Mr Mitchell said the real test of the genre would come this summer with the release of American Pie II and the Scary Movie sequel: "If they don't work out like the studios hoped, it could be the beginning of the end of the gross-out movie."

Whether the world would mourn its passing remains a moot point.

Not so long ago, the runaway success of American Pie, Road Trip and the slasher spoof Scary Movie seemed to show the more moronic a movie could be, the more money it made. Teenagers, who make up nearly half of all cinema audiences, could not get enough toilet humour or the kind of wince-inducing visual jokes in which a sperm sample is mistaken for hair gel. There seemed to be no end to the trend - which spawned such purposefully sick shows as MTV's Jackass - until the past few weeks, when American adolescents have suddenly grown tired of politically incorrect comic gore, bouncing breasts and single entendres about Viagra that President George Bush has admitted he finds so amusing. Tomcats, the most heavily promoted teenage film ever - which made great play of its homage to Hannibal over its sad-lad hero eating a testicle - crashed when it opened a fortnight ago in the US, with an opening weekend take of a little over $8m (£5.5m), a fraction of its advertising budget. Get Over It, starring Kirsten Dunst, and the teenage horror flick Valentine also died, while the slightly more restrained Sugar & Spice sank without trace, too. Even the kings of the genre, the Farrelly brothers, the self-confessed "warped minds" behind Dumb and Dumber and There's Something About Mary, seem to have lost the knack of turning smut into brass. Say It Isn't So, a boy-meets-girl story of accidental incest - all done in the worst possible taste, of course - which they produced took a catastrophic $2.9m in its first weekend, hardly enough to pay for the premiere. But the brothers - who have been trying to make a comedy about conjoined twins called Stuck on You - refused to be cowed by the disaster and have managed to sign up Gwyneth Paltrow for their next film. This all might have been dismissed as a few isolated flops had the studios not been banking on the relatively cheap and fairly star-free teenage flicks to get them over a summer of threatened strikes by actors and writers. As it turned out, only the below-the-radar release of the small-budget See Spot Run - about a genius police dog with embarrassingly loose bowels - has done better than expected. The general malaise has even struck some of the young stars who emerged from the late 1990s vogue for slasher flicks and teen romances. Heart-throbs Scott Wolf and James Van Der Beek of Varsity Blues fame have found their careers becalmed, while even the "scream queen" herself, Neve Campbell, is struggling to find a decent role in grown-up films. Bruce Snyder of 20th Century Fox refuses to see it as a calamity and claims more stringent age guidelines on films have made them harder to sell to teenagers, who have traditionally found sneaking into films made for slightly older audiences part of the fun of going to the cinema. But Robert Mitchell, of Screen International, regards it more as poetic justice for studios whose cynicism and hunger to cash in on the likes of American Pie has rebounded. "It is always the way that the second wave of these type of films have to be cruder than the first and often the joke begins to wear thin," he said. "We could be on the verge of the backlash, or it could be that audiences just don't want to see inferior films trying to ape what went before. "These sort of films have a great attraction for the studios. They are relatively cheap and are aimed squarely at the biggest group who go to films." Few of the gross-out films that have gone down in flames over the past month are likely to get the big release in Britain they might have been guaranteed last year. But Mr Mitchell said the real test of the genre would come this summer with the release of American Pie II and the Scary Movie sequel: "If they don't work out like the studios hoped, it could be the beginning of the end of the gross-out movie." Whether the world would mourn its passing remains a moot point. webTitle: Three years for rape of terminally ill woman

fields.headline: Three years for rape of terminally ill woman
fields.trailText: A bare-knuckle fighter who raped a terminally ill woman at a nursing home was jailed for three years yesterday, to the disgust of her BBC News presenter husband.
fields.body:
A bare-knuckle fighter who raped a terminally ill woman at a nursing home was jailed for three years yesterday, to the disgust of her BBC News presenter husband.

John Archibald, 29, was earlier convicted of the "bestial" attack on the 58-year-old, who is afflicted by the degenerative brain disorder Huntington's chorea.

Jailing him at Reading crown court, Judge Mary Jane Mowat told Archibald, who is mentally impaired: "What you did was unbelievably wicked and disgusting."

Archibald made the attack on February 9 last year while visiting a relative at the home in Buckinghamshire with his brother, Mark, 28.

Archibald plied his victim with cannabis and raped her twice in front of another terrified resident, who was in a wheelchair.

Archibald, who lives at a caravan site near Gerrards Cross, Buckinghamshire, was also convicted of indecently assaulting the woman, who cannot be named for legal reasons. His brother was acquitted of indecent assault.

After the case, the victim's husband said Mark Archibald had threatened him in the public gallery, snarling: "We're going to get you."

The TV presenter said outside court: "It's a classic example of British justice showing undue consideration for the convict at the expense of the victim."

Thames Valley police have offered to install a panic alarm at his home and to keep the house under surveillance.

Press Association

webTitle: No queues for peas at Harvester

fields.headline: No queues for peas at Harvester
fields.trailText: A British restaurant chain yesterday asked the nation to ponder a most pressing point of its culinary future: "To pea or not to pea? - please phone in your answer."
fields.body:
A British restaurant chain yesterday asked the nation to ponder a most pressing point of its culinary future: "To pea or not to pea? - please phone in your answer."

Tired of throwing thousands of the little green vegetables away as diners eat the steak and chips but neglect the peas, Harvester has set up a hotline on the future of the 70s staple.

As chicken tikka masala replaces fish and chips as the national dish, mango chutney has become more popular than marrowfat peas as the accompaniment of choice.

But it is not just the foreign stuff that is hastening the pea's demise: even those tucking into traditional fare are none too impressed with the pea. "Many of our restaurants report that at the end of the meal a lot of plates still have peas left on them," said a Harvester spokesman, Jason Reece.

Although the pea is being eschewed for polenta and the salad bar, Harvester is prepared to give it a limited reprieve before it is removed permanently.

Even the pea's scientific name, Pisum sativum, is unappetising - but there are those confident it will stand firm against passing fads - it has, after all, been part of the British diet since the Norman conquest. "Peas are very good for you and they are very palatable. Sometimes people do need a change from time to time, but, mark my words, people will always come back," said Geoffrey Gent, director of the Processors and Growers Research Organisation.

Harvester's hotline is 0121 365 2640

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Mother charged with murder
fields.body:
Mother charged with murder

Susan MacLeod, 24, from Stornoway, Lewis, appeared at Glasgow sheriff court yesterday charged with murder of her three children, whose remains were found this week in a flat at Govan. She was remanded in custody.

Ex-head jailed for cruelty

Geoffrey Lloyd, 56, former head of Regent special school in Tividale, West Midlands, was jailed for 12 months at Wolverhampton crown court after admitting six charges of cruelty.

Council staff vote on pay offer

Council workers in England and Wales are to vote on a 3.5% pay rise offer which union leaders said should be enough to avert the threat of industrial action.

M25 warning criticised

Motorists' organisations criticised a government leaflet telling drivers to avoid using the M25 in rush hours. The RAC dubbed it "condescending".

Doctor cleared of jab killing

A doctor was cleared of negligently killing a two-day-old triplet with an anti-epileptic drug. Judge David Clarke directed the jury at Liverpool to find Kosalakumar Karunaratne not guilty after the prosecution said it had no more evidence.

£55m police gun centre

Metropolitan police officers are to hone their skills at a £55m US-style gun training camp at Gravesend, Kent, due to be completed by early 2003.

Carry on running

Treadmill runner Rory Coleman, 36, of Long Eaton, Derbyshire, completed his seven-day 250-mile target a day early yesterday, but decided to carry on and reach 300 miles - before running the London marathon tomorrow.

webTitle: Blackmail tormenter ends life in hospital

fields.headline: Blackmail tormenter ends life in hospital
fields.trailText: An obsessed and lonely woman on remand in a psychiatric hospital for blackmailing a former international footballer has been found dead, it emerged yesterday
fields.body:
An obsessed and lonely woman on remand in a psychiatric hospital for blackmailing a former international footballer has been found dead, it emerged yesterday. It is believed she committed suicide.

The body of Carolyn Pick, 36, was discovered at St Luke's hospital in Middlesbrough, where she was being held pending sentencing, late on Thursday. Her death was not being treated as suspicious by police or hospital staff. Cleveland police said they were preparing a report for the coroner, but would not confirm the patient's identity. The hospital said it would investigate after police had finished their inquiry.

Ms Pick was due back at Newcastle crown court in two weeks to be sentenced for blackmailing the footballer, who cannot be named for legal reasons.

The court heard how she had threatened to ruin her victim's family life and reputation by releasing a series of chilling tapes - which never existed. She harassed her victim for five years and bombarded him with letters, photographs of herself topless and crude songs.

The victim had telephoned her once in 1995 because she left a message, purporting to be from Paul Gascoigne, to call her flat in Sunderland. But he denied engaging in inappropriate conversations with her.

Ms Pick was found guilty of blackmail last October and was warned by the judge that she faced a prison sentence of up to 14 years for a crime which was described in court as sinister, menacing and relentless.

Her victim told the court that some of her calls were suggestive and pleading, others abusive, vitriolic and threatening. He said: "I am a family man. I was certainly very worried when these letters were getting sent out to people I know. It was degrading stuff and very distressing."

When he appeared in the witness box, her eyes bulged, she smiled widely, licked her lips suggestively and winked at him. She was told by the judge to modify her behaviour.

She had left a message for her victim which said: "I'm never going to get over the way you have treated me. I have a tape recording that could ruin your career and I want revenge."

Giving evidence, she broke down in tears and said she was very sorry. She said she felt devastated and empty inside. "I waited every night for him to call me, but he dumped me," she said. "He treated me like a chatline prostitute."

The court heard that she made no specific demands to the footballer but referred to her fondness for big houses, expensive cars, fine wine and restaurants. She had been cautioned by the police in 1997, but had ignored the warning.

Ms Pick was a former secretary who was a finalist in the 1986 Miss England North East beauty competition. She lost her father to cancer two years ago, and her mother suffers from severe dementia.

When she was convicted of blackmail, her sister Doreen said: "She has become lonely. It's not good for you to be on your own all the time. Your mind starts to play tricks."

fields.headline: Angles on nationality
fields.trailText: We Scots are used to London media describing your own champions as English whilst Scottish winners are British. But claiming satan is British in the eyes of Hollywood (What kind of Brit are you? April 19?) is too much.
fields.body:
We Scots are used to London media describing your own champions as English whilst Scottish winners are British. But claiming satan is British in the eyes of Hollywood (What kind of Brit are you? April 19?) is too much. Villains are always English. Scots are noble downtrodden heroes!
Dr Nick Fiddes
Edinburgh

 England is the land of the Angles, so why do we tolerate these bloody Saxons coming over here, sponging off our benefits and diluting our homogeneous Angle culture? It's like living in a foreign country sometimes.
Elijah KooBoodee
Rushden, Northants

 So the British have to cut up their spaghetti into short lengths so that they can eat it without making a mess (Letters, April 20). When Italians eat roast beef, the infants have it cut up on their plates by mummy so that they don't make a mess with the gravy.
Michael Ghirelli
Hillesden, Bucks

 If your readers can't manage to open the tin and spoon the alphabet shapes on to their plates without splashing themselves, the country is really going to the dogs.
Toby Wood
Peterborough, Cambs

 I've just downloaded the Steve Bell screensaver. What a brilliant idea! On those days when I'm feeling old and conservative, it will keep me cynical and radical.
Joe Phillips
Nottingham

 Is Stefan Stern after a job in the Foreign Office? His letter (April 20) is one of the most offensively sycophantic you have ever printed.
Graham Rickson
Leeds

 Re the Jack the Ripper letter (Report, April 20): one look at the spelling and it had to be a Guardian sub-editor.
John Denton
London

fields.headline: Terms and conditions
fields.trailText: Here are a few suggestions for Pam Darby (Letters, April 20) to help get her through to the next school holiday with a bit less stress.
fields.body:
Here are a few suggestions for Pam Darby (Letters, April 20) to help get her through to the next school holiday with a bit less stress.

1) Have a word with your head about the large amounts of extra money paid to schools this year through the standards fund, specifically for resources, books, teaching assistants and supply cover for teacher's admin work.

2) Before the Easter holidays are over, treat yourself to a new hairdo. (I don't know of anyone in any job who is able to do this during worktime, but try asking the headteacher - you never know!)

3) Assure your children that although they may spend their holidays trudging round museums and historical sites with their parents, they are tons better off than the children of other working parents who struggle to get two weeks holiday at the same time (without risking the wrath of the school, when the only holidays they can have turn out to be during term time.)

4) Finally, if you still feel aggrieved, try comparing your salary with that of the school secretary!
Christine Hanslip
(School secretary) Frodsham, Cheshire
c.hanslip@ic24.net

 Jane Clark urges teachers to "wake up and smell the coffee". I notice that there are thousands of ex-teachers who have joined the "real world" and seem to prefer it. They certainly aren't queueing up to return to education. Funny that - maybe they prefer only having 25 days holiday.
Mark Webster
London

 Jane Clark boasts about working 50-60 hours a week say more about the bad state of British management than they do about the lack of professionalism of teachers. No one should be forced to work more than 35 hours a week, and if things were organised properly, they wouldn't have to. Jane, get a life.
Timothy Green
(Company director) Harrow, Middx

 I understand Jane Clark's frustration,but she is wrong when she says she doesn't "get the choice" to spend time with her kids. Come and be a teacher, Jane, we need people with your IT skills.
John Eglin
London

 Apparently teachers have to visit "the doctor, dentist, vet, hairdressers etc" in their own time! I'm sure this shocking insight will help to lay to rest once and for all the clearly false impression that exists in the private sector that "planet Teacher" is not in particularly close proximity to planet Earth.
Russell Clements
London

fields.headline: Patent case for change
fields.trailText: The decision by the pharmaceutical industry not to seek enforcement of its intellectual property rights in South Africa (Shamed and humiliated, April 19) is being cast by the media as an issue of global profiteering trying to exploit poor nations.
fields.body:
The decision by the pharmaceutical industry not to seek enforcement of its intellectual property rights in South Africa (Shamed and humiliated, April 19) is being cast by the media as an issue of global profiteering trying to exploit poor nations. However, there is a broader context. The laws governing intellectual property rest on agreements between national governments and inventors. Once it has been established that an invention has been made, the inventor is granted a monopoly in return for two considerations: disclosing to the world how to practice the invention, so that the knowledge available to future inventors is increased; and paying annual fees to maintain the patent in force. In the past this may have been a fair settlement between the interests of society and the inventor; the power of global capitalism in the 21st century may require different arrangements.

It is already within the remit of governments to set other conditions. Until fairly recently, many European countries insisted that inventions be exploited in the market within a few years of granting the patent, otherwise the patent rights were forfeit; this prevented the practice of companies buying inventions which threatened their market position and then burying them. At present, the EU is setting stringent conditions on patent licences, with the aim of maintaining a level playing field for competition between companies, significantly impinging on their freedom to decide unilaterally how to exploit their monopoly.

The South African case opens up the possibility of an initiative to modify the laws on intellectual property, so that the continued grant of a monopoly would require companies to make the product available at a reasonable price. In the case of pharmaceuticals, it would enable companies to control quality - one of their strongest arguments against trade in generic drugs - and to maintain profits through increased sales at lower margins. In the UK, it would enable the NHS to have a more sensible negotiation with drug suppliers about price and quality. Regulation along these lines would also be a step towards establishing a more mature relationship between society and the large corporations, and essential requirement for harnessing their technological and operational skills in creating a sustainable economy.
Prof Chris Adams
Llangollen, Clwyd
Chris@xef6.demon.co.uk

 The pharmaceutical companies' retreat marks a remarkable victory for developing countries' right to use legally enforceable, and so sustainable, measures to secure affordable prices for drugs - rather than having to rely on corporate hand-outs. With Nelson Mandela due in London next week and the argument that the court case prevented public comment gone, Britain must end its fencing-sitting complicit support for the drug industry. The government should now give its clear backing to the measures adopted by South Africa - and support other developing countries who want to use a similar approach as part of their strategy to tackle killer diseases like HIV/Aids.
Ben Jackson
London
ben.jackson@actsa.org

fields.headline: The race card is a blank
fields.trailText: With "race" now being high on the agenda in the run up to the election (Polly Toynbee, April 20), isn't it about time we reflected on what the use of the term actually means?
fields.body:
With "race" now being high on the agenda in the run up to the election (Polly Toynbee, April 20), isn't it about time we reflected on what the use of the term actually means? For nearly half a century scientific thinking has challenged the concept that there are different races of human beings. In July 1952 Unesco issued a statement prepared by an international grouping of geneticists and anthropologists to the effect that all human beings belong to one single species, homo sapiens, and that there is no evidence for the existence of human races. Subsequent studies, including the recently published draft human genome, have shown that human beings are one of the most genetically homogeneous species and that we all share over 99.9% of our 30,000 or so genes.
Dr Reg Dennick
University of Nottingham

 I often get ridiculed in my local pub for being a member of the Conservative party, but I get viciously insulted if I attack my attackers for their racist remarks. These bigots have declared they will be voting Labour. If ever a politician was playing the race card, it's Robin Cook (Report, April 19).
Jarod Weaver
Southwell, Notts

fields.headline: A celibate replies
fields.trailText: If you have any curiosity as to why a Guardian reader of 20 years' standing might suddenly decide to change his newspaper, look no further than Muriel Gray's puerile commentary on the Nolan report on child protection in the Catholic church (Come in Cardinal Jedi - your church needs you, G2, April 19).
fields.body:
If you have any curiosity as to why a Guardian reader of 20 years' standing might suddenly decide to change his newspaper, look no further than Muriel Gray's puerile commentary on the Nolan report on child protection in the Catholic church (Come in Cardinal Jedi - your church needs you, G2, April 19). Her pantomime language ("pesky old religion and its wicked and wanton ways") is but an intensification of the style of coverage which the Guardian reserves for Christian faith, and its Roman Catholic form in particular.

Ms Gray's column is both ignorant (misunderstanding the process of laicisation, damning the Nolan Report for producing mere "recommendations" - which is all any commission can ever do) and mischief-making (church schools are "sectarian"; the Catholic church is a "corrupt, hypocritical and decadent institution ... whose arrogant behaviour is tainted with hypocrisy and duplicity"; it's clergy are at once "perfectly innocent well-meaning men" and, by implication, a bunch of paedophiles - as caricatured in the accompanying illustration).

I have lived as a celibate even longer than I have read the Guardian and, while I would be happy to see married folk ordained, I have yet to discover why freely embraced clerical celibacy is a "quite wicked requirement". To live well celibately requires rather more self-knowledge and understanding of human relationships than I detect in Ms Gray's writing. She is the weakest link. Goodbye.
Rev Rob Esdaile
Catholic chaplain to the University of Sussex
catholicsussex@netscapeonline.co.uk

fields.body:
Usually your fascinating obituaries make me wish we had similar articles about the subject while they were still in a state to benefit from the publicity, but a couple of recent flaws are worrying. Nyree Dawn Porter (April 12) supposedly disappeared from TV after the Forsyte Saga - except, presumably, for the 52 episodes of the prime-time series The Protectors, which didn't even get a mention. Similarly, director Michael Ritchie's film Prime Cut, maybe his best, was absent from an otherwise thorough obituary (April 19).
J Stewart
London

fields.headline: Firm code
fields.trailText: Confectionery companies (plus manufacturers of clothing and producers of bananas and coffee) have long been associated with questionable labour practices (Slavery summit, April 19).
fields.body:
Confectionery companies (plus manufacturers of clothing and producers of bananas and coffee) have long been associated with questionable labour practices (Slavery summit, April 19). Such practices continue to be employed despite several conventions of the International Labour Organisation and UN. Companies should now, as a minimum, seek to sign up to codes of conduct (eg the ethical trading initiative), which stipulate requirements on child labour, health and safety, etc. They should also work with a wide range of organisations (NGOs, trade unions, local communities) to show in an open and transparent way that the code is being implemented.
Rob Lawson
National Centre for Business and Sustainability, University of Salford
R.Lawson@thencbs.co.uk

fields.headline: Post haste
fields.trailText: I also fear census statistics will be in error (Letters, April 18). I have already seen two people posting their yellow census envelopes.
fields.body:
I also fear census statistics will be in error (Letters, April 18). I have already seen two people posting their yellow census envelopes. Neither the form, nor the leaflet, spells out sufficiently the need to post the form on or after April 29. Job loss, birth and even death could be underreported. This could not happen with previous censuses as the form was collected after census day.
Susan Stirling
Ilford, Essex

fields.headline: The old fish and the sea
fields.standfirst: It should have had a happier ending
fields.trailText: Every dog has its day: also every fish. And now is the time to rehabilitate the halibut. It has not had a good press.
fields.body:
Every dog has its day: also every fish. And now is the time to rehabilitate the halibut. It has not had a good press - which may have something to do with the fact that it has spent so much time lying on the sea bed that both its eyes and all of its colouring are on one side of its body. Earlier this month a book review in this paper of Wittgenstein's Poker described the title as "about as hip and sexy as a halibut on a fishmonger's slab". That's about par for the course, so to speak, for this fish which is only remembered as a steak on a plate, not in its own right.

Not any more. This week halibut hit the headlines after the capture of a 20-stone monster off Rockall, standing - or lying - eight feet in its bare fins. It was too big to be the subject of a fisherman's tale because no one's arms have a span that wide. It will doubtless soon receive due acclaim on the halibut's own dedicated web site (www.halibut.net). But that will not be any satisfaction for the fish, which is already being eaten, even as we write, in an Aberdeen restaurant. This is sad bordering on tragic. Surely, after evading the best of our nets for 35 years, this lord of the sea deserved something better. It should have been thrown back.

fields.headline: Cash 18-30
fields.standfirst:
In the clinic: Richenda Gambles
Age: 23
Occupation: features writer
fields.trailText: Richenda Gambles, 23, lives in Reading and works as a features writer for a news agency.
fields.body:
Richenda Gambles, 23, lives in Reading and works as a features writer for a news agency.

The problem

"I earn £16,000 and would love to buy a house; renting seems such a waste of money. But I want flexibility and buying a house is such a huge commitment. Supposing I want to go travelling or decide to move from the area, would I lose a lot of money by selling within a year? What about renting it out? Also, is it possible to get a mortgage on my salary - bearing in mind I have no savings and still have a student loan of £6,000 that needs repaying?"

The solution

Our experts agree that Richenda should wait until she is more certain about her future before she takes the plunge and buys a property.

1 Prices in Reading are high and on a salary of £16,000 the maximum Richenda can borrow from the Northern Rock under its Together mortgage is 3.8 times her income, which is £60,000. The advantage of this particular product is that there is no mortgage indemnity guarantee required and it is a flexible contract without any tie-in or redemption penalties.

The arrangement fee is £395, which can be added to the loan, and there is a "help with costs" option that allows £200 towards legal fees and a refund of the valuation and administration fee of £205. There is a tie-in of five years if this option is taken.

I think Richenda should wait until she is more certain of her immediate future and, if possible, start saving for a deposit.
Liz Lyke, Options for Women

2 Property purchase should not be entered into lightly - buying a property is a medium to long-term investment, and there are a number of issues to be considered. How much will you pay for the property? How much will you borrow? What about initial costs, such as stamp duty, legal fees, and a mortgage adviser's fee: how will Richenda pay for these? If she moves in a year's time, she is unlikely to recoup these costs and lenders are unlikely to be sympathetic to her letting out the property while she goes off travelling.

Richenda has not thought this through. She should not consider buying until she has saved some money and is ready to settle.
Carl Melvin, Millbrae Financial Services

3 In most cases, the sooner you get your foot on the property ladder the better, and it's difficult to see property prices reducing in the short term. It is important, however, not to rush into a long-term financial commitment if you are not ready. Also, selling your property in a year's time may not be economically viable.
Walter Avrili, Charcol

webTitle: EuroDirect: Talent scouts who mean business

fields.headline: Talent scouts who mean business
fields.standfirst: How does a company ensure a supply of the right recruits? They look to soccer's schools of excellence, as Dr Martin Bradbury explains
fields.trailText: How does a company ensure a supply of the right recruits? They look to soccer's schools of excellence, as Dr Martin Bradbury explains.
fields.body:
Perhaps it is not surprising that the leading UK football clubs have the best youth development strategies when you consider the time they spend identifying and developing the qualities that are the hallmark of young players such as Steven Gerrard of Liverpool or Wes Brown at Manchester United.

But instead of Manchester United or Liverpool consider EuroDirect - a European market leader in the database marketing industry - and understand that, whether an organisation is searching for the next David Beckham or for a top marketing analyst, the same challenge is a facet of staff recruitment.

So how does an employer approach the task of spotting something as elusive as "personal qualities" in its recruitment wish-list, when limited to the intelligence gathered from stage-managed interviews and "sexy" CVs that are economical with the truth?

The approach to recruitment and staff development of EuroDirect, Skipton Building Society's marketing offshoot, mirrors that of top soccer teams. To spot and grow its own talent it has teamed up with the School of Geography at the University of Leeds.

This link with a local higher education institution offers a valuable lesson for other companies wanting to recruit the brightest and the best.

There is evidence that the relationship between higher educational institutions and employers is changing. This is principally a corollary of the new service- and IT-related occupations that flourish in the UK's post-industrial economy; the steady expansion of the proportion of young people who enrol for higher education; and the evolution in expectations of graduates and employers.

Although universities and colleges offer a wide range of courses, few students become archaeologists, philosophers, or marine biologists. This does not invalidate the worth of broad-ranging courses because, along with the life-skills "learning" implicit with independent student life, they produce highly employable graduates.

In reality, however, new employees still have much to learn before they achieve commercially acceptable standards. This reflects the rapid rate of change in business perspectives rather than any shortfall in the quality of courses.

EuroDirect has kept a traditional recruitment approach using advertisements and interviews, but this is largely used to hire experienced staff.

Yet internal promotions fill the majority of its management positions. How then does the School of Geography help the company's recruitment strategy?

First of all, it is clear that, apart from a high academic rating, the School of Geography at Leeds is special in other ways, particularly in terms of its willingness to accept responsibility for a role in graduate employment.

This is maintained through specific taught modules and a willingness to deal with the business world.

Senior EuroDirect staff noted these characteristics during the 1990s and enduring connections were established. Departmental staff, such as school chairman Graham Clarke, working closely with students, were happy to match the qualities of graduates with those required for available jobs.

Proper interview procedures were maintained, but EuroDirect could approach its initial meeting with prospective employees safe in the knowledge that the school had enjoyed a three-year relationship with each candidate.

It soon became routine for EuroDirect to contact the school whenever graduate recruits were required and it gained huge confidence in the quality of its recruits.

The fact that, to date, all staff recruited in this way remain at EuroDirect, is real evidence of the successful "match" of recruit to employer. The relationship has not stopped here. EuroDirect has enrolled senior analysts on advanced statistics courses jointly sponsored by the company and the school, and eight staff are in postgraduate studies.

EuroDirect's association with the School of Geography has clearly been mutually beneficial. Graduate and postgraduate students of the School now make up 25% of EuroDirect staff and the School can rebut any accusation of living in an ivory tower by pointing to its relevance to the hard-nosed commercial world.

From a broader perspective, the EuroDirect story signposts an innovative route to recruitment that, given imagination and commitment from employers and academia, will ensure that top-quality staff and businesses find themselves playing in the same team.

 Dr Martin Bradbury is Client Services Manager of EuroDirect.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Dr Alexander Galitsky, executive chairman and founder TrustWorks
fields.trailText: Dr Alexander Galitsky, executive chairman and founder TrustWorks.
fields.body:
TrustWorks is an information security company that provides confidentiality and authentication to rectify the security issues thrown up by increasing use of the internet.

When did you first become a manager?

In 1983, when I became head of a software department writing software for spy satellites.

What has been your best moment in management?

There are several. When you run your business based on a vision and when that works in practice, it makes me very happy each time.

What was your greatest mistake?

Believing that western managers know more than their Russian counterparts.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Seeing Russian technology being embedded in Sun Micro Systems security software.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

That it takes me a lot of effort to convince them before they share my vision.

What management wisdom is most over-rated?

Experience. It can help, but it can also sometimes stand in the way.

What is the one lesson you have learned that you would pass on to young managers?

Never be afraid to make new mistakes.

Who is your management hero?

Sergei Pavlovich Korolev, the driving force behind the Soviet space programme, and Jack Welch, of General Electric US.

Who is your favourite politician?

Nelson Mandela, for enduring personal suffering and still being dedicated to bringing peace and reconciliation.

Do you think European executives are overpaid?

In a start-up it is normal to take a cut in your income but you expect that to be more than compensated for by stock gains in the future. European managers are not willing to do that. They don't seem to be prepared to invest in their future.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

Make the borders more open. For business people outside the EC it is a real hassle to enter the UK.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?

Since we used so many slogans in the Soviet era, I'm very conscious about glib phrases.

What annoys you most?

Answering the irrelevant questions of immigration officials because I have a Russian passport.

How do you relax?

Skiing downhill.

What is your favourite city?

If I can have two, they would be San Francisco and Moscow.

What is your greatest regret?

No longer having the time to climb mountains.

What is your biggest fear?

That immoral politicians will misuse the power of the internet and other cool technologies to control people.

What would you really like to have been?

In each stage in one's life you have a different idea of what you want to become. At this stage, I am happy being myself.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: From the top

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Analysing the profiles of board members of major plcs some years ago, there was no surprise in discovering that women were a rarity unless titled through marriage or good deeds, or so high profile that they had a presence on multiple boards. More sur prising was the discovery of the fertility of the average male senior executive, who had invisibly combined a high intensity career with the parenting of above average numbers of children.
fields.body:
Analysing the profiles of board members of major plcs some years ago, there was no surprise in discovering that women were a rarity unless titled through marriage or good deeds, or so high profile that they had a presence on multiple boards. More sur prising was the discovery of the fertility of the average male senior executive, who had invisibly combined a high intensity career with the parenting of above average numbers of children.

The fertility of successful careerists has been brought into the open with the announcement of junior health minister Yvette Cooper's planned maternity leave, followed shortly after by the shock news for business pages of the pregnancy of Debenhams' chief executive, Belinda Earl, only months after her appointment.

The business inconvenience of women's predilection for pregnancy as the last line of defence of die-hard chauvinists is blown out of the water when the company is deliver ing above average results in a struggling retail market.

We are beginning to see the fraying of the differentiated women's career model, which in study after study showed that women could not have it all. To succeed in corporate life is to forego long-term relationships and more especially motherhood, according to the model.

The argument that success and fertility don't mix was first made in the 19th century when medical experts drew attention to the gynaecological dangers to women in study. It was restated only 10 years ago when Felice Schwartz wrote an award-winning article for Harvard Business Review in which she called for the separation of organisational women into two camps.

An elite of career primary women who would not interrupt their careers would break through glass ceilings and would provide effective management and role models. In the other camp would be "mommy trackers" who would trade ambition for flexibility, choosing motherhood over advancement.

Schwartz's arguments now look flawed, not just because mothers are starting to get to the top and are expecting flexibility in order to do so, but because flexibility is becoming a universal expectation, rather than a bargaining tool for one gender.

"Family friendly policies", which have become a key offering in many UK organisations, were implicitly shaped by "mommy track" thinking; combined with the economics that retaining a long-serving employee through offering flexibility in when and where work is done, is a cheaper option than managing high turnover. They have become part of the employer brand in attracting those who have parenting or elder care responsibilities.

Ironically, their brand value is being devalued as they become a cause of disquiet for those without families, who want flexibility as a right in itself. Individuals report having to put together cases to justify reduced working, where the judgment is made on the perceived value of the activity, rather than the business implications of their reduced presence.

The death knell to a belief system which lives in the shadows of organisational thinking may come through people such as Belinda Earl. If her four months of maternity leave still leaves Debenhams ahead of its competitors on performance, she will have proved the aphorism that the more important an individual is to a business, the longer they should be able to stay away before it becomes a business problem.

The real test, however, will be when the first male CEO of a FTSE 100 announces that he is taking six months off just for himself, and the City does not shudder.

 Carole Pemberton is managing consultant, CareerMatters.

fields.bodyText: Analysing the profiles of board members of major plcs some years ago, there was no surprise in discovering that women were a rarity unless titled through marriage or good deeds, or so high profile that they had a presence on multiple boards. More sur prising was the discovery of the fertility of the average male senior executive, who had invisibly combined a high intensity career with the parenting of above average numbers of children. The fertility of successful careerists has been brought into the open with the announcement of junior health minister Yvette Cooper's planned maternity leave, followed shortly after by the shock news for business pages of the pregnancy of Debenhams' chief executive, Belinda Earl, only months after her appointment. The business inconvenience of women's predilection for pregnancy as the last line of defence of die-hard chauvinists is blown out of the water when the company is deliver ing above average results in a struggling retail market. We are beginning to see the fraying of the differentiated women's career model, which in study after study showed that women could not have it all. To succeed in corporate life is to forego long-term relationships and more especially motherhood, according to the model. The argument that success and fertility don't mix was first made in the 19th century when medical experts drew attention to the gynaecological dangers to women in study. It was restated only 10 years ago when Felice Schwartz wrote an award-winning article for Harvard Business Review in which she called for the separation of organisational women into two camps. An elite of career primary women who would not interrupt their careers would break through glass ceilings and would provide effective management and role models. In the other camp would be "mommy trackers" who would trade ambition for flexibility, choosing motherhood over advancement. Schwartz's arguments now look flawed, not just because mothers are starting to get to the top and are expecting flexibility in order to do so, but because flexibility is becoming a universal expectation, rather than a bargaining tool for one gender. "Family friendly policies", which have become a key offering in many UK organisations, were implicitly shaped by "mommy track" thinking; combined with the economics that retaining a long-serving employee through offering flexibility in when and where work is done, is a cheaper option than managing high turnover. They have become part of the employer brand in attracting those who have parenting or elder care responsibilities. Ironically, their brand value is being devalued as they become a cause of disquiet for those without families, who want flexibility as a right in itself. Individuals report having to put together cases to justify reduced working, where the judgment is made on the perceived value of the activity, rather than the business implications of their reduced presence. The death knell to a belief system which lives in the shadows of organisational thinking may come through people such as Belinda Earl. If her four months of maternity leave still leaves Debenhams ahead of its competitors on performance, she will have proved the aphorism that the more important an individual is to a business, the longer they should be able to stay away before it becomes a business problem. The real test, however, will be when the first male CEO of a FTSE 100 announces that he is taking six months off just for himself, and the City does not shudder.  Carole Pemberton is managing consultant, CareerMatters. carole.pemberton@careermattersconsulting.co.uk

webTitle: Jobs and Money: My big break

fields.headline: The lawyer who put cream in our coffee
fields.standfirst: Sahar Hashemi was bored with her job, which gave her the drive to found Coffee Republic. Adeline Iziren talked to her
fields.trailText: Sahar Hashemi was bored with her job, which gave her the drive to found Coffee Republic. Adeline Iziren talked to her.
fields.body:
Coffee Republic, one of the first coffee-bar chains to take off in the UK, might never have seen the light of day if co-founder Sahar Hashemi had plugged away as a lawyer in London rather than take an impromptu trip to New York.

That was in November 1994. Sahar was at a career crossroads and decided visiting her brother Bobby would be the perfect respite. While eating out at a Thai restaurant, Sahar mentioned to Bobby how much she yearned for New York's skinny cappuccinos and fat-free muffins when back home in London.

Bobby, an investment banker, knew his sister was seeking a new challenge after five years as a solicitor in the City and suggested she look at running her own coffee shop. He even offered to pay her to do the research.

Back in London, Sahar spent endless hours in a business library carrying out research and, on one memorable day, spent five weary hours getting off every station on the Circle line to inspect the coffee bars. She concluded that Londoners were compromising on quality, which didn't surprise her since she had never found a decent cup of coffee while working in the City.

The Department of Trade and Industry backed the proposed coffee venture with a £75,000 loan. Then, in November 1995, a year after Sahar's chance remark over a Thai meal, the first Coffee Republic was opened in central London's upmarket South Molton Street.

"The whole idea of Coffee Republic was to offer coffee that met individual requirements. Our customers can have semi-skimmed coffee, iced coffee as many shots dry or wet (dry is lots of foam, wet is less foam) and can flavour it with cinnamon, nutmeg and honey."

Despite the wide range of choice, business got off to a slow start. "People weren't used to fancy names for coffee like macchiato, skinny latte and mocha, so we encountered slow sales, plus difficulty in finding and keeping staff."

The siblings had no intention of giving up. They hired a PR company, which led to a few favourable press articles.

By spring 1996, the business began to pick up and in December that year, the second coffee shop was opened in central London. "In October 1997, we reversed into a public company on the Alternative Investment Market and that helped us raise £8.5m for further expansion," says Sahar.

"In July 2000 we went on to the main London stock exchange. We have now raised a total of £25m, enough to open 40 coffee bars a year. We've gone from no bars to 82 in exactly five years," she says. The latest, in London's Hanover Street, opened last week.

Behind Coffee Republic's phenomenal growth are more than 800 employees in coffee bars around the country, including Manchester, Birmingham and Cardiff.

Overseeing staff and the business is a strong team of directors, she says. Sahar and Bobby no longer get involved in the company's day-to-day running, but remain very much hands-on. Bobby is Coffee Republic's creative director and Sahar is the brand marketing director.

Sahar's role entails visiting a branch of Coffee Republic for breakfast every day. "I go in as a customer, judge it as a customer and stay for an hour. I make sure the quality remains the same and true to the Coffee Republic spirit."

Though Sahar's lifestyle is more relaxed she still has to work hard. "My ethos is that success is 99% perspiration and 1% inspiration. The goal is to make sure we don't be come a big corporate company, forgetting why and how we started."

Sahar credits her legal training with enabling her to run the business so successfully. "It gives you amazing discipline and structures your mind," she says. "I don't think I could have started Coffee Republic without it."

Iranian-born Sahar embarked on a law career after studying at Bristol University. She was excited when taken on by City law firm Frere Cholmeley but became dissatisfied.

"I started getting bored with not seeing the fruits of my labour. I would give advice to clients, but I wanted to make things happen."

After her father died suddenly in 1994, she quit her job and took a five-month break in Argentina to learn Spanish. On her return she started job-hunting but with little success.

Fed up, she decided to take that long weekend break to New York. "It was the best thing I ever did," she enthuses.
