webTitle: Charities: Working commercially in the charity sector

fields.headline: Give and take
fields.trailText: Those "What's it all about?" moments can strike even the most motivated worker - and at any time of day. You know them. Everyone else in the meeting is arguing passionately about the big idea, while deep down you admit to yourself that you don't give a toss. Or it could be during a quiet moment when, as you're checking your emails, you lose sight of what you're doing, and wonder whether there really is more to life.
fields.body:
Those "What's it all about?" moments can strike even the most motivated worker - and at any time of day. You know them. Everyone else in the meeting is arguing passionately about the big idea, while deep down you admit to yourself that you don't give a toss. Or it could be during a quiet moment when, as you're checking your emails, you lose sight of what you're doing, and wonder whether there really is more to life.

Thoughts turn to "giving something back" or using your skills for something more worthwhile, but you know that making a move to a not-for-profit organisation would involve a serious change in lifestyle. It's a tough one.

Yet as charities market themselves with increasing ferocity and the so-called corporate baddies are having to do environmental and ethical housekeeping to make sure they don't lose out when consumers make informed choices between brands - is the divide between the commercial and voluntary sectors so clearly marked? And, when it comes to carving a career in either , who's to say that you can't mix and match and move between the two? Surely there are skills to be learned in each camp?

"There used to be a thing about what the commercial sector did one day, the voluntary sector would do a few years later, but I think the gap is narrowing," says Jim Minton, director of marketing at Centrepoint, the London-based charity that provides accommodation, education and training for 16-25-year-olds who are homeless. Mr Minton used to be a sales manager for Bass, looking after 100 pubs. He left the brewing world to work for Shelter doing account management of trusts and foundations and is now intent on building the Centrepoint brand.

So was selling beer a good training ground for selling a charity?

"There is a parallel," he says. "You're going round pubs and they've got to buy their beer from somewhere. It's really down to relationships. It's the same with trusts and foundations. They've got money to give away and if they can believe in the organisation through you, you've got a fair chance of getting money from them".

Yet what about taking what he has learned and going back to Bass?

"At the moment I'm building quite a good career in the voluntary sector. I'm good at it, and I know what I can do. Skills could definitely be transferred back. Although I don't think I could take the Centrepoint brand experience and go back to Bass and say: 'I want to be the Carling brand manager'. It's not going to happen."

Nevertheless, Mr Minton is studying for a MBA in his spare time and he seems happy speaking in the jargon of a brand manager in any blue chip company. If Centrepoint were a fashion brand, which brand would it be?

"Diesel, French Connection, Gap," says Mr Minton, needing little time for deliberation. "We're adamant that we don't want to be a bog standard, free biro, charity brand. We want to be our own brand."

Yet just as other high street brands compete with each other, so must charities. This competition often means charities are perceived to be spending more and more of donors' money on extravagant advertising and direct marketing campaigns which naturally invite criticism.

"I think a lot of people don't understand how charities operate. I didn't have a clue before I came here," admits Wendy Brown, who left financial services consulting at PricewaterhouseCoopers to work for Save the Children.

"A lot of work goes into the gap between somebody handing over some cash into a collection box and the money reaching a child in Africa living on less than a dollar a day."

Ms Brown is communications coordinator for the UN Special Session on Children that is taking place in September. For the first time, children are being invited to be delegates. Save the Children is trying to help governments around the world to include children in their delegation and to help children to be heard at the event.

Since starting her job in January Ms Brown is enjoying her new working environment. "Working with children is quite an emotional issue so people tend to be more passionate, although some people can get passionate about mortgages," she admits.

But what benefits is she bringing to Save the Children?

"I guess the answer is a different perspective. I suppose that can hinder in that it takes me longer to understand where other people are coming from but at the same time perhaps I'm thinking in a slightly more commercial way and that creates a good balance." Ms Brown's contract ends in September, after which she would definitely consider something else at Save the Children if it came up.

But is it generally easy to make a move into the charitable sector?

"It's easier at the lower levels", admits Cathy Daniels, account director at specialist recruitment agency Charity People. "And finance people do it. People in their mid to late 20s and early to mid 30s are most likely to do it, particularly people who've worked in agencies or consultancies. They've quite often worked hard in an agency environment where there's a lot of dissatisfaction and their social life suffers," she explains.

Ms Daniels is on the look-out for people with good marketing, communications and business development skills, all of which are directly transferable to fund raising. "And good general management and administrative skills," she adds. With a database of 4,000 clients and 80,000 candidates, the market is "buoyant". "We don't have to do a lot of new business," she admits.

And at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO), work is being done to shift perceptions about working in not-for-profit organisations. "Some people think the pay in the voluntary sector is really, really bad," says Ben Kernighan, who has been involved with producing the brochure: Working for a Better World, which helps to set the record straight. "Pay at the more junior level is often comparable with the private sector. But at the higher level, you don't get the astronomical salaries you get in the commercial sector."

Which is something that Martin Brookes, former senior economist at Goldman Sachs has had to "resolve in his head" before joining Amnesty International as a researcher in economic relations and human rights.

"There was a nagging doubt at the back of my mind that said: 'Do you really want to be doing this for the next 30 years, or is there something you can do which you would feel more comfortable with when you wake up in the morning and go into work'?"

The new role for Martin Brookes also represents something of a departure for Amnesty. And what is his role exactly? "As I've defined it to myself so far," he says, "it's essentially trying to link economics to human rights. Part of it will be trying to think about how we get companies to be conscious of their role in improving human rights in the countries in which they operate and also to see that they don't violate human rights through their own operations."

His job will entail working closely with Amnesty researchers around the world. "It's fascinating," he says. "In the past I was looking at economics for economics' sake but now I'm looking at economics for human rights' sake. That is the shift".

One of the cultural shocks for Mr Brookes is the fact that Amnesty is an organisation heaving with lawyers. "Economists have a completely different way of doing things. Lawyers are very procedural by nature whereas economists are just interested in an idea or a problem and how to get an end result."

So does that mean that Amnesty International is buried under red tape? "There is more structure here," says Mr Brookes diplomatically. "Although I came from an institution that is probably the least bureaucratic place that I can imagine. In the whole time I was at Goldman Sachs I probably only wrote one memo."

Was it difficult to make the move from a leading investment bank to a leading human rights organisation?

"As soon as I had the interview here I was very keen to do the job," he says. "And my colleagues were very understanding. No one said: 'You're mad' although when some of them said: 'That's very brave' they might have really meant: 'You're completely mad'." But surely it must be great to have left a pressured environment to to spend your days having cosy chats with co-workers about the bigger picture? Rather than just putting the world to rights in the pub, it must feel so much better if you're genuinely trying to do something that makes a difference.

"This is not about putting your feet up," cautions Mr Brookes. "It does feel more relaxed, but I'm not sure if that's because I'm very new and once we're working on projects it might get as busy as Goldman Sachs, although without the intensity of the markets moving."

One thing is certain. The differences between the commercial and not-for-profit sectors may not be so easy to define in clichés - greedy capitalists versus do-gooders - in the future. And in career terms, it might mean there are new opportunities for people who want to combine passion and purpose with strategic career development.

"I've followed my heart to do this, but it's also intellectual, and this is the crux of it. It's a new area and it's one that's not going to disappear. It doesn't rule out going back to the City at some point - particularly with the growth of things like ethical investment and business and social responsibility. It's actually a combination of something emotional and something intellectually challenging. To be honest I don't think I could get that combination in the private sector."

Save the Children, 020 7716 2053

Amnesty International, 020 7814 6200
